The DICTIONARY of sir Thomas Eliot knight.

Londini in aedibus Thomae Bertheleti typis impress. Cum priuilegio ad
imprimendum solum.

THE COPY OF THE KINGS GRACIOUS PRIVILEGE.
HENRY THE EIGHT, by the grace of God, King of England and of France,
Defendour of the faith lord of Irelande, and supreme heed in earth
immediately under God of the universal Church of England, To all prynters of
books within this our realm, and to all other officers, mynysters* and
subjects, these our letters herynge or saying, gretynge. we late you wit,
that we of our grace especial, have given privilege unto our well beloved
servant Thomas Berthelet, that no manner person within this our ^ealme during
the natural life of the said Thomas, shall printe any manner of books, what so
ever our said servant shall prynt first or shall prynt again upon other men's
corrections the same within the space of six years next ensuynge the
pryntynge of every (...) he book so printed by our said servant. wherefore we
woll and command you, that ye nor none of you presume to prynte any of the
said books, during the time of this our privilege, as ye intend to eschew
our displeasure.

TO THE MOST EXCELLENT PRINCE, AND OUR most redoubted soueraygne lord king
HENRY the.VIII. king of England, and France, defender of the faith, lord
of Irelande, and Supreme heed in earth immediately under Christ, of the
Church of England, his humble and faythefull servant, Thomas Elyot knight
desires perfect felicity.
TRVELY I am, and ever have been of this opynion, most noble, most
puissaunt, and most virtuous Prince, that the Royal astate of a king here
in earth, next unto god, is of men most to be honored, loved, and feared in an
incomparable degree and facion. For no man having the free use of reason,
beholdynge at his eien the disposition most wonderful set by divine
prouydence in things above us, about us, and underneath us, with the sundry
alternations of time, will deny, to be of those things one principal ruler
and moderatour, by whose eternal sapience all things ben governed. Unto that
office of governance is (as it were by the general consent of al people) one
name appropried, in the which although by diversity of langages, the letters
and syllables are oftentimes changed, yet the word spoken has one
signification, which implies as much as a KING in english, as it may appear
to them, which do read holy scripture, and will mark how often god is there
callid king, and also the prophets do so frequently name him. More over the
paynims being only ladde with natural affections, called Jupiter, to whom
above other their goddis, (...)
they reserved the power universal, king of goddis and of men: as who says,
there may be no greatter name given unto him, whom they supposed to be the
gyuer of life unto creatures. To the which example, for the similitude of that
divine office men did attribute unto their soueraygne governors that excellent
denomination, calling them semblably kings, and assigning to them the common
distribution of Justice: Whereby the people under their governance, should be
kept and preserved in quiet life, not exercysed in bestiall appetite, but
passed forth in all parts of honesty, they finally should of god be rewarded
with immortality. This well consydred, it shall be to all men apparent, that
they, which rebel against kings, be ennemies to god, and in will confounders
of natural order and providence. But above all things, I have in most
admiration, the majesty of you, which be very kings raygnyng in Justice,
when I consider, that therein seems to be a thing supernatural, or (if it may
be spoken without derogation unto goddis honor) a divine influence or spark
of divinity: which late appeared to all them that beheld your grace syttyng
in the Throne of your royal astate, as supreme heed of the church of England
next under CHRIST, about the descision and condemnation of the pernicious
errors, of the most detestable heretyke John^ Nicolson, called also Lambert,
at the which time your highness, more excellently than my tunge or pen can
express, declared to be in your royal person the perfect image of kyngely
majesty, compacte of these excellent qualities, true Religion, Sapience,
Justice, and Mercy, all men reioycinge at the manifest and most honorable
declaration of your evangelical faith: meruaylynge at the fulmination of the
most vehement arguments procedyng from your hyghnes in the confutation of
abhomynable heresies: extollynge the just reprehencions of the perverse
opinions and interpretations of the arrogant masters of the said Lambert, in
whose writings, and his own propre wit, he more trusted (as your highness
trewely alleged against him) than in the plain context of holy scripture,
and the determinate sentence of holy and great learned doctors: Inioyenge also
as well at your gracis most wonderful pacyence, in the long sustayninge of
the folyshe and tediouse objections of the said Lambert, as also at your most
christian charity, in mouynge and exhorting so stubborn an heretic, with
the most gentle and perswasible langage, to recant and forsake his myscheuouse
heresies. This majesty your true and loving subjects beholdynge, and than
herynge the spirit of god speaking in you, his enoynted King, and mynister
elected: they were with joy so replenyshed, that when they desired to express
each to other the comfort, which they than received, the same comfort was of
such importance, that it might none otherwise be declared, but by abundance
of tears, sent out of their eyes by unspeakable gladness. More over the presence
of you, which are kings, do minyster to them that be inferiors unto you, an
amplification of powers called natural, contained as well in the wit and
senses, as in the force or puissance of corporal members. to the confirmation
whereof, how many men have been known, which er they have attained to the
familyar acquayntaunce of kings, have been demed to be, some but of a mean
wit and knowledge, some but of a base courage or prowess, which afterward
have exceded in wit or courage all men's expectations, and finally been of all
men allowed for honorable and notable personages. Of this wonderful majesty
in your royal person, most gracious souerayn lord, I have my self, in my
self, late found a meruaylous experience. For about a year passed, I began
a Dictionarie, declaryng latin by english, wherein I used little study,
being than occupied about my necessary busynes, which let me from the
exact labor and study requisyte to the making of a perfyte Dictionarie: But
whiles it was in printyng, and uneath the half deal performed, your hyghnes
being informed thereof, by the reports of gentle master Antony Denny, for his
wisdom and diligence worthily called by your highness into your privy
Chamber, and of Wyllyam Tildisley, keeper of your gracis Lybrarie, and after
most specially by the recommendation of the most honorable lord Crumwell,
lord privy seal, favorer of honesty, and next to your highness chief
patron of virtue and cunnyng, conceived of my labors a good expectation, and
declaryng your most noble and beneuolent nature, in fauouryng them that will
be well occupied, your highness in the presence of diverse your noble men,
commending mine enterprise, affirmed, that if I would ernestely travail
therein, your highness, as well with your excellent counsel, as with such
books as your grace had, and I lacked, would therein aid me: with the which
words, I confess, I received a new spirit, as me seemed: whereby I found
forthwith an augmentation of mine understanding, in so much, as I iuged all
that, which I had written, not worthy to come in your gracis presence, with out
an addition. Wherefore incontinent I caused the printes to cesse, and beginning
at the letter M, where I left, I passed forth to the last letter with a more
diligent study. And that done, I eftesones returned to the first letter, and
with a semblable diligence performed the temenant. In the which my proceeding,
I well perceived, that all though dictionaries had been gathered one of an
other, yet nethelesse in each of them ar omitted some latin words, interpreted
in the books, which in order preceded. For Festus has many, which are not
in Varros Analogi: Nonius has some, which Festus lacks: Nestor took not all
that he found in them both. Tortellius is not so abundant as he is diligent:
Laurentius Valla wrate only of words, which are called elegancies, wherein he
is undoubtedly excellent: Perottus in Cornucopie, did omit almost none that
before him were written, but in wordis compounde he is to compendiouse: Fryere
Calepine (but where he is augmented by other) nothing amended, but rather
appaired that which Perottus had studiousely gathered: Nebressensis was both
well learned and diligent, as it appears in some words, which he declares in
latin: but because in his dictionarie words are expound in the spainyshe
tunge, which I do not understand, I can not of him show mine opinion: Budeus
in the exact trial of the native sense of words, as well greek as latin, is
assuredly right commendable, but he is most occupied in the conference of
phrasis of both the tunges, which in comparison are but in a few words:
Diverse other men have written sundry annotations and commentaries on old
latin authors, among whom also is discord in their expositions. When I
consydred all this, I was attached with an horrible fear, remembryng my
dangerous enterprise (I being of so small reputation in lernyng in comparison of
them, whom I have rehearsed) as well for the difficulty in the true expressing
the lively sense of the latin words, as also the importable labors in
serching expending and discussing the sentences of ancient writers. This
premeditation abated my courage, and desperation was even at hand to rent al in
pieces that I had written, had not the beams of your royal majesty entered
into my heart, by remembrance of the comfort, which I of your grace had
lately received, wherewith my spirit was reuyued, and has set up the sail of
good courage, and under your graces governance, your highness being mine only
master, and styrer of the ship of all my good fortune, I am entered the
goulfe of disdaynous envy, having fynished for this time this simple
Dictionarie, wherein I dare affirm, may be found a thousand mo latin words,
than were together in any one Dictionarie publyshed in this royalme at the time
when I first began to write this commentary, which is almost two years
passed. For beside the conference of phrases or fourmes of speaking latin and
english, I have also added proper terms belonging to law and phisike, the
names of diverse herbs known among us: also a good number of fishes founden as
well in our occean, as in our rivers: Moreover sondrie poysis, coin, and
measures, sometime used among the ancient Romans, Greeks, and Hebrews,
which knowledge to the reders not only of histories and orations of Tullie, but
also of holy scripture, and the books of ancient physicians, shall be found
pleasant and also commodiouse. Nor I have omitted proverbs, called Adagia, or
other quick sentences, which I thought necessary to be had in remembrance.
All be it for as much as partly by negligence at the beginning, partly by
untrue information of them, whom I trusted, also by to much trust had in
Calepine, some fautes may be founden by dilygent redynge, I therefore most
humbly beseech your excellent majesty, that where your highness shall happen
to doubt of any one word in the first part of this warke, or perchance do
lack any word, which your majesty shall happen to read in any good author,
that it may like your grace to repair incontinente unto the second part,
which is mine addition, sekyng there for the same word in the letter, wherewith
he begins, trusting verily, that your highness there shall be satisfied. And
for as much as by haste made in printyng, some letters may happen to lack,
some to be set in wrong places, or the ortography not to be truly observed,
I therefore have put all those fautes in a table following this preface: whereby
they may be easily corrected: and that done, I trust in god no man shall
find cause to reject this book, but rather thankefully to take my good will
and labors, gyuynge to your majesty most hartye thanks, as to the chief
author thereof, by whose gracious means men being studious, may understand
better the latin tunge in six months, than they might have done before in
three years, without perfyte instructours, which are not many, and such as
be, are not easy to come by: the cause I need not to rehearse, sens I ones
declared it in my book called the Governor, which about.viii. years passed,
I did dedicate unto your highness. And for my part, I render most humble
thanks unto your majesty, for the good estimation that your grace retayneth
of my poor lerning and honesty, promising therefore to your highness, that
during my life natural, I shall faithfully employe all the powers of my wit
and body, to serve truly your majesty in every thing, whereto your most
excellent judgment, shall think my service convenient and necessary, In the
mean time and always, as your bounden servant, I shall heartily pray unto god, to
prospere your hyghenes in all your virtuous procedynges, granting also that
your majesty may long reign over us, to the incomparable comfort and joy
of all your natural and loving subjects. AMEN.

THO. ELIOTA EQVES LECTORIBVS VERE DOCTIS.
ETSI NIHIL DVBITO DE VESTRO candore, prudentia, ac benignitate lectores
candidissimi, metus tamen liuoris alieni me uehementer cogit, ut in huius
operis principio uos aggrediar praeoccupatione quadam, non tamen artificiosa,
sed perquam simplici ac uerecunda: qua solum erratula, perpauca nimirum
deprecando, morsus inuidorum, qui nusquam non sunt, facilius euitarem. Nostis
optumi uiri quam periculoso certamine, lis adhuc pendeat inter huius aetatis
medicos de re herbaria: qua, me hercle, ut nihil extet humanae saluti
conducibilius, si probe cognoscatur: ita nihil pene deterius, aut magis noxium,
si quicquam in ea, male intelligendo, quod lectori futurum sit fraudi, perperam
committatur: quod cum ipse cognorim, alioqui cupidus redigendi in hos
co^mentarios quorumcunque uerborum quae apud latinos authors reperiantur,
sensus integros ac genuinos: coepi cum quibusdam herbariis ac pharmacopolis
agere, quos existimaueram ea in re perquam gnaros fuisse, ac perdiligentes, ut
stirpium non solum nomina, uerum etiam figuras ipsas mihi scribenti
suppeditarent. at homines uel improbe suam ignorantiam dissimulantes, uel ut
mihi imponerent (quod magis existimo) turpiter mentie^tes, alias figuras,
aliaque nomina mihi praebueru^t, qua^ earunde^ herbaru^ fuisse, quas ego nosse
cupiebam, postea diligentius inuestigando per meipsum comperi: quo factum est,
ut ab his delusus, uel potius proditus, aliquot herbas ac arbores aliena fide
male deceptus, huic Dictionario sub falsis nominibus inseruerim: quod tandem
cum ex solidioris doctrinae uiris, sero propemodum consultis, tum ex
inquisitione perdiligenti, tam in libris Dioscoridis et Galeni, quam in ipsis
styrpibus a me ia^ uisis ac multo penitius consyderatis deprehendissem, adeo
tantae negligentiae me certe poenituit, ut eo nomine tot mensiu^ labores (ut
mihi uidebatur inaniter exhaustos) flammis consumpsissem: ni me potentissimi,
ac long sapientissimi Principis nostri Henrici octaui Regis Angliae numen,
interpellasset: cui meam fidem in perficiundo hoc negotio paulo ante
obstrinxeram: facturum igitur me satis existimabam uobis uestrique similibus,
uiris utique bonis aeque atque doctis, si in tabellam, appendicem huic
epistolae, herbarum uocabula uel a me perperam interpretata, uel non satis
cognita diligenter coegero, quo minore cum periculo lectores quicquid mihi
deciderit imprude^ti resarcire possint. Abest enim quam plurimum, ut huiusce
rei me quicquam pudeat, cum in manibus tractentur cottidie libri doctissimorum
hominum, tertium aut quartum recogniti, nouisque additionibus iterum atque
iterum in lucem aediti, quod hercle cur mihi tantum non liceat, neque moribus
ne du^ legibus ullus quisquam praeiudicauerit. Sed mihi obiicient aemuli, multa
quidem uerba, quae apud Calepinum reperiantur, uel a me sponte praetermissa,
uel mihi nimium festinanti stolide dilapsa. Neutrum confitebor hercle nam cum
primum statuissem Dictionarium latino anglicum (ita iam lubet rei nouae, nouum
nomen effingere) pro quodam meo nepote co^ficere: in animo tum erat neque
plureis graecas dictiones aggerere, quam quae uideri possent ualde necessariae,
ad eos authors intelligendum, qui latin scribentes clarissimi reputantur.
Igitur non alia graeca uocabula desumpsi mihi, qua^ ea quae uel in ciuitatem
receptae (ut dicere solent) locum quempiam apud probatum aliquem authorem
adornassent, aut maiorem copiam, aut sensum illustriorem praebuissent. caetera
quaecunque penes huiusmodi authors uel nusquam reperta, uel ab iis ipsis
circumscripta, ne meam operam in depingendis chartis nimium otiosis imprudenter
luderem, libenter praetermisi, quod scirem, graecas literas nosce cupientibus,
alioru^ librorum, quos Lexica uocant, haud minorem copiam extare, nec mihi duos
parietes de una fidelia dealbare admodum uacabat: nam quid per deum immortalem
arrogantius dici possit? quid equidem stultius? quam in latino Dictionario ex
uerbis graecis, aceruos ingentes colligere, miscellaneasque co^sarsinare, cum
ad rem literariam plaeraque nihil faciant, imo nonnumquam officiant cum
inquirentem sedulo latinam aliquam dictionem, diu^^us quam par sit retineant.
Denique praetermisi nimia uetustate iam obsoleta uocabula, quae Terentii,
Plautique uenerandam antiquitatem long praecedere, aut plebeiorum sordes
nimium olere uideantur. tum quod authors quibus usui fuerunt eiusmodi uoces
nusquam extent: tum quod nulla in re, latin loquentibus utiles, plurimum
stylo, puritatique sermonis officere uehementer poterint. Si quis obscoena
uocabula desyderet, quibus iacentem uenerem inter legendum suscitare queat:
alios dictionarios consulat, meu^que contemnat, hoc nomine (si lubet) quod
eiuscemodi uocibus careat. Noueram humani sensus quantum fuerint semper ad
incendium prompti, si delitescentem igniculum ex lasciuiusculis uerbulis uel
modice delibauerint: sciebam quam auidi sint homines tam foede, ac demu^
poenitendae uoluptatis illecebris animos perluendi, qua^ praecipites fueri^t ad
exequendu^, quod libido suaserit. Praeterea non ignoraba^ ipsam Venerem non
tantopere solicitatam omnino quiescere: leuioresque impressiones efficere.
Malebam igitur (conscius futurae rationis, quam apud Christu^ iudicem initurus
sum) uideri quibusdam gratum aliquid subtrahere, ob idque male audire apud
cinoedos quamlibet procaces: quam damno cum meo tum aliorum inexpiabili, facem
saeuienti Cupidini, lasciua uerbositate subministrare. Viculos quosdam, pariter
atque rinulos et monticulos admodum ignobiles, quos extra Cosmographorum
tabulas, uel nusquam reperietis uel perquam raro, id tamen cum sui situs
descriptione satis commoda non curarim tantopere, ut in his uellem tempus and
chartam inaniter decoquere, contemptus idem accidit in otiosis nominibus, quae
neque tropu^ afferant, nec in quopiam authore fabulam illustrent. Ceterum pro
tam inani farragine comparaui lectoribus suppellectilem long commodiorem, ex
his dictionibus, quae in legendis authoribus, ob sensus diuersitatem, haud
mediocrem difficultatem afferant. Adieci praeter herbarum ac piscium cognomina,
quorum nullus dictionarius ante hunc meminit (ni fallor) mensuras ac pondera,
tam ueterum graecorum atque latinorum quam etiam Hebreorum. hanc equidem
operam, cunctis hominibus qui in literis tum sacris, tum prophanis studiose
uersentur, me pulchre nauasse iudicaueritis, quoties memineritis, quam insigni
uecordia ad lectionem iucundissimam rei tam uulgaris ignorantia per docti
homines caecutire uideantur. Tandem ne nimis longa praefacione, uobis in rebus
maioribus atque grauioribus occupatis, potius fastidium quam benefitium
afferam, id breuiter a uobis impetrare cupio, ut meam uoluntatem in hac re
aequi bonique consulatis. cogitetisque apud uosipsos, id operis iam coeptum ab
equite britanno, barbarissimo scilicet, utpote in paternis tantum aedibus
educato, nec ab anno aetatis duodecimo ab altero quopiam preceptore literis
instructo, sibi ipsi nimirum duce tam in scientiis liberalibus, quam in utraque
philosophia: quod procul abest, ut ostentando dicam uel arroganter: sed ut
gratiis DEO OPT. MAX. cum a me tum ab his, quibus hic meus liber fuerit utilis,
utrinque redditis: alii musarum uberiori benefitio freti, meo quidem exemplo,
parem aut maiorem operam aggredi, pro sua Republica non dubitarent. Vos ualete,
memores, primos conatus, cuiquam scribenti, uix unquam feliciter cecidisse.

THE TABLE OF CORRECTIONS.
ACETABVLVM, read a saulcer, wherein vyneger or other like sauce is put. Put out
the resydue, and read it in the table of measures. Acinicula, read Acuncula.
Acus, read it in the addition. Aedilitas, litum, read litium. Agaranomus, read
Agoranomus. Ambrosia, read in the addition. Antista, read Antistita. Apiastrum
read an herb, which has leaue^ like to black horehound, but greatter, and
more tender, and are not so rough, and smells like a cytron, some do take it
for March. Appositus, iette to, read set to. Archarius, read in the
Addition. Assiptor, read Ascriptor. Assec^a, read Assecla.
BIothenatos, read Biothanatos. Biremes, add to, also ships, having it
raunges of ores, Bon, add to, also the people of Benar or Berne, and the
marches thereof. Brabenta, read Brabenta. Buglossa, read, is that herb, which
is commonly called Borage.
CAdus, read in the Addition, and also in the table of measures. Calix, read in
the addition. Calydonia, read, It is also a country in the north part of
Scotland. Calta, read in the addition. Camerinam mouere, read in the
addition. Carcritoma, read Carcinoma. Cardinum, read Cardamus. Carpatine, put
out okers, and read cokars. Cerates, read the four score and sixtenthe part
of an ounce. Chameleopardus, read like a panther. Censio, read Censeo. Chena,
read clena. Choenix, read in the table of greek mesures. Chus, read in the
table of greek measures. Climacterius, read climactericus. Commeats, read
commeatus. Consuersco, read consuesco. Coriarius, add to, also a curriar.
Cura, carae, read curae. Cynomia, read Cynomyia. Congius, read in the Table of
Romayne measures.
DEcussis, read in the addition. Demeanculum, read demeaculum. Demensum, read
in the addition. Duellium, read Duellum. Haematices, read haematites. Increpo,
pere, add to, uel pare.
LApathos, read in the addition. Latico, read latito. Legacitius, read
Legatitius. Leucantha, read Leucacantha. Latumae, read Latumiae. Lonem radere,
read Leonem radere. Lesbos, for Ageum, read Aegeum. Lingua bula, read Lingua
bubula. Litem suam facere, there for one, read one. Lucifigus, read Lucifugus.
MAlo, mauul, read mauule. Marconiani, read Marcomanni. Mastiche, add to
commonly called Mastix. Matter matrina, read and has a mother living.
Medimnus, read in the table of measures. Mediocris, dlere, read mediocre.
Medius, a, um, in the myddell. Melamirus, read Melanurus. Membraneus, read of
parchmyn or velum. Merdo, oreur, read ordure. Metreta, and metretes, read the
greek table of measures. Mina, read in the addicion and in the tables of poyse
and money. Modius, read in the table of measure. Muralis, add to the end
pelitory of the wall
NEdum, after, for fundere, read funderem, Nihil cum fidibus graculo nihil cu^
amacino sui, read, cum amaracino sui. Nucamenta, things on the bowghes of
nutte trees or pitche trees hangyng down like frynges, and be not leaves.
Numeris omnibus absolutus, on every part perfyte, put out ly. Olus atrum, for
persely read Alysander. Ozinum, read ozimum.
PAralleli, for lon read son. Patrizo, for like a father, read like his
father. Pectunculus, a little fyshe, add thereto, I suppose it is a cockyll.
Pharmacentice, read Pharmaceutice. Pituita, for rowme read rewme. Puuia, read
pluuia. Pollex, read a finger breadth, and the third part of a finger. Polus,
of extre, read of an axe tree. Pupugi, read the pretertence of pungo. Putitius,
a fool, read a fool.
Qui, read after the latin, wherefore was Epicurus more happy that he lived in
his own countray, than Metrodorus which lived at Athenes. Quinarius, read at
the end, which is of our money.iii. pens farthing, or therabout.
REmuncopae, for driven read drawn. Renones, read after wherein the ancient
Almaynes.
SAlillum, read a little saltsellar. Salinum, read a saltesellar. Saxatilis,
pisces saxatili, read saxatiles. Scytae, Scythia, put them out there, and
read them after. Scorpiuros, put out all the description of the herb, and
read a little herb called also Scorpioides, having small leaves, and the sede
thereof is like the tails of Scorpions. Sestertius, and sestertiu^, read them
afterward in the table of coin. Sextarius, read in the table of measures.
Singillatim, for every ouche read eueriche. Specimen edere, to show a proof.
put out the residue. Sprarchus, read spirarchus. Spithama, read after in the
table of measures. Squilla, read at the last end, I suppose it a prane.
Sernunt se somno, read sternunt. Struma, for which is, read wherein is. Sulcus,
sometime it is put of a dyche, read for a dyche.
TThysus, put out all, for as much as it is before declared in Thyrsus.
Trachelum, read for tho sail, the sail. Trulla, read a treye. Tucetum, read
at the end. also a sausage.
Vafer, for fly, read slye. Vlex, for to ti, read to him.
In the addition.
Adarca, for grownyng, read growing. Agger^^, read aggerere.
Here ends the Corrections.
coat of arms or blazon

A. ante B.
A Sygnifieth of, or from. Ab, and Abs, be of the same sygnification, only A,
goth before a word, which begins with a co^sona^t: ab and abs goth before a
word that does begin with a vowell. Abatis, two words made of the preposition,
a, and the ablative case plurell of Batus, which in english is a measure,
signifies an officer, that has the orderyng of measures, Esdra.
as a clerk of the markette, Abaccidentibus, an officer, unto whom it
belongs to write such things as do chance. Abacti, officers deposed, or such
as be constrained to resygne their authority. Abactores, thieves that steal
cattle. Abacus, a countyng table, or cupborde. Abaculus, of Pliny is taken
for account. Abalienatus, he whom a man puts from him Abalieno, aui, are, to
put or turn away. Abana, a river in the country of Damask under the hill
called Libanus. Hieron.
Abanec, a gyrdell that the priests of Jews did wear. Abambulo, aui, are, to
ascend or mount up. Abaphus, vndied or vncoloured. Abauus, my great
grandefathers father. Abax, abacis, a cupboorde, or dresser, also an
astronomers tables. Abaci, the tables inbowed, whereon pylars do stand. Abbas,
atis, an abbotte. Abbatissa, an abbess. Plinius.
Abarimon, a countreye in Tartari, where men have fete turned backwarde, and
be wonderful swifte, and be wild. Abaster, one of the horses of Pluto king of
Hell. Abdera, a city in the realm of Thracia. Abderita, a citesyn of Abdera.
Abdias, the name of a prophet. Abdico, aui, are, to expel or put out of
favor, or resygne an office, or to refuse his son or kynsman. Abdicauit
filium, He refused him for his son. Abdicauit se magistratu, He has resygned
his office or dignity. Abdico, ixi, cere, to deny or forsake. Abdo, didi,
dear, to hyde. Abdomen, the fat about the kydneyes. It is also the vdder and
teates of a sow, full of milk, which is in Italy had for a delycate meat.
Abduco, xi, cere, to lead away, or lead out, or pull away, or take with.
Abellinae, fylberdes of Abellino, a city in Naples. Abemo, emi, ere, to take
or put of a garment. Abemito uestem, Put of thy cote. Plau, ce.
Abeo, iui, uel ii, ire, to depurte, or go away. Aberceo, to forbid. Eam
abercet domo, He forbyddeth her his house. Aberro, aui, are, to err or wa^der
very much, to depart far of, or a sonder. Aberu^co, aui, are, to wede out,
or pluck out. Abessa, the name of a Judge in Israel. Abfore, to be away.
Abgrego, aui, are, to sever or take out of the flock, or to draw sheep.
Abhinc, before this time. Abhorreo, ui, rere, to abhor, to hate. Abhorresco,
to fear to behold. Abiecto, aui, are, to cast often away. Abies, ietis, a
fyrre tree. Abietarius, a carpentar. Abigeatus, tus, felony in stealing
cattle. Abige^us, a stealer of cattle. Abigo, egi, gere, to drive away any
thing, that is evil or noyous. also to drive away cattle by theft or
deceyte. Abiicio, ieci, iicere, to cast away, to renounce to despise.
Abintegro, yet again eftesones. Abintestato, intestate or without testament.
Abiudico, aui, are, to recover or take away by judgment. Abiugo, aui, are, to
unyoke, discharge, or put asonder. Abiungo, xi, ere, to fever or sonder.
Abiurati, sworn brethern, or confederatis. Abiuro, aui, are, to deny by an
oath, or to keep a thing wrongfully. Abiudicatum, adjudged, given by judgment.
Ablacto, aui, are, to weaue. Ablaqueo, aui, are, to rydde the earth from trees
or vynes, and cut away the upper rotes, that they may bear the more fruit.
Ablego, aui, are, to send away. Abligurio, iui, ire, to consume in banketting
or farynge delycately. Abloco, aui, are, to set or let to an other. Abluo,
ui, ere, to wasshe of. Abnego, aui, are, to deny utterly. Abnepos, otis, A
son in the fourth degree in lyneall descent. Abnuo, nui, ere, to deny or
refuse with countenance or beck, to beck away. Abnuto, signifies to do the
same oftentimes Aboleo, eui, uel ui, ere, to put out, or raze out to anulle, or
undo for ever. Abolesco, to bring to naught. Abolla, a Senators habyte, or a
sowldiours cloak. Abominor, atus sum, nari, to take for ylle luck, or have in
detestation. Aborigines, people, which first held the country about Rome,
and lived abroad having no houses. They may also be taken for any other
people, whose beginning is not known. Abonor, abortus sum, aboriri, to be
borne before natural time. Aborsus, an untimely birth, nygh to the conception:
which may be called aborsion. Abortus, an untimely birth, nyghe to the just
time of delyueraunce, whereby the child dies. Abortio, onis, et Abortinus,
the birth dystroyed with some hurt, or other mysaduenture, or medycine.
Aborno, tiui* tire, to bring forth a child, (...) be perfect. Abortrium,
idem quod abortus. Abortinus, a, um, that thing, which procures the said
untimely birth. Abpatruus, My fathers great uncle. Ab^ado, ^i, dear, to pare
or scrape away. Ab^^e, out of the matter, or out of the purpose* unseemly,
inconvenient. Abte^o, aui, are, to renounce, or forsake. Ab^tua, against thy
profit. A^, p^^ ere, to take fro, or take by fors. Ab^^gu^, they which being
at liberty, (...) them selu^s to an other man's rule, by their consent. (...),
aui, ^re, to take away. (...), to dissolve or repel a law. (...), an herb
called southern wode. (...), tumpere, to break of, pluck (...) cut of.
(...), of or fro. (...), a river of Armeny, that incloseth the (...) Armente.
(...), dear, to go away. (...), et ab^cen^o, a departing. Ab^us, is of
phisytions taken for an impos^ume or botche, or for a course of evil humors
to some part of the body, whereby matter is engendered. Abse^do, di, dear, to
cut of. Abse^do, signifies the same. Abscio, iui, ire, to go out of
remembrance. Abscondo, di, dear to hyde. Abscus, it is, absent, or away.
Absentaneus, a, um, that which in absence is done. Absentia, absence.
Absentio, tire, to think contrary. Absento, aui, are, to be absent. Absimilis,
much unlike. Absis, idos, the struck of a cart whele, wherein the spokes he
set Absisio, tere, to depart from a place* sometime it signifies to
abstain or leave of. Absoleo, ere, to be out of use. Absoletus locus, a place
unoccupied or neglected. Absoluo, ui, ere, to loose that which was bounden.
also to perform or accomplish. Also to spare or forgive, to pardon, to speed,
to assoyle. Absono, absonaui, absonare, to discord or sown euylle. Absonus,
na, number, that which sowneth not well, or discordeth, or scantly may be herd.
Absorbeo, bui, nel absorpsi, ere, to swalowe, or suppe of all, to devour or
consume. Absque, without. Abstemius, he that drinks no wine. Abstentus,
accursed out of the church. Absterreo, ui, ere, to prohybyte or let, or
put fro. Abstinentia, abstinence, a virtue in forbearynge to take an other
man's goods. Abstineo, ui, ere, to absteyne or forbear, or tempre. Absto,
stiti, stare, to stand far of. Abstorqueo, torsi, quere, to get by force
or tourmentes. Abstraho, xi, ere, to take by force or by craft Abstrudo, si,
dear, to hyde. Abstulit, of Aufero, he has birefte, taken away, or borne away.
Absum, fui, abesse, to be away, or far of, or to fail, or to be distant or
absent. Absumo, psi, ere, to spend or consume. Absurdus, surda, surdum,
inconvenient, foolysshe, discordinge, dishoneste, abhorringe, or odious.
Absynthium, wormewoode, Absyrtides, be ylandes in the Venitian see. Absyrtus,
the brother of Medea, whom she did cut into pieces, and threw into the sea,
when she fled from her father with Jason. Abundantia, haboundance, more than
sufficient richesse. Abunde, habu^dantly, plentuously, enough, and more than
enough. Abundo, aui, are, to habunde, to have out of measure more than enough.
Abuolo, aui, are, to flee away. Abutor, abusus sum, abuti, to abuse, to use a
thing: dishonestely, uncomely, contrary to that, that it serves for, out of
order, or in vain. Abusiue, improprely, against Nature, or custom. Abydena,
trifles, things of small estimation, wanton toys, things unseemly for
men to use. Abydeni, a people in Asia, which having their City distressed
with a long Syege, fell into a furye, or madness, and slew all their wives,
their chylderne, and afterward them selves. Abydos, the city of the said
people. Abyla, a hylle in the occean See against Spain, which is called oone
of Hercules pylars. Augustinus Ambrosius.
Abyssus, is a depenes without bottom.
A ante C.
AC, signifies sometime, and. as Doctus ac iustus es, Thou art kunnyng and
just. Sometime it is taken for Than, as Haud secus ac iussi faciunt, They do
none otherwise than they be commanded. Sometime it does signify as, as
Superbis perinde, ac si Rex esses, Thou art as proud as if thou were a king.
Acatia, is the juice of a fruit called siliqua. It may be called also in
England veriuyse. Acadoemia, a university, which took that name of a place
nighe to Athenes, where Plato the great philosopher taught phylosophye.
Academici, were a sect of philosophers, which followed and taught the
opynyons of Plato. Acanthis, idis, a bird that feeds on thystelles, and
makes her nest with claye, and is called in english, a Tytmusse. It was also
a boy, which the poets do feign was transformed into a flower of his name.
It is also a bushe, like a white thorn, with less leaves, mosy, and
pryckynge. Dioscorides says, that it is an herb, that grows in stony and
moist ground, and has leaves brother and longer than letyse, in form like to
rockette, somewhat black, and in broysynge soft and fatty, having a stalk of
two cubytes high, of thyckenesse of a man's finger, garnyshed under the top with
little long leaves and pryckynge, whereunto grows a white flower. Acapna,
dry wodde that smoketh not. Acara, a town in the myddelle of Hungarye.
Acarnania, a part of a royalme in Greece, named Epirus. It is also a little
countreye in Egypt: and it is a city by Syracusis in the royalme of Sycile.
Acarpia, lack of fruit. Acatalectos, a verse, wherein one syllable lacks.
Acatium, the greattest sayll in the ship. Accalaurentia, the name of her,
that nourished Romulus and Remus, the first builders of Rome. Accedo, accessi,
dear, to goo to, or approach. Sommetyme it sygnifyeth to give an ear or
harken, to take heed, and to make much of. Accelero, aui, are, to make haste
or speed. Accendo, di, dear, to kendle, inflame, provoke, or give boldness.
Accensi, were sowldiours appointed to be about great officers for defense of
their persons. Festus says, that it were they, which after the death of
soldiers were put in their places. Varro affirms, that they were ministers
ready at the commandments of principal officers. Accentus, an acce^t or
tune, whereby a syllable is pronounced. Accepso, in the stead of acceperim, I
have taken. Acceptabula, all vessayle or other thing, that may receive and
keep what so ever shall be put into it. Acceptilatio, an acceptaunce, a word
of the law, which happens in this wise. One says to an other, Art thou
contented with that that I have promised the? or that by my bargain I owe to
the? The other says, ye I am contented. This is Acceptilatio. Also wherein so
ever I have bounden my self by receyuynge of any thing, it may be called
Acceptilatio. Acceptum, thankful, pleasant, allowable. Acceptum fero, to
knowledge my self to have received, that is not yet paid, also to take
thankfully. Accerso, siui, sire, to call forth, or send for. Accerso, sere,
tertiae coniugationis, to goo to call, or fetch. Accidens, is an accident,
which may be, or not be, without corruption of that, wherein it may be.
Accido, di, dear, to fall down in doing reverence. Accingo, cinxi, cingere,
to gyrde, to prepare, to make redye to do some thing. Accinctus, gyrte, redye,
quycke in his business. Accio, iui, ire, to call to. Accipio, coepi, cipere,
to take, to here, to suppose, to know, to understand, to receive, to entreat
or entertayne. Accipiter, a hawke. Accliue, stepe bendynge. Acclino, aui, are,
to enclyne or bend to. Accliuis, sieve accliuius, rysynge upward to a small
top. Accludo, to shut to. Accola, the next inhabytant. Accola campi, He
that dwellethe next to the field. Also he that comes out of one countreye,
and dwells in an other. Accolo, to dwell by or nyghe, specially hills or
waters. Acco^modo, aui, are, to accommodate, appropre, to apply, make apt,
set in order, give, or inclyne. Acc^edo, didi, ere, to give crede^ce, to
assent. Accresco, creui, crescere, to grow to. Accubi^um, a bed or couche to
lie on by day time, as it was the manner of the old Romans, to eat lyenge
on their beddis. Accubicus, the lyenge in the said manner. Accubo* accubui,
bare, to lie by, or to sytte, or lie down to cate. Accumbo, cubui, bear, to
lie down, to lie by, to lie or sytte down at feasts and bankettes. Accu^bere
mensa^, to sit at one table. Accumulo, aui, are, to accumulate or gather in
heaps, to increase. A^^uro, aui, are, to take good head. Accu^a^us, ta, tum,
wherein is much dylygence, curtouse. Accurate, diligently, curiousely.
Accu^^^o, (...), ^ere* to ru^ne to, to speed thither Accusato^ius, ^^a, tium,
which conteyneth an accusation. Accuso* aui, are, to accuse. Ac^dra, siouthe,
pen^ysenes, heaviness of heart, werynesse. Acc^^^^, ^^^tas ^um, to be weary, or
to wax slouthefull. A^ et acentreta, things whereof the paynt in the mids is
not known. (...) acere, to be sour or sharp. (...)* ^um, without a heed.
(...) a tree, the wodde whereof is most gentle to work in, and is named in
english Dowgeon. (...), et Aceracris, acre, sower as (...) sommetyme it
betokens strong, sometime sharp. Acer inimi^us, a sharp enemy. Also
sore, as Acres animaduersores, soore punysshers. Acredo, A^^tudo, Acritas,
sharpness, or sowernesse. Acriter, sharply, or sowrely. Acer, ace^^s, chafe
of mylsede. Acerosum frumentum, vnkleane wheat. Acerbitas, bytternes of taste,
sharpenes of time, cruelty in man. Acerbo, baui, are, to trouble, to make
bitter, or abhomynable. Acerbus, ba, bum, unripe, bitter, difficult, or
peynefulle, as, Robustorum iuuenum acerba mors, The death of young men is
peynefulle, as who says, they dye with greatte difficulty. Acersecomes, He
that never cuttethe his hear. Aceruatim, in heaps. Aceruo, aui, are, to
gather into heaps. Aceruus, a heap or gatherynge together* specially of
grain. Acesco, sci, scere, to wax sour or tarte, specially in lykour.
Acetabulum, a kind of vessel, which may be called a charger, or a basyn, and
was a vessel, wherein were things sacrified. Acetare, to move or stir.
Acetarium, a salate of herbs. it is also a gardeyn, where salate herbs do
grow. Acetum, vynegre. Achaei, people in Grecia. and sometime they be taken for
greeks generally. Achaeron, it is, is of poets taken for a river of hell.
Achaia, a region in Grecia. Achareon, the main sail of a ship. Achates, was
the name of the companyon or mynton of Aeneas the Troiane. It is also the name
of a precious stoone found in Sicile, which is in color brown, and has
cerkles black and white. Achetae, gresshoppers, which chirpe loud and
pleasantly. Achilleum, a sponge, which is very soft, and has small holes.
Aciaeris, a hatchet of brass, which among the paynyms was used in sacrifice.
Acicula, a pynne. Acidula, pears that be sower. Acidus, da, dum, sour, or
sharp. Acies, betokens the edge of a knyfe, or other weapon or tool. Also
the front of an host, at the ioynynge of battle, more over that part of the
eye, which is called the syghte. Acinacis, a crooked sword that the Persyans
used. Acini, be little kernels, which be in grapis, raisons, pomegranates,
and other beries. Accipenser, or Aquipenser, a kind of syshe which has the
scales turned toward the hedde. Aclanes, he that never cries. Aclytes, a
weapon used in the old time. Aconitum, an herb, wherein is most fervent
poison. Acontiae, certain impressyons in the fyrmament like to fyrye darts,
which do seem to fly. Acopa, medicines to remedy werynesse. Acopis, a
precious stone like a glass, with small golden dropes, wherewith if oil be
heat, and the body therewith anointed, it dissolueth all werynesse. Acor, ris,
a tartenes like unto unripe wine or pomegranates. Acquiesco, eui, escere, to
lean, as to lean my heed or arm upon any thing. Also it signifies to
assent to other men's sayings. Acquiro, siui, rere, to attain a thing that is
sought for. Acraton, pure wine, without a lay, or vnmixte. Acredo, dinis, the
sharpnes that is in fruits, which be not ripe. Acredula, the wodde lark.
Acrimonia, tartnes, which biteth the tu^ge, and perceth the heed, as in the
taste of garlyke, oynions, and other like things. It signifies sometime
sharpnes in speking or mind: sometime lyuelynes and quyckenesse of wit.
Acrochordones, a kind of wertes, as great as beans, so small at the roots,
that they do seem to hang by a synewe. Acroma, a subtle sentence or lesson,
requiringe much study and search. it is also taken for all things to be
recited or done, to delight the audience. Acta, water ba^kis, or which me^ do
call stro^des, whereon the sea flows. Also it is that which we call acts,
concerning men's lives or private busynes put in writing. also such deeds as
have happened out of judgment. Acri^ata be those, which have happened in judgment,
proprely they, which be in doing. Acreon, the name of a man, whom Diana,
because he did se her nakid, turnid i^to an heart, and so was he torn and slain
of his own hou^dis. Actio, onis, betokenith sometime pronunciation, sometime an
oration written, sometime an action in the law, sometime an history, sometime
a defense, otherwhyle a recompense in words for benefit received, as
gratiarum actio, for thanks. generally it is taken for act or deed in every
thing. Actiosus, busye. Actito, aui, are, to practice, specially in civil
causes. Actor, which both the deed. Also in the law the plaintiff,
complaynant, or demandaunt. Also a player of enterludes. Also a man's factour
or baylyffe, that has the charge of his business. Actualia nomina, names,
which do proceed of act, as Rex, a regendo, of gouernynge, Dux a ducendo, of
leadynge. Actuarius, ria, rium, active. Actuarius, a substantive, signifies a
notary or scribe, or any other that writes spedily. Also it betokenith a kind
of ships, which be callid barkis. Actum est, it is lost. Actuosus, full of
acts. Actus, ta, tu^, performed, also arrived, thrust in, brought to, or
feared. Actus, tus, a deed, the parts of a comedy or play, a days warke in
tyllage. Actutum, anon, without tarienge. Aculeus, a prycke or slynge. Acumen,
the sharpnes of every thing. it signifies also clerenes of wit. Acumino,
aui, are, to sharpen. Acinicula, a small nedell. Acuo, ui, ere, to make
sharp, as a knyfe, or other thing like. sometime it betokenethe to teach,
otherwhile to steer. Acupictores, imbrowderers. Acus, ci, a fish called a
banstikle or ba^ning. Acus, aceris, chafe. Acus, acus, a nedell, also chafe
of corn, also an order in battle. Acutus, ta, tum, sharp, but in voice it
betokens high and small, as a treble.
A, ante D.
AD, by him self, or joined to an other word, signifies to, or at, as Vado ad
oppidum, I go to the town. Erat ad ripam fluminis ingens arbor, There was at
the ryuers iyde a great tree. Some time it signifies against, as, Ad illum
mihi pugna est, Against him is my war. Sometime it betokens in comparyson,
sometime cause, as, Ad quid hoc fecisti? For what cause, or whereto did thou
this? Sometime about, as Ad duo millia hominu^ occisa sunt, There be slain
about two thousand men. Also after, as, Ad haec, After this. Ad annum, during
a hole year. Ad diem, at the day appointed. Ad tempus, for a while. Ad
exemplum, to the example or lykenes. Ad extremum, finally at the last. Ad
pedes defilio, I light on my fete. Ad rem facit, it makes for the matter, or
is convenient. Ad rem pertinet, it belongs to the purpose. Ad uerbum, word
by word. Ad unum, unto the last. Adaeque, semblably, so much: as, Adaeque
miser, so much a wretch. Adagia, an old wife, which late had a child.
Adagium, a proverb, or as I might say. an old said saw. Adamas, adamantis,
a precious stone, called a dyamant. Adamo, aui, are, to love very well.
Adamussim, by rule, straight as a line. Adapto, aui, are, to join to. Adaquo,
aui, are, to water horse or cattle. Adarea, a frothe or foam growyng on reeds
in the fennes. Ad calendas graecas, signifies Never. For the old greeks had
no calendes. Addico, xi, dicere, to say, to judge, to appoynte, or depute.
Addictus, he that is judged, appointed, or deputed. Addictus, ta, tum, openly
sold. Also Addicere was when the judge in the old time delivered the dettour to
his credytours, to do with him what they lysted. Addisco, didici, discere, to
learn well, or add to in learning. Additus, ta, tum, added or put to. Addo,
didi, dear, to add, join, or put to. Add^^^^, ^m, cere, to learn. Add^^mio,
miui, ^e, to sleep. Add^^^, xi, cere, to bring to, or bring forth, sometime to
draw or pluck together. A^^^^tations, a frownyng forcheed. sometime ^^ducere
is to ertende or thrust out. Ad^^^, di, ^e^e, to devour. Ade^^^, so much,
moreover, surely, without doubt. Sometime it signifies even, as Ture^^ ^o eras
audies uerba, Thou thy self (...) shalt here his words. (...), to go to, to
demand, to attempt, to make assault. (...), the fat of all thing. (...),
opteyned gotten, or founden. (...), ta^i, ta^e, to dwell by. (...), moreover.
(...), to clean fast, to set sure, to (...) to. (...), to blow or to
breathe on a thing. (...), aui, are, to bind to, or tie, or (...). (...), ui,
bear, to put to, to have by me. (...) thermore. (...), at time appointed.
Ad^^^, yet, hitherto. Ad^^^, (...), cere, to lie by. Adid^^, short battes of a
cubyte long and an half, having pikes of iron in them, and were tied to a
line, that when they were thrown, he that did cast the^, might pluck them
again unto him, hurlebattes. Adigo, egi, adigere, to procure or styre, to bynd
by oath, or promise, to bring or drive to, to fasten or join to. Adirciales,
feasts that pryestes made in the old time. Adiicio, ieci, iicere, to cast
to, to add or put to, or increase. Adiicere oculum, to look on, or consider.
Adimo, emi, ere, to take away, or diminishe. Adineo, iniui, i^e, to put in.
Adinstar, like to. Adipales, feasts that priests were wont to make.
Adipatus, ta, tum, larded, basted. Adipiscoi, adeptus sum, to get or optain:
ioynid with a person it signifies to overtake. Aditio, tionis, an access, or
repair. Adito, taui, tare, to go to. Aditus, tus, access, coming to, or
entry. Adiudico, aui, are, to adinge. Adiugo, aui, are, to yoke or join to.
Adiungo, xi, ere, to join to, to apply. Adiuro, aui, are, to deny with an
oath, to conjure. Adiuto, aui, are, to help often. Adiuuo, aui, are, to help.
Adiutorium, help. Adiumentum, help. Adlimina, a porter, which does keep the
utter gate. Ad liquidum, clearly, evidently, plainly. Admando, aui, are, to
send to, to deliver any thing to one to bring to an other. Admanus, at
hand, ready. Adminiculor, aris, et Adminiculo, are, to aid, to succor.
Adminiculum, aid, supportation. Admiratio, a wonderynge. Admiror, raris, ratus
sum, rari, to wonder. Admissarius equus, a stalyon horse. Admissionales, vshers
of the chamber. Admissura, the act or time when beasts does their kind in
generation. Seasoning. Admitto, misi, mittere, to admit, to put to, to bring
in, to suffer, to sustain, or take. Admodu^, very much, somewhat, resonably.
Admodum, as it were. Admolior, iris, molitus sum, liri, to put or add to.
Admoneo, nui, ere, to warn, to exhort. Admordeo, momordi, dear, to byte
soore. Admoueo, ui, ere, to move to, or put to. Adoleo, leui, lui, ere,
adultum, to begin to grow, to do sacrifice with incense, or other fumes, to
burn sweet things. Adolescentia, is the aege between chyldehode and man's
age, which is between xiiii. and.xxi. Adolescentior, aris, atus sum, to be
wanton, or full of youth. Adolescenturio, iui, ire, to play the boy. Adonia,
festiual days, which were kept in the honor of Adonis, the derling of Venus.
Adonis, the name of a child, which was son of Cynare, king of Cypres, whom
Venus had for her derlynge, which was slain with a bore, whom the poets
fained, that Venus turned into a purple flower. Adonidis horti, gardeyns for a
little time pleasant, which shortly decayen. Adoptio, an election of an
heir out of the course of inheritance, as by will or gift. Adoptitius, he that
is adopted or taken in the stead of a son. Adoptiuus, the son of him that is
adopted. Adopto, aui, are, to elect or apoint an heir. Adoratio, reverence due
to god, or saints. also an inward devotion and affection to him that
reverence is done unto: and is an express mocyon or act of reverence done
with the body. Adorea, et adoreola, A praise that is given to them that have
victory. Also a cake of fine wheat, which they used in sacrifice. Adoreum,
sede corn. Adordior, iris, adorsus sum, riri, to speak to, to begin.
Adorior, adortus sum, to set on suddenly, to begin. Adorior hunc, I set
on him. Adoro, raui, are, to honor with inclination of the body, to bescche.
Ad plenum, perfectly, fully. Adprimus, chief of all. Adpulsus, Adpulsio, the
dryfte of sheep to the water. Adrepo, psi, ere, to crepe to. Adrumo, maui, to
grudge or make rumor. Adruo, rui, ere, to turn the earth in tyllage. Adscire,
to join or put to. Adsum, fui, esse, I am here, er present, or at hand.
Adsummam, in conclusion, finally. Adtempus, for a time. Adueho, uexi, uehere,
to bring to or carry to. Aduena, a stranger. Aduenio, ni, uenire, to come to.
Aduentitia bona, goods which do come unlooked for. Aduentitius morbus,
syckenes that comes without our defaute, and of some men is called an
vncome. Aduentitius, He that commethe to a place by chance. Aduentito, aui,
are, to come often to. Aduento, aui, are, to come nigh. Plautus in Mustellaria.
Aduentores, commune resorters, or haunters to a place. Aduersarius, an
adversary. Aduersitores, servants, which do fetch home their masters after
dynar or supper. Aduersor, satus sum, sari, to repugne or be contrary, or to
refuse. Aduersus, contrary, or against. Aduerto, ti, tere, to turn to.
Aduiuo, uixi, uiuere, to live yet. Adulor, atus sum, lari, to flatter.
Adulatio, flatterye. Adulter, adultera, a man or woman auoutrer. Adulterinae
claues, counterfaite keys. Adulterinus, na, nu^, counterfaite, or forged.
Adultero, raui, rare, to cou^terfaite or forge. Adulterium, auoutry. Adultus,
ta, tum, full grown. Adumbro, aui, are, to make or give shadow, to represente
or express, as peynters do, that do shadow images in plain tables, to make
them show imboced or round. Adunco, aui, are, to make crooked. Aduncus, crooked
or hooked. Adunguem, to the perfection. Aduno, aui, are, to gather together.
Adunum, eueryche one. Aduocatus, an advocate. Aduoco, caui, care, to call to,
or call to help. Aduolo, saui, are, to fly to, or nygh a place. Aduotu^, after
mine, or thin, or his appetite. Adusque, until. Adytu^, the chauncell or other
secret place of the temple, where none came but priests, or persons
sanctified.
Ae, ante D.
AEdere spiritum, to yield up the ghost, Cicero ad Attic.
to dye. Aedere facinus, to do an ill deed. Aedere stragem, to make a slaughter
of me^. Tit. Liuius.
Aedere nonuna, to tell the names to be written. Aedere librum, to set forth
such a book. Cicero in V^^e.
Aedere scriptum, to show forth writing. Aedere praelium, to make battle.
Aedepol, an oath among gentyles, sygnyfyenge by Pollux house. Aedes, a house.
and if there be joined thereunto the name of god or of a saint, it sygnifieth a
church, or temple. Aedes saluatoris, saint Saviors church. Aedieula, an
oratorie, or place, where images were kept. Aedificiu^, all the hole building
of the house. Aedifico, caui, care, to build. Aediles, officers, whose charge
was to see to the keeping up and maynteynyng of temples, and private houses,
and to make provision for solemn plays. Aedilitas, litum, the office of the
Aediles. Aedilitius, He that had been ones in that authorytie. Aeditiuus the
prelate of the temple. Aediticius, a Judge or arbitratour chosen of the one
part. Aedituor, ari, to rule over the temple or house Aeditus, ta, tum, high
and strong. Aedituus, the prelate of the temple or church, and may be now
called the person or paryshe priest. Aedo, aedidi, tum, to set forth or
publyshe. Also it signyfyeth to bring forth by generacyon.
Ae, ante G.
AEger, gra, grum, sick. Aegipanes, beasts like to men, having fete like to
gotes. Aegre, greuousely, or heuily. Aegrumonia, syckenes. Aegroto, aui, are,
to be sick. Aegrotatio, syckenesse. Aegrotus, ta, tum, sick.
Ae, ante M,
Aemulor, emulatus sum, aemulari, to envy without malice, or to follow, or
study to be like to an other. Aemulus, he that follows or enuieth another,
only for desire of glory.
Ae ante N.
Aenatores, blowers in trumpettes. Aeneus, aenea, aeneum, brason. Aenigma, it is,
a derke question, hard to be understood. Aenigmatistes, he that pourposeth
hard questions. Aenum, a cawdron.
Ae, ante Q.
Aequabilis, equal. Aequabilitas uitae, wherein is no variety or ^^^ble.
(...), of one age. (...), equal, plain, like, of like age. (...), like wise.
Aequamentum, indifferency. Aequaminis, he that is neither extolled with
prosperity, nor disco^forted in aduersite. Ae^ua^mitas, taking in good part.
Aequa^mite^, moderatly, pacie^tly, coldly. Aeque^ustly, or as well.
Aequabonique facio, I take in good part, I seek not, or care not. Aequid^ale,
the time when the days and the nights be of one length. Aequilibrium, of even
weight or poyse. Aequimanus he that uses the one hand as well as the other.
Aequinoctium, the time of the year, when the day is as long as the night,
which is twice in the year. In spryng time about the viii, Calendes of Aprile:
And in Autumn about the.viii. calendes of October. Aequinoctiale, the
adjective of aequinoctiu^. Aequiparo, aui, are, to compare or make equal
Aequipolleo, ui, ere, to have like power, or be of like estimation. Aequitas,
equity, justice, or enennes. Aequiualco, ui, ere, to be equiualente, or of
like valor. Aequiuocum, one word having diverse sygnifycations. Aequo, aui,
are, to make even or plain. Aequor, the sea, sometime other waters. Aequus,
even or plain.
Ae, ante R.
Aer, the air sommetyme wind, blaste, breathe, or sound. Era, rae, money
numbered. Aerarii milites, sowldiours waged. Aerarium, a tresory, where tresure
is kept. Aere diruti milites, sowdiours, which for some defaute were put out
of wages. Aeripes, which is as swyfte as the wynd. Aerius, of the air or like
to the air. Aeratus, myxte with copper. Aerugo, ginis, rust or canker in
metal, specially in copper or silver. Aeruginosus, rustye, or cankred.
Aerumna, labor paynfull, care of mind, with heaviness, infelicitie. Aeruscate,
to get money by falsehode.
Ae, ante S.
Aes, aeris, is proprely copper or brass. It is oftentimes taken for money,
sometime for trumpettes. Aes nostrum, Money that other men do owe unto us.
Aes alienum, money that we do owe to other men. Aes suum, money that other men
do owe unto him, whom we speak of. Aes ductile, metal that wol be sone
molte^. Aesculum, an oak that bears maste. Aestas, Summer. Aestimabile, that
which may be valewed. Aestimatio, a pain set. Aestimo, aui, are, to esteem,
to value. Aestiua, places to be in for shadow in the summer time. Astiuo, aui,
are, to dwell or be in a summer place. Aestuaria, places whereunto the sea
flows and ebbith, or meres, filled with salt water. Aestuo, aui, are, to wax
hot, to bourne, to flow like the sea. Aestuosus, hot, or feruente. Aestus,
tus, tui, heat of the wether, or burning of the sun. Also the vyolence or
troublous motion of the sea.
Ae, ante T.
Aetas, age. Aetate, an aduerbe, signifies long time. Aeternus, everlasting.
Ether, the fyrmament. Aethera, rae, the air. Aethra, sygnifieth the same.
Ae, ante V.
Aeuum, long or everlasting time.
A ante F.
AFer, or Apher, a man born in Affrike. Affabilis, a man easy to be spoken
unto. Affabilitas, gentylnes in heryng. Affabre, counnyngly, craftily.
Affabrum, counnyngly or craftily wrought Affaniae, tryfles. Affatim,
abundantly. Affecto, aui, re, to seek affectualli, to trouble when it is put
with damno, or other like. Affectata oration, a curyouse form of speaking.
Affectatio, curyositie. Affectate, curyousely. Affectus, ta, tum, troubled or
vexed. Affectus, tus, tui, et affectio, affection or natural motion, as
gladness, desire, and such like. Affero, fers, attuli, afferre, to bring to.
Afficio, eci, ere, to move affection or disposition, either to good or to ill.
Afficit me gaudio, It makes me glad. Afficit me dolor, It makes me sorry.
Affecit cum laetali uulnere, he gave to him his deaths wound. Affigo, gere,
to nail to, or fasten. Affines, in fields betokens adioynyng: In men it
betokens alyance by marriage. Affirmo, aui, are, to affirm. Affirmatio,
affyrmaunce. Affligo, flixi, gere, to punyshe. Afflictatio, punyshement of the
body with syckenesse. Afflare, to blow wind. Affluo, fluxi, fluere, to
ouerflow or abunde. Affore, to be present. Africa, The third part of the
world, wherein is Carthage, Numidia, and all the countries now called
Barbarye. Affricanus, a man of Affrike. Also the most noble captain Scipio,
was called Affricanus, because he subdewed that country to the Romans.
Affrico, cas, caui, uel affrixi, to rub. A front atque a tergo, A proverb
signifieng the conferring of things passed, with the state of things
present.
A ante G.
AGame^non, was the general Capytayne of the greeks, at the syege of Troy.
Agamnestor, was king of Athenes. Age, Go to. Agedum, go to yet. Agellus, a
little syelde. Ager, agri, a field. Sometime a territory belonging to a
town, wherein is includid fields, meadows, woddes, and waters. Sommetime a
manor with the demeanes. sometime the arable field only. Agger, eris, a heap
of stones or turfe. also a bulworke, or a countremure to a fortress or camp
in battle. sometime it sygnyfieth a caulsey. Aggero, aui, are, to heap up.
Agglomero, to make up on heap, by adding to. Agglutino, naui, nare, to
join together. Aggrauo, aui, are, to be bourdenouse or chargeable. Aggredior,
gredi, to goo to, or come to, to invade, to begin, to attempt. Aggrego, aui,
are, to gather to gyther. Agilis, nymble, or light. Agilitas, nymblenes,
dexterity. Agina, wherein the beam of a pair of balance is hanged. Aginator,
he that is meuid with a little gain. Agiographa, books of holy scripture. Agito,
tare, to do often, to pryck, to compel, to trouble, to persecute, to vex, to
consider, to reuolue, to solycite. Agmen, an hooste of men. Agnati, kynsmen of
the fathers side. Agnatum, that which is in birth more than need requires.
Agnomen, the surname that I have by my father. Agnosco, noui, noscere, to
know. Agnus, a lamb. Ago, egi, agere, to do, to lead, to drive, to labor,
to here, to speak, to pronounce, to feign, to goo. Nudi agunt, They go naked.
I extend or sprede. Radices agunt, Pom. Mel.
They sprede their roots. I treat of a thing, I give. Ago gratias, I give
thanks. I bring forth, also to expel. Venena membris agit, It expellethe
poison out of the members. Agolu^, a staff to drive cattle with. Agonia,
fere and heuines, or vexatio^ of mind. Agonisma, the reward of victory.
Agonista, a champyon. Agonizo, aui, are, I contend, or fight valyantlye.
Agonotheta, he that makethe a commune game, and payethe the reward to them
that do win it. Agaranomus, he that sets the price of vyttayle, a talker.
Agoraeus, a markette manne, a haunter of markettes. Agrarius a landed man. Also
he that favors the laws, which be made for the ordering of possessions.
Agrarius, ria, rium, pertaining to lands or possessions. Agrerus, a greste,
wild grown, without culture. Also he that is rude and beastlye, without
gentle manners. Agricola, a husband manne. Agricolator, the same. Aggripetae,
they that do ask their portion in division of lands. Agrippae, they which be
borne with their feet forewarde.
A ante H.
AHenum, a port to heat in drink. Ahenus, a vesselle of white brass or
copper, which is bryghte both within and without.
A, ante I.
Aio, ais, ait, I say, thou say, he says.
A, ante L.
ALa, a wynge of a bird, and a wyng of a battle, which is proprelye of
horsemenne. A^er* et alactis, alacre, quycke of spirit, (...) wit, lusty of
courage, merry, and he that lives in hope: proprely he that is in a mean
between glad and sort. Sometime it betokens a man ready and willing, thereof
comes Alacritas, redynes or promptnes of will. also feruentnes of mind.
Al^tas* ta* tum, wynged. Alaeda, a lark. Albanum, the parget of a wall.
Albedo, albeuido, albor, whytenes. Albeo, ba^, b^re, to be white. Albeus, et
albeolus, a chessebourde. Albieo, aui, are, to be white. Albidus, a, um,
somewhat white. Albo, aui, are, to make white. Albugo, gitus, a white spotte in
the eyes. also the white of an egg. Album, a table openly set up, wherein
either the names of officers, or some public decree is written. Albumen,
albuminis, the white of an egg. Albumum, the fat that is in some tree.
Albus, ba, bum, white. Alcedmes, et Alcyones, are birds of the sea, which do
hatche their young chykens on the land, and do lay their eggs on the sands,
in mids of the winter, and wha^ the sea is most troublous, if they do lay,
it becomes suddenly calm, and the storms and wyndes do cease, until these
birds have all hatched, and brought up their chykens, and made them ready to
flee: which is in the space of.xiiii. days. This bird is little more than a
sparowe, his feathers be purple of color, myxt with white, and has a long
neck and a small, his byl somewhat grene, long, and sclender, and this bird is
seen very seldom. Alea, a dye, playinge at dies. sometime it signifies chance.
Alea fortunae, The chance of fortune. sometime peril. Aleator, a dysar.
Alecula, a sprotte. Ales, alitis, a bird, sometime it signifies swyfte in
fleing, or runnyng: as Alite planta, swyfte of foot. Alexicacon, a remedy to
put away myschiefe, or any ill thing. Alexipharmacum, the general name of
medicines, which do expel syckenes. Alga, reyte, or wedes of the sea. Algeo,
alsi, algere, to be in pain, proprely for cold, to chyll for cold. Algor,
grefe, sometime it signifies cold. Alias, an aduerbe, sygnifieth, or else,
else where, an other time, sometime. Alias res agis, Thou take no heed what
is spoken. Alibi, else where. Alica, a drink made of wheat brayed in a stone
mortar, the husks of the wheat being taken clean away. Alicubi, somewhere,
aliubi. Alicunde, from some place. Alienigena, a stranger borne. Aliemgenus,
na, number, that which comethe out of an other country. Alieno, naui, nare, to
alienate, to put away, or put of. Abalieno, are, to separate, to put a
sonder. Alienus, na, nu^, diverse, unlike, not agreeable. Aliger, any thing that
has wings. Alimentum, alimonia, sustynaunce, fode, or living. Alioqui, or
else, except that. Aliorsum, to some other place. Alipedes, swyfte runnynge
horses. Aliptes, he that anoynteth a man, and a surgion that heals wounds.
Aliqua, by some place. Aliquando, sometime. Aliquantisper, a little while.
Aliquantum, aliquantulum, somewhat. Aliquatenus, in some part, by some reason.
Aliquid, some thing. Aliquis, some man. Aliquis est, He is a man of no small
estimation. Aliquo, to some place. Aliquorsum, toward some place. Aliquot,
some, nor many, nor few. Aliquoties, at sometimes. Aliter, or else, contrary
wise. Aliunde, from an other place. Alius, alia, aliud, other, or an other.
Allabor, labi, to flow by, sail by, or row by Allatus, brought. Allecto, aui,
are, to allure or draw to, by fayrenes, to allure. Allectus, allured. Allego,
lexi, gere, to ascrybe, to cheese, to assygne. Allego, aui, are, to send, to
allege, or bring forth, to depute, or give authority. Allegoria, a figure or
inuersion of words, where it is in words one, and an other in sentence or
meaning. Alleluya, praise ye our lord. Alleuo, aui, are, to lift up. Allex,
and allux, the greatte toe, when he lies over the next toe. Alliatum, a
sauce made with garlyke. Allicifacio, feci, re, to allure, to draw to.
Allicio, exi, licere, to allure. Allido, si, ere, to squatte or throw any thing
against the ground or walls. Alligo, aui, are, to bind to. Allium, garlyke.
Allophylos, a stranger. Alloquor, to speak to. Allubesco, to do it gladdely,
to obey, to favor, to consent. Allucinatio, a blyndenes of mind. Allucinor,
to be deceived in opinion, to fantasye. Alludo, allusi, alludere, to do a
thing in iape, to speak merrily, or consent. sometime it sygnifieth to speak
some thing, which secretly has some other understanding. Alludere ad
hystoriam, to speak or do some thing agreeable with sum history before
written. Alluo, lui, ere, to flow nigh to, to wash as the water does the
ground, when it flows over it. Allunium, a floode caused by rain, or by
ryuers when they rise. Alluuies is when abundance of water mixed with claye,
covers the ground. Almus, ma, mum, al thing that norysheth us, properly the
earth is so called, Alma tellus, because we have thereof our sustinance. Sometime
it signifies quiet, Almus dies, A quiet day. in Virgile. Alma, a virgin
hid, or secret. Alnus, an alder tree. Sometime it signifies a ship or
bote. Alo, alui, alere, to nouryshe or feed. A long, far of. Alopecia, a
syckenes of the heed, whereby the hears do fall of. Alps, the mountains,
which do depart now Italy and France. Altar, an altar. Alter, rius, teri,
an other, the other, one of the two. Alius, an other, the other. Alter, the
other, the second. Sometime it sygnifieth both. Vnus aut alter, one or both.
Vnus et alter, The one and the other. Alter, teris, sieve alteres, teris, poyses
of lead, made to lift up with both hands, to exercise men, which may not
otherwise labor: whereof there be now many in England, specially in the
chambres of stud^tes. Altercor, caris, to contend with words one with an
other on sundry parts. Alternatim, by turn, one at one time, an other at an
other time. Alternis, now one, now an other. Alternis diebus, sondrye days,
where one day is between. Alternare, to do things by turn, now one and than
an other. Alternatio, succession by turn. Altero, aui, are, to alter or
change. Alteruter, both the one and the other. also or the tone or the
the other. Althaea, the great malowes. Altilis, in plurali, altilia, all thing
that is franked to make fat, be it beast, fyshe, or foul. Altilis gallina,
a hen franked or fed Altisonus, he that makes noise from above, Altitonans,
he that thoundereth, which name the paynyms gave to their god Iupyter.
Altiuolans, all thing that flies high. Altrinsecus, to the tone or the the other,
Apuleius.
to the tone part, between the one and the other, in the higher part. Altus,
ta, tu^, high, deep, proprely in the sea. Vergilius.
it sygnifieth also excellent, glorious, ancient. Aluearium, et Alueare, a
place where hiues be set. also a stock of hyues. Alueolum, et alueolus, a
basket or mawnde, also a culuerhole, a chessebourde, or tables to play on.
Alueus et aluus, a hyue for bees, a vessaile to wash in, the bealy of any
thing that lacks life. sometime it signifies a ship. Aluini, they which
be much vexed with freattynges in the bealy. Alumen, alumme. Alumnari, to
nourse or bring up. Alumnus, a son or scolar that is brought up of a man, as
of his own father, either with sustinance, manners, or learning. Aluta, lether
properly tawed. sometime it is put for a bag or a pourse. Alutamen, any thing
made of lether. Alutarius, a tawyer. Aluus, the bealy. also a hyue.
A, ante M.
AMabilis, bile, amyable, worthy to be loved. Amabo, of fellowship, a good
fellowship, a familiar word used among friends. Amabundus, he that is a great
lover, or amorous. Amando, aui, are, to countremaunde. Amans, amanus, a lover
be it man or woman. Amante^, louyngely. Amanuensis, a clerk or secretarye,
always attendynge. Ama^acus, maioram. Amo, aui, are, to love heartily. Amaresco,
sci sce^e, to wax bitter, or to be bitter. Amaritudo, dinis, bytternesse.
Ama^^l^ntus, vexed with malice. Amasius et Amasia, he or she that louethe,
(...) loved. Ama^or, a lover, or he that is amorous. Amato^culus, a small or
simple lover. (...), like a lover. (...), a drink charmed, to make a (...).
(...), ria, rium, that which per^th to love. (...), a servant. (...), a
cyrcuite of words, or a tale ^wen in length. (...), sa sum, that abounds in
such form of speaking. Ambidexter, he that uses both hands like well.
Ambigo, to compass, also to doubt. Ambigue, doubtefully. Ambiguum, a doubt.
Ambio, iui, ne, to compass, to seek for promotion, to desire, to pray, or
entreat. Ambitio, nis, inordynate desire of honor or authority. Ambitiosus,
he that immoderately desires honor. Ambitus, ambitus, a cyrcute: also the
offense of ambition, made by the laws. Ambo, both. Ambrosia, was called of
the Paynyms the meat of goddis. Some do say, that it is an herb of the kind
of Mugworte. Ambulacrum, a private place to walk in, a walk or galerie.
Ambulatio, walkyng, and a walking place. Ambulator, a walker or styrer. Ambulo,
aui, are, to walk or stir about. Amburo, bussi, rere, to bourne all about.
Amens, mad. Amentum, a thonge, or that which is bounden to the mids of a
darte, or iauelyne, to cast it. Ames, amitis, a perch for a hawke. Ametor, he
that lacks his mother. Amice, frendely. Amicinum, a can or pot, wherout
they power wine. Amicio, ciui, cire, to clothe, to put on a garmente.
Amicitia, amity or frendshyppe. Amictus, cta, ctum, cladde. Amictus, ctus,
ctui, a garment or apparayle. Amicus er amica, a friend, a lover. Amicus, ca,
cum, joined to a thing, lacking life, signifies profitable, or wholesome. Amita,
my fathers sister, mine aunte. Amitini, cosyn germayns by brother and sister.
Amitto, misi, tere, to suffer to depart, to lose to send, to let pass, to
take fro. Amnis, a river, or brook. Amodo, from hensforthe. Amaeno, naui,
nare, to make merry, or glad. Amaenus, na, number, pleasant or dilectable. Locus
amaenus, A delectable place. Amaenum ingenium, a pleasant wit. Amaenitas,
tatis, pleasure, dilectablenesse, or myrthe. Amolior, I remove with great
pain. Admolior, I put to, or set upon a thing. Amor, love. Amoueo, moui,
mouere, to remove, to put from a place or a thing. Amphora, a measure, which
every way contains a foot it may be used for every pot that is carried
about. Amphorarius, he that bears the pot, a tankarde bearer. Amplector,
ti, to embrace. Amplio, aui, are, to make more, to draw to. Ampliatus, a man
repried, or delayed in judgment, upon some difficulty or consyderation.
Amplitudo, greatness of power or majesty, sometime it sygnifyeth largenes,
Terrae amplitudo, The largenes of the country Ampliuagus, much wandryng.
Amplius, more. Amplus, pla, plum, large, wide. Amplustra, Amplustria, uel
Aplustra, The takelynge of the ship. Ampulla, an oil pot. Also a bottelle
or flagon. sometime it signifies a thing that is blown or puffed. Suetonius
in Domitiano.
Suetonius uses that word for a drynkyng glass. Ampullor, I swelle for
pride. Amputo, taui, tare, to cut of. Amula, a water pot, and it may be used
for holy water pot. See Calepine. Amuletum, any thing that is ordained
against poysonynge. Amurca, the mother or some of all oils. Amussis, the
masons or carpenters rule. Amigdalus, an almonde tree. Amigdalum, an almonde.
A, ante N.
AN, whyther, or if. Anas, natis, a ducke. Anatinus, like a ducke. Anatarius,
ria, rium, of a ducke. Anathema, in holy Scripture betokens separation, else
where it signifies a thing offered or set up in a temple or church, as
things offered and hanged up. Anathematizo, aui, are, to curse or give to the
deuylle. Anatomia, anotomie or cuttyng of men by phisytions, to consider the
inward parts and members. Anceps ancipitis, doubteful. Anchora, an anchore.
Ancile, a shield without corners, such one in the time that Numa was king of
Rome, was seen fall out of the sky. Ancilla, a maiden servant it was proprely
taken for a bondewoman. Ancillor, to serve humbly and diligently. Anclo, aui,
are, to draw wine or other lykoure. Anfractus, windinges and turnynges,
specially in the ground. Angaria, a constraynt or compulsion. Angelus, an
aungelle. Angina, a disease in the throote, called the Quynse. Angiportus, a
great hole in the earth with many tournynges, or that which has none issue
out, or a lane in a town, which leads the next way to a street, or that
which lies on an haven, whereby marchandyse is carried from the water, or
recaryed. Ango, anxi, angere, to tourmente or vex. Angor, anguyshe of body or
mind. Anxieras, anxietudo, anguysshe or sorrow. Anguilla, an eele. Anguis, a
snake. Angularis, lare, cornerde. Angulatim, cornerwise. Angulosus, full of
corners. Angulus, a corner. Angustia, straytnes, or perplexity of mind.
Angustus, ta, tum, strayte. Anhelitus, brethe or wind of a man. Anhelo, aui,
re, to fetch wind, or draw breath. Anhelus, he that drawethe his breathe
peynefullye. Animaduerto, tere, to consider, to take heed, to set my mind,
to behold, and to think. Animaduersio, consyderacion, punishment.
Animaequius, maequia, quium, pacyente, or sufferynge. Animal, all thing that
has life, and is sensyble, commonly it is taken for a beast. Animalis, le,
that wherein is life. Animans, idem quod animal, saving that it is more larger.
For it may sygnyfye all thing that has spirit, as well in heaven, as on
earth. Anima, the soul. sometime life. Animatus, animata, matum, that has
soul or life. Animo, aui, are, to give courage or boldness, to quycken:
Animositas, boldness. Animosus, bold. Animus, the mind, the will. sometime it
is put for the soul: sometime for affection or delectation, sometime for wind
or blast, sometime for wrath, sometime for a sown. Annitor, to resyste, or to
help, to set to my mind. Annals, Histories of acts yearly done. Annalis,
le, Annarius, ria, rium, that which is done yearly. Annascor, to grow or to be
borne by a place or manne. Anniculus, la, lum, that which is of done year
old. Annilis, le, aged. Annilis fabula, an old wives tale, or a tale without
fruit. Annona, vyttayles, sustynance, or living. Sometime it betokens
fyndyng in board and apparayle. Annonariae expensae, expenses in vitayle.
Annosus, sa, sum, aged. Annoto, aui, are, to note, to entitle. Annotinae naues,
ships that carry corn. Annuatim, yearly. Annuus, a year. Annus, a, um, that
duryth one year. Anquina, the cord wherewith the sail is bound to the maste.
Anquiro, to seek. Ansa, the ear or handel of a pot or cup. And sometime it
sygnifieth occasion. sometime a bouckle. Anser, a goose. Anserinus, na, number,
like a goose. Antae, the poostes on every side of the door. Ante, antea,
before. Ante alios, above other, before other, more than other, or beside
other. Antecapio, coepi, capere, to prevent. Antecedo, cessi, dear, to go
before, to excel. Antecello, cellui, lere, to excel or have preemynence.
Antecessum, paid before hand. Anteccoenium, a colation or drinking between
dynar and supper. Anteeo, iui, ire, to precede or excel, or goo before.
Antefero, to put before, or set more by. Ante ha^, before this time, or
before that time. Ante^^quium, the first turn in speaking. Antelucanus, na,
number, that which is before (...) light. Anteluco iui, are, to wake before day.
Antelucuio, before day light. (...), the cross piece whereto the sail (...).
Antepagmentum, a portall. (...), ^ere, to prefer. (...), ^^nge before. (...),
outward pyllars or posts, whereby (...), or frame to sustained. (...), they
which be next the stan^ appointed for to defend it. (...), to excelle, or
stand before. (...), to make my judge. (...), neui, nite, to preuente. (...),
to prevent. (...), the bear of a woman, that is laid (...), foreheed, now
gentylwomen do (...) their rolls. (...), all (...) is before us. (...), to
preuente. (...), a book of medicines. (...), a medicine to expel poison.
(...), an example. Ann^^na, a pentiell. Antipa^^us, he that sercheth for
antyquities, or redethe old warkes, or uses old form of speaking or
writing. Antiquo, aui, are, to make void, to reduce to the first state, to
repelle. Antiquare legem, to repel a law. Antiquus, a, um, ancient or old.
sometime it signifies noble or worshypfull. Antiquitas, tatis, auncientie.
Antiquitus, of ancient or old time. Antistes, antistius, a prelate. Antisia,
an abbess or prioresse. Antistitium, prelacy, or preeminence. Antistitor, he
that has over other preemynence. Antila, a Pumpe to draw water. Antrum, a
den. Anularius, a ^eweller that sells rings. Anulus, a ring. Anus, nus,
an old wife. Anus, ni, an arse. Anxifer, he that causes sorrow. Anxius,
anxia, careful or heuye. Anxietas, anxietudo, care or heaviness.
A, ante P.
Apage, remove, put away, or drive away. Also it has a signification of a
more vehemence: as Apage hanccanicula^, Away with this bytche: or, hens away
with this bytche. Apage sis, let be, get the hens. Apella, without a
skin. So be the Jews called of Horacius, because they be cyrcuncyded. Aper,
apri, a boore. Aperio, ui, ire, to open, to disclose, to expownde. Apes uel
apis, a be. Apex, apicis, the crown of the heed, the top of every thing.
it sometime sygnifyeth a mytar. Apexabo, the gutte which is full of blood,
mixte with grease. Apluica, one of the three partis of the world whereof the
inhabitants be at this day called generallye Moors or Morynes, the countries
be now called Tunyse, Fese, Marocke. Apianus, na, number, that wherein bees do
delight. Apiarium, the place where as hyues be set. Apiarius, he that
nourishes bees. Apiastra, a bird which doothe deuowre Bees. Apiastrum,
smallage, an herb. Apicaeones, sheep, having small bodies, and little
wolle. Apicula, a young be. Apinae, nurtes without shales. Apionia mala,
round appulles, which I take to be they, that are called pomeroyall. Apium,
an herb called ache, sometime it is taken for our commune persely. Apologia, a
defense or answer to a rebuke. Apologo, aui, are, to require or ask.
Apologus, a fable, wherein beasts or trees do speak. Apophoretum, a present.
Apopthegma, matis, a short and quycke sentence. Apoplexia, a sodeyne palsy.
Apostata, a Rebelle. It is now used for them, which do forsake the relygion,
that they have ones received. Apostema, an impostume, wherein corrupted humors
have recourse in any part of the body. Apostolus, an apostel. it proprely
signifies a messanger. Apotheca, a wine seller, or shop, wherein things be
set to sale. Appareo, rui, rere, to appiere. Apparitores, officers of
justice, attendyng on the great ministers, to somon or attache whom they will
command. Apparitura, the office of a Sergeaunt or baylyffe. Apparatus, tus,
apparaylynge or deckyng. Apparatus belli, preparation for wars, artyllerye.
