Appellatio, a namynge, or appelynge to a higher judge. Appello, aui, are, to
name or call familiarly to me. Also Vlpian the great lawyer will have it to
sygnyfye, to wowe a maiden to have her virginity. sometime it sygnifieth to
arryue: Sommetyme to appeal to a higher judge. Appello, appuli, appulsum, to
aryue. sometime to apply or set my mind, to direct. Appulsus, appulsus,
coming of beastis to wateringe. Appendeo, appendis, pendere, to hang by or
nighe. Appendix, that which hangs at an other thing. Appendo, dis, dear, to
hang up, to way in a balance or beam. Appero, ui, tere, to desire much, to
go to. sometime it signifies to be at hand. Dies appatebat, The day was
come, or at hand. sometime to wound or stryke at, as, Leua^s se alis, os
oculosque hostis, rostro et unguibus appetit, Rysynge with his wings, his
talons and beke, he wounded the face and eyes of him that faught on the other
part. Applaudere, to move hands or feet for joy, or to beat any thing to
the ground. Applico, applicaui, applicare, uel applicui applicere, to join to,
to lay to, or set to, or to apply. Applodo, plosi, dear, supra applaudere.
Appluda, chafe. Apporto, aui, are, to bring to. Appositus, ta, tum, put to,
or set to. sometime it signifies convenient, or to the purpose. Apprime,
chiefly, principally. Approbus, very honest. Apricari, to sytre or go abroad
in the air, or in the son. Apricus, a place set against the son.
Aprilis, the month of Apryll. Aprinus, bores flesh. Aprono in genua, to knele
on my knees. Aptitudo, aptenes. Apto, aui are, to join, to agree two things
together. Aptus, ta, tum, apt, agreeable, mete, necessary. Apud, at, when it
is joined with a person, it signifies with.
A ante Q.
AQua, water. Aquagium, a cundyte. Aqualiculus, a little trowgh. Aqualicus,
the panche. Aqualis, A basyne to wasshe in men's hands. Aquaricola, a place,
wherein water is cast. Aquariolum, Aquarium, a wasshyng place. Aquaticus, that
which haunteth the water, or lives therein. Aquatilis, the same. Aquatus, ta,
tum, that, wherinto water is put. Vinum aquatum, Alayed wine. Aqueus, a, um,
watrye. Aquila, an egle. Aquilex, he that sercheth for water, or co^uayeth it.
Aquilifer, the standarde bearer of the Romans. Aquilo, the northest wind.
Aquilus color, russette. Aquiminaria, all water pottes. Aquitania, Guyen. Aquo,
aui, are, to fetch or bear water. Aquosus, sa, sum, full of water. Aquula,
little water.
A ante R.
ARa, an Aultare. Aranea, a copwebbe. Sommetyme a spyder. Araneus, a spyder.
Arator, a ploughmanne. and sommetyme a ploughe ox. Aratrum, a ploughe.
Arbiter, tri, an arbitratour. Arbitrarium, arbitrable. Arbitrium, arbytrement,
will, an espyall. Arbitror, to trow, to judge, or awarde. Arbor, et arbos, a
tree. Arborator, a lopper of trees. Arborescere, to wax to a tree. Arboreus,
ea, reum, of a tree. Arbustum, a place where trees be set, proprelye Elmes,
wythye, or Salowe, it may be taken for an orchard, or a hoppeyarde, or a
vyneyarde, where vynes do grow up by trees. Arbustum, a vine that runs up
in height by a tree or a pole. Arbusto, aui, are, to set vines by trees.
Arbutu^, an appull called a wyldinge. Arbutus, a wyldyng tree. Arca, a coffer.
Arcanum, a thing secret, or of few known. Arcatus, bent like a bow. Arceo,
cui, ^re, to strain, to put of, to drive away. Arcera, a horse lytter.
Arcesio, to accuse, to call for. Archa^^us, a steward of householde.
Archerypus, the first example or pattern. Atch^at^t^ti, a chief phisytion.
Archima^nus, chief Look. Architector, aris, ari, to make craftily. (...), the
counnyng of diuysyng of (...). (...), et architectus, a diuiser of buil^^^^, or
a master of the warkes. (...), master of the feast. (...), the treasone of
Minumentes (...) belonging to a king or a (...). (...), to strain
oftentimes. (...), ^um, straight. (...) ^a^^ened like a bow, (...), a
crossebowe. (...)* a little coffer or caskette. (...), a relle that womenne
do wear (...) beedes, to bear water or milk (...). (...) a bow, the rant
of a roufe. Ard^a, a by^^^e called an heron. Ardei^o, a b^sy manne medlynge
with many things. Ardeo, a^^, dear, to burn, to love ardently, or excedyngly*
to make haste, to be co^sum^d, to desire. Ardens, it is, hasty in doing, quycke
witted. Ardesco, to be hasty. Ardnus, high and difficult, hard to com to. Area,
a large place in a City kept ever clean, where merchants do assemble: as I
have seen in diverse cities in Almayne. Also it is every place marked out to
buyld or to set an house in. Also a floor, where corn is thrashed. Areator, a
thresher. Arefacio, to make dry. Arena, sand. Arenaceus, ea, eum, sandy.
Arenatus, arenata, natum, pargetted with lyme and sand. Arenosus, sandye.
Arenula, fine sand. Areo, rui, rere, to be made dry. Areola, a bed in a
garden. Aresco, scere, to wax dry, or to be made dry. Aretalogus, a bragger
or a vaunter of his own virtues, sometime a forger of lies, to make men merye.
Argentaria^ facit, he makes or occupies a bank for exchange. Argentarius, a
banker, with whom men do make their exchange of money. Argenteus, a, um, of
silver. Argentum, silver. sommetyme it sygnifyeth plate. Argilla, potters
claye. Argumentatio, the declaration of an argument. Argumentor, mentaris,
mentari, to argue or raison. Argumentosus, sa, um, that which is done with
great reason. Argumentum, is a raison, making a proof, whereby one thing is
gathered by an another, and the which confirms that, which is doubtefulle,
by that which is not doubtefull. sometime it signifies a mattier, sommetyme
coiecture, sometime a short exposition of that which follows, other while
sentence. Arguo, gui, ere, to reprove, to impute, to accuse, to show.
Argutiae, sharp words or shrewde. Argutor, aris, ari, to speak sharply,
shrewdly, or pertely. Argutulus, somewhat perte. Argutus, ta, tum, reproved.
sometime it sygnyfyeth shrewde, and he that can in speaking sharply inserche
a man's mind. Also shryll of voice. Arguti hommes, they that speak much in
few words. Argutum, s^lender or small. Ariditas, et aritudo, dryenesse.
Aridus, dry. Aries, arietis, a Ram. Also a piece of ordinance or engyne,
made like a rams heed, to beat down a wall. It is also oone of the.xii.
signs that the Sun passes by. Arietinus, of a ram. Arieto, taui, are, to
hytte or throw down. Arista, the berde of corn, sometime it is put for
wheat. Arithmetica, aulgoryme, the science of noumbrynge. Arma, orum, harneyes
and weapon. Also the instruments of all manner of crafts, Also standards and
baners, sommetyme battayles. Armamenta, tools, instruments, all store for
wars or ships. Armamentarium, an armorie or storehouse for ships or
ordinance. Armarium, a study where books are laid, or a dry larder. Armati,
armed men. Armatura, armure. Armator, an armorer. Armentarius, the keeper of the
armorie, Armentum, store of horse or nete. sometime it sygnifyeth cattle.
Armiger, geri, proprely an esquyer for the body, as he, which always
attendynge about a knight, bears his hedpiece, his spear, and his shield, a
custrell. Armillae, rings that gentylmenne used to wear about their arms,
as at this day some men and women do use, called bracelettes. Armille neutri
generis, a facyon of deceit. Armillum, a vessel wherein they vsid in their
sacrifice to put wine. Armipotens, puissant in arms. Armo, aui, are, to arm.
Armus, the shoulder of a beast, or the pynion of a foul. Aro, aui, are, to
ear or plowe land. Arquatus morbus, the syckenesse calledde the iaundise.
Arreptitius, he that is obsessed with an ylle spyrite. Arrha et Arrhabo, ernest
money. Arrigo, rigi, ere, to water ground. Aripio, pui, ere, to take. Arrogo,
aui, are, to give to much, to presume, to make mine heir. Arrogans, arrogant
or presumptuous. Arrogantia, arrogance, presumption. Ars, artis, a craft,
subtyltie. Arteria, a synewe like to a vain, wherein the spirit of life does
walk, as the blood does in veins. Articulatim, from ioynte to ioynte.
Articulo, aui, are, to join one ioynte to an another. Articulus, a joint. also
a moment or parcel of time. also a color of Rhetorike. Artifex, a crafts man.
Aruficium, the practice of a craft. Arto, aui, are, to strain, to thraste
together, to wrynge. Artocopus, a baker. Artoptitius panis, breadde made of
wheat, which to hard and soore dried, biskatte. Artuo, aui, are, to cut a
sonder. Artus, members. Aruina, talowe. Arundinetum, a place where reeds do
grow. Arundo, a read, or cane. Aruspex, he that tells of things to come by
lokynge in beasts bowelles. Aruum, a falowe field. Arx, arcis, a fortress or
castelle, specially standing high.
A ante S.
AS, assis, a pound weyghte. In the old time in the partition of land, or
other like thing inherytable, they called the hole, As, and the parts
divided, ounces. Asaronim, peynted pament, which may not be swepte. Ascendo,
di, ere, to clymme, to ascend, to goo up. Ascia, a chyppe axe. Ascio, aui, to
chyppe or cut with an axe. Ascio, is, to know surely. Ascisco, sciui, scire,
to presume, to take upon me a thing. Ascisco, ascisci, asciscere, to admytte,
to take to me. Ascribo, psi, bear, to add to, to attribute, to impute.
Asscriptitius, he that is added to the nombre of other. Assciptor, oris, he
that follows the example of an other, or he that writes many copies of others
exaumples. Asella, the arm hole. Asia, one of the three parts of the world.
Asinarius, an asseherde. Asinus, an ass. Asotus, prodigal, wanton,
incontynente. Aspecto, aspectaui, aspectare, to behold stedfastely. Aspectus,
sight, beholdynge. Asper, unpleasant, as well in sight and herynge, as in
taste, also hard or grievous. Aspergillus, a holy water stycke. Aspergo,
aspersi, gere, to spring or cast water. Aspergo, ginis, a spryngynge of
lycour. Aspernabilis, he that is worthy to be dispysed, or refused. Aspernor,
aris, ari, to despise, to refuse, to abhor. Aspero, asperaui, asperare, to
make sharper or hard. Asphaltum, the deed see. Also a certain claye there
founden, which ones burning, will never be quenched. Aspicio, aspexi,
aspicere, to behold, to see. Aspiro, aui, are, to aspire, to look to come to a
thing, to blow, to favor, to give aid, to give all my study and wit to
obtain a thing, to touch, to go to. Aspis, an adder or serpent. Aspo^to,
aui, are, to carry away. Assatu^a, roste meat. Assec^a, a page, and he that
follows in all thing the will of an other man. Assector, a^^s, ari, to keep
company. Assenso^, oris, he that consents. Assenno, ^i, ^^^e, and assentior,
to consent, or assente. Assentor, aris, to flatter in commendyng an other man's
acts that be ill. Assequor, eris, qui, to follow, to get, to obtain.
Asseres, bourdes. Asse^^^, ^is, to sow, or plant by. Also to claim, to
affirm or approve, to manumise or make free. Assettio, an affyrmaunce.
Assessor, oris, associate to a man in office or auctorytie. As^^^no, to keep
diligentely, to take heed of one. Asse^^^^, as, are, to affirm. (...), (...)
lytte with or by an other, or I am assocyate. (...), is, de^e, to rest me, to
sytte down, t^ sytte by. (...), centynuall, or sufficient. (...) fiderassores,
Sufficient sureties. Assigno, aui, are, to assygne or appoint. A^, ^e, to leap
forth also Assilire, is to leap, as a horse leapeth a mare. Assis, is, a sawen
bourde. Assino, (...), assis^ete, to be here, to defend a man's cause. Asso,
aui, are, to lay bourdes, to roste. Assue^ac^o, wont. Assuetudo, went, or
custom. Assuetus, accustomed. Assula, a chyppe. Assulatim, in chyppes. Assumo,
assumpsi, mere, to take proprely it sygnyfyeth to take to much on me. Assuo,
ui, assuere, to sow to, or piece. Assurgo, rexi, gere, to rise to an other
better than my self, to give place, to grow upward, Assus, a, um, roasted.
Ast, but. also therefore, as well, moreover. Aster, a Sterre. Asteriscus, a
little mark in writing like a Sterre, Asthmaticus, he that drawethe his
wind short. Astipulor, to lean to, to favor. Asto, astiti, to stand by, to
be present. Astragalizo, to play at dyse or tables. Astragalus, the play at
tables. Astringo, to join, or bind together, to bind by covenant or promise.
Astrolabium, an Astrolabe or instrumente of astronomy. Astronomia, the part of
astronomye that concerns judicials and practice. Astrologia, the speculation
and reasonyng concerning the celestial or heavenly motions. Astrum, a celestial
body compacte of many sterres, as a sign. Astruo, to build, to join oone
house to an other, to fortify, to affirm. Astus, craft or subtlety. Astu,
craftily, or subtylly. Asturiae, subtylties. Astutus, ta, tum, subtle or
crafty. Asylum, a saynctuarie.
A, ante T.
AT, a voice, which signifies in the words that do follow, wrath or
indignation. Sommetyme it signifies (but yet) which is a discrepaunce in the
words that are spoken. Sommetyme it sygnifyeth Sed. At contra, contrary wise.
Attamino, aui, are, to foul or defyle. At at, russhe, or sye. Attauus, a
greatte graundefather. Atar, tra, trum, black or dark. Athleta, a greatte
wrastler, or a great runner at commune games. Athletica, the craft of wrastlyng
or ru^nyng. Athletheta, the judge in games of wrestling or runnynge. Atomus, a
thing so small, that it may not be divided or made smaller. Also Atomi, be
motes of the son. Atque, and so, as it were. Atqui, surely, all be it. Atra
bilis, Melancoly. Attramentarium, an ynkehorne. Attramentum, ynke, blache, that
showmakers do occupy. Atratus, a mourner that gothe in black. Atri dies,
dysmall days. Atricus, a porter that keeps a gate. Atriensis, an huyssher of
the halle. Atrium, an inner court. Atrox, atrocis, cruel, terrible, or sour
in countenance. Attendo, di, dear, to take heed, to consider, to intend.
Attente, intentifely, with a fyxed mind. Attentio, a mind set or fyxed.
Attento, to attempt. Attenuo, to appeyre, to make weaker. Atticismus, a
peculyare eloquence used in Athenes. Atticisso, to speak like a man of
Athenes, Atticus, ca, cum, of Athenes. Attiguus, by or nigh ioynynge to.
Attineo, ui, ere, to pertayne. Attiner, it besemeth, it is conuement. Attingo,
attigi, tingere, to touch almost. Attollo, to auaunce, to lift up, to bring
to, to take away. Attonitus, ra, tum, amassed or abashed. Attrecto, aui, are, to
feel. Attribuo, bui, ere, to attribute, to put upon one by blaming or
accusynge, to assygne, to commytte.
A ante V.
AVceps, a fowler or byrder. Auctio, onis, an increase, or an open sale of
private goods. Auctio hastae, portesale of the goods of men attaynted for
treason or felonye. Auctionarius, the salesman. Auctionor, to sell by port
sale. Aucto, aui, are, to gain, to win. Author, he that begins any act, or
is the first causer or procurer of any thing. Autoramentum, an indenture or
obligation whereby a man is bounden to do service. Also ernest money. Autorare,
to bind by erneste or writing to serve. Autoratus, he that is bound to
serve, specially in wars. Autoritas, tatis, authority. sometime it signifies
power. Auctuarium, uel auctarium, over measure or weyghte. Aucupatorii, lyme
twigs. Aucupium, et aucupatio, byrding or fouling. Aucupor, to go a byrdynge,
or a foulyng, or hawkynge. Also it signifies, to search by craftye means.
Audacia, hardynesse. Audacter et audaciter, boldly, adue^turously. Audaculus,
hardye, spoken in derisyon, or contempt. Audax, audacis, bold or hardy, or
trustyng well in him self. Audeo, ausi, audere, to dare, to presume. Audio,
diui, dire, to bear, to consider, to perceyne, to grant that which is asked,
to do the thing that is commanded. Auditio, herynge, or audience. Auditorium,
a place where men do here lessons, or propositions. Auditus, tus, heryng, one
of the flue wits. Auelio, to carye away. Auellana, a fylberde nutte. Auena,
otes. Sometime it is put for an ote straw, or a wheat straw, or reed. Aueo,
uere, to couaite. Aue, be thou glad or joyful, as the vulgar people says,
Rest you merry. Auersor, aris, to abhor, to refuse. Auersus, backewarde, or
on the backehalf. also angrye. Aduersus et anersus, forward and backewarde.
Auerto, ti, tere, to turn away. Auertor, teris, ti, to disdain. sommetyme it
signifies to turn away, to turn fro. Auerunco, aui, are, to turn away,
or put away. Aufugio, gi, ere, to flee hense. Augeo, auxi, gere, to
increase. Auctus, ta, tum, increased. Augesco, sci, scere, to wax greatte, or
be great, to be grown. Augmento, mentaui, me^tare, to increase, or make more.
Augur, auguris, he that tellethe by birds voices, or by their flyeng or
sytting, what shall happen. Auguro, as et auguror, aris, rari, to tell by
such craft, what shall happen. Augusins, noble, or full of majesty, wherefore
the emperors of Rome were and yet be called Augusti. Augustus is also the
month next after July. Auia, a grandame. Auiarium, a thycke wodde without
way. Also a place where birds be kept and nourysshed. Auiarius, a keeper of
birds. Auicula, a little bird. Auidus, a, um, couetyse. Auis, a bird.
Auitus, ta, tum, that which is left by auncetours. Auitus ager, Old
inheritance. Auius, a, um, without way. Aula, a haule. sometime the palaice or
court of a prince. Aulea, tapesry, hangynges of noble men's houses. Auoco,
caui, care, to call away. Auolo, aui, are, to flee away. Aura, sometime
betokens a soft wynd, sometime brightness, sometime favor. Auramentum,
gyltynge. Auraria, a gold mine. Aurarii, gylters. Auratus, ta, tum, gylte.
Aureae, the hedstall of a horse. Auris, an ear. Aureus, a piece of gold in
money. Aureus, a, um, of gold. Aurichalcum, latin metal. Auricomus, be that
has hear as bryghte as gold. Auricula, the care lap. Auricularius, a
secretarye or priuye counselor. Auriferum, that bears gold. Aurifex,
ficis, a gold smyth. Aurificina, a gold smythes shop. Aurifin, a thief that
steals gold. Auriga, a carter or driuer of a cart. Aurigor, aris, to drive a
cart or some thing like. Also to govern. Auri^calpium, an ear pyker. Auritus,
great eared. Auro, aui, are, to gylte. Aurora, the morning, or son risynge.
Aurum, gold. Aus^ulto. aui, are, to bear diligently, or give good care.
Auspex. auspicis. idem quod augur. Also it signifies the person that makes
the marriage on the man's part. Also the chief capytayne in wars.
Ausp^^^im, the sign or token showed by ^yrdes of things that shall follow.
Also if betokens fortune governance, or disposition of a capytayn. Also it is
a token or signification of things to come. Ausp^^o^, a^is, cari, to take
lykelyhode. Also to begin or enter into a business. Aus^er, in, the southe
wind. Austerus, sour or sharp. Also soore or without pity. Autho, aui, are,
to make moist. A^^, or, either. Autem, verily, but, or else. Autograplium, his
own hand writing. Autumo, to suppose, to affirm. Autumnus, harvest.
Auunculus, the uncle of the mothers side. Auus, the grandfather. Auxihor, aris,
ari, to aid or help. Auxiliarius, he that commethe in aid of an another.
Auxilium, aid, or help,
A, ante X.
AXis mundi, is a line imagined to go straight from the north to the south,
dyuydynge the world as it were in two parts: at the ends are supposed to be
two points in heaven, which are called the north pole and the southe pole.
Axungia, swynes grease.
B, ante A.
BAcca, a berye, as a baye bery, an hawe berye, an eglantine berie. Baccatus,
garnysshed with precious stones. Bacchanal, lis, the place where the solemnity
of Bacchus was kept. Bacchanalia, feasts of the paynyms, which they did
celebrate with all abominations of lechery. Bacchar, a wine port. It may be
called a quaxinge pot. Bacchor, aris, ari, to celebrate the feast of
Bacchus, to run up and down like a mad man. Bacchus, among the Paynims
the god of wine or drunkenness. Baculus, a staff. Balius, a horse of bay
color. Baiae, arum, a place in the royalme of Naples, where be naturalle
bathes of warm water both pleasant and wholesome: And by translation some poets
do so call all other natural hot bathes. Baiulo, aui, are, to bear. Baiulus,
a porter or cariar of bourdens. Balaena, a greatte fish, which I suppose to
be a thurlepoll. Balanus a kind of acornes. it is also a suppositorie to help
them that be costife. Also a sweet oyntme^t made of Mirabolanes. Balo, aui,
are, to blete like a sheep. Balbucinor, aris, to mastle in the mouth. Balbus,
he that can not pronounce well his words when he speaks. Balburio, iui, ire,
to stamer or stutte. Balinea, a bayne or a bathe. Balius, balia, liu^, baye
color. Balista, a crossebowe, or a brake. It may be used for a gunne.
Balnearia, all things belongyng to a bain. Balnearius, of a bayne,
Balueatorius. Balneator, the keeper of a bayne, or he that serves in a bayne.
Balneum, a private bayne. Balnea pluraliter, a commune bayne. Baltheus et
baltheu^, a belt, a sword girdel. Bambatium, cotton. Baptisterium, a bathe or
vessel to wasshe in the body. A dienge vate, a font. Barathrum, a
unmeasurable depenes. Baratro, an unthrift that in lechery and glottony
deuoureth his substance. Barba, a berde. Barbari, in the old time were all
people, except greeks. proprely it be they, which do speak grossly, without
observing of congruite, or pronounce not perfectly, specially Greek or latyne.
Also they that abhor all elegancie. Moreover it signifies them, which be
without letters, fires or cruelle of manners or countenance, barbarouse.
Barbaria, the countreye where dwellythe people rude or beastly. Barbaricarii,
weauers of cloth of baudekin. Barbaricus, barbarous. Barbarismus, the corrupt
form of speaking or pronouncynge. Barbatus, ta, tum, berded. Barbitium, the
berde. Barbitos, an instrument of musyke, which I suppose is that, that men
call doulsimers. Bardiacus, a garment. Bardocucullum, a thrummed hatte, or a
shepardes cloak. Bardus, a fool. Sometime a mynstrel that syngeth iestes or
fables. Barrire, to braye like an olyphant. Barritus, the brayinge of an
oliphant. Barrus, an olyphaunt. Basia, honest kysses, sweet kysses. Basiator, a
kysser. Basiatio, a kissing. Basilica, a place where people do assemble for
suites in the law, and civil iugementis be exercised, and counsayles holden.
Also it may be taken for a halle, or other large place, where suitors do
attend, or men do wait on rulers, or great feasts be kept. It also
sygnifyeth a cathedral church. Plaut. in Epi.
Basilica nux, a wall nutte. Basilicon, a kings robe. Basilicus, ca, cum,
royal. Basilice, royally. Basilicanus, he that keeps the place called
Basilica. Basiliscus, a Cocatrice, which is a serpent in the deserts of
Aphrica, with a white cyrkle about his heed, having a sharp heed, red eyes, and is somewhat black of color, and is so venymous, that he sleeth men
and beasts with his breath, and with the sight of his eyes. Basis, the foot of
a pylar, or that which susteyneth any like thing. Also it signifies the
foundation or ground of a matter. Batris, a vessel with a long handell.
Batillus, a sire pan. Battiola, a wine pot or flagone. Batuo, i, ere, to
beat with a rod. Batus, a measure for wine or oil. Baubare, to bark like a
dog. Baxiae, slyppers, proprely of philosophers, or such other. Beatus, is
he, which has abundaunce of all thing that is good, and is perfect in all
things that be worthy praise, or ought to be desired of a good man. sometime
it is taken for noble or fortunate. Beatitudo et beatitas, is a heap of good
things gathered together, of it self sufficient without lack, and a very
perfection according to virtue. Bellaria, bankettynge dysshes, as tartes,
marchepaynes, and other like. Bellarius, ia, um, apt for the war. Bellator,
a warryour. Bellatrix, a woman warrior. Bellatulus, bellatula, a wanton word,
which is as much to say, as little fair one, well favored child, praty
maiden. Bellax, acis, used or haunted in wars. Bellicosus, fires or warlyke.
Bellipotens, puissant in battle. Bello, and Bellor, aris, ari, to make war.
Bellus, la, lum, fair, pleasant, good. Bellulus, la, lum, somewhat fair.
Bellum, signifies all the time that the wars do continue. also battle or
war. Bellua, a great cruel beast or a monster. Beluata, tapesry, wherein is
wrought or painted the fygures of beasts. Beluinus, na, number, beastely. Beluina
rabies, A beastly furye. Been, well, honestly, or prosperously. Been de te
mereo, I entreat the well, Thou art beholden unto me. Benedico, dixi, cere, to
praise, to say well of a man. Benedicus, a man well tunged, or fair spoken
Beneficiarius, he that receives a benefitte or good turn of an other.
Beneficus, he that is beneficial or lyberall. Been uertere, to turn to good.
Precor deu^, ut haec res been uertat tibi, I pray god this thing may turn
the to good, or may be for thy profit. Been uolo tibi, I would the good.
Beneuolus, favorable. Beneuolentia, favor or good will, an intent to do
well. Benignus, na, number, gentylle, benygne, and bounteouse. Benignitas,
bounteousenes. Beo, aui, are, to comfort, to make happy. Berillus, is that
which is commonly called Crystalle. Bes, bessis, a weight of.viii. ounces.
Bestia, a beast. Bestiarii, men which in old time faughte with beasts in
the syghte of the people. Beto, to walk forth. Varro.
Bibaculus, he that drinks often. Bibax, cis, bibosus, a great drynker.
Biblia, the wife of Duilius the Romayne, which was of so great chastity,
that she was at that time an example, when it was a thing monstrous to here of
unchastity. Bibliopola, a stacyoner, or a book sellar. Bibliotheca, a lybrary.
Bibo, bibi, bear, to drink. Bibulus, la, lum, that souketh up shortly. Biceps,
bicipitis, that which has.ii. heedes Biclinium, a chamber with.ii. beds.
Bicornium, that which has two horns. Bicorpus, that which has two bodies.
Bidental, a place where they used to sacryfyce sheep, when any house was
bourned with lyghtnynge. Bidentes, sheep with.ii. teth, called in some place
hogrelles, or hogattes. Biduum the space of two days. Biennis, bienne, any
thing of two years old. Biennium, the space of two years. Bi^a^^am, in two
parts, or two manner of ways. Bi^^^ie, the same. (...) arbor, that bears
twyse in a year. (...), clefte. (...), that has two doors. (...), he that
has two foreheedes. (...), a double thief, or he that has stol^^^ (...).
^^^^^^atus, ta, tum, double forked. (...), a carte drawn with two horses.
(...), he that has badde two wives. (...), beasts commen of two sundry
kinds. (...), cattaylle or beasts yoked two together. (...), a beam with two
balances. (...), a town in Spain. Bi^^^^^s, waying two pounds. Bilinguis,
double tunged. Bilis atra, the humor of Melancoly, proprely that which
brings a man to fransy or madness. Biliosus, he that has abundaunce of that
humor. Bimaritus, he that has had two wives. Bimembris, of two parts,
having two members. Bimestris, two months old, or two year, accounted of the
moon. Bimulus, of two years age. Bimus, of two years. Binus, na, number, two,
idem quod duo. Binae litterae, two letters. Bini tabellarii, two messangers,
bina iuga boum, two yoke of oxen Binarius numerus, the number of two. Binominus
et binominis, he that has two names. Bion, the name of a philosopher.
Biothenatus, he that is violently slain. Bipalium, a spade to dygge with.
Bipara, she that has had two byrthes. Bipatens, open on both sides. Bipennis,
having two wings. Also a twyebyll, wherewith carpenters do make their
mortaises. Bipertior, iris, tiri, to diuyde in two parts. Bipes, pedis,
having two fete. Bipedalis, et Bipedaneus, two foot long or broad. Biremes,
ships with two tops. Bis, twyse. Bisaltae, a people in Scythia. Bisellium,
a seat or form, whereon two men only may sytte. Bisextus, one day added to,
in four years. Bisextilis annus, the leap year. Bison, it is, a beeste having
oone horn, and a very long mane. Bistonis, a city, and also a great meare
or poole in the country of Thrace. Bisulcus, ca, cum, cloven footed. Bythynia,
a royalme in Asia, which now the turk has. Bithynium, a city in Bithynia.
Bitumen, a kind of natural lyme, whereof the old walls of the City of
Babylon were made. Biuium, a way having two paths. Bizen, a city of Thracia,
Plin, li. 4,
of Plynie called Bizian.
B ante L.
BLesus, he that stamereth, omittynge some letters in speaking. Blandicus, he
that flattereth. Blandidicus, a fair speaker, or flatterer. Blandior, iris,
iri, to flatter, to speak fair for advantage. Blanditiae, flattering, fair
speech. Blasphemia, cursynge, reprochynge, commonly blasphemy, which is now
only referred to the despite of god. Blasphemo, aui, are, to curse, to
reproach, to speak in the derogation or despyte of an another. Blatero, aui,
are, to babble in vain, and from the purpose. Blatta, is proprely the long
fly that flies in the leame of a candell, and is of the kind of mothes. It
is also a silk worm: and blatteus, being an adjective, is purple color.
Vestis blattea, a purple garment. Blattaria, an herb, also called Verbascon.
Blax, soft, delicate, wanton, that can not decerne things, and which vaynely
bosteth him self. Blepharo, onis, he that has great brows. Bleprae, a people
in Aphrike, which have their visages in their breasts. Blittus, an herb
being of the kind of betes, having no sent, Blittea meretrix, an unsavory
queen.
B ante O.
BOa, a serpent in Italy, so greatte and large, that on a time when one was
kylde, there was a child all hoole found in his bealy, Plin. lib. 8. capi. 14.
as Pliny writes. Boarium forum, the markette place, where oxen be sold.
Bocchyris, a man's name. Bodellium, a kind of sweet smelling gum. Boemia,
the royalme of Boeme. Boeotia, a country in Greece, wherein was the city of
Thebes. Baetis, a river in Spain by the country of Granado. Boiae, gyues or
fetters. Boii, people of Germany. Boletus, a musherom. Bolis, idis, a darte
with wild fire. Bolus, a mass or lump of metal, or other like thing.
Bombitatio, the noise that bees make. Bombus, a great sown or noise, as it
were of a trumpe, or gunne, a bownce. Bombycinus, na, number, of sylke, Bombycina
uestis, A garment of sylke. Bombix, icis, a sylke worm. Bonae fidei possessor,
a feffee of trust. Bonaria, calmenes of the sea. Bona nenia, By your license,
No displeasure to you. Boni consulas, take it in good part. Bonitas,
goodness, honesty and justice. Bonum, good, which is contrary to ill. Bonus,
a good man: Also beneuolent, peasyble, lyberall, plain, easy to speak to,
worshypfull, treatable, merciful. Boo, oas, are, to below like a cow.
Boots, a sterre which follows Charles wayne. Boreas, the northesterne wynd.
Boreus polus, the north sterre, called the lode sterre. Boristhenes, a great
river in the countreye of Scythia. Borith, a herb that fullers use. Bos,
bouis, a rother beast, be it bulle, ox, or Cow. Bosphorus, the name of a
part of the sea, which lies in two sundry costs: one by Constantinople, the
other more north. Bostar, an ox house. Bostrychites, a precious stone like to
womennes hear. Botrys, a cluster of grapes. Botrytes, a precious stone like to
a black graape. Botulus, a puddinge made of the inward of a rother beast.
Bouatim, like an ox. Bouicida, a sla^ter man. Bouile, an ox stalle. Bouillae,
larum, a town not far from Rome. Bouinator, he that with great noise cries out
on a another man. Bouinor, aris, to below out like a cow.
B ante R.
BRabenta, he that is ordained a judge in any game of wrastlynge, runnynge, or
leaping. Bracca, that kind of mantell, which now comes out of Irelande, or
a long garment made of rough frise. Braccharii, the makers of such clothe.
Brachiale, the wrestebone of the hand. Brachialia, bracelettes, which some
gentylmen and gentle women do use about their arms. Brachiatus, that which
like an arm holds any thing up, a proppe, or shore. Brachium, an arm.
Brachylogia, shortenes of speech. Bracmanae, philosophers of Inde. Bractea,
thynne plates of mettalle, horn, or wodde. Bractearius, a worker of plates.
Bracteator, the same. Bracteola, leaves of gold or silver. Bragada, a river
nere to Vtica. Branchiae, the gylles of a fyshe. Branchos, the rewme or
cattarre, which falls down by the chekes. Brassica, Colewortes, proprely
Cabeges. Brauium, the reward for wrastlynge, runnynge, or leaping, commonly
called the chief game. Breno, a captain or leader of the frenchemen called
Galli, which, builded Verona a city of Venece. Brephotrophia, an hospitalle,
where children be kept and nouryshed. Brene, Shortly, et breuirer, et breui.
Breuiloquus, he that speaks his mind a few words. Breuiloquium, a short
form of speaking Breuiloquentia, the same. Breuitas, shortenesse. Breuis
breue, Short. Breuiarium, a brigement. Briarcus, a giant, which was of an
exceeding greatness. Britannia, Brytayne, which does contein England,
Scotland, and wales. Britannus, et Brito, a man of that country. Bronchus,
the inner part of the throat, Bronchi, they which have their mouth and tethe
standing far out, tut mouthed. Bruchus, a fly, which eats corn, as it
grows. Bruma, winter. Brundusiu^, a city in the royalme of Naples. Bruseum,
an herbour or hedge made with thorns and briers wound together. Brutii,
people in the royalme of Naples, ioynynge to Sycile. Brutus, dull and gross
witted like to a be. Brionia, an herb called with wind, Brisso, aui, are,
to bruise out.
B ante V.
BVbalus, a beast called a bugill. Bubastis, a city of Aegipte. Bubo, a
shriche oule. also a botche. Bubsequa, a coweherde. Bubulcito, tas, to play
the herdeman. Bubulcus, a herd man. Bubile, an ox house. Babulus, la, lum,
that which longs to an ox or cow, as Lac bubalum, cow milk. Bucardia, a
stone like to a bugles heart. Bucca, the holownes of the cheke. Buccea, a
morsel. Buccella, the same. Buccellatum, breadde called byskat. Buccina, a
trumpette. Buccino, aui, are, to blow a trumpette. Buccinum, the sown of a
trumpette. Buccones, they which have great chekes. Bucculenti, idem. Buccula,
a little cheke. Also that part of a helmet, whereby wind is taken.
Bucentarius, a great ship or carrike. Bucentes, styngynge gnattes. Bucentrum,
a goodde prycke. Bucephalus, an ox heed. and the horse of Alexander the great
was so called. Bucera armenta, herdes of nete, Bucolica, the same. Bucula, a
heckfar. Buculus, a bullock, or steer. Bufo, onis, a tode. Buglossa, an herb
called langedebefe. Also a fyshe called a sole. Bugones, bees. Bulbito, aui,
are, to cast durte on one: proprely it is of children, which nourysses do
name cackynge. Bulbus, wyld garlyke having a leaf like to a lylly. it is
taken generally for all rotes that be round. Bulga, a male of lether, wherein
clothes be carried. Bulimia, great famyne or hunger. Bulis, a name of a city.
Bulla, a tablette or other thing hanged about ones neck, proprely when it is
holowe. A bobell of water, sometime the heed of a nail, otherwhyles studdes in
girdels or other things. Bullatus, he that is garnyshed with tablettes or
studdes. Bullio, iui, ire, to boil, or sethe. Bullare, to bubble, as water
when it boyleth. Bumastos, a great teate. Bumelia, a kind of ash. Bupina,
great thirst. Bupodes, great feet. Bura, or Buris, the hinder part of a
plough which is crooked. Burcana, an i will in the occean of Germany. Burdo, onis,
a mulette. Burgundia, Burgoyne. Busyris, a tyrant, which was king of
Aegypte. Bustum, a place where dead bodies have been burnt. Buteo, a kind of
hawks, which has three stoones. Buthysia, was called a great sacrifice,
such as Hecatombe is. Butyrum, butter. Buxentum, a town that the greeks call
Pyxunta. Buxeta, a place where box trees grow. Buxus, or Bussus, box tree.
B ante Y.
BYrsa, a hyde of a beast. Byssus, fine sylke. Byzantium, a city of Thrace
now called Constantinople, which was sometime builded by a king of Spartane,
called Pausania, whereof the people and inhabitants were called Byzanta^.
Afterward it was augmented by Constantine the emperor. and was the chief and
heed of all the empire oriental. Byzari, fantastical men, and of strange
inventions. Byrseus, a tanner, or cordynar. Byssus, a manner of fine flax or
lynnen. I suppose it to be cotton.
C ANTE A.
CABALLI, people of Asia. Caball^s, an horse, yet in some parts of England,
they do call an horse a cable. Cabyle, a cite in Thracia Cabytin, a city of
the lower Asia, all though Cabytli, be people in India. Cacabus, a pot or
cauldron, wherein meat is sodden. Cacus, a giant, whom Hercules did slay.
Cacabo, as, are, to call like a pertryche. Cacodaemon, an ill spirit.
Cachinnus, a scorn, or a loud lawghter in derysyon. Cachinnor, aris, ari, to
laugh immoderately and with a loud voice. Caco, cacaui, care, to shyte.
Cacaturio, idem. Cacoethes genesis neut, an ill manner. Cacosyntheton, an ill or
defourmed composytion. Cacula, a page. Cacumen, the top of a hylle. Cado,
cecidi, cadere, to fall, to dye. Cadere to happen. Cadere causa, to be
nonsuite in an action. Cadere formula, idem. Cadauer, eris, a dead body, or
carrayn. Caducus, ca, cum, falling, decayinge. Caducus morbus, the falling
evil. Caducarii, men having the falling evil. Caducor, ceris, duci, to be
overthrown. Cadulae guttae, drypyng of roasted meat. Cadiuus, ua, uum, that
which falls by it self, as Cadiua folla, leaves fallyn down by them self.
Cadiua poma, appulles fallen from the tree. Cadus, a wine vessel, it may be
taken for a pipe. Caduceus, et Caduceum, a rod, which poets supposid that
Mercury bare in his hand, as messanger of Jupiter. Caduceato^, an ambassatour
or Herault sent for peace, or to take a truse. Cadurcum, a keuerlede of lynnen,
most proprely a quilte. Cadiscus, a vessel wherein lottes for election or
consent of a multitude be put. Cadinus, the name of a Prince, which browghte
out of Phaenicia into Greece syxetene letters, and was the first that wrate
in proof, and found out the fusynge and casting of mettalles. Caecias, the
east northest wind. Caecus, ca, cum, blind, also dark. Caeci morbi,
syckenesses which be not apparent* the causes whereof, be hid from physicians.
Caecilia, a sloworme that is blind. Caecutio, tiui, tire, to se but little,
to be half blind. Caeculto, aui, are, to have a tymme sight. Caeco, caui, are,
to make blind* Caede^, death, slaughter or murder. Caedo, dis, caecidi,
cedere, to beat, or whyp* to cut, to stryke, to kylle, to me^ke. Caedere
ianuam saxis, to break the door with stoones. Cedo, to depart, to give
place, to obey. Cedere bonis, to leave the goods. Cedere iuri, to give over a
right or title. Cede manum, give me thy hand. Cedere, to succeed. Cedo, say,
Cedo cuium puerum, Tell or say, whose child or servant. Cedo, give, Quin tu
mihi argentum cedo, But yet give thou me thy money. Caedua sylua, woddes used
to be cut, Copeyses. Caesim, edgelinge. Also at one cut or choppe. Caelum,
heaven or the firmament. also a granynge iron. Coelestis, caeleste, heavenly, or
of heaven. Caelicus, ca, cum, idem. Caelitis, heavenly. Caelitus, heavenly
creatures. Caelicola, he that inhabiteth heaven. Caelebs, a syngle man or woman.
Also every chaste person. Caelibatus, a single life without marriage. Celsus,
a, um, high. Celius mons, a mountain in Rome. Caelo, aui, are, to grave in
metal. Caementu^, mortar, or any other gross matter, wherewith walls be
made. Caemen^arii, daubers, pargetters, rowghe masons, which do make only
walls. Caementitius, a, um, of mortar. Caene, a city. Caepe, an oynyon.
Caepula, a chybboll. Caepi, the preter perfect tense of Capio, I have taken.
Caeruleus, a blewe color. Caera, wax. Also Caere were writynge tables covered
with wax. Caero, aui, are, to lay wax on any thing. Caeratura, the waxinge.
Caereus, caerea, caereum, of wax. Also fat or tydye. Caeratum, a seared
clothe. Caerefolium, an herb called cheruyll. Caerrus, a taper, or wax
candell. Caereolus, a size candell. Caerulus, la, lum, et Caeruleus, lea, leu^,
blewe of color. Caerosus, a, um, that which is myxte with wax. Caerium, a
soore, which is like to a honye comb. Caeroma, an ointment made with oil and
netes dunge, wherewith men that wrastlyd used to anoynte their bodies. Also it
sygnifyeth the place where wrastlers were anointed. Caerete, an ancient city
in Tuskay. Caerinthe, three leaued grass, which brings forth white honey
suckles, called clyuer grass. Caesar, the emperor. Caesarea, a city in the
country of Palestina. Caesaraugustana, a city in the realm of Arragon.
Caesareus, ea, eum, pertaining to the emperor. Caesaries, hear, or a bushe
of hear. Caesenna, a city in Italy. Caesa, a waipon, sometime used in France.
it is also a part of an oration, not concludynge a sentence: as it were a
pyece of a sentence. Caesura, a piece as it were cut of from the remenaunt,
proprely of a verse. Caes^^um, an instrumente, wherewith iuorye ^^e bored. Also
a weapon like a dagger. Caesirium, a sheet. Caesius, gray of color or
blunket. Also he which has gray eyes. Caesones, they which be cut out of
the mothers or dames belyes. Caespes, cespiris, a turfe. Caespititius, a, um,
made of turfes. Caespito, taui, tare, to stumble. Caestus, tus, a weapon having
great plummates hangyng at the end of a clubbe. Caesius, caesti, a gyrdell or
corse, which the husband did put about his wife, when he was married, and
at night did pluck it of. Caeter, caetera, caeterum, the remenaunt or
resydewe. Caeterum, et caetera, be aduerbes sygnyfyenge, sometime moreover,
sometime from hensforthe, sometime Caeterum, is a conjunction, and signifies
sed, but. Caycus, the name of a river in Phrigia. Cain, in hebrewe signifies
envy. Caius, a propre name of a man. Cala, a byllette. Calabra, a convocation
place, where matters concerning devotion were treated. Calabria, a country
ioynynge to Naples. Calaber, bra, brum, of Calaber. Caladrius, a bird. Calae,
arum, a city in India. Calagurium, a town in Biskay. Calamintha, an herb
called calame^t or nep. Calanus, a philosopher of Inde, which in the presence
of the great Alexander, being of the age of.lxxiii. years, feeling him self
sick, made a bonefyre, and went into the top thereof, and bourned him self.
Calaris, a city in Sardin^. Calamus, a read, or wheat straw, Also a pen.
It is also taken for a pype, or whystell. Also a fyshynge rod, and a twigge,
whereon bird lyme is put. Also small branches of trees, also it is a pole to
mete with, containing six cubytes and a spanne, a met polle. Calamarium, a
pennar. Calamitas, generalle dystruction, or myserye. Calamitosus, miserable or
full of adversity. Calamistrum, a pynne of wodde or iuorye, wherewith men and
women do set or trim up their hear. Calantica, attire or burlette for a
woman. Calones, boys and knaves, which do follow hosts, and do either carye
the weapons of soldiers, or serve them of wode or water. Calathis, the name
of a city. Calathus, a baskette or hamper. Calx, hic, calcis, the heel. it
sometime signifies the end of a matter. sommetyme a stroke with the heel.
Calx, haec, lyme made of burned stones. Calcatus, cata, catum, pergetted or
white lymed. Calcaria fornax, a lyme pytte. Calcarius, a lyme burner.
Calcaneus, et calcaneum, the heel. Calceus, a show. Calcearium, a showmakers
shop. Calceolarius, a showmaker. Calceo, aui, are, to put on shoen.
Calceamen, et calciamentum, a show, pynson, or socke. Calcar, a spur.
Calcitro, aui, are, to kycke or wynse. Calcitro, tronis, a horse that does
flynge or kycke. Calcitrosus, a, um, that oftentimes flyngeth or kycketh.
Calculus, a peble stone. Also the stoone in the body. Also a chesse man. also
account. also the least weight or poyse that may be. Moreover a knyfe made of a
stone. Calculosus, he that is much diseased with the stone. Calculosus locus,
a stonye place. Calculo, aui, are, to cast account. Calco, aui, are, to
tread or press down. Caliga, a hose, or leg harnaysse. Caligatus, hosed.
Caligo, ginis, darkness. Caliginosus, dark. Caligo, aui, are, to make dark,
or be dark. Calor, er caliditas, heat, Caldor idem. Caleo, calui, calere, to
be hot or warm. Calesco, to wax hot. Calefacio, to make hot. Calefio, I
am made hot. Calidus, da, dum, hot. Calorificus, ca, cum, that which
makethe hot or warm. Callus, brawn, or hardness of the fete made with goinge.
Callidus, slye, or craftye. Calliditas, slyenesse. Calleo, ui, ere, to be hard
as drawn. Also to know perfectly. Calendae, the first day of every monthe.
Callis, a way much used. Callimachus, the name of a poet. Calisthenes, the
name of a philosopher. Cales, a town in France. Calistho, the mother of
Archias, which gave the name to the countreye of Archadia, whom poets fained
to be transformed into a bear. Calypsos, the name of an isle, also of a woman,
which received Ulysses when he escapyd drownynge. Calyptra, a woman's cappe
or bonette. Calliope, oone of the vyrgines, which be named Musae. Calix, a
cup to drink wine in. Also a pot, wherein potage is sodden. Calyx, the
paring or skin of an apple, or other like fruit. Also a keueryng made of
clay. Also that part, wherout springs a flower, which is grene.
Calliblepharon, a medycyne to make the eyes fair. Callirohe, a fountain in
Greece. Calydon, et Calydonia, a city in Greece, also it was a great forest and
wodde in Brytain, now called England. Calypso, the daughter of Athlas, a
Nymph or woman of the sea. Calopodium, a patyn, or slypper. Calopus, a beast
in Syria, which with his horns throws down great trees. Calaen^^, a city
in the country of Naples. Calpae, a mountain in the southwest part of Spain.
Calua, the sculle. Caluities, et caluitium, baldness. Caluo, aui, are, to make
balde. Calueo, I am balde. Caluesco, to wax balde. Caluaria, all the heed,
when the flesh is away. Caluo, ui, ere, to deceive or disapoynt. Calumnia,
a false or crafty accusation. Calumniator, he that accusethe or seweth a many
unjustly. Calumnior, aris, ari, to accuse or sue a man unjustly. Caluinarius
porcus, a swyne fed with grains, and such other vile things. Calastri pueri,
singing boys. Calta, an herb growing among corn, having a yelowe flower.
Cambio, iui, ire, to change. In the old time it signified to fight, to begin
a iournay, or to turn in a journey. Campso, aui, are, to turn an other way.
Cambyses, a king of Persia, grandfather of Cyrus. It is also the name of a
river in the country of Hyrcania. Camera, the false roufe of a house, sollar,
or chamber. Camerare, to make a fauce roufe of a house, or to make a solar, or
to sylde. Camerium, a town of Italy in the country of Picenum. Camertes, the
inhabitauntes of Camerine, a town in Sycile. Camerina, an herb, which being
bruised, provoke a man to vomit: whereof camme this proverb, Ne moueas
camerinam, for, procure not harm to thy self. Camillus et Camilla, was in old
time a boy, or a wenche that served the bishop, when he did sacrifyce. Also
the name of a man or womanne. Chamamelum, et Camomilla, an herb called
Camomyll. Caminus, a chymnay or fournayse. Caminatus, ta, tum, made like a
fournayse or chymney. Camaenae, idem quod Musae. Campana, a belle. Campania,
the royalme of Naples. Campus, a field. Campestria loca, plain countries.
Camparius, the keeper of the feldes. Campsores, exchaungeours. Camp, a worm
which eats herbs, and is rough with many fete, and is called a palmer.
Camus, a bytte or snaffyll. also a rain or cord, wherewith men being
condemned were bound. Canabus, a wine sellar. Canna, a cane, also an oil pot
or can. Canales, pipes, whereby water does run into a cundyte. Canalicula, a
little pipe. Canaliculatus, facioned like a pipe. Cannabis, hemp. Cannabinus,
na, number, made of hemp. Cancelli, latteses, or any thing made lattese wise.
Also secret places to look out. Also windows made with bars of wodde or
iron with diverse holes. Cancello, aui, are, to raze or put out, to cut or tear
any thing that is written. Cancer, cri, a kind of fyshe called a crabbe, also a
sign in heaven. Cancer, eris, a disease called a canker. Cancti, is the same
that Cancelli be. Canctis, a pylle in medicine. Candax, acis, a queen of
Aegypte. Candifacio, to make white, to bleache, to make to glowe like a burning
cole. Candela, a candell. Candelabrum, a candelstycke. Candeo, ui, dear, to
glowe like a burning cole. Also to be white. Candico, aui, are, to be white,
or to make white. Candidatus, was be among the Romans which labored for
some of the great offices in the publyke weal: and they were so named by cause
they did wear in the time of their election white apparayle. It may be
taken by translation at this time, for them that in universities be called
incep^oars, or regent masters. Also for them that be lately christened, or
newely entered into some honorable or worshypfull state. Candido, aui, are, to
make white. Candidus, da, dum, white. It is somtymes taken for gentle or
easy: as Candidus lector, a gentle reder, which does not openly reprove
that which he redeth. Candidus index, A gentle or easy judge. Candide, gentylly
or easily. Candidus, sometime sygnifyeth fortunate, and it sygnifyeth more than
Albus, as oryente white. Candifico, aui, care, to make white. Candor, oris,
bryghtnesse. Canentae, were of the old Romans named the apparayle pertainyng
to the heed. Caneo, et canesco, scere, to be hoar, or gray heared. Canephora, a
maiden, which bare on her heed a basket or cofer, wherein were jewels or images
of the gods. Cangrena, a sore called a canker. Cani, be taken for white
hears for age. Canica, branne, gurgeons. Caniceps, a beast, which has
only the face of a dog. Canicula, a little dog or bytche. Also a sterre,
whereof canicular or dog days be named Dies caniculares. Caniculus, a whelpe.
Caninus, doggisshe, or of a dog. Caninum prandium, a dinar without wine.
Canis, a dog, a kind of fyshe called dogfishe, a play at tables, a sign in
heaven, whereof there be two sterres, oone called Canis mayor, the other canis
minor. Canistrum, a baskette. Canities, graynesse of hears. Canna, a poet
which was in the time of Martialis. Canna, a cane or read. also a can or
pot. also a village in the country of Galilee. Cannae, naru^, a town in the
country of Apulia, where a greatte hooste of Romans was slain by Hanniball.
Cannetum, a place where kanes or reeds do grow. Cannitie, thatched houses.
Cano, cecini, nere, to sing, to play on the shalme or other instrument. Also
to praise, to prophecye. Canere receptui, to blow the retraicte in battle.
Canon, a rule, also the inner part of a targate, which keuereth the hand.
Canopus, a city in Aegypte. Canor, oris, melody, loud. Canorosus, a, um, full
of melody. Cantabri, people in Spain. Cantabria, a country in Spain.
Cantharia, a stone which has the prynte of a black fly called a byttell.
Cantharis, idis, uel Cantharida, cantharidae a green worm shynynge with a
gloss of gold, which is bredde in the top of ashes, and laid to a man's
body, makes it to blyster. Cantharus, a pot or a judge. Also a beast, whereof
there is found no female. Also a kind of fysshe. also the black fly called
the bytill. Cantherium, a manner of a charyot or wagen. also a perch or a
rail. Cantherius, a geldynge. Also a traunsome of timber. Canthus, the iron
wherewith the extremytie of wheels be bounden, the straake of a carte. Canthes,
organ pipes. Canticum, a pleasant or merry song. Cantilena, the melody of the
song. Cantio, a song. Cantiuncula, a little song. Cantiro, aui, are, to
sing often. Canto, aui, are, to sing or to charm. Cantus, tus, a song.
Canus, an old man. Canus, na, number, graye or hoar. Canustum, a town in the
countreye of Apulia. Capax, acis, that takes or conteyneth any thing, able to
receive. Capedo, the greatness of a vessel, or like thing that contains.
Capena, a town by Rome. Caper, a gelded got. sometime it is taken for the
bucke got. it also was the name of an old grammarion. Capero, aui, to frown
or lowre. Capesso, si, sere, to take, or to goo about to take, to receive.
sommetyme it sygnifyeth to bring in. Plautus.
Caperus, the name of a king. Caphareus, a mountain in Greece. Capharnaum, the
chief city in Galslee. Capillamentum, the hear of a man's heed. sometime the
tops of herbs, where the seeds do grow. Capillo, are, to make hear.
Capillatus, a, um, that has hear. Capillitium, the hear of the heed.
Capillotenus, just to the hear. Capillus, the hear. Capillus ueneris, an
herb called Maiden hear. Capio, coepi, capere, to take wyllyngely, or
vnwyllyngly. Sommetyme it sygnifieth to delight, to mitigate, to deceive, Capti
dolis, deceived with cautels. sometime to co^teyne. Du boni, quid turbae? aedes
nostrae uix capiunt, Good lord, what a company? vsieth our house woll conteyne
them. Also to make. Capri o ciuis, blind, also great lovers be named capti.
Capis, dis, a cup. Capistro, are, to halter, or put on a rope, or cord.
Capistrum, a haltar. Capitale, et capital, an offense punyshed by death.
Capitalis homo, a man that deserves death. Also that is prone and ready to
murder. Capitalis ira, mortal wrath. Capitalis locus, the place of execution.
Capitatus, ta, tum, that growethe greatte in the head. Capite censi, were
among the Romans the poor* sort of the people, which were discharged of
all exactions, and remained in the city only for generation. Capitellum, a
little heed or top of a thing. Also the highest part of a pyllar. Capitili,
any thing that covers the heed, commonly they do call it a hoode. Capitis
diminutio, a condemnation, whereby a man loses either liberty of his person, ^
is made bond: or is banished his country, or put out of the kings protection,
or renouncing his own family, is adopted or take into an other, which is
not now used. Capitolinus, was the surname of him, that found the heed, when
the Capitole should be builded. Capitoliu^, the palaice of the city of Rome.
Capito, tonis, he that has a great heed, also heddy or obstinate in opinion.
Capitosus, he that has a great heed, or a dull heed. Capitulatum, any thing
that is grown to a heed. Capitulu^, a little heed, also a chapter. Cappa, the
name of a greek letter, for which the latins use C. Cappadocia, a country in
the less Asia. Cappadox, docis, a man of that country. Capparis, a fruit
called Capers, wherewith we do make salates and sauce for mutton, which eaten
before meles, be very good for the stomach, and against diseases of the spleen.
Capra, a goote. Capella, a little goote. Capreolus, a kydde. Capraria, an isle
in the sea called Ligusticu^. Caprarius, a goote herd. Caprea, a beast which
does see wonderful quickly. It is also a kind of vynes so named. Moreover an
isle by Naples. Capreolus, a beast called a roo. It is also the tendrell of a
vine, which wyndeth diverse ways, called also Pampinus. Capreus, a, um, that
which is of a got. Caprillus, a, um, idem. Capricornus, a sign in heaven,
conteininge xx. sterres. Caprificacio, the paryng away of the bark of a tree.
Caprificus, a wild fygge tree, which runs up by walls. Caprigenus, na,
number, that which is of the kind of a goote. Caprile, a stable or pen, where
got* be kept. Caprimulgi, birds like to gulles, which appear not by day, but
in the night they come into got pens, and do souke the gotes, whereby the
vdders of them be mortified. Caprinus, na, number, of a got. Caproneae, the coppe
of lyttel mane, that is in the forheed of a horse, or other beast. Caprunculum,
a greatte vessel. Capsa, a coffer or cheste. Capsaces, a vessel wherein oil
is kept. Capsarius, he that kepith chestis, or apparel. Capsus, a covered cart.
Captio, nis, the act of taking or deceyuynge, or that whereby any thing is
taken. Captiuncula, the diminutiue of Captio. Captiosus, captious or
deceytfull. Captiuus, a prisoner taken in wars, or a sclaue. Captiuitas,
captivity or bondage. Capto, aui, are, to get the favor of oone with tayre
words, pleasant deeds, or rewards. Also to deceive or take quyckely.
Captator, oris, he that uses that craft. Captatio, the act or craft to
get favor. also deceyte or subtyltie. Captura, the apprehendynge or gettyng.
Captus, ta, tum, taken. Captus, tus, chance. also deceyte, perceiving of a
thing, or capacity. Captus hominum, Men's capacity. sometime dilectation, Non
possum adduci et suscipere e pecunia captum, I may not be brought thereto, and
take dilectation of the money. Capua, a city in the royalme of Naples. Capula,
a cup with a handell. Capularis senex, an old manne redye to be laid in his
beer. Capulum, a riding knotte. Capulus et Capulum, what so ever may receive
any thing into it: proprelye it is a beer, wherein deed corpsis are borne:
also the hyltes or handell of a sword. Capus, a capon. Caput, a heed. Also the
beginning of every thing. Also a chapter of a book. Caput tacere, to gather
a soore to a heed. Capys, a man's name that builded Capua. Carabus seu Caramus,
a fysshe calledde a Crabbe. Caraxus, was the brother of Sapphus. Carbasus i^
plurali Carbasa, a kind of lynnen cypres: also the saylle clothe of a ship.
Moreover it is a syne garment of women of sylke or lynnen. Carbo, a cole. It
was also the name of a Romayne. Carbunculare, to have a Carbouncle or botche.
Carbunculus, a botche, which comes of inflammation. it is also a kind of
precyouse stones, which do shine like a bournynge cole. Moreover a defaulte in
a vine, and other trees, whereby they are burned, which happens about the
canicular days. Also it signifies earth, wherein is found black slatte
stones. Carcer, ceris, a prison. Also Carceres were stables, wherein horses were
set, when they should run. Carcerarius, ria, rium, of a prison.
Carchesium, a standing cup with handelles. Carchoquios, a kind of frogs,
having on their bealyes yelowe spots. Carcina, a city. Carcritoma, atis, a
soore called a canker. Cardamomum, a kind of spice. Cardiacus morbus, a
syckenes which happens by weakness of the body, with much sweatte and
feblenesse of the stomach. Cardinalis, le, chief or principal. Cardineus, the
same. Cardinum, an herb, which some do suppose is Cressis. Cardo, dinis, the
post, whereon the door hangs, and is moved. Also a mere or bounds, which
passith through the field from the southe to the north. Cardo rei, the effect
of the matter or thing: the chief point of the matter. Cardo causae, the
matter in law. Carduelis, a bird called a goldefinche. Carectum, a place full
of sedges. Careo, rui, rere, to lack proprely those good things, which ones
were had. Sometime it sygnifieth to be without a thing: as Careo culpa, I am
without fault. Careo febre, I am without fever. Cares, the name of a caruer,
the scholar of Lysyppus. Carex, ricis, an herb hard and prickinge. Caria, a
region in Asia the less. Caries, a lyttel worm that eats wodde: It is also
putrefaction or fylthe grown by age or contynuance. Carina, the keele or
bottom of the ship. Carinae, narum, a street in Rome, wherein Pompey dwelled.
Carino, aui, are, to make a thing of the facion of a ships bottom. Also to
speak to a man's reproach. Caritas, tatis, scarcity, proprely of that which
serves for the sustinance of man. Carius, the name of Jupiters son.
Carmania, a country of the less Asia. Carmelus, the name of two sundry hills
in Judea. Carmen, minis, a verse or meter. Also the hole warke which is made
in versis. Sometime it signifies a charm. Carmenta, the name of a lady, which
had the spirit of prophecy, and gave answer in verses. Carminare, to card
wulle, or other like thing. Carminarii, they that do pike or make clean wulle,
or card. Carmon, a place in Messenia, and the temple of Appollo in Laconia.
Carnarium, a larder, wherein hangs salt flesh, sometime it sygnifyeth a
bowchers shambles. Carnarius, a boucher. Carnarius, a, um, that pertayneth to
flesh. Carneus, a, um, that which is of flesh. Carni, the name of certain
people in Italy. Carnifex, ficis, a boucher of men, or hangman, that cutteth
them in pieces. Carnifleina, the place where such execution is done. Also
the office or act of a hangemanne. Carnificium, the same act. Carnificinus,
na, number, pertaining to the said act. Carnificor, aris, ari, to play the
hangmannes part. Carniuorum, any thing that deuourethe flesh. Carnositas,
abundance of flesh. Carnosus, flesshye. Carnotum, the mydle region of al
France. Carnuntum, a town in the border of Germanye. Donatus.
Caro, carnis, flesh, proprely of that which is dead. Carpatinae,
plowghemens boots, made of vnta^ned lether, they may be called cokers.
Carpathos, an I Will against Aegypte, the mids between Rhodes and Candy.
Carpentarius, a carte wright, or carpentar. Carpentarius equus, a carte horse,
or charyotte horse. Carpentum, a chariot or wagen. Carpinus, a kind of trees.
Carpio, a fyshe called a carpe. Carpo, psi, pere, to gather or pluck. Also to
chese, to reprove, or taunt, to use.i. fruor. Also carpere uires, is to make
feeble. Carpere uiam, to walk. Carpere uirales auras, to live. Carpere lanam,
to tose woll. Carpere cibum, to eat. Carptim, pykynge out here and there.
Carra, re, a city of Arrabie. Carruca, a carte. Carrucarius, a, um,
pertaining to a carte. Carrus, a charyotte. Carreia, a town in Spain.
Carthaginensis, pertaining to Cartage. Carthago, thaginis, the city of
Cartage in Affryke. Caruncula, a little flesh. Carus, a, um, dear. Carya,
the name of a city in Greece. Caryatides, the images of women holding
garlandes, or other like thing set up to garnyshe howses. Caryca, a fygge,
specially dry. Caryota, a date. Casa, a cotage. Casaria, the woman that keeps
the cotage Cascus, a, cum, old. Caseus, chese. Caseus musieus, Rowen chese.
Casius, a hill, in the borders of Aegypte. Casia, a spice, which has the
virtue of Cynamome, and is wonderful soote in sauoure. Casito, aui, are, to
fall or drop oftentimes. Caspiae porrae, certain Mountayns in Asia. Caspium
mare, the sea which joins to the said hills. Casses, sis, nets which may
be called hays. Also an helmette, but than it has Cassidis in the genitife
case. Cassiculus, a little hay. Cassida, ae, an helmette. Cassiope, a sign
in heaven, that has.xiii. sterres, and is figured like to a woman, sittynge in
a chair. Cassita, a lark. Cassitias, the gum that droppeth out of afirre
tree. Casso, aui, are, to put out, or make of none effect. Cassius, a propre
name of a man. Cassus, a, um, void and of none effect. Castalius, a fountayn
in the foot of the hill of Pernassus, which was dedicate to the Musis. Casta
mola, was a kind of sacrifice, that the vyrgins Vestales made. Castaneum, a
chesten, or cheste nutte. Castellani, the inhabitauntes of a lyttelle walled
town. Castellarim, one lyttelle walled town after an other. Castellum, a
little walled town. It is also a cundyte, out of the which water rounnethe.
Casterium, a docke where ships be laid up. Castigo, aui, are, to chastise
with wordis. also to correct or amend* Castiras, taris, chastity. Castor, a
Beuer, which has the tail of a fyshe, in the residue is like to an ottar.
Castor et Pollux, were brethren both at one birth, which were honored for
goddi. Castra, castroru^, an army of men of war, when they lie or abide in
any place. Also the place where the host lodgethe. Also the Pauilions being
pyched. Castrametor, to lay or lodge an army. Castro, aui, are, to gelde.
Sometime to cut of generally. Castrensis, castrense, that which pertains to
an hooste or army. Castrum, a castle or fortress. Castula, lynnen clothe,
wherewith maidens did gyrde them self under their pappes. Castus, ta, tum,
chaste, honest, and contynent, or uncorrupted. Casura, a fall a decay. Casus,
hap, ruin, mysfortune, or myserie. also a case. Cattabathmus, a town in
Aphrica. Catechesis, instruction or informacyon to him that begins any
thing. Catechiso, aui, are, to instruct, to infourme or teach. Cataclysmus,
an universal fludde. Catadromum, the place where horses be coursed.
Catalecticum merrum, a verse wherein one only syllable lacks. Catalogus,
speech or writing where things be recyted in order and number, a rehersalle.
Cataphractus, armed at all pieces. Cataphracti equites, horsemenne on barbyd
horses. Cataphractae naues, keuered ships. Cataphrygae, Certain heretics,
which said that the holy ghost was not in the apostels, but only in them
selfs. Cataplasma, a plaster made with herbs and sewet. Catapotia, pylles in
medicine. Catapulta, an arowe. Catarthaera, a portculious, Also clouds.
sometime caves in the earth. Catarthactae, great courses of water, falling down
from high places. Also the places from whens they do fall. Catarthus, a rewme
or styllynge down of water or fleme from the heed. Catascopium, a ship that
watches or espieth for other. Cata^ta, a cage, wherein men be set, which are
to be sold. also wherein they were punysshed. Catastroma, part of a ship or
paueme^t. Catastrophe, a subversion, or a volume. Catechumenus, he that is
newly instructid. Categoria, accusation. Catellus, catella, a little hounde.
Catena, a chain. Cateno, aui, nare, to chain together. Catenula, a little
chain. Caterna, a company of men of war. some time a multitude of people.
Cateruarii, they that do assemble in companyes. Cateruatim, by companyes.
Catharctica, purgative medicines. Cathedra, a benche or stool. Cathinea, a
kind of earth, whereof latyne metal is made. Catholicus, vniuersalle. now it
is used for him that keeps the faith, as the universal church has obseruyd
it. Catillatio, a great reproach laid to gentylmen, which had robbed the
countries, that were alied to the Romans, and had riottously consumed the
goods. Catillones, lycke dyshes, glottons. Catillus, the over stone of a
mylle, called the runner. Catina, a city in Sicile. Catinus, a potage dyshe.
Catillus, idem. Cathortoma, the right work of virtue, a right deed.
Cathortosis, a right affection. Catus, wise, or wytty. Also the name of a noble
and wise familye in Rome. Catularia, one of the gates of Rome. Catulire, the
desire of female kind, to company with the male kind, proprely to goo assaute,
to rudder, to horsynge, or to blyssonynge. Catulitio, the goinge assault. etc.
Catullus, the name of a poet. Catulus, a kytten or young catte. Also it is
put generally for the young kind of all beastis. also for a dog. Catus, a
catte. Caua, a hole, wherein birds do bread. Cauedium, is a place at large,
having many porches, which serves to a commune, like a market place.
Caucasus, a very high mountain in Inde. Cauda, a tail of a beast. sometime a
man's priuye membre. Caudacus, gentle and pleasant. Caudax, dacis, the lower
part of a tree next the root. Also a table, having many leaves or tables.
Caudicariae naues, a ship which caryeth vytayles. Caudis, a town of Samnie.
Cauea, a cave or dark place in the ground. Also a cage or cowpe, wherein
birds be kept. Moreover a place where a comedy or interlude is playde. Caueo,
caui, cauere, to beware, to eschew: also to provide diligently, to take heed.
Cave tibi, Take heed of thy self. Cauerna, a cave or holowe place in the
ground. Cauilla, uel Cauillum, a mock or a ieste. Cauillo, aui, are, uel
cauillor, ari, to ieste to mock, to bourde. Caula, a sheep house, but proprely
a fold. Caulescere, to grow into stalk. Cauliculus, a tender stalk. Caulis,
a stalk or stem of an herb or tree. Also it is an herb called colewortes. It
is sometime taken for all pot herbs, the ru^pe of a beast, and for a shafte or
iauelyn. Caulon, a town, which of Pliny is situate in the first region of
Italy. Cauma, aris, heat. Caunus, an isle in the occean see. Cauo, aui, are, to
make holowe. Caupo, onis, a howkster that sells meare and drink. Caupona, a
woman that sells wine. Also the tauerner. Cauponaria, tauerners craft.
Cauponius, ia, iu^, ptaynyng to the tavern. Cauponor, to sell as howksters do.
Cauros, was an isle, which afterward was called Andros, and after that
Antandros. Caurus, a western wind. Causia, a hatte or cappe after the facion
of Macedonye. Causon, nis, a burning fever. Caussa, a cause or matter in
suite. Caussarii milites, soldiers, which for causes reasonable, were
discharged out of the army. Caussaria missio, a discharge of a soldier for
a reasonable cause. Caussatio, an in ward syckenes. Causatiuus, tiua, tiuum,
that is cause that a thing is done. Caussidicus, a man of law. Caussificor,
aris, to complayn me of a thing that does grieve me. Causso, aui, are, to
cause. Caussor, aris, to find the matter, or to bring for excuse. Caustica
medicamenta, medicines, which do burn the skin or the flesh. Caureres et
cauteria, is a markynge iron, or an instrument, wherewith soores ar burned.
Cauteriatus, ta, tum, marked or burned with that instrument, or marked with an
iron. Cautes, a ragged rock, or hylle fulle of greatte stoones. Cautum est, It
is ordained or provided by an act of parlyament or counsel. Cautio est, it
is need to provide or beware. Cautus, a man that is circumspecte. Cauus, a, um,
holowe. Cauus, an holowe place. Causter, a fludde of Lidis. Caystrus, foem.
genesis a city of Cilycie.
C ante B.
CEcrops, pis, the first king of Athenes. Cecropius, a, um, of Cecrops.
Cecropidis, a man or womanne, coming of him. Cecropide, men of Athenes.
Cecriphalea, a rock in the sea, or an isle. Cedar, a region of Arabie. Cedo,
cessi, dear, to give place, to goo away, to void, to withdraw, to grant, to
give. Cedo bonis, I leave my goods to an other. Cedere intercessioni, to
proceed no further, to admytte the contrary. Cedo iuri, I release my right.
Cedunt mihi ea bona, those goods ar com or happened unto me. Cedite manus,
give me your hands. Cessit, it happened. Cedo, in the imperative mode, Tell
thou. Cedir dies, among lawyers is, The time is come, that the debt is due to
be paid. Cedria, the first swearyng of the pitche tree. Cedrides, the fruit of
the cedre tree. Cedropolis, a town in Caria. Cedros, an yland in the costis of
Germany. Cedrosis, a white vyneyarde. Cedrus, a kind of trees, which is
excellent for buyldinge, forasmoche as the tymbre thereof is great, and very
light: also it dureth long, and is never eaten with worms, and is soote in
savor, having leaves like to a cypress tree. Celebresco, I am in great fame,
or am renoumed. Celebris, bre, famous. Also swifte, honorable. Celebritas,
tatis, renoume. Also a great assemblye. Celebriter, honorably. Celebro, aui,
are, to celebrate or bring in renoume, to make good report. Also to haunte,
to honor, or worship. Celer, eris, swyfte, quycke. Celero, aui, are, to do a
thing quyckely, to make haste. Celeres, runnynge horses. Celeustes, he that
calls on the mariners, to row or labor. Celeusma, the shoute or cry that
shypmen or botemen do make, when the master does whystell or call. Cella, a
cellar, wherein any thing is kept. Also where we be pryuily washed. Also a
secret place in the temple. Cellaria, a wine sellar. Cellarium, a storehouse.
Cellarius, he that has the charge of a cellar or storehouse. Celatim,
privily. Celo, aui, are, to hyde, or will not know. Celox, a swyfte ship, or
bark. Celsus, high. Celtae, French men. Celtiberi, a people in Spain, of
Celtis, French men, and Iberis Spayniardes assocyate together. Celtis, a kind
of sweet trees growing in Affryke. Celydrus, a womannes apparayle. Cemellio,
a town in Ligursa. Cenchris, a byrd like an hawk, which makes a great sown
when he cries. Also it is the name of a town or country in Greece. Cenina, a
city of Italy. Cenomani, people in Lombardy. Cenodoxia, vain glory.
Cenotaphium, a tomb, where no man is buryedde. Censio, sui, ere, to suppose,
to show mine opinion or sentence, to determyne, to be discontent, to number
people, to the intent to take them, which be apt for the wars, or to leuye
or tax a subsidy. Censio, nis, a chastysement. Censor, a judge of men's
manners. Also such as was appointed to valewe men's goods. Censorius uir, he
that has been a Censour, or is worthy for his gravity to judge and correct
other men's manners. Censualis, he that does assiste or accompany the iuges of
manners called censors. Censui agri, were those fields, which by the law
civil might be boughte and sold. Censu^a, the authority or judgment of a
censour. Also correction of manners, law, or decree, concerning manners.
Census, sus, yearly revenues. Also valuation of goods. Also a subsidy, the
numbering of the people. Census, si, he that is assessed or taxed, capite censi,
taxed by the polle, or he that pays heed silver. Centaurea, a kind of herb
called Ce^tory Centauri, a people in the country of Thessaly, whom the poets
did feign to be the one half like a man, the other half like a horse. Also they
be certain great ships. Centaurus, a river, which was first called Euenus.
Centimanus, having a hundred hands. Centipeda, a worm called a Palmer,
which is heary, and has many feet. Cento, a quylte, or a iakke, or other
like thing stuffed with linen, floxe, or cotton, or a cushyn made of pieces
of cloth of diverse colors. Centrum, the point, which is in the very mids of
a thing. Centum, a hundred. Centies, a hundred times. Centum uiri, certain
judges in Rome, being of the number of a hundred and five. And their
iugementes were called Centum uiralia iudicia. Centunculus, a vile garment.
Centuria, a part of an host, containing an hundred men. Also a portion of
ground in the field, containing an hundred acres. Centuriatim, by a hundred
together. Also plentuousely, or in a great number. Centurio, nis, a capitayn
over one hundred of foot men. Centurio, aui, are, to divide men into a
company, contaynyng an hundred persons: or feldes into a hundred acres of
land. Centussis, a hundred pound weyghte, or a hundred pieces of that money
that were called Asses. Cephale, or lis, sygnifieth the heed. Cephalea, the
heed ache, when all the heed does ache. Cephalus, the name of a man, and of a
fish. Cepheus, the name of a king of Ethiope. Cephisia, the region Attica.
Cephisis, a laake nere to the sea Athlanticu^ Cepites, a precious stoone,
having many white strikes. Ceporus, a gardyner. Ceramicus, a place in
Athenes, where men being slain in battle, were buried. Also an another
place, where commune women dwelled. Cerastes, a serpente, which has horns
like a ram. Cerasus, a chery tree. Cerasum, a cherye. Cerates, a small
weight or poyse, which is the fourth part of a scrippule, the.xlviii. part of
an ounce. Ceratinae, is of Quint. called a spece of reasonynge inexplycable.
Cerberus, the porter of hell. Also a dog with three heedes, which Hercules
drew out of Hell. Cercopithecus, a beast called a Marmoset. Cerdo, nis, a
cobblar. Cereale, pertaining to Ceres the goddess. Cerebrum, the brain.
Cerebrosus, a man being braynsycke, or wild brayned, trusting only to his
own will. Ceres, the goddess of corn. sometime it is used of Poets for the
self corn, or breadde. Ceretani, a people in Spain. Ceretum, a town in
Italye. Cerinthe, es, an herb called a honysuckle. Cerinthus, a thing which
is found in honey combs, whereon bees do feed. Ceritus, madness or frensy.
Cice. Dolobelle. and ad Attic.
Cerno, creui, cernere, to see or perceive also to consider: sometime to judge,
or determine. sometime to try out. Also to sight in battle, to enter into
land, which is happened unto me by inheritance or gift. Cernuus, stowpynge or
lookynge downewarde. Certamen, a conflycte or byckerynge. Certatim, oone
contendynge or stryuynge with an other. Certisso, aui, are, to be certified or
sure. Certitudo, dinis, certainty or surety. Certo, aui, are, to contend or
strive. Certus, ta, tum, certain, sure without dout. sometime it sygnifyeth
even as we would have it. Certe et certo, surely. Ceruus, a heart, or a forke,
wherewith cotages be propped up. Ceruinus, na, number, of a heart. Ceruicale et
ceruical, a bolstar. Ceruisia, ale or beer. Ceruix, uicis, the hinder part of
the neck. Cerunina, ear wax. Cerus, a kind of oken trees. Cerussa, Ceruse,
or white lead, wherewith some women be painted, and cold playsters be made of
it. Cerix, cis, a pursyuant or bedyll. Cespes, cespitis, a tirfe. some do call
them sottes, grass and earth together. Cessim ire, to recule or go back.
Cesim ferire, to stryke edgelynge. Cesso, aui, are, to cease, to leave warke,
to abide. Cessator, he that is slow in dooinge his dewtie. Cestrum, an
instrument, wherewith iuorie is made holow. also a dagger, or a wunbyl. also an
herb, which is called Berayne. Cetariae, places nyghe the sea side, where
Tunye and other greatte fysshes be taken and saltyd. Cetarius, a fyshemonger,
or taker of great fysshes. Cetra, a light tergate. Cetrati milites, Sowldyours
with lyghteter gates. Cetus, a great fyshe called a whale.
C ante H.
CHabrias, the name of a noble philopher and captain of Athenes, which used
to say, that more terrible was an host of hearts, having to their capitayn a
lion, than an host of lions, having an heart their captain. Chalame, a city
of Perse, which now is called Aetisiphon. Chalaza, a gatherynge under the
skin like the disease called Bubo. Chalastra, a certain apparayle.
Chalcedonia, a city in Asie against Constantynople. Chalcis, dis, the name of
a city in Greece. also of an isle, and of a bird. Chalcites, a stone of the
color of brass, but more black. Chaldaea, a region in Asia, joining to
Arabie, wherein was the great cite of Babylon. Chaldei, be taken for great
astronomers of the country of Assiria. Chalestra, a city of Thessaly on the se
cost. Chalyx, a flynte stone, out of the which fire is stryken. Chalybes, a
people in the less Asia, in the country called Pontus, which people do dygge
greatte plenty of iron naked. It is proprely taken for steel. And also it is
the name of a fludde in Spain. Chamaecissos, an herb called ground iuy.
Chamaedaphne, an herb which grows in length wynding together in diverse
parts, and has leaves like to laurel or bays, and has a flower like to a
vydlette, and is called of some men perwyncle. Chamaedreos, an herb called
Germander. Chamaeleon, ontis, a little beast, having his skin spotted like
to a lybard, which changes into diverse colors, according to the thing that
he sees. They be engendered in Inde, and is of the quantity and figure of a
lysard, but that his legs be longer, and goes vpryght, and has a snoute
like a swyne, a long tail, and small at the end, his eyes be never closed,
he does never eat or drink, but is nourisshed only by air. Chameleon is
also an herb. Chamaemelon, an herb called camomylle. Chamaeterae, maidens
which were wont to sytte at their maystresses feet. Chamelopardalis, a
beast which is as great as a camel, of skin and color like Panther,
having spots of sondrye colors, and has his forelegges and neck long,
and the heed like a camel, his fete and legs like an ox. Chamelus, a beast
called a camelle, communely known. Chania, the country called Epirus,
Chaones, men of that country. Chaos, a confuse matter without form, made
first of nothing, whereof poets supposed all other things to proceed.
Characote, a frame, about the which vynes be wound and turned. Characias,
an herb called Spourge. Character, a token, a note made with a pen, a figure,
a style or form of speaking. Characteres, letters. Charadrius, a greatte
deuowrynge bird of the sea. Caraxes, the brother of Sapphus. Charistrium, a
grene marble stone. Carrisius, the name of a grammarion. Charistia, the plurell
number, is as it were a Christmas feast, or a wake, where kynnesfolke do
resort together, bryngyng or sendynge presents mutually. Charitas, charity
or love, proprely toward men, or a man's country. Charites, the graces, which
were supposed to be the daughters of Jupiter, which were three in noumbre, whose
names were Aglaia, Thalia, Euphrosyne: And where in speaking or writing
appeared to be a meruaylous dilectation or swetenes, ir was said that therein was
a grace, in latin, Charis. Chariophilon, a kind of soote spyce that grows
in India. Charon, it is, was named of the Paynyms, the booteman, that carried
sowles over the three ryuers of Hell, Acheron, Stix, and Cocytus. Catopus,
amyable, pleasant, gracious. Charta, paper. Also a leaf of paper, or other
like thing, wherein we do write. also a maiden that had never child.
Chartaceus, of paper. Chartilago, ginis, a grystell. Chartophylacium, a coffer,
or other like thing, wherein papers and rolls be kept. Charundas, the name of
a man, which gave laws to the Atheniens. Charus, well beloved. Charybdis, a
gulf of the sea by Sicyl, where in is dangerous saylynge, by reasone of stremes
flowynge contrary each against other, whereby ships be therein deuourid.
Chasma, a gapynge. or openyng of the firmament, or of the earth. Chelae, the
klees of a Crabbe, Crauaise, or Scorpyon. Chelonophagi, eaters of snayles.
Cheledonia, an herb called Selandine. also a western wind. Chelys, a snayle.
sometime it is taken for an harp or lute. Chelydros, a see snayle. Chemites, a
manner of tomb, like to yuorie. Chemiscus, a part of the foreshyp, whereby the
