ancre does hang. sometime it is taken for all the ship. Chennis, is an
yland, as Pompon. writes. Chenoboscion, a place where geese be fed. Chenopus,
a goose foot. Cheospes, a king of Aegypte. Cherronesus, the part of Greece
callydde now Morea. It is sometime taken for the north part of the great Asia,
it is also callid Chersonesus. Chersina, a kind of land snayles. Chersydros,
a serpent, which abides as well in water, as on land. Cherubin, one of the
holy orders of aungelles, wherein is the science dyuine and mystycalle.
Cherusci, a people of Germany. Chibis, an herb. Chilorus, a river of
Macedonic. Chiliarchus, a captain of a thousand me. Chilias, adis, the number
of a thousand. Chilon, one of the.vii. wise men of Greece. Chilones, men
having great lyppes. Chimaera, a got. Also a mountain in Lycia. Also a
monster, having three heedes, one like a lion, an other like a goote, the
third like a dragon. Chimerinos, a cerkle of heaven, into the which when the
son comes, the days be at shortest. Chymus, the juice procedynge of meat
digested, which by the veins comes into the members, and restores that
which is consumed by heat. Chios, an isle in the sea called Eous, which was
sometime called Aeolia, where mastix growith. Chiragra, the gout in the
fyngers. Chiragricus, he that has such a disease. Chiridota, a cote with
long sleues. Chirographum, et chirographus, an obligation or like instrumente,
whereby a man is bounden, and has put to his hand. Chiromantia, palmestry.
Chiron, nis, the name of a man, whom poets do feign to be the one half of a
man, the other half like a horse: who first did find the virtues of herbs,
and taught Aesculapius phisike, and Apollo to harp, and Astronomy to
Hercules, and was master to Achylles, and excelled all other me^ of his time in
virtue and justice. Chironium, is a sore in the legs or fete, which is hot,
and swells by the two sides. Chironia, wild vine. Chironomia, a facyon of
gesture with the hands used in daunsynge, or in keruynge of meat. Chirotheca,
a glove. Chirurgia, surgerye. Chirurgus, a surgion. Chaena, a cloak. Chlamis,
idis, a cloak, which proprely is worn by men of war. Chlamidatus, cloked.
Chobar, signifies all the greatte floodes, which be in the region of Caldee.
Choenix, ici^, a certain measure, contaynynge four times the measure called
Sextarius. Cholera, an humor called choler. Also a syckenes called the colyke.
Choliambi, a certain kind of verses. Chondros, a grain of frankensence.
Choragium, stuff, proprely wherewith that place is adorned, where as shall be
enterludes or disguysynges. Choragus, he that kepethe such stuff or
apparayle. Chorannel, certain men that live in woddes in Persia, which are so
swyfte, that they take hearts with runnynge. Choraula, the craft to blow
trumpettes, or to play on shawlmes, or other like pypes. Choraules, players on
the said Instruments. Chorda, a cord or rope. Chorea, a daunse. Choriambus,
a foot in meetre, which has the first syllable, and the last long, and two
in the myddell short. Chorius, a foot in meter, which by an other name is
called trochaeus, and is but of.ii. syllables, the first long, the second
short. Chorobates, a measure to meet ground with, or a masons rule. Chortos,
hay, or grass mowen. Chorus, the company of players or dauncers. also a quyar.
Chresis, is use, and carachresis is abusyon. Chreston, an herb called cycorie.
Chytrapus podis, a treuytte. Columella
Chrestus, the name of a noble author of Athenes. Chria, a notable sentence
spoken shortly, to exhort to virtue, or dissuade from vice. Chrisis, unction.
Christus, anointed. Chromaticus, whose color never changes, but is always
one. Chronica, little, an history of acts done, with the times expressed,
Cronicles. Chronicus, ca, cum, temporal, or pertaining to time. Chrysia, a
city in Phrigie, and an ylande in Indie. Chrysendeth, any thing bounden with
gold. Chryses, the name of a Prophet among the gentiles. Also of a maiden
given by the greeks to king Agame^non at the battle of Troy. Chrysippus,
the name of a famous and noble philosopher. Chrysoaspides, knights that had
shyldes of gold. Chrysocolla, a stone with the powder where of paynters do make
a golden color, also goldsmythes do use it to sowder gold. Chrysocoma, golden
hear. Chrysocomus, he that has golden hear. Chrysogonum, that brings forth
gold. Chrysolampis, a stone of fyrye color by night. Chrysomela, apples of
the color of gold. by an other name callid apples of Armeny. Chrysolitus, a
precious stone of the color of gold. Chrysopastus, a stone with golden
spots. Chrysothemis, the daughter of Agamemnon and Clytemnestre.
Chrysostomus, the name of a bishop of Constantinople, and also of an
hystoryen, which were so called for their eloquence. for Chrysostomus is in
english a golden mowthe. Chus, a certain measure containing syx times the
measure called Sextarius. Chytra, a pot with feet, or a tryuette.
C. Ante I.
CIbale, pertaynyng to meat. Cibarium, meat. cibarius, a, um, vile. Cibarius
homo, a vile person. Cibarium uinum, ill wine. Cibo, aui, are, to feed.
Ciborium, a kind of appuls of Alexandry. Cibus, meat. Cicada, a grassehopper.
Cicatricosus, he that has many tokens of wounds. Cicatrix, icis, a token or
scarre, where a wound had been. Cicer, eris, a grain like to peason.
Cicercula, differs from Cicer oonely in color. Cicero, onis, the name of
the most noble Romayne, which was the father of latyne eloquence. Cichorea,
and Cichorium, an herb callydde Succorye. Cicina, a night crow. Cicindula, a
fly which shines by night. Cicinia, a little lean serpent in Italy.
Cicones, a people of Thrace. Ciconia, a bird called a storke. also it is a
certain rule or measure. Ciconius, the name of him that buildid Brixis
Cicorium, an herb that grows every where. Cicum, the thyn rynde of
Pomegranates. Cicur, uris, tame. Cicuro, aui, are, to make tame. Cicuta, a
venomous herb, which grows two cubytes in height, with a grene stalk full
of knottes, bushy in the top, having leaves smaller than Coriander, and
seeds greatter than anyse sede, and is horrible in savor: Some does now use
that name for Hemlocke. Cidaris, a cappe, which the kings of Persia did use,
and also the bishops in the old law. Cieo, and cio, ciui, to move a thing,
or to call. Bellum ciebam, They did set forth to battaylle. Cileo, lui, ere,
to move or stir a thing. Cilicia, a country ioynynge to Syria. Cilicium, any
clothe or garmente made of hear. Cilium, the over skin wherewith the eye is
closed. Cilix, licis, an inhabytant of Cilicia. Cillibe, and cilliba, a round
table. Cilones, men having great round foreheedes. Cima, the tender part of
the stalk of herbis. Cimana, things that be four square. Cimbri, a people
called Danes. In the old time they inhabyted not only Denmark, but also all
the yles from Selande to the north see. Cimerii, people of Scythia, they that
do dwell in the countries, where as is continual cold and much darkness.
Cimex, a stynkynge worm bredynge in wodde or paper. Cimolia creta, fullers
klaye. Cinediae, stones found in a fyshes heed. Cinedus, a wanton boy without
shamefastnes. Also a daunser of galyardes and wanton maskes. It is also taken
for a tumblar. Cincinni, hears that be trymmed. Cincinnati, men having their
hear trymmed. Cincticulus, a short cote called a ierkyn. Cinctus, tus, a
short garment, which the Consulle did wear, when he proffered battaylle.
Cinis, neris, ashes. Cineraceus, and Cinereus, a, um, of the color of ashes.
Cinericius, a, u^, bake^ or roasted under ashes. Ciniflo, nis, he that makes
hot the instruments, wherewith men or womenne did trymme their hear. Cingo,
cinxi, cingere, to gyrde or compass about. Cingria, a short pype, having a
small sownde. Cingula, a gyrthe for beasts. Cingulum, a gyrdell for men.
Cinna, a city of Thessaly. also the name of a Romayne, which exceded in
cruelty. Cinnabaris, a stone called a Sanguinary. it is also called in latin
Sanguis draconis, dragons bloudde. it is put into sondrye medycynes to staunche
bloudde. Cinnamomum, and Cinnamum, a spyce called Cynnamom. Cinniligium, a
gyrdell, which a bryde or new wedded wife wears, a corse. Cinnus, a hear
of a man or woman's heed, or a medly of diverse things together. Cipetum, a
soote plant or herb, which is good to break and expulse the stone. Cippus,
a pair of stocks. Also a lyttelle hylle, which men call a barowe. Also a
tomb, a pyllar. Circa, about, nyghe. Circe, the name of a woman, by whom a
city in the country of Campania, called Circium, was builded. Also a wytche,
which turned the company of Ulysses into beasts. Circe^ses ludi, were
certain games in Rome wherein horses ran with chariottes. Circerus, a great
ship, which they of Asia used. Circino, aui, are, to compass, to make a
cerkle. Circinus, an instrument called a compass. Circiter, about: and it is
referred sometime to time, as Circiter calendas Iunias, About the first day of
June. sometime it is referred to the place. Circiter in media arce, About the
mids of the castle. sometime to the thing. Circiter duo millia hominum caesa
sunt, There were nygh two thousand men slain. Circites, hoopes of brass or
iron. Circitores, officers in cities, which do go about to see that good rule
be kept. Circius, a sowtherne wynd, which is wonderfulle vehement.
Circuitores, the serchers of watches. Also they which do go about the streets
to sell garments or lynnen clothe. Circulo, aui, are, to compass or close
with a dyche, or other like. Circulatim, by cerkles, or in the form of a
cerkle. Circulator, he that gothe about to show him self, or what he can do,
or to deceive the people. Circulatorius, ia, ium, pertaynyng to such auaunters
or deceyuers. Circulatrix, she that gothe about to get money with daunsynge
or tumbling. Circulus, a cercle or compass. Circum, about. Circumago, egi,
agere, to lead about, to turn about. Circumiaceo, ieci, iicere, to put
about. Circumlitio, onis, bournishinge, klensynge, or polishinge. Circummitio,
to send about. Circummunio, iui, ire, to enclose, wall in, or dyche in.
Circumnascor, to grow about, Circumplector, to embrace or close in.
Circumscribo, psi, bear, to write, or draw about with a line. Also to deceive
one in bargaynynge with him. Fratre^ circumscripsit in diuisione haereditatis,
He deceived his brother in particion of the inheritance. Also to gather,
comprehend, or descryue throughely. Cuius scientiae summam breuiter
circumscribo, The effect of whose learning I will comprehend or descryue
shortly. Apulcius.
Circumsecus, on both sides. Circumsedeo, cessi, sedere, to besiege.
Circumsido, sedi, sidere, to go about to besiege. Circumsisto, stiti, sistere,
to stand about one, to defend him. Circumspectus, Circumspect. Circumspicio,
exi, cere, to look about. Circumspicuus, a, um, that may be beholden on all
parts. Circu^sto, steri, stare, to stand about. Circumuado, to invade, or
perce on al parts. Circumueho, uexi, uehere, to carry about oftentimes.
Circumuenio, to compass a man, to deceive him, to close him i^, as in wars,
to opp^sse. Foenore circu^uentus, Oppressed with usury. Circumuolito, aui, are,
to flee about. Circumcelliones, tavern haunters, or raylers about.
Circu^cido, cidi, cidere, to cut about a thing. Circumcolo, colui, colere, to
dwell now here now there. Circumcolumnium, a place set about with pillars.
Circundare, to go about as a ring does about a ma^s finger, or a diche about
a close. Circumeo, iui, ire, to go about any thing. Circumfero, to carry or
bear about. Also to cleanse. Idem ter socios pura circumtulit vnda, Vergil. 6.
Also be cleansed his company three times with clean water. Circumflexus, bowed.
Circumfluo, to abound. Circumfluere, is also to flow or rounne about, as
water about a city or Countreye. Circumfluus, a, um, that flows about.
Circumforaneus, a, um, that may be, or is often carried about. Circumforanei,
malaperte guestes and tellars of tidings in markettes. Circuo, iui, ire, to go
about. Circus, a Cercle. Also a round place walled about, of the which
there were three in Rome, where there was made certain games. Circius, the name
of an isle in Mysia. Cirnea, a cup. Cirri, hears curled, or feathers that do
grow on the top of abyrdes heed, as a lark or an heron. Cirracus, a kind
of baume. Cis, a worm among corn, which I suppose to be called weuyls. Also
it sygnifieth on this side: as Cis Rhenum, on this side the River of Rhyne: Cis
Alps, on this side the mountains called Alps. Some time it sygnyfyeth less.
Cis naturae leges, Less than the laws of nature may suffer. Salust uses it
ones for beyond. Cis Rhenu^ atque intra mare nostrum er oceanum, Beyond the
river of Rhine, and within our see, and the occean see. Cisalpina Gallia, was
sometime that countreye, which is from the mountains callydde Alps, unto the
River of Rubycon. Cicium, a carte. Ciciarius, a cartar. Cispius, a mountain in
Rome. Cisseus, a king of Thrace, father of Hecuba, queen of Troy. Cissybium, a
cup or bolle made of iuy. Cissites, a precious stone like an yuy leaf,
bright of color. Cista, a cheste, coffer. Cisterna, a cesterne, Citatus,
called, sommoned, or cited. Cithara, a harp. Citharis, a byshopes myter.
Citharista, an angle of France by Marcile, lyinge out to the sea.
Citharistria, a woman harper. Cithariro, aui, are, to harp. Citharoedus, a
harper. Cytisus, an herb called chickwede. Citimus, ma, mum, the last. Cito,
aui, are, to cite, to sommon, or call. Citorus, a mountain where grows
ple^tie of box trees. Citra, on this side. somety^me without. Citra
adulationem, without flatterye. Citreum, an orange. Citrus, a tree called a
citron tree. Citrum, a fruit called pome citron. Cittium, a town of Cyprus.
Citus, quycke, hasty, swyfte. Sommetyme divided or parted. Cito, soon,
shortly. Ciuicus, ca, cum, is the same that ciuilis is. Ciuica corona, a
garlande of oken leaves, used to be given to them that had saved a citesyn in
battle. Ciuilis, le, that pertayneth to a cytesyn. Ciuilis homo, a man
expert in those things, that appertain to the ministration of a common
weal. Ciuilitas, tatis, courteysy, civility. Ciuis, a citesyn or demsen. Also
Ciuis meus my country man. Ciuitas, tatis, a city, proprely it is the
multitude of cytesens gathered together, to live according to law and right.
Cius, a river of Thrace. Cizicus, a city in Asie the less.

CLades, dis, a discomfyture in battle, a destruction of men. Clam, priuilye,
unawares. Clam me profectus est, vnwaares to me, he went his way. Clamo, aui,
are, to cry, to call. Clamor, oris, a cry, a clamor, a noise. Clamosus, a,
um, clamorous or full of noise. Clandulum, secretly. Clandestino, privily, or
secretly. Clandestinus, a, um, privy, or secret. Clango, xi, gere, to sown a
trumpette. Clangor, oris, the sown of a trumpet. sometime the cry that geese
or other like birds do make. Clanius, a city of Champayne, nere to the city
Acerras. Clarco, ui, ere, to appear, to be well known, and to be clear. Clare,
clearly, apparently. Clarifico, eci, cere, to make clear or apparent
Clarigatio, a clerynge, a subsydie or task granted by a commune consent.
Clarigo, aui, are, to ask clearly. Claritas, tatis, clerenes, sometime
nobylitie, or honourablenes. Claro, aui, are, to make noble or honorable.
Claros, a city in Greece. Clarus, a river, which rounneth from the high
mountains of Alps, into the river called Danubium. Clarus, ra, u^, clear,
noble, honorable, famous Classiarius, diligent. Classicus, an officer, which
with a tru^pette or tabore called people together. sometime a man being in
reputation. Classicum, a people or noise of trumpettes, or belles to call
menue together, or to goo to battle. Classicus, ca, um, pertaining to
nauyes. Classis, a navy of ships. sometime it is taken for one ship.
sometime companyes or sorts of people, ordered in a city alter the value of
their substance. Also Classes be degrees or forms in schools: as prima
classis, the first degree or form. etc. Clatro, aui, are, to shut a
wyndowe, specially a lattyse wyndowe. Clatrum et clatrus, a lattyse wyndowe, or
any thing made like a lattyse. Claua, a clubbe. Clauarius, an offycer
appointed to deal the emperors gift of money or coin among the soldiers.
Clauator, he that uses a clubbe. Clauatus, set with nails. Claudeo, to
halte. sometime to err. Claudianus, the name of a poet. Clauditas, halting,
lamenesse. Claudius, the name of an emperor of Rome Claudo, si, dear, to
shytte. sometime to compass: also to put of: also to halte. Salustius.
Claudus, a, um, lame. Clauicula, a little kay or clubbe. Clauicularius, he
that bears the kayes. Clauiculus, the tendrelle of a vine. Clauiger, idem
quod clauicularius. Clauis, a kaye. Claustrarius, a maker of kayes and locks.
Claustrinus, a keeper of the cloister, or of any other place, wherein any living
thing is enclosed. Claustrum, a cloister, or other place, where any living
thing is enclosed. Clausula, a little sentence, or a part of a sentence.
Clausura, a shutting in. Clauus, a nail. Also the stern of a ship. Also a
corn on a man's toe or fingar. Moreover, Claui be little swellynges of hard
flesh in the corner of men's eien. Also puffes growing in the stemmis of great
trees. Also in harneys, that which is called the river. Moreover Clauus is a
garment pirled or powdered with spangles, like nails heedes. wherefore the
propre garmente of a Senator was called Iatus clauus. Clazomenae, a city of
Iome, which Paralus builded. Clazomenia, an ylande, which is called
Marathusa. Cleantes, the name of a philosopher, which succeeded Zeno in his
schole. Clearchus, the name of a philosopher. there was a noble capytayne of
the same name, of whom Xenophon writes in the expedition of Cyrus the less.
Clemens, it is, merciful. Clemencia, mercy. Clementer, mercyfully. Cleobulus,
the name of oone of the seven wise men of Greece. Cleodamas, the name of a
geometrician in the time of Plato. Cleombrotus, the son of Pausanias,
captain of the Lacedemons. Cleopatra, the name of a lady queen of Egypt.
Clepo, psi, pere, to stele. Clepsydra, a dyall, which dyuided the hours by the
rounnynge of a certain measure of water. It was also the name of a fountain
in Athenes. Cleronoma, heritage. Cleronomos, an heir. Clerus, chosen by lotte.
Also a worm, which distroyeth and corrupts honey co^bes. Clibanarius, he
that fyghtethe in iustynge harnayse. Clibanus, an oue^, or the mouth of a
furneis. Cliens, it is, a clyent or servant retained. Clientela, the nombre of
clyentes or of servants retained, also their office or duty. Clientularium,
an yearly fee, for counsel, or assystence. Clima, it is, is a portion of the
world between south and north, wherein is variacyon of time in the length of
the day, the space of half an hour, which is set out in the tables and
chartes of Cosmography Climacterius, ca, cu^, signifies the degrees of man's
life by seven years, in the which he is in danger of death or mysfortune.
Climactericum tempus, the said daungerouse time. Climacterum, idem. Climax, a
ladder, and the figure callydde gradation. Clinicus, a physician, that heals
with medicines. Also he that is so syck, that he can not arise out of his
bed. Clinopodion, an herb. Clinopale, wrastlynge in the bed. Clio, the
name of one of the mu^^s. Clisis, declynation. Clitellae, a packesaddell. Also
the name of a place in Rome. Clitellarii, packehorses of mules, that do serve
for caryage. Clitomaclius, the name of a philosopher. Clitorius, a fountain in
Greece. Clitumnus, a river in Italy. Cloaca, a synke, whereby water passethe, or
gutter. Cloris, a maiden or nymphe, which was married to Zephyrus, unto whom
was assygned for her dower, to have reuie over flowers. Clotho, one of the
fatal ladies, having power over man's life, in dyssoluynge thereof. Cludo,
si, dear, to shytte. Cluo, ui, ere, to contend or fight. Clumae, the husk of
barley. Clunaculum, a bowchers choppyng knife. Clupea, a cite of Affrike, next
to Cartage. Clunes, the buttockes or haunehes. Clymene, the mother of
Promotheus, daughter of Oceanus. Clypeus, a shield or targate of fotemen,
Clismus, a pourgation or washing. Clytemnestra, the wife of Agamemnon.
Clyster, eris, and Clysterium, a glyster.

COacesco, coacesci, coacescere, to wax all sour. Coaetaneus, of one age.
Coagmento, taui, rare, to join together, or make like. Coagulo, aui, are, to
gather into a kourde or cream. Coagulum, curde or cream. Coalesco, coalui,
coalescere, to gather together, to increase. Coarcto, aui, are, to strain or
press together. Coasso, to planke or bourde. Coaxare, to make a noise like a
frogge or tode. Cocalus, a king of Sycile, to whom Dedalus fled out of
Creta, whom Minos king of Crete pursued. Coccentum, a meat made of honye and
popye sede. Cocceus, a, um, et Coccineus, a, um, of scarlette color. Coccina,
a scarlette vesture. Coccinus, et Coccus, scarlette color. Coccum, grain
wherewith cloth and silk is grayned. Cochlea, a snayle, sometime the shelle,
sometime cokles. Also a winding staire or vyse. Cochleare, a spone. Cochlium, a
wyndynge stayre. Cochlides, round ladders. Coclites, a man, having but one
eye. Coctie, a part of the mountayns of Alps. Coctilis, hoc coctile, soden or
baken. Coctito, aui, are, to boil. Coctiuus, a, um, easy to be boiled.
Coctonum, cotton. Coctus, ta, tum, sodden enough. Coculum, a pot to boil in.
sommetyme cocula do sygnyfie styckes, which will soon be on fire. Cocus, a
Cook. Cocynthum, a mountain in Italy, that divides two sees. Cocytia,
sacrifices that were done in honor of Proserpine. Cocytus, a river of Hell.
Coccis, igis, a bird called a cocowe. Coda, a tail. Codarremula, a bird
callydde a wagge tail. Codex, icis, the body of a tree, or a great book or
volume. Codicillus, a lybell. Codiculus, a dyminutife of codex, when it is put
for a book. Codonia, an yland, that the almayns keep. Codius, the propre name
of a king of Athenes, which to save his country, willingly lost his life.
Coeliacus, he that is sick of the colycke. Coemeterium, a church yard.
Coena, a soupper. Coenacularia, the way or craft to ordain a supper.
Coenaculariam facere, to let a house in diverse parts to sundry persons,
wherein are many parlers or drinking houses. Coenacularius, he that does let
such houses to hyre. Vlp. de pignor. act. l. Solutum. Coenaculum, a parler, or
other place where men do soupe. Coenaticus, ca, cum, pertaining to suppers.

endeavor my self to soupe. Coenipera, a goer about to suppers vnbode^. Coeno,

commune. Coenula, a light soupper. Caenum, myer. Coeo, iui, ire, to come
together with other, to join to, to draw together, to gather together, to do

straight, to compel or constrayn. Coetus, an assembly of people. Cogitatim,
aduysedly. Cogito, aui, are, to think. Cogitatio, onis a thought. Cognati,
kynnesmen. Cognitor, oris, he that pleads an another man's cause, his clyent
being present. Cognobilis, known. Cognomen, a surname, which a man has of
his auncetours. Cognomines, diverse men of one surname. Cognomino, aui, are, to
give a surname. Cognosco, noui, noscere, to know, to consider, to understand,
to lie with a woman, to judge a matter, or here a mattier to judge it. Cogo,
coegi, cogere, to constrayne, to gather to gyther, to milk a beast, to make
lycour thycke or hard, to press into, to set or bring in order. Cohibeo, ui,
ere, to restrain, to keep of, to let. Cohors, it is, a company of men of
war, a court wherein pultrie is kept. Cohortor, aris, ari, to exhort.

togider. Coinquino, aui, are, to soil, or make foul. Cois, a garment of fine
sylke. Colaphizo, aui, are, to buffette. Colaphus et colaphum, a buffette.

conferring together. Collatis signis pugnare, to fight in a field pyghte.

that which is gathered. Collega, a fellow or companyon in office. Colliculus, a

together. Seipsum colligere, Ci. Tus. 4
to bring home again the parts of the mind, that were dispersed. Also to
prepare. Virgilius.
Se colligit in arma, he made him ready to fight. Colligo, aui, are, to bind
together. Collimare, to wynke with one eye. Collina porta, a yate at Rome.
Collino, to line, or lay by line. Collis, a hylle. also colles the back.

Colluuies, when the earth is covered with water by greatte floodes. Collutilo,
aui, are, to defyle. Collyrida, a cake. Collyrium, a medicine for soore eyes.
Colo, aui, are, to strain out lycour. Cola, a streynour. Colo, ui, ere, to
worship, to love, or favor, to haunte, to inhabyte or dwell, to lead, Hanc
uitam colo, I lead this life. to tylle, or husband ground. Colobium, a
iacket or cote without sleues. Colocasia, a bean of Egypt. Colochynta, a
fruit which purges fleme. Colon, a gutte, which goth from the left side unto
the right, in the which the dunge takes his form, and there is the disease
called Colica, the colyke. It is also a membre or part of a sentence. Colonia,
people sent to dwell in a place, which is not inhabyted. Also a house of
husbandrye. Colonicus, ca, cum, pertaining to housbandrye. Colonus, a
husbandemanne. also coloni be they, which are sent to inhabyte a country or
town. Also a high place in Athenes, where Neptune was worshypped. Colophon,
onis, the name of an isle: and also of a city in Greece. Colophonem addere, to
make an end, or fynishe a warke. Color, oris, color. Coloriae uestes,

a serpent, which lies in the shadow of woddes. Colum, a strayner. Columbar,
aris, a pyllory. Columbaris, et hoc columbare, of a dove. Columbarium, uel
columbaria, a douehouse or culuerhouse. Columbatim, in the manner of doves.
Columbarius, he that takes doves. Columbaria, an ylande in the Tuskayn see.
Columbus, et columba, a culuer or dove. Columbinus, a, um, of a culuer.
Columella, the name of oone that wrate of husbandry most eloquently.
Columellares dentes, cheke tethe. Columen, luminis, the succor or stay, the
wind beam of a house. Columis et hoc colume, hole. Columna, a royal city in
Bruce. Columna, a pyllar. Columnus, was in old time that we call now culmus.
Coluri, certain cerkles in the celestialle Sphere. Colus, a distaffe.

Collybistes, an exchaunger. Collybia, fygge tartes, fartes of Portyngall, or
other like things. Coma, all the hear together called a bushe Comagena, a
country in Syria. Comare, to have much hear, or a great busshe. Comatus,
ta, he or she that has a greatte bushe. By translation it is said of trees
or herbs, that have long leaves or flowers. Comata, a shepardes name in
Theoer. Comata Gallia, all France, a this half the mountains. Comatulus, a
boy with a fair busshe of hear. Combino, aui, are, to combyne or confederate
together. Comburo, bussi, burere, to burn or consume with fire. Come, an herb
called gotes bearde. Comedo, edi, edere, to eat. Comedo, donis, he that
consumes his own goods ryotrously. Comes, mitis, a companyon or fellow. Also
a name of dignity, which we call an earl. Comessatio, a bankette after soupper.
Comessari, to bankette. Comessabundus, vsyng to bankette. Cometes et cometa, a
blasynge sterre. Comis, gentle, full of good humanity. Comiter, gentylly.
Comitatus, tus, a felowshyppe. Comitialis dies, the day when people assembled
at Rome, for the election of officers. Comitialis morbus, the falling sycknes.
Comitium, a congregation or assemble of the people for election of officers.
Also the place where the election is made. Comitor, aris, to accompanye or goo
with one, or keep fellowship with other. Comma, a point ending a sentence, where
many sentences be: as, Nihil tibi profuit nocturnum praesidium palacii, nihil
urbis uigiliae, nihil timor populi, nihil concursus omnium bonorum: There is
Comma four times. Commanducatus cibus, chewed meat. Commanducate, to chewe
meat. Commeat^s, tus, a saulfe conduct, or leave to depart. sometime vytailes
for an army or multitude of men. sommetyme for a passage of men. Commemoro,
aui, are, to remember. Commendaticius, a, um, that wherewith a man is remembered
or recommended. Commendo, aui, are, to commend or praise, sometime to
recommende. Commentaculum, a marshals or huyshers rod. Commentor, tatis, to
think on, to make mencyon, to dispute, to write commentaries, or books for
remembrance. Commentarium, uel commentarius, a brigement or other book,
containing things briefly written. Also it signifies a comment. Also a book
of remembrance or a Register or exposition. Commenticius, a, um, feigned, or
devised for the time. Commentum, a comment or exposition, a matter feigned.
Commeo, aui, are, to go hither and thider, or to go to, or with an other.
Commertium, an intercourse or liberty to carry marchandyse from one place to an
other. Also a commutation or form of bieng and selling together. Also a
famylyarytie or custom. Commereo, ui, ere, to commytte. Si senserit ^e timidum
pater, arbitrabitur commeruisse culpam, If thy father do perceyuethe to be
aferde, he woll suppose, that thou art gyltie, Terent. in Phor.
or haste committed the offense. Also commerere, to deserve. Q. Curtius
Commessari, to feed more than enough. Commigro, to goo with one to a place.
Co^militones, fellows together in wars. Commilitium, fellowship in wars.
Comminiscor, sceris, to call to remembrance. Comminus, forthewith at hand,
hand to hand. Commissura, a joint of any thing that is closed and opened, as
proprely of tables, which be joined. Commitigo, gaui, gare, to knock.
Tere^tius.
Tibi uti co^mitigari uideam sandalio caput, That I may see the knocked on the
heed with his slypper. Committo, misi, mittere, to commyt, or inioyne, to
offend, to join together. Also to do and begin. Salustius.
Quibus dictis mox praeliu^ commisere, That spoken, they began battle. Also to
deliver, to compare, to bring in contencion, to put together, to confiscate or
sease for a forfayture. Ci. in Ver. act. 3.
Commodata res, a thing lend without advantage. Commodatarius, he that
takes a thing of lone, he that boroweth. Commoditas, tatis, a commodity.
Commodo, aui, are, to do for an other man's commodity. Also to lend.
Commodum, profit or commodity. Also good, apt, or conueniente. sometime it
is an aduerbe, and than it sygnifieth the same time, in good time, scarsely.
Commodum discesseras heri, cum Trebatius uenit, Thou were scasely departed,
when Trebatius was come. Commodus, a, um, profitable, or apt. Commoereo,
rui, rere, to be all heavy or sorry. Commonefacio, feci, facere, to warn.
Commoneo, nui, ere. Idem. Commotria, a maiden that does array or apparayle her
maystresse. Commoueo, ui, ere, to trouble, to turn or change a man's mind. to
hurt. sometime to depart. Tu et cura, ut ualeas, et te istinc ne temere
commoueas. Farewell, and take heed that thou depart not hense to hastily. Ci.
Ty^^,
Communico, aui, are, to communicate or depart some thing with an another,
which I have. Communis, commune, common. Commuto, aui, are, to change one
thing for an other. Commutare uerba, to chyde, or to give a shrewde word for
a good. Como, psi, ere, to apparayle gorgiously, to trymme, proprely it
belongs to women. Comoedia, an interlude, wherein the common vices of men and
womenne are apparently declared in personages. Comoedice, gentylly and
pleasantly. Comoedior, aris, to ieste, or scoff. Comoedus, a player in
enterludes. Comicus, a maker of enterludes. Compactum, an agreement or
appoyntme^t Compagino, aui, are, to put or join together a thing that is
lowsed. Co^pago, ginis, a ioining together of things. Compa^, aris, equal, or
even like, Comparatiuus, a, um, comparatiue, wherein begins excess
incomparyson. Comparo, aui, are, to compare or make equal, or more, to
ordeyne, to prepare, to join, to deuyse, to bye. Comparatio, comparyson,
preparation, or byenge, Compasco, to feed or keep cattle. Compascuus ager, a
common field. Compedes, gyues or fetters. Compeditus, a, um, fettred or gyued.
Compello, pull, pellere, to compelle or constrayne, to join or bring
together. Compello, aui, are, to speak to, to accuse. Compendiarius, a, um,
co^pendious or brefe. Compendiosus, a, um, very profitable. Compendium, a
saving or sparyng, or advantage, a compendious or short form in wrytinge
or other act. Compendifacio, to make compendious. Compenso, aui, are, to make
recompense, or amends. Compensatio, onis, a recompense, or satisfaction.
Co^perendino, to defer, or put of, or delay. Comperendinatio, a delay.
Comperendinaria dies, a day over in matters of law. Comperio, ii, ire, to
know of an other man. Comperior, iris, to find, or imagine in mine own
opinion. Compertus furti, founden gyltie of felony. Compertum habeo, I know or
perceive. Compernis, he that has his knees nyghe to gither, or long fete.
Compesco, scui, scere, to assuage, to mitigate Competo, tii, tere, to ask, or
sue for an office, or other like thing against an other that does the
semblable. Competit, It is mete or couenient. Hoc illi competit, That is mete
or conueniente for him. Also it is suffycyent. Compilo, aui, are, to take by
extorcyon or wrong, or as the vulgar speech is, Compilare is to polle and
shave. Compilati, polled by extorcion. Compingo, pegi, pingere, to thruste.
Quid faciam nunc, si tres uiri me in carcerem compegerint? How shall I do
now, if the officers thruste me into prison. Sommetyme Compingere is to
compact, or put togider. Compita, many paths going into oone way,
Compitalia, feasts or drynkynges, made where as be many paths. Compitalicius,
cia, um, belonging to the said feasts. Complector, eris, to embrace or hold
strait Complector te amore, I love the ba^ttlye. Complector cogitatione, I
bear in mind. Complector animo, I consider. Compleo, eui, are, to fulfylle, or
fill to the top, to fynyshe, or perform, to make up. or supply that lacks.
Complex, plicis, partener, co^panyon in act. Complexus, imbracynge or collynge.
Also agreement in words or sentences. Complico, aui, are, to fold or wrappe
together. Complodo, si, dear, to clappe together the hands for joy. Complura,
right many. Compluries, very often. Compluuium, a gatter, wherein fallyth rain
from many houses. Compono, to put or ioyn together, to make ordeine, or
dispose. Also to compare, to adorn, to gather, to recreate, to appease, to
conclude, to accord or agree, to redeem, to dissemble or feign. Compos, potis,
he that has his purpose or desire. also ever content. Compos animi, of sownde
remembrance, not mad. Compos uoti, he that has his own desire or appetite.
Compositio, onis, a making, an ornament, a composition or agreement.
Compraedes, sureties or pledges together. Co^primo, pressi, primere, to press
or thrust together, to hold or refrain. Also to defloure a woman. Compressus,
a defloration or rauyshement. Comptus, tus, fresh apparayle. Compulsus, a, um,
compellyd or hytte with any thing. Compunctus, a, um, marked, or spotted.
Compungo, xi, gere, to punche, or prycke, or stryke. Computo, aui, are, to
deem, to accounte, to decerne, to impute. Comum, a city of France on this side
the mountains, the inhabytantes whereof are called comenses.
C ante N.
COncateno, aui, are, to bind together with chains. Concauus, a, um, holowe.
Concedo, cessi, dear, to grant, to permit or suffer, to depart away, to go
to a place, to consent. Concentus, tus, a consent, many voices in one tune,
or accord in musyke. Concept^culum, or conceptab^ilu^, any thing holowe and
apt to receive or hold, as a vessel. Concepta uerba, words expressed and
pronounced. Conceptus, ta, tum, conceived. Conceptus, tus, a conception of a
child within a woman. And also a conceyte or thing conceived in thought.
Concernere, to concern. Concertatum, debated in reasonynge. Concha, proprely a
muskle. sometime the shell of a muskle, oyster, or cockle. Also every vessel
that is holow, and open above, proprely a bolle, wherein lynnen clothes be
washed. sometime a wine vessel. Also a trumpet, as it semethe made of earth,
like to such as the poor men do use, which have the falling sycknes, and do
come from the place in Ducheland, called saint Cornelius. Conchis, a meat made
of beans. Conchon, is called a vessel of the greeks, or the holownes of the
eyes. Conchus, a perle. Conchile, and conchilium, a kind of shelle fyshe, out
of the which a lycour is taken, wherewith sylke is dyed purple. it is sometime
taken for the purple color. Conchiliata uestis, a purple garmente. Concido,
cidi, ere, cisum, to cut in pieces, to die. Caesar. Concido, concidi, ere,
concasum, to fall down all together. Et muri ciuitatum concidem, (...).
And the walls of all cities shall fall all together. Conciliabulum, a counsel
house. Conciliabundus, he that is redye to give counsel. Consiliatrix, a
woman that endeavors her to make agreemente between men and their wives.
Concilio, aui, are, to accord or make friends together. Conciliare
affinitatem, uel pacem, to make alyance or peace. Conciliare odium, uel
inimicitias, to get hatred or displeasure. Concilium, counsel, or the
assemblye of counsaylours. Concinnitudo, dinis, aptenes, or proprenes.
Concinno, aui, are, to make apt, or propre, or fytte. Concinnus, a, um, apt,
fytte, propre. Concinere, to agree in one song, or one tune. Concio, ciui, cire,
to call together a multitude. Concio, onis, a pulpet or stage, wherein he
stands that exhorts people. Also an assembly or congregation of people,
called together, to here the commandment of the king, or other in authorytye
in the weal publyque. Also it is the oration or proposition made unto them,
called a co^cion. Concionalis, he that is wont to make orations or propositions
to the people. Concionatorius, ria, rium, pertayninge to a Concyon. Concionor,
aris, ari, to preach or purpose a matter to the people. Concionator, oris, he
that preachethe or purposes an oration. Concipio, coepi, cipere, to conceive
or apprehende, to delyberate, or determyne in mind. Concipere iusiurandu^, to
swear in recyting the oath, as it is ministered. Concito, aui, are, to steer.
Conclamatum est, it is at a point, or paste remedy. Conclaue, a privy or
secret chamber. sometime a bankettynge chamber. Concludo, clusi, dear, to
conclude or make an end. Conclusio, onis, a conclusyon or end of a mattier.
Concordare, to be at a co^corde or agreement. Concoquo, coxi, concoquere, to
digest. Concordia, concord or agreement. Concorporo, aui, are, to make one
thing of diverse. Concors, dis, of one will or mind. Concrepare, to make a
greatte noise, or to creke, as a door does in the openyng. Concretum,
congeled or conglutinate. Concubitor, oris, he that medlethe with a womanne.
Concubium, the first sleep in the night, or the depest of the night.
Concumbo, bui, concumbere, et concubo, aui, are, to lie together, to accompany
together, in the act of generation. Concupisco, piui, piscere, to coueyte or
desire fervently. Concupiscentia, a fervent desire or appetite carnal.
Concutio, tii, tere, to shake. Condecet, it well becomes. Condecenter,
agreably. Condecentia, a besemynge. Condemno, aui, are, to condemn. Condecoro,
aui, are, to make cleanly, or honest, to polyshe. Condico, xi, cere, to
appoint, to ordeyn, to promise, to ask again, to deny, to assign by mouth,
to denounce, or declare. Tit, ^^. ^^.
Condictio, onis, an action in the law, or appointment to a day certain.
Condictum, a promise. Condio, iui, uel dij, dire, to season meat, to powder,
or otherwise order it, to preserve it from corruption. Condimentum, that
wherewith things be preserved from corruption, or else made dilectable in
taste. Conditaneus, a, um, that which is to be preserved. Conditio, onis,
Condition, fortune, estate, election, or choice. Conditionem accepit, He took
the bargain or promise, or he agreed. Condititia cibaria, powderid meat, or
other wise preserved. Conditiuus, a, um, that which may be powdered or kept.
Conditor, oris, A maker. Conditorium, a Sepulcher, a place wherein ordinance
for war is kept. Condo, didi, dear, to lay saulfe, or hyde. sometime to
make, or build. Ci. Tus. lib. 5.
Condocefaceo, foeci, facere, to make to know. Condris, an herb, called false
dittayn, by cause it is like dyttayne, but it has less leaves. Conducibile,
profitable. Conduco, xi, cere, to bring with me, to hyre, to take a house or
land. also to gather, to convert. Conducere, to profit. Conducit, it is
profitable. Conductitius, a, um, that which may be hired or taken, or is used
to be hired. Condalium, a ring. Condyloma, atis, a swellynge in the fundement,
sometime hard, sometime soft. Condylos, the knuckle of a finger. Confecta,
things voyded or concluded by reason. Confercio, to stuff, or porre.
Confertus, ta, tum, gathered as people be gathered in a prease, thycke set.
Confertissima turba, in the thyckest prease. Confero, tuli, far, to put
together, to set forth, Plautus.
to prepare, to put in. Ne posterius in me culpam conferas, Put not at the last
the defaut in me. Consilia conferunt, They keep their counsels together. To lay
to, or join. Nouissima conferam primis, Terentius
I will lay to, or join the last to the first. Confer, to profit.
Confer in pauca, To conclude shortly. Columella
Also confer, to lay together. Sitque uttique proximum horreum, quo
conferatur rusticum instrumentu^, To both, next there must be a barn, wherein
may be laid up together instruments longyng to husbandry. Also Confero, I
give. Multa contuli in Catonem, I have given or attribute much to Cato, I have
favored much Cato. Contuli me domum, I went home. Contuli me ad Catonem, I
went unto Cato. Conferua, an herb which grows in fresh waters like to a
sponge. Confessor, oris, a confessor. Confestim, eftesoones. Conficio, eci,
ficere, to perform or finyshe, Lacta^tius.
to perish or be consumed, to distroy or sle, to explicate or declare.
Honestatis pars co^fecta est, qua^ tibi cupio esse notissimam, The part of
honesty is declared, which I would should be unto the perfitely known. Cic.
offic.
Also to bring to pass, Si me amas, co^fice, If thou love me, bring it to
pass. Also to gather money. Permagnam dices ex illa re pecunia^ confici posse,
Thou wylt say, that a great sum of money might be made of that thing.
Conficere to break. Plinius.
Nucem dentibus conficere, To break a nutte with his tethe. Also to consume or
waste. Terentius
Qui cum hic non uideant me, credant me conficere argentum suum, who because
they se me not bear they believe I waste their money. Also Confici, to be made.
Quomodo potest ex multorum deorum aceruo unus deus confici? By what means may
there be of a heap of gods one only god made? Co^fido, di, dear, to trust,
to be sure, to dare. Confidens, it is, he that regards no laws, nor fears
any thing. sometime it sygnyfieth constant, assured. Confidenter, constantly,
assuredly, sometime hardily, boldly, aduenturously. Confinis hoc confine, next
to or adjoining. Confinium, a border or march of a country or land. Confit,
it is made to gither. Confiscare, to sease for a forfaiture. Confiteor, eris,
to confess. Conflages, places, wherinto many wyndes do blow. Conflare, to
blow together, to blow like as one blows the fire. Conflata pecunia, money
coined. Conflare mendacium, to imagine a lie. Conflare inuidiam, inimicitias,
odium, to stire or procure envy, hostility, hate. Conflauit aes alienum, he is
run in debt. Also Conflare, to gather. Conflauit ex his omnibus populum, Of
all those he gathered a great multitude. Also to make. Et cur uae rigidum
falces conflantur in ensem, Vergilius.
And the crooked sith into the hard sword is made. Conflatile, that which is
apt to be wrought like metal. Conflicto, aui, are, to fight often.
Conflictor, aris, ari, to be vexed or troubled, to fight. Confligo, fligi,
gere, to fight as men do in battle. Confluere, to come or run to gether,

hoc conform, of a conformity or like in facion, conueniente. Conforto, aui,
are, to comfort. Confugio, fugi, gere, to flee with other. Confundo, fudi,

vaynquyshe by words. Also to steer. Congedus, a River in Spain, nere to a
town called Bilbilis. Congenulo, aui, are, to knele. Congero, gessi, ere, to
gather to gyther, or heap up. Congiatium, An alms, or other lyberalle
gift, given by the prince unto his people, be it in money corn or vitayles.
Congius, a certain measure, wherein Sextarius is six times, and the lycour
therein contained wayeth ten pound. Conglobare, to bring or come round
together. Congratulor, aris, ari, to rejoice with a another man of his good
fortune. Congredior, eris, gredi, to go with an other to fight, or dispute.
Congressus, us, A battle. Congrex, of the same flock. Congruo, grui, ere, to
agree. Congruum, Agreeable. Co^grus, and Co^ger, A fish called a Conger.
Coniectarium, effectual, or parfyte. Coniecto, aui, are, to suppose, to judge.

what shall happen. Coniectura, A conjecture. Coniecturale, that which is
coniectid, or gathered by conjecture. Coniectus, us, a certain direction of
rayson unto the truth. Conifera arbor, a tree which bears fruits being
smaller at the one end than at the other, like a pyne appull. Conijcio, ieci,
ijcere, to cast to coniecte. Coniecit se in fugam, He put him to flyghte.
Coniicere in uincula, To cast into prison, or to lay a man in the stocks or
gyues. Coniecit se intro, He went his way in. Coniecit se in pedes, He took him
to flight, he took him to his legs. Coniicere tela, to cast darts, or to
shoot. Coniicere in letitiam, to bring to a gladness. Coniugalis thorus, the
chamber where the busbande and wife do lie. Co^iugo, aui, are, to yoke
together, or mary. Coniugium, marriage. Coniungo, xi, ere, to join together.
Coniunx, iugis, A wife. Coniugus, a, um, that which joins. Coniuro, aui,
are, to co^sure or conspire with other for an ill purpose. Coniuiatio, a
Conspiracye. Conniueo, and Co^niuo, is, iui, uel xi, to wink, and is used to
be spoken, when men wol let things pass, that ought to be looked on.
Connubium, matrimony. Conoides, the female of the Cipresse tree. Conon, nis,
the name of a king of Athenes. Conopoeum, A Canapy, proprely such one as
hangs over beds, and is wroughte like a net, to keep out gnattes, which do
stynge men in their beds. Co^quinisco, co^quexi, co^quiniscere, to ducke with
the heed. Consalutare, to salute one an other. Consanguineus, Coseyne.
Consanguinitas, tatis, Kynred. Conscendo, di, dear, to klyme. Conscientia,
Conscience. Conscisco, sci, scere, to consent, determyne, or grant to a
mattier wyllynglye. Consciscere mortem, To kill wylfully. Conscius, conscia,
that knowith with an other. Conscius sceleris, party or privy to the offense,
accessarye. Conscribo, psi, bear, to write things together. Conscripti, they
whose names be written or registered to supply a number, which do lack: or
such as be new chosen or added unto the other. Consecranei, Tertullianus.
such as be dedycate to one sect or opinyon. Co^secro, craui, are, to
dedicate or consecrate. Consectanei, they which be of one sect. Consector,
aris, to follow all together. Consensio, A Consent or accord of one mind or
purpose. Consentio, tii, tire, to Consent. Consentaneus, a, um, agreeable.
Conseptum, An enclosure or place enclosed, Conseptus, ta, tum, enclosed.
Consequentia, things which do follow or ensue. Consequiae, sequeles.
Consequor, to follow immediately, to optain, or get, to express. Verbis consequi
non possunt, They may not be expressed in words. Conserere manu^, to fight
hand to hand. Consero, seui, serere, to sow or set herbs together.
Consessus, sus, Men sitting together. It may be taken for a sessyons or
sitting of men, which be commissioners. Consido, sidi, dear, to sytte or
abide together. It may be used to sytte at a sessyons. Consiliarius, a
counselor. Consilio, iui, uel, lui, lire, to leap together. Consilior, aris,
to take counsel. Consilium, a counsel. It may be taken for commyssioners or
judges assigned. Cic. pro Ros^.
Consisto, stiti, sistere, to stand fast or sure, to abide boldly by a
thing. Consistorium, a counsel house, specially in a princis palace.
Consobrini, cousyns germains of two brethren or two systers. Consolabundus, he
that comfort a man. Consolida, the name of an herb, called Confery.
Consolor, aris, ari, to give comfort, or take comfort. Consono, nui, are, to
make one sown together. Also to accord or agree. Consors, it is, a fellow or
companyon, some time it sygnifieth like. Consortium, fellowship or company.
Conspicio, spexi, cere, to see or behold. Conspicilium, a lowpe to look out
of a house, or wall. Conspicilia, spectakles. Conspico, spexi, ere, and
Conspicor, aris, ari, to behold. Conspicuus, a, um, circumspect, wytty, or of
a sharp and quycke wit. Also apparent or plain to perceive. Conspi^o, aui,
are, to conspire or consent. Also to blow together. Conspiratio, nis, a
conspiracye. Constantinopolis, Constantinople, a city in Thrace. Consternium,
a place where men, when they were bayned, laid their garments. Consterno,
aui, sternere, to throw down, or overthrow. Consternati, men overthrown,
sometime abashed. Consternatio, tionis, an abashement. Consterno, straui,
sternere, to straw, to paue. Constituo, stirui, stituere, to ordeyne, to
govern, to provide, to covenant, to form. Cicero.
Corpus been constitutum, A body well co^plexioned. Constitutio corporis, the
complexion. Constitutio causae, which our lawyers do call the matter in law.
Constitutus, ta, tum, ordained. Consto, stiri, stare, to persyste or abide in a
thing. Constat animo, He is of a steadfast mind. Constat pedibus, He is sure
of his feet, or hoole. ^is^ania.
Constat, it costeth, it is sold for. Constare, to stand together, to be
manyfeste or known, to agree. Constan^, it is, constant or steadfast.
Constanter, constantly. Constantia, constance, or stedfastenes. Construo,
struxi, struere, to build, to ordain. Consuesco, sueui, suescere, to be
wont. Terentiu^
sometime to use carnallye. Cum eius consueuit matre clanculum, He had company
with his mother priuelye. Also to use for a custom. sometime to live. Columel^.
Nec magis humo quam stagno consueuerunt, They live as well on land, as on
water. Consuetudo, dinis, custom or usage. Also carnal company. Consuefacio,
to accustom. Consul, lis, a chief officer among the Romans. Consularis, He
that had been consulle, or were mete to be consul. Consulatus, tus, the
office of Consul. Consulo, lui, sulere, with a datyue case, to give counsel:
with an accusative case, to ask counsaylle. Also with a dative case, it
sygnifieth to provide, to help to. Grauiter de se consulere, To do sum
hurt to him self. Consulto, taui, tare, to give or ask counsel often, to
delyberate or show mine advise often. Consulto, delyberately, or aduysedly.
Consultor, toris, he that gives counsel, sometime he that asks counsel.
Consultus, ta, tum, a wise man. Consultus, tus, and Consultum, the thing that
is consulted. Sometime an act of counsaylle. Consummo, aui, are, to sum up
in a recknynge, to fynishe or perform, or make up, or make perfect.
Consummatus, ta, tum, perfyte, at a point. Consumo, sumpsi, sumere, to
consume, or distroye. Consuo, ui, ere, to sow together, or join. Consyderate,
with a consyderation. Consyderatus, he that does a thing with consyderation.
Consydero, aui, are, to consider. Contabulari, to bourde, or to lay bourdes on
a roufe or flower. Contagium, and Contagio, Contagionis, and Contages, an
infectiue syckenesse. Contamino, taminaui, taminare, to vyolate, or defyle,
with myxtynge things together, to dishoneste. Contemno, contempsi, contemnere,
to dispyse, or contempne, which is less than despysynge. Contemptus, tus,
despyte. Contemplatio, onis, a beholdynge, specially in the mind with devotion
to god. Contemplo, aui, and contemplor, aris, to behold intentifely with great
affection. Contemporanei, they which be at one time. Contemptibilis, bile, he
that is to be despised, or not regarded. Contemptor, aris, to set little by.
Contendo, di, dear, to contend, or resyste, or strive, to cast or shote a
darte or arow: to continue, to make haste, to enforce. Contentio, onis,
resystence, strife, or debate. Also a sharp oration apt to confirm or
repreue, a continuance, an inforcement or setting forth with vehemence.
Contentus, ta, tum, that which is contained. also content or satisfied.
Contineo, nui, ere, to contayn, to withhold, to let. Conterraneus, country
man. Contestari, to ask together witness. Conticeo, ticui, ceere, to hold my
peace with other. Conticesco, idem. Conticimum, bed time, or the first part
of night, when men prepare to take their test, and all thing is in silence.
Contigno, aui, are, to raufter a house. Contignatio, onis, the raufterynge.
Continens, it is, firm land, that is none i will. also centynuall. Continenter,
continually, contynentely, or fyrmely. Continentia, continence, a virtue,
refusing things that are pleasant. Also resistance of ylle. Contineo, nui,
ere, to refrain, to keep back, to contain, to keep together. Contingo, tigi,
tingere, to touch. Contigit, It has happened. Continuo, aui, are, to continue.
Continuus, a, um, contynuall. Continue, contynually. Contor, aris, to abide.
Contorie res, things wounden and twysted. Also such matter, as oone part can
not agree with an other. Contra, again a place, a person, or a thing on the
other part. Contracto, aui, are, to attain, or comprehend. Contradico, dixi,
dicere, to contrary in wordis, to say contrary. Contraeo, to goo contrary or
against a thing. Contraho, traxi, trahere, to gather together. Contrahere aes
alienum, To be indetted, to commytte, to make a contracte or bargayne, to draw
together. Contrahere, to shrynke. Nerui contrahuntur, the synewes be shrunken.
Contrahere frontem, to lowre. Bona contracta, goods gotten by conqueste.
Contrarius, a, um, contrary. Contrauenio, ire, to happen contrary, come
contrary. Controuersia, a controversy or variance. Controuersiosus,
lytigious, or full of controuersye. Controuersor, aris, to contend or vary.
Controuersus, a, um, contrary, or in contrary wise. Res controuersa, matter in
controuersye. Contubernium, a fellowship or a company. Contubernalis, a fellow
or companyon, or of one company. Contumax, macis, di^^bedient, or froward in
opinyon, he that will not be persuaded. Contumacia, dysobedyence, a self will,
or frowardenes. Contumelia, a reproach, a thing done or spoken to a man's
rebuke. Contumeliosus, he that uses to speak rebukefully. Contundo, tudi,
tundere, to break to pieces, or stryke down. Contuosi oculi, eien loking
narowe. Contus, a long spear or morys pike. also a long pole with iron at
the end, wherewith shypmen do gauge the water. Conuallis, a valey having
hills on both sides. Conuaso, aui, are, to gather by stelthe. Conuenae,
people assembled of diverse countries, dwelling in one country or town.
Conuenientia, a congruence. Also a coming together of people. Conuenire, to
come together, or to assemble in one place. Also to agree, to sewe at the law,
or bring in judgment. Also to determine, to speak with one, to accord.
Conuenit inter me atque hu^c, it is agreed between him and me, De pretio
conuenit, we are agreed of the price, In manu^ conuenit, She is my wife.
Conuentae, couenantes of marriage. Conuenticulum, a congreation, most commonly
for an ill purpose. Conuentio, onis, and conuentu^, a covenant. Conuentus, an
assembly of people, warned by the chief officers commandment. Conuentus
maximus, may be taken for a parlyament. Minores conuentus, sessions of the
peace. Conuersor, aris, to be conuersaunt. Co^uersatio, conversation or
familiarity. Conuerto, uerti, tere, to convert, or turn. Conuexum, the
outward part and rou^denes of a thing that is holowe. Conuicinium, a
neyborhode. Conuicior, aris, ari, to speak in reproach. Conuicium, a reproach
or rebuke. Conuictor, oris, a daily companyon at table, or a daily geste.
Conuiualis, le, pertaining to feasts. Conuiuor, aris, ari, to feast or
bankette, or to take meals with other men. Conuiuator, toris, a feaster or
banketter. Conuiua and conuictor, a beden gest, he that is invited or beden to
dinner or supper. Conuiuium, a feast or bankette. Conuoluolus, a little worm
with many feet and heary, that eats the leaves of vynes. Also an herb
runnynge up by bushes, having a flower like to a lyly, but it has no
sauoure. peradventure that which is called withwynde. Conuoti, sworn
brethren, or men making one auowe or promise. Conus, proprely the pyneapple
tree, by translation it is a figure in facion like to a pyne appull. Also the
crest of an helmet or salet. Coniscare, to bushe or streke heed to heed as
rams do. Conoides, pyneappull trees female. Coos, uel Cos, uel Co, uel Coum,
the name of an isle nigh to the Rhodes. Plautus
Cous, a, um, of that isle. Copis, plentuouse. Copia, plenty, eloquence, power,
leave, or license, multitude. Copiae cornu, is rehearsed, when we will sygnifie
to be plenty of all things, in that which we speak of. Copiosus, a, um,
plentuouse. Copula, a couplyng or ioynyng together, couples or fetters.
Copulatiuus, ua, uum, that coupleth, or may cowple. Coquina, a kytchyn.
Coquinor, aris, ari, to do the office of a coke Coquinaria, cokery.
Coquinarius, a, um, pertaynyng to cokery. Coquo, coxi, coquere, to seethe or
boil, to make ripe, to make ready, to digest. Coquus, a cook. Cor, cordis, the
heart. sometime it is taken for the mind. Eras. in Ci^ilia.
Corn edito, Do not tourment thy mind with care or heaviness. Cora, a city
that Dardanus builded, of which the inhabitants are called Corani. Coracesius,
a part of the hill Taurus. Corallium, a stone called coral. Corallobachates, a
stone with golden rays. Coram, before, openly, in presence. Corambla, an herb
that makes the eyes duske and weak of sight. Corax, acis, a crow. Coraxicus,
a part of the hill Taurus. Coraxis, a mountain in Asia, also a flood. Corbis,
a baskette. Corbita, a great ship, called a foyst. Corbona, the treasure of
the temple among the Jews. Corchorus, a vile herb. Corculum, sweet heart.
also wise men were so called among the Romans. Corcyra, an isle in Greece.
Cordatus homo, a wytty man, and of great memory. Cordi est, it is to my mind,
it co^tenteth me. Cordolium, sorrow, grefe at the heart. Corduba, a city in
Spain. Cordus, a, um, that thing, which spryngeth or comes late in the
year. Cordum foenum, latewarde hay. Cordi agni, latewarde lambs. Coreaceus,
a, um, of lether. Coriago, aginis, the syckenesse of cattalle, when they are
clunge, that their skynnes do cleave fast to their bodies. Coriarius, a
tanner. Corinthiacus, a, um, of Corinthe. Corinthia uasa, plate made of the
metal of Corinthe, which was myxt metal. Corinthus, a city in Achaia,
which was in that part of Greece, that is now called Morea: whereof came a
proverb, Non est cuiuslibet Corinthum appellere, It is not in every man's power
to ariue at Corinthus, which does signify, It pertayneth not to every man to
attempt thingis dangerous, or hard to acheue. Vide originem in chiliadibus
adagiorum Erasmi, uel in Aulo Gellio. Corium, the skin of a beast, also
lether. the pane of a wall made with lyme and sand. Corna, ae, the name of.ii.
cities. Cornelia, a noble woman of Rome. Cornetum, a grove of hauthorne.
Corneus, a, um, of hawthornes. Cornicen, a blower in a horn. Cornicor, aris,
ari, to make a chattryng like a choughe. Cornicularius, a certain office in
arms, concerning capital sentences. Cornicu^ oculos configere, Eras. in
Chilia.
to prick out the crows eien, is a proverb used, when we would signify, that
one with a new devise, had obscured the doctrine or estimation of them, which
had been before him, and had made them to seem, that they knew or see nothing.
It may be also said, where one man will make all other men blind, that have been before him; and reprove or dissolve that, which has been allowed by wise
men. Corniculum, a garment pertainyng to soldiers. Also sometime a town in
Italy. Cornigenus, a, um, of the kind, which has horns. Corniger, geris, al
thing that bears a horn. Cornupes, pedis, every beast that has horn on his
feet. Cornix, nicis, a bird called a chowgh. Cornu, a borne: by translation,
the corners and wyndinges of ryuers. Also the two ends of a battle be
callid, Dextrum cornu, et sinistrum cornu. Cornucopiae, was a horn that
Hercules plucked from Achelous, which horn the Hymphes or immortal ladies
filled with sweet flowers and fruits. Cornupeta, a beast that stryketh with
his horns. Cornus, nus, a hawthorne tree, Cornutus, a, um, that which has
horns. Corolla, a garlande. Corollarium, that which is above the very
measure. also a little crown. Corona, a crown, a garlande, a chaplette, a
company of people standing round like a cerkle. Also the cerkle about the moon. Coronamentum, a multitude of crounes, or garlandes. Coronarius, ria, a
maker of crowns, or garlandes. Corone, a town in Greece in the parts now
named Morea. Coronea, a city in the parts of Boeotia, in Greece. Coronis,
nidis, the nose of a ship. Also an end, the extreme part, the top, the
borne, or other like. Corono, aui, are, to crown, or set on a crown or
garlande. Corporalis, le, corporal. Corporatio, corporatura, the quantity,
state, or facyon of the body, corporature. Corporcus, ea, um, that which is of
a bodily substance. Ennsus.
Corporo, aui, are, to kill. Corpulentus, corpulente or gross in body, fleshy.
Corpus, corporis, a body. sometime it signifies but flesh only. also
sometime all manner of substance. Corrado, rasi, dear, to shave or scrape, to
take away, spoil, sell, or alienate. Corrigo, rexi, rigere, to correct, or
amend. Corrector, toris, a correcter, or amender. Corripio, pui, ^ere, to
rebuke. proprely it is to take a thing quyckely, and with haste. Corripitur
febre, he is taken with a fever. Corripitur somno, He is fast a sleep.
Corriuare, is proprely of beasts, to go together to watrynge. Corrugi,
furrows made in hills, to co^ney water, to wash the owre of metal.
Corrumpo, rupi, rumpere, to corrupt, to viciate, to distroy, to suborne, to
tempte, or procure by gifts. Corruptela, corruption or defylynge. Corsica, an
I Will in the myddell see between Bean and the I Will of Sardinia. Cortex, corticis,
a rynde or bark. Cortina, a dyers fat. Also it is the table of Apollo, from
the which he gave answer. Cato takes it for a vessel, out of the which
oil is let run. Also that which is called a corteyne of lynnen cloth or
sylke. Also places divided with cortaynes be called Cortinae. Cortinale, the
place where vessels be set, wherein wine and honey is sodden. Cortinon, radyshe
seed. Cortona, a city in Tuscane. Cortyna, or gortyna, a cite i^ the i will of
Ca^dy Corus, the northwesterne wind. Also a measure contaynynge.xlv. bushels.
Corusco, aui, are, to brandyshe or glytter. Coruus, a crow. Corybantes, the
priests of the Idol Cybeles, which as mad men waggyng their heedes and
daunsynge, playinge on cymbales, ran about the streets, prouokyng other to do
the semblable. Coryces, curious persons, crafty inuestigatours or serchers of
mattiers. Also a hylle in Crete, lyenge on the sea side. Corycium, a
gardeuiandes or walet, or other like thing to put in vitayles. Corycum, the
name of a city and mountain in Sycile. Corydalus, a lark. Coryletum, a grove
of hasylles. Corylus, an hasyll and a hasylle nutte, or fylberde. Corymbi,
bearies of an yuy. Corymbites, a kind of spurge. Coriphaeus, the chief in
every order. Corythus, a bow case, or a quyuer for arowes. Corythus, a town in
Tuscan nere to Aretiu^ Coryza, the pose, or distillation out of the heed into
the eyes and nose. Cos, cotis, a whetstone. Cosmera, a chamberer, or woman,
that apparayleth her maistresse. Cosmicus, ca, cum, worldly. Cosmographia, the
description of the world. Cosmographus, he that discribith the world. Cosmus, a
propre name. Cossi, worms bredde in trees, which the people of Phrigia, did
eat for a delycate meat. Also men or women that have their bodies riueled or
full of wryncles. Costa, a rybbe. Costus, uel costum, a tree or her be, which
is very soote in savor. Cosyros, an I Will in Aphrike. Coticula, a touch stone,
whereon they try gold and silver. Cotidie, daily, day by day. Coton, a haven
made with stoone. Also a town in Byria, of the which a certain kind of
small fygges, are called plurally, cotona, uel coctona. Cotoneum, a quynse.
Cothurnus, a slipper, specially high corked. sometime it is taken for a high and
arroga^t form of speaking or writynge. Coturnix, nicis, a bird named a
quayle. Cotyla, a vessel or cup to drink of, such as Diogenes used, before
he learned of a child to drink out of his hand. Cotyle, all the holownes of a
cup: also a measure about the quantytie of half a pynte: also the ioynte of
a man's thygh. also a weight of.ix. ounces. Cotylum, a place in the mountain of
Ida, out of the which rounneth three great ryuers, Scamander, Granicus, and
Aesopus. Couinum, a manner of a chariot. Couinarius eques, horsemen that faughte
leapyng out of a chariot unto horseback. Coxa, ex coxendix, dicis, the thigh
of a man. sometime the hyppe or joint of the thigh. Conuictus, tus, a living
together in house, or at one table. Conuoco, caui, care, to call to gyther.
C, ante R.
CRabro, onis, a great waspe, called a hornette. Cranaus, a king of Athenes.
Craneum, a place of exercise at Corynthe. Cranium, the foremooste part of
the schulle. Crantor, oris, the name of a philosopher. Crapula, an inflammation
and heed ache, which comes of excess of drinking. It is also taken for
drunkenness. Cras, to morrow, in time coming. Crastino, is the same. Eras. in
Chil.
Crassamentum, thyckenesse. Crassa Minerua, a gross wit, which does nothing
exactely. Crascesco, cessi, cessere, to make fat, or full of flesh, or
thycke. Crassiore Musa, with a more plain or intelligible senes. Crassus, a,
um, fat, fleshy, thycke, gross, poysye. Crassities, and crassitudo,
fatness; thicknes, grossenes. Crastino, aui, are, to defer from day to
day. Crastinus, na, number, pertaining to to morrow, or time to come. Cratera,
uel crater, teris, a greatte cup. Also a greatte hoole on the top of the
meruaylouse hylle of Ethna in Sycyle, out of the which issues flames of fire.
Craterus, the propre name of a man, of whom Persius speaks in his.iii.
Saty. Crates, grates of iron or wodde. Also the name of a philosopher, which
to the intent he moughte the more quietely study phylosophye, he being rich,
threw all his goods into the sea, saying, Hens with a myschiefe ye ungracious
appetytes, I had leauer drown you, thanne ye should drown me. Supposing,
that he moughte not have virtue and richesse together. Crathis, the name of two
ryuers, the one in Greece, the other in Calaber. Craticula, a gredyron, whereon
meat is broyled. Cratinas, a river in Affrike. Cratinus, a poet which wrate
comedies. Cratylus, the name of a philosopher, to whom Plato wrate a book.
Cratio, iui, ire, to cover with grates. Cratippus, the name of a philosopher.
Cratos, power, or dominion. Creo, aui, are, to make of nothing. Also to get
children. Creatura, a creature or thing made of nothing. Creber, bra, bru^,
frequent, or accustomed. Crebro, often. Crebresco, crebrui, crebrescere, to be
wont, to be commune. Credibile, that which may be byleued. Creditor, oris, he
unto whom a man owes any thing. Creditum, that thing that is owed. Credo,
didi, dear, to believe, to trust, to committee, or deliver a thing to be
saufelye kept, to publyshe. Credulus, he that believes lightly. Credulitas,
tatis, light believe. Crementum, increase. Cremera, a river. Cremium, fried
meat burned to the pa^ne. Cremor, oris, the juice of barley steapyd in water,
beaten and pressed, Crenae, the dentis about the leaf of an herb or tree like
to a saw. Also it is the scores, which men unlearned do make on styckes for
their remembrance. Also Crena, is the nocke of a bow or arowe. Creontes, the
name of a king, whose daughter Jason married, wha^ he had left Medea.
Creophilus, the name of a poet. Crepetus, a, um, doubtful, ambiguous.
Crepida, and crepis, pidis, a shoe with lachettes, some take it for a corked
shoe or slypper, because of the noise, which it makes when a man goes.
Crepidatius, ^ii, he that makes shows or slyppers. Crepido, inis, a creek on
the waters side, whereon the water beats. Also the mouth of a well, and the
extreme part of any place. Crepitaculum, a tymbrell, or other instrument, which
being touched with the hand, makes a sownde. Crepito, taui, are, to make a
noise or bounsynge. Crepitulum, an ornament of the beed, which with me^ynge of
the heed yeldethe a sown. Crepitus, a bounse or great dynne or noise. ^
Crepo, pui, pere, to make a greatte noise or sown. Crepere, to be broken.
Crepundia, tryfles or small gifts given to little children, as napkyns,
little belles, tymbrelles, and such like toys. Also the first apparayle of
children, as swathels, wastcotes, and such like. And by translation they say, A
crepundijs erat uirtuti deditus. From his chyldhode he was ever given to
virtue. Crepusculum, the break or first spring of the day, called the twie
light. Cresco, creui, crescere, to grow or increase. Craeuit haereditatem, He
is increased in his lyu^l^de, or he has taken possession. Creta, an I Will called
now Candy: also a stone called Chalk. Cretatus, ta tum, laid with chalk.
Cretaeus, and Cretensis, a man of Crete or Candye. Creterra, a buckette to
draw up water. Eras. in Chil.
Cretizare cum Cretensibus, a proverb used where a crafty man will deceive him
that is crafty: a thief steal from a thief, or a liar lie before them, which
use to make leasynges. Creticus, ca, um, of Crete or Candy. Also a foot in
meter, which has the first and third syllable long. Cretosus, a, um, full
of chalk. Cribro, aui, are, to syfte or sarce. Cribrum, a sieue or a sarce.
Crimen, minis, a fault, an offense, blame, matter laid against one by action
or suite. sometime a false suspicion. Criminale, criminalle, wherein is an
offense or fault. Criminor, aris, ari, to blame, to rebuke, to lay to ones
charge, to accuse. Criminosus, a, um, rebukeful, worthy blame Crimissus, a
river of Greece. Crines, hear of the heed. Crinire, to lay forth the hear.
Crinitus, he that has much or long hear. Crinita stella, a comete or blasynge
sterre. Crinon, a red lylye. Crisa, the name of a town builded by Crisus,
Phocus son. Criticus, he that judges the acts or warkes that men do write.
Critici dies, the days wherein physytions give judgment of the contynuance of
the syckenesse. Crito, a philosophers name of Athenes. Critabulus, was a
physician, of whom Pliny speaks lib.vii. Crobylon, a cawle to wear on ones
heed. Croco, crocito, to make a noise like a raue^. Crocinum et croceum,
colored like saffron. Crocodilus, a beast in Aegypte, living sometime in
water, sometime on land: and is facioned in the body like a dragon, sauinge
that he lacks wings. Crocotir^um, cakebreade. Crocotulae, garme^tis of the
color of saffron. Crocotularius, a dyar. Crocus, saffron, a spice. Crocuta, a
beast in Ethiope, which with his tethe breaks all things in pieces, and
deuoureth it, be it wodde or metal. Cronia, feasts dedicate to Saturn.
Crotalum, an instrument, which the Egiptians used in sacrifice made of.ii.
plates* which beaten together, made an harmony. Crotalus, he that has a
sownynge voice, and a shyll. Crudaria, a vain of silver. Crudelis, le, cruel.
Crudesco, crudui, crudescere, to be raw. Crudus, da, um, raw, fresh, or new
made, not type. Crudus homo, whose stomach can not digest well. Cruditas,
tatis, rawnes, or lack of digestion. Cruento, aui, are, to make blody.
Cruentus, a, um, blody, cruel. Crumena, a purse. Cruor, bloudde which
commethe out of a wound. Crus, cruris, the part of the leg, which is from
the knee down unto the ancle called the shanke. Crusta, the utter part of
every thing that is not eaten. Also the scurfe of a scabbe or wound, also
plaster of a wall. Crusto, taui, are, to lay plaster, or pargette. Crustata,
whereon is laid plaster, or thyn shardes of stone. Crustarius, a pargettour.
Crustulata, a meat made of crustes of bred. Crustulum, crustum, a crowst of
bread, of a pasty, or of roasted, broyled, or fried meat Crustumina pira,
pears read on the one side. Crustuminum, a town in Italy. Crux, crucis, a
cross, galowhowse, or other like. Cruciatus, tus, tourment. Crypta, a secret
place within the earth. Crypticus, ca, cum, secret or hid under the earth.
Cryptoporticus, a place under ground, with wyndowes like to a parler, where
men do dyne in the summer time for hear. Crystallus et chrystallu^, a stone
called cristal. Cristallina, vessel and cups of cristal stone.
C, Ante T.
CTenes, certain teethe. Cteniatrus, he that heals diseasis of horses and
catell. Ctesiphon, the name of a work man, which builded the temple of Diana,
at Ephesie, a work wonderful, and renoumed through the world: the which was
after bourned of one Herostratus, only because he would for some deed be spoken
of.
C, Ante V.
CVbatus, tus, a sittyng on brood, as a benne does. Cubicularius, a servant
that awayteth in the chamber: a chamberlayne, or grome of the chamber.
Cubicularis, lare, that perteynethe to the Chaumber. Cubiculum, a bed
chamber. Cubile, a bed, sometime it is taken for a closet. Cubito, aui, are,
to lie often with one. Cubitus, et Cubitum, an elbowe, sometime a measure
called a cubite, that is to say, one foot and an half: but a cubite in
geometry contains.vi. of our common cubits. Cubitale, a sorsleue of a
garmente, which keuereth the arm from the elbowe downwarde. Cubo, cubui,
cubare, to lie down, properly it is of sick men. Cubatio, a lyinge. Cubus, is
a figure four square on all parts like a dyce. Cucubo, aui, are, to make a
noise like an oule. Cuculio, onis, a keuerynge of the hedde, which men did
use when they walked in the night. Cuculus, et Cucullus, a byrd called a
cuckoo. Cucullus, a cloak to defend rain and wind. Cucuma, a chafar, wherein
water is het. Cucumer, eris, et Cucumis, a fruit called a cocumber.
Cucumerarius, a garden where cocumbres do grow or be kept. Cucurbita, a fruit
called a gourde. Also cucurbita, and Cucurbitula, is a cup, wherewith Surgyons
do draw out blood with scarysying of the skin, called cuppynge.
Cucurbitarium, a place where gourdes be sown. Cucurbitarius, a lover of
gourdes. Cucurio, iui, iri, to make a noise like a cock. Cudo, cusi, cudere, to
strike, as smythes do. Cudere pecunia^, to make or coin money, also cudere,
to break or broyse. Cuias, cuiatis, of whense. Cuius, cuia, cuium, whose.
Cuium paecus, whose catall. Culcitra, a mattresse. Culeus, a sack, also a
measure containing xxx. bushels. Culex, culicis, a gnatte. Culigna, a bolle or
dyshe to drink of. Culina, a kechyn, sometime the meat that is dressed.
Culinor, aris, ari, to do the office of a cook. Culleolum, the utter shale of
a nut, which is grene. Culullus, an erthen cup, such as the galye cups be.
Culmen, culminis, the roufe of a house. Culmus, the reed or straw of corn,
from the rote to the ear. Culpa, is an offense done not weetinge, or not
intending to do hurt. Culter, et Cultrum, a knyfe. Cultellum, a lyttel knife
or a whittill. Cultrarius, was he that killed the beast, and divided him in the
sacrifice to Idolles. It may now be taken for a slaughter man. Cultus,
cultus, apparayle, sometime it is taken for honor done to god. Cum, with, when,
whiles, where, albeit, for asmoche, as well. Cum mihi tum illi, As Well to me as
to him. In cum is some thing less understand, in Tum sum thing more. Quod
cum omnibus confitendum est, tu^ nobis praecipue, which thing ought to be
confessed of all men, and of us most specially. The ancient writers, when it
sygnifyed when, where, and forasmoche, they wrate it Quom. Cum dicto,
forthewith after that he had spoken. Cum imperio est, he bears a rule. Cum
maxim, excedyngly. Cum potestate est, he is in authority, or in an high
office. Cum primis, very. Cum primis nobilis, Very noble. Cum stomacho,
dysdaynfully. Cum tempore, in a certain space. Cum uema tua, with your
license. Cuma, a town in Greece. Cumae, a city in Campania. Cumanus, a man of
that city. Cumatilis, tile, a color called blewe. Cumera, a greatte vesselle,
wherein corn was kept. Cumetum, a vessel used at weddynges. Cuminum, an herb
and sede called co^myn. Cumulo, aui, are, to make an heap, to fill, to add
more. Cumulatim, in an heap, or heaped up. Cumulus, an heap. Cunae, et
Cunabula, cradels, wherein children be rocked. sometime it is taken for the age
of infancy. Cunctator, o^is, a tariar, a differrer. Cuncti, all together.
Cunctor, et Contor, aris, to tarry, to prolo^ge time, to abide, to doubt.
Cunctatio, onis, a tarienge, an abydyng, a prolongynge of time, a doutynge.
Cuneus, an axe to cut wood, which is small and thyn before, and broad and
thycke after, that the wodde may ryue the better. also a wedge to cleave wodde
with. By translation it is a company of foteme^ in battle, that goth in a like
order, small before, and broad behind: there was a like form in the Theater or
place, where men beheld plays, it is sometime taken for a company of people.
Cuneatim, in the form before declared. Cuneatus, ta, tu^, that which appears
to be in the said form of Cuneus. Cuniculus, a beast called a cony.
Cuniculum, an hole in the ground. Cunila, an herb called sauery, whereof be
diverse kinds. Cunire, to dunge as a child does. Cunnus, a woman's wyket.
Cupa, a cup. Cupedinarius, an hucstar that sells meat and drink. Cupes,
Cupedia, et Cupedula, delicate meats, or desire of deynty meats. Cupido,
Cupidinis, the son of Venus, god of love. Cupido in the feminine gender,
vehement desire or appetite. Cupidus, da, dum, desyrouse. sometime it
signifies a lover. Cupiditas, tatis, couaytise. Cupide, desirously. Cuprum,
metal called coper. Cur, wherefore or why. Cura, care, thought, study,
diligence, warke or labor, also love. Curatio, cure. Curator, gardeyn in
socage, or he to whom the custodye of a man mad or folysshe is committed.
Also he to whom any thing is committed to survey, or to provide things
necessary for a weal publyke, or to order such things as he has in charge,
concerning as well private things as they that do belong to a comminaltie:
he may be properly called a suruayour. Curatorius, a, um, belonginge to
surueinge. Curcura, an island in the sea Adriatike. Curculio, onis, a littell
worm in grayn called myte or wyuell. It is also the wesyll of the throat of a
man, whereby he draws wind. Cures, a city of the Sabines. Curetes, a people
of the I Will of Crete or Candy. Curia, a court, that is to say, where the senate
is, or officers exercisynge such things as they have in charge. it is
sometime taken for the persons in the court. Curiales, they which be of that
court. Curio, onis, a bedell or criar. Curionem agnum, Plautus calls a lean
lamb. Curio, also of Varro is taken for a place, where priests consulted of
things concerning divine ceremonies. Curiosus, sa, sum, curiouse, taken
sometime on the ill part, where more dylygence is used, than is necessary or
expedient: sometime on the better part, where we be very careful and busy
about things, concerning either our selfs or other men. Curiositas tatis,
curiosytie, or to much dilygence. Curious, the name of a noble Romayne, unto
whom when the ambassadors of Samnytes had brought a great sum of gold for
a present from their people, desiring him to take it, and use it at his
pleasure, he answered, that Marcus Curious had lever have dominion over rich
men, than to be rich him self, and that he, which could not be vaynquished in
battayl, might not be corrupted with money. Curo, aui, are, to care, to be
doing of a thing. sometime to prepare, to heal one that is sick, to take
refection or comfort. Curriculo, quyckely. Curro, cucurri, currere, to run.
Cursus, us, et cursura, a course. Cursor, oris, he that runs in post.
Cursim, runnynge. Cursito, aui, are, to run often. Curso, aui, are, to run
always or often. Cursorius, a, um, pertainyng to runnyng. Curruca, a little
bird, which hatchethe and brings up cuckowe birds. Currus, a carre.
Curriculus, a little carre. Curriculum, a short space of time. Also a
runnynge place. Curtus, ta, tum, short. Curuamen, minis, a crookedness.
Curuesco, uesci, uescere, to be crooked. Curuipes; he that has a crooked foot.
Curulis and curule, were lyttelle carres, or drayes, having in them chaires of
yuorie, wherein they satte, which were heed officers in Rome. sometime it is
used of poets for the same officers. Curuo, uaui, are, to bow or make crooked.
Curuus, a, um, crooked. Cuspis, idis, some time signifies the point of any
weapon, sometime the stele, sometime a spear heed. Custodia, the custody,
