keeping, or ward: sometime he that keeps, sometime he that is kept, sometime
the prison. Custodio, diui, dire, to keep, to observe. Custoditio, the keeping.
Custoditus, ta, tum, kept. Custos, odis, a keeper. Cutis, the inner skin.
C, Ante Y.
CYamea, a stone, which being broken, is like to a bean. Cyaneae, or
Cyanitae, Islands or rather rocks under Thrace Bosphore. Cyaneus, a, um, and
Cianus, a, um, a brighte blewe color, or blunket. Cyathus, a cup. it is also
a measure, contaynynge as much as a reasonable manne may drink at one
draught. Cybele and cybeles, was the wife of Saturn, and was named of painims,
the mother of the gods, which has diverse other names, as it shall appear in
their places. Cyclades, yles in the greek see. Cyclas, cladis, a woman's
kyrtell. Cyclus, a round place in Athenes, where things were sold. Also a
coin or poyse. Cyclops, clopis, an ancient people, inhabitynge the isle of
Sycile, which were like gyauntes, having but oone eye in their foreheed.
Cydnus, a river of Sicile, the water whereof was meruaylous cold. and as Pliny
says, auayleable for the gout in the fete Cydon, one of the notablest towns
of Candy. Cygnus, a swanne. Cylindrus, an instrument, wherewith men do beat
floores, or do ram with. Also every thing that tourneth about quyckly. Also
stones round and long like beade stones, called langattes. Cylindraceus, a,
um, in the form of a langatte. Cyllene, a hylle of Archadie, where they say
Mercurius was nouryshed. Cyllenius, one of the names of Mercury. Cylydros, a
serpent that rolleth him self, as he gothe. Cyma, young colewortes. Also the
tender part of the stalk of every herb. Cymatilis, chamlette. Cymba, a
boot. Cymbalum, an instrument of music. Cymbalistae, they that play upon
cymbals. Cymbium, a piece or cup to drink wine in. Cyminum, cummyne. Cyminus, a
laake in Italy. Cynaethium, a city of Archadie. Cynanche, a syckenes called
the squynce, which is in the throat and jaws. Cynegetica, volumes written of
hunting. Cynici, a sect of philosophers, which lived in pouerte without shame,
like doggis. Cyniphes, biting gnattis with long legs. Cynocephalus, a beast
having the body like to an ape, and the heed like a dog. Also people under
the great cane, having heedes like dogs. Cynoglossa, an herb callid hounds
ru^ge. Cynomia, dog flies, which do souke blood from a beast.
Cynorrhodos, the flower of Eglantyne. Cynos, in latyne is canis, a dog. Also
a city in Locris. Cynosbatum, a thorn, the leaf whereof is like the step of
a man's foot, and has black bearies like to grapes. Cynosura, a figure of
sterres in heaven, called Vrsa minor. Cynozoon, a stynkynge herb. Cynthia, one
of the names of the moon. Cyparissus, a cypress tree. Cypirus and cyperis, an
herb, having leaves like sedges, also a rote like to ginger. Cyprium aes,
copper, metal. Cyprus, an isle called cypers. Cyrcerum, a great ship, or
carrike. Cyrene, nes, a famous city in Libia. Also a city in the isle of
cypers. Cyreneus, a man of that city. Cyrnus, the isle which is callid
Corsica, or Corse. Cyrnea, a goblette to drink wine in. Cyrrhea, a city in
the mountain of Helycon. Cyrrus, the name of.ii. ryuers, one in Armenia, the
other in Media. Cyrus, the name of diverse kings in Persi. Cyssus, a kind of
yuye, that grows alone. also the name of a river. Cythera, plural. an isle
against Candy. Cytheron, an hylle in Boeotia. Cytisus, an herb, which is
good to give to cattle against the rotte. Cyzicus, the name of an I Will by
Greece.
D, Ante A.
DACIA, a countreye beyond Hungry, on the north part of the river of Dano,
or Danubius. Daci, and Dani, people of that country. Dacicus, ca, cum,
pertaining to that country. Dacus, ca, cum, idem. Dactylus, a finger, a foot
in meter, having one long syllable, and.ii. short. it is also a date.
Dactylides, grapes being long like a finger. Daedalus, the name of an
excellent carpentar of Athenes, which first found the saw, the twie bylle,
and the awgor: and made the place in Crete callydde Laberynthus. Daemogorgon,
onis, whom paynyms called the god of the earth, first creatoure of the earth.
Demon, nis, a damned spirit. sometime it is taken for the soul, being in
the body of man. Daemonicus, ca, cum, dyuellyshe. Daemonium, a spirit.
sometime it is used for a godheed among the paynyms. Daemoniacus, and
demoniosus, possessed with an ill spirit. Dalmatia, a country on the river of
Dano, called now Slauony. Dalmata, a man of that country. Dalmaticus, ca, um,
of that country. Dalmaticatus, apparailed like a Slauanoise. Dama, a falowe
dear. Damascus, a city in Siria. Damia, one of the names of the goddess
Cybele. Damatris, the priest of her temple. Damnas, condemned. Damnifico,
feci, facere, to do harm. Damno, aui, are, to condemn, to disherite* to
compel, to deliver. Damnum, harm, or hurt. Damnosus, a, um, harmefull, or
hurtful, or having much harm. Damoetas, a shepardes name in Virgill. Damon,
a philosophers name of Pythagoras sect. Dan, a town which is the bounds of
Judea, on the north part. Danaus, the king of Argyues, which had fyfty
daughters, who all, saving one, slew all their husbands in one night.
Danaides, the daughters of Danaus. Dani, a people now called Danes. Danisma,
usury. Danista, he that lends for usury. Danubius, a famous river, now called
Danowe, wherinto do flow.lx. ryuers. Danunt, Plautus does use for dant, they
give. Dapalis caena, a soupper, whereat be many and diverse meats. Dapatice,
feastfully, plentuously. Dapes, delycate and precious dysshes, or bankettes.
Daphne, the propre name of a little maiden, and also of a wodde. Daphnis,
nidis, in latin is a laurel. also the son of Mercury. It was also a
dilectable place without the city of Antioche, Also it was the name of a
portion of Lycia by the sea side. Daphnites, one of the names of Apollo.
Daphnoides, an herb like to Laurel, now called Laureole, as I suppose.
Daphnon, a place, where laurel grows. Dapifer, he that bearith a dishe at a
banquet. Dapino, to give, as it were a delicate dishe. Dapsa, a sacrifice, which
was made in winter, and in spring time. Dapsile, abundantly. Dapsilis,
abundant, liberal, or large. Dardanarii, forstallers of markettes, which do
bye before hand, to selle dear afterward. Dardaniae arts, witchecrafte.
Dardanus, the name of a prince, reigning in that part of Phrigia, where Troy
stood, which was of him called Dardania. Darius, the name of diverse kings of
Persia. Daricus, money of Persia. Darideus, the name of a king of Persia in
the time of Tyberius, Caius, and Claudius themperours. Datarius, a, u^, given.
also an officer in Rome which subscribed the date of letters. Datatim, one
gyuyng to an other, as at the tossynge of a balle. Daunia, a part of Italy,
now called Appulia.
D Ante E.
DE, of, joined with a verb, or nowne, it signifies withdrawinge or taking
away, as, Decorrico, I bark or take away the rynde: Depilo, I pluck away the
hear. sometime it signifies downward, as Deorsum descendo, I go downewarde.
Sometime contrary, as, Dehortor, I give contrary advise: Dedoceo, I teach
contrary, Terentius
sometime it sygnifieth for, as, Qua^tum me amas de fidicina hac? How well
do thou love me for this singing wenche? Deambulatorium, an aley to walk in,
it may be sometime used for a galery. Deambulo, aui, are, to walk up and down.
Deamo, aui, are, to love heartily. Deartuo, aui, are, to ioynte, or to cut of by
the joints. Deauro, aui, are, to gylte, to lay over all with gold.
Debacchor, aris, ari, to rage, as it were in a drunkenness, to be wodde
angry. Debello, aui, are, to vanquyshe, or take one in battle. Debeo, bui,
ere, to owe, or ought. Debilis, wealte or feeble. Debtor, toris, he that owes.
Debitio, onis, the act of owinge. Debtor, toris, a dettour. Debitum, a debt
or duty. Debiti iudicatus, condemned in an action of debt. Debrior, aris,
ari, to be drunk. Decachinnor, aris, ari, to skorne. Decachordum, an
instrument with ten strings. Decacumino, aui, are, to strike of the top.
Decalcatum, laid with lyme. Eras. in Chi^ia.
De calcaria in carbonariam, out of the lyme kill into the cole pit. A
proverb, whereby is sygnifyed from oone myschiefe to an another. Decalogus, the
book of holy scripture, containing the ten commandementes. Decapolis, a
country in Judea, beyond the river of slume Iordane, contaynynge ten
cities. Decapulo, aui, are, to empty pottis or cups. Decedo, decedere, to
depart from a place, to mynyshe or appaire. Decedere uia, to goo out of the
way, or to give the way to an other of courteisye. Decedere de suo iure, to
remytte somewhat of his right. December, the name of one of the twelve
months. Decemiugis, a teeme of ten horses. Decempeda, a perch or poll ten
fotelonge. Decempedator, he that meateth with such a polle. Decendium, the
space of ten days. Decerno, decreui, decernere, to decree, determyne, or
discuss. Decerpo, psi, pere, to pull, or pluck of. Decerto, aui, are, to
contend or fight together. Decet, it besemeth, it is convenient. Decens, it is,
convenient. Dedecet, it is inconvenient, unsitting. Decido, di, dear, to cut
of. also to decide or discuss a matter in variance. Decido, ere, to fall of,
or away. Decidua, are those things that fall away, as leaves of trees. Decima,
a tenthe part. Decimanus, sieve decumanus, na, number, great, as Decumana porta,
The great yate or entry into a camp of an army. Decumanus, a general
receyuer or collectour of taxes or subsydies, or other like exactions. Decimo,
aui, are, to take away the tenthe part from the resydue. Decimari legiones,
was when the tenthe person of every legion was put to death. Decimus, ma, mum,
the tenthe, the chief or principalle, as, Decimum quodque ouum, Every tenthe
egg. Decimus quisque fluctus, Every tenth river. Decipio, decepi, decipere, to
deceive. Decipula, a grynne or trap to take birds. Decircino, aui, are, to
vnbowe, or to bring out of compass, or roundenesse. Decius, the name of a
noble house of the Romans. Declamo, aui, are, to declame, or to exercise in
feyned orations. Declamatorius, a, um, pertaining to such exercise.
Declamatio, onis, an exercise in sained orations. Declaro, aui, are, to
declare, to open a thing which is dark. Declino, aui, are, to eschew, to
leave, to turn away, to lead away, to alienate. Decollo, aui, are, to stryke
of a heed by the neck, also to deceive, or disapoynte. Plautus
Vna est, quae decollauit, One womanne there is, which has deceived him.
Decolor, oris, ylle colored. Decoloro, aui, are, to stayne, to spylle the
color. Decoquo, decoxi, decoquere, to boil, or to sethe very much. sometime
to change, or digest perfitely. Also to consume or wast a man's substance, or
to bring detrymente or loss. Decoctor, toris, he that has wasted all his
substance, and is brought to extreme poverty, specially by lecherye and dyse
playenge. Decor, decoris, a beautye. Decoro, aui, are, to beautify or make
fair, or pleasant to the eyes or the ears, to honor. Decorum, a
semelynesse, or that which becomes the person, having respect to his
nature, degree, study, office, or professyon, be it in doing or speaking, a
grace. sometime it sygnifyeth honesty. Decorus, ra, rum, honest, semely,
fair. Dedecus, dishonestie in act, reproach. Decoruco, aui, are, to bark.
Decores, a bare or thredebare garment. Decrepitus, a very old man. Decrepita
senectus, extreme age. Decresco, feere, to wax less. Decretorius, a, um,
iudiciali, Also decreed, stablyshed. Decretorium tempus, decretorium sydus,
whereby judgment is given of the increase that shall succeed of any thing.
Decretum, a decree, a thing determined. Decubo, aui, are, to lie down.
Deculto, aui, are, to hyde under. Decubo, cubui, cumbere, to lie down, also to
dye. Decuplatus, ta, tum, ten times dowbled, or ten fold. Decuplo, aui,
are, to double ten times. If it be an aduerbe, it sygnifyeth ten times, or
ten fold. Decuplum, like wise. Decuppa, he or she that sellethe wine by the
port. Cicero in Pisonem.
Decurio, onis, an office or dignity, having authorite orther over ten men
of arms, or the tenthe part of a company. Also it was taken for the lord
Chamberlayne to the Emperor. Suetonius in Domit. Cicero.
Also they were in other cities the same that Senators were at Rome Decuria,
was the order, office, or company, which was under the office of Decurio. Also
the company of iuges, as we have of the kings Benche, Commune place, and
Escheker. And Decurio, he that is chief of them. Decurro, decucurri, rere, to
run down, by translation it sygnifieth to run from the one end to the
other. Decursio, Iustes, as at the tylte or randon. Decursionem indicere, to
proclaim iustes. Suetonius in Nero^.
Decurtatus, ta, tum, shortened, abbreuiated. Decus, decoris, honor. Dedecoro,
aui, are, to disshonour, reprove, or defyle. Decusso, aui, are, to cut or
draw out in length, or to cut or deuyde in ten parts. Decussatim, in ten
partis. Decussis, the perfyte number of ten. Decutio, cussi, tere, to stryke
of. Dedico, aui, are, to dedicate, or tell a message. Dedignor, aris, ari, to
disdain. Dedisco, dedidici, dedicere, to vnlerne, or forgette. Dediditio, a
renderynge up of a place besyeged. Dedititius, a, um, given or subject to an
other man's commandment. Dedo, dedidi, dedere, to give utterly, or for ever: or
to become subject, to render up, or yield. Dediditionem facere, sygnifieth the
same. Dedoceo, cui, cere, to teach a man other wise, than he has before
learned. Dedoleo, lui, lere, to cease from sorrow, or pain. Dedolo, aui, are,
to hew or cut, like a Carpenter. Deduco, xi, cere, to bring down, or to
lead, or draw, or bring from one place, or one thing to an other. sometime
to move from his purpose. sometime to bring home honorably from any place.
Deerro, aui, are, to go out of the right way, or reason. Defalco, aui, are, to
cut of, take away, defalcate. Defamo, aui, are, to defame. Defaeco, aui, are,
to draw from the dregs, to cleanse or fine. Defectio, onis, rebellyon,
decreasynge, defaulte, lack. Defectus, ta, tum, that which saylethe, or
decays. Defectus, tus, lack. Defectus solis and lunae, the Eclyps of the
son and the moon. Defectus animi, sownynge or lyenge in a trance. Defecta
corpora, bodies consumed with syckenesse. Defendo, di, dear, to defend, to
put of, to prohybyte. Defensito, taui, tare, to defend often. Defero,
detull, defer, to bring to, to disclose, to accuse, or appeal, to bestow,
to give office or dignity, to attribute. Defer nomen, to complain.
Deferueo, ferui, ere, to be cold, or pacyent. Deferuesco, sci, scere, to wax
pacyente or cold, to appease him self, or withdraw his furye. Deficio feci,
ficere, to fail, not to suffyse, to lack, to leave, to disagree, to rebelle,
or depart from him, with whom he is retained, or goes from one Capytayne to
an another. Defectus, tus, lack, rebellion, or departing against covenant or
promise. Defector, oris, be that so departs or rebelleth, or goth from one to
an other. Defigo, fixi, figere, to set or fyxe on, or to perce or thrust
through. Definio, iui, re, to define, determi^e, or discuss. Definitio,
definitionis, a definition, which expresses in few words, what it is that
is spoken of, as, Homo est animal, rationale, mortale, A man is a thing lively,
reasonable, and mortalle. Defioculus, he that lacks sight in one eye. Defit,
there lacks. Deficio, defeci, deficere, to lack, or to be insufficient.
Cicero.
Also to forsake or fail. Prude^tia nunquam deficit oratorem, Prudence never
fails an oratoure. Caesar.
Quem sanguis uiresque deficiunt, whom blood and strength faylleth. Also to
forsake his captain, and go to his adversary. Ab eo defecerat, He went from
him to his enemy. Deflacco, aui, are, to wear out. Deflagro, aui, are, to
bourne excedyngly. Deflecto, xi, tere, to bow down. Defloreo, and defloresco,
ere, to fade, or to fall away as flowers do: or to lose beaultie. sometime it
signifies to burgen or flower. Defluo, xi, ere, to flow downward, to fall of
or away, or come to nothing. Deflulis, a, um, that which flows or falls
away from any thing. Defluuiu^, defluxus, the falling of the hear. Defodio,
di, dear, to burye or hyde a thing in the ground, to dygge down or into the
earth. Defoetus, ta, tum, destytute. Deformis, me, foul, deformed. Deformo,
aui, are, to destroy, or waste, to make in picture the form of a thing.
Defraudo, aui, are, to begyle, to minisshe or take away the profit from an
other. Defrico, caul, are, to rub much, or to rub of. Defrigo, xi, gere, to
fric much. Defringo, xi, re, to break town, or cut down. Defrugo, aui, are, to
consume or wear out the profit, specially of ground, whereof should come
corn or fruit. Defrutare, to boil new wine. Defrutum, sodden wine. Defugeo,
gi, ere, to refuse. Defundo, fudi, dear, to pour down. Defungor, geris, to
use no longer, to leave or resygne, to perform. Degener, is, he that in his
manners is unlike to his auncetours, or base of lynage. Degenero, aui, are, to
be unlike to his auncetours in manners. It may be said of fruits, which wax
wild. Deglabro, aui, are, to pluck of hears, Dego, degi, degere, to lead,
to live, Plautus.
to expelle, to pulle of. Degitur corium de tergo meo, The skin is pulled of
my back. Degulo, aui, are, to consume in glotony. Dehinc, from hensforth,
moreover. Dehisco, sci, scere, to gape wide open. Dehonestamentum, a
disfyguringe, or dyshonestye. Dehonesto, aui, are, to dishoneste. Dehonestus,
ta, tum, very honest. Deianira, the wife of Hercules. Deidamia, the concubyne
of Achilles, on whom he begatte Pirrhus. Deiero, aui, are, to take an oath, to
swear deeply. Deiicio, ieci, iicere, to throw down, to cast down, to
turn away, to put out of office. Dein, moreover, furthermore. Deinceps, one
after an other in order, from hensforth, or thensforth, afterward. Deinsuper,
upward. Deintegro, from the beginning to the end. Deiphile, the mother of
Diomedes. Deiphobus, the name of a son of Priamus and Hecuba. Deiugo, aui,
are, to unyoke, to vnioyne, to disseuer. Deiurium, a great and solemn oath.
Deiurus, he that swears solemnly. Delabor, delabi, to be let down, or fall
down to be consumed or wasted. Delachrimor, aris, ari, to weep or send out
drops like tears. Delanio, aui, are, to cut in pieces. Delapidata,
pauementes. Delasso, aui, are, to make weary. Delator, toris, a secret accuser,
a co^plainer Delatio, an accusation secretly made, or a secret complaynt.
Delebile, that which may be put out, or put away. Delectatio, delectation
in the se^ces of heryng, saying, taste, and smellyng. Delecto, aui, are, to
delight, to lead, to allure to a thing. Delector, aris, ari, to take
delectation or pleasure. Delectus rerum, choice or election of things. Also of
men. Delectum habere, sommetyme signifies to take musters for the wars.
Delego, aui, are, to assign to some office message, or other necessary and
great busynes, to commytte a cause or matter to be determined, to send in
ambassade or message. Deleo, leui, ere, to distroy, to put out any thing
that is written, to remove or put away. Deleretion, venom. Deletile, that
distroyeth or puts out. Deliacus, ca, cum, of the isle of Delus. Delibero,
aui, are, to be advised, to take advise, to determyne, to doubt, to consult.
Deliberatiua oration, wherein any thing is consulted. Delibo, aui, are, to taste
a thing, sometime to vyolate, to distroy, to sacrifice, to drain water by
forowes. Delibro, aui, are, to pull of the bark or rind of a tree. Delibutus,
ta, tum, oynted. Delicatus, cata, catum, delycate, wantonlye brought up.
Delicias facere, to be wanton, to be squaymyshe, to play the cockeney.
Delitium, and delitiae, a wanton word, which uneath may be expressed in
english, used between a man and a woman in wanton pastyme. Meum delitium,
meae delitiae, my sweet heart, my darlynge, my joy, and such other like,
expressed best by them that be Venus secretaries. Delico, aui, are, to
explane. Delictum, an offense when a thing is undone, omission. Deligo, legi,
ligere, to chose or pyke out. Delimo, aui, are, to fyle or shave of from any
metal. Delinimentum, delectation, an allectyue, or swetenes in feelynge.
Delinio, iui, ire, to anoynte, to rub pleasantly, to towche. Delinitus,
touched swetely, anointed, pacified, appeased. Deliniate, to draw, as a
paynter does, er he do lay on colors. Delitum, blotted. Delinquo, deliqui,
delinquere, to omytte to do well, to offend. Deliquium, lack. Deliquium
animi, when a man is in a swowne. Deliquium solis, the eclyps of the son.
Deliro, aui, are, to go out of the right way, proprely to go out of the forow,
and make a balke, as ploughmen do. Also to dote. Delirus, he that swaruethe
from reason, a dotarde or dotynge fool. Deliteo, tui, ere, to hyde me.
Deliresco, I go to hyde me. Delos, an isle nygh to Greece. Delphi, a city and
people in Greece. Delphicus, ca, cum, of that city. Delphin, inos, a greatte
fysshe, called a Dolphyn. Delphis, a temple of Apollo in Greece. Delubrum, a
place, wherein be diverse images of god and saints. Deludo, si, ere, to mock.
Delumbis, be, weak, sometime wanton. Deluo, lui, ere, to wash clean, or wash
out. Deluto, aui, are, to lay klaye on any thing. Demagis, much more. Demando,
aui, are, to commit holy. Demarathus, a king of Spartan. Demarchus, a ruler
of the people. Demeanculum, a place to descend into a Cellar. Demeare, to go
down, or go away. Demens, it is, mad. Dementia, madness. Demensus, sa, sum,
measured. Demensum, wages given every month. Dementio, tiui, ire, to be mad.
Demento, taui, tare, to be mad, to make mad, to make foolyshe. Demereo,
rui, ere, to win or get. Demereor, eris, reri, to bind by friendship, to win ones favor, to make a friend, to deserve much. Demetior, to met
diligently, to esteem. Demeto, tij, tere, to met. Demetrias, a town of
Thessalie. Demetrius, a man's name. Demiror, aris, ari, to marvel much. some
time it signifies to know not. Demitto, misi, tere, to send down, to humble
my self, to lay down. Demissitia tunica, a long cote. Demissus, a, um,
humble. Demo, mere, to take away, or abate. De capite demptum, appayred in
substance or valewe. Democratia, a form of a commonwealth, Ti. Liuius
where the people have authority. Democraticus, he that favors the common
wealth, where the people has authority. Democritus, the name of a philosopher.
Demodocus, the name of a harper i^ Homer. Demolior, iris, to throw down any
thing that is builded. Demonstro, aui, are, to show openly. Demonstratiuus, a,
uum, that shows, or is showed, or mete to be showed. Demonstratio, onis, a
showing. Demonstratiuum genus, a form of speaking, wherein orators did
either commend or dispraise any man openly. Demophon, the son of Theseus and
Phedra king of Athenes. Demorior, eris, to dye utterly. Demoror, aris, to tarry
long, to keep back, or cause to tarry. Demonsthenes, the name of a famous
orator. Demulceo, cere, to stryke gentilly and softly with the hand, as we do
to children or hounds, when we make much of them. Demum, at the last.
sometime it signifies only, or always. Demussata contumelia, displeasure done
by dissimulation. Denarius, a certain coin, after the diversities of
countries, diverse in weight. it is taken now for a penny. Denarius, a, um, that
which contains the number of ten. Denarro, aui, are, to tell in order.
Denaso, to cut or pull of the nose. Denato, aui, are, to swymme down.
Denego, aui, are, not to give, or to deny to give. Denigro, aui, are, to make
black. Deni, ten together. Caesar lib. 5. Vxores habent deni duodenique
inter se communes, They have wives ten and twelve men together, commune
among them. Denique, in conclusyon. Denomino, aui, are, to name. Denoto, aui,
are, to blame. Dens, dentis, a toothe. Denso, aui, are, to thycken or make
thycke. Densus, a, um, thycke, hard, closed together, compacte. Densitas,
tatis, and densitudo, dinis, thicknes. Dentale, the share of a plough.
Dentatim, in order like tethe. Denticulus, dentatus, ta, tum, de^tosus, sa,
sum, toothed. Denticulare, to thruste in his teethe. Dentifricium, a medycyne,
wherewith the tethe be rubbed, to make them white. Dentiloquus, he that
speaks between the tethe, or lyspeth. Dentio, ire, to put forth tethe, or
breed teethe. Dentiscalpium, an instrumente, wherewith teethe be scraped.
Dentitio, onis, a puttyng forth or growinge of tethe. Denubo, psi, bear, to
mary or wedde. Denudo, aui, are, to dispoile or make naked. Denuncio, aui, are,
to show or tell a thing to an other man, or denounce. Also Denunciare
testimonium, to bring witness into the court of judgment, is they do in the
Chauncerie, where witnesses are compelled to come. Denuo, again. Deorsum,
downewarde. Depalmo, aui, are, to buffette. Depango, xi, gere, to plant or
set. Depeciscor, cisceris, to covenant or promise or agree, or patise.
Depectus, a, um, couenanted or patised. Depectus est cum hostibus, he patised
with the ennemies. Depecto, xui, uel, xi, tere, to keme diligently. Depexus, a,
um, kempte, trymmed. Depeculor, aris, ari, to rob a commune weal a prince,
or a place hallowed. Depelli portenta, wha^ monstrous or strange things do
happen, betokenynge some ill aue^ture to happen, to repele it by prayers,
auowes, or other goood deeds. Depello, puli, pellere, to put down, put
away, or remove. Depulsus, put down. Dependeo, ere, to hang down of a
thing. to depend. Dependo, di, dear, to pay. Dependere penas, to be
punysshed, to suffer peynes. Deperdo, ere, to lose. Depereo, ii, ire, to
perysshe, to dye, to love inordynately. Depesco, scui, ere, to drive cattle.
Depessus, rent, torn. Depilis, without hear. Depilo, aui, are, to pull of
hear. Deplano, to make plain. Deplanto, to set. Depleo, pleui, plere, to
fylle. Deploro, aui, are, to lament, to bewail. Deploratus, ta, tum, without
hope of recovery or remedy. Depono, posui, nere, to lay down, to deprive or
take away, to leave a thing in an other man's custody. Depositus, ta, tum,
laid down, left in an other man's keeping, also desperate. Depopulor, ari, to
distroye or waste a countreye. Deporto, aui, are, to carry or bring away. to
banyshe. Deportatus, banysshed. Deposco, poposci, deposcere, to desire much,
or require. Depositorius, he that leaves a thing with an other man. Depositum,
that which is left in an another man's keeping: or that is laid to pledge.
Depraedor, ari, to rob a country or town. Deprauo, aui, are, to make ylle,
to deprave. Deprecor, cari, to beseech. Deprecari uenia^, to ask forgyuenes.
Also Deprecari, to refuse, to desire the contrary, to put away, or deny that
which we would not have, to have in detestation, to resyste, to deliver a man
by prayer. Deprehendo, di, ere, to take a man unawares. Deprehensus est in
sermon, He was taken in his words. Deprehensus est in scelere, He was taken
with the fault. Also deprehendere to know, to perceive. Deprimo, re, to keep
down, to thrust down. Depromo, to draw out, to declare. Depso, psi, psere, to
warke a thing with the hands, to the intent to make it soft. Depuber,
depuberis, a child or young beast, which are not come to ripe years. Depudet,
he has laid aside shame. Depudico, caui, are, to dishoneste or vyolate a
womanne. Depugno, aui, are, to fight valyantly. Depurgo, aui, are, to cleanse
any thing under foot. Depuno, to make clean or pure. Deputo, aui, are, to
cut of, to esteem, to judge, to repute. Depuuio, ere, to beat. De^^^, the
name of a people in Asia. De^ce, a well most cold in summer. Dereli^quo,
dereliqui, derelinquere, to forsake utterly. Derepente, suddenly. Derideo,
risi, dear, to laugh, to scorn, to mock Deripeo, ripui, pere, to take away, to
dispoil. Deriuo, aui, are, to derive from one to an other, to lay to one, as to
lay to a man's default, or charge, to take from one, and give to an other.
Derogo, aui, are, to mynysshe, to derogate, to take away. Der^aei, a people of
Greece in the costs of Thrace. Deruncinare, to cut or pull of that which is
superfluous. Deruo, ui, ere, to fall down. Desaeuio, saeui, uire, to be wodde
angry. sometime to cease to be angry. Descendo, di, ere, to go down, to
descend. Descio, iui, ire, to know not. Descisco, iui, sciscere, to disagree,
to leave one and go to an other, to rebel. Discobinatus, wounded or cut.
Describo, psi, ere, to write out of a copy, to order or appoint, to paynte or
write aduysedly, to declare or describe. Deseco, aui, are, to cut in sonder.
Desido, sedi, ere, to sytte still, or contynually, to sit on a thing, to sit on
a chamber stole. it is also proprely when the earth does gape or chinke. Terra
desedit, the ground opens or gapeth. Desero, ui, ere, to leave or forsake.
Deserto, taui, are, to forsake. Desertus, forsaken, not inhabitable, where no
man dwells, a desert or wilderness. Deseruio, uiui, ire, to obey or serve
humbly, sometime to do ill service. Deses, desidis, unoccupied. Desiderium, a
desire. Desidero, aui, are, to desire. Desiderati, deed or slain. Desidia,
slouthfulnes. Desidiosus, a man full of idelnes, slothful. Designo, aui, are,
to assign, to note or signinifie, to do a thing newely. Designator, toris, a
marshall, which sets or appoints every man to his place, convenient to his
degree or office. Designatus, assigned, ordained. Desilio, lui, ere, to leap
or light down. Desino, sii, nere, to leave, to cease. Desinere artem, to
leave the craft. Desipio, pui, ere, to do folishly, to wax folish. Desisto,
desuti, desistere, to leave of. Desolo, aui, are, to make desolate. Desolatus,
a, u^, that is made desolate or distroyed. Desolor, ari, to comfort.
Despectio, onis, a despysynge. Despecto, aui, are, to look behind. Despectus,
ta, tum, despised. Desperatio, onis, despair. Despero, aui, are, to despair.
Desperatus, a, um, desperate. Despicabilis, to be despised. Despicientia,
despectus, despectio, dispite. Despiceo, spexi, cere, to look or behold
down, to despise. Despicor, caris, to despise. Despicus, a watcheman, to se
who comes, as it is in Calyce. Despolio, aui, are, to dispoyle or to rob.
Despondeo, di, ere, to affyance or betrouth. also to promise. Despondere
animum, to be in desperation, or weary of life, to despair of any thing, that
a man seeks for. Despondere sapientiam, to despair, to com to great wysedom.
Despumo, aui, are, to skymme or claryfye any lycour. Despuo, ui, ere, to spet
down, or spette on a thing. Desquammo, aui, are, to skale a fyshe. Destino,
aui, are, to purpose, to appoynte, to depute, to prepare, to chese, to tie to
a thing, to set a price. Destituo, ui, ere, to forsake, to leave, to deprive
or take fro, to lowse, or unbind, to set down a man. Cecilius.
Destituit omnes seruos ad mensam ante se, He did set down all his servants
at the table before him. Destringo, xi, ere, to bind hard or cut.
Destructile, that which shall be destroyed. Destruo, xi, ere, to distroy or
throw down that which is builded. Desubulo, aui, are, to perce, proprely with
an awle or bodkyn. Desudasco, to sweat. Desudo, aui, are, to sweatte much or
labor. Desuesco, ueui, scere, to discuss or bring out of custom. Desuerudo,
dinis, a disuse. Desultor, toris, he that can vaunte a horse, and leap from
one horsbacke unto an other. Also those men of war, that in time of battaylle
would leap down of their horses quyckely, and fight on foot, and leap up
again as quyckely, were Desultores. Desultorii equi, horses which served for
that purpose. Desum, defui, deesse, to lack. Desuper, from above. Desursum,
the same. Detego, tegi, tegere, to disclose or discover Deter, lacking
somewhat. Detergeo, tersi, gere, to wype of, to make clean. Determino, aui,
are, to determine, to discuss. Detero, teri, terere, to bruise, to beat out,
as grain is beaten out of the ear with threshyng or treading. Deterreo, ui,
ere, to put in fear, to let by fear. Detestabile, abhomynable. Detestor,
ari, to abhore. Among Ciuilyons, detestari is to summon a man with witness.
Detestatio, abhorryng, execration, summonyng with witness, Also Apuleius
takith it for geldynge. Detexo, xi, xere, to weaue, or to wind. Detineo, nui,
ere, to withholde, to restrain from liberty. Detondeo, detondi, dear, to
sheare or clyp. Detono, aui, are, to make a great sound. Detorqueo, si, quere,
to bow, to turn out of the right way. Detracto, aui, are, to eschew, to
forbear, to hinder by report or act. Detractores, detracters, backbyters.
Detraho, xi, here, to draw of, to report ill. Detrimentum, detriment or damage.
Detrime^tosum, that which is cause of much damage or hurt. Detrudo, si, ere,
to thruste down. sometime to constrayne or enforce. Detrullo, aui, are, to put
from one vessel into an other. Detrunco, aui, are, to cut of short. Deturbo,
aui, are, to beat down. Deturpo, aui, are, to make foul, or defyle.
Deucalion, onis, the name of a king, who in fables is said did restore
mankind distroyed with a floode. Deueho, xi, ere, to carry from a place.
Deuenio, ueni, nire, to comme down from high to low, from richesse to
poverty, from prosperity to adversity. Deuenusto, aui, are, to make foul.
Deuerbero, aui, are, to beat much. Deuerro, ri, ere, to swepe clean.
Deuestio, uestii, ire, to unclothe. Deuexo, aui, are, to vex much. Deuexus,
a, um, holowe or like to a valaye. Deuincio, xi, cire, to bind fast. Deuinco,
uici, uincere, to vanquyshe. Deuio, aui, are, to go out of the way. Deuirgino,
aui, are, to defloure a maiden. Deuito, aui, are, to eschew. Deuius, a, um,
out of the right way. Deunx, cis, a poyse, which is a pound, lacking an
ounce. Deuoco, aui, are, to call aside, or away. Deuolo, aui, are, to flee or
rounne from a higher place to a lower. Deuoluo, ni, uere, to tumble or roll
down. by translation it signifies, it is fallen, or com from one to an other,
or happened. Deuoluta est haereditas, The i^herita^ce is fallen or com. Deuoro,
aui, are, to devour. sommetyme to bear. Hoc taedium mihi deuorandum est, This
labor I must sustain. Deuotio, onis, a curse, a vow to dye, or to make a man
dye. Deuoto, aui, are, to bind by a vow. Deuotorius, a, u^, concerning a vow
or curse. Deuotus, ta, tum, vowed or cursed. Deuoueo, ere, to vow or curse, to
consent to dye. DEVS, god. Dexter, dextri, of the right hand. sometime it
signifies apt, convenient, quick and dyligent, prosperous, favorable.
Dexteritas, tatis, aptnes and redynes in the thing that a man goth about.
Dexter, tra, trum, right, or apt. Dextero, aui, are, to couple horses in a
teme, Dextrale, a bracelet to wear on the right arm. Dextrocherium the same.
Dextrarii, horses joined in a teeme. Dextrorsum, toward the right hand.
Dextimi, horsemenne being on the right wynge in battle.
D Ante I.
DIA, an addicion to women's names, when their folyshe lovers will make them
equal to goddesses. Diabolus, the dyuelle. how be it in greek it sygnifieth
proprely a falls accuser. Diaconus, a deacon. Diadema, a cappe, which an
emperor or king wears under his crown. Diaeta, a parler to suppe in. Also
dyete in eating and drinkyng. Also a place where iugementes were given.
Diaetarii, servants that do awayte on the table. Sometime such as do haunt
dyners and suppers, to the intent to steal somewhat. Dialectus, a manner of
speech, as we would say diversities in english, as Northern speech,
Southern, Kentyshe, Deuenishe, and other like. Dialexis, dysputation.
Dialectica, logyke. Dialis, Iupyter. Also it sygnifyeth of one day, as Consul
Dialis, a Consul of one day. Dialogus, a disputation between two. Diameter, a
line, which diuydeth any figure into two equal parts. Diana, the daughter of
Iupyter, which fleinge the company of men, to the intent that she would not
be meuyd with carnalle iustes, she contynually exercysed her self in hunting
wild beasts: and for her chaste life, she was honored of the paynyms for a
goddess. She is also taken for the Moon. Diapasma, a sprynkelynge of water,
or other like. Diapason, a concord in musyke of five tunes, and two half
tunes. Diapente, of five. Diaphanum, clear throughout, as crystal. Diaphonia,
a discord. Diaphora, a difference. Diaphoreticus, ca, cum, that which does
dissolve and send forth humors or vapors. Diaphragma, is a thynne skin or
caulle in the body, which separateth the heart and lunges from the spleen and
liver, and is called the Myddrefe. Diarium, prouysion for oone day. Also a
book declarynge what is done day by day. Diastole, a distinction or point,
whereby one word or sentence is distinct from an another. Diatessaron, of
eyghte. Diatretum, a cup imboced, and cunningly wrought. Dibapha, purple
twyse dyed. Also a garment thereof. Dica, a cause, an accusation, a judgment.
Dicacitas, tatis, scoffing or bourdynge. Dicaculus, and dicacula, merry in
talkyng. Dicaearchus, a just Prince. Also the name of a philosopher. Dicax,
cacis, a rayler, or reprocher. Dico, caui, to vow, to offer, to dedicate.
Dico, xi, cere, to say, to tell, to bydde, to promise, to affirm, to
defend: as Cicero dixit causam Milonis, Cicero defended Miloes cause. Dicere
sententiam, to give sentence or iudgemente^ Dicere leges, to appoynte laws, or
condycions of peace, as by the vanquysher to him that is vanquyshed. Dicere
diem, to sewe a man, or call him up, (as we use to say) by action, writ, or
commandment, proprely to cause a man to be bounden to appear and make
answer. Dicere causam, to make answer to action or playnte. Dicere mulctam,
to set or assesse a fine or sum of money to be paid by him, which has
committed a trespace. Dicere ius, to give commandment or sentence on a pain.
Sometime it sygnifyeth to govern by laws a town or country. Dicere
sacramento, to take an oath. proprely as they do, which be retained in wars.
Dictannus, an herb called dittayne. Dictator, the highest office in the
publyke weal of the Romans, which was also called Magister populi, the
master of the people: which for the space of six months, had the
authority of a king. And therefore that dignity was never given but only
when the state of the city was in any ieoperdie. Dictatura, the office or
dignity of dictator. Dicte, a city in the isle of Crete or Candy. Dicteria,
tauntes, or quippies, or short and sharp reasons. Dictio, onis, a word, a
form of speaking. Dictito, aui, are, to speak often or in diverse places.
Dicto, aui, are, to speak or declare that an other writes, or bears in
remembrance. Also to inuestigate or expound the sense of any author. Also to
bring to remembrance. Dictata, Interpretations, exposytions, or declarations,
made by masters unto their scholars. Dictum, spoken, or said. Dicta,
sygnified merry sentences. Dicturio, iui, ire, to goo about, or prepare to
speak. Dictynna, one of the names of Diana. Dictynnus, a hylle, wherein the
temple of Diana was sytuate. Dictys, one of the Centaures, and an hystographier
of Candy. Didascalus, a schole master. Dido, the name of a lady that builded
Carthage. Diduco, xi, cere, to bring into sundry parts, or to divide or pulle
aparte. Didymae, arum, ylandes of Aphrike, that bound^ on Aegypte. Didynnis,
the name of a man, and in latin it signifies Geminus, in english, a twinne
or double. Diecula, a little while. Plautus.
Dierecta, in an ill time. Dies, diei, a day. Sometime it sygnyfyeth time or
season. Dies critici, the days in which physicians do give a certain
judgment in syckenes. Diescit, it is day, it waxes day. Dies legittimi,
among lawyers be called ordinary days, or days in court. Diem dicere, an^,
dicere diem. Diespiter, one of the names of Jupiter. Dieteris, the space of two
years. Diffamo, aui, are, to sprede by fame. Differo, distuli, differ, to
spare or defer. sometime to bring from one place to an another. sometime to
report abroad, sometime to divide or cut asonder, sometime to set in order.
sometime differ or be in difference. Cic. At uide quid differat inter meam
opinionem and tuam, But se now what difference is between thine opinion and
mine. Diffibulare, to unbuckle, to open, to vngird. Difficilis, difficile,
hard, uneasy. Diffido, dear, to mystruste. Diffindo, di, ere, to cleave in
sunder. Diffinio, niui, ire, to diffine or declare in few words plainly, the
sygnyfycation of a thing. Diffinitio, onis, a diffinition, or declaration of
the nature quality or propre sygnification of a thing by generaltie,
specialtie, and difference. Diffiteor, fisus sum, diffiteri, to deny. Diffluo,
xi, ere, to flow abroad. Diffugio, gi, gere, to fly asonder, or on diverse
parts. Diffundo, di, dear, to power out, or scatter. Diffundere diem, among
lawyers, to continue the matter until an other day. Digamma, among latynes
is the letter F. Digamus, he that has had two wives, commonly called Bigamus.
Digama, a womanne that has had two husbands. Digeries, a disposition or
order. Digero, gessi, gerere, to dispose, to order, to interpret or make
plain, to deuyde, to dygeste. Digitalis, le, pertaining to the finger.
Digitali crassitudine, The thyckenesse of a finger. Digitalia, things worn on
the fyngers. Digitus, a finger. Digitum transuersum, sygnifyeth in a sentence,
a little or small distaunce. Digitum transuersum ab eo non discedebat, He
went not from him a finger bredde. Digladiari, to fight together with swords.
by translation to contend or strive. Dignatio, favor or familiarity. Liuius.
Dignitas, tatis, honor given or dew to a man for his merits. sommetyme
astate of nobility, or great authorytie. sommetyme beauty, proprely of a man,
specially in gesture and communication. Digno, aui, are, and dignor, ari, to
judge one to be worthy, or to be esteemed worthy. Dignosco, noui, scere, to
discern or know by diverse means. Dignoro, aui are, to mark, as men mark
beasts to know them. Dignus, na, number, worthy. Digne, worthyly. Digredior,
dieris, gredi, to depart or goo away. Digressio, and digressus, a departing.
Diiouis, Iupyter. Diiudico, caui, care, to judge betwyxte two things. Dilabor,
eris, labi, to slyppe or go away, to fall down, as ^ house does. sometime
it signyfieth to fail. Dilacero, aui, are, to tear or rent in pieces.
Dilapido, daui, are, to consume goods, or spend ryotrously or wastefully.
Dilato, aui, are, to stretche out in breadth. Dile^ma, it is, an argument, which
on every part taunteth him, to whom it is spoken. Diligens, it is, diligent, or
loving. Diligentia, dilygence or love. Diligo, lexi, ligere, Plautus.
to favor or love meanly sometime to diuyde. Dilorico, aui, are, to undo, or
cut a cote, or other thing being sowed. Dilucescit, the day appears.
Dilucidus, clear, bryghte. Diluculo, an aduerbe, which signifies betyme in
the morning. Diluculo, laui, lare, to wax day, to appear to be day.
Diluculum, that portion of day, which is before that the son ryseth.
Diludium, the leauyng of play, or the space between recreations or plays.
Diluo, ui, ere, to wasshe, to make clean, to put away, to release, to alaye,
as wine is alayde with water: or to tempre, to purge, or discharge a crime.
Dilutus, ta, tum, alayed or tempred. Dilutus color, a faint color, or
imperfect color. Dilutum, is wine or other lycour, wherein any herb or other
thing is depid by a certain space, which some phisytions call infused.
Diluuium, is when the earth is surrounded or drowned with much rain. Dimauo,
aui, are, to flow abroad, as diverse streams out of one spring. Dimembro,
aui, are, to deuyde. Dimensum, and demensum, measured. Dimico, aui, are, to
sight or contend with some thing. Dimidius, a, um, the half deal of that
which is divided. Dimidium plus toto, is spoken where a man intends to show
that that the mean is best. Dimidiatus, a, um, the half deal of that which
is not severed or divided. Diminuo, ui, ere, to minyshe, to cut of.
Dimissoriae literae, letters sent from oone to an another. Dimitto, si, tere, to
send diverse persons into diverse places. Sometime it sygnifieth to let to
depart, to give leave, to cease, to leave, to let pass, to suffer, to
humble. Deiecit uultu^ and dimissa uoce locuta est, She did cast down her
look, and with an humble voice said. Also to give, to let down. Dim^ssus, a,
um, is sommetyme taken for abiecte. Dimulgo, aui, are, to publyshe abroad.
Dynas^ae, potestates. Dindymene, and Dindyme, one of the names of Cybele,
called the mother of the gods Dindymus, the rydge of the hylle of Ida in
Phrigia. Diobolares meretrices, harlottes, which be hired for little money.
Diolares, harlottes, which keep abroad in the feldes and woddes. Dioecesis,
sios, a jurisdiction, a governance. Also the diocese of a bishop. Diminutus
capite, and diminutio capitis, Vide ante, capitis diminutio. Diodorus, a
philosopher of Socrates sect, and Diodorus Siculus, a story writer. and an
other Diodorus, Ci. in Br^to. and Tus. lib. 5.
a stoike philosopher, of whom Cicero writes. Diogenes, a famous philosphers
name. Dione, a goddess of the sea, mother of Venus. Dioptra, a geometrical
instrument, to discern altitudes and distaunce. Victrunius uses it for
wayinge or pluckynge up of water. Dioscoron, an isle in the borders of Italy.
Diospolis, a city of Aegypte. There be four other of the same name in
Aegypte, but very small cities in comparyson of this. Diotae, vessels of earth
with handels, wherein wine was kept. Diphthera, a shepeherdes cote made with
sheep skynnes. Diphthongus, two vowels joined together called a dipthonge, as
ae, oe, au, ei. Diploma, it is, a Charter of a prince or city, or a writ.
Diplois, idis, any garmente lyned, but it is taken for a doublette. Dipondium,
a weight of two pound. Dipsacon, white brere. Dipsas, a serpent, of whom if a
man be bitten, he dies for thyrste. Dyrrachiu^, a city in the realm of
Naples. Dirae, cursings. Dirce, a woman's name, the wife of Lycus king of
Thebans. Diribitores, distrybuters of money, or pay masters. Dirigeo, gui,
gere, to shrynke for cold, or for fear. Dirigo, exi, gere, to make straight,
or right. Directus, a, um, right or straight. Direct, straight, or in a right
form. Dirimo, remi, ere, reptum, to break or leave of. Ears consilium
diremit, That thing brake or dissolved the counsel. also to put of, or
defer. Diripio. Vide in deripio. Diris, an high hylle of Maurytayne now
called Atlas. Dirus, ra, rum, vengeable. Diritas, tatis, cruelty, vengeance.
Dirumpo, rupi, rumpere, to braste or break a sonder. Diruncio, iui, ire, to
wede out, or purge that which is naught. Dis, ditis, called the god of
richesse, sometime it signifies rich. Discapidino, aui, are, to unclose or
open. Discedo, scessi, dear, to depart. sometime it signifies an exception
as, Quum discesserim a fratre, nemo est mihi te charior, Except my brother, no man is to me more dear than thou art. Also it sygnifieth dyuysion or
opening. as, Ci. 1. (...)
Quum terra discessisset, magnis quibusdam imbribus, discendit in illum
^^^atum, when the earth by thoccasyon of much rain opened, he went down
into the cleft or swalowe. Discepto, aui, are, to dspute or contend.
Disceptatio, disputation or contencion. Discerniculum, diuersytie. Discerno,
decreui, cernere, to depart or sundre one thing from an other. Also to strive
or vary, to know distinctly. Discerpo, psi, ere, to pluck or tear in piecis.
Discinctus, dissolute, or neglygent, or unable for the wars, cowarde. Seruius.
Discindo, scidi, scindere, to cut of. Disciplina, lerning as it is perceived
of the scholar. It is also a good form of living. Disciplinosus, apt to
learn. Discipulus, a scholar or disciple. Discludo, si, dear, to shut out.
Disco, didici, discere, to learn. Dedisco, ere, to forgette that which was
ones learned. Discobolus, he that throws a dyshe. Disconuenio, ni, nire, to
disagree or discord. Discordia, discord. Discors, dis, he that agrees not
with an another. Discrepo, aui, are, to disagree or discord. Discretio, onis, a
separation. sometime election of good from ill, discretion. Discretus, severed
or parted. Valla says, that it is he that discerns the qualyties of men,
and value of things. Discrimen, minis, diversity or difference. also the
shedynge or partynge of the hear. Also it sygnifieth peril. Discriminale, an
instrument, wherewith the hear is parted or shadde. Discriminatim, a sunder
here and there. Discrimino, aui, are, to deuyde. Discrutior, ari, to be much
vexed or troubled in mind. Discumbo, cubui, cumbere, to sit at meals.
Discuneatus, opened wih a wedge or other like thing. Discurro, rere, to run
hither and thither, or wander. Discus, a dyshe. Also a round thing of wodde
or mettalle, which in playinge is thrown from one man to an another. It is
sometime taken for the hole figure of the son or the moon. Discutio, ssi,
tere, to cast or shake down, to remove, to examyne, or discuss. Disertus,
eloquent in words. Disiicio, disieci, disiicere, to cast a sonder. Disiungo,
xi, ere, to vnioyne, to separate. Dispalescere, to publyshe abroad. Dispalo,
aui, are, to wander. Dispalati, scattered. Dispello, dispuli, dispellere, to
expelle or put from many places or many ways. Dispendiosus, sa, sum, harmful,
unprofitable. Dispendium, loss by neclygence, or superfluous expenses. Also it
signifies harm. Dispe^do, di, ere, to spe^de, also to stretch out. Dispenno,
ere, to stretche. Dispensator, toris, a steward, or other offycer, layinge out
money for howseholde: a disposer of things. Dispenso, aui, are, to lay out
money. Dispereo, rii, tire, to be lost utterly. Disperdo, di, ere, to lose.
Dispergo, spersi, gere, to sow abroad, or to scatter. Dispertio, tiui, ire, to
give part to one, part to an another. Dispesco, cui, ere, to drive beasts
from their pasture. Dispesso, ssi, ere, to sprede abroad. Dispicio, xi, cere,
to discern, to espy, to consider. Dispicientia, circumspection, aduysement,
diligent consyderation. Displodo, si, dear, to sprede. Dispondaeus, a foot in
meter, that has four syllables long, as Oratores. Dispono, sui, ere, to
dispose, to order. Dspungo, xi, gere, to take account, or examyne any manner of
thing written. Dispunctio, an examination. Disputo, taui, tare, to dispute, to
make plain to be understand. Disquiro, siui, rere, to inserche diligently, to
inquyre. Disquisitio, where every man's opinyon is asked in a matter, which
requires judgment. Disraro, raui, rare, to make thynne that which is thycke.
Dissuauior, ari, to kiss swetely, and with much delectation. Dissecatus, ta,
tum, cut as a body is in an anotomye. Dissectio, onis, an Anotomie. Disseco,
caui, care, to cut in pieces. Dissentaneus, a, um, not according. Dissentio,
tire, and dissentior, tiri, to think contrary, or to disagree. Dissero, rui,
rere, to sow seeds, sometime to dispute or declare. Disserto idem. Dissertio,
a particion of lands. Dissideo, ere, to be at variance or discord. Dissidium,
variance or discord. Dissilio, liui, ire, to lepe down from a place, sometime
to braste. Dissimulo, aui, are, to dissemble or feign a thing, which is not
as it seems to be. Dissipo, aui, are, to scatter or sprede abroad or
dispatche, also to bring unto naught. Dissitus, ta, tum, set far of,
distant. Dissoluo, ui, uere, to lose or vnbynd, to speed to pay several
dettes. Dissolui, to be paid or discharged. Dissoluere religionem, to do
against the relygion, to break the relygion. Dissonus, na, number, that which
does not accord. Dissulto, taui, tare, to leap hither and thither. Disto,
aui, are, to differ, to be distant. Distantia, distaunce. Distendo, di, dear,
to stratche out, or retche, to fill, as a bottell is filled. Distentus, fulle.
Distero, terete, to break small, to pound or to braye syne. Distichon, two
versis. Distillo, aui, are, to distylle, or drop down. Distillatio, onis, a
distyllyng, specially from the heed, callid a reume or catarf, the pose.
Distineo, nui, ere, to let or withholde with business, or vrgente causes, to
hold or put back. Distinguo, xi, ere, to dyuide. Also to make dystinction.
Distito, aui, are, to stand aparte, or be dystant one from an other. Distraho,
xi, here, to pluck away, or to dyuide, or to withdraw a thing. sometime by
translation it is taken for to sell. Also to fynisshe or conclude matters in
variaunce. Controuersias distrahere, to end controversies or suites.
Distribuo, ui, ere, to dystrybute, or give in sundry parts to diverse persons.
Distringo, xi, gere, to bynd fast, or to strain hard, to rub of or cleanse
the fylthe or soil of the body, to thretten to stryke, or to draw out a
sword. Gladium distrinxit, He drew out his sword. Sommetyme to gather,
Columel.
as, Sereno caelo manibus distringi oliuam opertet, In a fair clear day the
olyues must be gathered by hand. Districtus negotiis, let with business.
Distorqueo, distorsi, quere, to draw awrye, or aside. Disturbo, aui, are, to
cast down. Disulcus, an hog, which has the bristils of his neck divided.
Diteo, and ditesco, sci, scere, to make rich, or be rich. Dithyrambus, a
verse made in the honor of Bacchus. Ditio, onis, a domynion. Dito, aui, are,
to make rich. Dittochaeus, a foot of four sillables in verse, having one
long, an other short, an another long, the fourth short. Diu, long time.
also the day time. whereof comes Interdiu, in the day time. Diutius, lengar.
diutissime, lengest. Diuagor, ari, to wa^der from place to place. Diuarico,
aui, are, to stryde, or to spread wide one from an other, as bowghes of a tree.
Diuello, li, ere, to pull away by violence. Diuendo, didi, dear, to selle to
diverse persons, or in diverse parcelles. Diuerbia, the parts of a comedy or
interlude, where many persons speak together. Diuersito, aui, are, to turn
often to a thing, or to resort. Diuersor, ari, to resort, or repair to a
place. Diuersorium, an inn, whereto men in journey do resort to bayte or be
lodged: a lodging. Diuersorius, a, um, pertaining to an inn, or lodging.
Diuersus, a, um, diverse or separate. Diuerticulum, a by way, or side way, out
of the high way. Diuerto, ti, tere, to turn from one thing to an other, to
take lodging, or to bayte. Diuerto ad te and apud te, I come to lodge with
the, or to tarry for a time with the. Dives, diuitis, rich. ditior, rycher,
ditissimus, rychest. Diuexo, aui, are, to vex or trouble. Diuidia, tediousnes.
sometime it betokens discord. Diuidiculum, an heed of a cundyte. Diuidium, a
particion or diuident. Diuido, si, dear, to divide or part in sonder.
Diuiduum, that which may be severed or diuyded. Diuinipotens, he that has
power in divine things. Diuinitus, godly, or of god. Diuino, aui, are, to
tell truth, as well of things present, as of things passed. for the more
part it signifies to coniecte of things present, what shall happen.
Diuinatio, onis, a foreiugement or conjecture. Also where a matter comes in
judgment, without writing or witness on any of the parts, that judgment may
be called Diuinatio, a divination. Diuinus, na, number, that which pertayneth to
god, divine. Diuisio, onis, whereby we declare what is in variance, or whereby
we do express of what things we will treat. Also a diuysyon into sundry
parts. Divisor, oris, among the old Romans was he, which at the election
of greatte officers, diuidid or gave money to the people, in the names of them
which sued for the office, to the intent for to attain it. Diuitiae,
diuitiarum, diuitiis, diuitias, riches. Diuito, aui, are, to make rich. Dium,
the day light under the fyrmament. when we say, Sub dio aliquid fieri, it
sygnifieth some thing to be done abroode, or out of the house. Diunt, old
writers used for dant, they give. Diuortium, a dyuorse, or separation of a man
and his wife. sometime a departing from any other thing. Diurno, aui, are, to
live long. Diurnus, na, number, pertayninge to day, as Diurni libri, books
containing the actis done every day. sometime a days hyre. Dius, dia, come of
a gentle stock. Diutule, a little while. Diutinus, tina, number, long
contynuynge. Diutissime, very long, or to long. Diuturnus, na, number, long
continuynge. Diuus, ua, uum, worthy a divine remembrance, Now they take Diuum,
and diuam, for a man or woman saynct.
D Ante O.
Terentius
DO, dedi, dare, to give. Also to offer, or proffre. Vt tes dant sese, As
things offer them selfs. Vergilius.
Also to bring. Magnam dabit ille ruina^ arboribus, He shall bring a great
fall unto trees. Also to say, Quamobrem has parts didicerim paucis da bo, For
what cause I learned that part, I will tell the in few words. Also to obey,
Terentius
to conform. Da te mihi, Conform the to my will. Also to commit or do. O
Aeschine, pol haud paternum istue dedisti, O Eschines, in good faith in this
thou have not done like a father. Dare operam, to apply, to give or take heed,
or to help. Do manus, I render me, or I am vanquished. Dare poenas, to suffer
punyshement. Dare ueniam, to forgive. Dare potestatem, to commytte authority
or power, or remyt a thing to an other man's pleasure or liberty. Suarum
ominum reru^ illi potestare^ dederat, He gave him the rule of all that he had.
Dare fidem, to promise faithfully. Dare facultatem, to give liberty or power
to do a thing. Dare manum, to put into his hand pryuily, as they do to men
of law, or privy solyciters, or corrupt officers. Dare damnas, to pay damages,
or to make satisfaction. Dare auribus, to flatter, or speak to please.
Salustius.
Dare negotium, to assign or appoynte business, or a thing to be done. Ci.
Teren. Plaut. Eras. in Chilia. Vergilius.
Dare in uiam, to take a journey. Dare in pedes, to flee or run away. Dare
uerba, to deceive by fair promyses, or pleasant demonstration. Datum est, It
is predestinate. Doceo, cui, cere, to teach or give knowelege, or to inform,
to advise. Docibilis, apt to be taught. Docilis, lightly taught or instructed.
Docilitas, aptenes to learn. Doctrina, ae, doctrine, which proceeds of the
teacher. Disciplina, learning taken of the scholar. Documentum, a lesson.
Doctus, ta, tum, learned, that is to say, knowing a thing without experience.
Vide peritus. Dodona, a city in Greece, whereby was a wood, in the which men
thought that trees spoke. Dodone, the daughter of Jupiter and Europa. Dodra,
was a drink made of nine things, herbs, iuyse, water, wine, salt, oil,
bread, honey, and pepper. Dodrans, antis, a poyse waying.ix. ounces. Dogma,
atis, a certain determination, which in sects of philosophers every oone had,
without the which the sect failed. sometime they be called placita. Dolabra,
a carpentars axe. Dolabro, aui, are, to hew as a carpentar. Dolentia, grief.
Doleo, ui, ere, to feel pain or grefe. Dolere caput, pedes, oculos, the heed,
fete, or eyes to ache. Doleo tuis rebus aduersis, I am sorry for thy mysfortune
or trouble. Doleo tuam uicem, I am sorye on thy behalf. Dolium, any great
vessel of wine, as a tu^ne, pipe, butre, or hoggisheed. Doliaris, great as a
tun. Doliaris heluo, a gorbelyed glutton. Doliarium, a wine sellar. Dolichus,
a space of ground contaynyng xii. furlonges. Dolo, aui, are, to cut or hew
with an axe or sithe. Dolio, iui, ire, to grave in metal. Dolobella, an
hatchette. Dolon, the propre name of a man of Troy, Varro.
that was very swifte of foot. Dolones, a scourge, having a dagger, or other
like thing closed within it. Seruius. Liuius.
It is also a certain taklynge of ships. Also a little sail called a
trynkette. Dolopes, a people of Thessaly. Dolor, is, grief or pain of body or
mind, also sorrow. Dolorificus, ca, cum, that which makethe grief or sorrow.
Dolus, deceypte. Dolus malus, every crafty deceit to compass a man, whereby he
receives damage. Dolosus, deceytefull, or crafty. Doma, it is, a solar or flat
keuerynge of a house. it is sometime taken for the house. Suetonius
Domesticatim, by householdes. Domesticus, ca, cum, pertainynge to household.
sometime it sygnifieth tame. Domestici, householde servants. Domicilium, a
mansyon place. Domicoenium, an home suppar. Dominor, ari, to rule or have
souerayntie. Domiporta, a pylar or other like thing, that bears up an house.
Dominus, a lord or master, to whom other do service. Dominium, a lordeshyp or
rule over other. Lucretius.
Domis, was taken of old writers for dominus. Domitalis, apt to be tamed or
broken. Domitura, the act of tamynge or brekyng of any wild beast. Domo,
aui, are, to make tame, sommetyme to vaynquyshe, as Domare hosts, to
vaynquyshe enemies. Domitor, oris, a tamer or breaker of that, which is
wild. Domitio, onis, a retournynge home. Domus, mus, mui, a house generally.
Domus, domi, mo, a dwelling house. Domun^ula, a little or poor house. Donum,
a gift or reward. Donarium, a house, where such things were kept, that
were given to the gods. It is sometime taken for a gift or reward.
Donatiuum, a gift in money or grayn, given by emperors unto the people. also
to sowldiours above their wages. Donatiuus, he that is able to give. Donatus,
he to whom any thing is given. rewarded. Donax, cis, a reed or cane, whereof
they made arowes. Donec, vatyll. sometime as long. Donec uiuo, as long as I
live. Dono, aui, are, to give lyberally and freely. Donysa, an isle in the sea
Aegeum. Dorcas, cadis, a bucke or a do. Doria, and Dorica, names of countries
ioynynge to Athenes. Dorion, a town of Achaie. Doors, people in Greece nygh to
Aetolia. Doris, a Nymph of the sea, and is interpretate bytternesse. Dormio,
miui, ire, to sleep. Dormito, aui, are, to sleep soundely. Dorsualia, panels,
which horses do wear on their backs, when they carry or draw. Dorsuarius,
ia, um, that which bears or carries any thing on the back. Dorsum, a back
of man or beast. Dorilaus, the name of a river in Phrigia. Doryphorus, a yoman
of the guard, or other like, which for gardyng of his masters person, bears
always a iauelyn or byll. Dos, dotis, dowery, land given in marriage, to the
husband or wife, for cause of the marriage only. Dotes animi, indowmentes of
the soul, that is to say, virtues and good manners. Dotes corporis, indowmentes
of the body, that is to say, beauty, strength, health. etc. Dotalis, le, that
pertayneth to dowerie, as bona dotalia. Doto, aui, are, to indowe.
D ante R.
Dram, ae, a poise or weight, ponderynge.lx. where corns, taken out of the
mids of the ear. Also a coin of Athenes, signed with a bullock. Draco, nis
a dragon. Draconarius, a standerde bearer. Dracones, of Pliny be taken for old
branches of vynes. also it is an herb, which is otherwise called Pyretum, it
bourneth and byteth the tongue, as well the lease as the root. Draconites, a
precious stone, taken out of the heed of a dragon, while he lives. Dracontium,
an herb called dragons. Dracunculus, a little dragon. Dragma, a grype or
hand full. Dracontia, an herb called dragons. Drama, matis, where in a comedy
or interlude, diverse personages be brought in, some abydyng, some departing.
Drangiana, a province in Asia the more. Drepanum, the name of a city.
Dromedarius, a beast like to a camel, but of a wonderful swiftenes. Dromus,
the place where men do rounne horses. Drupae, a kind of olyues. Drusus, the
name of a Romayne, of right noble lynage, and eloquence: but he was proud and
ambicious. Dryas, the propre name of a man of Thessaly, friend of Nestor.
Dryades, were fairies of woddes. Dryidae, sieve Druidae, were in the old time
religious, or rather superstitious persons in France, which used art
magike. Drylon, a river of Dalmacie. Drymodis, afterward Pelasgus, is now
called Archadie. Dryos, slyme growing in oaks. Drypetae, a kind of olyues.
D, ante V.
DVbio, aui, are, to be in doubt. Plaut.
Dubiat quid agat. He is in doubt, what he should do. Dubito, aui, are, to be
in doubt, or to tracte time. Dubitatio, and dubietas, doubt. Dubitanter,
dubitatim, doubtfully. Dubious, a, um, doubtful, Dubious is he that has two
ways, and woteth not which to take. Ducatus, tus, the act of a capteyn, or
guide. Also a duchy. also Ducatus, ti, a coin callid a ducat. Ducenarius, a
captain of.CC. men. Duco, xi, cere, to lead them that be willing, to have
respect to a thing. some time it signifies to allecte or stir with some
pleasant mean. also to reuolue: also to draw, as a man draws a sword,
also to get. sometime it signifies doing, as Ducere somnos, to sleep. Also
to build or make up. sometime to turn away. as Ducere uultus, to turn away
the visage. to delay or prolonge. to go down. Ego me duco ab arbore, I went
down of the tree. Also to wedde, or do the act of marriage. Varro.
Duco, aui, are, to govern. Ductarius funis, a cord that is drawn. Ductilis,
and ductile, easy to be drawn. Ductim, with leysour. Ductiro, aui, are, to
lead about often. Ducto, aui, are, to lead about. Dudum, but late. Duella,
a poyse, contaynynge.ii. drammes and.ii scruples. Duello, aui, are, to fight
within lystes, or in battle. Duellator, he that does battle. Duellona, men
in old time called Bellona. Duillus, a citesens name of Rome, which Duelium,
battle. first tryumphed for victory on the sea. Duis, of the ancient
writers was used for dederis. Dulcadium, every sweet meat. Dulcis, and dulce,
sweet. Dulcedo, Dulcitas, Dulcitudo, and Dulcor, sweetness. Dulcesco, sci,
scere, to become sweet. Dulciarius panis, a marchepayn made with almondes and
sugar. Dulciarius, a pastlar. Dulcifluus, flowynge swetely. Dulciloquus, he
that speaks swetely. Dulcisonus, sownynge swetely. Dulco, caui, dulcare, to
make sweet. Dulia, the service of a bondeman or slave. Dulichium, an i will in the sea Maliake, or as some say, Ionio. Dum, sometime signifies when, or whiles,
as, Dum dormis, fures domu^ intram, whiles thou slepest, thieves enter in to the
house. sometime until, sometime as long. Also it signifies wherefore: also, so
that. sometime it does but make up a word: as, Adesdu^, paucis te uolo, Come
hither, I would a few things with the. Dummodo, so that. Dumtaxat, only.
Dumetum, a thorny or busshy ground. Dumus, all kinds of thorns or breres.
Duo, two. Duo, dui, ere, to give. Plautus.
Duodeni, twelve together. Vide deni. Duplaris numerus, a nombre doubled.
Duplares, knights, or such soldiers as had double alowaunce. Duplex,
duplicis, double, or two. Cato de re rustie.
Duplico, aui, are, to make double. Dupli, double so much. Duplus, a, um,
double. Durabile, durable. Dutacinae vuae, grapes with thick skynnes. Duram,
some think to be the name of a river, nere to which the gyantes made the
tower Babel: Some woll it to be a field, Daniel. 3.
as in Daniel. Duramen, and duramentu^, the arm of a vine. Durateus, ea, um,
wodden, or of wodde. Dure, and duriter, hardly, or cruelly. Dureo, rui, ere, to
be hard or cruel. Duresco, sci, scere, to wax hard. Dureta, the Spayniardes
call a vessel, that they use to wasshe and bayne them in. Duria, or Turia, the
name of a river nere to Valentia. Duricia, and duricies, hardness. Duro, aui,
are, to endure, to sustain or suffer. Durus, ra, rum, hard, paynfull, or
cruel. Dux, ducis, a captain or leader.
D ante Y.
DYnastes, a lord, a prince, a ruler. Dynastia, might, power. Dyrrachium, a
city in Cicile, which first was called Epida^nus. Dys, in composition,
signifies yuell, difficile, or impossible. Dyscolia, difficulty. Dyscolus,
intractable. Dysenteria, frearynge of the guts. Dysonoea, difficulty in
fetching breath. Dysuria, a syckenes, which lets a man that he can not
pysse, called the strangurie.
ERE TVA, pertainyng to thy profit. E Republica, concerning the common weal.
E ante A.
EAntes, the name of a story writer, which was in that age, that Pygmalion
reigned in the east part. Eatenus, unto that, in that manner of wise. Ebenus,
uel ebenum, a tree, which is black in color, and is odoriferous, when it is
bourned, it has virtue to cleanse the eyes. This tree grows in India, which
being cut, wareth as hard as stone. Sola India nigrum fert ebenum, India
alone brings forth black Ebenus. Virg. 2. Geor. Eboratus, a, um, of yuorie
without. Eboreus, ea, um, of yuorie. Ebosus, an isle, between the Isles Ophiusa
and Pythiusa, the earth of which isle serpents can not abide. Ebrio, aui, are,
ebriulo, to make drunk. Ebrius, ia, um, drunken. sometime abu^dant. Ebrietas,
tatis, drunkenness. Ebriosus, a, um, often drunk. Ebron, a mountain in
Palestina. Ebudes, yles in the sea about England, where the people do live by
white meat and fysshe. Ebuleus, the son of Iupyter and Pros^^pine. Ebullo,
aui, are to braste out, or bubble up, as water does when it rayneth. Ebulum,
an herb, of some called walwort. Ebur, and ebor, oris, yuorie. Eburneus, ea,
um, eburnus, of yuorie. Eburones, people of the countreye called Liege, or
Luke, beyond Brabant.
E Ante C.
ECbasis, a figure in speaking, called digression, where a man leaves for
the time the principal matter. Ecbatana, the chief city of the royalme of
Mede. There is a city in Syria of the same name, sommetyme called Ephiphania,
and may be written Egbatana. Ecce, an aduerbe demonstratiue, which sygnyfyeth,
Lo, see, proprely where a thing suddenly happens. Ecce tibi, wylt thou see,
take heed. Ecclesia, an assembly, a counsel. Among christen authors, it
signifies the congregation of people in the faith of Christ. Ecclesiastes, a
preacher. Eccubi, lo where. Eccum, eccam, eccos, eccas, lo he is here: lo she
is here, lo these men be here, loo these women be here. Echemythia,
taciturnitie, or stylnesse. Echeneis, a little fysshe, which retayneth a
ship under saylle, that he can not move. Echidna, a water serpent.
Echinades, been Islands in the sea Malyake. Echinus, the vttermooste shaale of
a cheston nutte. It is also an Hedgehogge. Also a fyshe like to the same beast,
also a vessel of tynne, wherein cups be washed. Also the name of a city.
Echion, a certain medicyne. Echioni, Thebans, so called of Echyon, oone of
the five, that help Cadruus to build Thebes. Echites, a stone specked like a
Serpent. Echo, a sound, which reboundeth to the noise or voice, that is made
in a valay, or in great woddes. Eclegma, atis, a medycyne, which must not be
eaten or chewed: but being in the mouth, suffered to still down into the
stomach by little and little. Eclipsis, a wanynge or faylynge. Econa, an
image. Econcula, a little image. Econtrario, contrary wise. Ecphrasis, a
plain interpretation of the letter. Ecquando, at what time, or lo when.
Ecquis, but who, see who. Ecquid, but what, lo what. Ecstasis, a stonye, a
dampe, a traunse, when a man forgets him self. Ectasis, a figure, whereby a
syllable naturally short, is produced. Ecthlipsis, where, in, joined with a
vowell, is not sowned. Ectropium, when the nether lydde of the eye falls,
and can not join with the over lydde. Hecyra, a mother in law.
E Ante D.
EDax, edacis, a greatte eater or consumer. Edo, edonis, the same. Edentatus,
tootheles. Edento, aui, are, to make tootheles. Edentulus, toothelesse. Edera,
Iuye. Edessa, a City beyond the river of Euphrates. Edico, xi, cere, to
command, to ordeyne, to declare. Edict^, ordinances or commandments of
them, which be in great authority. Edo, es, edi, esum, uel ^^tum, to eat or
feed. Ede nasturtium, is applied to a cull and gross person: and for as much
as Nasturtium, called Cressis, being eaten, does make the nose tynkell, and
thereby causes the dulle spirits to wake, therefore by this proves is meant,
Pluck up thy spirits: or, awake dullarde or luske. Edituus, a sextan of a
church. Edilia, all things that appertain to be eaten. Pac.
Edissero, edisseris, to explane, to declare. Edissere fabulam hanc, Declare
this fable. Edolo, aui, are, to hew or cut clean and smothe. Edom, Esau was
so called, and the country where he reigned. Edomus, a hylle nere to Pangcum
in the borders of Thessalye. Edones, people of Thrace, nere to the sea cooste.
Edonides, were women which slutred with a divine furoure, did celebrate the
mysteryes of Bacchus. Edonii, people of Thrace. Edonus, a hill, where the same
people inhabyteth. Cicero in Phil.
Edormite crapulam, to sleep out a surfette. Educo, xi, cere, to bring forth,
also to draw out, Virgilius.
as, Hoc dicens, eduxit corpore telum, That saying, he drew the weapon out
of his body. Sometime to reyse up. Educo, aui, are, to nouryshe or bring up
from chyldehoode. Educatio, nourishyng or bryngyng up of children. Edulco,
aui, are, to make very sweet. Edulis, le, that may be eaten. Edulium, is what
so ever is set on the table at diner and supper to be eaten, save the breed.
Edurum, not hard.
E ante E and F.
EEton, Andromaches father, that reigned at Thebes in Cilicie. Effartio,
effarsi, ire, to stuff or fill a thing. Effari, to speak. Effaxillo, aui, are,
to cut of by the arm pit. Effero, extuli, efferre, to carry out or put out.
sometime to overcome or subdue. also to commend: sometime to hold up, to set
forth: sometime to mynisshe or appayre. Effero, aui, are, to make images of
wild beasts. Efficax, acis, effectuell. Efficaua, effect or virtue. Efficio,
eci, icere, to bring to effect. Effectus, effect. Effigles, a sign made to
the l^^ely similitude of man or beast. Plaut.
Effigia, the same. Effiugo, xi, gere, to make like. Efflagito, aui, are, to
desire or ask a thing impo^^^nately. Efflictim, excedyngly. Efflo, aui, are,
to blow away, or blow forth. Effloreo, and effloresco, to blo, as a flour does
at the first coming out. Effl^o, ^xi, ere, to flow or rounne out, as water
does out of a fountain. Effodio, ssi, and di, ere, to dygge out. Effoemino,
aui, are, to effeminate or make delycate. Effoeminati, m^nne wanton and
delicate, or tender, enduryng no hardness. Effoeta, she that has lately
brought forth a child. Also a womanne paste teemynge. Terra effoeta, land:
spent or worn with bearing of much grain. Effoetus, ta, tum, barayne,
consumed, feeble. Effrenus, na, number, without a beydell. Effugio, gi, ere, to
escape. Effundo, fudi, ere, to power out. sometime it signifies to consume, to
put out. Effusus, sa, um, discomfited, scattered, put out, or powered out.
Effugium, discomfiture, or flight. Effutio, iui, ire, to speak unadvisedly, or
folyshely, or hastily.
E ante G.
EGelaste, a town in the hither Spayn. Egelidor, aris, to relent or dissolve,
as yse that thawith. Egenus, nedy, or lacking somewhat. Egeo, egui, ere, to
need or lack. Egens, lacking. Egesta, a city in Sicile, which Aeneas
builded. Egestas, tatis, necessity or lack of things necessary, poverty.
Egero, ssi, rere, to bear out. Egestosus, a, um, very poor. Egredior, eris,
gredi, to go forth, or go out. Egregius, a, um, excellent. Egregie,
excellently. Egurgito, aui, are, to draw out, as lycoure out of a place.
E ante H, and E ante I.
EHo, an Interiection of calling. it signifies how. Eho dum ad me, How come
hither to me. Eia, sommetyme it exhorts, sommetyme it blames. Eiiceo, eieci,
eiicere, to cast out, or put out. Eiectitius, a, um, being cast out. Eiulo,
aui, are, to cry out, to wayle. Eiurare, to do beside the law. Eiusmodi, and
eiuscemodi, the same. Eiusdem farinae, of the same sort or co^dicio^. Eiusde^
notae, of the same estimation or state.
E Ante L.
ELabor, eris, elabi, elapsum, to slyppe or slide. sometime to escape. Elaboro,
aui, are, to labor. Elacateria, a sauce used in the old time. Elamitae, be
called the princes of Porsyanes, of Elam the son of Sem, as Josephus says.
Elatus, proud, high. Elea, a city in the country of Lucania. Eleates, a man
of that city. Electio, onis, an election, an approbation. Electo, aui, are, to
chose. Electrum, that which is in english called ambre, whereof beads be
made, It is also taken for a mettalle, part gold, part silver. Plin.
Eleemosina, alms. Elegans, it is, elegaunte, fresshe, gorgyous, clean,
polyte. Elegantia, elegancy, gorgiousnes, clennes, beauty in words. Elegia, a
lamentable song or verse. Elegus, the same. Elegiacus, ca, cum, pertaining
thereto. Elegiographus, a writer of lamentable versis, or balades. Elego, elegi,
eligere, to chose. Elei, people in Greece in the country some time called
Peloponessus, now Morea. Elementa, the first or pryncipall mattier, whereof al
things do take their beginning: which be four in number, fire, air, water,
and earth. Also the letters, whereof sillables be made, are called elementa.
Elenchus, an argument, reprouynge subtly an other argument. It is also a
table in a book, to show the places by letter or other wise. It is moreover a
great perle, or other precious stone, which women were wont to hang at their
cares. Eleo, eui, ere, to spotte, or soil. Elephas, antis, uel elephantus, ti,
a beast, called an olyphaunt. It is sometime taken for yuory. sometime a
syckenes called lepry. Elephantezographi, be called these peynters, which
peynt with yuorie. Elephantia, seu elephantiasis, a kind of leprie, wherein the
flesh does swelle, and is full of spots. Elephantiacus, a lepre.
Elephantini libri, among the old Romans were books, wherein their laws were
written, which concerned the nobility. Elephantinus, pertaining to an
olyphant. Eleus, a river, which waters a greatte part of Media. Eleules, a
purgation. Eleuo, aui, are, to lift up. sometime to take away, to mynyshe, to
extenuate. Elusa, an isle against Cypers. Elusis, and elusin, a City in the
prouynce of Africa, not far from Athenes. Eleusina sacra, ceremonies of Ceres
the goddess. Elutherius, the name of a man, and is interpretate, free,
gentle. Elutheria, freedom, gentylnesse. Elices, sorrows in the fields, to
conueye water. Elicio, cui, cere, to bring out, to draw out, to provoke.
Elicito, to draw often. Elico, aui, are, to turn up so down. Elico, onis,
he that tourneth things out of order. Elido, si, dear, to hytte against a
thing, to break, to press out, to exclude, to strangle, to kylle. Eligo,
legi, eligere, to chose. Elimino, aui, are, to put or cast forth from a place
far of. Elimo, aui, are, to put out. Elinguis, without a tunge, specheles.
Elinguo, aui, are, to pluck out ones tunge. Eliquo, aui, are, to melte. Elis,
a city of Archadie. Elissa, one of the names of Dido. Elixo, aui, are, to
sethe or boil. Elixus, a, um, sodden or boiled. Elychnium, the match, which
is in a la^pe, and stands in oil. Elogium, a testification or witness in
words, of praise or dispraise, of honor or reproach. Elocutio, onis, a
propre form of words and sentences. Elongo, aui, are, to remove fer of, to
make long, to defer. Eloquentia, eloquence. Eloquium, speech in a pleasant
manner. Eloquor, eris, qui, to speak, proprely it is, wha^ I set a thing forth
in speking, that the herers may understand it, as I conceive it. Elotae, among
the Lacedaemonians was as much to say, as commune mynysters or servants, as
sergeauntes, or such as in London they do call yomen. Elpenor, a companion of
Ulysses, which with other, Circe turned into an bogge. Elucesco, sci,
cescere, to be very bright. Elucisico, caui, care, to deprive of light. Elucus,
he that is sick of the drink of yesterday. Also a lover of trifles. Elugeo,
gi, gere, to leave mourning. Elucido, aui, are, to shine or make bryghte
outewarde. Eludo, si, ere, to mock or deceive, Also to leave playenge. Elumbus
and elumbis, he that has feeble loins, and can not stand upright. Eluo, lui,
luere, to wash out. Eluo, aui, are, to live in glotony, or to spend
superfluousely. Elusco, aui, are, to make one purblynde. Eluto, aui, are, to
soke out water. Elutrio, aui, are, to power out of one vessel into an other.
Eluuies, ordure or fyithe caused of abundance of water, or other lycour.
Elysium, a place where poets did suppose the sowles of good men to dwell.
Elysii campi, the same place.
E ante M.
EMacio, aui, are, to make lean. Emancipo, aui, are, to infraunchyse or make
free, or set at liberty. sum time it is used in the contrary sense, to
bynd or make bond. It is most commonly where a man dispossesseth him self,
and does alienate his land to an other. Emancipator, a feffour, or alienour.
Emaneo, emansi, emanere, to dwell out of a place. Emano, aui, are, to issue or
flow out. Emansor, oris, he that wandreth long, and at the last retourneth
home: a lurker. Emargino, aui, are, to take away scurfe about the brymmes of
wounds or soores. Emasculo, aui, are, to gelde, or to take away the courage of
a man, or to abuse a man child in lechery. Emath, a city that is now
called Antioch. Emathia, a part of the realm of Macedonia. Emaus, a notable
city of Palestine, which now is called Nicopolis. Emax, cis, he or she that
is redye to bye any thing. Emacitas, tatis, redynes or custom to bye.
Embamma, matis, sauce. Emblema, blematis, pictures made of wod, stone, or
metal, of one color, set in wodde stone or metal of an other color: as we
see in chesse bourdes or tables, callid cou^ters: it is much used in Italy.
Embrio, onis, signifies the child conceived before it receives perfect
shappe of a man or woman. Emedullo, aui, are, to take out marowe. Emendico,
caui, care, to ask in form of beggynge. Emendo, aui, are, to amend. Emergo,
