emersi, gere, to issue or come out of the place where a thing is drowned.
Emereor, emereri, to deserve to the vttermooste. Emeriti milites, old worn
soldiers, which were pardoned of wars, and not withstanding had pencyons,
which were called Emerita stipendia. Emineo, eminul, eminere, to show or excel
above all other, to be higher than other. Eminulus, a, um, a little rysynge in
height. Eminus, far of. Emissarium, a sluse, or place to let water out of a
ponde or river. Emissarius, sommetyme it signyfieth him, which is sent before
in battle to epsy, or to skyrmyshe. sometime a servant, which is always at,
hand, ready to be sent forth. Also it signifies such a person, which is
ordained of him that is in any great office or authority, to advance his
bribery. Also it sygnifyeth a horse stalyon, which serves to get coltes.
Emississius, a spyall. Emitto, misi, mittere, to send forth, to publyshe, to
manumise. Emo, emi, emere, to bye. Emodus, a hill, which about the border of
Indie, is divided into two bowghtes. Emolumentum, profit gotten of labor.
Emortualis dies, the day of death. Emorior, emori, to die utterly. Empedocles,
the name of a Philosopher, which supposed all things to have their being of
amity, and variance. Emphasis, an express signification of that, which is
intended. Emphyteosis, the making of a thing better than it was, when it was
received or letten, as land. Emphyteota, he that takes a thing, and
promyseth or couenaunteth to make it better than he received it. Emphracta,
ships or barges kouered. Empiricus, a physician that practices.
Emplastratio, is graffyng between the bark and the wodde. Emplastrum, a
plaster. Emporetica charta, paper, wherein marchantes or grossers do put
their wares. Emporium, a place wherein is kept a mart or fair. Emporeuma,
shepmanshyppe. Emptitius, a, um, that which is or may be boughte. Emptito,
aui, are, to use to bye. Emunctorium, an instrument, wherewith the shuffe of a
candell is taken away, a shuffer. Emungo, xi, gere, to snuff a candelle. Also
to make clean a man's nose. sometime it signifies to dispoyle a man of money,
proprely by craft. Terentius Horatius.
Emunctus auro, spoiled of his treasure. Emunctae naris, of a clean and sure
judgment. Emussicata, made or wrought by rule.
E ante N.
EN, loo, see. Energia, a demo^stration, when a thing is so discryued, that it
seems to the reder or herer, that he beholds it, as it were in doing.
En^aema, an innovation or renewynge. It was among Jews the feast of
dedication of their temple. Encanthis, a disease in the eyes. Encans^u^,
vernyshe, enamyll, or other pycture, wrought with fire. Enchaldion, a handell
of a thing. sometime a dagger, sometime that part of an ore, that the water man
holds. It is usurped for a book in so little a volume, that a man may always
carye it with him. Enduros, a beast bredde in the orient, as great as a bull.
Enchinia, thynne oyntementes. Encumbomata, maidens kyrtelles, or pety ^^etes.
Encychos, and Encyclia, the cyrkle or course of all doctrines. Encyclopaedia,
that learning which comprehends all lyberall sciences and studies.
Endelechia, a consuminate perfection, which Aristotle did put besides the
four elements. Endeploro, aui, are, to make intercessyon with tears.
Endoprocinctum, when men went out of the camp unto battle. Endromis,
midis, a mantell such as Irishe men and women do now wear. Endymion, the
name of a man, which found the course of the moon. wherefore the poets
feigned, that the moon loved him, and descended down to kiss him, whiles he
slepte. Energia, an efficacy or operacion. Energificus, effectual. Eneruo,
aui, are, to debilitate or make feeble. Eneruis, and Eneruus, without synewes.
Engaddi, a city in Judea, from whens the precious balm comes. Enim,
forsothe. sometime it is expletine, and does but fylle up a sentence, to make
it sound well. sometime it is a copulative: Sed enim, but forasmoche. Enipeus,
a river of Thessaly, nere to which the battle was fought between Caesar and
Pompey. Eniteo, tui, tere, to endeavor, to enforce to do a thing. Enitor,
teris, enixus sum, eniti, idem quod eniteo. Enixe, and Enixum, dilygently with
all force. Enna, a city of Sycile, sytuate in a high place. Ennius, the name
of an ancient poet. Enoch, a man's name in holy scripture. Enodis, enode,
without a knotte. Enodo, aui, are, to cut away the knottes, or to vnknytte.
Enormis, enorme, great out of measure. Enos, is interpretate a very man. Ens,
entis, the being of every thing. Ensis, a sword. Enthymema, enthymematis, a
short or imperfect syllogism. Enucleo, aui, are, to take out the kernel of a
nutte. It is also to declare or make plain a sentence. Enascor, sceris, sci,
to grow or spring of a thing. Enarro, tare, to tell out at length.
Enarratio, a plain declaration or exposition. Enyalius, the son of Bellona.
E ante O.
EO, is, iui, ire, to goo. Eo uenum, ire uenum, to be sold. Eon, the compass of
the eye. Eo, therefore, forasmoche, unto that. Eous, the cast. Eo usque, in so
much.
E ante P.
EPaminondas, the name of a valiant captain of the Thebans. Epanalepsis, a
replication or repetitio^. Ephabus, the son of Jupiter that builded Memphis
in Aegipte. Eparcus, the presydent of a province. Epauxis, an increase.
Ephebia, the age wherein oone enters into the state of a man.xv. or.xvi. years.
Ephebus, he that is of that age. Ephemeris, a book, wherein is written that,
which is done daily, or a book of reckning. Ephemerinos, a fever contynuyng one
day. Ephi, a measure containing.iii. bushels. Ephippium, the harneis of a
horse or mule. Ephori, great officers among the Lacedaemonians, by whom the
kings power was restrained. Ephira, re, or Ephire, res, a town of Achaie,
which now is called Corinthus. Epialos, a fever caused of fleume. Epibata, a
soldier on the sea. Epibatra, the ladder that gothe up to the top castle.
Epicharmus, the name of an excellent philosopher of Syracuse. Epicheremata,
arguments made in reasonynge. Epicedium, versis in co^me^dacion of a deed man,
a gay laud. Epicterus, the name of a stoik philosopher. Epicurus, the name of
him, which did put the principal goodness in voluptuositie. Epidamnus, a city
in Sycile, but the Romans after they had subdued it, would have it called
Dyrrachium. Epidaurus, a city in Greece. Epidicticon, demonstratiue. Epidromes,
the armynge of a net. Epiglossis, a small thing in the innermost part of
the tunge, like a littell tunge. Epigramma, a superscription. Epigrammatarius,
he that writes verses, called Epigrammata. Epigriphus, he that has a crooked
nose. Epilepsia, the falling syckenes. Epilepticus, he that has that disease.
Epilogus, a conclusion in writing or speking. Epimenides, the name of a
philosopher. Epinicia, verses contaynyng praises. Epinyctides, a wheale or
pushe, which ryseth on the skin by night. Epiphanes, notable, or famous.
Epiphania, a manyfestation. It is also a solemn feast in the church.
Epiphonema, an exclamation. Epirrhedium, a waggen, or carte. Epirus, a country
in Greece. Episcopatus, a byshopryche. Episcopium, a bishops palace or house,
or a place to epsy out of. Episcopius, a, um, pertaining to espiall.
Episcopus, a bishop, sometime an epsy. sometime a clerk of the markette.
Epistola, a letter sent from one to an other. Epistolium, a little epistle.
Epistomium, a spowte sendynge forth water from a cundite. Epistylium, the
chapter of a pylar. Epitaphium, a scripture written on a grave or sepulcher.
Epithalamium, a song being song at a wedding, or verses made in the
praise of them that are married. Epithema, a medicine laid to the regyon of the
heart or liver, to cool it. Epithetes, a disceyuer. Epitheton, an addition,
proprelye applied to a thing for some notable quality, which it sygnifieth, as
Seuu^ mare, The rough see. Garrula pica, The chatterynge pie. Crudelis Nero,
The cruel Nero. Campi florigeri, The flouryshynge fields. Epithymia, miae,
concupiscence, desire. Epitogu^, i, a garment worn upon a gown. Epitome, mes,
a brigement, or breuiate. Epitritus, a foot of four sillables, of which one
differs ever from the other three. Epitrope, procuration, wardshyp. Epityrum,
a chese cake. Epithyrum, a mean to conserve olyues. Epos, epodos, a kind of
verse, or song, which contains things concerning as well god as manne. Also
which has the first verse lengar than the second, as, Beatus ille, qui
procul negoriis Vt prisca gens mortalium. Epulae, meats. Epulum, a great
feast, whereunto all the people assembled, which among the old Romans was
made either to the honor of some of their gods, or at the burieng of some
notable personage. It may be now taken for a church feast, or feast of a
brotherheed, Cicero and L. Planco^
or dinner made at a burial or interment. It has been sometime used for a uate
bankette. Epularis, are, bilongynge to a feast or banquet, as Epularis sermo,
communication mete for a feast or bankette. Epulor, ari, to eat at feasts or
bankettes. Epulatorius, ia, ium, apt to be eaten at a feast or bankette.
Epulis, flesh that grows on the gu^mes about a man's tethe. Epulo, nis,
plurali epulones, men boden to a great feast, or they which come vnboden, to
eat the reuercion. Among the gentiles they were called by the pristes, to eat
that which was left of the sacrifice.
E ante Q.
EQuarius, ia, ium, pertainyng to horses. Vale. Max.
Equarius medicus, a horse leche Eques, a horseman, contrary to a foot man.
sometime it is taken for a knight. But I suppose, that among the Romans,
Equites, were taken for them, whom we call gentylmen. Equester, equestris,
equestre, pertaining to eques, as, Equestris ordo, the state or degree of
gentylmen. Equestres copiae, the number or company of horsemen. Equestria, the
places assigned to gentilmen, where they satte to behold any solemn syghtes
or plays. Equidem, verily. Plinius. Varro.
Equiserus, a wild horse. Equila, a little mare. Equile, a stable for horses.
Equimentum, the hyre of a stallyon to season a mare. Equinus, na, number, of a
horse. Equio, iui, ire, when a mare desires to be seasoned. Equiria, runnynge
with horses: a play dedicate to Mars. Equisessor, a man on horsbacke.
Equisetum, an herb called horsetayle. Equiso, onis, a horsebreaker.
Equitabilis, bile, able to be ride^, also a place in which horses might easily
walk. Equitatus, an host of horsemen. also the act of ridynge. sometime the
state or order of gentylmen. Equitium, the esquirie or company of the stable.
Equitius, the propre name of a man, and surname of a familye in Rome. Equito,
aui, are, to ride. Equitatio, a riding. Equuleus, a horsecolt. Also a manner of
turment made of bournynge plates, like to a horse, wherein men were tourmented.
Equulus, a nagge or little horse. Equus, a horse. Equa, a mare. Equus citatus,
a horse taken up: Equus carpentarius, a carte horse.
E ante R.
ERado, asi, ere, to scrape of, or out of a thing. Erasinus, the name of a
river. Erasisiratus, the name of a famous physytion. Erato, the name of one of
the Musts. Eratosthenes, the name of a philosopher. Erciscere, to divide,
proprely lands. Erciscundae familiae, of householde to be divided or parted
among diverse heirs. Ercinia, a wonderful greatte wodde in Germany. Ercius,
one of the names of Jupiter. Erebus, one of the ryuers of Hell. Eregione, on
the other side. Erenata, by occasion whereof. Erembi, people in Arabia, which go
naked. Eremea, uel tua, for my profit or thine. Eremodicium, a discontynuance
of action, done through absence or negligence of the parties. Eremus, a
deserte or solytary place. Erepublica, for the profit of the publyke weal.
Eretum, a streate of the Sabynes. Erga, toward. Erga festum natalis Christi,
Again Christmasse. Ergasterium, a warkehouse. Ergastes, sieve ergasticus, a
workman. Ergastulum, a house, where men were compelled to work on stone or
metal. Now is it taken for a prysone, and sometime for the prisoners.
Ergastularius, the gayler or keeper of the prysone. Ergastulus, a gayler.
sometime it signifies a labourer. Ergasylus, the propre name of a man.
Erginus, was a tyranne, which Hercules subdued and slew. Ergo, therefore.
sometime it is spoken dysdaynously. Fac ergo quod libet, Than do as the list.
sometime exhorting. Ergo age, go to. sometime it signifies because, Illius
ergo, for his sake. Virtutis ergo, because of virtue. Ergatum, an engyne to
draw up things of great poise or weight, callid a crane. Erguminus, a man
possessed with an ill spirit Eriboea, the stepmother of Mercury. Erica, an
herb growing in woddes, and is like to maioram. Ericthonius, the first king
of Athenes, which invented a chariotte. Eridanus, a river in Italy, now called
Po. Erimantus, a diuinour. Erinaceus, an hedgehogge or vrchyn. Erinnys, the
name of oone of the furyes of hell. Eriphyle, the wife of Amphiaraus, and
systar of Adrastus, which betrayed her husband for a bracelette at the siege
of Thebes. Eripio, pui, pere, to take away, to deliver. Eripuisti mihi
pecuniam, Thou haste taken my money from me. Eripuisti me a periculo, Thou
haste delivered me from peril. Eripuisti a me librum, Thou haste taken my
book from me. sommetyme to make haste. Eripe fugam, Flee away in haste. Eris,
an herb growing in Aegypte, and may be interpretate contention. Erodius, a
foul, the greattest that fleeth^, and ouercometh and eats the Egle. Erogo,
aui, are, to distribute. Errabundus, much wandering, or vacabunde. Erraticus,
ca, cu^, that crepeth here and there, as, Vitis erratica, a crepyng vine, that
shoteth out in diverse places. Erratus, tus, erratum, ti, an error or sin.
Errone^, start^rs aside, vagobundes. Error, error, properly where falsehode
(...) affirmed or taken for troth* or troth for falsehode. Erro, aui, are, to
err, to wander. Erubeseo, but, bescere, to be ashamed, or to blusshe. Eruca,
an herb called Rokat. also a worm called the canker worm, which commonly is
upon ^olewortes. Eructo, taui, tare, to belke or broake wind out of the
stomach. Erudero, aui, are, to throw out, or carry away rubbell, as mortar,
stones, and other like things of old building decayed, or pulled down.
Erudio, iui, ire, to teach any art or science. Eruditio, doctrine or
teaching. Eruditus, learned or taught. Eruila, a grain called tares. Erunco,
caui, care, to wede out. Eruo, ui, ere, to draw out with force. Eruum, a kind
of pulse. Erugo, an unkindly moisture, whereby corn growing is putrified.
Plin. lib. 4
Erymathus, a mountayn in Archady, where Hercules overcame a bore, that
destroyed the fields. There are also a wodde and a river of the same name.
Erythace, bees meat, while they labor. Erythacus, a bird called Robyn
redbrest. Erythea, an I Will, the countraye of Gerion, where the air is so
benign, that men well nere are there immortal. Erytheus, was a king of
Athenes. Erythios, an herb called read betes, as I do suppose. Erythraeum, is
called the red see, this see is between the Indie and Aethiope occean. Eryx,
the name of a mountayn in Cicile, and of a city thereon builded, wherein was
edified a temple to Venus, whereof of Venus is called Erycina. Ouidius.
Quid geminas Erycina meos sine sine dolores? O Venus, why do thou
continually double my sorrows?
E Ante S.
ESca, all manner of meat, as well for men, as beasts. Escarius, a, um
pertaining to meat. Escaria mensa, a table, whereat men do eat meat.
Esculentus, ta, tum, any thing to be eaten. Esculus, an oak bearing acornes.
Esito, aui, are, to eat. Essei, certain religious men of the Jews. Esseda, a
wayne. Essedone^, a people, which ^oo eat their frende^; when they be deed,
and drink in the sculles of their heedes. Esto, be it. Esuriales feriae, wake
days. Esuries, hanger. Esurio, iui, ij, ire, to be a hungered.
E Ante T.
ET, and, as well, Te admirantur and ciues and hospites, As well thy country
men as strangers do wonder at the. sometime it signifies but, by an
interrogation, sometime, That is to say, Annos natus (...) sexaginta, and
senex, Now three score years old, that is to say an old man. Etsi, all be it.
Etenim, for. Etesiae, wyndes which do commonly blow in summer, about the
canicular days. Ethalia, the name of an isle in the sea called mare ligusticum,
which is by Ieane. Ethanion, the name of a certain vessel. Et^ocles, the
sun of Oedipus and Iocasia his mother. Ethicus, moral. Ethmus, the myddell
bridge of the nose. Ethnicus, a gentyle. Ethologos, he which with voice,
gesture, and countenance expresses the manners of men. Etiam, also, moreover,
ye, ye forsothe. Etiamnum, also. Etymologia, true saying, or true exposition,
or reason. Ethopeia, an imytation of other men's manners. Ethici pictores,
paynters, which in pyctures do lively set out the manners and affections of
men.
E Ante V.
EVado, si, uadere, to escape, to pass with danger, to appear, to clymme, to
deliver, to be, to come to. Euadne, Mars daughter, of Thebes, the wife of
Aesopu^: and the wife of Capanei was so called, which louyd her husband so
ferue^tly, that when she hard he was take at Thebes, she fell nere deed in a
swowne, and after when his funeral was celebrate, she l^pte into the fire.
Euaenerus, a king of the Lacedemonia^s. Eualeo, iui, ere, to wax hole or
strong. Eualesco, scere, to wax very strong. Eualuo, aui, are, to put or
set out of the doors. Euan, an exclamation to the praise of Bacchus, and is
as much to say, as Bone puer, O good child. Euander, the propre name of
Carmentis son, and is interpretate a good man: he left his country
Archadia, and came into Italy, and entryng into the mouth of Cyber, and
expulsyng the inhabitants, rested in the hylle Palatine, where he began to
build the town Palanteum. Euaneo, et euanesco, scere, to vanishe away.
Euangelium, good tidings. Euanidus, a, um, unfruitful. Euapelus, a fool or
ideote. Plautus.
Euax, an interiection of reioycynge. Euax iurgio uxorem tandem abegi, Heida, I
have yet at the last driven my wife away with chiding. Euboea, an isle in the
greek see, and the name of a city situate in the same. Eubulus, the name of a
story writer, and is interpretate prudente. Euca^pia, a city of Phrigia,
where grow great plenty of very fair grapes. Eucharistia, good grace, a
renderynge of thank. It is now taken for the sacrament of the altar.
Euchila, meats of good juice. Euclides, the name of a famous Geometrycian.
Eueho, euexi, euehere, to carry out. sometime it sygnifyeth to extol or lift
up. (...).
Euemerus, the name of an old story writer Euenne, to happen by chance.
Euenus, a river descendyng from Thrace, and deuydynge Calydonie. Euentus, tus,
hap. sometime it is taken for the end* or conclusion of a thing. Euenta,
things which happen in conclusyon. Euentum praestare, to waraunt all that,
which shall happen. Euerriator, he that has goods of the testatour with
condition, that if he perform not his last will, or do distourbe it, he shall
lose all that he has. Euerro, rri, rere, to swepe clean. Euerto, ti, tere, to
turn up so down. Euestigio, by and by, at an instant. Euganei, people of
Venece. Euganei montes, mountains in Italy by Padowe. Euge, well done.
Euidens, entis, evident, apparent. Euilla, a country in the orient, about the
which the river Phison, which we call Ganges, that comes out of Paradyse,
does rounne. Euiratus, of womanly or chyldyshe conditions. also he that
lacks his genitours. Euiro, aui, are, to take away a man's members of
generation. Euiscero, aui, are, to bowel or draw out the guts of any thing.
Euito, aui, are, to flee, to eschew, or beware. Eulogium, a word well spoken,
a praise, a benediction. Eumelus, the son of Admetus, king of Thessaly,
gotten on Alcesta his wife. Eumenides, furies of hell. Eumolpus, a ma^s name
of Athenes, whom Suidas writes to be the son of Museus the poet. Eumonides,
a man's name of Thebes. Eunucho, and eunuchiso, to gelde men. Eunuchus, a man
gelded. Eunomia, a just constitution or ordynance of laws. Euoco, aui, are,
to call out, to call forth, or call away. Euocare testes, to bring forth
witness. Euocati, souldyours, which for some necessity be sodaynely called
out of the fields unto battle. Eupalia, a town in Locris, which sum call
Eupalion, and some Eupolyon. Euphonia, a good sound. Euphorbium, an herb.
Euphorion, a poetis name of Calcidonye, whom Gallus did translate. Euphrasinu^,
an herb called Buglosse, Euphrates, one of the ryuers, that comme out of
Paradyse, which passes through the city of Babylon. Euphrosyna the propre
name of a woman. Eupilis, a laake in France Cisalpine. Euryale, the daughter of
king Minois, which brought forth to Neptune, Orion. there was an other of that
name, the daughter of Proetus, king of Argiue. Euryalus, the name of one of the
princis of Peloponnese. Virgil feineth a Troyane to be so called. Euripides,
the name of an excellent poet among the Greeks. Euripus, a small cundyte
rysynge of a great height. Also a diche made to enclose places to play in, in
the stead of hedges. some do take it for a small ponde or stewe. Euripus, an
arm of the sea, or a narrow passage between two places. Euronotus, a
northeaste wind. Europa, that part of the world, which we do inhabyte, so
named and called of Europa, the daughter of Agenor, king of Phenice. Eurotas,
a river that rounneth before the town of Lacedemona. Eurus, the east wind.
Euricion, the name of a goldesmythe. Euricratidas, a man of Lacedemonye. Virgi.
Plut. Ovid. Herod.
Euridamas, a man of Troy. Euridame, was the wife of Leutichis, king of
Spartans. Eurydice, the wife of Orpheus. Eurylochus, the king of Phlegia,
which distroyd Thebes, before Cadmus buildid it. Eurypylus, one of the sons
of Hercules that reigned in the isle Cous. Eurerpe, one of the Musis. Eutheca, a
storehouse. Euthymia, quietenesse, suertie of mind, or hartis ease.
E Ante X.
EX, sygnifyeth of, or fro. Ex fide, fama. Cic. ad Atticum, Summa erit haec,
statues, ut ex fide fama, reque mea uidebitur, This shall be the hoole effect,
that thou do, as it shall seem to be for mine honesty, according to the
trust that I put in the, and for my profit. Ex dignitate tua, et ex repub.
facis, Thou do according to thine authority, and for the weal of thy
country. Exactio, a pyllynge of the people. Exactor, a demaunder of money.
some english it a Comtroller. Exactus, ta, tum, passed, very dylygente,
exact. Exacerbesco, ere, to wax sharp. Plautus.
Exaedifico, aui, are, to build perfectely. also to drive out of the house.
Exaggeratio, a heapynge together. Exagito, aui, are, to vex, to anger. Exalto,
aui, are, to mount or lift up, some time to praise very much. Examen, minis,
a swarm of bees, Also the nedyll or tongue in balaunces and beams. Sommetyme
it sygnyfyeth a just examynacyon. Examino, aui, are, to examyne. Examurco,
aui, are, to draw oil clean from the mother. Examussim, justly by rule.
Exanclo, aui, are, to draw out clean, to emptye, sommetyme to suffer, to
make. Non potest hic sine tu^ opera exa^clari clauus, Pac.
This nail can not be made without thy help. Exanguis, exangue, without
blood, tymorous, or fearful. Exanimalis, without soul or life. Ex animo
est, It is as nature requires. Ex animo facio, I do it with my good will, or
as my mind gives me. Ex animi sententia, according to mine appetyte, or as I
would desire it. Ex animo illi faueo, I favor him with all my heart. Ex animo,
aui, are, to kill, Plaut.
sometime to make aferde. Priusquam intus redii exauimatus fui, Or ever I came
in again, I was made aferde. Q. Cut^ius.
Multos exanimauii rigor insolitus niuis, The unaccustomed chyllyng of the
snow deprived many of their lives. Exanimus, ma, mum, and exanimis, exanime,
deed, put in fear. Exanimatus, ta, tum, made aferde, or troubled in mind:
sometime it signifies deed. Exanio, aui, are, to put clean away. Colum^^.
Exanthema, a wheale or a pusshe in a man's skin. Exarefio, exarefieri, to
be dried up. Exaresco, sci, scere, to dry. Exarmo, aui, are, to make tame,
proprelye to break the tethe of wild beasts. Exarmare, to unarm, or to take
harneysse from a man. Exarmare nauem, to take away the taklyng from a ship.
Exarmare actionem, to make the accyon faynte or feeble. Exaro, aui, are, to ear
well, also to write. Exasceare, to polyshe, or make plain, as carpentars do
after that they have hewed. Exaspero, aui, are, to make sharp, Also to make
very angrye. Ex ass, of the hole. Haeredem fecit ex ass, He made him heir of
all the hole. Exauctoro, aui, are, to put out of wages, sometime to disgrade a
knight, or other like. Exauctorati, soldiers or servants put out of wages,
or dismissed of their service. Exauctoratus, deposed, or put out of office.
Exaudio, iui, ire, to here beneuolentelye or perfectely. Exbalisto, aui, are,
to trumpe or deceive. Ego hunc communem meum, atque nostrum omnium hostem
exbalistabo lepide, I wolie feately deceive this min enmy, and al ours in
commune. Excandescentia, vehement anger or wrath. Plaut*
Excanto, aui, are, to charm. sommetyme to shut out. Excandesco, sci, ere,
to be very angry. Excandefacio, feci, facere, to chaufe, or make angry, or to
make very hot. Excarnificatus, torn or rent with tourmentes. Excarnifico,
caui, care, to rent or cut in pieces. Excedo, cessi, dear, to depart or go
forth, to pass or excede. Excello, li, ere, to excelle. Excelsus, a, um,
high or great. Exceptio, an exception. Excepto, aui, are, to take or draw to.
Exceptor, oris, he that writes fast that which other men do speak.
Excerebro, aui, are, to beat out the brains of any thing. Excetra, a
serpent, of whom the heed being cut of, three came up for it. It was also
called Hydra. Excerno, excreui, excernere, to shite. proprely it is to try out
the ill from the good. Excerpo, psi, pere, to gather here and there the chief
of any thing. Excidium, the sackynge of a town or city, or the utter
destruction thereof. Excido, excidi, dear, to fall out of a thing. excidere, to
cut out of a thing. Excidere animo, to be forgoten. Excidere formula, to
lose his action. Excieo, exciui, ire, to move or shake out. Excio, ciui, ire,
to move vehemently, or to call out, to waken. Excipio, excepi, excipere, to
except, to take or receive, to try or inserche, to separate, to take by
craft, to gather, to hyde, to succeed, to resyst without any business.
Excipere notis, to write in cyfer, or other compendiouse form. Excipula, a
we will to take fysshe. Excipuus, a, u^, wherewith any thing is taken. Exciso,
aui, are, to crop, to tear, or to beat. Excisus, a, um, gelded. Excito, aui,
are, to stire, procure, or incorage. Exclamo, aui, are, to cry out, to call
for al^wde. Excludo, to shytte out, to deliver, to hatche eggs, to make to
appiere. Excolo, excolere, to garnyshe or deck. Excompo^i^o, in order
appointed. Exco^^o, aui, are, to pluck of the skin or hyde of a beast.
Excors, excordis, a fool, or a man hartles. Excreo, aui, are, to spytte out.
Excrementum, things of dygestion expulsed moist or dry, urine, or siege.
Excresco, excreui, excrescere, to grow out, or to grow much. Excretum, the
refuse or of fall of any thing. Excubiae, biarum, watch, as well by day as by
night. Excubitor, he that watches. Erasmus in Chiliad.
Excubitus, watch. Ex diame^ro opposita, so contrary the one to the other,
that they may never agree. Excubo, aui, are, to watch, as they which in
battaylle, or in the guard of a pryncis person do. Excudo, excusi, excudere,
to beat or stryke out, sometime to find out with study. V^ primum silicis,
scintillam excudit Achates, Verg^
As soon as Achales had stryken fire of the flynte. Also to hatche. Excutio,
aui, are, to put out of court* Apollonium ideo excuriauit, quia nihil habebat,
Ve^^^*
Therefore did he put Apolonius out of the court, because he had nothing.
Exaehite, to be pacified, C^s^^*
to be assuagid of ire Excursio, a digression in speaking, a skyrmyshe in
wars. Excuso, aui, are, to excuse. Excusatoria epistola, a letter of excuse.

shake, to choose. Excussus, a, um, shaken. Excussores equi, gambaldynge horses.
Exdecimo, aui, are, to tithe out. Exdisposito, by an order, of a purpose.
Exdorsuo, aui, are, to break the backbone. Execo, aui, are, to cut without.
Exectus, gelded. Execro, aui, are, to abhor, to curse. Execratio, cursynge.
Exedo, di, dear, to eat, as a worm or soore does, to eat up. Exedra, a
parlour, or other like place. Exegematicus, a form of spekyng, where the poet
only speaks. Exemplum, an example to follow, eschew, or beware. Exemplar, a
sample, whereby we attempt to make a thing like to it. sometime the one is used
for the other. oftentimes they both do signifye an example, where one thing is
compared with an other. Exemptus, exempt or priuileged. Exemptus est rebus
humanis, he is deed. Exemptilis, exemptile; that which may be taken away, or
taken out. Exeo, exiui, exire, to go out, to exchewe, to braste out. In
memoriam exire, to be in remembrance. Exit in fabellam, It is made a fable.
Exit de potestate, He is not able to govern him self: he is in ward, or
under a gardayne. Exentero, aui, are, to make a hole in a thing. Exequiae,
funeralles, the which are done in the burial of any person. Exequior, aris,
ari, to execute the funerals. Exequor, eris, qui, to do or execute. sometime to
declare or express. Exerceo, cui, cere, to exercise. sometime to drive out of
the house, to set on warke, to use. Exercere discordias, et simultates, To
have variance or contencion. also to get or win. Exercere sumptus, To get
their expenses. Exercere tellurem, to tylle well the ground. Exer^^o, (...),
to amend or repair. Exer^m, exercise or use. Exerc^^^, taui, ture, to
exercise. Exercita^^o, exercise, use, or custom. Exercit^^s, ta* tum,
exercised, (...) labor, weried, hardened. Exercitus, tus, an host of (...) of
wa^te. Statius.
Exero, ^rui, erere, to go forth, to draw out, as a man will draw out a
sword. Fulgente^que exerit ensem, And he drew out his bright sword. Also to
lift up. Exertus, ta, tum, showed forth. Exerto, aui, are, to show forth
abroad. Exfio, I pourge or cleanse. Exhaeredo, aui, are, to disherite. Exhalo,
aui, are, to puff out. Exhaur^o, lui, rire, to draw out clean, to make
empty. Exherbare, to pluck up herbs or wedes. Columel.
Exherbandus est locus, The place must be weeded. Exherbatio, weedynge.
Exhibeo, bui, bear, to pros^re, to set abroad, for all men to behold. Exhibere
negotium, to put to business, or trouble. Exhomologesis, confession.
Exhorreo, rui, rere, to fear horryblye, or with trembling. Exibilo, aui, are,
to whistyll or hiss a man out of the place. Exifilare, idem. Exigo, exegi,
exigere, to expel or shutt out. also to require, to inquyre, to do. Exigere
pecuniam, to demand money. Exactus, ta, tum, expelled, demanded, perfectly
done, or performed. Exilium, exyle. Exilio, lii, iui, ire, to goo out
hastilye, or to leap out. Eximium, excellent, very great. Eximo, exemi, mere,
to take away, to except Eximor ex reis, Eximor noxae, I am acquit or
discharged of the offense or trespass. Eximor ex aerariis, I am clearly
discharged of all paymentes. Eximere actionem, to bar the action. Exin, from
thensforthe. Exinanio, niui, ire, to emptye, to bring to nowghte. Exinsperato,
unlooked for, which no man hooped. Existimo, aui, are, to trow or suppose,
to decerne or judge. Existimatio, sup^osel. sometime reputation. Existo, extiti,
existere, to be, to appear, to be set up, or advanced. Exitiabilis, bile,
deedly. Exitialis, le, deadely, or that causes death, or myschiefe. Exitium,
death, or mischief. Ex iure manum conserere, to detayne battle in the trial
of right. Exlex, he that lives without love, or out of love. Exodium, a song
at the end of a comedy or interlude. also the end of a matter. Exoles^o,
exoleui, exolescere, to leave growing. sometime to grow mightily. Exolerus,
he that is passed growing. also old, or out of use, it signifies also a man child abused against nature. Exoluo, ui, uere, to vnbynd, to pay al
clearly, to recompense or give in reward, to deliver. Suspitione exoluere, to
deliver from suspicion. Exoluere religione, to discharge from vow or
conscience. Exocularus, he that has his eien put out. Exomida, a garmente
without sleues, a taberde or chymere, or such as hermytes do wear, or mu^kes
when they do ride. Exopolis, he that dwells in the subbarbes of a town or
city. Exorabulum, a crafty form of desyryng or asking a thing. Exorbito,
aui, are, to go out of the track or carte lose, or to go out of the right way.
Exorcismus, an a diuration of comuryng. Exorcista, an adiurour or coniur our.
Exorciso, aui, are, to adjure or conjure. Exordine, without ceassynge.
Exordior, iris, iri, to begin. Exordium, a beginning. Exorior, iris, riri,
to be borne, to appear out, to rise, as the sun does, to invade. Exorno,
aui, are, to garnyshe or make fair, to apparayle rychely, to ordeyne. Sum
time to make foul, or out of apparayle. Exoro, aui, are, to induce or obtain
by desire, to desire heartily. Exors, exortis, out of felowshyppe. Exos, without
bones. Exosso, aui, are, to bone, or pluck out boones. Also to pulle out the
string of a lamprey. Exoricus, a, um, a stranger, that is come out of another
country, and dwells here. Expalpo, aui, are, to grope out. Expando, di, ere,
to sprede out. Expapillo, aui, are, to make nakyd to the pappes. Expato, aui,
are, to come abroad, or into an open place. Expecto, aui, are, to tarry or
abide, to observe or take heed. Expecto quid uelis, I mark what thou wylt
say: or else I desire to know what thou would. Also to hope. Expectate
uenis, Thou come even as I would have the. Expectoro, aui, are, to put out of
the breast or stomach. Expeculiatus, he that has nothing of his own.
Expedio, iui, ire, to deliver, to speed, to carye out. Expedire manus, to hold
up the hands. Expedit, signifies also, It is expedient or necessary. it is
come to pass. Expeditus, ta, tum, delivered. Expediti milites, soldiers in
light harneis. Expeditio, a setting forth toward battle. Expello, expuli,
pellere, to expel or put out. Expendo, di, ere, to ponder or weye, to examyne
straytely, to pay truly, to spend money. Expensae, expenses, or dispenses.
Expensum far, to spend or lay out money. Expergiscere, Expergefacere,
Expergificare, to wake a man out of his sleep. Expergiscor, eris, Expergifio, I
am wakyd, or wake. Experrectus, Expergefactus, ta, tum, wakened. Expergitus,
slepte enough. Expergo, experrexi, expergere, to waken. Experientia,
experience. Experior, iris, iri, to attempt, or assaye, or prove. Expertus,
ta, tum, attempted, taught. Expertus, a man of experience. Expers, it is, without
any part, lackyng experience. Expers doloris, without pain. Expers mortis,
never dyenge. Expers lucis, without light. Expersus, persa, persum, spronge
with licour or wette. Expes, without hope. Expeto, iui, tii, ere, to desire
much, or coueyte, to happen, to will. sommetyme to take, to pass over.
Expilo, aui, are, to rob, polle, or take by extorcion, or deceyte, to spoil.
Expio, aui, are, to pacyfie god with satisfaction or prayer, when we think
that he is displeased. Expiro, aui, are, to dye. Expiscor, aris, ari, to seek
for fysshe, to fish out, or search priuilye, to get or win. Tandem nescio
quid ab eo expiscatur, Finally I can not tell what he wynneth or gets by
him. Explano, aui, are, to make plain. Ter. Heau.
Expleo, eui, ere, to fylle, fulfylle. also to sacyate, to comfort. Explico,
plicaui, plicare, to extend. Also so to unfold, Ouidius,
to declare. Explicat ensem, He draws out his sword. Explicat and caenas
unica mensa duas, Martialis.
He makes two suppers at one table. Explodo, osi, dear, to drive out with
noise or rebukes, or clappynge of hands. Explosus, sa, sum, convicted, or
rejected. Exploro, aui, are, to bewail with exclamation, to search out
diligently, to prove with searching, to be aduysed, to dry or exhauste.
Explorator, an epsy, or priuye serchour. Exploratus, a, um, well known.
Expono, sui, nere, to expowne or declare, to set or bring a thing out of that,
wherein it is. sometime to cast out a thing, to the intent that it may perish.
Also to spend, to set forth. Expositio, an exposition or declaration, of
any thing diffyculte or hard to be understand. Expositi, chyldern cast out,
to be perished. Exposititij, the same. Exposco, exposcere, to ask or desire
instauntely. Expostulo, aui, are, to complain, to make a quarrel. also to will.
Expostulare iniuriam, To complain of wrong or displeasure, to him that does
wrong. Expostulatio, a quarrel or complaynt. Expostulator, he that co^playneth
of wrong done by his friend. Exprimo, to press or wring out, to express or
declare plainly. Exprobro, aui, are, to imbraide or twyte. also to lay in
reproach. Expromito, misi, mittere, to promise or undertake for an other.
Expromissor, he that promises, or is surety for an other. Expromo, prompsi,
mere, to show forth, or open. Expugno, pugnaui, are, to win by assault or
force. Expulso, aui, are, to meue a thing with much thrustynge, or to put
away. Expulsor, and expultrix, a putter away, man or womanne. Expungor,
geris, expungi, to be cancelled or put out, or rased. it is also spoken of
iuges, when they be put out of commission. It is also to quyte, as, Munus
munere expungitur, One good turn is quyte with an other. Expungo, punxi,
pungere, to put away, or remove. Expuncti, were soldiers discharged, or
put out of wages. Expuo, pui, puere, to spytte out. Exputo, aui, are, to shrede
or loppe a tree, to understand perfytely. Exquiliae, a mountain in Rome,
where watch was kept. Exquilinus mons, the same mountain. Exquiro,
exquisiui, exquirere, to search out. Ex syngrapha agere, to do things extremly
or rigorously: as it were that one sued another upon an oblygation sealyd.
Exta, the inward: as the heart, the liver, the lunges or lights, and the
spleen. Extemplo, forthwith. Extemporaneus, ea, eum, sudden. Ex tempore,
suddenly, without study, or for the time. Extemporalis, and extemporanea
oration, an oration or matter spoken or written without study. Extendo, di,
dear, to extend. Extenuo, aui, are, to mynyshe or make little. Exter, tera,
terum, strange, comen far of. Exterus, tera, terum, idem. Exterebro, aui,
are, to perce through. Also to enserche curiously. Extermino, aui, are, to
drive out, or pulle down. Pacuuius.
Exterminatus, banysshed. Externo, aui, are, to make mad. Externus, na, number,
which is not of that country, a stranger. Extero, teri, terere, to beat
out. also to whette or grynde. Exterreo, ui, rere, to put in fear. Extilio,
aui, are, to drop out. Extimesco, extimui, extimescere, to dread much.
Extimus, a, um, the outwardemost, or last. Extinguo, xi, guere, to put out,
proprely as fire, which may be efteloones kendlyd: sometime it signifies to
flee, or destroy: sometime to make a distynction or dyuersitie between
things. Extispices, sothesayers by lookynge in the inwardes of beasts.
Extispicium, and extispicina, the craft of soth saying. Exto, extiti, extare,
to be, to remain, to be apparent. Extollo, extuli, extollere, to aduant or
praise. Extorqueo, torsi, que^re, to find out the truth by tourmentes, to
take away by force, or pluck away. Extorris, is he that is made to void, or
is driven out of his country: also a vagabu^d. Extra, without. Ex tripode,
when we speak of things, which are very true, and not to be douted, as it
were spoken of goddis own mouth. Extrarius, he that is not of the same house
or kynredde. Extrema linea, is spoken, where a man would signify a thing to be
last, and after all other. Extremis digitis attingere, to towche with the
finger tops, is spoken, where is sygnified, that a man has uneath touched
or felt a thing. Extra telorum iactum, out of arowe shot, out of gunne
shot, signifies out of danger, or in safegarde. Extremus, a, um, sometime
it signifies the beginning, sommetyme the end, sum time the warste.
Extrico, aui, are, to deliver, to shake of any thing that lets.
Extrinsecus, outward. Extro, aui, are, to goo out. Extrorsum, from without.
Extrudo, si, dear, to thraste out. Extruo, si, truere, to ordeyne, to build
or set up. Extubero, aui, are, to swelle much. Extundo, tudi, tundere, to
find out with much labor. Exturbo, aui, are, to put away, or to put out or
from a thing by vyolence. Exubero, aui, are, to abound. Exuccum, without
juice. Exudo, aui, are, to send forth lycour. Exugo, exugi, gere, and exugeo,
to suck out. Exul, exulis, a banyshed man. Exulo, aui, are, to be banysshed,
to live in exyle. Exultabundus, reioysynge very much. Exulto, aui, are, to
rejoice excedyngely, to brag, to leap out. Exundo, aui, are, to ouerflowe.
Exuo, ui, uere, to put of, to dispoyle, or unclothe. Exupero, aui, are, to
excede. Exurdo, aui, are, to make deaffe. Exuuiae, clothing. Also hydes or
skynnes of beasts. Exuuiae serpentis, an Adders skin. Exybaphon, a salate of
herbs
F Ante A.
FABA, a bean. Faba cudetur in me, The bean shall be knockyd on me,
sygnyfyeth the peine or blame shall light on me. Fabacia, a bean cake. Fabalia,
the refuse or offall of beans. Fabariae Calendae, the Calendes of June.
Fabarius, fabaria, fabarium, pertaining to beans. Fabella, a short tale.
Faber, fabri, almoost every crafts manne that warkethe with the hand. Faber
lignarius, a carpenter: Faber ferrarius, a smith. Auri faber, a goldesmythe.
Faber, fabra, fabrum, pertaining to a smith. Fabre, workemanly. Faber^ime,
kunningly, very craftily, or well. Fabranus, the propre name of a man. Fabiro^,
in the ancient time was taken for a maynteyner. Fabius, the name of a noble
Romayne. Fabrefacio, fabrefeci, fabrefacere, to warke cunnyngly, to build.
Fabrica, a warkehouse, or forge, sometime the frame or warke. Fabr^^us, a noble
Romayne, who being wonderful pore, not withstandyng refused a great some of
money, sent to him by king Pirrhus, towchynge with his hands all his members,
and saying unto the kings messangers: As long as he might rule all that,
which he touched, he could lack nothing. Fabrico, caui, are, and Fabricor,
cari, to make, to inuente. Fabrilis, fabrile, bilonging to handy craftis.
Fabula, a fable or tale. Fabula palliata, a comedy of Greek. Fabula togata, a
comedy of latyne. Fabulator, a teller of fables. Fabulor, aris, ari, to talk.
Fabulosus, much talked of. Facerso, cessi, cessere, to go about to do a
thing* sum time to go away. Facesse hinc, Get the hens. Facessit ubi
negotium, he puts the to business. Fa^etiae, merry words or deeds without
dishonestie. Facetus, ta, tum, merry, pleasant. Facete, meryly, pleasantly.
Facies, a face, sometime the proporcion of all the body. Facile, lightly, or
easily, without let or doubt. Facilis, facile, light, easy, good to be
entreated. Facilitas, easynesse, gentylnesse. Facinorosus, full of myschief,
ungracious, harmefull. Facinus, an act or deed. sommetyme an ylle deed. Facio,
feci, facere, to do, to be occupied, to make. Facio plurimi, I make much of.
Floccifacio, I set not a straw by it. Facere uerba, to speak. Facere
lucrum, to win. Facere sumptum, to bestow cost. Facere iter, to go or ride.
Facere terrorem, to put in fear. Facere copiam, to give leave. Facere
iacturam, damnum, naufragium, to lose, to take harm, to go to wrecke. Facere,
is also to sacrifyce, to profit. Faciam ut te plarimum amem, I woll love the
much. Fac te esse qui sum, ymagin that thou were as I am. Facere conuicium, to
rebuke, or put to rebuke. Facere nomina, to get dettours, as by lendyng: as
they do now by exchange, and in shyftes, proprely called usury: and in
bargaynes of corn, cattle, and other like, or in letting of lands. Factio, a
diuisyon of people in sundry opynions. also an act. Factitius, a, um, made or
counterfayte. Factito, aui, are, to do often times. Factor, oris, a maker, a
factour. Factum, a deed. Factum atque transactum, done and brought to good
pass. Factura, the warke. Facturio, iui, ii, ire, to desire to do. Factus,
tus, the deed. Facula, a lynke, or lyttel torche. Facularii, torche bearers.
Facultas, tatis, power to do or speak. some time richesse. also faculty.
Facundus, a, um, eloquent, well spoken. Facundia, eloquence, or sweet and
pleasant speech. Faecatum uinum, wine that drynketh of the lies. Faeciniae
uuae, grapes, whereof commethe wine, having much lies. Faeculentum, full of
lies or dregs. Faecutinus, na, number, pertaining to dregs. Faex, faecis,
lies, dregs, or grounds of any kind of lycour. Fagus, gi, a beche tree.
Fala, a tower made of timber. Falcarius, he that fyghteth with a byll.
Falcarius, ia, um, pertaynyng to a bylle. Falcatus, ta, tum, hooked, also any
thing, whereon be hooks or other like thing. Falcicula, a little hoke or
byll. Falcidia lex, whereby legacies were defalcate or cut of, where the
fourth part of the goodis were not assignid to the heirs. Falcifer, he that
bears a byll or book. Falcito, aui, are, to cut with a byll or hook. Falco,
aui, are, to cut of or mow. Falco, conis, a hawke. Falernus, a country in
Campania, now in the royalme of Naples, wherein grew the best wynes of Italy,
called falernum. Falisci, people in Italye. Also a kind of puddynges.
Fallaciae, deceytefull words. Fallaciter, deceytefully. Fallax, acis, a person
deceytefull. Fallo, fefelli, fallere, to deceive, also to be hid. Falsarius,
a forger of wrytynges. Falcidicus, and falsiloquus, a liar, or false reporter.
Falsifico, aui, are, to forge deeds, writings, or seals. Falsitas, tatis,
falsehode. Falso, aui, are, to forge. Falsum habere, to deceive. Falx, falcis,
a hook or bylle. Fama, fame or renome. sometime opinion. Famelicosus, often
hungrye. Famelicus, ca, cum, hungrye. Famen, faminis, speech. Fameo, famui,
ere, to be hungry. Fames, hungre. Famiger, geris, a spreder of fame.
Famigerabilis, famous. Famigerator, a tellar of news or tidings, or a spreder
of fame. Famigerulus, the same. Familia, a householde, a family, or kynred.
Familiaria, were places of buryall for men and their servants. Familiaris,
are, pertaynyng to householde, also familyar. Familiariter, famylyarly.
Famosus, a, um, famous, as well in good, as in ylle. Famulanter, humbly,
seruysably. Famularius, a, um, seruisable. Famulatio, householde, or meyny.
Famulatus, and famulitium, service. Famulus, and famula, a household servant.
Famulor, ari, to serve. Fanaticus, mad. In the old time before that Christ
expelled the dyuel, when that dyuelles were honored in ydols, certain
persons, as well men as women, were possessed with dyuels, which lad them,
where they lysted, against their propre wylles, and caused them to speak
wonderful things, some also sodaynely, and often times tell what should
happen: wherefore they were thought to be inspired with goddis: those persons
were called Fanatici. Some time Fanaticus, is taken for the keeper of the Temple
or chapel, where the devil gave answers. Fanesii, people in the north
parts of the world, whose ears be so great, that with them they keuer all
their bodies. Fanum, a Temple, where the dyuell gave answers out of an ydoll.
Far, farris, sometime sygnyfyeth all manner of corn. All be it among ancient
phisytions it is taken for wheat meal. Caellu^ lib. 15.
Farratia, among the old Romans were the ceremonies of matrimony.
Farcimen, minis, a puddynge. Farcio, ciui, cire, to stuff. Also to frank or
feed, to be far, to cramme. Farfarus, or Farfar, a river of Syrie. Faris,
fatus sum, fari, to speak. Farraca, meats made of meal. Farrago, ginis, a
myxture of sondrye kinds of grain and corn. Sometime it is taken for a
myxture of things good and badde. Farreatio, a sacrifyce made with cakes.
Farreum, a wheaton cake. Farrinus, na, number, and farrinaceus, a, um, pertaining
to wheat. Farrinariu^, a place where wheat or meal is kept. Farcilis, le,
any thing stuffed. Fartile, stuffynge, or that wherewith any foul is crammed
or franked. Fartim, full stuffed or crammed. Fartores, and fartrices, puddynge
makers. Fartum, a puddynge. Fartura, the craft or manner of stuffynge or
crammynge. Fas, lefull before god. Fascelis, a name of Diana. Fascia, a
swathell or swathynge band, or other like thing. sometime any gyrdell.
Fascior, fasciari, to swathe a child. Fasciculus, a grype, or thing bounden
together. It is also a nosegay, or any thing knytte together, which may be
borne in a man's hand. Fascino, aui, are, to transform by inchauntment, or
to bewytche. Fascinus, and fascinum, and fascinatio, an inchauntmente to
transfourme or disfygure any thing. which so enchanted, is of the common
people called, taken, or forspoken, or forlooked. Fasciola, a little band.
Fascis, is a burdeyn or knytche of wodde, or any other thing. Also Fascis
sagittarum is taken for a sheffe of arrows. Fasces, rods bounden together,
and an axe in the myddell, which were borne before the chief officers of
Rome, in declarynge their authority, whereof some had six, and some mo.
Fasellus, a boot. Fasti dies, were certain days, wherein the offycer of Rome,
called Praetor, mowghte speak only these three words, Do, dico, addico. It
may be now used for holy days. Fasti, were certain books, wherein were
contained certain ceremonies and causes of sondrye things among the
Romans, concerning their feasts and solemnities, which were long kept
from the knowledge of the common people, until they at the last were deuulgate
by one Caius Flauius. Fastidio, iui, ire, to contemn with disdain, to abhor
or have in abomination. Fastidiosus, a, um, full of disdain. Fastiditus, ta,
tum, hatred, abhorred, abhomyned. Fastidium, hated, proprely where one
abhors the sight or presence of any thing. Fastigio, aui, are, to make or
raise up in heyght. Fastigium, an altitude, or the top or height of any thing.
Sometime it signifies the state of a person in any dignity, sometime the end
of a thing. Fastigium imponere, is spoken when a man will signifye a matter or
thing to be fynysshed and brought to a point. Fastus, tus, hautenes of mind,
pride. Fatalis, le, pertaining to destenye, fatal. sometime mortal. Fateor,
fassus sum, fateri, to affirm, to confess. Fathisco, scere, to gape wide, as
the earth does in a great drythe. Fatidicus, fatidica, a reder or teller of
destenyes, or a southsayer. Fatifer, fatifera, a brynger of death or pestylence.
Fatiloqua, a witch. Fatigo, aui, are, to make weary, to trouble much, to
stryke, to stere or provoke, to restrain or let. Fatiloquus, fatiloqua, a
sothsayer. Fatisco, fatiscere, to be weary. Fator, aris, ari, to speak much.
Fatuitas, atis, folyshnes. Fatum, the ordinance and disposition of almighty
god. Desteny, goddis providence. sometime death. Fatiuis, an ydiote, that lacks
natural knowledge. Fauentia, a city in Italye. Faueo, ui, fauere, to favor.
Fauere linguis, to keep silence. Fauilla, a sperke of fire. Fauni, goddis of
the woods. Fauonius, one of the wyndes, called the southwest wind. Gel.
Fauorabilis, favored of many. Fauorinus, the name of a philosopher.
Faustulus, a shepeherde, which was the nourisher of Romulus and Remus.
Faustus, a, um, prosperous. Plaut.
Fauste, prosperousely. Fauulus, a little honey comb. Fauus, a honey comb.
Faux, faucis, a cheke. Fauces, straight passages. Fax, facis, a torche, a
candell, or other like thing, which brennynge gives light. Faxim, let me do.
Faxint, let them do. Faxo, I will or shall do.
F Ante E.
FEbricito, aui, are, to be sick in a fever. Febricula, a little fever.
Febriculosus, he that has often the Fever. Febrilis, le, pertaynyng to a
fever. Febrio, iui, ire, to have a fever. Febris, a fever. Februarius, the
monthe of February. Februo, aui, are, to pourge sowles by sacrifyce or prayer.
Februa, sacrifices and ceremonies for purgynge of sowles. Februatus, ta, tu^,
that which was so purged. Februum, in the Sabines tongue is called purgynge or
clensynge. Faecialis, was a certain offycer of arms, which denounced war
or peace, where as was hostility or cause of battle: which may now be
taken for an ambassador, sent for such a purpose, or for an Heralde. Fell,
fellis, the gaulle. sometime it is taken for grief of the mind. Felis, a
Catte: sommetyme it sygnifyeth a weasyll. Fello, aui, are, to soucke. Femen,
minis, plurali femina, the inner and back part of the thygh. Feminalia, the
keuerynge of the thighs. Femur, femoris, the thygh. some english it the
hamme. Femoralia, breeches. Fenestella, the propre name of a story writer,
which flourished in the later days of Tyberius Caesar. Fenestra, a wyndowe,
sometime an entry into a thing. Fenestratus, ta, tum, open. Plaut.
Nulla est fenestratior domus, No house is more open. Fenestrenula, a little
wyndowe. Ferabites, wild. Ferae, ferarum, feras, wild beasts. Feralis, le,
deedly or mortal, lamentable. Feralia, and feralis dies, a day dedicate to the
infernal goddis, to pacify them toward the souls departed. Feralia, were
also the sacryfyces done for sowles. Feralia amicula, wyndynge shetes, and
such like things, wherein dead bodies were lappyd. Feralia officia,
sole^nities about deed bodie^ Feralis cultus, mourning apparayle. Feralis
dies, the day of buryenge. Ferax, acis, fruiteful, or that brings forth
much fruit. Ferbeo, bui, ere, to boil or sethe. Ferculum, a dysshe with
meat. Also a pagent, carried or borne to be looked on. sometime it signifies
the stage or place, wherein the pagent is. Fere, almost, nygh, welnygh.
Ferentarii, men armed in lygyt harnes, ready to come quickly to socours: which
sought with darts, swords, or slings. Ferentinum, a city, which after
Plini. stands in the first region of Italye. Ferentum, a town of the Sabius,
or Samnites. Ferettius, a name of Jupiter, given by Romulus, the first king of
Romans. Feretrum, a beer, whereon deed bodies are borne. sometime a thing,
whereon images, relikes, or iewelles are borne. Feretrus, a mountain, of which
the house of Pheretre was named, of which the duke of Vrbyne is descended.
Feriae, feriarum, ferias, holy days. Ferinus, na, number, wild as a beast.
Ferio, percussi, ferire, to stryke, to stablyshe, to knock. Ferire foedus, to
make a league or truse. Ferire iugulum, to slay, to hit the mark. Ferior,
aris, ari, to cesse from labor. Feriatus, unoccupied or ydell. Feritas, tatis,
a natural wyldnes. Ferme, almost, welnygh. Fermentescere, to increase or
wax. Fermento, taui, are, to meddel or myxt well together, as leven with dow.
also to leven. Fero, fers, tuli, far, to bear, to suffer, to lead or
bring, to say, to name, to desire, to bring forth, to have, to boste. Far
ad populu^, to ask the people advise. To take away, to receive, to obtain, to
accustom. Far fortunam, to use fortune: Far in oculis, to favor much.
Far acceptum, to receive, to write that which is received, to knowledge to
have received a benefyte or profit. Far expensum, to spend or lay out, to
write expenses, to bestow. Ferocio, ciui, cij, cire, to be fierce. Ferocitas,
tatis, fiersnes. Ferociter, fiercely. Feronia, the goddess of woods. also a
city under the hill Soractes. Ferox, ferocis, fierce, hardy. Ferramentarij,
they which warke in iron. Ferramentum, an instrument or tole of iron.
Ferraria, an iron Mine. Ferrarius, a, u^, pertaynyng to iron, or of iron. Far
iudicem, to agree to the sentence or judgment. Ferreus, ea, cum, of iron.
Ferro, aui, are, to set iron on. Ferratus, ta, tum, having iron on it, or
closyd in iron. Ferrugineus, a, um, grene color. Ferrugo, ginis, ruite of
iron, a murray color, some calls it a sad blewe. Ferrum, iron, sometime
weapon. Ferrumen, minis, glewe, syse, sowder, or such other byndynge or
cleauynge matter. Ferrumino aui, are, to join or myxe together, proprely
mettalles, to sowlder. Fertilis, le, fertile, or fruitful. Fertum, a Cake
made of sundry graynes and spyces. Ferueo, es, is, iui, ere, to be chauffed or
hette. Feruefacio, to cause to boil. Feruidus, a, um, fervent, dilygent.
Ferula, a rod or stycke, wherewith chyldrens hands be stricken in schools.
also a cane or read. also a pot stycke. Ferulatius, a, um, like a cane or
read. Feruor, oris, heat. Ferus, a, um, wild, cruel, terrible. Feritas,
tatis, wyldenes, cruelty. Fescenini, versis sunge at weddinges. Fessus, a, um,
werye. Festinanter, hastily, quyckely, or swyftly. Festinato, spedily, in
haste. Festino, aui, are, to make have, to be troublid. Festinus, a, um, hasty,
quycke. Festina lent, speed the slowely, is spoken, where a man will sygnifye
a thing to be done, neither to hastyly nor to slowely, but in a convenient
temperance. See my book of the Governor, in the chapter of Maturytie.
Festinatio, haste or speed. Festiuitas, tatis, myrthe. Festiuo, aui, are, to
keep holy day. Festiuus, a, um, merry, provoking myrthe, joyous. also
pertaynyng to holy days. Festuca, the young tender spring of a tree, or herb.
Also a moote. Festus, ta, tum, feastfull or solemn.
F Ante I.
FIber, a beast called a beuer, which is also called Castor, whose stoones
are used in medicine, and are called Castoreum. It is also a kind of waspes.
Fibrae, are the extreme parts of the liver, the heart, or the lunges, or of
other things wherein is any diuysyon, they may be called lappes, brymmes. Also
the spires of herbs or trees new sprongen. Fibula, a buckle of a girdell, or
other thing like thereto. Fibulo, aui, are, to buckle, to join together timber,
or bordes, or other like things. Ficaria, a fygge tree. Ficarius, an eater of
fygges. Ficedula, a bird. Ficetu^, a place where fig trees do grow. Ficetor,
oris, he that loves or gadereth fygges. Ficolea, a staff or stake of a fygge
tree. Ficosus, full of sores in the heed or berde. Fictilis, fictile, erthen,
or made of earth. Fictinus, tia, um, feigned, or dissembled, or counterfayte.
Fictor, oris, a counterfayter, a fayner. Ficulnea, a fygge tree. Ficulneus, a,
um, and ficulnus, a, um, of a fygge tree. Ficus, in the masculyne gender is a
fygge: in the feminine gender, is a fig tree. it is also a soore or scabbe,
growyng in the places of a man's body, where that hear is. Fidei co^missarius,
a feoffe of trust. Fide bona, without fraud or couyne. Fideicommissum, a
feoffement of trust. Fidei co^mitto, misi, tere, to infeffe. Fidesussor, oris,
a surety, or borowe. Fidelia, a vesselle serving to diverse pourposes.
Fidelis, faithful, loyal, trusly, or sure. Fidelitas, tatis, faythefulnesse,
loyalty, or surety. Fidem astringere, to promise faithfully. Fidem fallere,
to break promise. Fidem labefactare, to lose credence. Fides labefactata,
credence lost. Fide sua, mea, tua, iubere, to undertake. Fidena, a town in
Italy. Fidentia, confidence. Fides, fidei, belefe, trust, promise. It is a
stablenes and truth in promyses and couenauntes. It is also a faithful
execution of things committed or promised. Fidem habere, to believe. Fidem
accipere, to be believed. Fidem liberare, to keep promise. Fides, fidis, the
string of any instrument. sometime a harp or lute. Fides publica, the
credence or promise of all the people and rulers. Fidicen, cinis, a harp: it
may be called a fyddell. it is also he that plays on the instrument.
Fidicina, a woman harper or luter. Fidicula, a rebecke, or gytterne. Fidiculae
plurali, a tourment made with cords or strings, wherewith men be tourmented,
to make them to confess treason or felonye. Fido, fisus, sum, fidere, to
trust. Fidutia, trust, confidence: sometime hope: it is proprely that trust,
wherein any thing is deliueryd by one man to an other, to the intent that he
shall redelyuer it, when he is required. Fiduciaria possessio, a possession to
an other man's use, or upon condition. Fiduciaria mancipatio, aut uenditio, a
state in lands made upon confidence of trust, or a morgage. Fidus, a, um,
trusty. Figmentum, the warke or warkemanshyp: sometime a lie, or a thing
feigned. Figo, xi, figere, to thruste in. Columel. Virg. Ge. lib. 4.
sommetyme it sygnifyeth to drive or fasten in the earth. Palum humi fixit, He
drove the stake into the ground. also to plant or set. Ipse feraces Figat
humo plantas, He wolle set in the ground the fruitful plants. Iunenal.
Sometime to stryke. Figlina, ae, a potters warkehowse, or potters craft.
Figlina, plurali, vessel of earth. Figulus, a potter. Figura, a figure.
Figuro, aui, are, to make or form. Filiaster, a son in law by an other
wife, or an other husband. Filius terre, a new begun gentylman, or a
gentylman of the first heed. Filicula, fern growing on trees, callid in a
greek name polypodion. Filius, a son, filia, a daughter. Filii, sometime does
conteyne both sons and daughters. Filistim, a countreye, that is now called
Ascalon. Filix, licis, fern. Filum, a threde. sometime the proporcion of a
thing. Filo, aui, are, to spynne or make a threde. Fimbria, the skyrtes or
hemme of a garmente. Fimetum, a dunge hylle. Fimum, a box, out of the which
men do cast dyse. Fimus, dunge of cattle. Finalis, le, fynall, or last.
Findo, fidi, findere, to cut, to cleue. Fissilis, le, that which may be
cut. Fissura, a cut or clefte. Fingo, xi, gere, to make, to form, to fayn.
Finio, iui, ire, to fynyshe or end. Finis, the end, the conclusyon. also
intent or purpose, whereunto any other thing has relation, or is made or done
for. Fines plurali, the borders or marches of a country, bounds. Finitimus,
ma, um, nygh ioynynge. Finirio, a definition. Finitor, oris, a setter of
bounds. Fio, fieri, to be, to be esteemed. Firmamentum, a suertie or
stabylitie. also that, which is called the ground of a cause or matter. Also
the firmament or heaven vysyble. Firmo, aui, are, to make stable or sure.
Firmus, stable, constant, well fortified. Firmitas, and firmitudo, stablenes,
consta^ce, surenesse. Fiscalis, le, pertaining to the kings treasure.
Fiscella, a chief fate. Also it is a thing made with withes and halters,
wherewith cattle were so moselled, that they might not byte any young
sprynges or buddes of trees. Fiscellus, a little hill in Italye, not far
from Tyber. Fisci, fiscinae, fiscellae, great sachels, wherein were put great
sommes of money. Fiscus, the private treasure of princis. Fiscum, the kings
escheker. Fiscina, a greatte baskette. Fiscibilis, le, that may be cut or
slytte. fiscilis, the same. Fistula, a pype, as well to convey water, as an
instrument of musyke. Also the we sell or throat bolle. also a tappe or
faucette. also a disease or soore, which comes of a putrified humor, and
contynually runs. Fistulosus, full of holes like a sponge* Fistuca, an
instrumente, wherewith pi^^s of wodde be driven into the ground. and stones in
pauynge, called a rammer. Fistucatio, pylinge, or pauynge. Fitiges, be beastis
of Aethiope, of a brown color, having two pappes in the breast, as man has:
nor they be not so wild, but they may be tamed, nor so tame, but they woll
hurt those, that grieve them. Fixus, a, um, fyrme, fast.
F Ante L.
FLabellum, an instrument, wherewith in the heat of summer wind is fanned
blown into men's visages, to koole the^. Flabrum, a blowynge or puff of wind.
Flacceo, and flaccesco, ere, to wydder, or wax feeble. Flaccidus, a, um,
wythered, feeble, weak, hanging downewarde, lollynge, or flaggynge. Flaccum,
bruysed. Flaces, the ortes of olyues. Flagella, the small branches or twigges
of trees or vynes. sometime scourges or flayles, wherewith corn is threshed.
Flagello, aui, are, to scourge, to the thresshe, to blame or rebuke.
Flagitiosus, an ungracious person, full of myschiefe. Flagitium, an ill or
myscheuous deed, worthy rebuke and punyshement. Flagito, aui, are, to ask
importunately and with clamoure. Flagratores, they which for money do suffer
them selfs to be beaten. Flagrio, onis, a slave. Flagro, aui, are, to bourne
with a flame of fire. Sommetyme to love or desire inordynately. Flamea, clothe
or sylke of vyolette color. Flaminica, the priests wife, or a wedding gown
of vyolet color. Flameum, a typpet of vyolet sylke, which the new wedded
wife did wear. Flamen, hoc, the blaste in an instrument. Flamen, the great
priest among the gentyles. Flaminia, the house of the archeprieste.
Flamineum, a kerchiefe or typpette. Flamma, a flame. sometime peril.
Flamescere, to be inflamed. Flammeus, ea, eum, burning or flamynge.
Flammiuomus, sendyng out flames. Flandria, a country called Flaunders. Flaueo,
and flauesco, aui, ere, to be like gold, or of yelowe color. Flauus, a, um,
yelowe, or of the color of gold. Flebilis, le, lamentable. Flecto, and
flexo, xi, tere, to bow, to bend, to lead. Flegma, fleume. Fleo, eui, ere,
to weep. Fletus, weeping. Flexanima oration, an oration or spech, whereby a man's
mind is stirred to pity, reioysynge, or other like affection. Flexilis, le,
any thing that may be easylye bowed or bente. Flexura, the bowynge. Fligo, xi,
ctum, to tourment or vex. Flo, aui, are, to blow. also to make coin of
metal. Floces, lies or drastes of wine. Flocci, flocks of the shearynge of
woollen clothes. Flocculi, fine flocks. Floccifacio, and floccipendo, I set
naught by. Floralia, florales ludi, plays made in the honor of Flora, an
harlotte, which gave a great treasure unto the people of Rome. Floreo, rui,
ere, and florido, aui, are, to flourish or to have flowers. Also to excel.
sometime to prosper. Flos, floris, a flower. Floresco, sci, scere, to bourgen or
to bring forth flowers. Floreus, a, um, made of flowers. Floridus, da, dum,
garnyshed with flowers. sometime fresh or lusty. Floriger, eris, bearing
flowers. Florulentus, ta, tum, full of flowers. Fluctio, onis, the reume or
pose. Fluctiuagus, wandering in rivers or waters. Fluctuo, aui, are, to be
tossed as a ship is in the sea. also to doubt. Fluctuatim, troublously,
doubtfully. Fluctuosus, a, u^, troublous, unquiet, stormy. Fluctus, a floudde,
a wave of water styred by tempeste. Fluentum, a river, or stream. Fluescere,
to be resolved or relented. Fluidus, da, dum, flowynge, relentyd, resolved.
Fluito, aui, are, to flow contynually, sometime to flytte or swymme. Flamen,
inis, a great river. sometime the course of the water. Flumineus, a, um, of the
river. Fluminosus, a, um, full of ryuers. Fluo, xi, ere, to rounne, as water
does, to proceed or come of a thing, or to grow. Fluor, fluxus, and fluxio,
a flyxe. Fluta, a fyshe, like to an eele, called a Lampreye. Fluuialis, le, of
the river. Fluuiatilis, le, that which is in the river. Fluuius, a floudde or
river. Fluxu^a, lecherye. Fluxus, a, um, unstable, or that which dureth but a
while, large, or wide, relented, lecherous, and wanton.
F, Ante O.
FOcale, a kerchiefe, which men and womenne did wear about their
cheeks. Focaneus, a branch of a vine, which grows out of a twyste or
forked bough. Focaria, a fire pan. Focatius, bread baken on the hot coals.
Focillo, aui, are, to nouryshe. Focula, nourishynge meats. Foculo, aui, are,
to nouryshe or sustain. Foculus, a little pan, wherein fire is borne. Focus,
a pan or herthe, wherein fire is. sometime it sygnifieth fire. sometime
private houses or tenementes. Fodico, aui, are, to dygge. Fodina, a place where
a thing is dygged. Fodio, fodi, fodere, to delue. Foecundo, daui, are, to make
fruitefulle, (...) plentuouse. Foecundus, a, um, plentuous, or fruitful.
Foecunditas, plenty. Foedo, aui, are, to polute or defyle, to destroy, to
rent or tear, to consume. Foedero, aui, are, to confederate. Foederatus, a
confederate. Foedifragus, a breaker of leage or truse, or intercourse. Foedus,
da, dum, foul, defourmed, cursed, or cruelle. Foedus, deris, a leage between
princis, an intercourse, a truse after battle: sometime it signifies a law
made in the time of wars. Foelicitas, tatis, felycitie, prosperity,
abundaunce of all things. Foelicito, aui, are, to make prosperous. Foelix,
licis, having abundance of al things, prosperous, commodious, or profitable.
Foemina, a womanne. Also in beasts the female. Foenatius, ia, um, pertaining
to hay, as Falces foenariae, hooks or sythes for to cut hay. Foenebris,
bre, pertaynyng to vsurye, or unreasonable gain. Foeneratitius, a, um, the
same. Foenerator, oris, an usurer or lender for unreasonable gain. Foenero,
aui, are, and foeneror, rari, cum datino, to lend for usury. Foeneror cum
ablatiuo, To borowe, or make a shyfte, or to lay to morgage. Foeniculum,
fenell. Foenile, an hey house. Foenisecium, hay harvest. Foenisex, secis, a
mower of hay. Foenograecum, fenegreke. Foenum, hay. Foenus, noris, vsurye,
unreasonable, or unlawful gain, coming of that thing, which is lent.
Foeteo, tere, to stynke. Foetidus, a, um, stynkynge. Foetifico, aui, are, to
bring forth, most commonly as a beast or a bird does. Foeto, taui, are, the
same. Foetor, oris, stynche, or ill savor. Varro
Foetuosus, a, um, full of bredynge. Foetura, the time from the conception unto
the birth. Also the increase of cattle. sometime it signifies the increase
or coming forth of other things. Foetus, tus, all thing that is brought
forth by generation, sometime the fruit of trees. Foetus, ta, tum, full, or
great with young, as a woman with child or a beast. Foliacius, a, um, full of
leaves. Foliatus, ta, tum, leaued, or having leaves. Folium, a leaf. Follico,
caui, care, to snuff or fetch back wind with the nosethrylles. Folliculus,
the husk, wherein the ear of wheat or other corn is enclosed, when it is
grene, called the hose. Also for a sack, wherein corn is put. Follis, a
below, wherewith fire is blown. also a ball blown full of wind: semblably a
bed stuffed only with wind. it is also a bag, wherein money is. Fomentum,
a nourishment of natural heat. It is also any thing laid to the body in the
form of a plaster, to mytygate the pain or grief of any disease, called
fomentation. Fotus, the same. Fomes, fomitis, any matter, wherewith fire is
kendlyd and kept burning. sometime it sygnifieth that, which fervently
styreth us to do any thing. Fons, fontis, a fountain or well. Fontanus, a,
um, of a fountain: as Aqua fontana, well water. Fonticulus, a little well or
spring. Foramen, minis, a hole. For As, without. Foratia, a market woman,
which sells eggs, chykens, and other like things at the markette. Foratus,
tus, a hole. Forbea, a kind of hot meat. Forcipes, a pair of tongues or
other like instrument. Forcus, a propre name of a man. Forda, a mylche cow
that brings forth caulfes. Forem, res, ret, I should or had be, thou should
or had be, he should or had been. Fore, to be hereafter. Forensia, habytes or
robes, worn only in places of judgment. Forensis, se, pertaynyng to places of
judgment or courts, where laws be exercysed: also a iurrour. Fores, doors.
Forfices, sheares. Forficuli, little sheares. Fori, the hatches of a ship, or
place where men being in the ship, do walk up and down. Also stages or
galeries, from whe^s the noble men of Rome beheld the plays called Circenses.
Foruli, huches, wherein books were kept: now be they taken for keuerynges of
books. Foria, dunge that is lyquide or thynne. Forica, commune draughtes or
Iakes. Foriculae, little doors. Forinsecus, without. Forio, iui, ire, to
discharge the bealy of ordure. Foriolus, lose bealy, or he that has a laske.
Forma, form or shappe. sometime beaultie. Formiae, a town in Campania.
Formica, an Emote, or Ant, or Pismere. Formicatio, that which is commonly
called a ring worm. Formidabilis, le, that which is to be drad. Formido,
dinis, dread or fear. Formido, aui, are, to have great fear. Formidolosus, he
that fears other: also he that is feared of other. Formo, aui, are, to form,
to make in facion. Formosus, a, um, fair. Formucales, a peyre of tongues.
Formula, an instrument or deed in writing. a style in writing, and a form in
pleadynge. Formula iniuriarum, an action of trespass. Formulam intendere, to
bring an action. Fornacalia, days when the women did naught else but bake
breadde. Fornax, a chymney, or oven. Fornax calcaria, a lyme kylle. Fornax
lateraria, a brycke kill. Fornicarii, they which have stalles or bouthes under
the vaultes or arches of churches or palayces, where they sell their wares to
them that pass by, as they do in west mynster halle. Fornicarius, ia, um,
pertaynyng to lechery. Fornico, aui, are, to make an arch or a vault. Fornicor,
ari, to commytte fornication. Fornix, nicis, an arche or a vaulte. Foro, aui,
are, to perce or boore a hole. Forpices, cyssars to clyppe hear. Forte,
peradventure, perchance. Fortasse, fortassis, forsan, forsitan, the same.
Fortesco, sci, scere, to wax strong. Forticulus, a little strong.
Fortifico, aui, are, to fortify or make strong. Fortis, strong, puissant,
valyant of courage. also fair, sometime rich. Fortitudo, dinis, strength,
valyant courage. Fortuitus, ta, tum, that happens by chance. Fortuna, fortune.
Fors fortuna, good fortune or chance. Fortunatae insulae, the fortunate
islands, be so called of the abundaunce of fruits, of which Strabo
writes.li.i. Fortunatim, fortunately. Fortunatus, ta, tum, fortunate. Fortuno,
naui, are, to make prosperous, to augment with good fortune. Forum, a market,
where things be sold. Also a place where judgments are practiced, and
matters in law pleaded. Forum when it is taken for a market, has commonly an
other word joined therewith, as Forum boatium, the markette where cattle to
sold. Forum holitorium, the markette where herbs be sold. Forum piscarium,
the fyshe markette. Forum Iulium, a region or country of Italy which sometime
was called Iapidia. Forum Cornehi, a city of Italye, which now is called
Imola. Fossa, a dyche, or dyke, or a mote. Fossilis, le, that which is dygged,
or may be dygged. Fossio, dyggynge. Fossitius, a, um, that is dygged. Fossor,
oris, a digger or dycher. Fossula, a little dyche. Fossura, a dyggynge, Fotus,
ta, tum, nourished. Fouea, a den. Foueo, ui, uere, to nouryshe, to sustain,
to maynteyne, to weate or wash a thing, to ordeyne or set, to defend.
F Ante R.
FRacesco, sci, scere, to putrify for age. Fracidus, da, dum, more than ripe,
rotten as fruit is. Fraeno, aui, are, to brydell, to restrain. Fraenum, a
brydell. Fraenum mordere, to take the bytte in the teethe, sygnifieth to set
naught by. Plautus in Amp.
Fraetus, ta, tum, truslynge, aided. Fraeti uittute and uiribus, aided with
strength and puissance. Fraga, strawberies. Fragesco, sci, scere, to braste.
Fragilis, le, brokell, soon broken. Fragilitas, brotylnes, inconstancy.
Fragiliter, weakly, inconstantly. Fragitides, the two great veins, which do
appear on either side of the neck. Fragmen and fragmentum, a piece or gobette
of a thing broken. Fragor, oris, the noise, which is made at the falling of
any great thing, rushyng. Fragosus, a, um, uneasy to clymme. Fragro, aui, are,
to render a great savor. Fragrans, it is, having great or sote savor. Framea, a
spear, or iauelyn. Frango, fregi, frangere, to break. Franosus, a deceyuer.
Frater, tris, a brother. Fraterculus, a little or young brother. Fraterne,
brotherly. Fraternus, na, um, of a brother. Frater patruelis, a brothers son.
Fratilli, the fringe of tapesry, that hangs next the ground. Fratrare,
proprely is said of chyldernes breasts, when they do grow, to wax imbocyd.
Fratria, a brothers wife. Fraudo, aui, are, to begyle, to disappoynte. Fraudare
genium, not to satisfy the necessity of nature, or carnal appetite.
Fraudulenter, deceytefully. Fraudulentus, full of deceyte. Fraudulosus, a
begyler. Fraus, fraudis, deceyt. Also peril, danger. Fraxinus, an ash. Fraxo,
aui, are, to go in watch. Fregella, a little town in Italy. Fremitus, a
rorynge, proprelye of waters. sometime a murmuryng, rumble, or noise of people
assemblyd together. Fremo,, mi, mere, to rore or make a noise like great
waters. Frendeo, dui, dear, to grynde the tethe together for anger or pain.
Also to grunte or groan for pain. Frequens, eutis, acustomed, much hanted,
also assembled together, abundant. Frequens Senatus, all the Senators assemblyd
together. Frequentia, greatte haunte, and company of folk. Frequento, taui,
tare, to haunte, to goo together. Frequentatio, an hauntynge, an assembly.
Fretum, a narowe part of the sea, where it is mouynge and troublous. Sometime
it is taken generally for the sea. Friabilis, le, soon broken in small
pieces. Fribolus, almost worth an halfepeny. Frico, caui, cui, care, to
rub. Frictus, fricatio, and frictio, rubbyng. Frigefacio, feci, facere, to
cool. Frigefio, frigefieri, to be cold. Frigeo, gui, and frixi, to be cold
or slow. Frigero, aui, are, to cool. Frigesco, scere, to wax cold.
Frigidulus, a, um, somewhat cold. Frigidus, da, dum, cold, daungerouse, or
noyfull. Frigilla, a bird, which syngeth in the cold wether, a ruddocke.
Frigo, xi, and frigui, gere, to frye. Frictus, and frixus, a, um, fried.
Frigorificus, ca, cum, made cold. Frigus, goris, cold. sometime fear.
Frigutio, tiui, tiri, to leap up, or hoppe. Frio, aui, are, to break small,
specially betwyxte the fyngers. Frisii, people by Holande. Frit, the grain in
the top of the ear, which is less than a corn. Fritilla, a froyse or
pancake. Fritillus, a box, out of the which dise were cast on the tables.
Friuolarius, he that sells stuff of little valewe. Friuolus, a, um, vain,
light, of none estymation or value. Frixorium, a fryenge pan. Frondarius, ia,
ium, of leaves. Frondatio, a slyppynge of of leaves. Also brousynge. Frondator,
oris, a brouser, a wodlopper. Frondeo, and frondesco, descere, to bear or have
leaves. Frondeus, ea, eum, that is of leaves. Frondo, daui, are, to bring
forth leaves. Frondosus, a, um, full of leaves. Frons, it is, the foreheed, the
frunt. Also it signifies shamefastnes. also countenance. ^rasmus in Chiliad.
Frontem ferire, is spoken where a man sygnyfyeth, that one disdayneth
extremely an another. Frons, frondis, the leaf of a tree, with the branches.
Frondifer, bearing leaves. Frontale, the hedstall of an horse. Fronto, tonis,
he that has a broad forhed. Frontosus, having a greatte forehed, or not
abashed. Fructifer, bearing fruit. Fructificus, and fructuosus, fruitful.
Fructuarius, he that takes the fruit or profit of a thing. Pernour of
profytes. Fructuarius, ria, rium, that which bears fruit, or does pertayne
to fruit. Fructus, tus, and ti, fruit. also al profit or revenues that
comes of the ground. Fruges, aut frux, frugis, increase of all those things,
which the earth brings forth, most proprely of grain or corn. sometime it
signifies rent or revenues. Frugi, moderate, profitable, necessary. Frugi
homo, a good man, a thryfty man, an honest man, temperate in expenses.
Frugalitas, tatis, moderation in living, specially in apparaylle and dyete,
sobre rule, also suffyciencye. Frugalior, frugalissimus, more temperate, most
temperate. Fruiscor, sci, to use at liberty. Frumen, the uppermost part of the
throat, the gargyll. Frumentaceus, of corn. Frumentarius, ia, ium, pertaining
to corn. Frumentario, taking of corn. Frumentator, toris, a taker or
pourueyour of corn. Frumentor, aris, to gather or puruey corn. Frumentum, all
corn, that has berdes or eyles. it is most used for wheat or rye. Frunitus,
wise in using of a thing. Fruor, fretus sum, frui, to use with dilectation
and profit. Frustatim, in piecis or gobettes. Frustillatim, piece meal.
Frustra, in vain. Frustro, aui, are, and frustror, aris, ari, to deceive. also
to do a thing in vain, or vainly to employe. Frustum, a piece or gobette.
Frustulum, and frustillum, a little gobette. Frusus, a kind of brembyls,
whose pryckes be not hooked. Frutex, that which has a great stalk, and yet it
is no tree, as fenelle, caules, certain malowes, and other like herbs.
sometime it is taken for the stem or stalk. Frutetosus, a, um, having
abundaunce of such great herbs. Frutetum, seu fruticetu^, a place where
grows herbs with great ste^mes or stalks. Fruticescere, to be a stalk.
Frutico, aui, are, and fruticor, fruticaris, ari, to spring in stalk.
F Ante V.
FVcilis, le, false, colouryd. Fucinus, a lake in Italy. Fuco, caui, care, to
lay on a color. Fucatus, ta, tum, colored or painted, as some women be.
Fucus, a dorre or be without stynge, which enters into hyues, and eats up
honey. Also payntynge, where oone color is laid on an another. It is also used
for desceyte or falsehode. Fuga, flight. Fugax, gacis, he that flies lightly.
Also it signifies swyfte. Fugio, gi, gere, to fly, to run away, to escape,
to forgette. Fugiens laboris, abhorring labor or peyn. Fugitiuarius, a, um,
startyng away, flyttyng. Fugitiuae aquae, waters, which be taken out of a
commune river by stelthe. Fugitiuus seruus, he that runs from his master,
wyllyng never to return, or goth to a place, from whens he supposes that his
master can never recover him. Fugito, taui, tare, to use to runue away. Fugo,
aui, are, to drive away. Fulcio, si, cire, to supporte, to fortyfie. Fulcra,
