beddestedes. Fulgeo, si, gere, and fulgo, gi, ere, to shine. Fulgetrum, a leame
of lyghtnynge. Fulgidus, da, dum, bryghte. Fulgor, bryghtnesse. Fulgur, uris,
uel oris, lyghtnynge. Fulguratio, the lyghtnynge whenne it is in the clouds.
Fulgurator, the sender of lyghtnynge. Fulgutio, riui, rire, to cast
lyghtnynge. Fulgutitas, lyghtnes or bryghtnes. Fulguto, aui, are, to send
forth lyghtning. Fulica, a se byrd, more tha^ a culuer, and black. Fuligo,
ginis, the soote of a chymney. Fullo, onis, a fuller of clothe. Fulmen, minis,
lyghtnynge. Fulmino, aui, are, to lyghten. Fultura, a shore. Fuluus, ua, um, a
color mixte of grene and read, a dark yelowe. Fumatium, a smoky place, where
wine was laid, to the intent that it moughte the sooner ware old. also the
shanke or tonell of a chymneye. Fumifico, aui, are, to make smoke, to ince^se.
Fumigo, aui, are, to parfume. Fumo, aui, are, to smoke. Fumus, smoke. Funale, a
torche. Funales equi, horses, which coupled with an halter, did go before the
charyot. Funambulus, he that walks on a rope. Funda, a slynge. Also a
castinge net, a sach^ll or purse like a net. Also a cerkle of gold, or
other mettalle, wherein stones he set. Fundamen, and fundamentum, a
fundacion. Fundibula^^, slyngers of stones. Funditores, the same. Fundito, aui,
are, to pour out often. Fund^^^s, from the foundation utterly. Fundo, aui,
are, to found, to make stable. Fundo, fudi, fundere, to yette or cast metal,
to power out, to sheede, to throw down, to scatter, to give aboundantlye, to
speak much, to lay down. Fundum, the bottom of a thing. Fundus, that
which is used to be called land or soil. Funebris, bre, funeralle. Funepeus,
a goer on a cord. Funerale, pertaining to funeralles. Funereus, rea, reum,
pertaining to the deed body. Funero, aui, are, to burye. Funesto, aui, are,
to vyolate a place with a deed body. Funestus, ta, tum, vyolated with dead
bodies. Also mortalle, blouddy. also pertaining to deed bodies or death.
Funetum, bowed or howped, as sum vynes be. Fungor, functus sum, fungi, to
exercise an office. Fungi uita, to live. Functus uita, He that has fynished
his life. Fungus, a tadde stole, a mousherom. Fungosus, like a musherom.
Funiculus, a small rope. Funis, a rope. Funus, funeris, funeral exequies, or
solemnity of burienge. Sometime it sygnyfieth the deed corpse. Fuo, fui, futum,
to be. Fur, furis, a thief. Furax, acis, theuyshe, a great picker. Furca,
furcula, an hey forke. Furcifer, ciferis, a servant, which for some light
offense, was compelled to bear a forke on his neck, having both his hands
bounden fast thereto, and so to goo through the town, confessing his defaut,
and exhorting other, that they should not in like case offend, which was a
great reproach. Furcilis, a dungeforke. Furcilla, an heyforke, also a galowes.
Furfur, uris, branne. Furfureus, and furfuraceus, a, um, of branne. Furiae, the
furyes of Hell, which were three, Alecto, Tisiphone, Megera. Furiatus, a, um,
furyous. Furibundus, a, um, wood or very mad. Furio, aui, are, to make mad
or wood. Furiosus, a, um, mad, or wodde, frantyke. Furnaceus, a, um, baken
in an oven. Furnaria, bakers craft. Also a womanne baker. Furnus, an oven.
Furo, furi, furere, to be wood for anger. Furor, aris, ari, to steal. Furor,
roris, madness: Also furye, which is a vehement concytation or styrrynge of
the mind. Furtim, by stelthe, priuilye. Furtificus, a pycker or priuye
stealer. Furtiuus, a, um, that which is done by stelth, or very pryuyly.
Furtum, theft. it is defyned to be a deceitful handlynge or using of any
thing, or the possession thereof, to have thereby gain or advantage, which is
by the law of nature prohibited to be suffered. It is sometime any act that is
done privily, or to the intent it should be secret. Furti teneri, aut
obstringi, to be answerable to felonye. Furuae hostiae, sacrifice done to
Pluto and Proserpine. Furunculus, a little thief, also a be called a Stote,
that kills rabettis. It is also a sore callid a felon. also a sore callid a
cattisheer. Fuscina, a spear with many teethe, wherewith fyshers do take
troutes, or yeles, by throwynge of it, a troute spear, an yele spear.
Fuscinula, a flesh hook. Fuscus, ca, cum, brown of color, not fully black.
Fusile, that which may be molten. Fusim, abroad, as it were molten. Fuse, in
length, long. Fusores, melters, Fusorius, a, um, pertaining to meltynge, As
Ars fusoria, the craft of meltyng. Vas fusorium, a meltynge pot. Fusus, a,
um, molten. Fusus, si, a spyndell. Fustigo, are, to beat with a staff.
Futilis, le, that which will be soon powered out. Futilis, he that speaks all
that he knows shortly or unadvisedly.
G Ante A.
GABALVS, a galowe tree or gybet, whereon men be hanged. Gabata, a potagedyshe.
Gabinus, a garment with two lappes, whereof the one cast backward, did gyrde
him that did were it. which garment the consule ware, when he denounced wars.
Gades, two yles by the further parts of Spain, beyond Granade. Gaetuli,
people in Affrike. Gaetulia, a country in Affrike. Gagates, a stone called
Ieate. Galactophagus, an eater of milk. Galactopota, a drynker of milk.
Galatae, people that inhabyte Galatia. Galbanus, a gum of a certain tree,
which is much used in playsters. Galbinus, a, um, delycate, wanton. Galbuli,
things which do hang on cypress trees, like small hears. Galea, an helmet
or salette. Galenus, the name of a noble physician. Galerita, a lark. Galerus,
and Galerum, a hat. also a pirwike. Galla, a fruit called Gaulles. Gallicanus,
a, um, of France. Gallia, France. Gallicia, a royalme in Spain, callydde
Galyce. Gallicinium, the time when the Cock croweth. Gallicus, ca, cum,
French. Gallina, a hen. Gallinaceus pullus, a chyke. Gallinaceus, a house
cock. Gallinarium, a place where pultry is kept. Gallinarius, and gallinaria,
he or she that keeps pultrye. Gallus, a, um, french. Gallo, are, to be mad.
Gallograetia, a countreye in Asia, called also Galatia. Gallus, a cock, a
Frencheman, a priest of Cybeles, called the mother of the gods, Gamale, a
town in Judea. Gammarus, a fyshe called a lopstar. Salustius.
Ganea, and ganeum, a brothell house, a house of baudry and ryotte. Also Ganea,
is taken for gluttonye. Ganeo, onis, a Ruffyan, a haunter of bandy houses, a
ryotter. Also a rauyner of delycates, a frauncher. Ganges, a greatte river,
which enuyronneth India, wherein is found both gold and precious stones.
Gangeticus, ca, cum, of that river. Gangraena, a sore called a cankre.
Ganymedes, a Troyane child, which was feigned to be rauyshed of Iupyter, and
made his butlar. Gannio, nire, to bark or houle like a dog. Gannitus, tus,
barkynge, or howlynge. Garamantes, people in Affrike. Garganus, a hylle in
Apulia. Gargara, a mountayn, and also a city in Asia. Gargarisso, are, to
gargaryshe or wash the mouth and throat of a man. Garrio, ire, to babble.
Gariophylum, a spyce called cloves. Garrulus, a babblar. Garum, sauce mude with
fyshe. Garumna, a river in France. Gaudeo, gauisus sum, gaudere, to rejoice,
to be glad. Gaudere in sinu, to rejoice by him self. Gaudium, joy, myrthe,
an affection of the mind, conceived of an opinion of a thing good or
pleasant. Gaulus, a little round bote. Gausape, a mantell to cast on a
bed: also a carpette to lay on a table, some call it a daggeswayne.
Gausapina, a certain garment. Gaza, the treasure of a king. Curtius.
Gazophilaciu^, a place where tresure is kept
G, Ante E.
GEbenna, a hill and town in Sauoy, now called Geneura. Gedeon, the name of a
judge in Israel. Geenna, is taken in holy scripture for hell. Gela, a river in
Syetle. Gelabilis, le, that may be frosen. Gelasco, scere, to be frosen.
Gelasini, the Fooreteethe, which be showed in laughing. Gelasinus, he that
laugheth to make other men laughe. Gelicidium, a froste. Gelidus, a, um, cold
as yse. Gelo, aui, are, to freese. Geloi, fyeldes in Sycile. Geloni, a people
now called Tartariens. Gel^, use, sommetyme cold. Gemellas, little or small
twynnes. Gemibundus, full of waylynge. Geminus, a, um, the noumbre of two. Also
geminus, is a twynne, where many children are borne at one burdeyne, although
they be three or mo. Also it is the name of a man, which in hebrewe is Thomas.
Gemino, aui, are, to double. Gemma, the young budde of a vine. Also a precious
stone. Gemmo, aui, are, to budde or spring, as a young graffe or vine does.
Gemmascere, to begin to budde. Gemmatus, a, um, budded. Gemo, mui, ere, to
groan, or to wayle, or to make a lamentable noise. Gemoniae scalae, a place
from whense the bodies of persons condemned were thrown down. Gemo^^^^,
women great with child. Gemmsa, a corn, or like grief under the ^yttell too.
Gena, the eye lydde. It is sommetyme taken for the chekes. Genauius, a, um,
glouttonous. Gene^logia, a pedegrewe. Gener, he that maryeth my daughter.
Generalis, le, general. Generatim, generally. Genero, aui, are, to engender.
Generosus, a, um, of a gentyl or noble kind. Genesis, generation. Genethliacus,
an astronomer, or other like, which by the sterres set at a man's nativity,
tells his fortune. Genialis homo, a man in his house very lyberall and
fresh. Geniculatim, ioynted, as a wheat straw is. Geniculum, the joint of a
straw, or stalk of an herb. Genista, broom. Genitalis, le, pertaining to
the birth of a man. genitale solum, the natural country or place, where a man is borne. genitalis dies, the day of nativity. genitale semen, the sede
of generation, genitalia, the members of generation. Genimen, generation.
Genitor, a father. Genitrix, a mother. Genitura, sometime generation, sometime
the sede of generation. Genitiuus, a, um, that has power to engender, or that
which proceeds with generation. genitiuae notae, marks, wherewith a man is
borne. Genitus, ta, tum, begotten, engendered. Genius, an angel. Among the
Paynims some supposed it to be the spirit of a man. Some did put two
governors of the soul, a good and an evil, Bonus genius, and malus genius,
which never departed from us. sometime it is taken for nature it self, or
dilectation meued by nature. Genii, men, which do give all their study to
eating and drinking. Geniae, old veckes full of unhappiness. Genio dare
operam, to live voluptuousely. Genium defraudare, to absteyne from all things
pleasant. Genocha, a beast less than a fox, of color between black and
yelow, medlid with black spots, which will soon be made tame. Gens, gentis,
a people, sometime a kindred. Gentiana, an herb called Gencyan. Gentilis, a
kynseman of the same name and stock. sometime it signyfyeth a gentyle or
paynyme. sometime a country man. Gentilis, le, propre, or familyar to that
people, or kynrede. Gentilitas, tatis, gentilitie, the multitude of the people
or famyly. Gentilitium nomen, the surname or ancyent name of a man's auncetours.
Gentilitius, a, um, of the people or nation, gentilitia sacra, ceremonies of
that country or people. Genu, a knee. Genua, a great cite callid Geane.
Genuini, the innermoste cheke teethe. Genuinus sermo, the natural speech or
mother tunge. Genus, generis, is the beginning of every thing, either of the
person that engendered it, or of the place, where it was engendered. Orestes a
Tantalo ducit genus, Orestes has his beginning of Tantalus, or is of the
bloudde of Tantalus. Plato genere Atheniensis est, Plato is of his bloudde or
auncetrye an Athenyens. Also it sygnifieth kind. genus uitae, a kind of life.
genus mortis, a kind of death. genus animalium, a kind of beasts. Also it
signifies that, which contains many sundry kinds, as Animal comprehends
a man, a bird, a fyshe, and every of them is genus to that, which in them is
comprehended. As a brute beast is genus to a horse, a lion, a bulle, a dog,
etc. A bird is genus to an egle, a crow, a lark, a sparowe. etc. A fish is
genus to a whale, a porpese, a haddocke, a playce. etc. Geographia, the
description of the earth. Geomancia, superstitious warkinge in sorcerye, by
cerkles and pricks in the earth. Geometer, a geometritian. Geometria,
geometry, measuring and proporcionyng of fygures in the earth. Georgica,
pertaining to husbandry. Germani, Germaynes, or Almayns, They be also
brethren of one father and oone mother. Germania, the country named Germany,
or Almayne. Germen, minis, a branche of a tree or herb. Germino, aui, are, to
branche out. Gero, gessi, gerere, to bear. sometime it signifies to have.
Gerere magistratum, to exercise an office. Gesta, and gestaetes, acts, things
practiced or done. Gerrae siculae, tryfles. Gerres, fyshe of the kind of
herrynges, it may be called pylchardes. Gerrones, talkers of tryfelyng things,
or light matters. Gerulus, a porter, or a man hired to carye bourdeynes.
Gerula, a maid that keeps a child. Gerusia, a place where the Senate did
assemble, a parlyament house. Geryon, onis, the name of a king of Spain, which
was slain by Hercules. Gesa, a haulberde. Gessoriacum, as some men do suppose,
was the town, which is now named Caleys. Gestamen, minis, what so ever is
borne, a burdeyn or caryage. Gestatorium, that wherein any thing is carried or
borne, a flagon, a horse lytter. Gestatio, the exercise, where a man is borne
or carried on any thing. Gesticularius, a, um, pertaynyng to signs or tokens
of myrthe, with meuyng the body or hands. Gesticulator, he that playith with
puppettes. Gesticulor, aris, to make such signs or tokens of myrthe, as in
daunsynge. Gestio, iui, ire, to show the affections of the mind by meuyng of
the body, or any part thereof* sometime it signifies to delight. Gestito, taui,
are, to bear or were oftentimes Gesto, aui, are, to bear long. Gestat
ventre^, she to with child. Gestuosus, full of tokens of myrthe. Gestus, ta,
tum, borne, or done. Gestus, ^u^, gesture, or countenance with menynge of the
body. Getuli, a people in Affrike.
G, ante I.
GIarus, a littell i will in the sea called Ionium, where unto men condemned
were exyled. Gibber, and gibbosus, and gibberosus, he which has a crooked
back, or a great bunche on any part of the body. Gibbus, and gibba, a great
bunche. Gigantomachia, a battle of geantes. Gigas, gigantis, a gyaunt. Gigno,
genui, gignere, to engender or get. Giluus, ua, um, yelowe color. Gingeria,
uel gigeria, a mete made of sundry kinds of flesh, or of garbage of foul.
Gingiuae, the jaws, wherein the teth be set. Gingiuerim, sieve gingiberim,
gynger. Gingrio, gingrii, ire, to cry like a goose. Gion, a great river in
Egypt, otherwise called Nylus. Girgillus, a rele, whereon threde is wou^den
Gith, a sede, which is now called Nigella Romana: it is black like to oynyon
sede, and is very soote, and the sauoure thereof exhausteth reumes of the heed.
G ante L.
GLaber, bra, bru^, smothe, without hear. Glabella, the space between ye brows.
Glabresco, scere, to be without here, or smothe. Glabreta, a place, having
nothing growing in it. Glabriones, they which lack hear. Glacialis, le,
where yse is. Glacior, aris, ari, to be frosen. Glacies, yse. Glacitare, to
make a noise like a gander. Gladiatores, were men, which faught unarmed with
swords. Gladiatorius, ria, rium, pertainynge to that manner of fighting.
Gladiatura, the art or feate to fight with a sword. Gladiolus, a little
sword or wodknyfe. also the name of an herb like to sedge. Gladius, a sword,
also a kind of fish, which has a bone in his forheed like to a sword.
Glandatio, fedynge of swyne with maste, called paunage. Glandium, glandionica,
the part of a bore next the neck, the shield or gammonde. Glans, gla^dis,
mast growing on oaks, bech, chestons, and other like, it is also a pellette of
lead. Also a kernel growyng between the skin and the flesh, it is more
over the foreparte or nutte of a man's yerde. Glandifer, fera, diferum, that
which bears maste. Glaphirus, a, um, iocunde, pleasant, ingraued, polyte,
holow, famous, subtle. Glarea, sand, proprely sandy grauel. Glareosus, a, um,
sandy. Glasium, an herb like to plantayne, which makes a blewe color,
Caesar.
wherewith the ancient Butons dyed their vysages. some men english it woadde.
Glaucinum, oil, which does come from the olyues before they be pressed.
Glauciolus, a horse with a wall eye. Glaucium, an herb, which crepeth on the
earth nygh to salt waters. Glaucoma, matis, and glaucomatum, ti, and glaucoma,
mae, an humor in the eien, like crystal, which lets the sight. Glaucopis,
pidis, a man or womanne with graye eyes. Glaucus, ca, cum, gray color. Glaucus
substantinum, a god of the sea. also many men were called by that name. also
the name of a fysshe. Gleba, a turfe or piece of earth. Glessum, crystal, or
beryll. Glycyrrhiza, lykoresse. Glis, itis, a field mous, which slepeth all
the winter. Glis, glissis, potters claye. Glis, glitis, a thystell. Glisco,
sci, scere, to grow, to wax fat, to couerte or desire fervently. Globo,
aui, are, to gather round. Globus, and globum, a boule, or other thing very
round. Also a multitude of men or beasts gathered round together.
Globosus, a, um, round as a boule. Glocido, aui, are, to cackle as a hen
does. Glocio, cire, idem. Glomero, aui, are, to wind in round. also to gather
together in an heap. Quint.
Gloria, the consent of good me^ in the praise of a man or woman, callid
renome, glory. Glorior, aris, to auaunt, to the intent to have praises, to
extolle with bostynge. Gloriosus, a, um, renomed, sometime in the ill part,
vaynglorious, or bosting him self. Glos, glotis, the systers husband, or
brothers wife. Glossa, a gloss, or exposition of dark spech. Glossemata, words
not much used. Glossematicus, he that makes a commente on a book. Glubo, by,
bear, to pulle of the bark or rynde of a tree. Gluma, the husk of wheat.
Gluo, glui, ere, to streyne or wringe hard. Gluten, and glutinum, glewe.
Glutinamentum, al glewyshe matter. Glutino, aui, are, to glewe or join.
Glutio, tiui, tire, to swalowe. Gluto, tonis, a glutton. Glyciamerides, a kind
of meat.
G, ante N.
GNafalon, a certain floxe. Gnarus, a, um, skylfull. Gnare, skylfully.
Gnaritas, tatis, skylfulnes. Gnomones, the teethe, whereby the age of an horse
is known. They be sommetyme taken for that, which shows the hours in a
clock or dial.
G, ante O.
GObius, a fyshe, called a gogeon. Goaetia, a spice of wytchecrafte. Gomor, a
measure among the jews. Gomorrha and gomorrhum, a city in Judea which was
consumed for horrible sin against nature. Gonorrha, a disease, whereby a man's
seed gothe from him vnwyttyngly. Gorgia, the name of a great rhetorician.
Gorgones, monstrous womenne, which were vanquyshed by Perseus. Gortys, a
city of Candy. Gossampinus, a tree, which bears cotton. Gossipium, cotton.
G, ante R.
GRabatus, a cowche. Graculus, a bird called a Iaye. Graculo cum fidibus
nihil, The Iaye has naught to do with the harp. which is spoken of them,
which lacking eloquence or good letters, do scorn them that have it.
Gracus, and graculus, a chough or cadese. Gracchus, the name of a noble famylye
or house in Rome. Gracilis, le, gracilentus, ta, tu^, lean, or sclender,
sometime soft. Gracile, sclenderly. Gracilitas, cilitatis, leanness,
sclendernes, or softness. Gradus, a greese or step, a degree in
consanguinitie. De gradit delici, to be cast down from his place: whereby is
sygnifyed to be abashed or moved from constancy of mind. Deturbari gradu,
has the same signification. Gradior, to go by steps, or step. Gradator, a
great goer. Gradatii equi, amblynge horses. Gradatio, a form of speaking,
when of the first sentence springs the second, of the second the third,
and so forth. Gradatim, in order, or by course. Gradiuus, one of the names of
Mars. Gradior, eris, gressus sum, to go. Graecus, a man borne in Greece, a
Greek. Graecus, a, um, of Greece. Graecia, Greece. Graecanicus, ca, cum, come
out of Greece. Graecostasis, a place where Ambassadors adode, until they were
sent for into the Senate. Graiugenae, Greeks. Graecor, caris, ari, to ryotte
in bankettynge and rybaudrye. Gralae, crouches, or styltes. Grallatores, they
which do go on styltes. Grammatica, grammar. Grammaticus, he that teaches
grammar, or expoundethe authors, a profounde grammaryan. Grammatista, a
smatterer in grammar, a mean grammarian. Gra^maticus, ca, cu^, pertaining to
gra^mer. Grammatice loqui, to speak congruely. Grammatocyphon, he that
wrytethe on his knee. Grammatophylatium, the place where the records, or
commune writings be kept. Grammataeus, a chancellor. Gramme, a length
without breadth. Grammia, the fleume in the eyes. Gramen, grass: sometime all
herbs together, the swarthe. Graminosus, a, um, grown with grass or herbs.
Grando, dinis, hayle. Also a pushe like to a boil in the flesh, which
greueth a man when it is touched. Grandinosus, a, um, full of hayle.
Grandiuatus, ta, tum, hurt or wounded with haylle. Grandebalae, hears in the
arm holes. Grandis, grande, ancient, or great. Grandiusculus, la, lum,
somewhat great, or of good age, well stryken in years. Granditas, tatis, the
abundance of years, auncientie. Grandeuus, very old. Grandiloquus,
eloquente, he that speaks as it were with a greatte magnyfycence in words.
Grandiloquentia, a stately eloquence. Grandio, diui, ire, to make great. Grande
s^o, ere, to wax great. Granum, grain or corn. Granarium, a gray^arde,
wherein corn is kept. Graphis, phidis, the art of portraiture. Graphium, a
pensyll, wherewith men do write in tables. Graphicus, ca, cum, kunnyngly, or
perfectly wrought. Graphicus homo, a propre man. Graphice, proprely well, and
kunnyngly. Graphiarium, a case, wherein pensiles were kept, it may be called a
pennar. Grassator, he that by high ways, lies in awayt to rob or slay men,
an extorcioner. Grassor, aris, ari, to rob or slay men passing by the high
ways. Also to goo or come on one with a violent rage. Therefore in a sodayn and
violent pestilence, it is said, morbus grassatur, The sycknes kylleth me^
sodaynely. Gratia, grace, sometime it signifies thank, sometime a benefyte,
sometime reward* also peace or love, sometime cause or respect, also praise.
Gratus, ta, tum, thankful, pleasant, acceptable. Gratiosus, very thankful.
Also in favor, with the people, or well esteemed. Gratis, an aduerbe,
betokenynge without reward: sometime without deserte. Gratuitus, ta, tum,
without reward or vnhyred. Gratuito, an aduerbe sygnifienge, of good will,
without benefit. Grates, thanks. Gratificor, ari, to gratify, or do a
thing thankful, or to confer a benefit, or do a good turn. Grator, ari,
to give thanks to god with offrynges, also to rejoice of good fortune.
Gratulor, ari, with a dative case, to be joyous for him self or an other for
any good thing that has happened. Liuius.
Tibi de hac tua fcelicitate gratulor, I am joyous with the, or as glad as
thou art, of this prosperity that thou art in. Sometime it sygnifyeth to
give thanks unto god: but with an accusative case it signifies to take
thankfully any act. Grauis, grave, heavy, greuouse, sommetyme substancial,
grave, or having gravity, contrary to lyghtnes or wantonness, also great or
puissant, sometime old or aged, sometime sure or constent, sommetyme plentuous
or full. Terra grauts, land laded with corn. Grauiter, et grave, greuousely,
heuily, substancially, much, wisely, sadly. Grauatus, grieved. Grauedo, dinis,
heaviness, grief, disease. Sometime the mutre or reume of the heed.
Grauedinosus, he that has a heuye heed. Grauedinosus, a, um, that which
makes a heavy heed. Graueolentia, stenche or stynke. Grauo, aui, are, to grieve,
to burden, or lade. Grauor, ari, to be grieved, or to take grieuouselye.
Grauate, and grauatim, grievously, or displesantly, or paynfully. Grauesco,
scere, to be laded. Grauida mulier, a woman great with child. Grauido, are, to
get a woman with child. Grauastellus, aged. Grex, gregis, a flock, as well
of men, as of cattelle. Gregarius miles, a soldier taken at adventure, not
chosen. Gregarius pastor, the chief shepard, which has the charge of the
hole flock. Gregarius canis, a curre dog. Gregalis, le, cattle, which is
in the flock. Gregatim, in sundry flocks. Gremtale, an apron. Gressus, a
step, or goinge. Gressibile, apt to goo. Gressutus, ta, tum, idem. Grossus,
a, um, greatte. Grossi, green fygges. Grossuli, young fygges. Grossipion, seu
grossapinus, a tree, whereof comes cotton. Grossapina, cotton. Grus, gruis, a
Crane. Gruo, gruere, to cry like a Crane. Grumus, a barowe, or hyllocke.
Grumma, a thing, wherewith ground is measured. Grumia, a mydde place, from
whense goth four ways. Grunnio, ire, to grunt like a swyne. Grundio, idem.
Gryllus, a beast, more than a grassehoppe, which destroys corn. Gryphus, a
grype or gryffon. also a captious, an insoluble, or diffuse argument, a
ryddyll. Grypus, a nose rysynge in the myddell.
G, ante V.
GVla, the throat, sometime glottony. Gulosus, a glutton. Guliocae, the grene
shale of the wall nutte. Gummi, gu^me, which droppeth from trees. Gummatus,
ta, tum, dressed with gum or rased. Gummarae arbores, Trees that bryngethe
forth gum. Gumminum, oil made of gum. Gurges, gurgitis, a swallowe or
deep pyll in a water, or a goulfe. Gurgito, aui, are, to swolowe or devour.
Gurgulio, gulionis, the gully or gargylle of the throote, or throote bolle. It
is also a worm that bredeth in barnes, and eats up corn. Gurgustium, a
dark and vile habitation, a cabban or cotage. Gustus, tus, taste. Gustatus,
tus, idem. Gusto, aui, are, to taste. Guttus, a cruet, or other like thing,
out of the which lycour is poured dropping. Gutta, a drop. Guttatim, by
drops. Gutturnium, a lauer, or yewer. Guttur, gutturis, the thro^e.
Gutturosus, he that has a swollen throat.
G, ante Y.
GYgaeus, a laake of Lydie, Gygemorus, a little hylle, not far from
Thessalye. Gyges, the name of a king of Lydia, also a river of Lydia was
callydde by the same name. Gymnastes, he that teaches chylderne to exercise
them in wrastlynge, or other like. Gymnasium, a place, where is commune
exercise of the body. Sommetyme a schoolehouse. Gymnasticum, the art of
exercise. Gymnasiarches, the chief master of the schole or place of exercise.
Gymnosophistae, philosophers of Inde, which went always naked. Gymnici iudi,
plays exercysed naked. Gymnus, a beast, which commethe of a horse and an
ass mare. Gynoecium, a nourcerye. Gyneconitus, that part of the house, which
serves only for women. Gynephilus, a great lover of women. Gypsus, plaster.
Gypso, aui, are, to plaster. Gyrus, a cyrcute or compass. Gyro, gyraui,
gyrare, to compass or goo in cyrcuite. Gyttheum, a town, which Hercules and
Apollo, layenge there aside their strife and debate, builded together, and the
inhabytauntes of the same town are called Gyttlietes.
HABEO, MABVI, HAbere, to have, to hold, to possede or occupy, to esteem or
suppose, to call, to dwell, Pensi habere, to take heed. Frustra habere, to
deceive. Habere been seu male, to do or prosper well or ill. Been haber, it is
well. Res ita se habet, the thing is at this point. In custodiis haberi, to be
kept in prysone. Fortunas suas uenales habuit, he has sold all his goods.
Habeo tibi fidem, I put my trust in the. Habeo rationem, I have busynes, or I
have to do. Habere rem, to meddle with a woman. Habere rem cum aduersario, to
contend. Habere gratiam, to thank. Habeo audire, I can here. Habeo polliceri,
I can promise. Habet frustra, He is dysappoynted. Habitus, habitus, the
form or state of the body, sometime of other things, Also apparayle. Also it
sygnyfyethe a qualytie or propretie, which a man has conceived by
education, long exercise, or custom, habyte. Habitudo, dinis, the same.
Habitior, oris, more corporate. Habilis, le, hable. Habena, the rain of a
brydell. Habito, taui, are, to dwell. Habitaculum and habitatio, a dwelling
place or habitation. Hactenus, hitherto, so much. Hadrianopolis, a city in
Thracia. Hadrobalum, a kind of sweet smelling gum, that grows in Media.
H, ante Ae.
HAedui, people in France, which be now callid Burgonyons, and Burbonoyses.
Haedus, a kydde. Haedina caro, kyddes flesh. Haedile, a stable, wherein kyddes
be kept. Haedera, Iuye tree. Haederatius, ia, ium, of Iuye. Haematices, the
sanguinarie or blood stone. Haemonia, the country callid Thessaly.
Haemorrhois, a disease in the fundeme^t like teates or wartes, out of the
which issues bloudde, called emorrodes or pyles. Also a serpent, of whom if a
man be stryken, he bledeth to death. Haereo, haesi, haerere, to cleave or
stycke to a thing. sometime to doubt. Haeret in te omnis culpa, In the is
put all the blame. Haeresco, scere, to stick fast, or be thruste in.
Haesito, aui, are, idem quod haereo. Haeres, haeredis, an heir, or he, which
succedeth an other in his lands or goods. Haereditas, tatis, inheritance or
succession. Haereditarius, ia, ium, pertaining to inheritance. Bona
haereditaria, goods which do come by inheritance. Haeredipeta, crauers of
goods, flatteryng men to be their heirs. Haeredium, land, wherein a man has
a state of inheritance. Haeredidum, a lyttel inheritance. Haeresis, haeresios,
a sect, an heresy, an obstynate opynion. Haeresiarches, an arche heretic.
Haereticus, an heretic. Hagnus, a lamb. Hagnellus, a little lamb. Hagninus,
a, um, of a lamb. Halec, lecis, a fysshe called herryng. Also a sauce made of
fyshe. Halesius, a river not far from Aetna. Halialmon, a river of Macidon.
Halietus, an Egle, that haunteth about the sea. Halieutica, books contayninge
the properties of fyshes. Halimon, a thorn like to a white thorn, growing by
the sea side, and has leaves like to an olyue tree, but they be brother. Halo,
aui, are, to send forth savor. Halitus, breathe or vapor. Halo, the cirkle
or garlande about the Moon. Halicarnasus, a city in the less Asia.
Halophanta, a great liar. Halosis, the captivity. Halito, aui, are, to vapor
out. Halizones, people of Paphlagonie, so called because they are inuironned
about with the Sea. Hallucinor, ari, to be in a dream, to be deceived, to
err, or to take a matter wrong. Hamadriades, Nymphs or fayries of the woddes.
Hamus, a book. sometime a chain. Hamo, aui, are, to crook. Hamatus, mata,
tum, to be furnysshed with hooks. Hamiota, uel hamota, an angler or fyssher
with an angle or hoke. Hamatilis, le, pertaining to a hoke. piscatus
hamatilis, fysshynge with a hook, or anglynge. Hamonus, a, um, a color
somewhat read. Haphe, a color on the body, like to them that be leperous.
Hammon, onis, Jupiter in the egiptian tu^ge Harena, uide ante in arena.
Hariolus, a sothesayer. Harmonia, harmony or melody. Harpasa, a town of Asia.
Harp, a sword like to a sithe. Harpago, aui, are, to take by violence.
Harpago, ginis, a grapull of a ship. also a coupers instrument, wherewith he
dryueth on howpes, an addysse. Harpa, and harpax, acis, a grapelyng iron, for
to close ships together: also a poll with a hoke on the end, that shypmen
use. Harpocrates, the god of silence. Harpocratem reddere, to put one to
silence. Harpalice, a woman's name, the daughter of Harpalus king of Thrace.
Harpyiae, monstrous birds, having maidens vysages, and talons of a meruaylous
rapacitie. wherefore men that be ravenous, and great gatherers of goods, be
named sometime Harpy^ae. Haruspex, spicis, a dyuynatour, or tellar of things
to come by the lokynge in the bowelles of beasts. Also he, which observes
times in doing of things. Haruspicina, the art of him, which is a
dyuinatour. Haruspicium, the diuynation or telling of things to comme, by the
lokynge in beasts bowelles. H^^pis, pidis, the bowyng made like a cer^^^^ ^n
roufes of houses, or of a whele. H^^a, a spear. H^^^^pu^ae, were without iron:
and in the old time were given for a price to them that vanquished first in
battle. H^^ati, spear men. Ha^^le, a spear staff. H^^^a^ium, seliynge
under the standerde. Haitam abiicere, sygnifieth to leave suit, to despair of
the matter in variance. Hauicus ludus, reunnynge at the tylte with spears.
Haud, in no wise. Vergil^us.
Haurio, siui, iui, rii, ire, to draw or take out, to here, to see, to take a
thing gredylye, to wound, to fatigate or make weary, to make empty, to consume.
Haurire supplicia, to suffer punyshement or peynes. Haustus, tus, a draught in
drinking. Haustum facere, to drink. Haustrum, a bucket to draw water.
H, Ante E.
HEautontimorumenon, the name of one of the comedyes of Terentius, which is as
much to say, as tourmentynge him self. Hebdomas, madis, and hebdomada, ae, a
wike. Also the number of seven in days, years, or other time. Hebenus, a tree,
whereof the wod is black like geate, and it bears neither leaves, nor fruit.
Hebes, hebetis, dulle. Hebeo, and hebesco, ere, to be dull. Hebeto, aui, are,
to be dustre or made dark. Hebetudo, dinis, dullness, or duskyshenes.
Hebiones, of men in old time were callid poor folks. Hebraicus, Hebrician or
of Hebrewe. Hebron, a vyllage by Jerusalem. Hebrus, a river in Thracia.
Hecameda, the daughter of Arsinoi, which was given to Nestor for a gift.
Hecatombe, a sacrifice, wherein were killed a hundred beasts. Hecatompolis, a
country having an hundred cities therein. Hecatompus, he that has an hundred
fete. Hecate, a name of the moon. Hecta, the yexinge of a man. also a lyttelle
puff, which rises in breadde when it is baken. Hectica febris, the fever
that consumes. Hector, the son of Priamus. Hecyra, a mother in law.
Hedonius, expenses in voluptuous thingis. Heiulo, aui, are, to wayle, crienge
out. Heliocaminus, a place which is hette with the son. Helcium, the harneys
of carthorses, whereby they draw. Helenium, an herb commonly called Enula
campana, in english Helycampane. Heliopolis, a city in Grecia called also
Corinthus. Heliochrisos, an herb having a yelowe flower. A marygolde.
Helioscopium, a little tree like to a fygge tree, and has leaves like a
plane, but greatter and blacker. Helioselinum, an herb like to Smallage,
which grows in watery grounds, and has but one lease. Heliotropium, a
flower which in the son rysynge does open, and at the son set closes.
Some supposes it to be Marygoldes or ruddes. Helix, icis, of some men is taken
for a kind of wyllowe tree, of some men for yuie. Hellas, ladis, the country
of Greece. Helleborus, an herb, the rote whereof purges melancoly. Hellenes,
the son of Deucalion, of whom the Greeks were named Hellenes. Hellespontus,
an arm of the sea. which deuideth Greece and As^e. Heloi, in hebrewe
signifies god almighty. Helorus, a river in Sycile. Heluatia, a garment which
was used in Lidia, and was of the color of a cowes hyde. Heluela, small wortes.
Heluetii, people called Suycers, or Suyches, by desire of wars, enemies to
all mankind: subjects neither to god not to Prince. Heluo, onis, he which in
eating and drinkyng spends al his substance, a reueller. sometime a glutton
only. Heluo libroru^, an insaciable reder of books. Heluatio, revel, or
spending in riot. Heluor, aris, ari, to spend in riot. Heluolum, a color
between read and white like the color of clothe, called french tawnye.
Helxine, an herb, which has stalks somewhat read, and small burres on the
top, which do cleave fast unto clothes. Hem, an interiection of blaming,
disdaynynge, meruaylynge, or showing. Hemeridion, which dureth but one day.
Hemerodromus, a currour, which runs many miles in one day. Hemicranea, a
pain in half the heed, called the mygrim. Hemicyclum, a compass chair.
Hemicyclus, an half cerkle. Hemina, a measure of licour or corn, which may
now be taken for a pottell. Hemiola, gain of all, and half as much, as
of.iiii. s. be gotten.vi. s. Hemiolus, a proportion in Arithmetike, co^taynynge
the hole noumbre, and half that nombre: as one to three.xv to ten. Hemiomu^, an
herb good against all yexis. Hemis, half. Hemispherium, half the compass of
the visyble heaven or firmament. Hemistichium, half a verse. Hemitogium, half
a gown. Hemitritaeus, an half tercian fever, whose course is in every.xxxvi.
hours, or which has the course of a tercyan. Hemodes, certain isles in the
douche see. Hemerobius, one days sustynaunce. also a worm, which lives but
one day. Hemichorium, half a dance. Hemus, a mountain in Greece in the realm
of Thrace, which is six miles in height. Hendecasyllabus, a verse of a.xi.
syllables. Henula, a little chapel. Hepiolus, a fly like a butterflye,
which flies at night into the leame of a candell. Hepsema, must boiled to
the third part. Heptapolis, was sommetyme the name of Egypt, by reason of
seven cities, which first were in it. Hepthemimeris, where a syllable
naturally short, is made long in a verse, which does hap in the beginning
of the first foot. Hera, the name of Juno. Heraclea, a town in the co^fines of
Europa. Heraclee, a town very nere to Naples. Heracleon, an herb like to
Organum, it grows in watery places, and has a flower like a lylle: and when
the flower is fallen, it has a heed like popie. It is also an another herb
growing in plashes, having a little stalk, which excedeth not four
fyngers high, having a red flower, and leaves like Coriander: this herb
heals all wounds, if it be laid unto them. It is called Heraclion syderion.
Heracleotica nux, a wall nurte. Heraclides, the name of a philosopher.
Heraclitus, a philosopher, which always wept, when he beheld the people:
his warkes of a purpose were obscure ^ hard to be understand. Heraclius, the
name of an Emperor, it is also a touch stone. Herba, an herb. Also generally
all thing that grows on the earth, not being wod. sometime a wede. Herbam
dare aut porrigere, where a man yeldeth him, or confesses him self to be
vanquyshed. Herbula, a little herb. Herbosus, a, um, full of herbs or
grass. Herbaceus, a, um, of herbs or grass. Herbidus, a, um, idem.
Herbarius, he which knows the propreties of herbs, and makes medycynes of
them. Herbarius, ia, ium, pertaining to herbs. Herbare, to bring forth
herbs. Herbesco, ere, to make herbs or wedes. Herceus, one of the surnames of
Jupiter. Hercinia, a great wodde in Get many, which is in breadth.ix. days
journey. Herculanus, na, number, of Hercules. Hercules, the son of Jupiter and
Alcumena. Hercle and Hercule, an affirmative oath. Herculeius, a Romayne,
which favored the part of Marius. Herculeus, ea, eum, puissant or mighty.
Herebus, the depest place in hell. Heri, yesterday. Hericius, an yrchin or
hedgehogge. Herillus, a philosopher of Calcidonie. Herma, an image of
Mercurius. It is also an image, the heed whereof may be cha^gid. Hermae, be also
Images ferte or laid on Sepulchers. Hermathena, an image contaynyng the
figures of Mercury and Pallas. Hermaphroditus, the son of Mercurye and Venus.
Also he that is both man and woman. Hermerotes, small images, proprely of
little children with whynges. Hermes, is, and hermetis, Mercurye. Hermodo^cus,
a philosopher of Ephesie. Hermogenes, a propre name. Hermoglyphus, a grauer of
images. Hermon, a lyttelle hylle that standethe on Iordane. Hermopolis, the
name of a city that Hermes builded. Hermupoa, an herb called Mercury. Hermus,
a river, which in the mids, parts the fyldes of Smyrnee: and falling from
the hylle Dorylao, dyuideth Phrigia from Car^a. Hernia, the disease, whereof men
be called brosten: for that their bowels, or other matter, is fallen into their
coddes. Hernici, people in Campania. Hermosus, he that is brosten. Herodius, a
bird named a faucon. Herodes, the son of Antipater, which in the.x. year of
Augustus, was of the Romans declared king of Jews, and he reigned.xxxvii.
years. Heroida, a noble woman. Heroicus, ca, cum, noble, or pertaining to
nobleness. Herpeta, a terter. Hersilia, the name of Romulus wife. Herus, a
lord or master. Hesperia, Italy. Hesperia ultima, Spain. Hesperus, the weste
sterre. Hesperides, the three daughters of Atlas, which kept the gardens,
wherein grew the golden appuls, that were taken away by Hercules. Hesperidum
horti, the gardeynes, wherein were the golden appulies, now called Orenges.
Hesternus, na, number, of yesterdayes. Hestiaea, is a part of Thessaly says
Strabo, and Ptol. and in Homerus, it is a town in Euboea. Stephanus says, it
is a City in Acarnania. Heterogenus, na, um, of an other kind. Hetruria, the
country of Thuscan wherein the city of Florence is. Heu, alas. Heus, how.
Hexaclinum, a parlour, wherein six persons may soupe. Hexagonum, six
cornerde. Hexameron, of six days. Hexametrum, a verse of six fete.
H ante I.
HIarbas, the son of Jupiter, which was king of the Getulians. Hiacynthus,
an herb with a pourple flower, and has a round root. Hiacynthinae uestes,
garments of pourple color. Hiato, aui, are, to gape often. Hiatus, tus, a
gapynge. Hibiscus, an herb like to malowes, having a gretter lefe, and a heary
stalk, holyhok. Hic, this man. also here or in this place. Hiera, an isle
between Sicile and Liparis. Also the name of a way, of a womanne, the wife of
Thelaphus king of Misie. Hieranthemis, the flower of the herb Camamele.
Hierapicra, a medycyne to pourge flewme and cholere. Herapolis, a city in
Asia. Hierarchia, the holy governance, or principalytie. Hieri, people beyond
Sauromatas. Hierobotane, an herb called holy herb. Hieroceps, an isle in
Cyprus, nere to Paphus. Hierocomion, a laserhouse. Hieroduli, ministers in
temples and churches. Hierogliplicae, mystical letters or ciphers. Hieron, uel
hiereon, a chapel. Hierophanta, the declarer of mysteries or holy scripture.
Hierosolyma, Jerusalem. Hierotheus, the propre name of a man. Hila, a small
gutte or ars gutte. Hilaresco, scere, to be merry. Hilaria plurali, the.viii.
calendes of Aprile, when the day and night have equal hours. Hilaris, re, and
hilarus, merry, or joyous. Hilaritas, tatis, myrthe. Hilarious, the propre name
of a man. Hilaro, aui, are, to make one merry or joyous. Hilarodus, a synger of
a wanton and delycate song. Hilum, the little black, which is in the end
of a bean. It is sometime taken for nothing or naught. Himera, a river in
Sycile, divided into two parts, the oone fresshe water, the other salt. Hin,
a measure of the Jews, which contained of wine or water, the weyghte of
xviii. pound. Hinnio, iui, ire, to neygh like a horse. Hinnulus, a fawn or
hynde calfe. Hio, aui, are, to gape. Hippacen, chese made of mares milk.
Hippaco, aui, are, to fetch breath quyckely. Hippagium, carriage on horseback.
Hippago, ginis, a ferybote. Hipparclius, the master of the horses. Hippeas, a
kind of crabbe fyshe. Hippiades, images of womenne on horseback. Hippias, a
philosopher, which was expert in all sciences and crafts. Hippiatrus, an
horse leche. Hippo, mascul, genesis the name of.ii. cities. Hippocampae, fyshes
like horses. Hippocentaurus, a beast being half a man, half an horse.
Hippocomus, an horseskorcer. Hippocrates, the name of a phisytion most
excellent. Hippocrene, a fountain in Boeotia. Hippodame, mes, and hippodamia,
miae, the name of a woman. Hippodamus, a breaker of horses. Hippodromus, a
broad way, wherein many horses may run together. Hippoglotios, an herb called
Alexander. Hyppolytus, the son of Theseus, who at the complaynte of Phedra
his stepmother, was pursewed by his father, and he in a charyot fleing, was
overthrown among the sharp stones, and rent all to pieces. Afterward
Aesculapius reuyued him, and restored him to health. wherefore he would be
called Vi^bius, that is to say, twyse a man, forasmoche as he had twice
lived. Hippomachia, tournayenge on horseback and iustynge. Hippomanes, an
herb, whereof if horses bone eat, they forthewith rounne mad. It is also a
venomous humor, rounnynge out of the shappe of a mare, which if a man hap
to receive inward, he shall be mad. Plinius says, that it is a lyttelle
flesh in the forheed of a colte, when he is new foled, black, and as much
as a date, which the mare plucketh away with hyrrethe, as soon as she has
foled: and if any man do take it away before her, she never after will love her
fool. Hippomarathron, an herb like fenell, but having greatter leaves.
Hipponomus, a herd or keeper of horses. Hippopera, a maale or bougette.
Hippopodes, people in the Scythik occean which have fete like horses.
Hippopotamus, a beast living in the river of Nyle, having fere like an ox, his
back and mane like a horse, and neyeth like a horse, a wynding tail, and tusked
like a boore. Hipposelinum, an herb like parcely, and grows in dry
grounds, whereof horses do gladly eat. Hippotela, a fool of an ass.
Hippotoxata, an archer on horseback. Hippuris, an herb called in latin
Equisetu^, or cauda equina, in english, horsetayle. Her, Hiris, the palm of
the hand. Hira, the gutte, which is called Ieiunum. Hircipilus, a man that is
hear^e. Hircosus, a, um, that stynketh like a got. Hirquitalus, a child,
which passethe the age of.xiiii. years, and begins to be styrred with
lecherye. Hirquitallire, to enter into that age, or aptnes to lecherye.
Hircquus, the corner of the eye, also he that is gog^e eyed. Hirculus, a kind
of spikenarde. Hircus, a got bucke. it is also the rank savor, which issues
out of the arm holes. Hircinus, a, um, gotyshe. Hirrio, iui, ire, to narre
like a mad dog. Hirsutus, ta, tum, rough. Hirtus, ta, tum, idem. Hirudo,
inis, a horseleche, or blood sucker. Hirundo, inis, a swalowe. Hisciacus, he
that gapeth much. Hisco, sci, scere, to gape as one does for sluggishenes,
after sleep, or for lack of sleep. Also it is to proffre to speak, or open
the mouth to speak. Hismaelita, a farasyn. Hispalis, a city in Spain, now
callydde Sibyle. Hispania, a countreye in the weste part of Europa called
Spain, and was sometime callid Iberia, and Hesperia, and is inuyronned on the
southe part with the sea, callid Mare mediterraneum, which dyuydeth Europa
from Africa: on the north part with the sea called Mare Cantabricum, on the
weste with the great occian see with the mountains called Pyrenei, and the
royalme of France. And this country is divided by Pthelome into three regio^s,
Bethica^, wherein is Granado, Siuyle, Corduba. etc. Lusytania^, wherein is
Portugal, Galicia. etc. Tarraconenicin, wherein is Castyl, Lions, and Arragon.
At this time it conteyneth five relmes, Granado on the south part toward
Affrike, Portugal on the west, Galicia and Biscay on the north, Arragon on the
cast part, Castyl and Lions in the myddell. Hispidus, a, um, bristled or rough
heared. Historia, a storye. Historicus, a writer of stories. Histrio, onis, a
player in enterludes and stage players. Histrionicus, ca, cum, pertaining to
players. Histrix, icis, ^ beast having sharp pricks on his back, called a
porkpine. Hiulco, aui, are, to make to gape or chinke. Hiulcus, ca, cum,
gapynge, or chynked, as the ground to in a great drythe.
H Ante O.
HOc, this or that. Hodie, to day. Hododocus, a robber by the high way.
Hodoeporicum, a book to carry in journey, which may be called a iournall.
Hodoeporus, a trauayler by the way. Holocausium, proprely the beast, which
having his bowelles taken out, is laid hole on the altar and bourned.
Holographum, a testament all written with the hand of the testatour. Holor,
oris, a swanne. Holoserica uestis, a garment all of sylke. Holus, alias
Homolus, a hylle of Thessaly. Homeromasux, ticis, the reprocher of Homere,
generally Homeromastices, be taken for all reprochers, and false correctours of
learned men. Homerus, the poet of all other most famous and excellent, who
wrate the battle between the Greeks and Troyanes wonderful eloquently: but
how truly, wise me may coniect. Also he wrote the travail of the prudent
Ulysses. Finally both wor^^^ are worthy to be radde, for the marvelous
invention, and profitable sentences in them contained. Homicida, a murderer, a
mankyller. Homicidium, mourder, or manslaughter. Homilia, a Sermon. Homo, a
living creature, having capacity of reason, subject to death, a man,
woman, or child. Homocapnus, a man, which sits always in the smoke, or by
the fire. Homoeosis, a simylitude. Homogalactos, a foster brother. Homogenes,
of one kind. Homoglossus, of the same tongue or la^gage. Homoleum, a cappe of
the old facion. Homologia, a confession, consent or covenant Homomeria,
lykenes in partis or members Homonoea, the propre name of a woman, whereby is
signified concord. Homonymon, of like name. Homo triu^ literaru^, signified
sometime in mokage a man of a noble lineage, because noble men wrate their
forenames, Erasmus in Chiliad.
their names and surnames with three letters, as. P. Cor. Scipio, C.I. Caes. It
is sommetyme taken for a thief, because in Fur are but three letters. Homousios,
of like substance. Homosipyi, they which sleep together under one ruff.
Honestas, tatis, honesty. Honesto, aui, are, to reward with honor. Honestus,
ta, tum, honest. Honor, oris, honos, noris, honor, dignity, sometime
beauty, also reverence, honesty. Honorarium, a present given to ambassadors,
great officers, and justices at their first coming, or executing of their
autorities. Honorem praefari, to speak with reverence, as when a thing shall
be spoken, which is vile or dishoneste. Honoraria, plays made at Rome, to the
honor of Bacchus. Honorarius, ia, um, pertaining to honor. Honorificens,
honorificentior, honorificentissimus, a, um, using or doing things
honorably. Honorifico, aui, are, to do honor, or to honor Honorificus, ca,
cum, that brings honor. Honoro, aui, are, to honor. Honorus, a, um, that is
with honor. Hopistographi, rolls written on both sides. Hora, an hour.
Horaeum, summer honye. It is also a sauce made of fyshe. Horarium, the space of
an hour. Horda, a cow great with calfe. Hordearius, ia, um, pertaynyng to
barley. Hordeum, barley. Horestes, the son of king Agamemnon, which slew
his mother, because she conspired with Aegisthus her aduouterer, to slay his
father. Horia, a fyshers bote. Horizon, it is, a cerkle dyuidynge the half
sphere, or over part of the firmament, from the other half, where, to our
sight, it seems that the heaven touches the earth. Hormesion, a precious
stone of the color of fire. Horminode, a grene stone, compassed with a cerkle
of the color of gold. Hornus, na, um, of this years, Hagnus hornus, this
years lamb. Homae fruges, This years grain. Hornotinus, a, um, of one years
growing. Horologium, a dyall or a clock. Horomasdes, among the Caldees was
named the good god. Horoscopos, the diligent markynge of the time of the birth
of a child. Horoscopo, are, to mark the hour. Horoscopus, that part of the
firmament, which every hour rises from the cast, astronomers do call it the
ascendent. Horoscopus, pa, um, every, thing, wherein hours be marked.
Horrearius, the keeper of the barn. Horreo, rui, ere, when a man thinks that
his hear does rise, also to quake for cold or fear. sometime to fear much.
Horresco, scere, when a man feleth within him great cold or trembling to
begin, as in a fever, or in a greatte fear: Sum time to quake. Horreum, a
barn, wherein corn is laid. Sometime a store house, wherein any other thing
is kept. Horribilis, le, horrible or terrible. Horrificus, idem. Horridulus,
tymorous. Horridus, da, um, rough, also terrible. Horrifico, aui, are, to make
aferde. Horripilo, aui, are, to be rough. Horrisonus, na, sonum, having a
terryble sown or voice. Horror, oris, tremblyng for cold or fear, also
horryblenes. Hortatus, tus, exhortacyon. Hortensia, the daughter of Hortensius,
a woman most eloquent. Hortensius, an excellent orator of Rome, of a
wonderful memory. Hortor, aris, ari, to exhort. Hortus, a knotte gardeyne,
or a gardeyne for pleasure, or an orcharde. Horula, a little hour.
Hostomaticus, syckely. Hospes, hospitis, a geste, or mutual friends dwelling in
sundry countrays. also a stranger or a man, inhabiting out of the country.
Hospita terra, a country, whereby a man may peasibly pass. Hospitalis, le,
using a gentle entertaynement, or gladly receyuynge a stranger. Hospitor,
aris, ari, to receive frendely into his house. Hossimi, they that be borne
without nosethrylles. Hostia, an hooste or sacrifice offered to attain
vyctorie of ennemies. Hosticus, ca, um, hostyle, or enemy. Hostilis, le,
pertaining to an ennemy. Hostimentum, recompense, one for an other. Hostio,
iui, ire, to recompense, to assuage, or abate, to offend. Hostis, an enemy.
Hostium, a measure of a hundred and forty bushels. Also a door. Hostorium, the
staff, wherewith all measures be made even, a stryke.
H Ante V.
HVber, bera, berum, fruitful, or plentuouse. Huber, eris, a pappe or vdder.
Hubertas, tatis, plentye. Hubertim, plentuousely. Huberrime, very plentuousely.
Hubero, raui, rare, to make plentuouse or fruitefulle. Hubertus, ta, tum,
abundant or plentuous. Huc, hither. Huic, to that place. Also to him or her.
Hui, an interiection of scornynge. Huiusmodi, and huiuscemodi, such. Hulula, a
shriche owl. Hululo, aui, are, to howl. Humanitas, humanity or nature of
man. also doctrine, pertainynge to man. Humanitus, of men. Humaniter, gentylly.
Humanus, na, um, gentle, tractable, courteyse, merciful and frendely.
Humecto, aui, are, to make moist. Humeo, mui, ere, to be moist or wette.
Humesco, scere, idem. Humerus, the shoulder. Humidus, moist. Humigatus, wette.
Hum^^is, le, base, low. also simple or pore, abiecte, vile. Humilio, aui, are,
to make low, poor, or abiecte. Humilitas, tatis, baseness, or lowenesse,
humility, which as Speusippus defyneth, is a gentylnesse of the mind,
lackyng wrath or anger. Humo, aui, are, to burye, or hyde. Humor, oris, humor
or moisture. Humus, earth being moist. Humi, a low on the ground. Hunni,
people which came out of Scithia, and inhabyted Hungarye.
H Ante Y.
HYacynthus, is a precious stone, of the color of fine gold, which being
worn in such wise, that it touches the flesh against the heart, or the vain,
which comith from the heart into the left hand, preserves one from the
pestilence. It is also a purple flower, which has a round root, some do
suppose it to be called in english, flower gentle. Hyacinthina, were solemn
ceremonies done in the night. Hieronimus co^tra Iouinianu^
Hyapes, seven sterres, in whose rysynge and goinge down it always rayneth.
Hybrides, half wild. Hyalargus, a glasyer. Hyalus, glass. Hyalinus, glasye.
Hyberia, a region in Asia, joining to Armenie, enuyronned with the mountayns,
callid Cauca^^. It is also the old name of Spayn. Hyberna, places where men of
war do rest them in winter. Hybernacula, places prepared to winter in.
Hybernia, Irelande. Hyberno, aui, are, to make abode in winter. Hybernus, na,
um, pertayninge to winter. Hyberus, a greatte river in Spain, nigh to
Tarrhacon. Hyble, uel hybles, a city in Sycile, and a mountain nygh to it,
which does grow full of time: And therefore the honey, which is there, is of
all other most pleasant. Hybrida, is a dog, engendered betwyxte a hounde and
a mastyue, called a lymmar, or mongrell. Hybris, idis, a kind of hawks,
which seldom is seen in the day, but seeks his pray in the night.
Hydaspes, a great river in Indie. Hyderon, a disease, when the skin is filled
with water. Hydraulis, an organ player. Hydra, a water serpent. It was also a
monster, with whom Hercules faught: and as soon as he had stryken of one heed
of the monster, immediately sprange up an other. Hydram secare, to meddle with
an endelesse matter, or where after one myschiefe happens an another. Hydria, a
water pot. Hydrolapathon, water dockes. Hydromantia, divination in calling of
spirit (...) to appear in water. Hydromel, water and honey sodden together.
Hydropota, he that drinks always water. Hydrops, hydropis, the droppesy.
Hydrus, a water serpent. Hydruntes, a city in Calabria. Hyemo, aui, are, to
rest in the winter time. Hyems, winter. (...) de Animal.
Hyena, a beast like a wolf, which has a mane over all his back and neck,
but the hears be longer and harder. Hymber, a shower of rain or hayle. Hymen,
a skin in the secret place of a maiden, which when she is defloured, is
broken. Hymenaeus, was called the God of marriage. Hymera, the name of a river.
Hymettus, a hill by Athenes, where was honey of all other most precious.
Hymnus, a praise in a song. Hyoscyamos, an herb called henbane. Hypoepa, a
city, where were meruayllous fair women. Hypaetra, an aley in a gardayne, or
galerye without any covering. Hypagogeus, an Instrumente, wherewith stones are
polyshed. Hypanis, a river in Scythia. Hypata, a city of Thessaly.
Hyperaspistes, a protector, a great shield. Hyperbaton, a long dependynge, or
superfluous sentence. Hyperbole, excess in aduauncynge, or depressynge: As
higher than heaven, whyter than snow, swyfter than lyghtnynge, slower than a
snayle, warse than the dyuell. Hyperbolicus, ca, um, excedyng credence.
Hyperborei, people in the northeaste part of the world. Hyperthyrum, that
which is next over the browe of a man. Also sum say Hyperthyron, is a
transumpte or haunce. Hypercatalecticum metrum, where abounds one syllable or
two. Hyperion, the son. Hyphen, where diverse words be pronounced under one
accent, as qua^doquidem, utcunque* etc. Hypnales, adders, which styngyng a man,
he dies slepynge. Hypocaustum, a hot house or stewe. Hypocrisis, false
dissimulation, feigned holiness. Hypocrita, an hypocrite. Hypocondrium, the
inward part of the body above the nauil, and under the stomach.
Hypodidascalus, an vssher or substytute in teaching. Hypogeum, a place under
ground. Hypomnema, matis, an exposition or comment. Hypopodion, a foot
stool. Hypostasis, substance. it is also that, which does rise in vryne,
where there is good digestion, if the resydence be white, light, and rysynge in
facion like a pear, the small end upward. Hypothicos, a lynnen rochette.
Hypothyron, a groundsyll or thresholde. Hypothyra, seu hypothyrides, the door,
or rather the place open, where the door is. Hypozigia, all drawing cattle.
Hypsicratea, the wife of king Mythridates, which followed him in all his
wars, being armed like a knight. Hypsipile, a lady, which loved Jason, and
when he returned not at the time, which he promised, she threw her self
into the sea. Hypethra, an alaye to walk in. Hyrcania, a country in Asie.
Hysginum, a color like scarlette. Hysopus, and hysopum, an herb callydde
Hysope. Hysterologia, and hysteron proteron, a manner of speaking, where the
last is set before the first, and as it is said, the cart before the
horses.
IACCHVS, one of the names of Bacchus, called god of wynes. Iaceo, cui, cere,
to ly. sometime to be. In medio ca^pus iacet, Salustius.
In the middel is a feld. also to be deed. Ille iacet, Lucanus. Cic. de sinibus.
he is deed. sometime to be conte^ned or naught set by, Maximas uero uirtutes
iacere necesse est, uoluptate domina^te, Carnal dilectation ruling, needs must
excellent virtues be nothing set by. Iacio, ieci, iacere, to throw, cast, or
shoot, sometime to set or lay. Iacere fundamenta, to lay the foundation.
Iacobus, a propre name. Iactanter, bostyngely. Iactantia, booste. Iactatio,
idem. Iactito, taui, tare, to boste often. Iacto, aui, are, to throw, to
reuolue, or toss in the mind, to vex, to throw down and beat, to auaunt
or glory, to speak vaynly, to set forth, to toss, to cast out. Iactuose,
braggyngly. Iactura, damage or loss, proprely as when a man has much goods
in a ship, and by force of tempest, is constrained to throw it into the sea,
lest the ship should perish. Iaculatio, iaculamen, and iaculame^tum, a shot,
or cast with a darte, or iauelyn. Iaculo, aui, are, to shoot or cast far.
Iaculor, aris, idem. Iaculum, any thing that may be shot or cast far,
most commonly a dart or light iauelyn. Iaculus, a serpent, that lies under
trees, and suddenly with a meruaylous vyolence perceth any beast, which
happens to pass by him. Iam, now. Iambus, a foot in meter, which has the
first syllable short, the other long. Iam diu, long agone. Iamdudum, now
late, but a while sens. Iamiam, even now. Iam olim, now late. Iampridem, a
little while paste, but late. sometime forthewith. Iam tum, fro that time.
Ianiculum, a town not far from Rome. Ianira, the daughter of Ocean and
Tethis. Ianitor, toris, a porter. Ianthina, violet color, or purple. Ianua, a
door or yate. Ianuarius, the month of Ianyuer. Ianus, some suppose to be
Saturn, some to be Iaphet, one of the sons of Noe. Cicero calls him the
superior world, or heaven, he was made having two visages, either because the
heaven tournynge, the year retourneth, where it began: orels because it
knows what is passed, and aforeseeth what shall happen. This god, or rather
ydoll, had a temple in Rome, which in the time of wars was always open, and in
the time of peace was shut. And therefore when in stories mention is made,
that the temple of Ianus was shut, than is it to be understand, that the
Romans had peace universally. Iapetus, the father of Prometheus. Iapigia, a
country in the realm of Naples. Iapix, gis, a wind, which comes out of the
parts of Apulia, and is a western wind. Jason, onis, he which first
conquered the Fleece of gold. Iaspis, pidis, a stone called Jasper.
Iatraleptes, a physician or surgion, which cures with oyntmentes.
Iatraleptice, curing by oyntmentes.
I Ante B.
IBerus, a river in Spain. Iberia, the ancient name of Spayn, also an other
country nigh to Armeny. Iberi, and Iberes, Spanyardes. Ibi, there. Ibis, a
foul or bird of Egypt, which is high, and has stiff legs, and a long
byl. They profytte much to the countreye in kyllyng and eating serpents,
which out of Libia be carried into Egypt, with a sowtherne wind. Also it is
taken for an enuyous person.
I Ante C.
ICaria, an isle in the sea Icario, which is also called Icaros. Icarus, the
father of the chaste Penelope. There was also an other Icarus, which was the
son of Dedalus, who having wings, with his father flewe out of the isle of
Crete: but when he flewe higher than his father commanded him, the wax,
wherewith the feathers of his wings were glued, being molten with the heat of
the sun, and the feathers falling of, Icarus was constrained to fall into the sea, which was afterward callid Mare Icariu^. Also Icarus is a mountain in the
regio^ of Athenes. Ichneumon, a beast in Egipte, of the greatness of a catte,
and is facioned like a mous, who crepeth into the body of a Cocodryl, when he
gapeth, and eatinge his bowels, sleeth him. It is also a kind of waspes.
Ichnographia, an instrumente like a compass, wherewith are made the
descripcyons of the son. Ichnusa, the isle now called Sardinia. Ichthiocolla,
fyshe glewe. Icthybolus, a fysher. Icthyophagi, people which do live by
eating of fyshe. Icthyopola, a fishmonger, or seller of fish. Icthyopolion, a
fyshe markette. Icthyotrophia, a ponde or stewe, wherein fyshes be fed. Ico,
ici, icete, ictum, to stryke. Icona, uel Icon, an image. Iconicus, ca, cu^, so
painted or fourmed, that in every membre the very similitude is expressed.
Iconismus, a description. Iconium, a town in the countreye of Capadocia, an
other in Asie the less. it is also a man's own image like him self. Icteros,
a sycknes called the Iaundise. Icterus, a bird called a yelowe hamer.
Ictericus, he that is disesed with the Ia^dis. Ictis, idis, a white wesyll,
which destroys be stalles, and eats the honey.
I Ante D.
ID, that, Id quod res est, which is troth. Id aetatis, of that age. Ida, a
mountayn, which lies nigh Troy. Ide^ dactili, people called also Corybantes.
Ideus, a, um, of the mountain of Ida. Id^^ium, a city in the isle of Cypres.
Idalus, a mountain and a wodde in Cypres. Idaspes, a famous river, which
passes by Parthia and Inde, wherein is golden gravel, and precious stones.
Idcirco, therefore. Idea, a figure conceived in ymagynation, as it were a
substance perpetual: and like as of one seal proceeds many pryntes, so of
one Idea of a man proceeds many thousands of men, and semblably of other
Ideas proceeds things innumerable. So that Ideae, be as it were eternal
examples, whereby all other things be created: and this is Idea, whereof Plato
speaks. Idiopathia, the propre passion of a disease. Idem, the same thing,
or the same man. Identidem, eftesones, in the same wise. Ideo, for that cause.
Idicus, ca, cum, of the mountain of Ida. Idiographum, a private writing.
Idiographae literae, a private letter. Idioma, matis, a propre form of speech.
Idiota, Idiotes, a man or woman unlearned. Idolatra, a worshypper of idolles.
Idololatria, ydolatrie. Idolium, a little ydoll. Idolothysia, offrynges to
ydols. Idolothytum, that which is offered to idols. Idolum, an ydoll. Idoneus,
ca, eum, apt. Idula, a sheep that was offered every Idus to Iupyter. Idumaea, a
regyon in Syria, ioynynge to Egypt, and bordereth upon Palestina. Idus, Ides
of months, which do divide Honas from Calendes.
I Ante E.
IEcur, coris, and iecinoris, the liver of a man, or other thing living.
Iecusculum, a little liver. Ie iunium, fasting. Ieiuno, aui, are, to fast or
absteyne. Ieiunum, the gutte, which goth down to the fundement. Ieiunus, he
that is fasting. Ientaculum, a breakefaste. Iento, aui, are, to eat meat
before dinner.
I Ante G.
IGitur, therefore, from hensforth, afterward. Ignauia, cowardenesse. Ignauus,
a, um, cowarde. Ignifacio, eci, facere, to set on fire. Ignesco, scere, to be
set on fire, or to be made fire. Ignarium, any thing, out of the which
fire may be beaten. Ignia, certain fautes, which erthen pottes have in the
inealynge. Igniculi, are certain prouocations, naturally given to embrace
virtue. Igniculus, a sperke of fire. Ignio, iui, ire, to inflame. Ignipotens,
one of the surnames of Vulcanus. Ignis, the fire. Sometime it is taken for an
harlotte. Ignis sacer, a sore, wherein is an exceeding inflammation and burninge.
Ignitabulum, a fire pan. Igniuomus, he that spytteth fire: the son is
sometime so called. Ignobilis, le, unnoble, unknown, foolyshe, of none
estimation. Ignominis, without renoume. Ignominia, reproach, infamye.
Ignorabilis, le, unknown. Ignoro, aui, are, to know not. Ignarus, ignorant,
without knowledge. Ignorantia, ignorance, lack of knowledge, and is referred to
the wit of the perso^ne. Ignoratio, lack to be known, and pertains to the
thing or act. Ignosco, noui, noscere, to learn and know perfectly. Also to
forgive, to have excused to know not, or be ignorant. Ignotus, unknown, also
ignorant.
I Ante L.
ILa, the leeste porcyon of a thing, that may be imagined. Also the stuffynge
of a puddynge, or other like thing. Ila, or Ilua, an ylande in the Tuscayne
see. I Will, is that which is set in the highest part of a man. Ileosus, the
colycke, and he that has the colycke. Ileos, the colycke. Ilex, licis, a tree
called holy, or holme. Ilia, the guts. Iliacus dolor, the frettynge of the
guts. Ilias, adis, the warke of Homerus, of the syege of Troy. Iliberis, a
city in the province of Narbone. Iliceus, a, um, of holy or holme. Iligneus,
a, um, idem. Ilione, the propre name of a daughter of Priamus. Ilioneus, the
propre name of a Troyane. Ilissus, the name of a river in the prouynce of
Athenes. Ilium, the palais of Priamus. Illaetabilis, le, without myrthe, or
lacking myrthe or pleasure. Illatebro, aui, are, to hyde in corners.
Illaudatus, not worthy to be named. Ille, he. Illecebrae, things dilectable,
which draws and allurethe the mind to embrace them, flyckerynge
intycementes. Illecto, aui, are, to draw pleasantly. Illex, illegis, lawless,
also wanton. Illex oculus, a wanton eye. Illibatus, ta, tum, untouched,
untasted. Illiberaliter, vngentillye, excedyngely ylle, myscheuously. Illicet,
now go to, incontinent. Illiceo, illicui, cere, to provoke or styre
pleasauntlye. Illectus, ta, tu^, plesantly stired or provoked. Illicium, a
provocation. Illico, anon, in the same place. Illido, lisi, dear, to drive or
beat to a thing. Illisus, a, um, driven or beaten to. Illineo, iui, ire, to
anoynte on. Illino, iui, ire, to annoynte hard, to spotte or soil. Illix,
licis, a provocation or styringe. Illuceo, xi, cere, and illucesco, scere, to
be light or clear. Illudo, si, ere, to mock, to hurt in iapyng, or playenge.
Illuminus, a, um, without light. Illunis, dark, when the moon does not shine
Illustris, famous, clear, noble in renoume. Illustro, aui, are, to make light
or clear, to make famous or well known. Illuuies, uncleanness, fylthynesse
in manne or garment. Illiria, a country now called Slauonye, which has on
one part Italy, on an another part Germany, on the east side Greece, on the
weste the Venyce see. Illiricus, ca, cum, of Illiria. Ilus, the king of
Troyanes son, that builded Ilium.
I Ante M.
IMaginarii, baner bearers, wherein be images painted. Imaginatus, ta, tum,
fygured or fourmed into an image. Imagino, naui, nare, to make images, or to
counterfayte. Imaginor, aris, ari, to imagyne. Imago, imaginis, an image, a
symylitude, Vergilsus.
a shethe, or case. Imaguncula, a little image. Imaus, a mountain in Judea.
Imbecillis, le, and imbecillus, a, um, feeble. Imbecillitas, tatis, feblenesse.
Imbellia, cowardyse. Imbellis, le, unapt to wars, cowarde, or weak. Imber,
a shower. Imberbis, be, beardelesse. Imbibo, by, bear, to drink in. Imbrex,
bricis, a spowte or gutter, out of the which rain is conuayed from the
house. It is sometime taken for the tyle or slatte, that lies on the house.
Imbricium, the covering or eueisynge of the house. Imbrico, to cover with
tyle, or other like thing. Imbricosus, a, um, full of gutters. Imbrus, an
Island of Thrace, and a town in the same is so called. Imbrifer, bryngyng
showers. Imbubino, aui, are, to defyle with menstruous flyxe. Imbulbito, taui,
tare, to defyle with chyldes dyrte. Imbuo, bui, buere, to dye clothe or sylke,
to teach. Imitor, aris, ari, to follow the exaumple of an another. Immanis, ne,
cruel, great, horrible. Immanitas, tatis, cruelty, greattenes. Immineo, nui,
nere, to procure, to endeavor Imminuo, nuere, to cut of. Salustius in c^.
Catil.
Imminuere ius, to defalcate or mynyshe the authority or state of a person.
Immissum, laid in to abide, as a beam of a house, or other like thing.
Immitto, misi, immittere, to send in. sometime it sygnifieth to let grow in
length. Neque barbam immiseris istam, Lucilius lib 3 V^^g ^^ne. lib. ^.
Neither let this berde grow in length. Respicimus dita illuuies, immissaque
barba, we beheld, O what an horrible fylthynesse and a bearde grown in
length. Also to bring or send on the contrary part. Lact. li. 4.
Hoc futurum esse dixerunt, ut post breue tempus immitteret deus regem, qui
expugnater Iudaeos, It should come to pass said they, that god should send
to the contrary part a king, which should vanquyshe the Jews. ^
Alij Tarquinium a Cicerone immissum aiebant, ne C^a^ius, suscepto malorum
patrocynio rempub. turbater, Some said, that Tarquine was brought in craftily
by Cicero, lest that Crasius, in taking on him the defense of mysdoers, should
thereby bring sedicyon into the weal publyke. Immo, but rather, ye rather.
Immolo, aui, are, to offer in sacrifyce. Immutus, exempt, without office or
charge Imminutas, tatis, fraunches or liberty. Immunitus, ta, tum, not
defended. Impago, ginis, a tenon, which is put into the mortals, also a pynne,

never offends. Impedimentum, let, impediment in wars. Impedimenta, is the
caryage and trasyke, that goth with the hooste. ^
Impedio, diui, dire, to let, to stay, or supporte, to defyle. Impeditus, is
proprelye he, that has his fere so bound, that he can not goo. Impedo, aui,
are, to vndersette. Impello, puli, pellere, to persuade instantly, to enforce,

expenses. Impense, pro ualde. Est impense improbus, he is a very ill man.
Impensius, exceeding, more greuouse, or displeasunt. Impensibilis, without
consyderation. Imperator, the chief captain in wars, now, the emperor.

stately, rigorousely. Imperitabundus, full of rule, or ruling much. Imperitia,
lack of knowledge. Imperitus, not expert, easy to be deceived. Imperito, aui,
are, to rule or govern. Imperium, a solemn commandment, a preeminence in

to detayne. Implicat ad speculum caput, she bound up her heed at a glass.

false ware for good. Imposturam facere, to deceive in manner aforesaid.
Impotens, tentis, he that can not resyste his appetite or affections. sometime

also inability to resyste. Impraesentia, and impraesentiatum, at this time, or
for this present time. Imprecor, aris, ari, to desire, to wyshe. Impressio,

defaulte. Impropero, aui, are, to imbrayde a man with some defaute.

sometime very circumspect. Impubes, and impuber, a man child before the age

mum, the lowest or most low.
I Ante N.
IN, sygnifieth in. Also In rempub. toward the publyke weal. In meam partem,
on or for my part. In particidam, against a murderer. In nauem ingreditur, he
went into the ship. also it sygnifieth space of time. In noctem, unto night. In
lucem, until day* also for. Vergilius.
In magno munere, for a great reward. In diem addicere, to fell upon condicon,
that a thing be done by a day. In dies singulos, day by day. In horam, for
oone hour. In horas, from hour to hour. In manu uel manibus est, It is in
his power, at hand, or easy, or in hand. In manum dari, to be given a part
or severally. In medium afferre, to bring forth to a common use or commodity.
In mentem uenire, to come to mind, or remembrance, to be considered. In
numerum, in order. In ordinem ducere uel cogere, to bring down from
authority, to mynysshe estymation or power. In posterum, finally, in
conclusyon. In re tua, for thy profit. In rem praesentem uenire, Budeus.
where the lands in debate comes in view, by the assignement of Iuges, unto
them which be called viewers, which shall see the bounds and quantity of
the land in variance. In spem uenire, to begin to hope. In rem praesentem
producere, Plinius in epist.
to bring the matter to light, to express the thing perfectelye. In re
praesenti, in a plain and evident matter. Quintii.
In tempore, in season, oportunately. Inaccessa, an ylande of Egypt, to the
which is no coming. Inachus, the first king of Argiues. Inanescere, to be
vain, and of none estymation. Inaniloquus, a bablar. Inanimus, ma, um, without
soul. Inanio, iui, ire, to make emptye. Inanis, inane, empty, vacaunt, ydell,
light in estimation. Inanitas, and inanitio, emptynes, voydenes. Inaresco,
scere, to dry up. Inarime, an isle in the Tuscayne see. Also a mountain.
