Innato, aui, are, to swymme in a place. Innocuus, a, um, vnharmefull, he that
does none harm. Innotesco, sci, scere, to be known. Innoxius, a, um, wherein
is no damage, that which can do none harm. Innumerato, in a redynesse. Innuo,
nui, ere, to grant or assent with noddynge of the heed. Ino, the name of
Cadmus daughter, the wife of Athamas king of Thebans. Inocco, aui, are, to
harowe in. Inoculo, aui, are, to greffe. Inodorus, without sauoure. Inolesco,
sci, scere, to wax great. Inopiosus, a, um, needye. Inops, pis, poor,
lacking help. Also unburied. Inora, beasts without mouths. In posterum, at
the last, in conclusyon. Inprimis, specially, principally, chiefly. Inquies,
quietis, and inquietus, ta, tum, vnrestefull, vnquyete. Inquieto, aui, are, to
vnquyete or trouble. Inquilino, inquilinaui, quilinare, to dwell in a strange
place. Inquilinus, he that dwells in a place, where neither he, nor his
auncetoures were borne. Inquino, aui, are, to defyle or polute. Inquio, I say.
Inquiro, siui, quirere, to inquyre. Inquisitius, more intentifely, more
inwardly Insanio, iui, ire, to be mad or peuysshe, to dote, to do
unadvisedly. Insanus, mad, peuyshe, doting, regarding no counsel, froward,
intractable. Insania, madness, peuyshenes, dotage, frowardenesse. Inscitia,
ignorance. Inscius, a, um, ignorant. Inscienter, ignorauntly. Inscribo,
scripsi, scribere, to write in or upon, to name or entitle. Inscriptus, a, um,
unwritten, written upon, named, or entitled. Insecta, be all flies and worms,
that be divided in their bodies, the heed and breaste from the bealy and tail,
as bees, waspes, emotes, or pismeres, and such like. Insequor, eris, sequi, to
follow or pursue. Insero, serui, rere, insertum, to set in, to ioyn. when it
has inseui, insitu^, it sygnyfyeth to greffe. Inserto, aui, are, to set to.
Insertorium, the bond or thonge, wherewith a tergat or buckeler is hanged on a
man's arm. Inseruio, uiui, ire, to serve. Insideo, es, sedi, sidere, to sytte
on, to sytte in, or be in, to besiege, to abide in a place. Insidiae, wiles to
entrap a man, er he be ware. Insidior, aris, ari, to practyse wyles, to
intrappe or betray a man. Insidiosus, a, um, full of wyles. Insidiose, wylyly,
craftily. Insido, is, sidi, ^e, to enter to thinte^t to abide. Insignia, signs
or tokens of honor, whereby every astate or great authority is known, as
robes, maces, swords borne upright, cappes of mayntenaunce, and other like
things. Also sometime tokens of doctrine and virtue: as staves typped with
silver, which bedels bear before doctors, hodes furred, crowns of laurel.
etc. Insignio, iui, ire, to note with sum sign. Also to doubbe knights.
Insignis, ne, notable, excellent, marked with some special token to be known.
Insigne, a notable sign or token. Insignite, and insigniter, notably. Insilio,
liui, ire, to leap in or up. Insimul, together. Insimulo, aui, are, to accuse
or appeal, also to feign or dissemble. Insimulatio, an accusation or appeal.
Insinuatus, a, um, wound together. Insinuo, aui, are, to bring into, to
conioyne, to put in a man's mind covertly and craftily. Insinuatio, a colorable
and crafty beginning of an oration, dissembling some thing. where the matter may
not be favorably herd. Insipidus, a, um, unsavory. Insipiens, entis, without
discretion. Insisto, institi, insistere, to set fast and fyrmely, to endeavor,
to provoke or solicit. sometime to assyst. Insitio, onis, greffyng. Insititium,
the stock. Insitium, the greffe. Also a iegot or other like meat stuffed with
flesh and eggs chopped or mynced. Insitiuus, ua, uum, infarcyd or stuffed.
Insolens, not wont or accustomed, haut, arrogant, presumptuous. Insolentia,
seldomnes of use in any thing. vnhauntynge of a place. Also presumption wanton
pride. Insolitus, not wont. Insolo, aui, are, to dry in the son, to blech.
Insolatus, a, um, sunned. Insolatio, a sonnyng. Insomnia, ae, lack of powar to
sleep. Insomnium, a vain dream. Insomnes noctes, nyghtes without sleep.
Insomniosus, slepy, or he that slepith much. Insons, insontis, innocent, or not
gyltie. Insonus, a, um, without noise. Inspectius, more aduysedly. Inspecto,
taui, tare, to behold attentively* to wait on. Inspicio, spexi, cere, to
behold, to ouersee, to control, to consider a thing thoroughly. Inspectio, a
beholdynge, an ouersyghte, Cicero. Ti. Liuius
a controllemente. Inspector, an ouerseer, a controller. Inspico, aui, are, to
make a thing small, like to a wheat reed. Inspiro, aui, are, to inspire, to
blow in. Instans, it is, an instant, the least part of time. Instantia, things
that be present. Instanter, instantly. Instantia, diligence. Instar, as it were
or like. Instatio, the instant time. Instauro, aui, are, to new make, or begin
any thing. sometime to renew or reform, to reedify Instat, it is nigh, it is
com, it is at hand. Caesar ubi se diutius duci intellexit, et die^ instare, qua
die frumentum militibus metiri oportebat, wha^ Caesar perceived that he was
delayed, and the day. was nigh come, when he must needs deliver corn to his
men of war. Insterno, straui, sternere, to cover, to sprede. Instrata,
trappers of horses. Instratu^, a cou^terpoynt. also it signifies all tapisry,
which serves to cover any thing. Instigo, inxi, gere, to meue inwardely.
Instinctus, inwardly meued. Instigo, aui, are, to stere or prick forward.
Instita, a purfyll. Instito, aui, are, to repugne, or withstand. Institor,
oris, a chapman, a mercer, also he that sells apparayle and fine stuff,
goinge about therewith. Institorius, ia, ium, pertaynyng to chapman. Instituo,
tui, tuere, to institute, to begin, to instruct or teach, to ordain.
Institutiones, instructions in doctrine. Institura, ancient manners and customs,
also ordinances. Pro meo instituto, for my purpose. Insto, as, instiri,
instare, to require instantely, to solicit, to stycke to, to resist, to
persist, to prease on, to come on, or immediately follow. Instat, it is now.
Instratum, the trappier or apparayle of an horse, a horseclothe. Instrumentum,
an instrument or tool. Also ordinance of war, vessel and all necessaries of
household and husbandry. sometime it signifies a deed or charter, concerning
land dettes or couenantes. Instruo, xi, struere, to set in order or array, to
instruct, to fournyshe, to prepare. Insubres, lumbardes, proprely men of the
duchy of Melayne. Insucco, aui, are, to soke in lycour. Insuesco, sueui, scere,
to be wont. Insuetus, ta, tum, not used. Insula, an i will inuiro^ned with water.
It is also a house in a town, having none other house joined to it, but streets
on every side of it. Insularis, re, belongyng to an isle. Insularius, a, um,
most vile, proprely men banyshed into Isles to dygge metal. Insulatus, ta,
tum, made an isle. Insulto, taui, tare, to leap up, to scorn or speak in
the reproach of a man. Insultura, a leaping up or into a thing. Insum, inesse,
to be in some thing. In summa, universally, always, finally. Augustinus
Insummo, are, to fynyshe. Insumo, psi, ere, to spend or lay out money.
Insuper, furthermore, moreover. Insusurro, aui, are, to whisper in ones care.
Integer, gra, grum, if it be spoken of age, it signifies young and lusty: if it
be spoken of a man it signifies honest in all points and qualites, in a thing
it sygnyfyeth entier or hoole. Integer aeui, lustye of age. Integrasco, sci,
scere, to be renewed. Integro, aui, are, to begin again, to renew. Integrum
mihi est. It is in my power, or at my pleasure, at mine arbiterment.
Intellectus, understanding. Intellectualis, of understanding. Intelligibile,
that may be understand. Intelligo, lexi, ligere, to understand.
Intelligentia, the perceyuyng of the mind. Intemerara, perfect sacryfyces,
all things observed. Intemperiae, goddesses, having power to do harm.

all thing is in silence. Intempestas, taris, the caulme of the water, Salustius

when there is no tempeste. Intempestiuus, ua, um, thing out of time or
season. Intempestiue, untimely. Intendo, di, dear, to bend or stretche. Also

Intendere animu^, to set or fix the mind. In tenebris saltare, signifies to
do a thing unadvisedly, and without any judgment. Intentatus, not assayed.
Intentio, signifies not intent or purpose, but for the act that is appointed
or executid. Intento, aui, are, to menace. Intentus, ta, tum, set or fyxed.
Inter, between, among. Inter sacrum et saxum, in the point to peryshe and be
utterly lost. Interamna, a city in Italye. Interaneus, a, um, that which is
within. Interanea, the inwardes of man or beast. Interaresco, sci, scere, to be
dried up. Interbibo, by, bear, to drink all out. Intercalaris, re, and inter
calarius, a, um, put or set between. Intercalaris dies, the day of the leap
year. Intercalo, aui, are, to set or put between. Intercalaris mensis, the
month, in the which certain days were set, that lacked to make the year
complete, which month is Februarye. Intercalaris uersus, a syngular verse,
often repeted among other verses. Some do call it, in english balades and
songs, the foot or refrette of a ditie. Intercapedo, dinis, a space or pawse.
Intercedo, cessi, cedere, to make intercession. also to go between, or be
between. Intercedit mihi tecum amicitia, There is amite between the and me.
Tribuni intercesserunt, The tribunes did let or prohibit. Intercessio
Tribunorum, a let or prohibition of the Tribunes against the authority of
other officers. Intercido, cidi, re, to cut aso^der in ye middis. Vide Cale
pinum.
Intercisa and porrecta, cut of and made longer. Intercido, cidi, ere, to

unware, to take in the mids, or in the mean while, sometime to take all.

is an adjective it signifies inward. Intercutibus uitiis madentes, ouerwette
with inward vices. Intercutaneus, ea, eu^, that is within the skin. Interdico,
xi, cere, to prohibit greuousely: also to resyste or let. Interdictum, a
prohibition. Interdiu, in the day time. Interdum, sometime. Interea, in the
mean while, also never the less. Interea loci, in the mean space. Intereo,
ru, ire, to dye utterly. Interitus, death. Interequito, aui, are, to ride
between. Interest mea, tua, sua, nostra, uestra, it behooves me, the, him, us,
you, or it pertains to me, the, him, etc. also it makes matter, or is a
diversity. Nihil interest tui, It is no matter to the. Si nihil interest
regis, peto ut dum dico, uinculis liberer, If it be no matter to the king. I
pray you, whiles I do speak, let me be without gyues. Sometime it signifies
to be in the mids. Inter^oemineu^, a woman's privy toke^, whereby she is known
from a man. Interfici, feci, to slay. Interfluo, xi, ere, to flow between.
Intertundo, fudi, fundere, to pour between. Intergerimus, a wall added to an

Interi, they that be within. Interiaceo, cui, cere, to put between, to cast

Interimo, emi, imere, to kylle. Interior, and interius, the inner. Interiungo,
ere, to tarry. Interlino, inere, to enterline. Interloquor, eris, qui, to speak

Intermedius, a, um, in the myddell. Intermestris luna, the new moan at the

ask or demand. Interpensiua, certain pieces of timber, which are set

water into the spoutes. Interpensiui parietes, walls, which rise upon an
other wall, and have no fundacion in the ground. Interpola, new inventions,

to promise upon the credence and consent of all the people. Interpremo, to

Interrogati legibus, to be tried by examination, that they had offended

Intersono, are, to make noise in the mids or between. Interspiro, are, to
spring up in the mids. Intersterno, to straw between, or throw things
between. Interstitium, a distance or space between. Intersum, interesse, to be
present. also to differ, to be diverse. Stulto intellige^s quid interest? What
diversity is there between a fool and a wise man? Intertextus, a, u^, woue^ or
wrought between. or ^inselde, as cloth of tinsyl, or bawdekyn. Intertrigo,
ginis, gallynge, which happens by the occasion of sweat between the legs,

are, to be vacant or void between Interuallum, a space between. Interuello,

Interuerro, re, to take away craftily or falsely. Interuiso, ere, to visit
among, or now and tha^. Interula, a shyrte or smock. Intestabilis, he which
by the law can make no testament. sometime it signifies detestable. Intestatus,
he that dies without making any testament, intestate. Also he that dies
making none heir by testament. also a man out of credence, whom no man
will take for a witness. Intestina, the bowelles, or inward part of man, or
other thing living. Intestinum bellum, where people do war within their
own realm. Intestinum odium, hate with heart and mind, mortal hatrede.
Intestinum opus, the inward building of timber and pargette. Intingo, xi,
gere, to deep, as one does his finger into lycour. Intorqueo, si, quere, to

in. Intra, within. Intra modum, less thanne a mean, short of a mean. Intra
fama^, les tha^ the opinion that me^ have. Interius, more inward. Intimus,
most inward, most secret. Intrarius, idem. Internus, na, number, which is
within. Intrico, are, to wrappe. Intrimentum, damage either to the gyuer, or to
the receyuour. Intrinsecus, within. Intritus, brayed in a mortar. Intro, into a

unsure. Intybum erraticum, cicorie or white endive. Galenus. Plinius. Columel.
Inuado, si, re, to invade, to enter, to app^he^d. Inualesco, lui, scere, to

Inualetudo, dinis, feblenesse. Inuectiue orationes, orations made against one
in reprouyng his manners and living. Inueho, uexi, uehere, to carye in a
thing, to carye a thing into a place. Inuehor, eris, uehi, to rebuke one

which a man seeks for. In uerba iurare, to be sworn as princis cou^saylours

and order. Inuerto, tere, to turn in, to turn up so down, to turn in
and out after the vulgar speech, proprely to turn every thing contrary to the
right form or facion. Inuestes, young children without hear on their bodies.
Inuestigo, are, to seek out, to find in seking. Inuestigabilis, le, that may
not be found with seeking. Inuestio, iui, ire, to adorn or garnishe a thing.
Inueterati, old shrewes or unthrifts, me^ in living unthriftily waxed old.
Inueteresco, raui, scere, to were out for age, to be out of use, to be aged or
old. Also worn out, almost consumed. Inuicem, together, one the other.
Inuicem d^^gunt, they do love one an other. also it signifies for thy part.
Habes res urbanas, inuicem rusticas scribe, Now thou know the affairs of
the city, for thy part write what is done in the country. Inuidentia, envy,
grief to behold or here that an other man prospers. Inuideo, uidi, dear, to
have envy at an others prosperity. Inuideo tibi doctrinam, I have envy at thy
learning. Also to see inwardly or through a thing. Inuisus, uisa, uisum,
hated. Inuidia, envy, hatred, ill will. Salustius in Iugarth.
Inuidia facti sui, the displeasure of his act, or attemptate, or the deed
wherefore he was envied and hated. Inuidiosa res, a thing, which bredeth envy
or hatred. Inuidiose, enuyousely. Inuidiosus, an enuyous person. sometime he,
which is envied. Inuidus, he that has envy. Inuigilo, are, to have watch of
a thing, or to lay watch, to care. Inuinius, he that never drynketh wine.
Inuisus, a, u^, never seen. also hatid or odious. Inuitatus, boden, as to a
feast or bankette. Inuito, are, to bydde. also to delight, to fylle the bealy.
Inuitus, ta, tum, vnwyllynge, or against a man's will. In^^^^uersam,
universally. Inuius, a, um, lacking a way, or where nothing can pass.
Inumbro, are, to make shadow: sometime it signifies to defend. Inunco,
uncare, to catch, as it were with an hook. Inundo, to ouerflowe, or
surrounde. Inundario, a floudde. In unguem, to the point, perfectly. Inuoco,
care, to call in, to call for help, also not to call. Inuolo, are, to
steal, to lay violent hands on one, to flee out. Inuolucris, a bird not ready
to flee. Inuolucrum, that which is wrapped. Inuolucre, as a thing which is
wrappped together. Inuoluo, uere, to wrappe. Inuolutus, ta, tum, wrapped.
Inuoluolus, and inuoluola, a worm like a canker. which is on vynes, and when
he is taken of, he wrappeth him self round together.
I Ante O.
IO, an interiection, signifieng sometime grefe, as in Tibullo. Vrorio, O I
burn. Sometime excessive gladness. as in Ouidio. Dicite io paean. Iochabella,
the name of Moses mother. Ioseph^^
Iocus, plurali ioca, a merry word, disporte. Iocor, aris, ari, to speak
merrily, or in disport. Iocosus, a, um, and iocularis, lare, merry, sportfull,
provoking myrthe. Ioculus, a little sport or myrthe. Iolaus, the son of
Iphiclus, of whom the people of Sardinia, were named Iolenses. Iole, the
daughter of Euritus, king of Aetolia, whom Herculus loved. Ionia, a region of
the less Asia, wherein were the city of Ephesus, Milerum, and Clazomenae.
Ion, a stone of a vyolet color. Ionia, a city of the Athenienses. Ionicus,
ca, cum, and Ionius, a, um, of Ionia. Ioppe, a city of the country of
Palestina, not far from Jerusalem, standing by the sea, which some men do
suppose to be the hauyn, called Port Iaffe. Iordanis, a river of Judea,
commonly called flume Iordane. Ios, an isle where Homerus was buried. Iotapata,
a city in Syria. Iouin^ani, were men of arms, so called of Maximian the
emperor, which did valyantly in the country of Illiria. Iouis, the
genitive case of Jupiter.
I Ante P.
IPhianassa, the wife of Mela^pos, whom for her beauty Juno turned into furye
or madness. Iphigenia, the daughter of king Agamemnon, with whom he did
sacrifice going to Troy. Ips, ipos, a little worm, bredynge in horns and
vynes. Ipse, ipsa, ipsum, he, she, that same, by demonstratynge or showing the
person or thing spoken of. Ipsemet, he him self. Ipsippe, to him and none
other. Ipsulces, plates embosed like to fygures or images of men or women.
Iphitus, the son of Praxonidis, which first ordained the solemn plays
called Olympiada.
I Ante R.
IR, the holownesse of the hand. sommetyme it sygnifieth the hole hand. Ira,
wrath, an appetite to punyshe him, of whom we be offended. Iracundia, anger,
displeasure against one, a desire to be revenged. Iracundus, shortly or soon
angry, hasty. Irascor, etis, irasci, to be angrye. Irate, angrely. Iratus,
angrye. Irceus, a kind of pud dynges. Ircipes, an harowe. Ire inficias, to
deny. Ire pedibus in sententiam, to consent to the sentence or raison of an
other, which has spoken, or to be of the same opinyon. Irenarches, and
irenarcha, he which is in authority to see peace kept in a countreye or
city, which among us may be called a Justice of the peace. Iris, iris, uel
iridis, the rain bow. it is also a flower deluce, the root whereof is very
soote, and is commonly called Yreos. Irnium, oil of Ireos. Ironia, is a figure
in speaking, when a man dissemblyth in speech that which he thinks not:
as in scoffyng or bourdyng, calling that fair, which is foul in deed, that
good, which is ill, that eloque^t, which is barbarous. Semblably reasoning
contrary to that I think, to the intent to mock him, with whom I do
dyspute or reason. Ironice, mockyshly, scoffyngly. Ironicus, he that uses
that fasshyon in speaking. Irrasus, vnshauen. Irraucio, raucui, cere, to be
hoorse. Irrenumerabile, that may not be rewarded or recompensed. Irreparabile,
that may not be repaired or restored to the first astate. Irrepo, psi, pere,
to crepe in. Irreprehensus, a, u^, that can not be reprouid. Irretio, iui, ire,
to be taken or holden in, as it were in a net. Irretitus, taken, lapt in with
craft, or fair promyses. Irrigo, to water ground, to bring water into the
fields out of a river. Irriguus, gua, guum, the ground or field that may be
easyly watered. sometime the water, which may be easyly diryuied into the
fields. Irripio, pere, to pluck in. Irrito, are, to make void and of none
effect. Irritus, ta, tum, void, of none effect or force. Irrito, having the
last syllable saving one, long, to provoke, to kendyl wrath, to stir
up. Irrogare mulctam, to set a pain. Irructo, are, to blow in by
belkynge. Irrugio, gere, to braye out. Irrumo, are, to suck in. Irrumpo,
rupi, irrumpere, to break in, or enter with force. sometime to break asonder.
Irruo, to rounne hastilye or furiousely into battle, or upon any thing.
sometime to fall in, or cast in.
I Ante S.
IS, a pronowne, which signifies he. Isaeus, a famous rhetorician, which
inue^tid to make every matter co^pendious. Isagoge, an introduction.
Isagogicon, a way to introduce, or begin to teach. Isapis, a river nygh to
Caecenna. Isara, a river coming out of the Rone, where the hylle called
Cemenus is joined to the Rone: and so runs by Druentia into the goulfe of
Venyse. Isacia, an isle ageynste Velia, callydde also Oenotris. Isauria, a
region of the less Asia. Isaurum, a cite in the country of Pa^philia. Ischia,
the houckle bone. it is sometime taken for the ache in the said bone, which
vulgar phisicions do call Sciatica. Ischiadicus, uel Ischiacus, he that has
the ache in the hyppe, commonly callid Sciatica. Isiaci, the priests of the
goddess Isis. Isis, called also Io, one of the harlottes of Jupiter, whom he
turned into a cow for fear of Juno his wife. Isitium, a certain puddynge.
some call it an Isynge. Ismarus, a mountain in Thracia. Ismenias, the name of
an excellent minstrel, which played on the shalmes. Ismenus, a river in the
country of Boeotia. Isocolon, where two sentences are in like length.
Isocrates, the name of a famous oratoure, of wonderfulle eloquence, out of
whose schole proceeded the most excellent orators of Greece. Isodomon, a
form of building, where every thing is equally straight. Isonomia, equalite
of laws, as where they be indifferent and like to al manner of persons.
Isopleurus, three edged. Israel, sygnifieth a man saying god. Issa, an isle in
the Venician see ioynynge to Slauonie. Issus, a city in Sicile, and a river of
Siria. Ister, istri, the great river called Danubius, in ^uche Danowe. Ister,
the greattest river of Europa, called also Danubius, Danowe. Istic, there,
where thou art. Isthmus, a narowe part of the countreye, where two sees are
but a small distaunce asonder. There be diverse such places in Grecia, and of
them were certain plays called Isthmia. Istria, a part of Italye, marchynge
on Illiria, called now Slauonye.
I ANTE T.
ITA, so, so much, therefore. Ita sane, ye truly. Italia, Italye. Italus, an
Italyan. Italica, a city in Italia, which by an another name is called
Confiniu^, There is an other in Spayn, where Silius Italicus was borne.
Italicus, ca, cum, of Italye. Italicensis, a citesen of Italica. Item, in like
wise. Ite^, eris, itiner, itineris, a iourneye. also a way. Iter habeo ad
Caesarem, I take my journey to the emperor. Itero, are, to do a thing
eftesoones, to goo back again. Iterum, eftesoones, or again. Ithaca, the
country of Ulysses. Ithome, a town in Peloponeso, an another in Thessaly.
Ithonia, a country in Greece. Ithyra, a town on the mountain of Taurus.
Ithyphallus, the name of Priapus the most dishonest and abominable ydoll. Also
the secret membre being in prosperity. Itidem, semblably, also. Itinerarium, a
commentarye or book of remembrance, contaynynge things committed in
iourneyes. Also it is a calendar of miles in the distance of places, with the
time of abode in every place, like to iestes of princis. Iteneror, aris, ari,
to goo in iourneye. Ito, taui, tare, to go much. Cicero.
Ituria, a region in Arabia, or Siria, of which the people are called Ituraei.
Itus, and itio, a goinge. Quid noster itus and reditus, what our goinge and
coming. Itys, the son of Tereus and Prognes, who, as poets do feign, was
turned into a fesaunt.
I, Ante V.
IVBA, the mane of a beast. Also the name of a king of Barbarye. Iubar, a
sterre, which is also callid Lucyfer and Hesperus. it is sometime taken for
bryghtenesse. Iubeo, iussi, iubere, to command, to desire, to wyshe, to
exhort, to decree. Iubilo, are, to declare in the voice, the joy and
gladness of the heart, which may not be expressed with words. Iubilum, joy
and gladness in voice, not expressed in words. Iucundor, aris, ari, to be
joyous and merry. Iucundus, a, um, he or that, which is the cause that an
another reioyseth, dylectable, pleasant to see or here. Iudaea, Iewry, or the
country of Jews. Iudaeus, a Jew. Iudex, iudicis, a judge. Iudex ordinarius,
he that has authority of his propre iurysdiction, to sytte in judgment
without commission. As the chief Justice of England, the Mayre of a city
incorporate, and a Coroner. Iudex delegatus, he that sytteth by commission, as
all other judges and justices. Iudicialis, le, of a Judge. Iudiciarius, a, um,
pertaining to a judge, or that which is to be iuged. Iuditium, judgment.
Iuditium habere, to give judgment. Iudico, are, to judge or deem, to suppose,
Lau. Vall^ in Barpt, i^ ciu^. lib. ^.
to give sentence, to condemn. Iugale uinculum, the bond of matrimonye.
Iugalis, he that is yoked. Iugantinus deus, was among paynyms the god, whom
they supposed to have authority over the rydges of hills. Iugarius, a street
in Rome, where was an altar of Juno, which men supposed did join matrimony
surely. Iugeratim, by sundry furlonges. Iugere, to cry like a kyte. Iugerum,
and iugus, geris, as much ground as one yoke of oxen will ear in a day. some
suppose it to contain in length 240. feet, in breadth half so much. some
say, that it is more. Leonardus Portius says, by the authority of
Columella, that Iugerum contains.xxviii. thousand and.viii. hundred fete.
Iuges, oxen like in greatness, callid yokes, or payres. Iugis, contynuynge in
one thing. Iugiter, contynually. Iuglans, andis, a wall nutte. Iugo, are, to
yoke or couple together. Iugosus, rydged. Iugula, a celestyalle Sign,
contaynynge three sterres. Iugulo, are, to slay, not only with weapon, but also
with syckenes. Quartana neminem ingulat, The fever quartayn sleeth no man.
Iugulus, the foreparte of the neck, which is dyuided in two great synewes.
Cells. Is. 4.
Dexter, and sinister. Iugulum ferire, to slay proprely in the neck. Iugulum
petere, when an orator or man of law, touches vehemently the point of the
matter, and with manifest and sore arguments and reasons, seems to assault
and oppress the contrary part, as it were with sharp weapons. Iugum, a
yoke. also the rydge of an hill or bank, also the beam, whereon weauers do
turn their web. Also a thing like to a galowes, under the which in sign
of reproach, they which were vanquisshed, were constrained to creep, which
was made with two spears standing, and one spear ouerthwarte. Also a frame,
whereon vynes are joined. Also a beam, whereon bala^ces do hang. Also the side
beams in a ship, in the which the traunsomes are fastened. Iulis, a city
in the isle of Caea, the country of Simonides the poet. Iulia, a kynred,
which proceeded from Ascanius, son of Aeneas, called Iulus. also a town in
Cales, in the country of Spain. Julius, the month of July, which took his
name of Julius Caesar. Iulus, otherwise namid Ascanius, the son of Aeneas.
Iulus, is also a little worm with many fete, bredynge in vynes and oaks, which
is also called Conuoluolus, Inuoluolus, and Voluola. It is also the mosynesse
of the outward part of fruits. Also the young fruit immediately after that
the flowers be fallen. Iuli, be also the mosynesse or soft hears, which do
grow on the beardes and visages of young men, before that they be shaue^: and
sometime it signifies the same young men. Iulus, is also a fyshe, which is
guide unto whales: which also is called Hegeter. it is moreover a song
dedicate to Diana. Iumentum, every beast that drawethe or bears burdeyns.
also a lyttel carre. Iunctim, ioyntely. Iunculi, meat callid iunkettes: also a
fresh chese made on rushes, callid a iackeman. Iuncus, a bulle rushe. Iuncus
odoratus, a spyce that is medicinable, specially to make the brethe sweet.
Iungami, people in the country of Liguria. Iungo, xi, gere, to join. Iunix,
icis, a young cow or hefar. Iuniculi, small vynes joined together. Iuniperus,
a sweet bushe, called Ieoneper. Iunis, n^, young, whereof comes Junior,
younger. Iunius, the monethe called June. also a man's name. Juno, the wife of
Iupyter, it is sometime taken for the air. Iunonia mayor, and minor, be two of
the fortunate Isles. Jupiter, iouis, the name of a great prince, which for his
wysedom and prowes was honored of the gentyles for chief of all gods, It is
also the name of a planette, which is always beneuolent in his influence and
course. Iuramentum, an oath. Iuratus, sworn. Iurgiosus, a, um, braulyng, full
of conte^tion. Iurgium, a braulynge, or a small contention. Iurgo, are, to
braule or chyde. Iuridicus, ca, cum, according to the law, or belonging to
the law. Iurisdictio, jurisdiction, power, or authority to ministre and
execute laws. Iuro, iutare, to swear. Iurulentus, ta, tum, full of juice, or
lycoure. Ius, iuris, law, authority, liberty, power, right. sometime the
place, where the law is ministered. Also lycour or juice. De iure meo, tuo, suo
decedere, to omytte some part of the rygour or extremity of the law. Pro suo
iure agere, and summo: iure agere, to take the extremite of the law. Summu^
ius, the rygour of the law. Iuscum, and iusculum, brothe, wherein meat has
den sodden. Iusiurandum, a solemn oath or promise made to GOD. Iussa,
commandments. Iussus, a, um, commanded. Iusta, sacrifices done for deed
men: now it may be used for funeral exequies. Iusta soluere, Cicer pro Roscio.
is proprely in funeralle obsequies, to do and perform al things thereunto
necessary. Iustitia, justice, rygtuousnesse. Iustitium, a cessynge for a time
from minystration of laws in places judicial. Iustus, a just or rightuous
man, an upright and true meaning manne. It is taken often times in holy
scripture for a virtuous man or good man. Iustus, ta, tum, equal. mean
between two extremities. Iusta magnitudo, neither more nor less, the just
quantity. sometime it sygnifyeth greatness. Iusta pars, the greatte part.
Iusto labor, with great labor. Iustas inimicitias, great hostility. sometime
it signifies among lawyers, true or very. Iustus filius, his very son.
Iuturna, the sister of Turnus. Iuuamen, iuuatio, and iuuamentum, help.
Iuuenalia, plays vowed for the health of young men. Iuuenalis, le,
pertaynyng to youth. Iuuenalis dies, a day celebrate to youth. Iuuenalis, is
also the name of a poet, which wrate Satyrs. Iuuencus, and iuuenca, young,
not only men but also beasts. Iuuenculus, idem. Iuuenesco, scere, to wax, or
be young. Iuuenilis, le, young. Iuueniliter, yongely. Iuuenis, a young man.
Junior, oris, younger. Iuuentus, tutis, youth. sometime a multitude of young
men. Iuuo, uas, iuui, are, to help, to delight. Iuxta, nighe, jointly or
together, even like, according. Salustius in Catalinar.
Nunc uero quo in loco res nostrae sint, iuxta mecum oe^s intelligitis, Now
how the matter stands, ye all know as well as I: or else, in what case our
busynes is, ye understand all as much as I do. Iuxtim, nygh to. Ixon, a
great white bird, of the kind of Ravens.
L ANTE A.
LABASCO, labascere, and labascor, sceris, to fail or decay. Labefacio,
labefacere, to break or destroy. Labefacto, ctare, to make feeble, to appaire.
Labellum, a lyppe. Labeo, onis, a man or womanne having greatte lyppes.
Labes, a spotte, which sodeynely happens to things that are smothe, a
blemyshe. Labecula, a little spotte. Labia, and labra, lyppes. Also Labrum is
the brymme or brynke of a river or fountain. Also a fat or like vessel
necessary to be bayned in. sometime a fat for wine after that it is pressed.
It may be used for a keele vate, wherinto ale or beer is put. Labicanum, a
town in Italy. Labici, the inhabitants of that town. Labicus, was the name
of the son of Minos, who was named also Glaucus. Labilis, bile, unstable,
which will soon fall, slypper. Labina, slyppernesse. Labo, are, to fall
down suddenly. Labor, eris, lapsus sum, labi, to slide, to dye, to fail, to
fall down by little and little. Labor, labor, travail. Laboriae the name
of a country in Italye, vulgarly called Terra laboris, the land of labor.
Laborinus, a field in Campania, where the stubbyll of corn is so great, that
the people do burn it instead of wodde. Laboriosus homo, a paynefull man.
Laboro, rare, to labor, to be in heaviness or grief. Labrusca, wild vine.
Labyrinthus, a maase, or any buildyng made like a maase, out of the which it
were hard to get forth. Lac, lactis, milk. Lacaena, a kind of apparayle.
also a woman of Lacedemonia. Lacedaemon, uel Lacedaemonia, a city in the part
of Greece, which is now called Moraea, whereof Menelaus was king. Lacer, and
lacerus, a, um, torn or rent. Lacerna, a short cloak, which men of war
be wont to wear. Lacernatus, cloked, or cladde in a cloak. Lacero, are, to
tear in pieces, or to give many wounds. Lacertus, and lacerta, a Lyzerde, an
Euet: also the part of a man's arm, from the elbowe to the wreste of the
hand, proprely the brawne and synewes of the arm. Lacertosus, having greatte
brawnes and synewes. Lacesso, siui, and cessi, ssere, to rent, or goo about to
rent the good renoume of a man. Also to provoke a man to wrath or displesure,
with words, writynge, or act: to rail on a man, to prycke a man with some
ill language or act. Lachana, all kind of herbs. Lachanopoles, a syller of
herbs. Lachanopolium, the herb markette. Lachesis, one of the three ladies
called Parcae, which poets did feign, to have the rule and contynuance of
man's life. Lachrima, a tear in weepynge. Lachrimo, are, to weep. Laciniae,
gardinges of a garment, proprely where the skirtes be cut in sundry facion.
In lacinias, in pieces. Lacinia, is also a red musheron, which springs at
the rote of a chesten tree. Laciniosus, a, um, cut in sondrye facions,
wyndyng and tournynge diverse ways. Lacinium, an elbowe of land, lyenge
between the sea, called Hadriaticum, and the sea called Ionium. Lacon, onis, a
man of Lacedemonia. Laconia, the countreye, where Lacedemonia stands.
Laconicus, nica, nicum, of the countraye of Laconia. Laconicum, a hotehowse or
dry bayne. Laconismus, a short form of speakinge. Lactarius, ia, um, meat
made of milk, all herbs, which have juice like milk. Lactarius, rij, he
that makes sundry meats of milk. Lacteo, ere, to suck milk. Lactes, places
within the rybbes of a man, benethe the nauyll, so tender, that it may not
suffer any wound or stroke, as Probus says. Some say that they be caules,
wherein the small bowelles do lie. Lactesco, scere, to be turned into milk, or
to be filled with milk. Lacteus, a, um, of milk or like milk, also that
which is nourished with milk. Lacticinia, white meats made of milk.
Lactidiaci, stryken about the nauyll. Lacto, are, to feed with milk, also to
deceive with fair words. Lactuca, an herb called letuse. Lacuna, a dyche,
wherein water stands. also a trenche, whereby fields are drayned, Some
english it, a synke. Lacunar, a beam of timber. Also such a thing as does
yet hang in merchants houses, overthwart their halles, whereon be set a
great number of candelles. Lacus, cus, a deep place always full of water which
is deriuied into brokes and rivers, also the vesselle, which receives wine,
when the grapes are pressed. Also the pryncipalle beam that gothe
ouerthwarte the house. Lacuturres, greatte cabages. Ladanum, a sweet gum,
which goth into the making of pommanders. Ladon, a river in Arcadia.
L ANTE AE.
LAedere maiestatem, to derogate any thing of the kings auctorytie or
prerogative. Laedo, laesi, dear, to hurt or do displeasure. Ci. in Ver.
Laesae religionis culpa, heresye, or lollardy, contempt of religion or
ceremonies. Laemargia, gluttonye. Laemargus, a glutton. Laemuschaton, the
reward given to him that vanquyshed at playenge or fighting with weapons.
Laena, a garment lyned, which the dyuynours called augures, did wear. Laerte,
a city in Cilicia. Laertes, the father of Ulysses. Laertius, the name of one,
which wrate the lives of Philosophers. Laetabilis, glad, or reioycefull.
Laetamen, compass or mucke laid in the fields, to make corn and grass to
grow plentuousely. Laetifico, are, to make glad. Laetisco, scere, to be
glad. Laetitia, gladness, reioycynge of the mind, which does also appear
outwardly. Laetitudo, inis, idem. Laeto, are, to make glad. Laetor, aris,
ari, to be glad, or to rejoice with outward signs. Laetus homo, a glad
man. Laeta ouis, a good sheep. Laeta seges, and letu^ legumen, plentyfull corn
and grain. All other things, not having life, being called Laeta, do
sygnifye dilectable to behold, or that do please the eye of the beholder.
Laeuigo, are, to plane, or make plain, or to polyshe. Laeuis, laeue, smothe or
plain. Laeuitas, tatis, playnnesse or smothenesse. Laeuo, are, to make smothe.
Laeuor, oris, smothenesse. Lagari uersus, verses, which do halt in the mids
of the foot. Lageos, a kind of grapes. Lagana, be thynne cakes made with
flower and water, whereto was put fat brothe, pepper, saffron, and cynnamom.
Lagonon, the frettynge of the guts. Lagoena, a pytchar pot. Lagia, one of
the names of the i will of Delos. Lagois, a kind of fyshe, which may be called
the hare fyshe. Lagoplithalmos, he that has eien like a hare, or in whom the
ouerlyds of the eien do not meue downewarde. Lagotrophia, a warren or park of
hares. Laguncula, a little pytchar. Lagygies, people in Sarmacia. Laicus, a
lay man. Lais, the name of a famous harlotte, unto whom for her beauty
repaired the richest men of Greece. Laletania, a country in Spain. Lalisiones,
coltes of wild asses. Lallare, to speak like a baby: in the which word the
greek does approach nerer to the english than to the latin, as babazin,
which made a latin word, (...)
is babare, it may be transferred to the mother or norice, that babeleth with
her child when she gives to it the dugge. Lamae, the raggydnesse of rocks.
Lambo, bear, to lycke with the tongue. also to touch, to flow, or run
softly. Lambrus, a river in Italy, which meteth with the river of Po, called
Padus. Lambrani, people dwelling about the said river of Lambrus. Lamentabilis,
le, lamentable. Lamentarius, a, um, that causes lame^tation. Lamentor, aris,
ari, to lament or bewail. Lamentatio, onis, lamenting or wailyng. Lamiae, be
women, which beholdynge, children, or gyuyng to them gifts, do alter the
form of them, which children be afterward called elfes, or taken with the
fayrye. And some such women will suck the bloudde from chyldern. They be
also those, which be called ladies of the fayry, which do allure young men to
company carnally with them, and after that they be consumed in the act of
lecherye, they coueyte to devour them. Lamia, is also a beast, which has a
woman's face, and the fete of a horse. It was also the surname of a noble
Romayne, and also of a famous harlot. Lamina, a plate of metal. Lamirus, one
of the sons of Hercules. Lampas, a leame of fire, or brightenes of the son,
most used for a lamp. Lampetra, a fyshe called a lamprey. Lampsacus, a city
on the border of Asia, upon the river called Hellespontus. Lampsacenus, a, um,
of that city. Lampytis, a gloo worm, or a worm callid a globerde. Lana,
woulle. Lanaris, re, that bears or has wolle. Laneus, a, um, woullen.
Laneus, a fyshe. Lanitium, the occupienge of woll. Lanitius, a, um, woollen or
of wolle. Lanate paecus, beasts having woll. Lanarius, a wulle man, or he that
occupies or sells wolle. Lanatus, a, um, cladde or wrapped in wolle. Lanatus
lupus, a fish so called for his whitenes and softenes. Lancia, a spanish
iauelin with a broad heed. Lancearius, he that bears a Iauelyn. Lanceatus,
armed with a iauelyn. also wounded with a iauelyn. Lanx, cis, a dyshe, which
of some is callid a potenger. also a balance. Lancino, are, to strike, to rent
with the teth. Lanerum, a garment made of vndied woll. Langa, a beast, which
is found about the river of Po. Langueo, and languesco, ere, to languyshe, to
be sick, to be faint, to be aferd, to be idell. Languidus, da, dum, faint,
sick, aferde, idell. Langurium, langettes of aumbre, like to long beadestones.
Languor, oris, languour, faylyng of strength and natural all moisture.
Laniena, the flesh shambles, or shop where flesh is sold. Sommetyme it
sygnyfyethe dismembrynge. Lanificium, cardinge and spinning of woll. Lanificus,
he that does work woulle, to make it mete for the clothyar. It may be called
also a woll wynder. Lanio, are, to cut like a boucher. Lanifex, ficis, idem
qui lanificus. Lanionius, a, u^, pertaynyng to bouchers craft. Lanista, he that
had the reule over sword players, and caused them to be taught, and after
sold them. Also that ordained birds to fight. Lanium carnarium, a slaughter
house. Lanius, and lanio, onis, a boucher. Lano, are, to put in woll, or to
dress with woll. Lanugo, the soft hears or mosynes in the vysages of chylderne
and women. Also on fruits called peaches, and some herbs as long wort,
clary, and such other. Laodicea, a city in Asia. Laodomia, the wife of
Prothesildus. Laomedon, ontis, the father of Priamus. Lapa, and lapathes, an
herb called Clote* which bears bourres, that cleauen to clothes and
cattle. Lapathos, seu lapathiu^, an herb called sorel. Lapicida, a mason.
Lapidarius, a, um, pertainyng to stones. Lapidesco, ere, to be made or turned
into a stoone. Lapidicina, a quarre of stones. Lapido, are, to strike with
stoones. also to strike sometime without stones. Lapillus, a little stone, also a
precious stone. Lapio, iui, ire, to make hard as a stone. Lapis, pi^^s, a
stone but less than that, which is called Saxum. Lapis, is sommetyme taken
for a mile. Ad tertium aut quartum lapidem, at the third or the fourth mile.
De lapide empti, were slaves or bondmen sold. Lapithe, people of Thessalie, of
whom Perithous was king. Lapsana, wild colewortes. Lapsio, a fall. Lapso,
are, to fall often. Lapsus, us, a fall. Also a small offense done by
negligence, an oversight. Lapythos, a city in the isle of Cypres. Laqueare,
laquear, and laquearium, the roufe of a chaumber, which is imbowed or fretted.
also a plain beam in a rouffe. Laqueatus, a, um, haltered, snarled, tied or
bound fast. sommetyme it sygnyfieth holowe or bowynge. Laqueus, an halter.
Lares, gods, which the paynyms did suppose every person had belongyng unto
him* which were also called Penates, both the which words be also taken for
pryuate dwellynges or houses. Mei lares, mei penares, my house or dwelling
place. Laranda, a city of Lycaonia. Lararium, a private chapel or closette
in a man's house. Lardum, larde, or the fat of an hog. sometime swynes
flesh salted. Larentia, a famous harlotte, which because she made the people
of Rome her heir, they named her a goddess, and callydde her Flora. Largior,
iris, iri, to give lyberally. Largitas, tatis, largenes, or lyberalitie.
Largitio, lyberalle expenses, to win a man's purpose. Largus, a, um, large,
or free of expenses. Large, abundauntly. Larine, a fountain in Attica.
Larissa, the name of one city in Thessalia, an other in Asia, the third in
Italy. Larius, a brook by the city of Comum. Larix, icis, a tree of the kind
of fur, out of the which issues a soote gum. Larodij, people in Scithia.
Larua, a spyrite, which apperethe in the night time. Some do call it a hegge,
some a goblyn. Also a masker, or he that wears a visour. it is sometime taken
for the same visour. Laruatus, he that is feared with a spirit, and is becomme
mad. It sommetime signyfieth a masker. Laruale, an image defourmed, pale,
lean, and horrible to behold. Larum, a little black waterfowle. Lasanum, a
chaumber pot, or vrynall. Lasciuio, ire, to be wanton. Lasciuus, a, um,
wanton. Lasciuia, wantonness. Laser, the juice of an herb called Laserpitium,
commendable in sundry medicines. Lasibus, old writers used for Laribus.
Lasseo, and lassesco, lassus sum, sere, to be weary. Lascea, an isle in the sea
called Egeu^. It was also called Andros. Lasso, are, to be weery. Lassus, a,
um, weery. Lassitudo, werynesse. Lastaurus, a greatte lechour. Latebra, and
latebrae, brarum, a priuye place, where men do hyde them. Sommetyme it
sygnifieth an excuse. Latebro, are, to hyde. Latebrosus locus, where as be many
priuye places. Lateo, tui, tere, to be hid. Later, a tyle. Laterani, yeman of
the guard. Lateranus, the name of a co^sul of Rome, of whose house was made a
church of saint John^, which is now callid Lateranensis. Laterculus, a
little tyle. Laterem lauas, thou losest thy labor. Lateritius, a, um, made of
tyles. Laterna, a lantern. Lato, latescere, to be broad. Latex, ticis, all
manner of lycour: but it is most commonly taken for water. Latomia, a dungeon
in the prison at Rome. Latomus, a mason. Latialis, le, and latiaris, re, of
latin, of that part of Italy, which was called Latium. Latibulo, are, to be
hid. Latibulum, a den or bury, where beastis do hyde them. sometime it is
used for a secret place or cave, wherein men be hid. Laticlauius, a Senator.
Latifolium, that which has broad leaves. Latifundium, a greatte or large
field, great and large possessions. Latinae, narum, sacrifyces to Jupiter named
of the latins, who first did ordain them. Latin, in the form of latyne.
Latinitas, tatis, latyne speech. Latinus, na, um, latin, or of the people
called latins. Latinus, the propre name of Aeneas father in law. Latico, are,
to lurk. Latium, a part of Italy. Latius, a, um, of that country. Latinius,
a mountain in Ionia, where poets say the moon kyssed Endymion. Latomiae, was
a strayte prison in the city of Syracusis in Sicilia, an other in Spartha. It
is also a quarry, out of the which stones are dygged. Latona, was mother of
Apollo and Diana. Latonia, called also Diana, and is also taken for the moon.
Latria, the honor and service, wherewith god only is worshypped. Latres, a
servant. Latrina, a syege or iakes. Latro, are, to bark as a dog does.
Latrocinium, thefre, robbery. Latrocinor, trocinari, to robe, also to serve in
wars. Latrones, robbers by the high way. Also souldyours retained. Among
the Romans it were those, which were always about the kings or Emperoures
person, as the guard is about the king. Also Latrones, seu Latrunculi, be
chessemenne, with which men do play at the chesse. Latrunculator, a
justice of gayle delyuery, or any Justice, which does give sentence on
thieves. Latus, lata, latum, broad. Late, abroad, in many places. Latitudo,
dinis, bredthe. Latuniae, quarres where stones are dug. Latus, lateris, a
side. Latus clauus, a senators robe or garment. it is put sometime for the
dignity of a Senator. semblably Laticlauium. Lauacrum, a bathe or bayne.
Lauatrina, a synke, wherinto foul water is cast or swepte, whereby pauementes
are made clean. Lauce, an isle in the sea called Pontus. Laudabilis, le,
laudable, commendable. Laudatio, a praise or commendation. Laudo, are, to
praise. Laudo testem, I take to witness. Lauerna, a goddess, under whose
protection thieves were in Rome. Lauinium, a city in Italye, called also
Lautentum. Lauo, uaui, are, and lauo, ui, ere, to wash. Lautus, and lotus, ta,
tum, washed. Laurea, a leaf of a laurel or bay tree, sometime a garlande made
of Laurel. Lamens, it is, a man of the town called Laurentum. Lamentu^, a
city in Italy callid also Lauiniu^. Lameo, are, to put on a garlande of
laurel. Lameola, a crown or garlande that vyctours ware in their triumph.
Lameus, a, um, of laurel. Lametum, a place, wherein do grow laurelles or baye
trees. Lautiser, and lauriger, is, he that wearethe a garlande of laurel.
Laurinum, oil of laurel or bays. Laurion, a place in Attica, where silver
was dygged. Lautus, a laurelle or baye tree. Laus, laudis, praise. Lautia, were
presents, which the Romans did send to ambassadors of other realms. Lautitia,
magnifycence and netenesse in dyners and bankettes. Lautrices, the wyfes of two
brethren. Lautulae, weate baynes. Lautus, ta, tum, washed. also nete or
clean, or elegant, rich. Laxitas, tatis, and laxamentum, release, pardon,
lowsenes, liberty. Laxo, are, to lowse or set at liberty, to release.
Laxus, a, um, lowse, large, wide, soft, weke. Laxum, an aduerbe, signifies
wide. Caesar.
Laxare manipulos, was in battle, when the sundry bendes or companyes of footmen were set in a ray, one man a convenient distance from an another, that they
might fight the more at their liberty.
LEae, an Island by Cyrenaica, a regyon of Affrike. Leiena, a lioness.
Leander, the name of a man. Lebes, lebetis, a caudron to boil in. Lebadia, a
city in Boeotia. Lectica, a thing like to bed, wherein rich men, and noble
men were borne by six servants. It may be taken for a lyghter. Lecanomantia, a
divination or prophecy by the noise of basins. Lecticarij, they which bare
Lecticam. Lectio, onis, reedynge. Lectipes, an herb. Lectisterniator, oris, a
chaumberlayne, or he that makes the beds. Lectisternium, a solemnity among
the paynims when in the honor of their goddis Jupiter, Juno, and Minerua,
beds were spradde in the temples, in the which first the idolles were laid,
in the resydue as many as might lie and eat. Lectito, are, to read often.
Lectrum, a part of Asia, lyenge into the sea. Lecturio, ire, to desire to read.
Lectus, a bed. Lectulus, a little bed. Lecythus, a pot of earth, which
served only for oil. Legatarius, ia, to whom any thing is bequethed.
Legacitius, pertaining to legacies. Legator, oris, he that bequetheth any
thing, the testatour. Legatum, a legacye or bequeste. Legatus, an ambassador,
that has commissyon to treat of matriers. He that is sent oonely to salute
or congratulate, is called Orator. Legerda, a city in great Armeny.
Legirupio, onis, a breaker of laws. Legio, onis, a company of men of war,
co^taynyng commonly, six thousand footmen, seven hundred thyrty and two
horsemen. Legionarius, a, um, pertaynyng to a legion. Legirupa, a breaker of
laws. Legislator, a maker or gyuer of laws. Legifer, idem. Legittimus, a, um,
according to the law. Legittimi dies, days in bank, when the party
should appear or plead. Legittima iuditia, iugementes confirmed by laws
written, or ancient custom. Legiuncula, a small legion. Lego, are, to send
as an ambassador, or as a legate, or deputy, to commytte, or appoynte, to
bequeathe. Lego, gi, gere, to gather, to read, to pass by to stryke. Legula, a
fyllet. Leguleius, a lawyer. Legulus, a gatherer of small things. Legumen,
minis, all manner of pulse, as beans, peason, vetches, tares. etc. Legumentum,
and legarium, the same. Leleges, seu lelegae, people, which were always
wandrynge, and dwelled sommetyme in Thessalia. Lema, a tear. Lemanus, a river
which runs into the river of Rone. Lembus, a swyfte lyttelle ship, which
may be called a bark. Lemnisci, labelles hanging down from garlandes.
Lemnos, an isle in the sea called Aegeum. Lemnia terra, that which is now
called Terra sigillata. Lemosi, they that weep lightly. Lemonici, a people in
Guyan, Lemonoise. Lemures, spyrites, which do walk by night with horrible
fygures. Lenaeus, one of the names of Bacchus. Lenas, a bawd. Lendiginosus, a,
um, full of nyttes. Lenio, iui, ire, to pacify, to appease, to treat
gentilly, to make plain, or smoth, to comfort. Lenis, lene, that which has
no roughnes, meke, tractable, soft of conditions. Lenitas, and lenitudo,
meekness, gentilnesse, easynesse to please, softenes, smothenes. Leniter,
softely, swetely, moderately. Leno, a baude, a merchant of hoores. Lenobates, a
treader of grapes. Lenocinium, the practyse of bawdry. sometime immoderate and
exquisyte clenlynes or elegancye, to stir a man to vice. Lenocinor, ari, to
practice baudrye. Also to speak fair, or allure oone with words, and other
pleasant things. Lenonius, a, um, pertaynyng to bawdes. Lens, lendis, a
nytte. Lens, it is, a kind of poulse called fatches. Lentesco, scere, to be
smothe, or tender. Lenticula, a poulse called chittes. Lenticula, a manner of
vessel, out of the which kings and princes were anointed, a Chrismatorie.
Lenticularis, re, like a chytte or fatche. Lentigo, ginis, a thing like a
little warte in the face read or black. Lentiscus, a little tree, out of
the which comes Mastix, a sweet gum. Lent, easily, softely. Lento,
lentare, to do a thing softely or easyly, slowely. Lentus, ta, tum, soft,
gentylle, easy, slow, remysse, ydell, cleauynge, or clammy. Lenulus, a
little or young bawd. Lenunculus, idem. Also a little fishers bote. Leo, onis,
a Lion. Leo risit, a proverb touching the^, which be sour of countenance,
fierce, and vncurteyse. Lonem radere, spoken where one atte^pteth a thing
dangerous, and almost impossible. Leocrates, the name of an excellent grauer.
Leodamas, the propre name of a philosopher. Leon, a philosopher. Leonides, was
king of the Lacedaemonians, which did feats of war against Xerxes king of
Persia incredible, and finally was slain in defendyng Greece, with four
thousand and eight hundrid greeks only, against.xvii. hundred thousand of
the hooste of Xerxes. There was also an other Leonides, which was tutour to
king Alexander, when he was a child. Leonina, an herb, which grows on
hills, whose flowers are like to a lions mouth when he gapeth. Leontopetalon,
an herb, having leaves like to colewortes, the stalk half a foot high, the
sede in husks as great as small peason, the rote like a rape rote, great and
black, which helps ageynste the styngyng and bytynge of all manner of
serpe^tis. Leontophon, a little worm, which if the lion do byte, he dies
incontinent. Leontophona, a little beast, whose heed is turned into ashes,
wherewith men do myxte flesh, and cast it in the ways, whereby lions do pass,
whereof if they do eat, they dye incontinent. Leontopodion, an herb callid
Pee de lion which has flowers like roses vnspradde. Leopardus, a Lybarde.
Lepadusa, the isle of Sicile. Lepidiu^, an herb like to a wyld parsnippe.
Lepidus, a, um, nete, polyte, and pleasant, as well in speech, as in
gesture. Lepor, oris, and lepos, oris, pureness or netenesse in speech. Also
the good grace and dilectablenesse in speech and gesture. Leporarium, an
enclosure, Varro.3. de re rust.
or place enclosed, wherein are kept any beasts for pleasure or hunting.
Leporinus, rina, rinum, of an haare. Lepra, leprye. Leprium, a city in Achaia.
Lepus, poris, an hare. Laeptoludiae, black fygges. Lepusculus, a l^uret or
young hare. Lerna, a place, wherein the city of Argon laid all their ordure
and fylthe. Lernaeus, a, um, of Lerna. Lerna malorum. the dunge heap of
mischiefs. Leros, an Island in the sea Icarie. Lesbos, an i will in the sea
called Agaeum. Lesbius, a, um, of, the isle of Lesbos. Lessus, us, a lamentable
voice, used in the burieng of men, us we do say, Alas. Lestorum, a region of
Indie. Lestry gones, a people in the extreme part of Italye, which did eat
the companyons of Ulysses, rostynge them on broches. Letalis, le, mortalle.
Letania, uel litania, a supplycation or commune prayer. Lethargus, a syckenes,
which causes one to sleep continually, and to forget al thing. Lethargicus,
he that has the slepynge or forgetting syckenesse. Lethe, a river of hell, the
water whereof as soon as it is drunk, causes a man to forgette all thing
that is passed. Letisicus, ca, cum, causynge death. Leto, tare, to slay.
Letatus, slain. Letum, death. Leua manus, the left hand. Leuca, a
promontorie or elbowe of land, nygh to Corinthus. Leucantha, white bryer.
Leucanthemis, an herb, which phisytions of late days call Camomylle.
Leucates, a mountain in Epiro. also an isle. Leuce, a littell town not far
from Smirna. Leucola, an isle by Cypers. Leuconium, white cotton. Leucophaeus, a
brown or a russette color. Leucophaeatus, he that does wear a russet
garment. Leucopum, and leucopus, white of naturalle color. Leucophlegmantia,
a white dropsye. Leucosyria, a country, which is now called Cappadocia.
Leucosia, an isle against Pestanum, in the the sea Thyrrhenum. Leucothaea, the
goddess, which was called Matuta, and Aurora. Leuctrum and leuctra, a town
in Boeotia. Leuis, leave, light. Leuitas, tatis, lyghtnes. Leui, one of the
sons of Jacob, the patriarch. Leuiathan, a dragon of the sea: it is taken in
holy scripture for the dyuell. Leuiculus, a, um, somewhat light. also wa^ton.
Leuidensis, se, thynne wrought, and of small substance. Leuifidus, da, um, of
light credence or trust. Leuir, ri, the husbands brother. Leuo, are, to lift
up. sometime to take away, to abate. Leuus, a, um, light. Also when it is spoken
of worldly things, it sygnifieth left, unhappy, contrary: when it is referred
to celestial things, it betokens right, fortunate, prosperous. For that
which to us is the left hand, to them, which are above us, and do look
toward us, is the right hand. Lex, legis, law. Lex municipalis, the
peculyar law, which every city has. Lex orchia, a law, which assigned
how many persons should be boden to souper, and that men should soupe at
their doors, to the intent that it moughte appear, how the law was obeyed.
Lex plagiaria, whereby men were whipped. Lexipyreti, medycines, which do heal
men of fevers. Lexouii, people in high France about Burbon.
L ANTE I.
LIae, be holes in the top of a maste, which do receive the cabulles, or
roopes. Liba, an isle in the Indian see. Libamen, minis, libame^tum, and
libatio, a taste or say taken, proprely in sacrifice. Libanius, the name of a
great Rhetorician. Libanotis, tidis, an herb called Rosemary. Libanotus, a
wind, which does blow out of the northweste. Libanus, a mountain between
Araby and Phenicia. It is also a tree, which brings forth incense.
Libellio, a writer of books. Libellorum praefecti, masters of the requests,
which do receive bills of supplication, being put in, to the king or prince.
Hieron.
Libellulus, a very little book. Libellus, a little book: also sometime an
epistell, a supplication, a lybell or declaration in the law, of debt,
trespass, covenant, and other like. Libens, willing. Libentiae, dylectations,
pleasures. Libenter, wyllyngely, gladly. Libentina, one of the names of Venus.
Liber, beri, the fynder of wine, called also Bacchus and Dionysius. Liber, ra,
rum, free, at liberty, not bounden, large, or greatte. Liber, libri, a book or
warke written, the inner rynde of a tree. Liberalis, le, lyberall. Liberales
arts, the lyberall sciences, or sciences belonging to a free manne. Liberale
iuditium, and liberalis causa, where a man contendeth for his liberty.
Liberalia, orum, the festiual days of Bacchus. Liberaliter, lyberallye.
Liberalitas, tatis, lyberalytie. Liberi, children, as well women as men.
Liberides, comes. P^^o^ua,
Libero, are, to deliver, to set at liberty. Liberare creditorem, to
content, or satisfy him, of whom money is borrowed. Libertas, tatis, liberty
taken always in the good part. Libertinus, and libertus, he that of a bondeman
is manumised or infranchised. Libet, it lyketh or contenteth. Libethra, a cave,
wherein was a well, called Libethros, where the Muses being conversant, were
therefore called Libethrides. Libethrides, the Muses, or ladies of sciences.
Libethras, a mou^tain in Macedonia, where the Muses did dwell. Libidinarius, a
haunter of lechery. Libidinosus, lecherous, wylfull. Libido, dinis,
sensuality, unlawful appetite or lust. Sometime it sygnifieth only appetite
or will. Libitina, a goddess, in whose temple were sold all things
pertaynyng to sepulture or funeralles. sometime for burienge. Also for death,
or the beer, whereon dead bodies are carried. Libitinarius, he that has the
suruayeng and charge about burienges. Libo, are, to taste any thing: sometime to
touch, sometime to sacrifice, sometime to take. Libra, a pound weight: sometime a
pair of balaunces. it is also one of the.xii. signs. Libra A^tica, contained
a hundred dragmas, and was called Mna, or Mina. Libra Romana, contained.xii.
ounces, that is to say four score and syxtene dragmas, Libralis, le, a pound
wright. Libramentum, poyse or weight. Libraria, a lybrary. Librarius, a, um,
pertaining to books, or of a pound weight. Librarius, a scriuener, a book
bynder. Librile, the hanging equally of the balance. Librilla, a cogell or
stone, to throw at one. Libripens, dis, a weyer. It was also among the
Romans he, which bought a bondsman or slave, taking a pound weighte of
brass in his hand, and saying: This man, which with this money and brason
pound is boughte to my use, by the laws of the Romans. I say, is mine own.
Libro, are, to way, to poyse, to make weightye, to houer. Libs, a wind, the
which blows out of the southe. Libum, a chief caake. Liburni, people of the
country called Liburnia, also commune messangers. Liburnia, a part of
Galmatia, or Slauony. Liburnum, liburna, liburnas, and liburnica, a light
ship, as a bark or galias. Libya, and libye, a royalme in Affrike. Libycis,
cidis, a city in Judea, on the east part of the river of Iordane.
Libycontes, stones, which are not very clear, Libycus, ca, cum, of Libra. Libya,
and Libyssa, a man and woman of Libya. Libyophoenices, people in Africa.
Liceo, cere, to cheapen. Liceor, ceris, ceri, to set the price. Licenter,
rashely. Licentia, license, unlawful liberty. Licentiosus, rash, using
unlawful liberty. Licet, it is lefull. sommetyme it is used for may. Mihi
licet, I may. Tibi licet, thou may. sometime be it so, admytte it. Lichas,
a measure, which excedethe not four fyngers. Lichenes, ryngewormes or
tetters. Lichenis, a foul breakyng out, which begins about the chynne.
Some do take it for the french pockes. Licia, be thredes, which sylke women
do weaue in lyncelles or stools. Liciatoriu^, a weauers shyttel, or a sylke
woman's tauell, whereon sylke or threde being wounden, is shot through the web
or lome. Licinia, a kind of olyue trees. Licitator, toris, a chepener, a
chapman, sometime it signifies a broker. Licite, lefully. Licitor, aris, ari,
to bye and selle for gaynes, or to bargayn by exchange or cheuisance, to
fight, to deceive a man by a craftye bargayne. Lictor, a sergeant, or other
like minister to execute corporal punyshement. A Consul of Rome had.xii. other
heed officers: syx which bare every one in their handis, rods and axes
bounden together, to do with them execution, as they were commanded.
Lictorius, a, um, pertaynyng to sergeantes and other like officers. Lictus, ta,
tum, lycked. Lidoron, a tyle in length one foot and an half, in breadth one
foot. Lien, nis, the spleen. Ligamen, minis, ligamentum, a bond. Ligellum, a
cotage. Liger, eris, a river in France called Loire. Lignor, aris, ari, to go
to carry wodde. Lignarius faber, a carpentar. Lignator, a carier of wodde.
Lignile, fuel, or a wodde stacke. Lignosus, a, um, as hard as wodde. Lignum,
wodde. Ligo, are, to bind. Ligo, onis, a spade. Ligula, a little tongue.
Liguria, the country in Italye, where the city of Geane is set. Ligurio,
ire, to eat lycorousely, or to devour sweet or dayntye meats. Also to eat
daintily or curiousely. Liguritor, toris, a dainty feder, an eater of delicate
meats. Ligus, guris, of the country of Liguria, a Ianuens of Ianeway.
Ligusticum mare, the sea that is by Ieane. Ligusticus, ca, cum, of Liguria.
Ligustrum, a tree, which does bear white flowers, and soote: whereof is made
an oil called oleum cyprinum: and this tree does grow in watrye places, as
wyllowes and salowes do. It is also an herb, which some men do call Mayor, and
grows by hedges. Ligyes, are people of Asye, which with Xerxes warred
against the Greeks. Lilibaeum, an hill in Sicile on the sea bank. Also a
town. Lilietu^, a place where do grow many lilyes. Lilinum, oil of lylyes.
Lilium, a lylye. Lima, a fyle. Limatulus, a little fyled. Limatura, powder,
which comes of filing. Limax, cis, a snayle. Also a man, which prieth or
seeks for some thing to consume. Limboratius, a maker of gardes or purfils.
Limbus, a purfyll of a woman's garment, or a guard of a man's garment. Limen,
minis, signifies not only the thrassholde of a door, but also the haunse,
sometime it signifies the enter of the door. sometime frendeshyppe, after the
expolytion of Seruius. Limenarcha, the wardeyn of the ports. Limes, mitis,
sygnifieth a bound or butting in fields. Limetanei agri, feldes lyeng in the
extreme marches of a country. Limetanei milites, soldiers appointed to keep
the borders of a country. Limito, are, to bound or lymitte how far a thing
doethe extend. Limitatus, ta, tum, bounded, lymytted. Limo, are, to fyle, to
polyshe. Limus, a vesture from the belly downward. Also mudde or slime, which is
in the water. Limus, a, um, crooked, a wrie, a skewe. Limis oculis spectare, to
look wantonly on the one side, to cast a wanton eye, to look a skewe.
Linamentum, lynnen. Linarius, a warker of lynnen. Linea, a carpenters line or
cord. it sygnifieth also every line generally, either made or ymagined to be.
Lineamentum, the facyon of a body. Linearis, are, pertaining to a line. Lingo,
xi, gere, to lycke with the tunge. also to suck down by little and little.
Linctus, tus, lyckynge or suckynge down. Lingones, people in France, called
La^gres. Lingua, a tongue. also a language. Also an instrument, wherewith men do
take medycines or salues out of a box. Lingula, a little tunge. Also a lachet
or lingell. Also Lingua and lingula, do sommetyme signify a spoone. Lingua
bula, an herb called Langdebefe. Linguax, acis, a great speker, full of words.
Lingulaca, a woman full of words. Also a fyshe called a soole. Linio, iui,
ire, to annoynte. Lino, ni, ere, to annoynte or lay on sum thing, that is
thycke. also to line. Linostrophron, an herb, which is also called Marubium.
Linozostis, an herb called Mercury. Linquo, liqui, linquere, to leave.
Lintearius, a mercer of lynnen. Linteolum, a piece of lynnen clothe. Linteo,
onis, a lynnen weauer. Linternus, a river and town in Campania. Linteum, a
shete. It is taken for all lynnen clothes. sometime for sails. Lintres, little
botes made of holowe trees. Linum, lynnen. Linus, he that brought first letters
out of Phenicia into Greece, and was master to Hercules. Lynx, a beast, which
has the face of a lion, the body spotted like a panther, and is of the
greatness of a do, whose vryne is suddenly turned into a precious stone.
Lipara, an isle by Greece. It is also a soft plaster. Liparis, a river in
Cilicia. Lipopsichia, a soundyng, where one seems to be dead. Lipopthymia, a
traunse. Lippio, iui, ire, to be porreblynde, or sand blind, or dymme of
sight. Lippus, bleare eyed. Lippitudo, the blearenesse of eyes. Lipsana,
scrappes, or leauynges of vitayle, or other things. Liquamen and liquatu^,
grease, or talow molten, sewet. Liquefacio, cere, to melte. Liquentia, a river
in Lombardy. Liqueo, iui, ire, to be liquide or soft, as oil. Liquesco, scere,
to relente. Liquer, it appears, it is sure. Liquido, are, to discover, or make
to appear. Liquidus, da, um, lyquide runnynge and soft. sometime pure, also
prosperous. Liquido, plainly, apparently, purely. Liquo, are, to melte. Liquo,
ere, to run out, as lycour does. Lira, a rydge of land, which is over the
surrowe. sometime it sygnifyeth an harp. Lirae be trifles or iapes. Liratim,
in ridges. Liris, a river in Campania. Liro, are, to make rydges. Litem
aestimare, to assesse damages and costs for the playntyfe in an action. Lis,
litis, debate, variance, controversy. Litem suam facere, where oae medleth in
an other man's matter, as it were his own. Litera, a letter. Literae, a letter
or letters that be sent. sometime it signifies sciences. Litera salutaris, was
in the old time, A, as betokenynge absoluynge, Litera tristis, B, as
sygnifyenge condemnynge. Literae fugientes, blind letters, which either in
defaulte of the ynke, or of the parchemente, or for auncientie, may not be
radde. Literarius, a, um, pertaining to letters or sciences. Litterator, oris,
a grammarian, or a master of grammar. Litteratura, grammar. Literosus,
lettred. Litteratus, idem. Liticen, a blower of a small trumpette.
Lythargyrium, lytarge, or white leed. Lithargyrus, a stone of silver.
Lithiasis, the grief of the stone. Lithocolla, a cement, wherewith stones are
joined together. Lithoglyphus, a granour in stones. Lithologema, a heap of
stones. Theophrastus.
Lithospermon, an herb, which has seeds like stoones, and grows among
corn: which herb curethe the stoone of the bladder. Lithostratus, a place
paued with square stoones. Lithotomia, a masons warkhouse, or quarre Litigator,
oris, a stryuer. Litigiosus, a, um, full of strife. Litigium, a debate, or
variance. Litigo, are, to vary, to strive, to sewe one an another. Lito, tare,
to please god with sacrifyce, and to obtain my desire. Littus, toris, the
banks, as well of the sea, as of a great river. sometime land butting on the sea called the sea side. Littoreus, rea, um, and littoralis, littorale, of the sea side. Litura, a blottynge or stryke through that, which is written,
cancellynge. Lituro, are, to blotte or stryke through, or cancelle. Litus, ta,
tum, enoynted. Lituus, a crooked staff, which the diuinours called Augures,
held in their hands, wha^ they appointed places in their divination. Also a
scepter, and a trumpette. Liueo, ere, to be black, to envy. Liuesco, scere,
to envy. Liuidus, a, um, he that has his skyn black with beatynge, also
envious. Liuius, the prince of latin historiens. Liuor, the color, which is
left on the skin, after beatynge or whippynge. Lucanus.
sometime it is taken for envy. Liuor edax tibi cuncta negat, The gnawyng envy
denayeth the all things. Claudius lib. 3.
Rabiem liuoris acerbi Nulla potest placare quies, No quiet can content the
ragynge of bitter envy. Lix, ashes. Lixa, a skullyon, which carries wodde or
water in an host, or to the kychen. Lixabundus, he that for a small reward
does most vile service. Lixinium, lie made of ashes to wasshe clothes clean.
Lixo, are, to whette. Lixos, a town in Africa.
L ANTE O.
LObus, the lap of the ear. Loba, a branch of the grayn called Millium.
Locarium, the hyre of a house or lodgyng. Locatarius, he that lets house or
land, a lessour. Locellus, a little place. Locito, are, to let. Loco, care,
to set or lay, as a house is set in a place, a foundation is laid. Also to
lay up, as a thing is to be kept. Sometime to give in marriage. Also to let
a thing to hyretor to rent, to make a lease. Locator, toris, the lessour.
Locrus, a city in the vttermoste part of Italy, which was named Magna
graecia. Locrenses and locri, people of Locrus. there were also people so named
in Greece. Loculamenta, places made with bourdes, wherein tame culuers, and other
birds or conyes are kept to bread. Loculatus, ta, latum, dyuyded into sondrye
places. Loculus, a little place. Also a purse, an almorie, a little coffer, a
biere, whereon deed bodies are borne to be buried. Locuples, pletis, rich,
abunda^t, sufficient. Locuples fideiussor, a sufficient surety. Locupleto,
tare, to make rich of yerelye revenues. Locus, a place. sometime a family or
kindred. also slede, as Loco patris te habeo, I take the instead of my father.
Loci, plurali numer. the secret parts of a womanne. Locusta, a fly with
long hinder legs, which bourneth corn with touching of it, and deuoureth
the resydue. In India be of them three foot in length, which the people of
that country do eat. It is also a see fish, like to a creuys, called a
lopster. Locutor, cutoris, and loculeius, a prater or a iangler. Lodex, uel
lodix, icis, a sheet. Loedoria, a taunt or reproach in scoffyng. Arifto.
Metheor^^.
Loelaps, a blaste of wind turned from the earth upward. Logica, logike,
one of the lyberal sciences, the c^a^t^ of reasonyng or arguinge. Logion, a
place where iuges give sentence: also a gathering of rent, or other revenues
Logodaedalus, he that speaks craftily to deceive: or in eloquente words
induces sentences vain, or of little purpose. Logomachia, a contencion with
words, or an vnd^^rete altercation. Logos, used for a latin word, is taken
for trifling words, or vain language. Loligo, ginis, a fyshe, which has his
heed between his fete and his bealy: and has also two bones, one like a
knyfe, the other like a pen. Lolium, a wiede growing in corn, called
Cockyll. Longobardia, a regyon of Italye, called Lumbardye. Lombricus, a
lampraye. Lomentum, bean meal. Longa Alba, a city in Italye. Longaeuus,
long lived. Longanimis, he that suffers long. Longanon, a gutte, out of the
which ordure issues. Long, an aduerbe, signifies long, far, exceeding.
Longinquus, a, um, far of, far, strange. Longisco, scere, to be long.
Longitudo, dinis, length. Longobardi, Lumbardes. Longurius, a long pole.
Longus, a, um, long. Longum, a long time. Lopades, a shelle fyshe.
Loquacitas, tatis, babblynge. Loquacito, are, to babble or speak much.
Loquax, cis, a babbler or greatte speaker. Loquela, speech. Loquor, eris, qui,
to speak. Loquitor, tari, to speak much. Lora, sieve lorea, a drink made of
grapes, after that they be pressed, called Second. Loram, servants which
served to bind men, or to beat them, when they were by their masters
commanded. Lorica, an haberion, a place made upon walls like an open galery,
with grates of timber or hurdels, to keep men from falling. It is also the
wall plate, before that mortar is laid on it. Loricatus, armed with an
haberion. Loricatio, wallynge with mortar. Lorico, care, to put on an haberion.
Loricion, a mantell. Loricula, in warfare is a munyme^t or fortification, that
the besigers of cites do make. Loripes, edis, whose fete ar, as if they were
bounden or gyrte. Lorum, a thonge of lether, or a colar, or other like thing,
wherewith beasts are bounden or tied. sometime a whip, wherewith a man or
beast is whypped. Lotaringia, a country between Pycardye and Normandy.
Lotophagi, people in Affrike, which do live by eating only of a fruit, callid
Lotos. Lorium, vryne or pysse. Lotos, and lotis, lotidis, is a notable tree in
Affrike, or herb, of whose fruit if a stranger do eat, he does
incontinently forget his own country. Loxias, one of the names of Apollo.
L ANTE V.
LVbentia, and libentia, myrthe, pleasantnes, most proprely in words. Lubido
pro libido, sensual appetite. Lubrico, care, to make slypper. Lubricus, ca,
cum, slypper, waueryng. sometime ready to slyppe or slide. Luca, a city in
Italye, of which the inhabytantes are called Lucenses. Lucae boues, were taken
of the old latins for Elephantes. Lucania, a countray belongyng to the
royalme of Naples. Lucani, people of the country of Lucania. Lucanica, a
pouddynge made of porke, ^ sawsage. Lucanus, a famous poet, which wrate the
battle between Caesar and Pompeye. Lucar, money bestowid in woddes, dedicat^
to goddis, called Luci. Lucaria festa, feasts, which the Romans made in holy
woddes. Lucellum, a little gain, a small markette. Lux, lucis, light,
sometime it signifies day. Luci, by day. Lucens, that which has his light
of an another thing. Luceo, luxi, lucere, to shine. Luceres, the third part
of the people of Rome, distributed by Catius and Romulus. Luceria, a city of
Apulia. Lucerius, a king of Ardea, which help Romulus against Tatius.
Lucerna, a lantern. Lucernarius, the lantern bearer. Lucernula, a sconse.
Lucesco, scere, to be bright or clear, as day. Lucetius, a name of Jupiter.
Lucetia, one of the names of Juno. Lucibile, that which is light of it self.
Lucido, are, to make clear, or to give light. Lucifico, care, idem. Lucidus,
da, dum, clear. Lucifer, the day sterre. Lucifigus, ga, which flees from
light, and delyteth in darkness. Lucilius, the name of an old poet.
Lucina, one of the names of the moon, called also the goddess of birth.
Lucini, they which have little eyes, and small syghte. Lucius, a man's name.
Lucretilis, an hylle in the countreye of the Sabynes. Lucrifuga, he that flees
from lucre or gains Lucrinus, a mere or great water in Ca^pania. Lucrio, onis,
a covetous manne, an inordynate gayner. Lucror, aris, ari, to gain, or to win. Lucrum, lucre or gain. Lucta, wrastelynge. Luctatius Catulus, a cytesyn
of Rome. Luctiferum, cause of waylynge. Luctificus, ca, cum, idem. Luctitor,
tari, to wrastell often. Luctor, aris, ari, and lucto, are, to wrestle.
Luctuosus, a, um, lamentable. Luctus, tus, weepynge and waylynge, the habyte of
mourning, Lucubro, are, to make any thing by candelle light. Luculentus, ta,
tum, full of light, clear. Lucullus, the name of a noble Romayne. Lucus, a
high and thycke wodde, sometime it signifies light, when it is of the fourth
declination. It is also a city in Spain by Compostella, which is now called
Lucensis. Ludia, a daunsynge wenche. Ludibruini, a mock, or any thing that is
mocked. Ludibundus, a, um, playing, or full of play. Ludicru^, any play or
pastime, or an interlude Ludicrus, cra, crum, pertaining to play or myrthe.
Ludifico, are, to mock. Ludii, and ludiones, players in enterludes or stage
plays. Ludius, and ludio, onis, a player. Ludo, si, dear, to play, to mock
or deceive in game. Opera luditur, The warke or labor is lost. Ludus, play in
acts, mirth in words: also a school or place of exercise. Lusus, us, idem.
Lues, pestilence in men, murrayn in beastis. Lugdunum, a city in France,
callid Lions. Lugeo, luxi, lugere, to mourn, to lamente. Lugubris, bre,
pertaining to mourning. Vestis lugubris, a mourning garment. Luma, a
brembyll. Lumbago, ginis, feebleness of the loins. Lumbare, breeches of hosen.
Lumbrici, worms called easts. Lumbi, the loins. Lumen, luminis, light.
Luminare, that which gives light. Luna, the Moon. Lunaris, re, pertaining
to the moon. Lunaticus, he that is mad or sick at a certain time of the
moon. Lunatus, ta, tum, like the moon. Luo, ere, to suffer punyshement or
death. Luere capite, to have the heed stryken of. Lupa, a female wolf. also an
harlotte. Lupanar, a brothell house. Lupanaris, re, pertaining to a brothel
house. Lupanarium, a brothell house. Lupari, to meddell with common harlottes.
Luparius, a hunter of wolfes. Lupatum, a hard bytte. Lupercal, a place
dedicate to Pan, the god of shepeherdes. Lupercalia, sacrifices and plays made
to Pan. Luperci, minysters of that solemnity. Lupinus, na, number, of a wolf.
Lupinus, a kind of poulse. Lupus, a wolf. Also a bytte for a horse. also a
hoke to draw up things our of a pyt. Also a kind of spyders. Lupus est in
fabula, a proverb, when he comes, which is spoken of. Lupum auribus tenere,
a proverb in things that be dangerous, either to retain, or to let goo.
Lura, the mouth of a bottelle. Luridus, da, dum, pale of color. Lurco, are,
to eat rauenously. Lurco, onis, a deuourer of his own substance Luscinia, a
nyghtyngale. Lusciosus, poreblynd. Luscio is the disease. Luscitus, he that
sees plainly by night. Luscus, porblynde. sommetyme a man having but one
eye. Lusitania, the realm called Portugal. Lusito, tare, to play often.
Lusorius, a, um, pertaining to play. Lustralis, le, pertaining to riot and
lechery. sometime a thing done every fyfte year. Lustrici dies, the day when a
child is first named, which in men chylderne was the nynth day, in womenne
childern it was the viii. day. It may now be used for the day of christenynge
of chylderne. Lustro, are, to go about in circute, to make satisfaction by
sacrifice, to consider in the mind, to shadow, to behold about. Lustror,
aris, ari, to search out. Lustrum, a den or cave of wild beasts in woddes,
an hid place and vile, a house where gluttonye and lechery is haunted, also
the hauntynge of the same vices: sometime it sygnifyeth the space of five
years. Also the general purgation of the city by sacrifice every fyfte year.
Luter, eris, a cup, wherein wine is delayde with water Lutesco, scere, to be
claye. Luteus color, the color of yelowe, approchinge toward read, of the
color of the yolke of an egg, or of wax new made. Luteola, a little flower
of the color of yelowe, in greatness and savor, not much unlike a vyolette.
Luteum oui, the yolke of an egg. Luto, are, to claye. Lutia, sieve lytra, a
beuar, or a beast much like to it, which gnaweth trees asonder. and does
haunte greatte waters, and lives like an Ottar. Lutum, claye. Lux, lucis,
light. Luxo, are, to lowse or make loose. Luxatus, whose bones are out of
ioynte. Luxurio, ire, to excede, to abunde more than is necessary in the body
or personage. Luxurior, aris, ari, to abound excessiuely in things
concerning the mind or goods: Also to be wanton with to much wealth or
prosperity. Luxuriosus, to prosperouse, or living in to much pleasure.
Luxuriosus, a, um, exceeding in abundance. Luxus, luxuria, and luxuries, all
superfluity or excess, as well in carnalle pleasure, as in sumptuous fare,
apparayle, or buyldyng.
L ANTE Y.
LYaeus, one of the names of Bacchus, called god of wynes. Lyceum, was the
