schole of Aristotell in Athenes. Lycaeus, a mountain in the countreye of
Archadia. Lycaon, the king of Archadia, whom Jupiter turned into a wolf.
Lycaonia, a country in Asia: after sum writers, it is a part of Archadia.
Lycaones, people in Asia the less, Ptho. li. 3.
nere to Lycia, as writes Ptolome. Lycastus, a city of Candy. Lychnis, an
herb whose flower shyneth by night, and first springs, and longest dureth:
which in drink helps them that are stongen with the Scorpion. Lychnites,
white marbyll. Lychnobij, they which do turn the day into night, and the
night into day. Lychnus, a match of a candelle, sometime the self candell.
Lycia, a country in the less Asia. Lycidas, the name of a Centaure, and of a
shepeherde in Vergile. Lycion, a thing made with the juice of an herb,
wherewith soore eis be cured. Lycisca, a dog commen of a wolf and a dog.
Lycius, one of the names of Apollo. Lycurgus, a king of the Lacedemoniens,
which gave to them their first laws. Lycus, a river in the countreye of
Caesaria. Lydia, a royalme in Asia the more. Lydus, a, um, of the country of
Lydia. Lyenteria, the flyxe or continual lowsenes of the bealye. Lympha,
water. Lymphaticus, a mad man, which like to a wodde dog, runs hither
and thither. Lympidus, a, um, clear, smothe. Lynceus, was a man, who (as
Varro writes) could see ships on the sea.Cxxx. miles from him, and did
nombre them. And some wrate, that he could see through a wall. And therefore
they, which have very sharp syghtes, be said to have Lynceos oculos, the
eien of Lynceus. Lyndus, a city at the Rodes, where they did sacrifice to
Hercules with reproaches and curses. Lynter, eris, a cockebote. Lynx, cis, a
beast like to a wolf, having many spots, whose sight does perce all
things. It is also a bird, which has a tongue like a serpente. Lyra, an
harp. Lyricen, cinis, an harper. Lysander, a Captain of the Lacedemonyans, a
man contentious, which did set all Greece in the Lacedaemonians top, and was
slain of the Thebans. Lysanias, an orator of Greece. Lysias, an orator most
pleasant, of whom Quint. speaks. Lysimachus, a noble man of Macedony, the
scholar of Callisthenes. Lysippus, an excellent caruer. Lysius, a river of
Archadie. Lytta, a worm in a dogs tongue.
M ANTE A.
MACARIVS, the name of a man. In latin it sygnifieth blessed. Maccabaeus, the
name of certain noble men, which were capitains of the Jews. Macaedonia, a
realm ioinyng to Greece, whereof the great Alexander was king. Macedo, onis, a
man or woman of Macedony. Macedonicus, ca, cum, of Macedonie. Macellarius, a
vittayllour or seller of all manner of vittayle. Macellum, a place where all
manner of vytayle is sold. Macellus is sometime taken for a lean man. Maceo,
and macesco, scere, to be lean. Macer, cra, crum, lean. Maceresco, scere, to
make soft with lyeng long in lycour. Maceries, and maceria, a wall of stone
without mortar, made in the stead of an hedge. also leanness. Macero, are,
spoken of the body, signifies to make lean, or thynne, or soft by steapynge
in lycour: referred to the mind, it sygnifieth to vex or inquiete. Machaera,
a sword. Machaerophorus, a sword bearer. Machaeropios, a Cutlar, or a
bladesmyth^e. Machaon, the son of Aesculapius, an excellent surgeon. Machina,
a thing craftilye invented, or a crafty invention, an engyne. Machinor, aris,
ari, to invent craftily, to deuyse, to ymagine. Macies, and macritudo,
leanness. Apulcius.
Macidatus, ta, tum, wette. Macilentus, lean. Macio, aui, are, to make lean.
Macra, a river, which rounneth between the mountains of Liguria. Macresco,
scere, to wax lean. Macreo, ere, to be lean. Macrobij, people of Aethiopia,
which do live very long. Macrobius, the name of a great learned man.
Macrochie, he that has long hands. Macrochera, a garmente with long sleues.
Macteae, precious meats. Macticus, he, which has greatte chekes, and a
gapynge mouth. Macto, are, to slay or kylle: also to beat, sometime to honor.
Mactra, an hutche, wherein bread is put: some do call it a brake, wherewith
dowe is wroughte. Macte uirtutis and uirtute, proceed in virtue. Macte animi,
be of good courage. Macti ingenio, men of excellent wits. Macula, a spotte, a
blemyshe: Also infamye or reproach. Sometime the masshe of a net or hole
between the thredes: also a net, images wrought in marble. Varro.
Maculo, are, to spotte or make foul. Maculosus, spotty, unclean, or foul.
Madaura, a city set in the bounds of Getulia and Numidia. Madefacio, cere, to
weate, to wash, to bain. Madefio, fieri, to be washed. Madeo, dear, to be
wette or washed. Madesco, scere, to sweat, or be through wet. Madian, a city
beyond Arabia on the south part in the desert of the Sarasyns, against the
cast part of the red see. Madido, dare, to make wette. Madidus, dida,
didum, wete or washed with lycoure. Madifico, facere, to make weate. Mador,
oris, moisture, sometime sweat. Mados, a certain kind of white vynes.
Madulsa, dronken. Maeander, a river of the countray of Phrigia, which has
many tournynges and wyndynges: and of that all crooked and subtle tournynge
ways, means, and deuyses, be called Meandri. There is also of that name a
mountain in India. Maedia, a city in the realm of Thracia. Maee, a kind of
great crabbes of the sea. Maemacrerion, the month of Septembre. Maenala, uel
Maenalus, a high mountain in Archadia. Maenas, adis, a fyshe, which I suppose
we do call a Menowe. Maenades, women, which did always follow Bacchus, with
their hear scatterid like mad women, running hither and thither. Maenoles, one
of the names of Bacchus. Maeonia, is a country in Asia the less, called also
Lidia. Maeonius, a, um, of Maeonia. Homere the excellent poet was named
Maeonius, either because that he was borne in that country, or else that his
fathers name was Maeon. Maeotis, a greatte mere in the country of Scithia,
which is always frosen. Maereo, es, look after in Maereo et Mereor. Maero, are,
to make heavy. Maeror, heuinesse with weeping. Maestit^a, et maestitudo,
heaviness. Maesto, et Maest^sico, care, to make heavy. Magalia, villagis. Magia,
Magike, which is in two sorts, one is the secret knowledge of the natural
qualyties and hid operations and causes of things, and that is called Magia
naturalis, natural magike: A another is superstionie and deuillishe, called
witch craft, sorcery, or other like detestable names, which is unlawful by
the laws of god and man. Magicus, ca, cum, perteynyng to magike. Magidae,
kychen bourdes, or instruments perteynynge to the kechyn. Magida, a kind of
bread. Maginor, aris, ari, to trifle. Magis, more. Magitteriu^, the dignite or
office of a master. Magistrauis, tus, a great offycer, a man having authority
in governance of people. all be it that some have more authority by the laws,
and some have less. Magister populi, the chief ruler of the people, by the
which name the Dictatour among the Romans was called. Magister, tri, a
master or teacher of sciences. Magistro, are, to rule. Magister scriniorum, an
offycer like to the master of the rolls. Magmata, confections made of diverse
sweet spices in paste only for the savor, as pomaundres and washing balls.
sometime it is taken for the dreggis of sweet oils. Magna Graetia, that part
of Italy from Larentum to Cumas. Magnalia, great things to be wondered at.
Magnarius, a great merchant. Magnanimitas, tatis, valiantness of courage or
heart, magnanimity. Magnas, atis, et Magnatus, a noble man, a man of great
estimation. Magnes, etis, an Adamant stone. Magnesia, a part of Macedonia.
Magnifico, are, to extol. Magnificus, he that does great things. Magna, at a
great price. Magnificentia, a disposition and administration in doing or
making of great things and sumptuous. Magnus, a, um, great. Magog, the son
of Iapheth. Maguderis, a kind of Caules called also Laserpitium. Magus,
signifies in the Persiane tongue a wise man, expert also in the mysteries of
their ceremonies, sometime it signifies a witch. Maia, the mother of
Mercurius. Maiestatem constituere, to confirm the astate of princes dignity.
Maiales, barowe hogs. Maiestatem soluere, to lose the preeminence of princes
dignity. Maiestas, tatis, majesty. Maiestatis crimen, mysprision. Maiores,
auncetours, progenitors. Mayor, oris, greatter. Maius, the monthe of May.
Malae, the chekes. Malaca, a city in Spain. Malatia, calm of the Sea, also
the grief of the stomach not susteynyng meat, abhorrynge all things, as a
womanne with child, some do call it the abomination of the stomach.
Malachites, a stone of a dark grene color. Malacisso, are, to knede or make
soft. Malaces, ces, a kind of malowes. Plaut. i^ Epi.
Malacostracha, soft as fish without shelles. Malacus, ca, cum, soft.
Malagma, it is, a mollifienge plaster, whereby hard impostumes be made soft or
ripe. Malasso, are, to make soft or ripe. Also to exercise. Male, ylle,
unhappily, vncommodyousely, myscheuousely Malea, a promontorie or hylle lienge
into the sea by Laconia, which is dangerous for ships to pass by. Male
audire, to be ill reported of, to have an ill name. Male cogitare de aliquo, to
have ill opynion of one. Male accepti, ill handled, ill entreated. Ci. in Ver.
Brutus i^ Cice.
Maledicentia, ill report. Maledico, xi, cere, to curse. Maledicus, ill
tonged. Malefica, a wytche, which with sorcerye does hurt to her neighbors.
Maleficus, a harm doer. Maleficium, and maleficentia, damage, wrong
displeasure, hurt, a myscheuous deed. Malefice, myscheuousely, harmefully. Male
meritus est de me, He has ylle entreated me. Male optare, to curse. Male
accipere, to entreat one ylle. Male accipere uerbis, to give ylle language to
one. Male acceptus, ill entreated, ill handelyd, shrewdely welcome. Male
cadere, to chance ylle. Male conciliatus, cost lost, he on whom a man has
lost all that he has bestowid. Fugitive prodi, male conciliare, Come forth
mycher, on whom I have lost all that thou costest me. Plautus in Amph.
Plautus in Asinar.
Male formido, I am ill or soore aferde. Male me habet haec res, I am sorry or
ill apayde for that mattier: or that mattier greueth me soore. Maleloqui, and
maledicere, to curse. Plaut. in Castle.
Male maceror, I am ill vexed, I am il at ese. Male mereri, to do displeasure.
Male metuo, I am ill aferde. Male moratus, ill manerde. Male morigerus,
disobedient, or froward. Terent. in Adelph.
Male odi, I hate deedly. Male precari, to ask a vengeance. Male ue^tat illi,
God send him yuell luck thereof, ill may he brook it. Male suada, she that
gives shrewed counsel. Malenolentia, malice, ill will. Maleuolus, malyciouse.
Malicorium, the rynde of a pome granade. Malign, enuiously, disdainfully,
maliciously Malignor, and maligno, to bear malice, to be hatefulle. Vergilsus.
Plinius.
Malignus, a, um, wicked, cruel, enuyous, and covetous, maligna uia, an ill
way. Malignus ager, ground that is ylle to be brought to tylthe. Maligna lux,
a dymme light. Malignitas, tatis, wickedness, malignitie, envy, malice,
vnprofytablenesse, the vice contrary to lyberalitie. Malitia, contrary to
virtue and goodness. sometime it signifies subtlety with deceyte. Malitiose,
malyciousely. Malleatus, a, um, hammered. Malleo, are, to warke with an hammer.
Malleolus, a lyttelle hammer. It is also a small boughe or twygge of a vine.
Also Malleoli be sommetyme taken generallye for small sticks. Malleus, an
hammer. Malluuium, and malluuiae, arum, a basyn, where in men do wash their
hands. Malobathrum, a sweet ointment, wherewith men were wont to wash their
hear. Malo, I had leauer, or rather: mauis, mauul. Malobathron, which in
latin is called foliu^, is a sweet herb growing in India, upon waters without
any root. Malta, a clay, which touching any other mattier or substance,
settethe it on fire. Malua, an herb called Mallows. Malus, an appull tree of
the femynyne gender. Malus assyria, nel medica, an orange tree. Malus, in the
masculyne gender, a maste of a ship. Malum, being an aduerbe, Terent. in
Phor^.
sygnifieth with a myschiefe, or like thing. Quid uo^ malum ergo me sic
ludificamini? Than wherefore with a myschiefe do you thus mock me. Quid tua
(malum) id referi? what with a myschiefe reckest thou therefore, or have thou
therewith to do? Malus, a, um, ill, contrary to good: sometime labor, vexation,
sycknesse, grefe, malice. Mamertini, people in Campania. Mamilla, a little
dugge, or pappe. Mamma, a dugge or pappe. Mammare, to give the dugge or breast
to a child. Mammeata, a womanne with greatte dugges or breasts. Mammillare, a
kerchefe, wherewith women do cover their pappes. Ma^mona, in the language of
Syria, worldly substance, richesse. Mammosus, sa, and mammeatus, ta, tum,
Plaut.
having great dugges. Mammothrepius, the child that soucketh long. Mamphula,
a certain bread used in Syria, which ere it be through baken, fallyth into
coals. Mano, are, to drop or stylle out, or run out softly. also to
descend, to proceed. Mana, in the old time, was taken for Bona, good.
Manapia, an Island in the north part of Britannia. Manceps, cipis, he that
byeth or hyreth any thing of the people. Mancinati, persons condemned.
Manciolae, little hands. Mancipium, that which is sole^nely bought before
witnesses. Also a man's propre goods or catell. sometime a bondeman. Mancupi,
the solemn form or manner of byenge any thing before wytnes, by lyuerye and
seyson, or possessyon taking, with other things executed, requysyte for the
assurance of any bargayne and sale. Mancipatio, the assurance by lyuerye and
possessyon. Mancupes, the principal takers of land, or other thing, whereof
grows yearly revenues. Also they, which do take on them to perform any
work in greatte. Mancupio dare, to give or selle a thing with warrantie.
Mancupio accipere, to take a thing with warantie of him, the which gives or
sells it. Mancipi, the interest or right of a thing. Mancipo, are, to
deliver in bondage, to deliver possession, to make lyuery and sayson. Mancipij
sui esse, to be his own manne, and none other man's subject or servant.
Mancipio dare, to deliver possession, reserving a rent. Vi^ruuius.
Mancipio accipere, to take possession or lyuerye and saison. Mancus, lacking
one hand. also generally that, which lacks any thing necessary. Mandatarius,
he to whom commandment is given. Mandatum, a commyssion. Also a
commandment, a charge. Mandatus, ta, tum, given in charge. Mandibula, a
^awebone, wherein the teethe be set. Mando, are, to commit, memoriae
mandare, to remember, to put in remembrance, to leave in memory, or for a
memorial. Mandare aeternitati, to write a thing, to the ^^^ent to be in
perpetual remembrance. Mandare literis, to put in memory. Mandare
siderahcuius, to put a man in trust with a thing. Mandare teriae semina, to
put sede into the ground. Mando, di, dear, to chewe meat, or grynde it with
the tethe. Mando, onis, a great eater, or he that is always eating. Mandra, a
cabin, a shepehouse, or oxehous. Mandragora, an herb called Mandrag, which
bears a little apple: the juice whereof dronken or smellyd to, causes a man to sleep. Manduces, imagis carried about in pagea^tis with great chekes
and wide mouths. Manduco, are, to chewe meat. Manduco, conis, a great eater.
Manducus, idem. Mane, early, also the morning. Maneo, mansi, manner, to
abide, to tarry, to persiste, to happen hereafter. Manner promissis, to keep
promise. Mane dum, tarry a while Mansio, onis, a place to abide in, also a
post place, for conuayinge of letters or other things spedyly. Manes, the
good and badde angel. Some time they be taken for deuylles, sometime for
spyrytes or sowles, not pourged of sin, sommetyme for the peynes, which
souls do suffer. Mango, onis, was taken for a seller of childerne to
abominable uses. It is also taken for such one as polyssheth or paynteth a
thing with a falls color, to selle it the deerer. Mangonicus, a, u^,
pertainynge to that craft. Mangonium, the craft to make things saleable:
Mangonizo, nizare, to polysshe, paynte, or trymme a thing, to make it more
vendible, or to be better sold. Mania, madness. Maniacus, a mad manne.
Maniae, arum, images defourmed. Manibus, pedibusque, with all might and main.
Manibus pedibusque ire in sententia^, is where in a parlyament, greatte
counsel, or other great assembly, to have the consent of many men, the
greatter part consentyng to one man's opinyon or sentence, to goo toward
him, holding up their hands, in token that they be thereunto agreed. Manicae,
sleues of a garmente. Also manacles to tie the hands together. Also gantlettes
and splyntes, and myttaynes, or long gloves. Manichaei, a sect of heritikes,
so called of an Archeherytyque called Manychen. Manicula, a little hand.
Manifestarius, a, um, notoryous. Manifesto, tare, to manyfeste or make
apparaunt. Manifestum, manyfeste or clear. Manifestum habere, to know surely.
Manifestus mendatij, proved a liar. Manifesto, an aduerbe, sygnyfyeth clerelye,
plainly. Manifestatius, a, um, clear, euydente, openly known. Manimoria,
things, which do abide in remembrance. Maniolae, Isles against India,
beyond the river of Ganges, where as be rocks of Adamant stones, which do
draw to them ships that have iron nails. Manipulus, an handefull, a grype,
a bend of men, proprely of ten soldiers. Manipularis, and maniplaris, a
standerd bearer, or baner bearer. Manipulatim, by bendes. Manliana imperia,
cruelle governance or rule, without any mercy. Manlius, a noble Romayne.
Manna, a delycate meat, which god sent to the Jews being in the deserte.
also a sweet dew, which falls in the mornings, and lyethe on leaves
congelyd like white honey, which phisicions do use for a medycine to purge
coler easily. Manna thuris, the powder or duste that comes of frankincense.
Mannus, an amblynge hackeney. Manor, aris, ari, to steal. Mannobarbulus, a
balle of lead to throw. also the caster thereof. Mart. li. 12
Mannulus, a nagge, a little horse. Mansisterna, a pytcher pot. Mano, are, to
run out, as lycour does: also to drop out, to appear out, as sweat out of
the poores. Mansio, one days journey. Manstus, stolen. Mansito, tare, to
abide long. Mansuesco, scere, to wax tame or gentle. Mansues, for mansuerus.
Mansuetudo, dinis, mekenes, gentylnesse, a moderate temperance betwixt pride

gentylly. Mansum, meat, which the nourices do chewe, and after give it to
the child, putting it into his mouth. Vestus.
Mansutius, a great eater: also ripe and apt to be eaten. Mansus, a, um,
chewed. Mantaelum, and mantaelium, and mantile, a towel wherewith men do wype

dyuels in ydolles gave aunsweres. Manthicora, a beast which is in India, in
body like to a lion, but more rough, having a face like to a man, and in his
mouth.ii. rewes or set of teeth, the rail of a scorpio^, and the voice of a
small trumpette: and is of color read, and will never be made tame. Mantica,
a bag, sometime a cloak. Manticula, a purse. Manticularius, a stealer of
napry, also a pike pours, or cut pourse. Manticularia, towels or other like
thyngis wherewith men do wype their hands. Manticulor, aris, ari, to do a

city in Greece. Mantis, a prophet. Mantiscinor, aris, ari, to stele or pike
craftily. Mantissa, the addition in weight. Manto, tare, among the old writers
to abide. Mantua, a noble city in Italy, where Vergile the excellent poor was
borne. Mantuanus, a, um, of Mantua. Mantuari^^ tunicae, sleuyd iackettes.
Manuarius, a, um, manual. Manubiae, the pray taken of ennemies: also money,

sueth a another. Manum ferulae subducere, to learn as scholars do in the

thing, whereunto we make title. Mapalia, cotages builded round like oue^s.

Sec. Mare coelo miscere, to trouble all the world. Marcipor, oris, the servant

round and white. Margarita, margaritum, margarites, margaris, garidis, a
perle, a Margarite: sometime generally all preciouse stones are called
Margaritae. Plinius.
Margaritarius, a seller of perles. Margariteferus, ra, rum, that which bears

kind. Masculo, are, to make manly, or strong. Masdoranus, a mountain, which
diuydeth Parthia from Aria. Massagetae, a people in Asia, which rounnynge on
horseback through deserts, do drink their horses bloudde myxte with milk,
they also do eat their parents, if they die for age: but if they be sick,
they cast them to wild beasts to be devoured. Massinissa, king of Numidia,
and great friend to the Romans. Massica, a country in the southe part of
Spain. Massicus, a mountain in Campania. Massilia, a cite in high France,
callid Marsiles. Massiliensis, se, of Marsiles. Massylia, cum y, a countreye in

Mastigophorus, a fellow worthy to be whipped. Also certain ministers, which
with whyppes removed the people, where there was much prease. Mastos, a teate.

cunning in aulgryme, musyke, geometry, and astronomy. Mathesis, and mathema,
lernyng by a demonstracyon. Matralia, the solemn feasts of Matuta, called the

kylleth his mother. Matrimonium, wedlock, matrimony. Matrix, cis, the mother
or matrice in a woman, in the which the child is conceived. also matrix is
any female kind that concenieth and bears. Also the city in a country,
where as is the archbishops see is called matrix vrbs, which in greek is
callid Metropolis. Matrona, a wife. also the name of a river in Burbon.
Matronalis, pertaining to a wife. Matruelis, the son or daughter of my
mothers sister. Matta, a matte. Mattiacae pilae, soap balls. Mattiacum, a
town in Germanye. Plaut. in Milite.
Matura aetas, full or perfyte age. Maturate, quickly. Iube marurate illam
exire huc, Bid her come for the quickly. Mature, tymely, nor to soon, nor to
late. Maturesco, scere, to be ripe. Matutitas, tatis, rypenes in all thing,
and as it were perfection. Maturo, are, to make ripe or perfyte, to do a thing
perfectly in due time and measure: sometime to do a thing spedily or quickly.
Maturus, a, um, ripe, perfect, sometime it signifies aged. Maturus homo, an
aged man. Matuta, the morning, or morrow. Matutinus, a, um, of the morrow.

was accou^tid to be one of the meruailes of the world, and for the famousnes
thereof, every great and notable sepulcher is callid Mausoleu^ Maxilla, the cheke
bone. Maximus, a, u^, greatest, or most in estimation. Maximates, the greattest
men in authority. Maximitas, tatis, ancient writers used for greatness.

hill callid Argeus, now called Cesaria. Mazeras, a river in the mouth of the sea, called mare Hircanum. Mazononiu^, a platter wherein meat is carried

MEapte, mine own. Meatus, tus, a passage, a way. Mecastor, a form of
swearynge, as who says, so Castor help me. Mechanicus, a crafts manne.
Mechanica ars, a handy craft. Mecoenas, aris, minion to Augustus the emperor,
and because he was the supporter of great learned men, all favorers and
succourers of learned men be so called. Meconis, a kind of letuse, which
causes a man to sleep. Mecon, in greek, is popye in english. Mecu^, with me.
Mecu^ facit, it makes for my purpose. Mecu^ sentit, he is of min opinion.
Medea, wife unto Jason, a witch and cruelle womanne. Medela, remedy by
medicine. Mederga, for erga, toward me. Medeor, eris, eri, to heal or cure.
Media, a region in Asia. Media vocabula, words which may be taken in a good
or ylle part, as tempestas which signifies tempest and time, facinus, a
notable deed good or ylle, ualitudo, health, or syckenes, and other like.
Medianus, na, nu^, that which is in the middle. Mediastinus, a drudge or lubber,
which does in the house all manner of vile service, as swepe or cleanse the
house, carry wodde to the kytchen, and other like drudgery. Budeus.
Mediastimus, a, um, the myddelmoste. Mediastrinus, the servant, which has
the rule of the house under his master. Medica, an herb, which specially
nourysheth horses, and ones being sown, eftesones springs ten years
continually, and commonly it is called Sylla. Medibile, in state to be healed,
curable. Medicabilis, le, curable. Medicamentarius, a phisycion.
Medicamentarius, a, um, pertaynyng to medicyne. Medicina, medicamen,
medicame^tum, a medicine. sometime it sygnifieth poison. Medicinalis, le,
medicynable. Medico, and medicor, aris, ari, to hele or cure. Medicus, a
phisytion. Medicus, ca, cum, pertaining to phisike. Medimnus, a certain measure
of corn, co^taynynge six times the measure called modius. Vide modium.
Mediocris, dlocre, measurable, in a mean, moderate. Mediocritas, tatis, a
mean. Mediolanum, the chief city of Lombardy, called Myllayne. Medioximus,
a, um, mean, or in the mids Medipontus, an instrumente, wherewith ropes are
made. Meditabundus, cerefull, studiouse. Meditarise, to exercise him self.
Meditate, studiousely, Plautus in ^tich. in Bacch,
perfectelye on the fyngers ends. Meditatio, a thinking or dyuysynge in
thought. also an exercise, as well of mind, as of body. Meditatorius, a, um,
which belongethe to medytation. Mediterraneus, in the myddel of the land, and
furthest from the sea. Meditor, aris, ari, to think deeply, and in thinking
to find out, to purpose, to lay snares, to sing or play swetely. Meditrina,
the goddess of phisyke. Meditrinalia, ceremonies used by them, which drank
must or new wine. Meditullium, the myddell. Medius, a, um, the mids equally
distant from the extremytes. sometime mean. Medium commune, among all.
Medius, a mean or mediator between.ii. men. Medius fidius, an oath, which
although sometime it had a another signification, yet may it now in a commune
form of speaking be used in this wise, by the faith of my body: sens Dius
for Jupiter, and fidius for filius, be now out of use. Meduacus, a River
about Venyce, called now Brent. Medulla, marowe, which is in bones. Plaut.
Medullo, are, to take out marowe, sometime to express utterly. Narraiam rem
nobis omnem, atique emedulla, Tell and express utterly to us all the hole
matter. Medullitus, innerly into the marowe. Medusa, a lady, of whom fables do
report, that her hears by Minerua were turned in to adders, and they which
beheld her were turned into stones: whom Perseus afterward slew. she is
sometime taken for one of the furtes of hell. Melansilium, a certain weapon to
throw. Maegabizi, priests of Diana, which always were gelded. Megaera, a
fury or turmentour of hell, which Paynyms supposed did provoke and ^^ere men
to woodnes. Megalesia, the festiual day, dedicate to Cybele, called the mother
of gods among Paynyms. Megalenses, and megalesia, plays to the honor of
Cybele. Megalium, a sweet oyntement. Megalop^epeia, an honorable facyon in
gyuynge or imployeng of great things, which besemeth a man of great courage.
Megaloprepes, he that does great things according to his dignity. Megara, a
City belonging to Athenes. It was also the name of oone of Hercules wives.
Megaris, idis, a country in Achaia. Megistanes, whom we do call nobles or
pieres of the realm. Mehercle, an oath sworn by Hercules. Meio, iere, to
pysse. Mel, mel is, honey. Mellene, a city in Arcadia. Melampus, a man's name.
Melamphyllon, an herb. Melancholia, melancolye. Melancoryphus, a bird called
a fynche. Melanthia, an herb called also Nigella. Melamirus, a fyshe having a
black tail. Plini.
Melandria, the lean parts of the fish called Tunny. Melculum, a wanton
word spoken by lovers unto their paramours, my litel honey. Meleagrides,
birds, which we do call hens of Genny. Melegina, an isle in the Venecian
see. Melenetus, a kind of faukons very little of body, black and puissant,
which haunteth mountains, and feeds her birds alone, a merlyon as I
suppose. Maelibeus, a shepardes name. Meliboea, a city in Thessaly. Meliceris,
idis, a soore or skalle in the heed like a honey comb, out of the which comes
an humor like honey. Melicraton, wine and honey sodden together. Melicerta,
whom the gentyls did honor for one of the gods of the sea. Melicus, a
musycyan. Melilotos, an herb called melilote. Melimela, sweet appulles.
Melina, a sweet shalme. Melinus, na, number, white russette, or a gynger color.
Melioresco, scere, to be better. Melipecta, meats made with honye. Melis, seu
melius, a beast called a graye, a brocke, or a badger. Melisphillon,
smallache. Melissa, a woman, who with her sister Amalthea, nourysshed Iupyter.
It is also an herb, commonly called baume. Melite, sieve melita, an I Will lyeng
between Italy and Epirus. Also a city made by the Carthaginensis. Melitites, a
drink made of honey and must, or new wine. Mellitones, places where bees be
norished. Melitaei canes, and melitenses, were praty littel hounds, in the
which ladies took pleasure and delight, which were brought out of the said isle
of Melite. Melites, a precious stone of the color of an orange. Melissus, the
name of him, which did first sacrifice unto ydolles. also the name of an
auuncient philosopher. Mellium, a dogs coler. Mellarius, a honey man, or
sellar of honey. Mellarius, a, um, of honye. Mellatio, the time of driuynge of
hyues, when honey is taken out. Mellanu^, new must, wherein honey is sodden.
Mellifico, care, to make honey. Mellificatio, making of honye. Mellificum,
idem. Mellifluus, a, um, sweet as honye. Melligo, ginis, a mell dew, which
falls on leaves of trees, and sometime on corn. Melliloquus, a sweet
speaker. Melilla, my honey, my sweetynge, a word of wanton dalyers. Mellisones,
they which do practyse dressynge of honye. Melliturgus, a warker or maker of
honey. Mellitus, a, um, myxte with honye. Melitus, the name of him, which
accused Socrates. Melizonum, a confection made with honye clarifyed. Apitius.
Melleus, a, um, of honey. also sweet, as Vox mellea, a sweet voice. Mellica, a
kind of poulse, of the color of read, of the form of Mylle. Melo, a river
called also Geon. Melodia, melodye. Melodes, he that syngeth cunnyngely, and
swetely. Meloessa, an isle by Sicile, in the which was great plenty of sheep.
Melomeli, when apples, very ripe and fair, be conserved in honey. Mellonia, uel
Melona, called the goddess of honye. Melos, odis, melodye, armonye. Melora,
and melote, a shepes fell or skin. Melpomene, one of the nine Musis.
Membrana, parchement or velume, wherein men do write, also the ouermoste skin
of any thing. Membrosus, a, um, having a great membre. Membraneus, a, um, the
par hemente or velume. Membranulum, a small membre. Membrare, to form
members. Membratim, by every membre. Me^bratura, the setting or order of
me^bres. Membrum, a membre. Memet, my self. Memini, I remember. Memerylus, a
lyttel tree like a citron tree. Me^non, the son of Thiton, which came to the
aid of the Troyans. Me^noniae aues, birds, which were supposed to grow of
the ashes of Me^non. Memor, oris, he that remembers. Memorabilis, le, worthy
remembrance. Memoratus, tus, et Memoratio, a remembrynge. Memoria, memory,
remembrance. Memoriale, a thing, which should be remembered. Memoriosus, he
that has a good memory. Memoriter, parfitely by heart, or with good
remembrance. Memoro, are, to remember, sometime to tell, or expound, to recite
or rehearse. Memphis, a great city in Egypt. Memphiticus, of that city.
Memphe, idem. Mena, a little fyshe, black in semer, and white in winter.
Menechmi, the name of a comedy of Plaut. Menalippa, queen of Amazon, whom
Hercules vaynquished. Menapij, people of the country called Gellarlande, or
Gylderlande. Menander, a famous poet, a writer of comedies. Menaria, an I Will
in the sea between Carthage and Sicile. Menceps, he or she, which is out of
her wit. Menda, et Mendum, a fault or vice in writing. Mendarium, a lie.
Mendaculum, a little fault or lie. Mendax, acis, a liar. Mendicabulum,
beggynge. Mendaciloquus, a teller of lies. Mendicitas, tatis, et Me^dicimoniu^,
beggary. Mendico, are, to beg. Mendicula, a certain vesture. Mendicus, a
beggar. Mendix, an office among the old Italyans called Osci. Meneletus, a
bird like to a small egle. Memana aedificia, building outewarde in prospectes
or galeries. Menix, an I Will against the less Africa. Men's, it is, the highest
and chief part of the mind. Mensa, a table or bourd to eat on. sometime
dinner or soupper. Mensarius, the banker or exchaungeour, of whom men do borow
money upon gain, called exchange. Mensio, a measure. Mensis, a month.
Menstrualis, and menstruus, a, um, pertaynyng to a monethe. Menstruatus, ta,
tum, that which has flowers like to women Menstruum, a woman's natural
purgation called flowers. Menstruus, a, um, that which happens every month.
Mensura, a measure. Mensurnus, a, um, monthly. Menta, et Mentula, the preuye
membre of a man. Mentagra, a dyssease, which covers all the face with a
skurfe. Mente captus, a mad manne. Mentha, an herb called mynte.
Menthastrum, wild mynte. Mentibor, for mentiar, I shall make a lie. Plaut.
Mentigo, a dyssease, which infectith beasts with scabbes about their
mouths and lyppes. Mentior, iris, iri, to lie. Mentoas, the famous river,
which is now called Danubius. Mentor, an excellent grauour of vessel. Mentum,
a chynne. Menus, a river in Germany. Meo, are, to go, to flow. Sidonius.
Meo nomine, for my cause, on my behalf. Mephiucus, ca, cum, stynkynge.
Meatus, condutes or ways, whereby any humor flows. Mephitis, a stenche or ill
savor, which proceeds of corrupt water or licour, mixed with earth. Meopte
ingenio, by mine own wit. Meracus, ca, cum, et Merax, racis, pure without any
mixture. Vinum meracum, wine without any water. Mercalis, le, Vendible, or
that, which may be bought. Mercator* oris, every byar, a merchant. Mercatura,
the feate of marchaundyse. Mercatus, tus, the act of byinge. Mercatus, ti, a
market, or fair. Mercatus, ta, tum, bought. Mercenarius, an hired servant.
Mercenarius, a, um, that which may be hired. Merces, cis, marchaundise, ware,
chaffer. Merces, cedis, wages, the reward of labor or service. Mercimonium,
that which is turned in byenge and selling. Mercor, aris, ari, to bye for to
sell for gaynes. sometimes to bie generally. Mercurialis, an herb called
mercury. Mercurius, was of the paynimes called god of Eloquence, and messager
of Jupiter, it is the name of one of the seven planettes. Merda, the excrement
or ordure of a man or beast. Merdo, are, to expel or cure. Merenda, meat
eaten at after noone, a collataion, a none m^le. Mereo, ere, et Mereor, eri, to
take wages, to deserve, to exercise a vile occupation. Mereor been de te, I do
somewhat for the, I d^serue to have the my friend, or to have thy favor. Male
mereor de te, I do the displeasure, I do ill deserve thy favor. Also Merere,
to serve in wars. Merere stipendia, to take wagis as a souldyour, or to be a
soldier. Plautus in ^ilite.
Meretricie, hoorishely. Meretricius, hooredome, or brothelry. Meretricium, a,
u^, perteyning to brothelry. Meretricor, aris, ari, to live in brothelry, to
play the harlote. Mere, purely. Meretrix, icis, an harlot, or brothell.
Mergae, pitcheforkes for to take up sheues. Mergites, gripes of corn. Mergi,
vines, or other small trees, which ar bowed and have the tops bow wise
turned and set into the earth. Mergo, si, gere, to drown in the water.
Mergulus, an instrument where the match of a lamp is contained. Mergus,
goris, a bukket to draw up water. Mergus, gi, a waterfoule called a dyue
doppar, some do call it a foul of the sea like to a gull, which dyueth under
the water to take fish. Meribibulus, he that drynketh much wine without water.
Meridies, noonetyde. Meridianus, a, um, perteynyng to none. Meridio, are, et
Meridior, ari, to dyne, to eat meat at noone, to sleep at none. Meridiatio,
noone rest. Merismos, a figure called also dystributio, whereby the oration is
distributed into so^dry sentences. Merito, worthily, with good cause. Merito,
are, to be worthy, also to serve in wars. Meritorius, a, um, that which is
let or set for advantage. Meritoria taberna, a house wherinto a man is
received for his money. Meritoria, howses or shoppes let to hyre. Meritum, a
benefit, a deserte good or ylle. Meritus, ta, tum, deserved, convenient.
Meritus, a mountain in the third part of Europa beyond Greece. Meroe, an isle
on the great river of Nilus in Egipte. Mero, was in scorn the name of Nero,
because he was so great a drynker of wine. Merobiba, she that drynkethe wine
without water. Merops, a bird which does eat bees. Meroctes, a little stone
of the color of leekes, which sweateth a lyckour like to milk. Meropes, men
of diverse languages. Meropus, a mou^tain in Greece by Thessaly. Meros, a hylle
of Inde, at the foot whereof is the city called Nisa. Merso, are, to drown
often. Merto, idem. Merula, a bird. Merum, wine vnlayde, without water. Merus,
a, um, soole, mere, pure. Merx, cis, one kind of marchandyse. Mesa, a river
which runs by Braband and the land of Luke and Gellar, called the Mase.
Mesapia, a country called also Apulia. Mesauli, entrees between the haule and
the parlour. Mesia, a Country ioynynge to Hungrye, Myse. Mesochorus, he that
plaieth on a flute or other pype in the mids of the daunsers. ^udeus.
Mesonauta, a drudge in a ship, or a ship page, which does all vile service
in the ship. Mesoleucos, a preciouse stone, black, having a white struck in
the mids. Mesomelas, a white stone, having a black line in the mids.
Mesonyxion, midnyght. Mesopotamia, a countreye lyinge between the two greatte
ryuers Euphrates, and Tigris. Mespilus a medlar tree. Mespilum, a fruit called
a medlar. Messala, a noble orator of Rome. Messalina, wife to the emperor
Claudius a woman of insatiable lechery. Messana, a city in Sicile. Messene, a
city in Greece. Messiah, Christ. Messis, harvest, sometime it sygnifieth the
corn or the grapes new mowen or gathered. Messio, onis, a reapynge Messor,
oris, a reaper. Messorius, messoria, rium, perteynynge to reapynge. Meta, a
but, or prick to shote at, sometime a mark or gowle in the field, where unto
men or horses do run, sometime a bound in lands. Also a reyke of corn or
heye, also the lower part of a myll. Meta lactis, a Chese. Metabasis, a
passage. Metabole, change. Metagonium, a promontory or mountain lyinge into
the sea, which divides Africa fro Numidia. Metalepsis, a figure, whereby a
word is put from his commune signification. Mettalli, hired soldiers.
Metallici, they which do dygge and warke metal out of the mines, wherein
metal is found. Metallum, mettalle. Metamorphosis, cos, a transformation or
chaungynge of figure. Metaphora, a translation of words from their propre
sygnifycation. Metaplasmus, a figure called transformation. It is a translatyng
of words being in prose into a form of meter, either for necessity, or to
augmente the elegancye. Metapontu^, a city in the realm of Naples.
Metempsychosis, the transposyng of souls after the opinion of the
Pythagoriens, out of one body into an other body. Metathesis, where one letter
is transposed from one place in a word into an another as Timber Tymbre.
Metaurus, et metaurum, a river of Vmbria, which runs into Flaminia.
Metellus, the propre name of diverse noble Romans. Meteoria, speculation in
high things. Meteorologus, he that is studious in such speculation. Meteora,
are books of Aristotle, wherein he treats of sterres, and such other
celestial things. Meteoroscopus, a beholder of high thingis Methodus, a
compendious or ready way, or a rule certain to learn by any science. Metonymia,
a figure called denomination, as Bacchus for wine, Venus for lechery, Cupido
for love. Methymna, a city in the isle of Lesboe. Meticulosus, temerouse or
fearful. Metior, tiris, tiri, to mete or measure, to give by measure, to
pass over. Meto, messui, metere, to reap. Metona, a town in Greece called
Modon. Metor, aris, ari, to set bounds, to measure land, to dispose.
Metopion, oil of almondes, also a tree in Africa, which destylleth down
gum like to rosyn. Metoposcopus, he that consydereth a ma^s face, and thereby
judges his condycions or affectes. Metreta, a measure for lyckour, which is
also called Amphora, and contained every way square one foot. Metropolis, the
chief city. Metropolitanus, a man of that city. Metropolites, the bishop of
the chief city. Metrum, a verse. Metuo, tui, tuere, to fear or dread with
trembling. Metus, tus, fear, dread. Metys, the refuse, of wax. Meu, an
herb. Meuani^, a city in the part of Italy, called Vmbria, wherein Propertius
the poet was borne. Meneuia, a city in wales called saint David. Meus, a,
meum, mine. Meum est, it is my duty or my part.
M, ANTE I.
MI, to me. Mica, a crumme of bread. Mico, care, to glisten, or shine. Diggnus
qui cu^ in tenebris mices, is applied to one, which is reputed to be an
honest man, and a trusty, which will keep touch and deceive no man. It may be
this wise translated, in a commune form of speaking, He is one, with whom
thou may assuredly bargayne. also to hold up now one finger, now two, as
men do when they trete or bargain together by signs. Miconium, an herb
called Popy. Microcosmas, a little world. Micrologia, curiosity about
things of no valor. Micrologus, a little communication. Micropsichia, feeble
courage, faint hearted. Micropsichi, they which have faint hartis. Micturio,
ire, to pysse. Mictytis, poor folks potage. Mida, a worm bredynge in beans.
Midas, a king of Phrigie, who excellyd all other in richesse. Miaesa, a town
in Macedonia. Mig^o, are, to remove from one place, to dwell in an other.
Miles, mi^^tis, a man of war, a soldier. Mil^^pte, Cato used for mihi ipsi.
Miletus, a city in Greece. Milesius, a, um, of that city. Militatis tua, the
high way. Militariter, warrely. Militia, war. sommetyme the exercise of
war. Milito, tare, to goo on warfare, or to be in wars. Milium, a small
grain called Myll. Mill and millia, a thousand. Millepeda, a worm having a
great number of feet. Millearium, a mile, also a cawdron, also a pyller in
Rome, wherein was graven all the ways of Italye. Milliarius, a, um, of a
thousand weight. Millies, a thousand times. Millus, a mastyues colar, made of
lether with nails. Milo, onis, the name of one, which at the game of Olimpus,
with his bare hand, slew a bulle, and after carried him a furlonge, and the
same day eat him every morsel. It was also a noble Romayne, for whom Tullie
made an oration, containing incomparable eloquence. Miluina tibia, a cornette,
or small shaulme. Miluus, and miluius, a kyte. There is also a fyshe and a
sterre of the same name. Miluinus, na, number, of a kyte, or like a kyte.
Mimallones, women dedicate to the folishe ceremonies of Bacchus. Mimas, a
mountain of Thracia. Mimus, a bourder or rayler, which in mocking other men
in gesture and countenance, does follow them, faynynge to be the same
persons, whom they do reprove. Mimi, be verses counterfaytynge much
wantonness without any reverence, having not withstanding sum wise sentences
myngled therewith. Mimicus, ca, cum, of such wanton facion. Mimographus, a
writer of such wanton matters. Mina, and mna, was the pound of Athenes, which
in weight contained.lxxv. dragmas: in money it contained a hundred dragmas or
old poyse grotes, whereof.viii. went to one ounce. Minae, arum, thretenynges.
also battylmentes of walls. Minax, acis, full of thretnynges. Minaciter,
thretnyngly. Mincius, a river of the Venecians. Minei, people in Arabia, nigh
to the red see Minera, and mineralia, are of sum used for mines, out of the
which metal is dug. Minerua, called goddess of doctrine and wysedom, which
was also named Pallas. Minerual, and mineruale, a reward given sometime by
scholars unto their masters, in meat or drink. Mingo, gere, to make water,
to pysse. Miniacius, a, um, read, of sinople color. Minime, and minimum,
lest. minime gentiu^, lest in all men's opinions. sometime minime signifies
no, in no wise. minime doctus unlearned. minime sapiens, unwise. minime mirum,
little marvel. Minio, are, to dye read. Miniati libri, limned books, having
letters of diverse colors. Minister, tri, a servant. Ministerium, service,
sometime generallye all warke. sometime ministeria be serua^tis. Ministro, are,
to serve, to give a thing in doing service. Minor, aris, ari, to thrette.
Minitor, aris, ari, to thrette soore. Minium, Synople or read lead. Minius, a
river in Spain. Minoa, the name of a city in Sycile, of an other in the i will
called Amorgos, by Sicile Minos, was the king of Crete, and gave to them
laws, whom paynyms for his excellent justice, supposed to be chyefe Judge of
hell. Minthos, bunge or ordure. Minotaurus, was a monster kept in Crete,
half a man, half a bulle. Minturnae, a city in Campania. Minuo, ere, to
mynishe. Minurizo, are, to sing small, or to feyne in singing. Minus, less.
Minutal, a meat made with chopped herbs, a iussell. Minutarius, a sellar of
tryfles or small haberdashe ware. Minutatim, piece mele, in gobettes. Minutim,
idem. Minutia, the smallest thing that may be seen. Minutus, a, um, minished.
Minyae, a town in Thessalia. Miniariae, mines, they be also veins of metal,
out of the which is taken synope. Mira, wonders or meruayles. Mirabilis, le,
meruaylous, wonderful. Miraculum, a miracle, a thing exceeding nature, or
commune reason. Mirifico, care, to make wonderful. Mirificus, ca, cum,
wonderfully done, mervaylouse. Mirmeciae, wertes in the privy parts.
Mirmillones, chalengers at fighting with swords. Miror, aris, ari, to
marvel, to like a thing. Mirum in modum, in a meruaylouse facion.
Misanthropos, he that hates the company of men. Miscellanea, a myxture of
diverse things. Vide compo^.
Misceo, cui, scere, to myxe or meddyll together, to confound together, to
trouble or to do a thing out of order or reason, sometime it sygnyfyeth to
serve one with drink. Misellus, a little wretch. Miser, eri, a wretch,
sometime innocent. Miserabilis, le, miserable, wretched, lamentable.
Miserabiliter, miserably, lamentably. Miserandus, to be pitied. Miserator, he
that does an act of charytie on him whom he pytieth. Misericors, dis,
merciful. Misere, miserably, pitiousely, vnhappyly. Misere, amat, he loves
excedyngely. Miserior, eris, misereri, to have pity. Miseresco, scere, to be
moved with pity. Miseret me, I have pity. Miseretur, I am moved with pity.
Miseria, misery, infelicitie. Miseritudo, idem. Misericordia, pity.
Misericorditer, pitiefully. Miseriter, miserably. Miseror, aris, ari, to have
pity. Misogynia, an hater of women. Missenus, an hill in Campania. Missiculo,
are, to send often. Missile, all thing that is thrown. Missilia, things
which the ancient emperors were wont to cast among the people, as bread,
cakes, sweet oynteme^t, and such like things, which was done in the Theater,
in the feasts, called Saturnalia. Missio, a message, also leave to depart.
Missito, tare, to send often. Missus, a, um, sent. Missus, us, a course, when
one thing comes in a distance after a another, a turn. Missum facere, to
omit or pass over a thing, also to give leave to depart. Mitellum, a lyttel
miter. Mitis, mite, mieke, simple, quiet. Mitesco, scere, to wax tame or
quiet, sometime to wax ripe. Mithra, the Persians do call the son, and also
the chief priest of the son. Mithrax, a stone of the color of a rose, but
against the son he is chaungeable. Mithriaca sacra, ceremonies of the son.
Mithridates, a puissaunt king of Ponthus in Asia. Mithridaticum, a medicine
like to tryakle, called Mitridate. Mithylenae, aru^, a city in the i will of
Lesbos. Mitigo, are, to mitigate, to swage. Mitifico, to pacifye or make
quyete. Mitra, a myter. It was also attire of womennes heedes. Mitto, misi,
mittere, to send, to leave or lay aparte, to give. Mirtere sanguinem, to let
bloudde. Mittesanguis, a bloudde lettyng, or a bloudshede. Mitterin, an Iyle
six days saylynge out of England, wherein is greatte plenty of tynne.
Mittas frenum affectibus, Brydelle thine affections. Mitte hunc ire, Let him
goo. Mitte hanc noxiam, Forgive me that fault. Cice. pro Cluencio. Asc. Ped.
Mittere in consilium, to let the iuges depart to give sentence, after that
the orator has finished his oration, or the lawyer his plee. Mixtarius, a
cup, wherein wine is alayde with water.
M, ANTE N.
MNa, idem quod mina. Mnemosyne, memory. Mnesterae, wowars. Mnestheus, the name
of a Troyane.
M, ANTE O.
MOab, a city of Araby. also the name of oone of the sons of Loath, of whom
the people are called Moabtae. Mobilis, le, mouable, sone moved. Moderatus, ta,
tum, moderate, temperate. Moderator, oris, a gouernoure, Modero^, aris, ari, et
Modero, are, to govern, to rule, to set a measure in things, to moderate.
Moderatio, moderation, temperaunce. Modestia, modesty, temperaunce. Modeste,
temperately, sobrely, advisedly. Modetius, temperate, well advised. Modialis,
le, that which contains a bushel Modi^us, ca, cu^, which excedeth not,
measurable, sometime little or few. Modi^e, meanly. Modif^cor, caris, cari,
to take the measure of a thing. Modiolus, a buckette, where with water is
drawn out of a well: or a pot fastened to a whele, which brings up water,
and pours it out. Modiparatores, men ordained to see measure kept. Modius, a
bushel: it was proprelye a measure of day things, which contained.xvi.
Sextarios, vide postea in sextario. Modo, new, now late, sometime it
signyf^^th so that. Non resert, modo id faciat, It makes no mattier, so that
he do it, also ^^^ly. Modo nostro, after our facion. Modulor, aris, ari, to
make or do a thing by number and measure, also to sing. Modulus, et
Modulamen, a song, a modulation, the time in singing. Modus, manner, measure,
furme, facion, way, quantite, Ci. ad At. Columel.
end. Etsi nihil scripsit, nisi de modo agri, although he wrote nothing but of
the quantity of the field. Moechor, aris, ari, to commytte auoutry. Plautus in
Castle.
Moechus, an auoutrer, or lechour. Moechisso, are, to commytte auoutry. Moenia,
walls of a town or castle. Plautus in bacch.
Moenitus, ta, tum, walled. Moereo, ere, to be sorrowful. Moero, are, to make
one sad and heavy. Moeror, oris, sorrow. Moestitia, idem. Moesta, a province
in Asia nygh to Pontus. Moestiter, heuyly, sorowfully. Moero, are, to make one
sorye. Moesius, a, um, sorry or sorrowful. Moesio, are, Moestifico, care, to
make sorrowful. Moga, a countreye in Asia, called now Cesaria. Moguntia, a
noble City in Germany, called Mense. Mola, a myl, it is also a great piece of
flesh without shape, grown in a woman, which causes them sometime to think,
that they be with child, it is also a cake made of mele and salt. Molaris, a
cheke tothe. Molaris, re, et Molarius, ia, um, perteyning to a myll.
Molendinarius, ia, um, idem. Molarius equus, an horse, which dryueth about a
malte myll. Molendinarius, a myllar. Moles, a thing that is very greatte and
weightye: sommetyme it is taken for diffycultie. Molestia, grief. Molesta
tunica, a garment which was myxt with some matter, which gathered fire, put
on some persons that should suffer death. Moleste, greuousely. Molesto, are,
to grieve, to offend, to do displeasure to one. Molestus, a, um, that which
greueth, offends, or discontenteth. Moletrina, a mortar or querne, wherein any
thing may be ground with the hand. Molimen, et molimentum, that which we
go about and endeavor us to do. Molior, iris, iri, to move, to be moved, or
styrted to do a thing. moliri classem, to prepare a navy. moliri iter, to
perform a iourneye. moliri habenas, to rule. moliri insidias, to lay snares,
to lay in awayte. Moliri arcem, to build a fortress. Moliri bellum, to make
war. Moliri is sometime to deuyse or invent, also to go about to do a thing,
to make, to be tarried or let. Moliri mora^, to tarry. Molitor, oris, a myllar.
Mollesco, scere, to wax soft, to be pacified from wrath. Molestra, a shepes
fell. Mollicies, et mollicia, softness, tenderness, delicateness,
womanlynesse. Mollicina, fine clothe or silk. Molliculus, la, tender delycate,
Mollifico, to make soft or tender. Mollio, ire, to make soft or tender, to
pacific or appayse, to make wanton or tender. Mollis, soft, tender. molle
ingenium, a wit which lyghtely takes. mollis homo, a man effemynate, or
womanly, not hardye or constant of wit, inuolued an wanton pleasures and
sensual appetite, sometime mollis sygnifieth ripe, also remiss, sometime
pleasant, also easy to be pleased. Molliter, gentylly with good will, easily,
delycately. Mollitudo, inis, softnes and gentylnes. Mollusca, a nutte with a
soft shale, a fylberde. Molluscum, the wenne of a tree. Molo, molui, lire, to
grynde. Molochinus color, a color like to the flowers of mallows. Molorthus,
a plumrule, such as masons and carpenters do occupy in squarynge of stone
and timber. Molossa gens, people in the part of Greece called Epirus. Molossus,
a mastiue dog. it is also a foot in meter. Molothros, a kind of white vynes.
Molucrum, a square piece of timber, whereon the paynyms did sacrifyce. It is
also the trendyll of a myll. Also the swellynge of a woman's bealy, which does
happen as well to maidens, as to wives. Molybdena, an herb called also
Plu^bago, it is also the oore of lead or silver. Molybditis, the spume or foam
of lead. Momentaneus, a, um, that which durethe but a little whiles, or
shortly alters. Momentarius, a, um, that which is done in a little space.
Momentum, the least part of time, which can not be assigned, a moment. Momus,
called the god of reprehencion. Momo satisfacere, to content him, whom almost
nothing may please. Momo iudice decertare, to contend before a rigorous and
extreme judge. Monachus, a solytarie person, all be it that it is used for a
monk. Monachris, a mountain in Archadia. Monarcha, a prince, which reuleth
alone without piere or companyon, monarche. Monarchia, the rule of one
monarchy. Monas, monadis, the number of one, unity. Monasterium, a place
solytarie. Monedula, a bird callydde a Choughe or Cadesse. Moneo, monere, to
warn, to put in remembrance. Monitor, toris, he that warns a man, or
puts him in remembrance. Moneta, money, also the name of Juno. Monetalis,
le, pertaining to money. Monetarius, a maker of money, a coyner. Monile, a
colar or be, which women use to wear about their necks, It is also a
poytrell of a horse. Monitio, warning. Monitus, tus, idem. Monitorius, a, um,
that which does warn, or exhort. Monna, an I Will pertaining to England,
which some do suppose to be Angle sey, sum Manne, between Lancaster and
Irelande. Monobeli, they which have a long thing like to spyttes. Also they
that be veraye high in personnage and above other. Lampridius in uita Alex.
Monochordium, an Instrumente, having many strings of oone sown, saving
that with small pieces of cloth, the sons be distinct, as Clauycordes be.
Monoechus, a haven of Liguria. Monoceros, otis, an Unicorn. Monoculus, a man
having but one eye. Monodia, a lamentable or mournyng song, such as is songen
in funeralles. Monodos, was a man, which instead of teethe, had but oone
boon, like as king Pirrhus had. Monogamus, he that never had but one
wife. Monogammi, men lean and yuelle colored. Monologium, a long tale of
one mattier. Monomachia, a battle, wherein oonely two men do fight.
Monomachus, he that fyghteth alone. Monophagia, a meal of one only meat or
dyshe. Monopodium, a table set on one foot or trestylle. Monopolium, where
one manne ingrosseth things, to have all in his own hand, that no man may
gain, but he only. It may be also one country or market, that takes away
the gaynes from other countries or markettes. Monoptaton, a word having but
one case. Monosceli, men in India, which have but one leg, so great, that
therewith they cover them selfs from the son. Monostelon, where as is but one
pyller. Monotropos, solitary, of one facion always. Monoxylon, a boat made in
oone piece of timber. Mons, it is, a mountain or hylle. Mons feratus, a country
in Italye. Monstrificus, a, um, monstrous. Monstro, are, to show. Monstrum, a
monster, that which excedeth or lacks in natural form or order.
Monstruosus, monstruosa, struosum, monstrous. Montanus, a, um, of a mountain.
Monticulus, a little hylle. Montigena, borne on a hylle. Montinagus, wandringe
by hills. Montosus, a, um, full of hills. Monumentum, a remembrance of some
notable act, as sepulchers, images, pylars, great stones, inscriptions,
books, and other like: whereby any thing excellent, concerning great wits,
kunnynge, entreprise in arms, puyssaunce, or richesse is remembered. Monycha,
chae, the name of saynct Austens mother. Monychus, a giant, one of the
Centaures. Monyma, the wife of king Mithridate, which after that her husband
was vainquisshed, killed her self. Mopsopia, the contray of Athenes. Mopsus,
the name of a Poet. Mora, taryenge, leysar. Moralis, le, pertayninge to
manners. Moramentum, taryenge, or abode. Moratus, instructed in good manners.
Morbidus, a, um, sick or scabbed. Morbisicus, ca, cum, that which causes
discase or sickness. Morbus, sickness, disease, a sore. Morbus animae, a
vice inueterate and hard to be cured, as ambition, avarice. Morbus regius, the
yelow iaundyse. Mordax acis, he that does byte, be it with the teeth, or with
langage. Mordeo, momordi, dear, to byte, to detract, or rebuke vehemently. ^
Mordere frenum, to gnawe on the brydell, which is spoken where it signifies
one to repugne against servitude or bondage. Mordicibus, with bytinges.
Mordico, care, to hurt with bytinge. Mordicus, bytinge hard and fast, as a
man holds a thing. Mordicus tenere, to hold fast, to persist obstinately in
an opinion or sentence. Moribundus, dyenge. Moriger, geri, obedient. Morigeror,
aris, ari, to obaye, to do as a man bedeth, to conform one man's manners to
another. Morini, people in france, dwelling about Turwan. Morio, onis, a
fool. Morior, iris, and eri, moriri, and mori, to dye. Morologus, he that
speaks treatably, sometime words treatably spoken: sometime it signifies him,
that speaks foolyshely. Moror, aris, ari, to tarry or abide, to let, or cause
to tarry. Moros, a fool. Morosus, waywarde, diverse in conditions, whom no man
can please, more curiouse than needs. Morotis, and Morosis, a madness or
frenesy, where a man loses his memory. Mors, it is, death. Morsicatim, bytynge
one another. Morsiuncula, a little bitte or snacke. Morsus, us, a bytt with the
teeth, a taunt in spekinge. Morsus, a, um, bitten. Plinius.
Mortalis, le, mortal. Mortarium, a mortar, wherein things are, brayed or
grounden. Morticina caro, moren flesh, which dies by it self, carrayne.
Morticini, corns which be on men's fete. Morticinum, corrupt. Mortiferus, a,
um, which causes any thing to dye. Mortuale, pertayninge to deed men. Mortuu^
mare, a great mere in Syria, where in no heavy thing may synke. Morula, a little
taryenge. Morus, a Mulbery tree, and a brembyl that bears black beryes.
Morum, a Mulbery, or black bery. Mos, moris, a manner, a co^dicio^, also
custom. Morem gerere, to obey. Moscatulae, pearis, which do sauoure like
musk, Mosculus, a calfe, also an herb. Moschum, Musk. Moscus, a Region in
Asia nyghe to the river of Phasis, divided into three partis, in the one do
dwell people called Colchi, in the second Hiberes, in the third Armenii. Moses,
sis, si, the great captayn of the jews which lad them out of Egipte. Mosini,
people in Asia toward the north. Motabilis, always mouinge. Motacilla, a byrd
called a wagtayle. Motiuus, a, um, mouynge, not abiding. Moto, are, to move
often. Motus, ta, tum, moved. Motus, tus, moving. Moueo, ere, to move, to
remove or put away Mouere animu^, to slyre or allure the mind. Mouere
tragoedias, to do things to be lamented. Mouere camerinam, to stere things,
which shall be to his own displeasure, that begins it. Mox, anon,
forthwith. Muceo, cui, to be fylthy or vinewed. Mucidus, a, dum, fylthy,
vinewed. Mucor, oris, fylth, vinue, such as is on bred or meat long kept.
Mucro, onis, the point of a sword or knife. sometime it is taken for a sword.
Mucronatus, ta, tum, poynted. Mucus, the fylthe, which comes out of the
nose. Mugil, lis, A fish called a codde. Lucilius.
Muginor, ari, to murmr. Mugio, gire, to bellowe like a cow or bull* sometime
it signifies the noise of thunder, or great wyndes. Mugonia, a gate at Rome,
whereby catell did enter into the city. Mugitus, tus, bellowynge of kyne, or
other noise like. Mularis, re, pertayninge to a mule. Mulceo, si, cere, to
pacyfye, to appease, to mitigate, to make sweet, to anoynte, to polyshe.
Mulciber, eris, one of the names of Vulcane, called god of fire. Mulctor,
ctaris, ctari, to punysshe, or be punysshed. Mulcta, a penalty, a
condemnation, a fine sessed. Mulctam dicere, to give an iniunction. Mulctam
committere, to forfayte, to run in the pain. Mulctam remittere, to pardone.
Mulctra, the mylkyng, the payle, wherinto it is milked, which is also called
Mulctrale. Mulctrum, the act of mylkynge. Mulei, certain shoes of purple
color, which the kings of Alba ware, and afterward the noble men of Rome.
Mulgeo, mulsi, mulgere, to milk or stroke. Mulgo, are, to publishe. Muli
mariani, forkes, whereon fardels were trussed and borne by men. Muli mariani, a
proverb referred unto the^, which be obedient to every commaundment, be it
never so greuouse. It may also be applied unto the^, which be inuolued in
perpetual and intolerable labors and business. Muli mutuum scabunt, mules
do gnappe one an other, a proverb applied to persons ylle and defamed, when
one of them commends the other. Mulier, eris, A woman, proprely she that is
no virgin. Muliebre folliculum, dicebant vuluam. Muliebria, natural
euacuations, which women have, called their flowers. Muliebris, bre,
perteynynge to women. Muliebritas, delicateness, tenderness. Muliebriter,
womanly, delicately, tenderly. Mulierarius, a follower, or dotar on women.
Muliero, are, to effeminate, or make like a woman. Mulierosus, a great lover of
women. Mulio, onis, and Mulius, a dryuer of Mules, a muletour. Mullus, a fish
called a Mullet. Mulsum, wine and honey soden together. Mulsus, a, um, any
licour mixed with honey* Multa, idem quod malcta. Multatitius, pertaining to a
forfait, or pain assessyd. Multesima, a part representinge an infinite
quantitye. Quam paruula pars, quam multesima constat, so little a portion, se of
how wonderful gretnesse it is. Multibarbus, he that has much hear on his
bearde. Multibibus, he that drinks much. Multicolorius, a, um, of many
colors. Apulcius.
Multifacio, ere, to make much of, to esteem much. Multifariam, many ways,
in many facions. Multifarius, diverse in manners or condicio^s. Multigenetis, re,
of diverse kinds. Plautus. Lucilius.
Multiforatilis, le, with many holes. Multi iugus, a, um, diverse, many
diverse, manyfolde. Multiloquus, full of speech. Multipes, having many feet.
Multiplex, plicis, manyfolde, diverse. Multiscius, a, um, knowinge much.
Multitia, garments made of fine thredes or sylke. Multiuidus, he that sees
much. Multiuolus, desyringe diverse things. Multo, and Mulcto, are, to
punysshe, to condemn, to put fro, to entreat ill, or disorder. Multare
matrimonio, to deuorse, or dissolve matrimony. Multus, ta, tum, much, many.
Mulus, a Mule. Mundanus, na, um, worldly. Mundities, and Munditia, clenlynesse.
Mundifico, are, to klense. Mundo, are, to wype, to make clean. Mundus, the
world, a woman's attire. Mundus, da, dum, clean, nete. Muneralis, le,
pertaining to gifts. Munerarius, he that makes a common game or play at his
propre charges. Muneror, aris, ari, and munero, are, to reward Mungo, xi, ere,
to make clean, proprely ones nose. Municipalis, le, privately or particulerly,
belonginge to one city. Municipale ius, the private law of every particular
city. Municipalia magisteria, civil offices in every city or town.
Municipatim, town by town. Municipium, a city or town incorporate, having
their propre officers and laws. Municeps, a citezen, or burgeyse, enioyinge
the liberties of the town. Munificus, liberal, Munificentior, more liberal,
Munificentissimus, most liberal. in the old time Munifici, were taken for
them, which consented to that, which their friends did or spoke. Munimen, and
munimentum, a fortifycation of a town or castelle. Munio, tui, and ij, nire,
to fortifye, to prepare, to repair. Munia, commune duties, offices. Munis, he
that bears the charges, which the people should do. Munus, neris a gylt, a
charge, a duty or office. Munera, commune plays and gaye sightes for the
people to behold, to rejoice them, prepared by officers of cities. As in Rome,
sundry plays, sword players, called Gladiatores, huntyng of wyld beasts.
Also now in the city of London, the watches and syghtes on midsomer nights.
Munychia, orum, the solemnities of Pallas. Murena, a lampraye. Murenulae,
small chains, which women do wear. Muralis corona, a garlande given to him,
which in the siege of a city first skalyd the walls, and entered. Muralis
herba, an herb called perytorye, or pelytorie. Murani, were the kings of
Alba. Muratus, ta, tum, walled. Murcia, goddess of slouthe. Murcus, a
slothful or luskyshe person. Murex, ^^is, a shelle fyshe, of whom comes
the lycour, which makes purple color. Sometime it sygnifyeth the same
color. Also an herb, which grows in a pyt, where no son shyneth.
Murginor, ari, to tarry, to be slouthfulle. Murguana regio, a country in the
southe parts of Spain. Murgizo, murgizonis, an ydell or slouthefull person.
Muria, water, wherein salt is sodden, brine. Muricatus, salted in bryne.
Murices, caltrappes, like three iron pryckes so joined, that being thrown, one
standethe vpryghte, used in battle for horsemenne. Fulgentius.
Muricati gressus, where oone gothe fearfully, as if he went on caltraps or
thorns Plaut.
Muricidus, a mouse killer, a fool, a rat killer. Muries, a bryne made with
salt sodden in water. Murmilonica scuta, targettes, wherewith men faught upon
walls. Murmur, the noise of rounnynge water. Murmurillum. idem. Murmurabundus,
and murmurator, he that murmureth. Murmuro, to murmour, or make noise like to
water. Murmurillo, idem. Murmurillum, a murmuring. Plautus.
Murrha, a stone of diverse colors, clear as cristall, having spots purple
and white. Murrheus, and murrhinus, a, um, of that stone called murrha, whereof
cups, pottes, tables, and other vessels were made: there be of them diverse
sent from Venyce. Murrhina, seu murrhynia, was wine made with diverse spices, as
that which is called ypocras. Murtius, a hylle at Rome, called also
Auentinus. Murtia, one of the names of Venus. Murus, a wall. Mus, muris, a
mouse or ratte. Musa, a sweet song. Musae, Muses, were maidens, whom poets
feigned to be the daughters of Jupiter and Memory, and that they were ladies
and governors of poetry and musyke, which were in number nine. Some call
them gyuers of eloquence, and do name them goddesses. Musaea, Musaica, and
Musiua, be warkes cunnyngely painted, that they seem to be in some place
imbocid out, in some place graven, although it be all plain. Museus, an
ancient poet, which was in the time of Orpheus, and was one of them which
went with Jason to the wynninge of the fliece of gold. Musaeum, a house,
whereunto learned men in all sciences used to repair, and dispute: it is also a
house dedicate to the musis. Musca, a fly. Muscula, a small fly. Muscari, to
be covered with moss. Boethius.
Muscarium, and muscaria, a flappe to drive away flies. It is also the top of
fenelle, dylle, and such other like herbs, wherein be the seeds. Muscarius,
a, um, pertaining to flies. Muscenton, a certain Rose, that springs of a
stalk with many small branches, and has leaves like to an olyue tree.
Muscerda, mouse dunge. Muschus, a beast, which bears musk, a musk catte.
Muscinus, a, um, of a fly. Muscio, onis, a catte. Muscipula, a trappe,
wherewith myse or rattes are taken. Musculus, a little mouse. Sommetyme an
engyne of war, whereby they are defended, which do approach the walls of a
place besyeged, to fylle the dyches, It is also a little fyshe, which guydeth
the whale that he do not run on rockis. Musculi, be certain pieces of hard
flesh compacte with synewes in the body, which do enclose the spiritual
members. Muscus, moss, which grows in wells and moist places, sommetyme
on trees, specially in cold countries. Musica, and musice, musyke. Musice,
hole, that nothing lacks. Musicus, a musycion. Musmones, sheep with hearye
wolle. Mussitabundus, a man speaking to him self privily. Mussito, tare, to
speak or talk alone. Musso, are, to talk softely and secretly, to keep
silence. Mustace, a tree having leaves like to laurel, but greatter and
weaker. Mustacula, a little instrumente made with two rules, between which
the show is put, whiles the sole is in sowynge. Mustaceus, and mustaceum, a
caa^e or paste made to comfort the stomach. Mustela, a beast called a
wesell. also a fish like a lampraye. Mustelinus, a, um, of a wesyll. Musteus,
a, um, sweet as must, or mustye. Mustum, new wine, new ale, new beer.
Mustus, ta, tum, new, young, late made. Mutabilis, le, chaungeable, mutable.
Muteo, mutui, tere, and mutesco, scere, to be muete, or dumme. Mutili, horned
beasts, of nature lacking horns, as oxen, gotes. etc. Mutilus, la, lum,
lacking sum principalle part, mutilate. Mutilo, are, to cut of, to
mynyshe, to take away. Mutinensis color, a natural color, as wull or clothe
never dyed. Mutio, tiui, tire, to speak softely, or with an vnperfyt voice, to
muttre. Mutito, tare, to feast one an other. Mutuli, scaffolde holes, or
places made on the walls for culuers to bread in. Muto, tare, to change, to
translate, to barter one thing for an other. Muto, tonis, the privy membre of
a man. Mutuatitius, a, um, borrowed. Mutunus, who was also called Priapus.
Mutuo, together, or one an other, Mutuo diligebant, They loved one an other.
Mutuare, sygnyfieth both to borowe and to lend. Mutuor, aris, ari, to borowe.
Mutus, he that can not speak. Mute, dumme. Mutuum, a lone, that which is
borrowed. Mutuus, a, um, one for an another, mutualle. Mutuus amor, mutual love,
where one loves an another equally.
M ANTE Y.
MYa, a shel fish in the sea called Bosphorus, which brings forth little
read stones, and round. Myagrus, the god of flies. Mycaene, and Mycaena, a
city in the part of Grecia, called Peloponesus, and a little region, where
Agamemnon reigned, the chief captain of the greeks against Troy, called
now Morea. Mycon, the name of a famous paynter. Mycone, nes, a little isle.
Mydia, an isle, named also Delos. Mydriasis, a syckenesse of the eyes, where no
color of the eyes ar changed, but makes them much brother: all be it it
takes away the sight, or makes a man to se the less, and the things, which
be seen, to seem less than they are. Mygale, a ratte. Mygdonia, a part of
Macedonia on the sea side, where Niobe was turned in to a stoone. Aristotle
says, that it is a part of Phrigia, ioynynge to Lidia. Solynus says, that
it was called Bebrycia, and after Bythinia. Mylochos, a butterfly, which is in
mylles. Myoparo, onis, a kind of ships used in the sea called Mare
Tirrhenum. Myophnos, a kyller of myse. Mymphur, a tourners pynne or spyndelle,
whereon he turns or warketh any thing. Myra, a city in Licia, whereof saint
Nycholas was bishop. Myriarches, a captayn of ten thousand me^. Myriades,
many times ten thousand. Myrias, adis, the number of ten thousand. Myrica,
a little bushe called in Italye Tamarico. Myrinus, the male kind of a
lampray, which has a tothe out of his mouth. Myrmus, the propre name of
Apollo. Myriophillum, an herb called myllfoyle. Myristica nux, a nuttemygge.
Myrlea, a town in Bythinia. Myrmecia, a little warte. Myrmecites, a stone,
wherein is the figure of an emotte. Myrmetiu^, a kind of spiders, like an emote
having a black bealy with white spots. Mirmillones, were sword players,
where the one provoked the other to battle. Myrsenium, a kind of fenell,
having gretter leaves, and a sharper taste. Myrsum, a town in the part of
Greece, called Peloponesus. Myrmicoleo, a little beast, which deuoureth emotes.
Myrobalanum, a fruit growinge in India, like unto plummes or damsyns, whereof
be diverse kinds, which easily do purge al superfluous humors, and also
comfort nature, in so much as a man, which eats them, being condite,
shall not look oldely. Myrobrecharij, they which do make sweet oyntmentes.
Myron, onis, the name of an excellent carner. also old oil. Myropola, a
seller of oyntementes. Myropolium, a place where oyntementes were sold.
Myrothetium, a box of sweet oyntme^tes. Myrrha, a sweet gum, called myrre.
Myrrheus, and myrrhinus, a, um, of myrre. Myrtetum, a place, where Myrtelle
trees be set. Myrteus, and myrtinus, a, um, of myrtelles. Myrtopetalum, an
herb called blodewort. Myrtoum, a porcyon of the sea, which is between the
sees called Aegeum and Ioniu^. Myrtus, a little tree, bearing bearyes of
sweet odor. Mys, mios, the name of a cunnyng grauer. also a shelle fyshe of
the sea. Mysia, a country beyond Hungarye, toward Greece. Ptholomeus writes
of two countries called Mysia, the more and the less, and both in Asia,
beyond Bythinia, not far from Ida. Mysteria, mysteries, things secret or
hid in words or ceremonies. Mysticus, ca, cum, mystical. Mystris, a fyshe
called a see mouse. Mythologia, a declaration or exposition of fables. Mythos,
a fable. Myxa, the fylthe which comes out of a man's nose. Myxus, a snuff
of a candell.
N, ANTE A.
NABATHA, the name of a certain city. Nabathea, a countreye between the red
see and the sea called Persicum, containing with in it Arabie. Nabatheus, a,
um, of that countreye. Nabis, in the langage of Ethiope, is a be having a
heed like a camel, a neck like a horse, legs and fete like an ox. Nablum,
and nablium, an instrument of musyke, called a psaltrie. Naccae, and neae,
fullers. Nactus, the participle of Nansciscor, Nactus sum, I have gotten,
nactus es, nactus est, thou, he has gotten. Nae, sygnifieth valde, or nimis.
Nae tu homo facetus es, thou art a very merry fellow. sometime it signifies
Certe, profecto, ita. Nae illi vehementer errant, surely they be far out of
the way. Nae ego multo libe^tius emerim diuorsoriu^ Tarracinae, In good faith
I had leauer have bought a house at Tarracine. Naeera, a woman's name. Naenia, a
mourning song, wont to be songen at burielles, sometime it signifies the
so^ge that the mother or norice does singe dandyllynge of her child. Neuia, a
woman's name. Neuus, a mole or like mark in the body or face, from the time of
the birth. Naiades, fayries, of the ryuers and fountaynes. Nain, a city of
Galyle. Nais, a river, which comes out of the hill called Taurus, and runs
in to the sea called Pontus. Nam, for, therefore. Nanciscor, sceris, nactus sum,
nancisci, to get or opteyne. sometime to find. Nancisci hospitium, to find a
lodging. Pom. Fest.
Nancitor, for nactus erit. Nanque, verily, truly: if it be set before other
words: if it be put after, it sygnifyeth for. Nanum, a little vessel and
broad. Plaut.
Nanium, a little woman. Nanus, a little person, a dwarf. Napataei, people
in Ethiopia. Napeae, called goddesses of flowers and woddes. Napaei, people in
the isle called Lesbos. Naphtha, a kind of pitche, also lyme, wherewith fire is
nourished. Napina, a place where Nauewes be sown. Napitae, people in Scithia.
Napus, a Nauew. Nar, the name of a river. Narane, a river in Dalmatia.
Narbasis, a city in Spain. Narbone^sis gallia, the south part of France
wherein is Dolphinay, Prouance, Langedok. etc. Narciscus, a flower in facion
like a lyllye, and white, saving that the chalese, wherein the flower is closed,
is purpleisome have purple flowers, leaves narower than leke blades, a stalk
half a foot high, plain without leaves, a round rote and white. Also the
name of a young man of excellent beauty, who for the love of a maid e^ died,
and after the fables of poets, was transfourmed into the same lylly.
Narcoticum, a qualytie or virtue in things to make a man to sleep. also to
make a membre insensible. Physytions use medycines, which have this virtue,
where the grief or ache is otherwise incurable, or where they will cut any
part of a man's body. Nardinum, the name of a sweet ointment. Nardus, the
herb and rote, which is called Spikenarde. Nare, to swymme, sometime to flee.
Virg. Geor.
Nares, nosethrylles. Narica, the name of a little fyshe, which does swymme
very swyftely. Naris, a river in Vmbria. Naritia, an isle in the sea called
Aegeum. Naritium, a city of the people named Locri in Greece. Narnia, a town
in Italy. Narnienses, men of that town. Narratio, a narration or report of
things that are done. Narratiuncla, a little narration. Narro, are, to
tell. Nartheticium, a place, wherein medycines are kept. Nasamones, people in
Affrike about Libia Nasamonites, a stone of color languyne, having black
veins. Nascor, sceris, sci, to be borne. Nasica, the surname of one of the
Scipions a noble Romayne. Nasiterna, a water vessel, wide above, having
handelles. Naso suspendere, to mock couertely, or craftelye. Nassa, a fyshers
we will or bow net, wherein if a fyshe be ones, he can not get out.
Nasturtium, an herb called Cresses. Nasus, a nose: sometime sharpenes in
speech, and tauntynge wit. also judgment in letters. Nasuti, taunters,
checkers, skorners, sometime wytty persons, which do quikly perceive a
thing. also men, which have their privy members very great. Nasute, wyttyly,
skornefully, tauntyngely. Nasutila, a tauntynge wenche, or a shrewe. Natalis,
le, et natalitius, tia, tium, the day of birthe or nativity. Natales, is
taken for progeny or dyscente, or blood. Generosi natales, gentyl blood.
Obscuri natales, a poor dyscente or low birth, sometime it is used for years.
Natalibus restitui, where a man has arms and title of nobylitie, Budeus.
given unto him by the king. Natatilis, that which can swim. Natatitius, a,
um, that which does swim. Natator, toris, a swymmer. Natatorium, natabulum,
et natatio, a place wherein men do swymme. Natatus, tus, the act of swymmynge.
Nates, buttockes. Natinatores, trauaylours, or they which have much
business. Natio, a nation. Natiuitas, tatis, birth. Natiuus, where a thing is
borne or begone. Natiuus color, the natural color. Nato, are, to swymme,
sometime to go, to tremble, to sail, or row. Natrix, a water serpent. also an
herb, whose rote smells like a got. Natura, nature, members of generacyon.
Sometime facion or manner. Naturalis, le, natural. Naturalia, the privy
members. Natus, ta, tum, borne. Natus, nata, son and daughter. Natus grandis,
aged or old. Naualis, le, pertaining to ships. Nauale, the docke where
shyps be laid up. Nauale, a docke or place where ships are made. Nauarchis,
the admyralles ship. Nauarchus, an admyrall. Nauaria, a country in Spain
called Navarre. Nauci, a nutte shale, a thing of naught. Nauci esse, to be
naught worth. Naucifacere, to set naught by one. Naucleriacus, et nauclerius,
a, um, perteynynge to a ship master. Nauclerus, and nauiclarius, a ship
master. Naucrates, a city in Egypt. Naufragium, a shypwrecke. Naufragor,
aris, ari, to peryshe on the sea. Naufragus, whose goods are peryshed. Nauia,
a holowe tree like a ship, which is occupied when grapes be gathered.
Nauicularius, a captain of a ship. Nauiculor, aris, ari, to row or be
rowed in a boat for salace. Nauigabilis, le, where a ship may pass,
Nauigable. Nauigatio, a iourneye or goinge by water in a ship. Nauiger, the
pilate of a ship, which rules the stern. Nauigium, the leadynge or setting
forth of the ship. It is also all kind of vessels to sail or row in.
Nauigo, are, to sail or row, that is to say, to be carried on water in a
ship or any other thing like. Nauis pomparica, a ship which serves only
for pleasure, having chaumbers and bankettynge tables for great men to solace
in. Nauis, a ship. Nauiter, diligently, valyauntly. Naulium, a city in
Liguria. Naulum, the fraite or fare paid for passage Naumachia, battle on
the Sea, also the place where the battle is. Naumachiarij, they which do fight
on the sea or water in ships or botes. Nauo, are, to accomplish dylygentely,
to give, to apply with effect, to be in aid. Iam mihi videor nauasse operam
quod huc venerim, now me seems I have well applied my labor, that I am come
hither. Nauare beneuolentiam, to confer or declare benevolence. Naupegus, a
ship wrighte. Naupo^itus, a river, which passes out of Slauony. Nausea, the
abhorrynge of things seen, whereby a man is provoked to vomyte. Nauseosus, a,
um, dysposinge to vomyte. Nausiabundus, dysposed to vomyte. Nauseo, care, et
nauseor, to be dysposed to vomyte, sometime to vomyte. Nausicaa, was daughter to
Alcinous, king of Phaeaces, which found Ulysses, when he escaped from
drounynge, and brought him to her father. Nausio, ere, to open or gape as a
bean does when he spryngeth. Naustilious, the son of Neptunus, and father of
Alcinous. Naustibulum, an hiue made of the facion of a ship. Nauta, et
