nauita, a shyppeman. Nautea, curriers bleche or lycour, also the stynkynge
water, which issues out of the pumpe of a ship. Nauticus, a ship master.
Nauticus, ca, cum, perteynyng to shipmen. Nautulus, a shypman, also a fyshe,
which is in similitude like to some that sailed. Nautilia, the craft of
shypmen. Nauus, quick, actife. Naxos, an isle in the sea called Aegeum.
Nazarcus, a man consecrate or dedycate to god. Nazarei were men, which had made
vows until a certain time. Nazaret, a little town in Galilea. Nazara, a
city in Cappadotia, afterward called Caesaria.
NE, an aduerbe, signifieng forbeading or dissuading. Tu ne cede malis, give
thou not place to adversity or mysaduentures. sometime it is a conjunction
copulative, and signifies nor or. neither. sometime rational, and signifies
wherefore. sometime causal, and signifies not. sometime lest, also or not,
whither. sometime it is an interrogatiue. Ego ne? I trowest thou? Nea, an i will
between Lemnos and Hellespontus. Necunde, nor from any place. Ne plura, ne
multa, but to be short, Cice. (...) Cluend^, and in Ve^. Ci. ^ C^.
what needs any longer tale, to make a short tale. Ne multis, in few words.
Ne multis Diogenes emitur, In few words Diogenes is bought. Ne dicam, I will
not say. Nectere moras, to make delays. Cor. Tacitus li. 1^.
Nec, nor. neque, nor. nequaquam, no. Necnon, and, or also. Nequicquam, in
vain, no or not. Ne viua^, I would I lived not. Ne viua^ si tibi concedo, I
would I lived not, or I would I should not live, if I grant that to the. Cicero.
Neutiquam, in no wise. Nequaquam, no. Necubi, in no place. Nedum, not only,
sometime nor yet, where the thing of least estimation is put last. Nedum,
sygnifieth not only, as Fundere pro te sanguinem, nedu^ pecuniam, I would
spend for the not only my money, but also my blood. where the thing of most
estimation is last put, it signifies nor yet. Ne crederem tibi obulum, nedum
vita^ meam, I will not commytte my life unto thy crede^ce, nor yet lend the
one halfepeny. Nec dum, nor yet. Neapolis, a city called Naples. Neapolitanus,
na, number, of Naples, Nebrides, feasts in the honor of Bacchus, also skins of
dear wherewith they were clad which kept the ceremonies of Bacchus Nebrodes, an
hyl in Sicile, where there is great plenty of falowe dear. Nebrundes, the
stones of beasts. Nebula, a vapor or mist rysynge from the water, which
either tourneth forthwith into a cloud, or shortly vanysheth. Nebularium, a
house where corn is thresshed, or wynn owed in time of rain. Nebulo, onis, a
thief, a knave, a lewd person, or vacabunde. Nebulosus, a, um, mysty.
Necessarius, a kynnesman. Necessarius, a, u^, necessary, needful. Necesse uel
necessu^, of force, it must needs be. Necessitas, tatis, need, necessity.
sometime a bond of friendship or kynrede. Necessitudo, dinis, idem. also
amity. Necim, the old writers used for nec cum, nor with. Perottus.
Necunquam, for necunquam aliquem. Necne, or not. Necum, in the old Spanyshe
tungue was the image of Mars, garnyshed with beams like the son, it also
signyfied in latyne mas, the male kind. Necydalus, a sylke worm, when he is
yo^ge sprounge out of the sede. Neco, caui, care, vel necui, to slay. Neci
datus, slain without weapon, as with poison, famyne, prisonement. Necromantes,
a Necromancer, or caller up of ill spirits. Necromantia, necromancy.
Necromanticus, a necromancer. Nectar taris, the drink of gods, sometime it
signifies immortality. Nectareus, a, um, immortal, deuyne. Necto, nexui,
nectere, to wind or plat together. Necubi, in no place. Necunde, from no
place. Nefandus, da, dum, horrible, not to be spoken or named. Nefarius, a, um,
cursed not worthy to live. Nefas, a cursed deed, a wicked thing, execrable,
detestable. Nefasti dies, days when it is not lefull. Nefrendes, pigs
weaned, called shotes. Negabundus, he that denies. Negabundus, for negans,
denyenge. Negatio, a denyer, a nay. Negatiuus, a, um, that which denies.
Negito, tare, to deny. Plautus in ^ercatore
Negligo, glexi, gligere, to neglect, to have lyttel regard. Neglectus, tus,
contempt. Neglectus, ta, tu^, contemned not regarded. Negligentia, negligence.
Negligens, it is, negligent. Negligenter, negligently, contemtuousely.
dysdeynousely. Nego, aui, are, to deny, to refuse, to say not. Negocialis, le,
perteynynge to denyenge. Plautus in ^^ch.
Negato esse ituram, say that she will not go. Negotior, aris, ari, to practyse
marchaundyse, to be occupied in business. Negotiosus, he that is much occupied
with business. Negociator, toris, a marchaunte, he that is busied in an other
man's affairs. Negotialis, ale, perteynyng to business, occupation, or
trouble. Negotium, remedy. Omnis res palam est, neque vllum pol de hac re
negotium est, quin male occidam, All the matter is known: therefore in this
case in faith there is no remedy, but that I will kill him. Negotiosus, a, um,
full of business, care, or trouble of mind. Negotium dare, to give in charge.
Negotium, business, occupation, sometime trouble, care, or labor of mind.
Negotiorum curator, a factour or solicitor in a man's business. Neleus, the
father of duke Nestor, which was at the siege of Troy. Nem, was used of old
writers for sometime, also for but, or except. Nemea, a great wodde, where
Hercules slew an horrible lion. Nemeaeus, of the wodde called Nemeae, which
is in Grecia, not far from the city of Argos. Nemesis, a goddess, which
was supposed to take vengeance on malefactors. some time it sygnifieth
fortune, also justice, also reproach. Nemartes, nymphs or maidens of the sea.
Ne my quidem, is applied to him that dare not speak. Ne my quidem facere audet,
He dare not ones mutte, or make countenance to speak. Nemo, no man, or none.
Nemo non, some man. Nempe, is an aduerbe confyrming a thing. for because,
surely, verily, sometime for. Nemus, nemoris, a wod for pleasure, wherein dear
or other beasts may feed. Nemoralis, et nemorensis, perteynynge to a wood.
Neo, neui, nere, to spynne. Neogamus, new married. Neomenia, the first day of
the new moan. Neophitus, a new man, or a plant newely sproungen.
Neoptholemus, is in english a new knight, It was also the name of Pirthus the
son of Achilies. Neotericus, he that is now, or was of late time. Nepa, vel
nepes, a scorpion. Nepenthes, a drink or an herb, which causes a man to
forgete heaviness. Also the herb called dorago. Nepeta, a city of the
country of Thuscane in Italy. Nephalia, feasts wherein no wine was sacryfysed
or drunk, but only mede, and they were called the feasts of sobre men.
Nephele, a cloud, also the name of a womanne, which was mother of Helles, who
gave the name to the sea callydde Hellespontus. Nephritis, peyn in the raynes
of the back. Nepita, an herb called nepe, or calament. Nenum, was sometime put
for non. Nepos, otis, the son or daughters son, sometime a waster of
goods, a riottouse person. Nepotes, do sometime signify all the descent,
which comes after a man's sons or daughters. Nepotor, ari, to live
prodigally, or riotously. Nepotulus, a dimynutiue of Nepos. Meus Nepotulus, my
little son, or young son, from the first descent. Nepotatus, tus, riot,
superfluous expenses. Neptis, the daughter of a man's son or daughter.
Neptunus, called god of the sea. Nepus, unclean. Nequa, no where. Nequalia,
detrimentes or harms. Nequam, a noughty fellow, a man to be nothing
esteemed. Nequando, at no time. Nequaquam, in no wise, not a whitte. Nequior,
oris, Nequissimus, warse, warste of all. Nequiquam, in vain, Nequicquam, not.
Ne quid nimis, nothing to to, that is to say, much exceeding, or much
lacking. Nequino, are, to be wanton, also to deny. Nequinu^, a city in
Italy, now callid Narnia. Nequinunt, in the old time they used for nequeunt,
they may not. Ne quis, that no man. Nequiria, vnthriftynesse, lecherous,
wantonness, vicious dalyaunce. Nequitus, and nequiter, unthriftily. Nereides,
nymphs or maidens of the sea. Nereus, was called oone of the goddis of the sea, and sometime it is put for the sea. Nerio, enis, the wife of Mars, called
god of battle. Neritae, a certain kind of shelle fysshe. see Pliny.
Neritos, vel Neritum, an isle or city nyghe to Epirus, a country of Greece.
Nerium promo^totium, Compostella, where saint James the apostelle lies. It is
also a little tree, having leaves like to an almonde tree, but greatter and
fatter. Nero, the name of an emperor, of a monstrous and cruel nature.
Neruiae, harp strings, or lute stringes. Neruiceus, a, um, of synewes.
Neruicus, he that has pein in his sinews. Neruij, people about Tournay.
Nerulani, people by Rome. Nerulonenses, people in Campania. Nerulum, a town in
the countreye called Lucania. Neruosus, a, um, that which has many sinews.
It is sometime taken for strong. Neruus, a synewe, it signifies sommetyme
strength. Also stocks, wherein offenders be put. Nerui be also stringes of an
instrument. Sometime it sygnifieth the priuye membre of a man. Nesa, a
country in Sicile, ioynynge to the hill of Ethna, which always sends forth
flames of fire or smoke. Nescio, sciui, scire, to not know, to be ignorant of a
thing. Nescius, he that does not know, or is not known. Nesium, uel Nes^s,
an isle by Campania. Nesia, a nymphe or maiden of the sea. Nessus, and Nesius,
sons of Ixion the Centaure. Nessotrophion, a place, where duckes are kept to
be made fat. Nestor, oris, a Capytayne of the Greeks, which were at Troy, who
lived the ages of three old men, and in gyuynge counsel was excellent. Neu,
for ne ue, nor yet. Neuceria, a city of Vmbria, which is a part of Italy. Ne
ue, or not, or no. Ne unquam, in no wise. Neuolo, I will not. Neuri, people of
Scithia. Neurobatae, goers on cords. Neuter, tra, trum, neutrius, none of
them. Neutiquam, in no manner of wise, in no condition. Neutralis, le, neutre,
of no part. Neutro, neither on the one part, nor the other. Neuus, a mark in
the vysage or body of a man or womanne, as a mole, a red or black warte.
Nex, necis, death by force. Nexilis, nexile, any thing that may be knit.
Nexo, as, and is, nexui, nexere, to knitte often. Nexus, a, um, knytte,
bounden. Nexus, nexus, uel nexi, a bond, an obligation Nexi, free men, that do
bind them selves to labor or service, Var^^.
to be acquitted of the dettes, which they owe. Nexus inire, to be bound by
oblygation or covenant. also to be wrapped in bonds, as is the commune
saying.
N, ANTE I.
NI, but if, except, lest that. Nicander, the propre name of a man. Nicanor, a
man's name. Nicator, a great vanquysher. Nicca, and Nicia, a city in Asia.
Niceteria, things given for vyctorie, as rings, colers of gold, and crowns
or garlandes. Nicopolis, a city in Egipte, where the emperor Octauian
vanquysshed Antonie and Cleopatra. Nicomedia, a city in the country of
Bithinia, in the less Asia. Nicostrata, the mother of Euander the old king of
latynes. Nicto, tere, to vent as the hound does, which follows the dear or
hare, or other game. Nicto, are, to wynke. Nictus, tus, a wynkynge, as when one
does sygnifie his mind to an other by loking. Nidifico, are, to make a neste.
Nidere, sometime to savor, sometime to shine. Nidor, oris, a savor or smell of
some thing burned or roasted: sometime it signifies grennynge. also brightness.
Nidulor, aris, to bread as a bird does, to make a neste, or air. Nidulus, a
little neste. Nidus, a neste, sommetyme it signifies the bird that bredeth.
Also a vesselle like to a neste. Also Nidi be coffyns, wherein marchantes do lay
their sundry wares. Nigella, a wiede growinge in corn, called also Lolium,
cockle. Also a black seed, good to smelle unto against rewmes or
distillations. Nigellus, a, um, somewhat black, brown. Niger, gra, grum,
black, foul. Also it is sometime used for deed. Nigidius, a noble philosopher
of Rome. Nigredo, nigrities, and nigritia, black color. Nigrefacio, and
nigresio, to make black. Nigreo, and nigresco, to be black. Nigrico, care, to
be somewhat black. Nigris, a fountain in Ethiopia, which is of sum men
supposed to be the heed of the greatte river Nilus. Nigro, are, to make black,
also to be black. Nigror, oris, blackenesse. Nihildum, not yet. Nihilifacio,
cere, to set naught by. Nihili pendo, ere, to esteem nothing. Nihilominus,
nethelesse. Nihil, and nihilum, nothing, naught. ^^^^tus in ^^cch.
Nihil cum fidibus graculo, Nihil cum amacino sui, The dawe has nothing to
do with the lute: nor the sow with maiora^: A proverb applied to them,
which presumynge to much of their own wits, do meddel malapertly with
things, whereof they can no skylle. Nil, nothing, none, naught. Nilion, a
stone like a Topace, but that it is more duskyshe. Nilus, a great river in
Egipte, called also Geon, and is one of the greattest ryuers of the world.
Niliacus, and niloticus, ca, cum, of Nile. Nimbifer, the bringer of storms or
shoures. Nimblis, an isle in the sea called Ionium. Nimbus, a sudden great
shower or storm of rain or hayle. Also a cloud or a great wind, also a
vessel, out of the which wine is drawn or powered. Nimbosus, stormy, or
showrynge. Nimirum, undoubtedly, surely. sometime it signifies but yet, no
marvel. Nimis, and nimium, an aduerbe, signifyenge abundance. Nimis bonus, to
good. Nimis malus, to ylle. Nimietas, superfluousnes. Nimius, a, u^, whereof is
to much, or excess. Ningo, ninxi, ningere, to snow. Ninguidus, da, guidum,
where there is much snow. Niniue, a great cite in Assyria, also an other
greatte city in the corner of Judea, toward Arabia. Ningulum, none, nor any.
Ninus, a great king of Assiria, and Babylon. Niobe, a woman, who having a
greatte number of children, and they being deed all at ones, so much lamented
and sorowed, that she lost her speech: wherefore the paynyms feigned, that she
was turned to a stone. Niphates, a river in the country of Scithia Niptrum, a
lauer. Nis, was of old time used for nobis. Nisaee, a lady of the fayrye.
Niseus, a place in Media, where fair horses were bredde. Nissa, a city in
Lydia. Nisi, but if, except. Nisus, a kings name, of whom it is feigned, that
he had one golden hear. It is also a kind of hawks. Nisus, sa, um, the
participle of Nitor, teris. Nisyros, a little isle by Greece. Nitedula, a seld
mouse. Also a glow worm that shines by night. Nitella, a toothe pike.
sometime it signifies elegancy in speech. Niteo, tui, tere, to be clean,
nete, gaye. Nitesco, idem. Nitide, clenlye. Nitido, are, to make clean or
bright. Nitidus, da, dum, clean, brighte. Nitor, teris, niti, to be styffe, or
to resyste against a burdeyn, to endeavor, to lean on a thing, to flee, to
be sustained, to enforce him self, or take pein, to travail. Nitere, to live
a pleasant life. Nitor, oris, clennesse, brightness, gayness. Nitrea, a
region or Contray in Egypt, also the name of two cities in Egypt, above the
city of Memphis. Nitrum, Salt peter. Niualis, le, of snow. Niuatus, ta, tum,
made cold as snow. Niueus, a, um, of snow, snowy. Niuosus, full of snow, or
where it snoweth often. Nixu^io, I will endeavor me, I will assay to do a
thing. Nixus, a, um, borne as a child is. Nixus, us, ui, birth of a child.
Nix, niuis, snow.
N. ANTE. O.
NO, are, to swymme. Nobilis, noble, notable. Nobilitas, nobilytie, nobleness.
Nobilito, tare, to make noble, or to add to dignity, or estimation, to cause
to be known. Noceo, cui, cere, to hurt, to indamage. Noctesco, cere, to be
dark. Noctes atticae, a book that Aulus Gellius made, which was so called,
because it was written in the winter nyghtes at Athenes. Nocticorax, a night
crow. Noctifuga, he that flees or exchuith the night. Noctiluca, is a name,
whereby the Moon is called because that she does shine by night, also a little
be, which shyneth by night. Noctiuagus, a wanderar or goar by night. Noctu,
at night, or in the night, by night. Noctua, an owl. Noctuae Athenis, oules to
Athenes, a proverb, whereby is signified any thing to be abundant, and more
than enough. Nocturnus, na, um, of the night. Nocuus, a harm doar. Nodo, are,
to knytte. Nodus, a knot. Nodosus, a, um, knotty, or full of knottis. Nodus
herculis, where there can be found nor beginning nor endinge, that which may
never be losed. Nodus is also in an host in battle, a throng of men, so
thick, that it can not be perced. Nodum in scyrpo quaeris, Thou sekest for a
knot in a rushe, it is applied to him, which is scrupulouse in a thing that is
not doubtful, but plain. Noegeum, a white napkyn. Noema, may be called every
sentence. Noenon, for non. Noeo^ae, the wertes, which be in the chekis of a
got or swyne. Noes, a river in Thracia, which runs into the river of
Ister, or Danow. Nolani, people in Italy. Nolito, or Noli, do not. Nolo, non
vis, nolui, nolle, to not will. Nolo, I will not. Nomarcha, a mayre, bayliffe,
or prouoste. Nomades, people in Scithia, called now Tartary. Nomae, sores,
which be grievous. Nomen, minis, a name, or nowne, sometime it signifies
worship, authority, nobleness of blood, kynred. Also cause. Eo nomine, for
that cause. Meo nomine, for my sake. Nomenclator, oris, an officer, which
called every man by his name. Nomenclatura, a namynge of men. Nomentum, a town
in Italy by Rome. Nomina, beside the commune signification, does also signify
dettours or dettes, also articles written. Nomina facere, to lend to many men.
Nomina exigere, to demand or call for dettes. Nominatim, by name. Nominibus
honestis, for an honest pretense or consyderation. Nomino, are, to name.
Nomisma, coin. Nomissis, nine pound weight of brass. Nomophilax, acis, a
kepar of laws. Nomus, a jurisdiction, as a mayraltie, a baylywyke, or
prouostshyp of a town. Non, no, not. Nonaginta, fourscore and ten. Nongenti,
nine hundred. Nonus, a, um, the nynthe. Non ita pridem, not long agone. Non
modo, not only. Nonnullus, some man. Nonnunquam, sometime. Non sobrius,
drunk. Non tacenda, prayseworthy. Nonacris, a place in the countray of
Arcadia. Nonae, nine days in every month before the Idus. Noricum, a contray
in Germany, wherein is the duchy of Bauaria, or Beuar, also the town of
Nurenbergh. Norma, a rule. Normandia, a contraye in France called Normandy.
Normatus, a, um, ruled. Noruegia, a royaulme called Norwaye. Noscito, tare, to
know much. Nosco, noui, noscere, to know, to favor tenderly. Noscomion, an
hospytalle or place, where sick folk are kept. Notabilis, le, notable.
Notae, notes, cyfers, marks, made for remembrance of some thing. Notarius, a
clerk, which writes instruments or plees. Notesco, notui, scere, to be
known or made known. Nothus, a bastard. Nothia, that which by some laws is
appointed to a man's bastard. Notifico, are, to make known. Notio, knowledge.
Notitia, idem. Noto, are, to note or mark, to make a mark or token, to write
after an example. Notus, ta, tum, known: also a friend, or of acquaintance.
Notus, noti, the southwynde. Nouacula, a barbers knyfe or raser. Noualis, land
sown every other year. Nouelletum, a new grown vine. Nouello, are, to tylle
new ground, or set new vynes. Nouellus, a, um, new. Nouem, nine. Nouenus,
the nynthe. Nouenarius numerus, the number of nine. Nouendium, the space of
nine days. Nouendiale sacrum, ceremonies the nynth day after the burienge.
Nouenniae, a city in Thracia. Nouerca, a stepmother, or stepdame. Nouercari,
to do like a stepdame. Nouitius, a, um, new or late begone. Nouo, are, to
make new. Nouocomenses, a people in Italy. Nouum Comum, a town in Italy.
Nouuncium, of nine ounces or inches. Nouus, ua, um, new, fresshe, late commen
up or begone. Noui homines, men of late commen up, which are not
gentylmenne of an ancient stock. Nouissimus, ma, mum, the last. Nouiter,
newely, or lately. Nouissime, last of all. Nox, noctis, night. Notesco, scere,
to be night. Noxa, pain, offense, or trespace. sometime it signifies hurt or
harm. Noxia, a fault. Noxius, noxia, noxium, harmefull.
N, ANTE V.
NVbecula, a little cloud. Nubes, a cloud. Nubilarium, a house, wherinto
corn is carried for fear of rain. Nubilis, maryable, of full age to be wedded.
Nubilo, are, to make clowdy or dark. Nubilosus, a, um, full of clouds.
Nubilus, a, um, clowdy, dark, Nubo, nupsi, nubere, to be wedded, or to wedde,
proprely of the woman's part. Nucamenta, things hanging down from the boughs
of trees or pitchtrees, and are no leaves. Nuceria, a town in Campania.
Nuceus, ea, eum, of a nutte. Nuci frangibula, a nutte crack. Nucleus, the
kernel of any thing. Nucula, and nucella, a little nutte. Nudipedalia,
ceremonies done bare foted. Nuditas, nuditatis, nakedness, symplenesse,
playnnesse. Nudius tertius, the day before yesterdaye: Nudius quartus, Nudius
quintus, Four days passed, five days sens. Nudare, to make naked, to
discover, or open. Nudus, da, dum, naked, uncovered. Nugae, nugarum, tryflynge
tales, fables, merry matters. Nugalis, le, tryflynge. Nugamenta, tryfles.
Nugatorius, a, um, tryflynge. Nugax, acis, a tryfler or sabler. Nugigerulus,
and nugigerus, a teller of lies. Nugiuendus, a seller of tryfles. Nugor, aris,
ari, to tryfle, or go about vain things. Nugator, toris, a tryfler or mocker.
Nullatenus, in no wise. Nullibi, no where. Nullo negotio, without pain or
labor, without any difficulty. Nullus, a, um, none. Nullus sum, I am undone.
Nullus dum, no man yet, none to this day. Number, for an, or vtrum, which happens
in a demand or question. Number ego te spoliaui? Did I rob the? Number nam, for
number. Numa, was the second king of Romans. Numatio, having great store of
money. Numellae, a tumbrelle, wherein men be punysshed, having their heedes
and fete put into it. Numen, proprelye is the will of God. Sommetyme the power
of god, sum time it sygnyfyeth god, sommetyme apparayle. Numerabilis, rabile,
that may be numbryd. Numeralis, rale, pertaining to number. Numerarius, seu
numerator, he that casts account, or reckneth a thing in numbres. Augustinus
Numeratius, ia, um, wherein is number. Numeratim, in number, or by numbres.
Numerato, promptely, redily, sometime in account or reckenynge. Fab. Quin. v^.
De Actore facile dicente ex tempore dictum est ingenium eu^ in numerato
habere, of the plaintyfe, wha^ he speaks quyckely and without study, it is
said, that he has a quycke wit and a ready. Claudius Isidorus testamento suo
dixit, Plin. li. 31.
quamuis multa Civilly bello perdidisset, tamen relinquere seruorum quatuor
millia, iuga boum tria millia sexcenta, reliqui poecoris ducenta quinquaginta
millia, In numerato po^do sexcenta millia, Claude Isidore said, that not
withstanding that he had lost much in the Ciuyle wars: yet had he
left in his testament four thousand slaves, three thousand and six hundred
yoke of oxen, of other cattle two hundred and fyfty thousand, In money ready
told syx hundred thousand pound. Numero, are, to number or count, to tell
money, to reken catell. Numerosus, great in nombre. Numerus, nombre, sometime
quantity, as of grain, it is also a precise order in harmony, in length and
shortenesse of syllables. And therefore sommetyme verses be called Numeri.
(...), in (...)
Also it signifies company or feloweshyp. It is also taken for the warste
sort of the people. Numeris omnibus absolutus, on every part perfytely.
Numidia, a royalme in Affrike. Numida, a man of Numidia. Numitius, a river in
Italy by Lauinium. Nummarius, nummaria, rium, pertaining to money. Nummarius,
a keeper and lover of money. Nummarus, moneyed, rich in money. Numitor, toris,
the grandfather of Romulus and Remus on the mothers side. Nummularius, he with
whom exchange of money is made. Nummulus, a little coin or piece of money
Nummus, and numisma, money. It was a coin, which was the tenthe part of a
golden penny. Nummus adulterinus, counterfayt money. Numella, a pair of
shakelles, or fetters for a horse. Nunc, now, at the last. Nunquando for number
aliquando. Valla in Rauden.
Nuntiatio, report, relation. Nuntio, are, to tell or sygnifye. Nuntius, a
messanger, sometime a message. Nuntium, idem. Nuncupo, are, to name. Nuncupare
uota, to make a solemn auowe. Caesar.
Nuncupare testamentum, to declare a will or testament by mouth. Nuncupatio,
a namynge, a declaration of a will. Nundinae, the market days, which in old
time was the nynthe day: and than did the husband men come to the city to
bie and selle, and also to here their laws declared, which were new made.
Nu^dinalis le, and nu^dinarius, a, um, pertaining to a market or fair.
Nundinatio, marchaundyse exercysed in fayres. Nundinator, toris, a market man.
Nundinor, naris, to selle openly: sometime to bye often. Nunquam, never. Ci. in
ver.
Nunquam non, ever. Nunquid, a demand. Nunquid ego sum? Is it not I? Nunquis,
que, quid? Is there any. Nunquid vis? will ye any thing with me? or, Is
there any thing that I may do for you? Nuper, late, awhyle agoone. Sommetyme
long ago. Nuper admodum, a little while ago. Nuperrimus, the last of all.
Nuperus, a, um, signifies late done, or happened, or new begone. Plautus in
^apt.
Nuptialis, le, pertaynyng to marriage. Nuptiae, marriage or wedding. Nupturio,
ire, to desire to marye. Nuptus, ta, tum, married. Nuptus, and nupta, the
husbonde and wife. Nuptus, tus, marriage. Nursia, an old city in Italy. Nurus,
a daughter in law, the sons wife. Nusquam, no where. Nusquam gentium, no
where, never. Valla in Rauden.
Nusquam non, for vbique, every where. Nutrico, are, and nutrio, ire, to
nouryshe. Nutricatus, tus, norture. Nutritious, the foster father. Nutritious,
nutritia, nutritium, that nourysshethe. Nutrix, cis, a nourse. Nutricula, idem.
Nutus, tus, a beck, or countenance with mouynge the eye or hand. Nuto, tare,
to becken or wynke. Nutu, ac tenutu, with a beck and rebecke, with a call and
a beck. Nux, nucis, a nutte. Nux auelana, a fylberde. Nux iuglans, a wall
nutte. Nux pinea, a pyneappull. Nux graeca, an almonde.
N, ANTE Y.
NIcteris, a reremous or back, with litel fete, that they seem to have none.
Nicticorax, racis, a night crow, or shryche crow. Nictileia, sacrifices by
night unto Bacchus. Nyctilopes, he that does see nothing by night, and
little in the evening. Nictimene, the daughter of Nictes, which lay with her
father, and afterward was turned into an owl, who would not be seen but at
night. Nymphae, goddesses of the waters, or spirited, being conuersaunt about
waters, elfes, women of the fayrie. sometime the Muses be so called. also young
bees, as soon as they have received their form. Nymphea, natural bathes.
Nymphus, he that is wedded, the brydegroome. Nysa, a man's name. also a city in
Arabia. Nysia, a kind of Iuie, having black beries. Nyserus, an isle by Grecia.
Nysus, the name of a man.
O, ANTE A.
OATARICA, the spaune of fisshe salted. Oaxis, a river in the isle of Crete or
Candy. Oaxus, a city in Crete or Candye.
O ANTE B.
OB, for at, ob rem, for my profit, ob oculos, Plaut.
before mine eyes. Obaeratus, bounden by ernest money. Obacero, are, to let a
man that he can not tell out his tale. Obambulo, are, to walk a gaynst an
other. also to walk together, or with an other. Obacerbo, are, to make one
angry. Obaresco, scere, to dry all about. Obaudio, ite, to here hardly, or
unwillingly. sometime to obey. Obba, a bottelle. Obcaeco, care, to blind.
Obdo, dear, to thruste again, or put to. Obdormio, ire, to sleep fast or
soundly. Obduco, xi, ere, to lay over, or cover a thing sometime to uncover or
open. also to bring against or overthwart a place. Obdulcesco, scere, to be
sweet about. Obdureo, rui, ere, and obduresco, scere, to be hard. Obduro,
are, to make hard. Obedio, dire, to obey. Obedo, dear, to consume or eat al
about. Obeliscus, a great stone, square like a butte, waxing smaller and
smaller, until the top, of a great height, made plain by a warkman: there
were of them diverse in Rome. Obelus, a spyt or broche, also a long strike in
writing like a spit, for a note or diversity. Obeo, iui, ire, to go to, to go
about, to be at hand, to mete with one. Obesus, a, um, fat, gross of body.
Obire mortem, obire diem, to dye. Obire vadimonium, to go to be surety. Liuius.
Obire legationem, to go in ambassade. Obire prouinciam, to exercise
authority. Obire bellum, to go to battle. Obire haereditatem, to take
possession of lands, wherein a man has a state of inherytaunce. Obedibo,
was in the old time used for obediam, I shall obey. Obequito, tare, to ride
about. Oberro, are, to wander about. Obesco, care, to feed fat. Obesus, a
man that is very fat. Obesitas, fattenesse. Obesus, a, um, in Virgil is
fat, Vergilius. Suetonius
in Neuio it sygnifieth lean or little. it is most commonly taken for fat
in the body. Obex, bicis, an obiecte or let. Obgannio, and ogga^nio, ire, to
whister in ons ear. Also to tell a thing often. Obherbesco, scere, to grow
up as herbs done. Obiaceo, cui, cere, to lie about. Obiecto, tare, to
object, or often impute, or lay to ones charge, also to cast out. Obiectum,
any thing that is before a man's eyes, and may be seen. Obiectus, ta, tu^,
thrown or laid against. Obiectus, tus, the layenge or setting of a thing
before ones eyes. Obiicio, ieci, iicere, to lay or throw against, or to lay
before one. Obigitare, to stere or move before. Sex. Pom.
Obinunt, they dye. Obiter, by the way, incidently, beside the purpose, in the
mean time, precisely. Obirus, ta, tum, the act or conclusion. Obitus, tus,
the dieng or decesse of a man. sometime the coming of one. The ancient writers
took obitum for the access of one. Obiurgo, are, to chide or rebuke.
Obiurgatio, chiding, rebukynge. Obiuro, rare, to bind by an oath. Obiurgator,
and obiurgatrix, he or she that chydeth or rebukes. Oblatio, offryng. Oblatus,
ta, tum, offered. Oblecto, ari, and oblector, ari, to delight. Oblectatio
oblectame^ and oblectamentu^, recreatio^ Oblicio, to take recreation or
pleasure. Obligo, are, to bind. Obligatio, an obligation or bond. Obligurio,
ire, to eat delicate meats gredily or rauenousely, and to consume goods in
feastynge and bankettynge. Obliquus, a, um, contrary to straight. Cor. Tacitus
lib. 2.
Oblique perstringere, to taunte or check. Oblimo, are, to cover with mudde or
soft claye. sometime to stop or daube. Oblino, ere, to imbrue or make foul.
Obliteratus, ta, tum, scraped out, or blotted. Oblitero, are, to scrape out, or
put out of remembrance. Obliteratio, a scrapynge or blottynge out of a
word. Oblitus, ta, tum, forgotten. Oblitus, imbrued, defiled. Obliuiosus, a,
um, forgettefull. Obliuiscor, sceri, sci, to forgette. Obliuium,
forgetfulness. Oblo^utio, ill report. Plautus in C^^gul.
Obloquor, eris, qui, to speak against or contrary, to report ylle, to
curse. Obloquutor, an ill reporter, or detracter. ^
Oblucinio, are, to err. Oblucinasse, to have erred. Obmanens, abiding long.
Obmoueto, move or put to. Obmordeo, ere, to byte. Obmutesco, as we communely
say, I hold my peace, I speak not, I hold my tongue. Obnato, tare, to swymme
against. Obnecto, to knytte fast. Obnexus, a um, fast knytte. Obnexio, a
fast knyttynge. Obnitor, teris, ti, to resyste. Obnoxious, a, um, bounden,
subject, apt, in danger. sometime it sygnifyeth gyltie or fautie. Sum tibi
obnoxious, I am bounden unto the, obnoxious morbis, subject to sickness.
Periculis obnoxious, subject to perils. etc. Minari interdu^ ferro, nisi sibi
obnoxia foret, And thretned her sommetyme with his weapon, if she would not be
obediente to his requests. Salustius. Colum. 5. Ci. ad At.
Obnoxium feris, Cast out to wild beasts. Obnoxie, fearfully, like a
subject. Obnubo, bear, to hyde. Obnubilo, are, to make dark. Obnuere, to
cover the heed or body. Obnuntiare, to deny, to resyste against a thing
purposed. Obolus, a poyse wayinge half a scruple. it was also a coin of
silver, which varied in poyse after the country, as obolus Atticus, Salu. in
orati. Memmii.
obolus Romanus, obolus Hebraicus. Oborior, ri, to begin to spring or come
forth Obrado, rasi, dear, to shave against the here. Obortus, a, um, begone or
spronge, as rumor obortus, tidings spronge. Ob rem, for the purpose. Obrepo,
pere, to come privily or steal in, to come unawares or unlooked for. Obrepere ad
honores, Ci. in (...)
to come or attain to honor by crafty dissimulation. Obreptio, the getting
or obteynynge of a thing in form aforesaid. Obrepticiae literae, letters
opteyned by the said means. Obrideo, dear, to laugh against one. Obrideo, si,
dear, to laugh at one, or to mock one. Obsio, a mock. Obrigeo, gui, gere, and
obrigesco, scere, to be or wax styffe for cold. Obrion, one of the yles
called fortunate. Obryzum, pure or fine gold. Obripio, ripui, ripere, is in
hydynge sum thing, which should be spoken, to atteyne the thing that we
desire. Obrodo, rosi, dear, to gnawe about. Obrogo, are, to check or
interrupte a man in his speech. Obrogare legem, to derogate one law by an
other. Obruo, ere, to overthrow, to cover a thing in casting an other thing
over it. Obrutania fulmina, lyghtnynges, which sodaynely happen, throwynge
down and burning things, before they be procured or looked for. Obsaturo,
rare, to be filled to much with a thing. Obsaluto, are, to offer my self to
salute one. Obsatum, old writers used for hallowed. Obsaeuio, ire, to be wode
angry against one. Plaut^^ in Epid.
Obscoeno, are, to bring or cause ill luck. Obscoenus, na, number, abhomynable,
all thing which is to be eschewed, dysshonest, unclean, pernicious, Also
brynging ill luck. Obscoenitas, villainy in acts, rybauldrie. Obscurus, a, um,
dark, hid, dysfuse, unknown, of no gentle blood. Obscuritas, darkness,
difficulty, vngentylnesse of bloudde. Obscuro, are, to make dark, to shadow,
to hide, to keep in silence or from the knowledge of other, to make of no
reputation. Obsecratio, a special desire. No. (...)
Obsecro, are, to beseech or heartily pray, Obsecrare ab aliquo, to desire of
one. Obsecro, is sometime an aduerbe. Hem, obsecro anis est? How, I pray the is
that he? Terent in Eunuc^o.
Obsecundo, are, to make prosperouse, also to obey or do all thing at an other
ma^s will, to make a thing better than it seems to be. Obsecundanter,
obediently. Obsepio, iui, ire, to enclose about with an hedge Obsequela,
dilygence, endeavor. Obsequia, things done to the pleasure or appetite of him,
that they be done for. Obsequens, obedient. Obsequentissime, with great
obedience. Obsequere animo, Take thy pleasure, make good chere. Obsequibilis,
diligent, ready to do that, which is commanded. Obsequiosus, idem. Obsequium,
redynes to do all that is commanded. sometime it sygnifieth flattery.
Obsequor, eris, qui, to follow an other man's pleasure. Obsero, seri, rere, to
sow or set about, to plant. Obsero, are, to lock or shut a door.
Obseruabilis, le, mete to be observed, worthy to be had in reverence.
Obseruantia, reverence, obseruaunce. Obseruatio, idem. Plautus in Asinar.
Obseruo, are, to awayte diligently with the eyes, and also the mind, to
honor, to take good head, to have in reverence. Obseruare ianuam, to keep the
door. Obses, idis, an hostage, or pledge in wars Obsessi, they which ar
besieged, that they may not issu out of the place where they are. Obsessor,
oris, he that lays siege. Obsidiae, arum, lyenge in awayte, to take away any
thing craftily. Obsidianum nitrum, a glass which is pure black.
Obsidionalis corona, a garlande given to them, which delivered a town or
fortress besyeged with enemies, which was of grass. Obsidior, aris, ari, to
ly in await to take one. Obsidium, obsidio, obsessio, a syege about a town or
fortress. Obsido, and obsideo, sessi, dear, to lay siege. Obsigno, are, to
close letters and seal them. Also to sign them. Obsignator, toris, he that
puts to his sele or sign to a deed or instrument. Obsipo, are, to throw or
cast, as when men of the country do say. Obsipa pullis escam, Cast meat
to the chyckens. Obsisto, stiti, sistere, to resyste. Obsitus, ta, tum,
wrapped, set about with herbs or trees. Obsolesco, scere, to decay, to wax
old, to be out of use. Obsoletus, ta, tum, decayed, old, out of use, worn,
as a garment, when it is bare. Valla in Rauden.
Obsonium, all meats, except bread and potage. Obsonus, sona, number, that
which has an ill sown. Obsono, and obsonor, nari, to feast or banquet.
Obsonito, tare, idem. Obsonatio, feastynge or bankettynge. Obsonator, and
obsonatrix, he or she that makes feasts or bankettes. Obsono, are, to sown
ill. Obsorbeo, bui, bear, and obsorbo, psi, bear, to suppe up all. Obsordeo,
dui, sordere, to be filthy or unclean, or sluttyshe. Nonius declaryth it to
wax old. Obstaculum, an obstacle or impediment. Obstetrico, care, to do the
office of a mydwyfe. Obstetrix, tricis, a mydwyfe. Obstinare, obstinately, or
fyrmely. Obstinatus, ta, tum, obstinate, firm, or stable Obstinatio,
obstynacie, styffenes in opinion. Obstino, are, to be obstinate, or persist
firm in one sentence or purpose. Obstipo, pare, to stop. Obstipus, crouped
shouldred. Obstitum, crooked, sometime vyolated. Obsto, stiti, stare, to
withstand, to let. Obstrepo, pere, to cry out on one, or make a noise.
Obstrigillo, are, to resist or repugne against, to speak in detraction of one.
Obstringo, xi, gere, to bind or tie. Obstrictus, bounden. Obstringere fidem,
to make a faythefulle promise. Obstrudo, fi, dear, to hyde, to stop a man's
throat, that he can not eat meat. Plautus in Stich. Pom. Fest.
Obstrudulentum, a stoppynge. Obstruo, xi, struere, to shut, to stop.
Obstructus, stopped or shut. Obstruere luminibus, to set that a man can
not look out of his wyndowes, Cice. pro domo sua.
or to stop his lyghtes. Obstupidus, a, um, astonyed. Obstupefacio, facere,
to abasshe, Plautus in Milite.
or make abashed. Obstupesco, scere, to be abashed. Obsum, obsui, obesse, to
hurt or hinder, or indamage. Obsurdesco, obsurdescere, to be or wax deaffe.
Obtempero, perare, to obey, or be at commandment. Obtendo, to lay an excuse.
Obtendiculum, a colorable answer. Obtentus, tus, a pretense. Obtero, triui,
obterere, to tread or thruste down, to suffocate, to bruyse. Obtego,
obtegere, to cover about. Obtestatio, an humble desire, proprely not to do a
thing. Also to take god or some other thing to witness. Obtestor, aris, ari,
humbly to beseech, to desire for gods sake, or for the remembrance of some
thing, which to him that is desired, is thankfully herd. Obtexo, ere, to
wayue about. Obticeo, cui, cere, to keep silence, not to speak. Obturo, are,
to shut. Obtueor, eri, to behold, to look on. Obturatio, shutting. Obtineo,
^ere, to opteyne, to hold, to retain still, to get, sometime to have. Si
istam animi firmitudine^ obtines, salui sumus, If thou haste that firmness of
courage, we be saulfe. Obtingere, to hap. Obtigit, it happened. Obtorpesco,
obtorpui, pescere, to be very slow or dull. Obtorqueo, obtorsi, obtorquere, to
wringe or wrythe about. Obtrecto, tare, to ylle report, to deprave, to have
in de^pyte. Obtrectater, toris, an ill reporter, or backbyter. Obtrectatio, ylle
report. Obtrigo, are, to bind by an oath. Obtrudo, si, dear, to thruste
down, to put to with force. Obtrudit fores, He pullid to the door. (...) in
(...).
Also to set forth. Aliquid prius obtrudamus, Let us first set forth
sommewhat. Terent in (...).
Obtrudere vxorem, to give to a man a wife against his will or appetite.
Obtrunco, uncare, to slay, also to stryke of a man's heed. Obtundo, dear, to
stryke, to break, to make dull, to hurt a man with speking, to make werye.
Obturbo, are, to trouble all. Obtusus, a, um, dulle. Obtutus, tus, and
obtuitus, a look or regard. Obuagio, gire, to cry out, as a child. Obuallo,
are, to enuyronne or compass about with a dyche or wall. Obuaricator, toris,
he that tourneth one out of the right way, or lets him that he may not
pass. Obuaro, are, to peruerte. Obuarico, care, to stop or let oone of his
passage. Obuenio, nire, to comme against, to mete with. also to happen.
Obuersor, aris, ari, to be present, to come in remembrance. Cicer. pro Sextio.
Obuerto, and obuerso, tere, to turn again, or back. Sed mihi ante oculos
obuersabatur reipub. dignitas, quae me ad se rapit. But before mine eyes camme
the estate of the publyque weal, which plucketh me unto her. Obuiam, an
aduerbe, which signifies before in the way, against one. Obuiam ire, to go
against one, to prevent. Obuio, are, to meet with one. Obuius, a, um, that
which meteth with one. Obumbro, brare, to make dark with a shadow: sometime
to defend. Obuolo, are, to fly against. Obuos sacro, the ancient Romans
used for obsecro, I beseech you.
O, ANTE C.
OCca, an harowe or dragge, which has iron teeth, wherewith cloddes are
broken. Occatio, a breaking of cloddes, or harrowynge. Occaeco, care, to make
blind. Occalleo, ere, to wax or be hard flesshed, or brauned, like as a bore
is. Occano, and occino, occanui, and occini, occanere, and occinere, to sing
against one, to lay in rebuke. Occaso, sere, to be lost, or undone. Plautus
in Casi.
Occasio, occasyon. Occasiuncula, a small occasyon. Occasus, us, death of man or beast. Also the going down of the son, or sonneglade. Occatorium,
an harrowynge. Colum^. li. 2. Pom. Fe^^.
Occedo, pro accedo. Occentassint for conuitia fecerint, They shall give rebukes
or words of reproach. Occento, tare, to cry out against one with rebukefull
words. Occentus, tus, where one syngeth against another. It may be also taken
for a countretenor. Occepso, pro incepero, I shall begin. Plaut^^.
Occidens, it is, the west, or ponent. Occidio, onis, a slaughter. Occido, di,
dear, to slay or wound to death, to fall grievously. Occisa res est, the matter
is dasshed. Occitantur, for frequenter occiduntur, they be slain here and
there, or in diverse places. Occido, dear, to fall down, to perysshe utterly,
to dye, to goo down, as the sun does, and other sterres. Occidit spes
nostra, our hope is lost. Plautus in Pseudo^^*
Occisa est haec res, this thing is lost or in despair. Occiduum, the place
where the sun goes down. Occino, nere, to sing to another. Occilare, to
bear or buffat. Plaut. in Casina.
Occissimus, of all other most lost or desperate. Occifio, onis, a slaughter
or death of men or catell. Occidi, I am deed, I am lost. Occipio, pere, to
begin. Occiput, and occipitium, the hinder part of the heed. Occlamito,
tare, to cry out. Occludo, dear, to shytte fast. Occludere linguam, to
stop a man from speaking. Occlusus, occlusior, occlusissimus, fast shut.
Occo, occare, to harrowe and break cloddes and balkes in the corn fields,
Also to cover with earth. Occulo, lere, to hyde. Occulto, tare, idem. Ocultus,
ta, tum, hyd, which is not known. Occulte, paiuyly, unknown. Occumbo, cubui,
cumbere, to be slain, to be deedly wounded. Occupatitius ager, the field,
which is neglected of the owner, and labored by other. Occupo, are, to
occupy, to get or take before an other man, to use in commune, to take or
hold a thing with force, to let or empeche, to possede, sometime to lend
for advantage. Occupans, it is, he that does occupy or use a thing, the
occupier. Cl. in Ver. act. 2.
Occupatus, let, in business, occupied. Occupatio, a color in rhetorike,
where the playntyfe in preventing the words of the defendaunt, reherceth that
which he will lay for excuse, and disproueth it. Plautus in Menech.
Occupare consilium, to find advise or counsel. Occupare locum, to take or
keep a place with force. Liui, li. 33.
Occurro, si, rere, to meet with, to come to remembrance, to offer him self.
Also to resist, to run, to come to mind, or remembrance, also to be
proffred. Occurso, are, the frequentatiue of occurro, to come often to
remembrance, to mete often, or run against one. Occursus, us, a runnynge
against one. Oceanus, the sea, which gothe about all the world. Alsoo a
great poole made in Rome, for many persons to swymme in. Oceanius, a, um, of
the occean see. Ocellatus, ta, tum, that which has eyes, or holes like to
eyes. Ocha, a goose. Ocquinisco, scere, to inclyne or bow to. Ochus, a river
which passes through Acarnania, a countray in greece. Ochra, oker, which
paynters do use. Otior, aris, ari, to be unoccupied, or without business.
Otiosus, ydell, unoccupied, quyete. Otium, vacation from labor, leyser,
quietness, ydelnes, lack of busynes. Ocreae, leg harneyse, boots. Ocreatus,
boted or harneised on the leggis. Octangulus, a, um, eight cornerd. Octo,
eight. Octies, eight times. Octonus, a, um, the number of eight, in sundry
partis. Octobris, the month of Octobre. Octopes, having eight feet. Sueton.
in Cali. Quint.
Octophorum, a carre with eight wheles. Oculatus, full of eyes, also quick
sigted, circumspect, espyenge a thing shortly. Oculatus testis, a witness
which saw the thing. Oculeus, full of eyes, wyly. Oculis captus, blind.
Oculitus eam amat, he loves her as well as his own eyes. Oculus, an eye,
alsoo a young budde of a tree. Oculu^ adijcere, to be in love with the thing,
which is seen. Ocymum, an herb. Ocyor, swifter, ocyus idem. Ocyssimus, a, um,
most swift. Ocyus, sooner, quicklyer.
O, ANTE D.
ODaea, places, wherein singing is exercysed. Ode, a song. Odfacio, for
olfacio, cere, to smelle. Odi, I hate, or have hated: Odisse, to hate, or have
hated. Odiosus, he that is hated, displesant, troublous, tediouse. Odiose, with
hate, displeasantly. Odit eum cane peius, and angue, He hatethe him wars than a
dog or a serpente: as who says, mortally without hope of reconcylynge.
Odites, oone of the sons of Ixion the Centaure. Odium, hate, displeasure,
tediousenes. Odoeporicon, an Itenerary, wherein is written the distance of one
place from an another, or a like thing, as the iestes of princis are, assignynge
their iourneys. Odor, oris, and odos, savor, sent. Odoramentum, every thing
that sauoureth well. also savor. Odorarius, a maker or seller of things that
smelle sweet. Odoratus, ta, tum, that which is perfumed. sometime that which
does savor, odoriferous, or smelling sweet. Odorator, a hounde made to the
suit. Odoriferus, a, um, idem. Odorisecus, a hounde or spanell, which hunteth
by sent. Odoro, and odoror, ari, to smell. Odorus, a, um, that which sends
furthe savor, or has a good savor.
O, ANTE E.
OEagius, a river in the countraye of Thracia. Oeanthe, a city, alsoo the
flower of a vine. Oebades, king Darius horsekepar, by whose polycye he
atteyned to the kyngedome of Persia. Oebalia, the countraye in Greece, called
also Laconia. Oebalus, a man's name. Oechalia, a city in Laconia. Oeconomia,
the orderinge and prouydinge of things concerning household, alsoo an order in
writing, whereby every thing is set in his propre place. Oeconomica,
pertayninge to husbandry. Oeconomus, a steward of household. Oeci, placis,
where women do sit and work with woull or sylke. Oecumenicus, universal,
pertayninge to all the world. Oecumenicum consilium, a general counsel,
wherein things are universally treated concerning all countries. Oedipus, a
man, which dissolved subtle and dark questions. Oedipodionius, nia, um,
belonging to Oedipus. Oenanthe, the bery of a wild vine. Oenamhinum, an
oynemente made of the said bery. Oeneus, the father of Deianira, the last wife
of Hercules. Oenophorus, a servant, which brings wine to the table.
Oenophorum, a pot wherein wine is carried. Oenopola, a vyntenar, or tauernour.
Oenopolium, a wine tavern. Oenotria, Italy. Oenotrides, two Isles nyghe to
Calabria. Oesipum, the fylthy oil, which is in wull, that is in the flanks of
a sheep, or about his neck, which oil is soden out, and used for medicyne.
Oestrum, woodnesse, or mad fury: alsoo a fly, which makes a great noise,
when he flies, some do suppose it to be, a dor, like to a be, but that he is
black and grettar. Oeta, a mountain in Thessaly. Oeteus, the father of Medea,
wife of Jason.
O, ANTE F.
OFfa, a poodinge, also a dish made with fatt broth, hard chese, peper, and
cynamom, or other like iunkat. sometime it is taken for a morsel. Offarius, and
offaria, a maker of such iunckettes. Offatim, in morselles. Offector, toris, a
dyar. Offella, a little morsel, as of flesh mynced, also a potage made with
pieces of flesh, as stuyd brothe or forced gruell. Offendo, dear, to meet
with, to fall into, to find by chance, to stryke or hytte any thing unware,
to offend. Offendere apud aliquem, to do a thing, which lyketh not them
that do see it done. Offendiculum, an impediment or let, an obstacle.
Offendimentum, and offendix, the knotte of a ribon or lase, wherewith a bonet
or hatte is knytte fast to the heed. Offensa, offensio, and offensus, us, an
offense. Offensatio, a metynge. Offensaculum, that which is laid in a man's
way, whereat he stumbleth. Offensator, satoris, he that stackereth in redinge,
as if he were not perfyte in reding, Quint.
or redeth otherwise than it is written. Offensans, it is, that which hurts or
lets. Offenso, are, to hytte often, or to let. Offensiuncula, a small
offense. Offercio, to stuff or fill. Offero, obtuli, offerre, to offer, or
present, to give willyngly, to promise. Offerumentae, strypes. Plau i^ Rudes.
Ne offerumentas habebis plureis in tergo tuo, quam vlla nauis lo^ga clauos,
tum ego ero mendacissimus, and if thou have not moo strypes on the skyn of thy
back, than a galy has nails, I shall be the falsyst liar that ever was.
Offerumenta, offrynges, things offered to God. Offerre auxilium, to promise
aid. Offerre crimen, Justin.
to put a complaynte against one. Offerre incendium, Cice. ad Pont, Cicero in
^ael^^*
Domus ardebat in Palatio non fortuiro, sed oblato ince^dio, My house in the
Palaice did burn not by any chance, but by fire thrast in by some man.
Pla^tus in ^en.
Offerre mendicitatem, to bring one unto poverty. Offerre moram, to let.
Offerre se obinam, to mete with one. Cic. off. 3. Terent. in Adelph.
Offerre stuprum, to commit aduoutry. Offerre vitium virgini, to defloure a
virgyn. Officere luminibus, to stop the lyghtes. Officina, a werkhouse, a
shop. Officialis, ale, pertayninge to offices or duties. Quint Ilia.
Officialis, an officer. Officio, ficere, to hurt, sometime to do, also to die
cloth. Officiosus, a seruysable man, or he that is glad to please, or does
well his duetye. Officiosus dolor, a grief which proceeds of a good cause or
raison. Officium, office, duetye, or a thing, which ought to be done. It is
sometime taken for honor done to one, and it may be used for that, which we
do call homage, done in such form as our law does appoint it, it is also
taken for benefyte. Cic. de amicitia.
Officium vsurpare, to do his duetye. Officiose, diligently, seruisably.
Offirmo, are, to abide in one purpose or opinion, to be obstinate. Offlecto,
xi, tere, to turn a thing contrary or about. Offoco, are, to power water
into the mouth of a man or beast. Offritiae, crafty or deceytfull taches.
Offringo, ere, to break with a plough, land cared before. Offuciae,
cawrellis, crafty ways to deceive. Offula, a little morsel. Offundo, fusi,
dear, to power about, to make dark or blind, to stayne, to cast in, or
bring in. Offuco, care, to put water or other lycour into a man's mouth, to
sowke down, as they use to do to like men, which for feoblenesse can not by
them selfs take any sustenaunce. Offuseo, are, to make black, or dark.
O, ANTE G.
OGdous, a king of Egypt, which first builded the city of Memphis. Ogdoas,
adis, the number of eight. Ogdolapis, a river which comes out of the hills
called Alps, and runs to Rome. Oggannio, ire, to prate, to braule, to
speak with chydinge. Oggero, ^si, gerere, to cast in, or set. Oculos oggerere,
to cast or set the eyes on one. Oggrassari, to go. Plaut. in Trucu.
Ogyges, he which first builded the city of Thebes. Ogygeus, a, um, made or
found by Ogyges. Ogygea, an I Will between Phenicea and Syria. Ogyris, an I Will in
Syria.

OHe, an exclamation, signifienge that he, which speaks that word ^s saciate
or weary of that, which he sees or heereth.
O, ANTE I.
Oino meli, wine and honey soden together
O, ANTE L.
OLea, is most proprely the fruit of an olyue: yet sometime it is used for an
olyue tree. Oleaceus, a, um, oily. Oleacu^, a color, which is mixed with grene,
black, yelowe, and white. Oleaginus, a, um, of an olyue tree. Oleagineus,
idem. Olearis, re, and olearius, a, um, pertayninge to oil. Olearius, a maker
of oil. Olearus, one of the Isles called Ciclades. Oleaster, a wild olyue.
Oleastellus, a diminutif of Oleaster. Oleastrinum, oil of wild olyues.
Olearus, a, um, of oil. Oleitas, the time of gatheringe of olyues. Olenus, a
city in Greece. Olenius, a, um, of that city. Olentica, things which have an
ill savor. Oleo, eui, and olui, olere, to savor, or have savor. Oleosus, a,
um, full of oil. Olesco, lescere, to grow. Oletum, a place where olyues do
grow, also the dung or ordure of a man, proprely it is a draught or iakes.
Oleum, oil. Olfacio, feci, facere, to smell. Olfacto, are, to smell much or
often. Olfactus, tus, the sense of smellyng. Olibantum, a measure of wine.
Olidus, da, dum, that which has a great savor, either good or badde, most
communely stinkinge. Oligarchici, they which do advance the state of noble
men and rich men, above the popular astate. Olim, sometime, as well in the
time passed as in the time to come, now late, long time passed. Olitor, a
gardynar, or sellar of herbs and roots. Olitorius, a, um, pertaining to a pot
garden. Oliua, an olyue tree. Oliueta, the time of gatherynge of olyue beryes.
Oliuerum, a place where do grow olyue trees. Oliuina, plenty of olyues, alsoo
revenues, which do come of olyues. Oliuitas, and oleitas, the qualytie of
olyues, the gatheringe time of olyues. Olino, are, to gather olyues. Plautus in
Pseudolo.
Oliuum, oil olyue. Olla, a pot. Ollares, grapes conseruyd in pottes. Olli,
for iili. Varro.
Ollula, a little pot. Ololy goues, crokynge frogs. Olor, oris, a wild
swanne. Olus, leris, herbs which serve for potage, pot herbs. Oluscula, small
herbs. Olus atrum, an herb called persely. Olympia, a city between the
hills of Ossa and Olympus. Olympia, orum, plays and great games, on the hill
of Olympus, made to the honor of Jupiter. Olympiacus, ca, cum, pertaining to
that plays or hill. Olympias, piadis, the space of five years, whereby the
old greeks did account, as we do now by the years of our lord: as ^he first
Olympias, the second, the third. and so forth. Olympicus, ca, cum, of Olympus.
Olypionices, he that has had victory in the games at Olympus. Olympius, a, um,
heavenly. Olympus, a mountain or hill in Greece, above the which appears no
cloud: and therefore among the Poets it is usurped for heaven. Olynthus, a
city in Thracia. Olyras, a river in Greece by the place called Thermopylas.
Olyfippum, a city in portugal, now called Vlysbona, in englysh Lusseborn.
O, ANTE M.
OMasum, a fat gut, or chitterling. Omen, minis, luck, also a word or
sentence suddenly spoken, after the which some thing happens to follow
according thereunto, above the expectation of them which herd it. Omentum, the
call or sewet, wherein all the bowelles are lapped, also the thynne skyn in the
heed, wherein the brain is contained: of some called the ryme of the brain,
and of surgeons Pia matter. Omentatus, ta, tum, mixed with sewet. Ominor, aris,
ari, and omino, aui, are, to guess what shall happen or follow. Ominator, oris,
he that tells a man's luck or fortune. Ominosus, a, um, lucky. Terea. in
