Omissus, a, um, left, not meddled with. Omisso animo, Vbi te vidi animo esse
omisso, wha^ I saw that thou caryddest for nothing. Omitto, omisi, omittere,
to forbear, to leave, to neglect. Omit hunc, let him alone, pardon him.
Terea. Phor^^.
Omit me, let me go. Omne tulit punctu^, he touched every point, A proverb.
applied to him, which omitteth nothing expedient or necessary, and is
therefore of all men commendyd. Omnibus numeris, in all points. Res est omnibus
numeris absoluta, it is a thing perfyte in all points. Omnifariam, all manner
of ways, of every kind. Omnifarius, a, um, sondrye, diverse, Omnigenus, a,
um, of every kind. Omnimodus, da, dum, all manner. Omnino, holy, thoroughly,
allwaye, finally. Omnipotens, it is, allmyghty. Omnis, ne, all. Omophagi, they
which do eat raw flesh. Omphax, acis, a grape not fully ripe. Omphacium,
licour made of fruit that is not ripe, as of grapes, and than is it called
veriuyse. Omphacium vinum, a grene wine not pleasant or sweet. Omphacinum
olcum, oil made of olyues, not being ripe. Omutesco, tescere, to be dombe,
and can not speak.
O, ANTE N.
ONae, sweet fygges. Onager, onagri, a wild Ass. Onerarius, a, um, that which
seruethe for bourdon. Onero, are, to charge, bourdon, or lade. Onerare populum,
to put impositions or taxes on the people. Oneratus, ta, tum, bourdayned,
ladyd. Onerarius, raria, rarium, that whereon bourbourdayne is laid. Onerosus,
a, um, bourdeinous. Onixes, a kind, of marble. Oniscus, a worm, which bends
him self like a bow when he goes, which is reed, and found under trees,
which have lain long on the ground. Onoba, a city. Onocentaurus, a beast
half a man, half an ass. Onocrotalus, a bird like to a swanne, which
putting his heed into the water, brayeth like an ass. Onomatopeia, a word
made of sown or pronouncinge, as bletinge of a sheep, lowinge of a cow,
hissinge of an adder. Ononium, a blind nettyll. Onus, oneris, a bourdon, a
lode. Onustus, ta, tum, lodyd. Onyx, ychis, a white stone, like to a man's
nail, also some be found in Inde, which are of diverse colors, having white
spots like unto eyes. Onychinus, na, um, made of the stone called Onyx.
O, ANTE P.
OPaco, care, to shadow. Opacus, ca, cum, shadowed, or in the shadow. Opera,
ae, wark, labor. Operae, plurali tantum, warkmen, laborers. Opera, warkes,
buyldinges, private or commune. Operam do, operam impendo, operam nauo, I do
mine yndeuour, I put to my diligence I spend my labor. Operarius, a laborar.
Operarius, a, um, that which is done with labor. Operculo, are, to keuer a
vessel. Operculum, a keueringe or led. Operaeprecium, profitable, necessary,
a joyful thing, much to be esteemed. Operimentum, any thing that keuerith.
Operio, rui, to keuer, or hyde. Operior, iris, iri, to tarry, to abide. Operor,
aris, ari, to wark. Operatio, the wark, or that wheraboute a man labors.
Operosus, a, um, busy, diligent in labouringe laboriouse, paynefull.
Opertorium, a coueringe. Ophiaca, pertaining to serpents, they were books,
which Nicander, and Petridius wrate, of the nature of serpents. Ophiophagi,
people in Ethiope, which do eat serpents. Ophiucus, the name of Esculapius,
because that he is ymagyned to hold a serpent in his hand. Ophites, a stone
having spots like a serpente. Opicus, pica, picum, unclean, dishonest,
shameless. Opici, they which used abominable rybauldry. Opifex, ficis, a
warkman, a craftys man. Opifi cium, the wark. Opigena, Juno, Juno was so called
of women, because they supposed, that she help them when they trauayled.
Opilio, onis, a shepeherde. Opima spolia, the spoil, which by one chief
Capytayne is taken from another in battle, as his cote armure or harneys.
Opime, aboundauntly, richely. Opimo, are, to make fat. Opimus, ma, mum, fat,
also rich. Opimium, seu opimianum vinum, wine which moughe endure good, two
hundred years. Opinabilis, le, that may be conceyned in opinion. Opinio, onis,
opinion, sometime hope, also fame. Opino, for opinor, I suppose. Opinor,
pinaris, nari, to suppose, Plautus in Bacch.
to have opinion. Opinatus, ta, tum, supposed. Opinator, toris, a supposar.
Opipare, plentuously. Opiparus, a, um, aboundaunt, fresh, or gaye. Coena
opipara, a delicate souper. Opis, opis, a lady, companyon to Diana, she was
also wife to Saturnus, and by her is signified the earth among the Poets.
Opistographus, a book written on the back side. Opisthotonicus, he that can not
turn his neck. Opisthotonos, the cricke, or disease, which lets a man to
turn his neck. Opiter, itris, he whose father deyed before his grandfather.
Opitulor, aris, ari, to help. Opitulator, oris, a helpar. Opitulus, Jupiter,
Jupiter the helpar at need. Opium, the juice of an herb called black Popye,
alsoo Opius, is he that fights in armure. Opobalsamum, balm natural, which
in a part of Judea, called Ierocinthe, stilleth out of a little thorn.
Opoponax, acis, the juice of an herb, called Panax. Oporice, a medicine made
of fruytes. Oporae, all fruits which do grow in the last end of somer.
Oporotheca, a place, wherein fruit is kept. Oportet, it behooves, it is
expedient or necessary. Oppedo, dear, to fart against one. Oppeto tere, to dye:
also to be slain. Oppetere sebrem, to fall into the fever. Oppidanus, a
cytezen or towns man. Oppidicus, idem. Oppidatim town by town. Oppido, an
aduerbe, signifienge very much, sometime it signifies furthwith, verily.
Oppidulum, a little town. Oppidum, a walled town, or city. Oppignero, are,
to lay in pledge. Oppilo, are, to stop or shit. Oppleo, ere, to fill full.
Opploto, are, to lament. Oppono, ere, to lay or put against. Opportunus, na,
number, that which is in due time, and as it ought to be. Salustius ^^^^g^r.
Opportunus iniuriae, fete or apt to take wrong. Opportunitas, tatis,
opportunity, convenient time. Opportunae, opportunatly conuenientely, as it
ought to be. Opprimo, ere, to oppress, to keep or shit in, to take sodaynely,
to rauyshe a woman, to grieve, to thrust hard. Opprobrium, and opprobramentu^,
a reproach Opprobro, are, to object against one, to reproach. Oppugno, are, to
assault. Ops, opis, the suster and wife of Saturn: also it signifies aid or
help. Opes, richesse. Opsonator, atoris, a puruayour of vytayles, or Catar.
Opsonatus, tus, and opsonatio, preparation for dinner, or souper. Opsonito,
tare, to prepare often for dinner or souper. Opsonium, al thing belonginge to a
meal, except bred and drink. Opsono, nare, and obsonor, onari, to prepare
things necessary for dinner, souper, or bankat. Optabilis, le, that which is
desired. Optato, with desire. Opticus, ca, cum, perspectife, pertaining to
sight. Optice, the science whereby the raison of sight is known. Optimates,
the heed men of a city, also they which defend the part of nobility and
rich men. Optimatus, tus, the state or condition of heed men of a town or
contraye. Optimus, best. Optio, the choice, the request or desire. It was also
to a captain in wars, a ministre to do his commandment, and be assistent
unto him. Opto, tare, to desire, to chouse, to require. Adopto, coopto, exopto,
vide suis locis. Opulento, tare, to make rich or plenteouse. Opulentus, ta,
tum, rich abundant. Opulentia, and opulentitas, richesse. Opuncalo, he that
syngethe like to a sheparde. Opulesco, scere, to be rich. Opus, operis, a
warke, a labor. Eius opere by his mean or diligence. Opus est, it is
necessary, or need. Si opus sit, if need be. Opus, opuntis, a city in Locris.
Opus intestinum, that which most communly is called impleme^tes of houshoulde,
proprely of timber, as fourmes, stools, cupboordes and other like things.
Opus est conuento. Ita res subita est, celeriter mihi hoc homine opus est, The
chance is so sudden, or the matter requires such have, that I must needs
speak with the man shortly or quickly. Opus est facto, it must needs be done,
or executed. Opus est remissam. Terent. i^ Hecyra.
Vosmet videte ia^ Laches and tu Pamphile, remissam opus sit nobis an reductam
domum, Now Laches and Pa^phile advise your selfs well, whither it be necessary,
that she be sent home, or fetched home. Opus sunt tibi, thou have need of them.
Plautus in Capt. Terent. in Heau.
Vt cu^ desponderim, des qui aurum ac vestem, atque alia quae opus sunt, That
when I have affiauncyd her, thou deliver money and apparayle, and all other
things needful. Plautus (...) Music.
Opere maxumo, with all means possible, in most hearty wise. Rex Seleucus me
opere orauit maxumo, vt sibi lationes cogerem, King Seleucus desired me, as
much as he possibly might, that I would geate him soldiers to be about his
person. Terent. in Eunuc^^
Thais maximo te orabat, opere vt cras redires, Thais desired the as hartyly as
she can, that thou woldeste come again to morrow.
O, ANTE R.
ORa, the extreme part of every thing, as the edge, the brym, the skirtes, the
hem, the border, the cabull that tyeth the ship. Ora marittima, the sea side.
Oraculum, where aunsweres were given by ydolles: sometime the answer, sometime
the saying of some wise man. Orarium, the vestement, wherein the priest does
say mass. Orata, a fyshe called a gylte heed. Oration, an oration, a prayer.
Orator, toris, an orator. Oratoria, Rhetorike. Oratoriae, like an orator, or
in form of Rhetorike. Oratorius, a, um, pertaining to an orator. Oratus,
tus, prayer. Orbiculatus, ta, tum, made round. Orbiculus, a little cerkle.
Orbicus, ca, cum, round. Orbis, a cerkle. Also the world. Orbs, dyshes, the
holes of the eien. sometime the eyes. Orbem facere, where people do gather
them round together in battle. Orbita, a whele, sometime the tracke that
wheels do make in the ground. Orbo, are, to depryue. Orbus, proprely blind.
Orbi, they which have lost their chylderne. Also orphans. Orbitas, the lack
of chylderne: sometime the lack of a father. Orbitus, ta, tum, round as a
cerkle. Orca, a great monster of the sea: also a great vessel, as a butte or
vate, wherein Rennyshe wine is put. Also a box, wherein dyce be shaken, and
after thrown on the tables. sometime a coffer. wherein wome^s payntynge is
kept. Orchades, thyrty Isles in the sea by Scotland. Orchestra, a place,
wherein the Senators and honorable persons sat to behold plays Orchomenus, a
mountain in Thessaly. also a city in Euboea. Orcomana, a beer, whereon dead
corses do lie. Orcus, a river of hell: alsoo an another in Thessalye. it is
sometime taken for hell. Ordinarius, a, um, wherein order is observed
ordinarye. sometime a scoffer or gester. Ordinare, to order or dispose. Ordior,
iris, orsus, iri, to be begin to speak. Ordo, dinis, order, the dew place,
the astate of men. In ordinem redigere, to keep oone within his bounds,
that he do not excede his degree. Sulustius in Iug.
Ordines, is in battle that, which is called the raye. Ordines seruare, to
kepethe raye. Ordinatim, in order. Ordines conturbare, to break or scatter the
raye. Orea, the bytte for a horse. Oreus, a name of Bacchus. Orestes, the son
of Agamemnon. Ore tenus, to the mouth. Orexis, is most taken for vomyte, all
be it sygnifieth appetite. Organa, all instruments of musyke. Organum, an
instrumente pertaining to building, also an ordinance of wars. Organarij,
makers of instruments. Orgia, ceremonies or songs, pertaynyng to infernal
gods, or to Bacchus. Orgyia, a measure contaynynge.vi. foot. Suidas does
write, that it is the space, which is contained between the hands stretched
abroad, which I suppose is a spanne. Oria, a fyshers boot Orichalcum, a
metal, which as I suppose is lattyn. Oriculum, for auricula, a little ear.
Oricos, a city of Epire. Oriens, orientis, the East. Orificium, the mouth of
any thing. Origanum, an herb, called organny. Origo, ginis, a beginning,
kind. Orion, a sign in the fyrmament. Orior, eris, and oriris, riri, to be
borne, to rise, to appiere. Oriundus, commen by auncetours out of some
country or city. sommetyme borne, Nati Carthagine, sed orundi a Syracusis,
Borne at Carthage, but by auncetoures descended from Syracuse in Sicile.
Oriza, a grain called Rise, which is most commonly eaten in Lent, with
Almonde milk. Orminium, an herb like to horehounde. Ornamentum, apparayle,
also honor. Ornithoboscion, a house where poultry is fed, a cowpe. Ornithon,
thonis, a place wherein birds are kept. Orno, nare, to garnish, to deck or
trymme, to make fair, to prepare, to make meet, to honor with some
authority or dignity. Ornatus, ta, tum, apparayled, trimmed, garnyshed,
instructed, fournyshed. Ornatus, tus, apparayl, trymming, deckyng. Oro, orare,
to pray, to demand, to speak openly and eloquently, as Orators do, to
plead. Orobia, a kind of Frenkynsence in little graynes. Orontes, a river by
the city of Antyoche. Orphanus, he which lacks his father and fatherly
succor. Orpheus, a poet, son of Apollo, and Calliopes. Orpheus, a, um, of
Orpheus. Orsus, he began. Orsus, he that begins to do a thing. Orsus, a,
um, begone. Orthodoxia, the right opinion or faith. Orthodoxus, a man of the
right opinion or faith. Orthogonius, a right corner. Orthographia, the right
form of writing. Orthopnoea, a disease, when a man can not fetch his
breathe, but holding his neck vpryghte. Orthopnoeci, they which have that
sickness. Orthostadios, a garmente, which was always worn vngyrte. Ortus, ti,
uide Hortus. Orti pensiles, gardeynes made on howses, or pyllours. Ortus, ta,
tum, borne. Ortus, tus, the birth or nativity, Also the rysynge of the son.
Ortygia, the name of an I Will. Ortix, tigis, a bird called a quayle. Oryx, gis,
a beast of the kind of gotes.
O, ANTE S.
OS, oris, the mouth, also the vysage: sometime the proporcion of all the
body, ^
sometime countenance, also presence, and language. Os distorquere, to make a
mow. Os durum, a shameless knave. Os sublini^e, to mock or deceive craftily,
with fair words or promyses. Plin de vi. (...).
Os, ossis, a bone. Ossum, idem. Osae, laws concerning devotion. Osanna, I
pray the save us. Osas^m, for Odi, I hate. Oscedo, dinis, yanynge or gapyng.
sommetyme stenche. Osci, people in Italye. Oscillo, are, to bow down. Ocilla,
little images of wax to be offered. Oscillum, a little mouth. sometime a
little image or poppette. Oscines, birds, which by their voices do sygnifie
somewhat to come or happen. Ocinum, a general name of birds, which do sing,
a singing bird. Oscis, the abhomynable use of carnalle sin. Oscito, tare,
to gape, as men do for lack of sleep. Oscitatio, gapynge, Also quyetenesse
from labor. Oscitanter, softely, aduysedly, sobrely. Oscitabunde, idem.
Osculana pugna, battaylle, wherein they, which were before vaynquysshed, have
the vyctorie. Osculum, a little mouth, also a kiss. Osculor, aris, ari, to
kiss. Osiris, osiridis, the son of Jupiter begot on Neobe, the daughter of
Phoroneus, which succeeded Phoroneus in the kingdom of the Argiues, and
afterward was king of Egypt, who after his death was honored for a god. Ossa,
a high mountain in Thessalye. Osseus, a, um, bonye, or of a bone.
Ossiculatim, one boon from an another in pieces. Ossifragus, fraga, gum, that
which breaks boones. Ossilegium, a gatherynge of bones. Ossiculum, a little
bone. Ossuaria, a shryne or like thing, where the bones of deed men are put.
Ostendo, di, dear, to show. Ostento, ostentare, to show often. Alsoo to
booste. Ostentum, a thing, which happens seldom, and betokens, that some
strange thing shall happen. As a blasyng sterre, thunder on a fair day.
Sometime it signifies a thing monstrous. Ostento, tare, to boste.
Ostentatio, boostynge. Ostentus, tus, a skorne. Ostia, ostiorum, the entrees of
greatte ryuers, sometime havens. Ostia, a town nyghe to Rome. Ostiarius, a
porter. Ostiatim, from door to door. Ostiensis, a little hauyn at Rome.
Ostium, a door or gate. Ostracismus, a manner of exylynge of men at Athenes,
which excellyd other in power or authorytie: which exyle was done by
delyuerynge of oyster shelles, wherein the name of him, which should be exyled,
was written. Ostracum, a shelle. Ostrea, an oyster. Ostrearius panis, Brown
breadde, the which men are wont to eat with oysters. Ostreatus, ostreata,
ostreatum, hard as an oyster. Ostrinae uestes, garments of purple color.
Ostrum, purple or other like color. Osus, osurus, participles of Odi. Osus
sum, osus es, osus est, I hate, thou hate, he hates.
O, ANTE T.
OTior, swyfter. Otior, ari, to be ydell or at rest. Otiosus, a, um, ydell,
sure. Otiose, idelly, at leiser, surely, without care. Otium, idelnes, vacation
from labor, also leyser, rest, quietness. Othryades, a man's name of
Lacedemonia. Othrys, a hylle in Thessaly. Otides, birds like to partriches.
Otus, a shryche owl.
O, ANTE V.
OValis corona, a garlande of myrtels, given to him, which had vyctory without
effusion of bloudde. Ouatio, a small triumph of a prince or captain, which
had victory of his enmies without slaughter of men, or where battle was not
denounced: in the which triumph the captain went on foot, or only did ride
on a horse, with a garland of myrtelles on his heed, and his souldyours
singing about him. Ouatus, ta, tum, which is in symylitude of an egg.
Ouans, ouantis, reioysynge, being joyful. Ouiaria, a flock of sheep. Ouicula,
a little sheep. Ouifera gallina, a broude hen. Ouile, a fold or
sheepehowse. Ouillus, a, um, of a sheep. Ouinus, idem. Ouis, a sheep. Ouo,
are, to rejoice with noise or voice in a multitude. Ouum, an egg. Ouum ouo
simile, one egg like an another, applied unto them, which be like of
conditions or person. Ouo prognatus eodem, of oone father and mother, or
brought up under one master, or in one school.
O, ANTE X.
OXygala, sower milk. Oxygarum, sharp sauce. Oxylapathon, sorrel. Oxymeli,
honye and vynegre sodden together. Oxyporon, sharp sauce. Oxyporopola, he that
sells meat in sharp sauce, or sowce. Oxysaccharum, sugar and vynegre sodden
together, of sum men called Syrupus acerosus symplex. Oxytoca, medicines to
make a womanne to bring forth her birth quyckely.
O, ANTE Z.
OZena, soores about the nose, which have an ill savor. Ose, stynche of the
mouth. Ozinum, an herb called basyll.
P, ANTE A.
PABVLARIS, pabulare, pertaining to fourrage or meat for beastis. Pabulatio,
fourraginge. Pabulator, a forra grour. Pabulor, aris, ari, to goo in
forragynge. sometime to feed, as a beast does. Pabulum, forage or meat for
beasts. Pacate, peasybly. Pace tua, pace uestra, by thy license, by your
leave, or license. Pachiri, hills in the less Asia. Pachisos, a river of
Sicile. Pachynus, a mountain in Sicile on the sea side, or an elbowe of the
land there. Pacifer, feri, a brynger of peace. Pacificatorius, a, um, that
which does pacyfie. Pacifico, care, to pacify. Paciscor, sceris, sci, to
make couenaunte, Plinius.
to bargayne, Paco, are, to mitigate, to apease, to accord. Pactilis, le.
platted, Pactilis corona, a platted garlande. Pactio, an accord, agreement.
Erasm. in Chiliad.
Pactoliopes, exceeding richesse. Pactolus, a river in Lydia, having golden
grauelle. Pactum, sometime a participle sygnifienge couenanted, promised,
sometime a nowne, signifienge a covenant. Pactum transitionis, a safe conduite,
Ti. L^uius.
to pass from one country to an other, a pasport. Pacuuius, the name of a
noble poet. Padua, and Patauium, a City in Italye, by Venyce. Padus, a river
in Italye called the Po. Padusa, a river, which sum say is an arm of the
Po. Paean, an hymn in the praise of Apollo. sommetyme the same Apollo. It is
now taken for any hymn, made to the land of God, or our Lady. Paedagium,
lodging for servants and chylderne. Paedagogium, a bond servant.
Paedagogus, he that is appointed to await on chyldern to see them well ordered.
Paeda^etus, a man's name. Paederastes, a lover of chylderne in unhonest wise.
Paederastia, a viciouse love of chylderne. Paedia, erudition and institution in
good arts, as Gellius teaches. Paedico, paedicaui, pedicare, to commytte
buggerye. Paedor, paedoris, sluttysshenesse, uncleanness, fylthe. Paedotribes,
and pedotriba, a schoolemayster. Paeon, a foot in meter, which is of oone
long syllable and three short. Paeonia, an herb callydde Pyonye. Also a
countreye in Europa, and is a part of Macedonye. P^stum, a city in Lucania,
where there is abundance of Roses. Paestanus, na, number, of that city. Paetus,
he that looks a squynte upward. Paganalia, ploughmens holyday, as wakes be
now adays. Paganus, a man of the countreye, or of the vyllage: sommetyme it
is taken for him that goth not to battle. Pagasa, a town of Thessaly, which
after was called Demetrias. Pagatim, vyllage by vyllage. Pagina, the side of a
leaf in a book. Paginula, a little side of a leaf in a book. Pago, gis,
pepigi, gere, pactus, to make covenant. Pagus, a vyllage. Pagytis, the name of
a river and of a city, of which the people are called Pagyritae. Pala, a
spade, also a p^ele to put in breadde into the oven. Also a fan to make wind.
Also the brodest part of a ring. Palae, wedges or pieces, or gaddes of
metal when it is fined. Palaca, pieces of fine gold. Palaemon, onis, was
callid a god of the sea. Palaestina, a country in Syrie, ioynynge to Arabie,
called in holy scripture Philist^im. Palaestra, a wras^lyng place: also the
exercise of wrastlynge. Ci. de ora tare primo
It is also the comeliness of mouynge and gesture, according to the state or
degree of the person, which shows it. Palaestricum, idem. Palaestricus, a
wrasteler. Palaestricus, ca, cum, pertaynyng to wrastelynge. Palaestrita, he
that uses wrastlynge. Palam, openly, before men, that all men may see it.
Palamedes, a noble greek, which sound certain letters of greek, Also to
set an arraye in an hooste, and the form of watches, with the watch word.
Palangae, leauers or porters, wherewith they left and bear tymbre, and such
like things of greatte weight. Palango, palangare, to bear on leyuars or
porters. Palangarii, men, which do bear on leyuers or porters, things of
great poyse or weyghte. Palatiar, and palatual, a Sacrifyce done at Rome on
the hylle called Palatinum. Palatio, onis, Vitrunius* li. 2.
a foundacyon made in a maryse ground with pyles of timber. Palantes, they
that wander about, and wot not whither to go. Palanteum, a city builded on
the hill called Palatinus. Palantia, a city in Arragonia. Palatha, a pressed
fygge. Palatim, an aduerbe sygnifienge scattered and wandrynge here and there.
Palatina officia, offices within a princes palayce or court. Palatinus mons,
an hylle at Rome. Palatium, a palaise of an emperor or great king. Palatus,
seu palatu^, the rouse of the mouth. Palea, chafe of corn, also a gristell,
which fallethe down from the neck of a cock or capon. Palearium, the
Dewelappe of a Rudder beast. Also a place, wherein chafe is kept. Paleatus,
made or myxte with chafe. Pales, called goddess of shepeherdes and of
pasture. Palene, a city, so called of Pallena, the daughter of Sython, and
wife of Cletus. Palepaphos, a city of Cypres. Palescamander, a river in Troy.
Palicenus, a fountain in Sicilia. Palilia, shepeherdes holidays kept in the
honor of Pales. Palimpsestus, parchemente rased. Palingenesia, a regeneration
or second natyuitie. Palinodia, a contrary song, or retractynge of that,
which oone has spoken or written: Now of sum men called a recantynge.
Palinodiam canere, to retracte that, which one has spoken or written.
Palinurus, was the Master of the ship, wherein Aeneas camme into Italye.
Alsoo an Elbowe of the land of Sycile into the Sea. Paliurus, a bryer, which
bears a codde, wherein are three or four black seeds. Palla, a woman's gown.
Palace, a concubyne. Palladium, the image of Pallas. Palladius, a man's name,
which wrote of husbandrye. Pallancana, a sharp oynyon, which causes the
eyes to water. Palladius, a, um, that songeth to Pallas. Pallas, autis, the
son of Euander, sommetyme king of Latynes. Also a Giant. Pallas, adis,
called goddess of battle, and also of wisdom. Pallax, acis, a concubyne,
such as one keeps instead of his wife. Palleo, lui, lere, to be pale.
Pallescere, idem. Palliastrium, a course mantell. Palliatae fabulae, Comedyes
or enterludes made in Grecia, and the personages there in were Greeks, as
Togatae fabulae, were enterludes in Rome, and the personages Romans, so
called because the ouermoste habyte of Greeks was called Pallium, of the
Romans Toga. Palliatus, cladde in a mantell. Pallio, are, to concele or hyde.
Palliolatim amictus, cladde in a palle. Palliolatus, idem. Palliolum, a short
mantelle. Pallium, a mantelle, such as knights of the garter do wear.
Pallor, oris, a palenesse of color. Paluster, ris, tree, and tra, trum, of the
fenne. Palma, the palm of the hand. Also a mesure called a handbrede,
sometime an ore to row with. Also a palm tree or daate tree. sometime it
sygnifyeth vyctorie. Palmam praeripere, to take the praise or honor from an
other. Palmare facinus, an act worthy the palm or sign of vyctorie.
Palmarium, worthy the sign or token of vyctorie. Palmaria spacia, a handbrede
space. Palmata, and palmaris uestis, a garmente of bawdekyn, which the consule
did wear in time of peace, and the vyctour in time of war. Palms, itis, the
small and tender branches, most proprely of a vine. Palmerum, the place,
wherein date trees do grow. Palmens, a, um, of a palm tree. Palmifer, and
palmiger, that bears palm, or date trees. Palmipedalis, a measure of a foot
and a handebrede. Palmipedes aues, all birds, which hau^ hole fete, as
commonly al water fowls have. Palmipes, splay footed. Palmyra, a great
castelle or fortress in the myddell of Syria. Palmyrena, a country in Syrie.
Palmo, are, to bind together: Also to do any thing with the palm of the
hand. Palmosus, full of palm trees. Palmula, a little oore or sculle. also a
date. Palmus, and palmeum, a mesure. If it be palmus mayor, it is of five
fyngers, or a hand breadth. If it be minor, it is but four fingers Palo, are,
to hedge or pale in: also to wa^der. Palor, palaris, to go asonder here and
there scattered. Palpebrae, the hears which do grow on the cheeks. Palpito,
rare, to quake or tremble. Palpator, toris, and palpo, ponis, a flatterer.
Palpo, and palpor, ari, to feel, also to flatter. Paludamentum, a cote armure.
Paludatus, cladde in a cote armure. Palumba, and palumbus, a stock douue, or
ring douue. Palumbarius, a certain hawke, which is long and black, and
flies the most part by night. Palumbes, wodde culuers. Palus, li, a stake or
pooste. Palus, paludis, a fenne or maryse. Pamphagi, people in Ethiopia, which
do ear of all manner of things. Pamphilia, a region in the less Asia.
Pampillum, a charyotte. Pampilona, a cite in the royalme of Nauer. Pampinarium,
a heap of grene branches. It is also the tender branch, which grows out
of the hard tree. Pampinarius, a, um, and pampineus, a, um, of grene
branches. Pampino, are, to cut of the small branches of a vine. Pampinus, a
vine leaf, or grene branch. Panagron, a greatte sweep net, which takes
all manner of fyshe. Pan, panis, called the god of shepardes. Panax, acis, an
herb, which has a leaf like to the leaves of a fygge tree. Also a long
stalk mosy, and on the top a ^^ap, wherein are sweet seeds, with a sharp
sent: and a has a yelowe flower, and grows in diverse parts of Grecia.
Panarium, a pantry, where bread is kept. Panchaia, a region in Arabie.
Pancarpia, a garlande made of diverse flowers, or of all flowers that may be
found. Pancraciastes, a man expert and excellent in all feats of actiuitie.
Pancratium, exercise in all feats, as wrastlynge, rounnynge, leaping,
casting of the darre, and other like exercyses of strength. Pancratius, he
that does exercise the said feats. Pandana porta, a gate of the city of
Rome, which was first and last opened, for all things to be brought into
the city. Pandecta, comprehendynge all things: it is also the volume of the
law civil, called also the digestes. Pandiculario, gapynge. Pandiculor, aris,
to gape as they do, which come from sleep. Pando, didi, dear, passum, and
pansum, to open Pando, aui, are, to bow down. Pandocheus, an inholder.
Pandochium, an inn, or commune lodging. Pandus, a, um, open. Panegytis, a mart
or fair, or great asse^bly. Panegyricus, an open and solemn comme^dation of
princis. Pangaeus, an elbowe of Thracia. Pango, pepegi, and panxi, pangere, to
set, to plant, to join one thing to an other, to fasten, to drive in, to
write, to singe, to tell. Panhormus, a city in Sicile. Panicum, a sudden
fear, whereby sommetyme men be distraught, or out of their wits. Panicula,
that which on sum herbs or trees do hang down like hears, long and
round. Panicum, a grain. Panifex, ficis, a baker. Panificium, the craft of
bakynge. Panis, breadde. Panis nauticus, byskette. Panis secundarius, raunged
bread, or chete breadde, or crybell bread. Paniscus, a god of the woddes.
Pantacratiasta, he that fyghteth with hands and feet. Suidas.
Pantathlus, he that contendeth in all manner of games. Panneus, a, um, woullen.
Pannicularia, things of small valor. Pannicularius, a draper that sells
clothe. Pannonia, the royalme of Hungary. Pannonij, Hungariens. Pannosus, he
that wears pore apparel. Pannuelium, a handekercher. Pannus, clothe.
Panomphaeus, a name of Jupiter, sygnyfyenge that he hereth all men's voices.
Pansa, plain footed. Panselmos, the full moon. Pantagia, a river in Sicyle.
Pantasilea, a queen of Amazon. Pantheon, a temple of all the gods. Panthera,
a beast called a Panter, which has spots of sundry colors. Pantheron, a
net, wherewith all manner of foul is taken. Pantices, a greatte bealye, also
the flux. Pantomimus, a dyssarde, which can fay^^ and countrefeyte every
man's gesture. Panurgia, subtyltie. Panus, panula, and panulla, a kyrnell in
the share or gryne of a man, or behind the care. It is also a weauers roll,
whereon the web of cloth is rolled or wounden. Papare, to call dad as a
child does. Papas, a father, as chylderne do call Dadde. Papauerata uestis,
a garment not pure white, but of the color of popye. Papauer, eris, an herb
called Popie. Pape, an interiection of wondering, will ye see, a wonderful
thing. Papaeus, in the tongue of Scithia, sygnyfieth Iupyter. Paphlagonia, a
regyon in Asia. Paphos, and Paphia, a city in the ylande of Cypres. Papia, a
city in Lumbardy, called Pauia. Papilio, onis, a butterflye. Papilla, a
little wheale or pousshe in the skin of a man. Also a cock in a cundyte,
whereout water comes. More over the nyppell or teate of a womannes breaste.
Pappa, pappe made with milk and flower. Pappo, pappare, to eat. Pappus, a
grandesyre or grandfather. It is also an herb called groundswell. Papula, a
whelke. Papyrus, seu papyrum, is a great rushe, which grows in the fennes
and marys grou^des in Egypt and Syria, ten cubytes high: whereof the first
paper was made, whereon men did write. we have growing in our fenny grounds
like russhes with black knoppes, long and round, which are called Now
Papyrus is called paper, wherein men do use to write or prynte books.
Papyratius, of paper, or of the said rushe. Papyrius, the surname of a noble
Romayn. Par, ris, like, equalle, meet, even, reasonable. Pares, two like one
to the other in form or degree. Parem esse, to be sufficient, to do or
sustain a thing. Paria, payres, two together of any thing. Paria facere, to
requyte, to do one thing for another, like for like. Par refer, idem. Par
pari, to recompense one thing with another of equal estimacion. Par impar, a
game that children used, called even or odd. Parabilis, le, that which may be
sone gotten, or will be sone ready. Parabola, a comparison, or resemblaunce.
Paracletus, an exhortar, a comfortar, an advocate. Paraclytus, a man infamed,
ill reported of. Paradiastole, a dilatinge of a matter by an interpretation.
Paradigma, an example. Paradisus, Paradise. Paradoxa, a sentence, contrary to
the opinyon of diverse. Paradromis, a galery, or walk. Paraenesis, a precepte
contaynynge an exhortation. Paraeneticus, ca, cum, contaynynge such precepte or
instruction. Paragoge, is a figure, when a letter or syllable, is added to a
word, as Dicier for dici. Paragraphe, a thing written before a sentence.
Paragraphus, and paragraphum, a paragrafe. Paralipomenon, left out, unspoken,
or unwritten, which ought to have been spoken or written. Parallel, lines in the
sphere of the world equally dissaunt, whereby the son, when he passes,
causes variacion in hours of the day. Paralysis, a sickness called the
Palsy. Paralyticus, he that is taken with the Palsy. Paranymphus, he that is
the mediator in matrymony between the man and the woman: she which is on the
woman's part is called Pronuba. Varro. de lin. lat.
Parapechium, a light cloak. Parapherna, that which is added unto the womannes
dower, called the ioynture. Paraphrasis, an imitation of words, setting out
the sense or meaning of the autour more plainly. Paraphrastes, he that does
not translate word by word, but expresses the sentence of the autour more
openly. Pararium aes, was double wages, given to horsemen for having two
horsis. Parasanga, a mile in Persya, contaynynge fifty furlonges. Parasceue, a
preparacion, also good friday. Parasiopesis, a figure in spekinge, when we
feign that we will not speak, and yet covertly it is declared what we do mean.
Parasitus, a haunter of other men's tables uncalled for, also he which to fill
his belly with meat and drink, speaks all way to the appetyte of him, with
whom he dines or soupeth. Paras^^aster, he that countresayteth him that is
called Parasitus. Parastarae, certain stones in pyiars. Parastata also one of
the bones in the shanke of the leg. Parastates, stones, which do sustain
both sides of a door, called Iambes. Paratragoedio, are, to brag or crake,
to speak great or high words. Parcae, ladies of desteny, also it signifies
the self destyny, or disposicion in prolonging or shortnynge life. Parco,
peperci, parcere, to spare, to forgive, or pardone, to let or prohibit, to
leave, to forbear or absteyne. Parcere prerio, to spare for cost. Parcere metu,
to put away fear. Vergilius.
Parce, scarcely, nyggardly, nyghly, fair and softly. Parciter, idem.
Parcitas, frugalytie, No. Mar.
or moderacyon in living. Parcus, a nygarde. Parcus, ca, cum, nighe, or
nygarde, scarce in expenses, sometime it signifies seeld. Parcus comitatu, he
that has a small train. Parcus opera, an easy warkeman, he that is more ydell
than occupied. Pardus, a carte of the mountain, some take it for a Panthere.
Pardalus, a bird of dunne color, which fleyth in flocks. Parectata, and
Parectatus, he that is newly issued out of a childs years, No. Mar.
and begins to have the tokens of a man. Parectonia, the mother of Plato,
the most noble philosopher. Parens, father, mother, or any other auncetour.
Parentela, auncetry. Parentalia, festes made at the buryenge of auncetours.
Parenthesis, is a sentence comprehendyd within another sentence, without any
detriment thereunto, being marked with one half circle at the beginning, and
another at the end, as in this wise. Nihil adeo principem decet, (quod omnes
quidem fatentur) quantu^ iustitia, prudentiae, atque liberalitati aequaliter
coniuncta, Nothing so well becomes a prince (which all men do confess) as
Justice equally joined with wisdom and bounteousnes. Parento, tare, to
celebrate the funeralles of auncetours or friends. Pappi, the flowers of
thistels, which be like feathers. Pappous, a, um, pertaining to my
grandfather. Paranomasia, a figure in spekinge, where one word is like to
another, but of diverse sygnifications. Nam inceptio est ame^tium, non amantium,
this beginning is of mad men, not of lovers. Paratus, ta, tum, ready. Parate,
redyly. Pareo, rui, rere, to appiere, to be seen, to obey. Parergon, some
thing added to, being no part of the matter, as when a payntour does make an
image, he does add to trees, or towns. Parethonium, a white color that
peynters do lay, which is fond in Egypt. Paribit, for pariet, she shall
bring forth a child. Parici, iuges assigned for capital causes, as murdre or
felony that requires death. Paries, etis, a wall of a house. Parieti loque^is,
thou speak to the wall, which may be said of him, that will not eftsoon
reherce that, which he heryth spoken. Parieta^ia, an herb called Pelitory.
Parietinae, old walls. Parilia, festival days, which the Romans kept for
preservation of their cattle. Parilis, le, equal. Parili^as, equalytie,
symilitude in quantity or quality. Pario, peperi, parere, to bring forth
children, the like thing in beasts, sometime to bring forth generally.
Parius, a, um, of the isle called Parus, from whens is brought marbelle stone,
called Parium marmor. Parito, tare, to prepare. Pariter, in likewise, equally,
semblably. Parma, a Targat, which foot men did use. Parmula, a bucklar.
Parnasides, the nine muses, or ladies of sciences. Parnassidae vestes,
apparayle belonging to maidens. Parnassus, a mountain in Greece, having two
tops, under the which the nine musis did inhabyte or dwell. Paro, are, to
prepare, to geate, to apparel. Paro, onis, a little ship or hulke. Parochus,
an officer, which provided for wood and salt, for ambassadors, also it is now
used for a priest, which is a curate, or parish priest. Paroecia, a paryshe.
Parodus, a passage. Paroemia, a proverb accommodate to the matter and time.
Paroeci, parysshonars, or they, which do dwell within one parish. Paropsis,
idis, a potage disshe, or potynger. Paros, an isle. Parotides, kernelles behind
the ears. Paroxismus, the fit in a fever. Parthasia, a country in Grecia,
called also Archadia. Parthasius, an excellent payntour. Particida, murderars
of their parents, betrayours of their countray, sometime murdre generally.
Patricidium, murdre of kynsfolke, or traison to the propre countraye.
Pa^ricidium, Marricidium, murdre of father and mother. Pars, partis, part.
Parts primas agere, to play the first part. Parts primae, the chief part.
Parsimonia, moderate expenses. Parsi, the pretertence of parco, I have spared.
Parthenis, an herb called Motherwort. Parthenium, Diosc^^^^*
is an herb which has small leaves like to Coriander, and a flower white
somewhat yelowe within, and has a greuouse savor. Some poticaryes do take it
for the less mugwort, but I find not, that it is taken for feuerfue. Celsus
writes, that it grows on walls. Parthenope, the old name of the city of
Naples. Parthia, a countraye in Asia. Parthi, people of that countraye.
Parthicus, a, um, of the countray of Parthia. Partiarius, a partinge fellow, or
copartner. Particeps, cipis, he that takes part. Participo, are, to give part,
or take part, to make another man partner, or of counsayl. Particula, a
portion. Particularis, re, particular. Particulariter, particulerly.
Particulatim, particularly. Particulones, coheyres, or comperceners, which have
inheritance together. Partim, partly, in part, some time part. Partim hominum
venerunt, part of the men did come. Partio, onis, a birth. Partior, iris, iri,
partitum, and partio, ire, Plaut. (...).
to part to deuyde. Parthissus, a river on the north part of Germania.
Partitio, a particion, or division. Partitudo, for partus, the birth of a
child. Partus, ta, tum, gotten with labor. Parturio, iui, and rij, to labor
as women do in travail with child. Partus, ^us, and par^i, and partuis, the
birth of a child, sometime the child self. Parulis, a swellynge of the
goomes. Paruifacio, cere, to set little by. Parui aestimo, idem. Paruipendo,
idem. Paruitas, the lytelnesse. Parum, a little. Parumper, a little while, or
time, also very little: sometime quickly. Paruus, a, um, little. Salustius
Paruulus, a little one. Parum habere, to set little by. Pasalli, pomaunders.
Pascales, sheep or pultry, which do feed at large. Pascha, Easter. Paschalis,
le, pertayninge to Easter. Pasceolus, a letherbagge. Pascito, tare, to feed.
Varro. dear rust.
Pasco, paui, pascere, and Pascito, are, to feed, to give meat to another, to
norysshe or bring up, to augmente. Pascere oculos, to content or playse the
eye^ with the beholdinge of a thing. Pascor, sceris, pasci, to feed as beasts
done. Pascua and Pascuum, pasture. Pascuus, a, um, that which serves to feed
catell. Pasiphae, the wife of Minos the king of Crete, who having company
with a bull, brought forth the monstre, called Minotaurus, which was half a
man and half a bulle. Passales, be as well sheep as pultry, which feed
abroad. Passex, eris, a sparowe, also a fisshe, called a playce. Passerculus, a
little sparowe. Passili, a little grain called vatches or fitches. Passim, here
and there, sometime it signifies from all places, sometime indifferently,
also over all. Passio, a passion, grief. Passiuus, a, um, that which signifies
passion, or causes passion or grief. Passiui amatores, they which do love
all women indifferently. Passum, licour made of raysons. Passus, a, um, spread
abroad, or open. Passus, us, a pace, which does contain five feet. Pastillus,
vel pastillum, a pasty. Pastinaca, an herb called parshyps, also a fish.
Pastino, are, to velue in a garden: repastino, vide in R. Pastinatus, tus,
deluinge. Pastinum, a debill, or setting stick. Pastio, onis, pasturinge, or
fedinge of catell. Pastomis, an instrument, which is set on the nosethrilles of
horsis, that will not be ruled, and is called of horsebreakers, Barnacles.
Pastophori, certain preestis in Egypt. Pastophorium, the chamber of the
Sexten, or him which keeps the Temple. Pastor, oris, a sheparde or herdman.
Pastoralis, le, pertayninge to the shepharde or herdman. Pastorius, a, um,
idem, Pastoricius, a, um, of fedynge or grasinge of catell. Pastus, a, um, he
that has eaten. Pastus, tus, meat, fedynge. Patagium, a cloak of cloth of
gold, used to be worn on rich garments. Patagiati, they which do wear
rich clokes. Patagiarij, the craftysmen that makes such clokes. Patara, a
city in the countraye of Licia. Patauium, a city in Italy called Padua, nigh
unto Venice. Patauini, men of that city. Patefacio, cere, to make open, to
declare, to disclose. Patefio, fieri, to be disclosed or discovered. Patella, a
little pan or a skiller. Pateo, tui, tere, to be open. Pater, tris, a father.
Patera, a brood piece or bolle of gold or silver. Pater^amilias, the good man
of the house. Paterpatratus, to whom it pertaynyd, wha^ trues should be taken,
to receive the oaths and appoyntement of both parts, and was there in, chief
and principal ambassador. Pater patrimus, he that is a father, and has his
father living. Paternus, a, um, pertaining to a father. Patesco, scere, to be
open. Pathe, troubles or vexacions of mind, passions. Pathetica oration, an
oration moving the hearer to indignation or pity. Pathmos, an I Will in the se
called Aegeum. Patibulum, a woden lock of a door, or a bar wherewith the
door is made fast, alsoo a place of tourment, a gybbet, galowes, or cross.
Patientia, patience. Patillum, a pair of tongues or other like instrument,
wherewith coals are taken up. Patina, a dysh wherein meat is carried.
Patinarium, meat, which is stewed upon a chaffynge dysshe. Patior, pateris,
pati, to suffer. Plautus in Asinar.
Patitor, suffer thou. Patrae, tarum, a city in Achaia. Patrator, oris, he
that does a thing. Patres conscripti, senators. Patria, a countraye.
Patriarcha, a prince or chief man of the fathers. It was also the name of
dignytie, of five chief Archebyshoppes, as of Rome, Antioche, Alexandry,
Jerusalem, and Constantinople. Patriarchatus, the dignity of a patriarche.
Patricida, he that kills his father. Patricidium, the murdre of a man's
father. Plautus in Can.
Patrice, nobly, or like a noble man. Patricius, a senators son, or commen
of Senators. Patrimonium, goods commen by inheritance, patrimony. Patrinus
and Patrimis, he which has his father lyuinge. Patrinus, a, um, of the
father, or pertaining to the father. Patritus, ta, tum, that which happens to
one by his father. Patrius* a, um, of the countreye. Patrizo, and Patrisso,
are, to be like a father. Patro, are, to perform. Patrocynor, aris, ari, to
defend them, which be pour, or be falsely accused. Patroclus, a noble greek,
companyon to Achilles. Patrocinium, defense of men being in trouble or suyte.
Patronymicum nomen, a name taken of an auncetour, as Priamides the children of
Priamus. Patronus, he that is advocate on the defendauntes part. Patrueles,
cosyn germayns, or right cosyns on the fathers side. Patruus, the fathers
brother. Patruus magnus, my fathers uncle. Patruus maximus, my grandfathers
uncle. Pat^agia, a river in Sicile. Patulico, care, to be open. Patulus, a, um,
wydeopen. Patulus bos, an ox or cow, whose horns do stand wide open.
Paucis, in few words. Paucus, ca, cum, few. Paucitas, tatis, fewness.
Pauculus, a, um, very few. No. Mar. Pom. Fest.
Paucies, seldom. Pauciens, idem. Pauens, it is, he that fears for a time.
Paueo, ere, to fear. Pauera, wheat, which springs not well out of the hose
when it grows in care. Pauesco, scere, to be aferde. Pauicula, a pauynge
bytell, Cato der^ ^ust.
wherewith stones be driven into the ground in the making of a pauement.
Pauidus, he that allwaye fears. Pauide, fearfully. Pauimento, are, to make a
pauement. Pauimentum, a pauement, or place paued, ^ floor. Pauio, ire, to
stryke. Pauito, tare, to be sore aferde. Paulisper, a very little while. Paulum,
and Paulo, a little. Paulatim, little and little. Paulominus, little less. Paulo
mox, by and by. Paulo prius, a little erst. Plautus i^ Menech.
Paululum, very little. Paululum modo, never so little. Terent. i^ Heau.
Paululo tum erat contenta, she was than content with a very little. Pauo, onis,
and Pauus, a pecoke. Pauor, oris, extreme fear. Pauper, pauperis, a pour man.
Pauper, peris, an adiectif pour. Pauperies, and Paupertas, tatis, poverty.
Pauper, ra, rum, poor. Pauperculus, and paupercula, a poor man, or poor
woman. Paupero, are, to make pour. Paupertinus, na, number, pour. Pausa, a
pause, leysour. Pausias, a noble payntour. Pauso, are, to pawse. Pauxillatim,
by little and little. Pauxillisper, idem. Pax, pacis, peace, a quiet liberty.
Paxillus, a little stake. Pax sequestra, a truce between two hostis.
P, ANTE E.
PEccatum, a sin, an offense. Pecco, care, to offend or sin. Pecorarius, a
herdeman, also he that does hyar catell. Pecorarius, a, um, pertayninge to
catell. Pecorinus, a, um, of rother beastis. Pecten, inis, a wayuers lowme,
also a comb. it is also the place about the pryuy members, where hear does
grow, it is also the sticks, wherewith a man stryketh doulcemers when he does
play on them, also a fish, sometime a harowe. Pectinatim, in the facion of a
comb. Pectino, to kembe, or to harowe. Pectitus, ta, tum, kembyd, or harowyd.
Pecto, xui, tere, to kembe, or trymme hear, to card woulle, to set a harp
or other like instrument. Pectoralis, le, pertayninge to the breast. Fascia
pectoralis, a breast kerchef. Pectorium, a certain carte sometime used in
France. Pectorosus, a, um, great brestyd. Pectunculus, a little fisshe.
Pectus, toris, the breast. Pectusculum, a little breast. Pecuarla, store of
catell: alsoo places where they be kept, also multitude of catell, alsoo
revenues that comes of catell. Pecuariam rem facere, to breed catel.
Pecuarius, a breedar of catell. Pecuarius, a, um, belonging to catell. Pecu,
indeclinabile. Pecua, in the plurell number, catell, beasts. Peculator, and
Peculatrix, he and she that steals a commune treasor. Peculatus, robbery of
the common treasour, or of a prince. Peculiaris, re, propre, or special.
Peculiariter, proprely, specially. Peculio, are, to punysshe by the purse.
Peculiosus, rich, of great substance. Peculium, substance, that richesse,
which is only in money and catell. Peculor, aris, ari, to steal a commune
treasour, or any thing from a prince. Pecunia, money, it is taken of the old
Ciuilions, for all things, which we call catell. Pecuniosus, rich. Pecus,
cudis, seu Pecus, pecoris, all manner of catell: sometime the multitude or
flock of catell, sometime it is taken only for sheep or gotes. Peda, and
Pedatura, the step or token of a man's foot. Pedalis, of a foot. Pedamen,
and Pedamentum, a stake or forke, whereby a vine, hoppes, or other like thing
is sustained, or borne up. Pedaneum, idem. Pedaneus, a, um, of the quantity
of a foot, in length, or distaunce. Pedanei iudices, inferior iuges, which
went on foot. Pedarij, were Senators, which did not show their opynions in
words, but only meuynge them selfs toward those persons, which had
raysonned, whose sentences they did approve, like as they do in the parliament
house. Pedatim, where one foot goes with the other, foot by foot. Pedatio,
the setting up of vynes. Cato.
Pedato, suddenly. Pedatus, footed. Pedem struere, to take him to his feet, to
run away. Pedem refer, to retreat or go back. Caesar. Cicer. pro Plan.
Pedem confer, to come to a point of a matter in controversy. Pedepressim, a
foot pase, softly. Pes, pedis, a foot, sometime it is taken for all the leg,
from the thyghe to the sole of the foot. Pedes ire, to go on foot. Pedes,
feet in meter, sometime lyse. Pedes, ditis, a foot man in battle. Pedester,
he that goes on foot, or is on foot. Pedetentim, softely and fair, by little
and little. Pedecosus, lousy, or full of lyse. Pedem ponere, to begin a matter.
Pedare, to set proppes, or to prop up a vine or tree, that it shall not fall or
bow down. Pedem reuocare, to retrayte or recule back. Pedestris oration, a
numerouse speaking or wrytinge in the form of a verse, or meter allthoughe
it be not a verse. Pedicillus, a little worm, which breeds between the
skin and the flesh. Pediculatus, ta, tum, any thing which has a stalk,
as the most part of fruit. Pedicularis morbus, the lousy sickness. Pedio,
dire, to stamp with the foot. Pediolus, a little foot. Pedica, any thing,
wherewith the foot is tied, as a fettar, a pair of gyues, or stocks.
Pedicosus, and Pediculosus, lousy. Pediculus, a fisshe, the stalk of an apple
or pear, or other fruit: also a louse. Pedissequus, and Pedissequa, a
servant, who follows allwaye the master, or mastres. Peditatus, an host of
footmen. Pedo, pepedi, pedere, to farte. Pedum, a shepecroke. Peganon, the
herb called Rue, or herb grace. Pegasides, the Musis. Pegasus, a horse, which
was feigned to have wings: it is also a sign or number of sterres in heaven.
Pegma, matis, a stage, whereon pageantes be set: or whereon plate and jewels do
stand to be looked on. Peieratio, perjury, a forsweringe. Peiero, are, to swear
falsely. Peior, peius, warse. Pelagus, the sea. Pelagicus, ca, cum, of the sea.
Pelamis, midis, fisshe called Tuny. Pelargos, a bird called a storke.
Pelasgis, a countraye in Greece called Arachadia. Pelasgi, people which came
out of Greece, and inhabited Italy: they be also Arcadiens. Pelasgicus, ca, cum,
of Arcadia. Pelias, a king of Thessalia, uncle to Jason. Pelicus, a prince, of
whom the people called Peligni took their name. Pelides, the surname of
Achilles. Peligni, people in Italy, which came out of Illiria. Pelion, a hill
in Thessalia. Pella, a city in Macedonia. alsoo a payle, whereinto kyne are
mylked. Pellax, acis, he that deceyueth with fair words. Pellacia, sayre
speech to deceive. Pellex, she that is a wedded man's harlot. Pellicator, a
deceyuer with fair words. Pellicatus, tus, the act or life of her, which
companieth with a weddyd man, aduoutry on her part. Pellicio, pellexi, cere, to
deceive with fair words, to move a man pleasauntly to do a thing. Pellectus,
meuyd, tempted. Pelliceus, cea, ceum, of a skin or hyde. Pellicula, the
skin. Pellicalo, are, to cover with a skin. Pellio, onis, a skynnar.
Pellis, a skin. Pellitus, cladde in skynnes. Pella, pepuli, pellere, pulsum,
to put out or expel. Pelluceo, cere, to shine bright, to shine through.
Pellucidus, a, um, very clear. Pellucide, clearly. Pelluo, luere, to wasshe
clean. Pellunium, a basin, wherein men's fete are washed. Peloponnesus, a
countraye in Greece, called now Morea: and lies between the sea called Ionium,
and the sea called Aegeum. Pelops, pelopidis, which vaynquysshed on horsbacke
in runnynge Oenomaus, father of Hippodamia, and wedded her. Peloris, a kind of
shelfisshe. Pelorus, a hill in Sicile on the sea side. Pelta, a Targat or
buckler, like an half moon. Peltati, they which do wear such bucklars.
Peluis, a basin. Pelusium, Pom. Fest.
a city in Egypt. Peminosus, a, um, stinkinge. Penates, the gentyles called
goddis of ma^s life: they be sometime taken for the most secret parts of the
house. Penarius, and Penarium, a cellar or store house. Pendeo, es, pependi,
pendere, pensum, to hang, or be hanged, to depend, sometime to be in pain.
Pendere animi, to be troubled in mind, to doubt what to do, to cesse from
all other things, and to attend to one thing, to be in suspense. Pendere
poenas, to be punyshed. Pendo, is, pependi, dear, to ponder or way, to
consider, to esteem or value, to pay, to sustain or suffer, look for
dependo, suspe^do, expendo, in their first lettres. Pendulus, la, lum, that
hangs. Pene, allmoost. Penelope, the wife of Vlyxes. Penelopes telam
retexere, signifies to do and undo, to take much labor in vain. Penes,
with, or at. Penes hunc, with him. Penetrabilis, trabile, that may perce, or
be perced. Penetrale, the inner part of the house. Penetro, are, to perce.
Peneus, a river in Grecia, which dyuydeth the countrayes of Elis and Achaia.
Penicella, a paynters pencell, wherewith he paynteth. Penicillus, peniculum,
and penicillum, a paynters pensell. Peniculamentum, the hemme of a garment, the
skirtes. Peniculus, sieve peniculum, any thing which serves to brusshe or
wype clean any thing. Penis, a tail: also the secret membre of a man.
Penitus, ta, tum, tayled, having a tail, also penitus inward. Penitus, an
aduerbe, utterly, to the vttermoost, far of. Penna, a pen, or quyll.
Pennarium, a pennar. Penniculum, a fether. Penniger, pennigera, gerum, that
which bears fethars. Pennula, a little fether. Pensa, that which is paid for
a thing bought, the payement. Pensa, in the plurell number, thredes of flax or
woull, when it is spunne, which may be called yarne. Pensiculate, wayghtely.
Pensiculo, are, to ponder a thing. Pensilis, le, that which hangs, or
stondeth on high. Pe^sile horreu^, a garnard, where corn is kept Pensilis
homo, a man hanged. Pensi nihil liabere, to ponder or consider no thing, Val.
in po.
not to ponder or consider any thing. Pensio, a pencion or yearly rent.
Pensito, tare, to ponder well a mattier, to pay money, to make recompense.
Pensitor, a ponderer or wayer. Verborum pensitatores subtilissimi, Gellius.
The most subtle ponderers of words. Penso, are, to ponder or way a thing.
Pensos, oris, a wayer. Pensus, a, um, wayed, examyned, sometime it sygnifieth
good and wise. Pensum, the flax, which is bounden on the distaffe, Ci. de ora.
out of the which the threde is drawn. sommetyme it sygnifieth the threde
that is spunne. It is also the execution or mynystration of an office. Also
regard that one has to a thing. Plautus in tru^ulen.
Pensilis hortus, a gardeyne made upon the roufe of a house, or upon pyllars.
Pensilis vrbs, a city standing on vaultes. Pentaphillon, seu pentepatalon, an
herb called cinkefoyle, which has five leaves, Pentapolis, a countray
between Palestina and Arabia, wherein were the cities of Sodom and Gomor,
bourned by the vengeance of god for sin against nature. Pentacontarchus, a
captain of fyfty men. Pentarchus, he that is captayn of five men.
Pentateuchus, the volume of the five books of Moses, that is to say,
Genesis, Exodi, Numeri, Leuiticum, Deuteronomium. Pentathlus, he that
exercyseth any of these five games, casting of the ball, or tryndell,
runnynge, leaping, wrastlyng, and throwynge the darte. Pentecoste,
whytsontyde. Pentesilea, a queen of Amazon, which was slain at the syege of
Troy. Pentimimeris, is a part of a verse, where a sentence is fynysshed in
the first syllable of the third foot. Pentorbon, an herb called also peony.
Penula, a Cloak, worn when hit raynethe. Penularium, a cloak bag.
Penulatus, cloked. Penuria, extreme necessity, penury. Penus, penoris, and
penum, and penu, and penuarium, a storehouse. Sometime stoore or prouysion of
vytayles. Plautus in A^lularia.
Penussime, utterly. Peonia, an herb called Pyonie, which bears a red
flower, and great round sede, wherein is marvelous virtue against the falling
euylle. Peplus, uel peplum, a kerchiefe or other like covering of the heed.
Peperci, I have spared, or forborne, or pardoned. Pepigi, and pupugi, the
preter tence of pungo. Also pepigi is the preter tence of pango. Pepigit
foedus, He made a league or alyaunce. Pepo, onis, a Melon. Per, sygnifyeth by,
joined with an another word it sygnyfyeth perfection. Perpulchrum, Very fair.
Pergraue, Veraye greuouse. Peraetatem, for or by reasone of his age. Peptica,
medycines, which do make good concoction in a man, that the meat caten, may
digeste well. Also salues and oyntementes, which do make impostumes ripe.
Pera, a scryppe or bag. Perago, egi, agere, to perform, to make perfyte, to
consider, to draw or cause to be drawn with force. Peragere reum, to accuse
one, and to sewe him to a condemnation. Peragro, are, to walk or go about a
place. Peramo, are, to love well. Peranno, annare, to contynewe or live over
year. Perardeo, dear, to bourne out or through. Perareo, ere, to dry up, to
be very dry. Peraro, rare, to tylle all through. Perbelle, very well, right
well. Perbibo, bibere, to quafte or drink all out. Plautus in Pom. Fest.
Cicer. ibi.
Perbitere, for praeire, to go before. Per causam, for a cause. Percedere, to
depart. Percello, li, ere, to stryke and overthrow. Percino, nere, to sing
stylle, to contynewe singing. Perclam, very priuyly. Perduaxo, for perdo.
Peredia, a meal, where men eat hu^grely. Percipio, caepi, cipere, to
perceive, to take, or receive. Percitus, styrred. Percoarcto, are, to bring
into a little room. Percolo, ui, ere, to worship much. Percontor, aris, ari,
to ferche. Percudo, di, dear, to break. Perculsus, and percussus, stryken.
Percunctor, aris, ari, to inquire, to demand. Percuro, are, to heal
perfytely. Percurro, rere, to run apace, to run by. Percutio, cussi, tere,
to stryke, or smite. Perdite, extremely. Perditus, ta, tum, lost, perysshed,
without recovery, out of hope. Perdius, abiding all the day, or watching all
the day, or he which does any thing in the day time. Perdix, dicis, a
partryche. Perdo, didi, dear, to lose, to slay. Perduco, duxi, ducere, to bring
to an end, to bring or lead by force. Perduellio, onis, treason against the
king, or the country. Also a traitor. Perduellis, an enemy. Peredo, edi,
edere, to eat much. Peregre, out of a man's propre country. Peregre uado, I
go out of the countreye, or on pylgremage. Peregre uenio, I come out of
strange countrayes, or from pylgremage. Peregrinor, aris, ari, to go into
strange countries, or on pylgremage. Peregrinus, a stranger or alyen.
Perendie, the day next after to morrow. Perendinus dies, idem. Perennis
fluuius, a course of water that comes with rain, or a brook that is only
made with rain. Perenniter, contynually. Perennis, ne, perpetual, ever
during. Perennitas, tatis, contynuaunce, long abiding. Perenno, are, to dure
or continue. Pereo, iui, uei, ^i, ire, to be lost or consumed, also to dye.
Peretro, are, to go or ride al about. Perfacul, the ancient writers used for
facile, lightly. Perfas and nefas, by right or wrong, by one way and other.
Perfect, perfitely. Perfectus, a, um, perfytte, accomplysshed, optayned.
Terent. in ^^nucho.
Perfector, toris, he that brings a thing to pass, or to a point. Perfero,
tuli, far, to bring in conclusion. Also to bring or tell tidinges. sometime
to suffer or endure. Perficio, cere, to accomplish, to bring to a point, to
obtain. Perfidiosus, a, um, full of disloyalty. Perfidiose, disloyally,
trayterousely. Perfido, dear, to trust much. Perfidus, false of promise, he
that does any thing against the trust that is put in him, disloyal.
Perfidia, falsehode against promise or trust, disloyalty. Perfidus, very
trustye. Perfines, for perstringas, strain thou hard. Pom. Fest.
Perflatus, a great blaste of wind. Perflo, are, to blow vehemently or
strongly. Perfluo, xi, fluere, to ru^ne out as water both out of a broken
vessel. Perfodio, dear, to door or perce through, ^^ stryke through, to dygge
through, or to the dottome or depest of any thing. Perfore, to come well to
pass. Perforare, to perce, or to make an hoole through. Perfortiter,
myghtily. Perfossus, a, um, perced through, stryken or dygged through.
Perfracte, obstynately. Perfrigefacio, perfrigefacere, Ci. o^^^e. ^
to make very cold. Perfrico, care, to rub much. Perfricuit faciem, aut
frontem, aut or, Is in a proverb as mohe to say, as he has laid aparte
shame, or he is shameless, or without abashement. Perfricte frontis, without
shaame or honestye. Perfructus est, he has taken the fruit or pleasure of a
thing, he has used or exercysed a thing, or has left the use or exercise
thereof. Perfruor, perfructus, perfretus, aut perfruitus, perfrui, to take all
the profit or commodity, to take pleasure or recreation in any thing.
Perfuga, he that flees to the contrary part in battle, or forsakes his
captain. Perfugio, gere, to rounne unto oone for succor. Perfugium, a place,
whereunto a man runs to have succoure, or to be kept from danger: It is
also taken for any thing, whereby a man may be succored. Perfunctorie,
passing over lyghtely. Perfunctorius, a, um, that which passethe lightly
away, or tarieth not long. Perfunctus, he that has done diligently his
office or duty. Perfundo, perfudi, fundere, to pour out, or drop out, or
stylle out. Perfunditque genas lachrimis, ^uidi^^.
The tears dropped down on his chekes. Perga, a town in Pamphilia, whereof
Diana was called Pergaea. Pergama, orum, the towers of Troy. Pergamena charta,
parchement. Pergamum, sieve Pergamus, a City in Asya, the country of Galene,
the famous Phisycion. Perge, go to, pass forth. Perge in virum, play the
man, goo to like a man, go to hardily. Pergin? will thou not leave? will thou
not be gone. Pergrandis, de, very great. Pergo, per^exi, pergere, to go, to

Suspen^o g^adu (...) perrexi, I assayed with a ^yght pass to go softely.

walk. Also a vine raised in the form of an herber* Sommetyme the company of

idem. Perhumane, and perhumaniter, right gentilly. Periander, oone of the seven

noble man of Athenes, in whom was a natural eloquence incomparable.
Periclitor, aris, ari, to be in peril, also to experyence or prove a thing.
Periculosus, a, um, dangerous. Periculum, peril or danger. sometime
experience or proof. Periculum facere, to prove. Perhiodus, a clause, a circute
in words, or contynuance in speaking. Perhiodicae febres, fevers, which come
by courses or fyttes. Perillus, was an artifycer, which made a bull of br^sse
wherinto (being glowing hot) men should be put, that in tourmentynge of them,
by they^ crienge, a noise should issue out like the mowynge or belowynge of a
bulle, the which engine when Perillus had given to Phalaris, the cruel
tyrant, he caused the crafts manne to be first put into it, to prove his
own experience. Perimo, emi, imere, to kylle. Peremptus, ta, tum, killed.
Peridoneus, a, um, very meet. Periege^i^, a compass or ^y^cuy^e. Perii. I am

much, even as, in this facion. Perinthus, a city of Thra^^^, which now is

Periphra^^^, circumlocution, one word expressed by many. Periplorema, a figure,
when a part of a sentence nothing necessary, is added unto a verse.
Peripneumonia, syckenesse of the lounges with the coughe. Peripneumonicus, he
which has that* disease. Peripsema, matis, the powder or dust that comes
of fylynge or shauynge of mettalle or wodde. Periscelis, idis, sloppes, which

perfyte in a science. Periuro, rare, to swear vntrewely, Plautus in Bacch.

to be perjured. Periuriosus, a man which is often forsworn. Periurus,

dear, to examine, also to consider. Perpense, advisedly, with a consideration.
Perperam, amysse, ouerthwartely, unhappily, wrongefully. Perperi, fools,

much peyn. Perpetim, perpetually. Perpetro, trare, proprely to do or to

porcyens or dyuyded. Perpetior, perpeti, to suffer pacientely, to endure.
Perpeto, perpetere, to ask importunately without cessynge, to perform.
Perpetratio, an act good or badde. Perpetuitas, eternity, an everlasting
contynuaunce. Perpetuum, and perpetuo, aduerbes, sygnifienge continually,
always, for ever. Perplaceo, perplacui, perplacere, to content very much.
Perplector, perplecteris, plecti, to bind or twyste hard or fast, to meddle
so together, that a man can not know what the thing means. Perplexe loqui,
to speak now one thing, now an other, that a man wotteth not what he
means. Perplexim, idem. Perplexor, aris, ari, to speak doubtefullye, as
words, wherein are two intendementes. Plautus in Aulularia.
At scio, quo vos pacto soleatis, perplexarier, pactum, non pactum est, Non
pactum, pactum, est, quod vobis lubet, well, I know well enough, in what facion
you are wont to speak, that a man can not tell how to take you: It was
promised, It was not promised, It was not promised, It was promised, even as
hit lysteth you. Perplexabile, a word spoken, which has two diverse
understandings, or that which is one thing in herynge, an another in
understanding. Perplexabiliter, doubtefullye. Perplexus, plexa, plexum,
perplexed, twysted together, or hard to be lowsed, intrycate, doubtefull.
Perpluir, perpluere, to rain in the myddell of a house. Perplus, much more.
Perpol, an oath, sygnyfyenge by Pollux. Sommetyme the word Per, does pertayne
to the words following. Perpol quam paucos reperias meretricibus fideles
euenire amatores, Terent. in Hecyra.
By God thou fyndeste very few true lovers happen to commune womenne. Where
per belongethe to quam paucos, and not to Pol. Perpoto, perpotare, to drink
all day, or to drink stylle, or contynually, or until one be drunk.

perpulchrum, very fair. Plautus in Stich.
Perpulchre, very well done. Perprurisco, perpruriscere, to have a great
ytche, or desire to clawe or scratche. Perpurgo, gare, to make all thing
clean, or net. Perpuro, perputare, to declare al. Plautus in Cistel.

head, that I may plainly declare all this matter unto you. Perquam, added to
any nowne adjective, augmentethe his power. Perquam doctus, Very well learned.

or to make an another to laugh. Perrogo, gare, to desire heartily. Perrumpo,

to be the herb, which in some country is called Donye. Personatus, tus, a

Peruitere, the old wrytars used, for perire, to be lost, to peryshe. Peruiuo,
nixi, uiuere, to live long, or until the vttermoste. Plautus in Cap.
Et si peruiuo vsque ad summa^ aetatem, tamen breue spacium est perferundi,

little to suffer all: wherewith thou thretteste me. Peruius, uia, uium, that

Pedes, and Pedibus, put for an aduerbe, signifies on foot. Pedes agmen
circuibat, the host went about on foot. In agmine non nunquam equo, Suetonius
in Caes.
saepius pedibus ante^bar, In the hooste, he went allwaye before, sometime on
horseback, but moore often on foot. Pedibus stipendia facere, to be a foot
man in wars. Pes, a louse: allsoo a cord, wherewith the sail in a ship is
bent. Pesnas, old wrytars used for pennas. Pom. Fest.
Pesestas, in old time vsyd for Pestis, Pom. Fest.
Pestilence. Pessum eo, ire, to go backewarde, to be lost or destroyed, to be
nowght set by. Pestifer, and Pestiferus, a, um, that which brings in

backewarde, downewarde, under foot. Pessundo, dedi, dare, to cast under foot,

mortality of men. Petalum, a leaf. Petasatus, he that wears a hatte.

house. Petaurista, a propre daunser. Petaurum, a cord, or a staff, or a
bourde, Iu^. pol*
or other like thing, whereon light personages do dance and prove maistryes.
it is also a rouste, where pultry does sit in the night. Petesso, sere, to
ask or require. Petigo, tiginis, a tettar that runs over all a man's face.
Petilansura, the howfe of a white horse. Pom. Fest.
Petilara, things that are dry. Petilus, la, lum, small. Petilius, a flower
which grows among brembilles, in the later end of somer, Plinius.
and is like a wild rose in color, and has five small leaves, the budde of
diverse colors, having within it yelowe seeds. Petimen, a sore in the
shoulders of beasts, Pom. Fest.
which I suppose is a fassion. Petitia, a certain kind of appulles. Petisso,
sere, old wrytars used for Peto, Pe^ot.
to ask or demand. Petitor, toris, he that asks or demands: among
lawyers he is called the demaundaunt: also it is a beggar, which asks allmes
from door to door. Petoritum, a chariot or wagon. Petiolus, a little foot:
also a perch whereon fruits or onyons be hanged. Petitio, onis, a petition.
Peto, petij, petete, to ask, to get or attayn, to desire, to lay awayt, to
abide, to strike, to go to a place, to seek. Petere gladio, to stryke with a
sword. Petere veneno, to poison. Petere blandicijs, to ^later. Petere tactu,
to feel. Petere mutuum, to borowe: also to remember. Petere iugulum, to kill,
to follow. Petere auribus, to here. Petere naribus, to smelle. Petere oculis,
to behold. Petere osculis, to kiss. Petere vi, to enforce. Petere, is also to
assail or make assault on one. Petra, a stone. Pom. Fest.
Petrones, Carles of the countraye: also a wether sheep. Petroselinum, an herb
called Persely. Petulans, it is, want on dishonest, reprocheful, proud,
viciouse, ready to do wrong. Valla in Rauden.
Petulantia, wantonness, viciousness, pride. Petrens, a, um, of a stone.
Petreleon, an oil, which naturally runs out of a stone. Petrosus, a, um,
stony or full of stones. Petulanter, wantonly, proudly. Petus, he that has one
eye less than the other. Petulcus, wanton. Pexo, are, to kembe. Pexae velles,
Some men in expoundynge Pliny, do suppose Pexas vestes, to be of such thing,
as is shorn, as syne woullen clothe, or velvet. Pexati, they which do wear
such manner of cloth, or sylke. Pezitae, moussherons, growing at the roots of
trees.
P, ANTE H.
PHaeaces, people of the I Will of Corcira. Phaecasius, a shoo. Phaedra, the wife
of Theseus, and stepmother to Hypolytus. Phaeton, the sun. Phagedaena a,
runnyng cancre or pock, which shortly eats the flesh unto the bones.
Phagones, great eaters. Phalacron, bold. Phalacrocorax, acis, a water crow,
it may signify a coote. Affranius.
Phalango, gare, to move or drive a thing upon rollers. Phalaris, a cruel
tyrant, which reigned in the city of Agrigentum. Phagus, a beeche tree.
Phagineus, a, um, of beeche. Phalangae, staves, whereon men do carye packes,
plain staves, also leauars, to lift things that be heavy. Phalangarij,
portars, which do carye packes. Phalangium, a spyder. Phalanx, angis, an
hooste of footmen, set in such order, that they may incountre with their
enemies, foot to foot, man to man, shylde to shylde. It is also the beam of
a balaunce. Phalanges, are the joints or spaces in the fyngars: they be also
rollers, whereon ships or great pieces of timber be removed. Phalarica, an
instrument of war, wherein wild fire is enclosed, that when it is by shot
fastened to timber, it burns all shortly. Phalerae, a traper or bardes for a
horse. Phaleratus, trapyd, or bardyd. Do^^. in Teren. Phor^^
Phalerata dicta, gaye words, pleasant speech. Phalerij, a city in Tuscane.
Phalisti, people in Italy. Phanaticus, frenetyke, he that has vain vysions.
Phaneta, one of the names of Bacchus. Orpheus.
Phanni, fantasyes, which happen to men in dremes. Phantasia, fantasy.
Phantasma, matis, a visyon. Phanum, a temple. Pharetra, a quyuar for arowes.
Pharetratus, he that bears a quyuar. Phariseus, a Pharyze, which was of a
sect of Jews, which lived in a more strayghter form than the commun people
did. Pharias, phariae, a serpent, which makes a furrowe in the ground with
his tail, as he creapeth, and so lyfteth him self up. Pharmacentice, that
part of physike, which heals with medicynes. Pharmacopola, a Potycary.
Pharmacum, a medycyne: sometime it signifies poison. Pharos, an I Will in Egypt.
Pharsalia, a countraye in Thessalya, where the battle was between Julius
Caesar and Pompey. Phasae, a word of Hebrew, which signifies a departing.
Phaseolus, a kind of poulse corn. I suppose it be that, which is called
Tares. Phasianus, a fesaunt. Phasis, a great river in the countraye of
Colchos. Phasma, atis, an horrible vision or sight. Pherecydes, a famous
Philosopher and wrytar of Tragoedies, which dyed of the lousy sickness.
Pheretra, things borne at great feastis or triumphs, as pageantes or jewels
of gold or silver, images, and such like things. Pheretrius, Jupiter.
Pheretrum, a thing, whereon pageantes are borne: also deed corpsis. Phia, the
general name to all plate, which serves for wine. Phiala, a pot or cup
of gold or silver, which serves for wine. Phidias, an excellent w^rkman, in
making great images of gold or yuory. Phidiacus, ca, cum, of Phidias.
Phiditia, the soupers, which the Lacedaemonians used, which were openly kept
with a meruaylouse temperaunce, every man bringynge his measurable portion of
meat and wine. Philadelphia, a city in Asia. Philagathus, he that loves
goodness. Philanthropos, a lover of mankind: also ge^tyll and kind.
Philargyria, couaytousnesse, auaryce. Philargyrus, couaytouse. Philema, a
kiss. Philetes, a kissar. Philodolus, he that loves his servants. Philenus,
he that loves wine. Philippei, a certain coin of gold. Philippi, a city in
Thracia. Philippenses, men of that city. Philocalus, a good man, a clenly man,
or elegaunt. Philomela, a nightingale: also a fair maiden, which was
defloured by Thereus, husbonde to her sister, whom poets do feign was
transfourmed to a nightingale. Philologus, a lover of words. Philonicus, a
brawler: sometime a lover of victory. Philosophia, philosophy, the love or
fauorynge of wisdom. Philoginos, he that doteth on women. Philopaes, he that
loves children. Philoponus, laboriouse, paynefull. Philosophaster, he that
would be like a philosopher. Philosophice, like a philosopher. Philothesia, a
solemn feast among the Greeks. Philosophicus, ca, cum, philosophical.
Philosophor, aris, ari, to study wisdom. Philosophus, a philosopher.
Philoxenia, hospitality. Philoxenus, he that keeps good hospitalytye.
Philtrum, a drink charmed, which causes a man to be mad for love. Philura,
seu Philyra, small things hanging down of trees or herbs, like unto
hears. Phyma, matis, a sore on the finger, which may be called a whytblowe.
Phlebes, veins. Phlebotomia, bloodeletinge. Phlebotomum, the instrument,
wherewith blood is leten, a fleme. Phlegethon, ontis, a river of hell, which
allwaye burns. Phlegias, the son of Mars, a king in Thessaly, and father of
Ixion. Phlegrae, a people in Thessaly. Phlius, a place in Grecia. Phlox, a
yelowe flower like a violet. Phlegma, maris, flewme. Phlegmon, onis, and
Phlegmone, nes, an inflammacion of blood, which grows into an impostume.
Phoca, a se calf, it may be supposed to be a Seal, which is fisshe, and
breedith on the land. Phocensis, of the countraye called Phocis. Phocion, a
noble counsaylour of Athenes, whose life is a myrroure to all counsayllours,
which let them read in the warke of Plutarchus, intytled the lives of noble
men. Phocis, cidis, a countraye in Greece. Phoebus, the Sun. Phoenices, people
in Syria. Phoeniceus, a, um, right Crymson. Phoenicia, a regyon in Syria.
Phoenicopterus, a great bird, having read feathers. Phoenissa, a woman of
Phenicia. Phoenix, nicis, a bird, which lives above syx hundred years, and
finally caryenge sweet spices up to a high mountain, by the heat of the
sun, and labor of her wyngis, kyndleth fire, whereby she being all burned,
of her axen ryseth another like bird: it is also a date tree, or palm, also a
little river in Grecia: it was also the brother of Cadmus, which raygned in
Phoenicia. Pholoe, a mountain in Archadia, full of wood. Phonastus, he that
techeth one to pronounce and moderate his voice. Phorbas, a shepeharde that
found Oedippum, after that he was hanged up by the feet. Phorcus, one of the
sons of Neptunus, which was taken for a god of the sea. Phoroneus, the
most ancient king of Grecia. Phosphorus, the ^^ye sterre. Phrasis, The
propre form, or manner of speech, which in one countraye is oftentimes dyuer
^e^ ^s Southern, Northern, Deuenysshe, Kentyshe, French, Picard, Gascoyne,
walon: some do set the negatife before the affirmatife, some contrary, some
speech is quick, some grave, some flouryshynge, some temperate. Phrene, the
mydryfe, which dyuideth the vmbles of a man or beast, from the bowelles.
Phreneticus, he that is vexed with a frenesy. Phrenitis, seu Phrenisis, a
syckenesse called frenesy. Phrine, a famous harlotte at Athenes. Phrigia, a
countraye in Asia the less. Phrygio, onis, a brawdrour. Phrynos, a lyzarde.
Phryx, gis, a man of Phrigia. Phthia, a city in Thessalia. Phthiriasis, a
syckenesse, in the which lyse do grow in such multitudes, that they devour
the body. Phthirophagi, people dwelling nyghe to the greek see, which lived
only by fisshe. Phthisicos, he that has the consumpcion of the lunges.
Physeter, a great fyshe in the French Occean see, which ryseth like to a
pylar above ships. Phthisis, a consumption of the body by a distillation
from the heed into the lunges, whereby the lunges are exulcerate. Phu, a
plant or herb, which some call Valeriane. Phygeton, a little swellyng or
botche, hard and read, burning and prickinge. Phylira, a tree called also
Tylia. Phyllis, a woman, daughter of Lycurgus, king of Thrace, which hynge her
self, despayriuge of the coming of Demoophon, whom she loved, whom poets
feign to be turned into an Almonde tree. Physica, warkes treating of the
nature of things, or the operacion of nature. Phisicus, a natural
philosopher. Physiologus, idem. Physionomia, seu Phisiognomia, a rule to know
a man's natural affections by his vysage or form of his members. Phyton,
one of the names of Apollo. Phitonicus, and Phitonica, he or she, which has a
spirit within them, that gives answer of things to come.
P, ANTE I.
PIabile, for the which satisfaction may be made, and god pleased. Piacularis,
re, that which is given or offered to god for satisfaction. Piabilis, that
which may be pourged or satisfied. Piacularia auspicia, tokens in sacrifice of
some heavy chance to come. Piaculum, any thing done for satisfaction of some
greuouse sin: sometime a great and haynouse offense. Piamen, seu Piamentum,
that which was given or occupied about satisfaction. Pica, a bird called a
py^. Picatus, cata, catum, pytched or rasyd with pitche. Picea, a piche tree.
Picenum, a countraye in Italy. Picens, it is, a man of that countraye. Picentus,
ta, tum, of the countraye of Picenum. Piceus, a, um, of pyche. Pico, care, to
dress with pyche. Pictatium, a table, pertaining to Iuges or bysshoppes: it
is sometime a plaster for the stomach or heed. Pictes, a wrastler. Pictor,
toris, a peyntar. Pictura, an image peynted. Picturatae vestes, imbroudred
apparayle, or rather of bawdekyn. Picturo, are, to make sundry pictures. Picus,
a little bird, which makes a hole in trees, wherein he breeds: it was also
the name of an old king of Latins. Picunnus, a pie. No. N^^.
Pieria, a mountain in Greece, dedicate to the Musis. Pie, and Pienter,
mercyfully, deuoutely, louyngly. Piens, it is, merciful, etc. Pientior,
Pientissimus, more and most merciful, most loving toward his pare^tes or
countraye. Pierides, the Muses. Pietas, etatis, the reverend love toward a
man's propre countraye and parents, of dyuines it is taken for the love and
honor due unto god. Lactantius calls it justice, Lact. lib. ^.
and devout worshyppynge and knowledge of god. Piger, gri, slow. Pigere, to be
sorry. Pigritia, Pigrities, Pigredo, Pigritas, Pigritudo, slownesse, ydelnesse.
Piget, piguit, pigere, it greueth, it dulleth, it lyketh or contenteth not*
Facti piget, he is sorry for that, that he has done: sometime, I am sorry.
Pigmentum, payntinge: also false color in speaking, disseytefull words,
pleasant lies. Pigmentarius, a maker or sellar of payntynge. Pigue, sloth.
No. (...)
Pigneratio, a pledgynge or gagynge. Pigneratitius, a, um, that which is laid
in pledge. Pignora capere, to take a distress. Ci. de ora.
Pignora, is sometime taken for children. Pignero, Pignerare, and Pigneror,
pignerari, to lay to pledge or gage, sometime to take pledge. Pignus, noris, a
pledge or gage, or pawn. Pigresco, scere, to be or wax slow. Pigre, slowly.
Pigredo, slothfulness. Pigrefio, fieri, to be made slow. Pigriria,
