slownesse. Pigritudo, idem. Pigror, idem. Pigro, are, to hold back, or tarry
one. Pila, a mortar, wherein any thing is beten with a pestill: also a pilar,
a ball, or any thing round as a ball. Pilani, they which fight with darts.
Pilates, a certain stone that is white. Pilatim, one pilar by another.
Pilatus, armed with darts. Pileatus seruus, a slave that is sold with his cap
on his heed. Pilentum, a wagan. Pileolus, a little bonet. Pileus, a cappe,
sometime liberty, for asmoche as bondmen, when they were infraunchysed, ware
copped cappes. Pilo, are, to begin to be heary, or grow in hear. Pilosus,
a, um, heary. Pilula, a little ball: also pills made for purgations. Pilum, a
barbours knyfe or rasour, also a dart of five foot long and a half.
Pilumnus, a man which found the manner to dunge land, and to grynde corn.
Pilus, a hear. Pilus, idem quod Pilum: it is also a pestell to braye or break
any thing withal in a mortar. Pinaster, a wild pyne tree. Pina, a fysshe
that has two great shelles. Pinachidia, tables made in books. Pinachtheca, a
case or place wherein tables are put or set. Pinarij, an ancient house or
famyly in Italy, of the which were the priests that sacrifised to Hercules.
Pindo, dis, si, sere: to braye or grynde. Pindus, a mountain in Thessalia:
also a city there. Pinea nux, a pyne apull. Pinetum, a wood of pynetrees.
Pineus, a, um, of a pyne tree. Pingo, xi, pingere, to paynte. Pinguedo, and
Pinguitudo, inis, fat or fattenesse. Pingue, inconvenient, sometime
fruitful, Vergilius.
commodiouse. Pingires horti, gardens that bring forth good herbs.
Pinguefacio, cere, to make fat. Pinguesco, scere, to be fat. Pinguiarius,
he that loves that thing, which is fat. Pinguitudo, fatness. Pingu^s,
gue, fat, he that is fat, corsy, unwieldy. Pingue, grease. Pinna, a quyll,
or pen, the harder part of a fether. Pinnae, imbatelmentes of a wall, a
muskle, which is founden in muddy waters. Pinnae, the fynnes of a fyshe.
Pinnaculum, a pynnacle of a tower. Pinnula, the over part of the ear, a little
quyll. Pinsito, tare, to braye in a mortar. Pinso, sui, sere, to braye or
grynde. Pinso, are, idem. Pinsor, he that gryndeth in a qwerne: also a baker.
Pinus, pinus, a pyneappull. Plautus.
Pio, ij, ere, to honor god. Pipatio, a clockinge of a hen. Pinus, seu
Pinea, a pyne tree. Pipare, to clock like a hen. Piper, eris, peper. Pipio,
iui, ire, to peep like a chicke. Pipio, onis, a pigeon. Pipleides, the musis.
Pipleus, an hill in Grecia. Pipulum, a rebuke. Plaut.
Pirum, a pear. Pirata, a rouer or robber on the se, a pyrate. Piratica, the
practice of pirates or robbers on the sea. Pirrhica, a daunsynge in harneys.
Pisa, a city in Greece between the two mountains of Olympus and Ossa: also a
city in Arcadia. Pisae, arum, a city in Italy, called Pise. Pisani, people of
the city of Pise. Pisarurus, a river in Italy. Pisaurum, a city in Italy.
Piscor, caris, ari, to fisshe. Piscaria, the fysshe markat. Piscarius, a, um,
pertayninge to fysshynge, Piscarius, a fysshe mongar. Piscatorius, a, um,
pertayninge to a fysher. Piscator, toris, a fisshar. Piscatus, tus, and
Piscatio, the act of fisshinge. Piscina, a fysshe ponder: it is also generally
every ponde, allthoughe therein be no fish. Piscinalis, le, pertayninge to
fisshe. Piscinarius, he that nourysheth fysshe. Pissis, a fysshe. Pisces, also
one of the.xii. signs. Piscosus, a, um, that may be fysshed, or is full of
fysshe. Pisculentus, idem. Pisciculus, a little fysshe. Pisci, people of the
city Pisa in Gretia. Pisidae, people in Asia. Pistacia, a certain kind of
nuttes. Pisistratus, a noble man of Athenes, which changed the commune weal
of that city from the rule of the people, to the rule of one governor: and
therefore he was called a tyrant, notwithstanding that (as he wrate unto
Solon, which mayntayned the populer astate) he ruled by their own laws, and
was rightwyse and gentle unto the people. Piso, Varro.
sere, is proprely to braye, for in the old time men used to braye or break
corn in mortars: but after that they had quernes to grynde with the hand,
they used Pisere to grynde, and Pisor for a gryndar. Piso, sonis, the name of a
noble famyly or house in Rome. Pistillum, a pestell. Pistor, oris, a baker.
Pistoria, a city in Italy. Pistoricus, ca, cum, and Pistorius, a, um,
pertaining to bakynge. Pistrilla, a mill. Pistrinum, and Pistrina, a
bakehouse, or grynding house: sometime it signifies for paynfull service.
Pistris, a ship. Pistrix, cis, a woman baker: also a monstruouse fysshe in
the Indiane see. Pistura, the craft of bakynge. Pistus, ta, tum, grounden or
brayed. Pisum, a pease. Pithacusae, Isles in the se against Campania. Pythacua,
a certain tyle, sometime made in Spain, which being cast into the water,
would not synke. Pithagoras, he which first brought up the name of a
philosopher: who was borne in Samia, and was a beautyfull man, and of excellent
wit, and therewith of a pure and clean living, absteyninge from the eating
of any thing that lived: whose Philosophy was mystical and secret, and
declared by numbres and proporcions. Pitheta, a Comete or impression in the
firmament, which is like a turine, and does appiere as it were through a
myste. Plautus in Milite.
Pithecium, a defourmed or ill favored woman. Pithonoscomes, a place in Asia,
where after the Idus of August, great flocks of Storkes do assemble together.
Pitpit, in the old tunge of Oskes sygnified quicquid, whatsoever. Pittacus,
one of the seven sages of Grecia, and was of the city of Mytelene. Pityocampe,
a worm which is in a pyneappull tree, whose bytinge is venymouse. Pitysma,
spettyll. Pitho, the lady and presydent of eloquence to persuade. Pitisso, are,
to syppe, or drink little. Pituita, flewme, or rowme, descending from the heed:
alsoo the pyppe, which chykens have. Pituitosus, flewmatike. Pitylisma, matis,
an exercise, where a man goes fast on his toes, and moves his arms forewarde
and backwarde. Pitylisso, are, to exercise in that form. Pityusa, an I Will,
called also Myletus. Pius, a, um, religiouse, devout, pitiouse, ge^tyll,
chaste: he that loves his parents or countraye. Pix, picis, Pytche. Pix
liquida, Tar.
P, ANTE L.
PLacabilis, easy to be pleased. Placabiliter, thankefully, contentfully.
Placator, toris, a pacyfyer of debate. Placae, plates of gold or silver.
Placendus, da, dum, that which ought to content. Placenta, a tarte. Placentia,
a city in Liguria. Placentini, people of the city of Placentia. Placeo, cui,
cere, to please, to like, to glory. Placide, quietly, patiently, peasybly.
Placidus, da, dum, gentle, meek, pacient. Cor. Ta^ lib. 14.
Placita, studyes or exercises. Ipse placita maiorum colebat habitu seuaero: He
in a sage garment, haunted the studyes of the ancient fathers. Placitum, a
firm consent in an opinyon, an ordinance. Placitus, ta, tum, that which
lyketh or contenteth. Placo, care, to pacyfye, to appease. Pladarotes, a
disease, whereby the eye lyddes wax feeble, and will uneath be plucked up.
Plaga, a wound, also a nett to take beastis* sometime the armyng cords: also
a great space in the earth, called a Cooster alsoo a shete for a bed:
moreover a great space on the earth, called also Clima. Plagae, and plagulae,
blankettes. Plagiaria lex, a law made against them, which were called
Plagiarn, which for their offense were whypped. Plagiarius, he that whyppeth
men. Alsoo he that byeth a man for a slave, knowinge him to be free. Alsoo he
that intyseth a man's servant to go from his master: also a stealer of books.
Plagiger, he that is borne to be whypped. Plagiosus, a school master, which
is a greatte beater. Plagium, the offense, for the which oone is whypped.
Plagosus, fulle of strypes, or he that beats much. Planaratrum, the culter
of a ploughe. Plancae, plankes. Planci, they which be splaye footed. Planctus,
tus, waylynge, sorowynge. Plancus, a noble man of Rome. Plane, truly. Planeta,
a planette. Plango, xi, gere, to weep or wayle, to strike or hytte. Catullus.
Plangor, plangoris, a noise made with the mouth, as in lawghynge, or
weepynge. Planidus, plain. Planidior, more plain. Planities, a plain or
level ground. Planior, playner, euenner. Diomedes
Planipes, he that gothe without shows. Also a player in an interlude.
Planta, the foot with the toes. Sommetyme only the soole of the foot. Alsoo
a plant or tree newely set: sometime an herb that grows low. Plantago,
ginis, an herb called Plantayne. Plantaria, settes or plants, or the places,
where plants be set. Plantaris, re, pertaining to the foot. Plantarius, a,
um, mete or ready to set. Plantigerae arbores, trees which bring forth
settes. Planto, tare, to set or plant. Planula, a plain, a ioyners
instrument. Planum facere, to declare or expound. Plaut. in ^ilite and in
^ersa.
Planus, na, number, plain, even, clear, apparaunt. Planus, ni, a deceyuour or
mocker, Also a Iugglar, which makethe things to seem in apparaunce, where in
deed no such thing is: As water to come into the house, or trees to grow,
or money of leaves or stones. Plasma, plasmatis, the w^rke of a potter, or of
him, which works in earth. Also a plaster. Plasmo, are, to make pottes, or
any other thing of earth. Plastes, a warker of images or other like thing in
earth. Plastice, the craft of warkynge in earth. Pla^anus, a plane tree.
Platane^um, a place where plane trees do grow. Platanodes, a promontory or
hill in Italy. Platanonis, ne, of plane tree. Platea, a high way or street,
Also a court in great places. Moreover a see gull. Plateae, a city in Boeotia,
not far from Thebes. Plateenses, people of the city of Plat^e in Greece.
Plato, tonis, the Prince and chief of all philosophers, as well in wisdom
and counnynge, as in good living and eloquence. Plaudi, they which have great
hanging ears. Plaudo, plausi, plaudere, to rejoice with countenance
Plausibilis, plausibile, that which the people does receive with joy, and
clapping of their hands. Plautus, a writer of comedies. Plaustrum, seu
plostrum, a carte. Plausus, sus, a reioycynge with voice and gesture, clapping
of hands together for joy Plebecula, the poor people. Plebeius, a, um, of the
people. Plebeius, plebeius, one of the comminaltie, Plautus is penulo.
not being a gentylman. Plebeus, idem. Plebicola, a favorer of the
comminaltie. Plebiscitum, a law, which sometime was made by the only consent
of the common people of Rome, without the authority of the Senate. Plebs, bis,
seu plebes, plebei, the commune people. Plecto, plexi, plectere, to punish, to
stryke. Plectrum, an instrument, wherewith men played on the harp or
doulcymers, for hurtynge of their fyngers. Also a spur set on a fighting
cock, when he lacked natural spurs. Pleiades, the seven sterres, which
marynours do use in tryenge of costs. Plemmyrium, a city in Sicili^. Plene,
largely, abundantly. Plenilunium, full moon. Plenitudo, dinis, fullness.
Plenus, na, number, fulle. Plerus, plera, plerum, of old time was v^d for more.
Plera pars, the more part. Pom. Fe^t*
Plaerique, pleraeque, pleraque, many, a great sort. Plerusque, pleraque,
plerunque, the more part of any thing. Plerique, sygnifyeth some. Plerique
omnes, for the more part. Terent in H^^vra. in Andria.
Plerunque, oftentimes, sometime. Pleonasmos, a figure, wherein is superfluity
of words. Plethtum, a measure of land, contaynyng a hundred fete. Pleuritis,
tidis, and pleuresis, a sycknes in the side, called the Pleurilye. Pleuriticus,
emitica, he or she, which has the Pleuresy. Pleuitas, vnnobilitie, baseness
of bloudde. Cato in No. Mar.
Plexus, a, um, wounden or bounden. Plico, caui, uel plicui, care, to fold.
Plicatilis, le, that which may be folden. Plintus, the name of two noble
learned men, the one wrate the most excellent warke, called the history of
Nature, the other wrate eloquente Epistles, and an oration to Tratane in his
commendation, which oration is called Panegyricus. There is also a warke of
the practice of phisyke in the name of Plinius, but whither it were of the
first Pliny or no, it is not very certain. Plocum, a small reed. Plodo,
si, dear, to make noise with hands or feet. Ploro, are, to weep. Ploratus,
tus, weepynge. Plorabundus, he that weepeth much. Cato.
Plostrum, for plaustrum, a wayne or cart. Plostrarius, a, um, that which
belongethe to a wayne or carte. Plostellum, a little wayne. Plota, a lampray.
Ploti, they which have plain feet without holownes in the soles of the
feet. Ploxinum, a coffer or cheste. Plumo, mare, to be in feathers. Also to
enbrowder. Vopiscus.
Pluma, a fether. Plumarius, ria, rium, of feathers, a warker with feathers.
Plumatilis, le, made of feathers. Plumbago, aginis, a vain of mettalle or oore,
wherein is both silver and lead, it is also an herb, which has leaves like
sorrel, and a great rote and rough. Plautus in P^nulo.
Plumbea ira, wrath which long contyneweth. Plumbatura, sowlder. Plumbata, a
pellette of leadde. Plumbatio, sowlderynge. Plumbatius, a plummer or worker in
lead. Plumbatae, balls or clubbes of lead, wherewith men faught. Plumbeus,
plumbea, beum, of the color of leadde, leedye. Plumbeus homo, a lumpyshe man
without courage or spirit. Plumbo, are, to leadde, to sowlder or ioyn
mettalle. Plumbum, leadde. Plumesco, scere, to be or wax penned. Plumeus, a,
um, of feathers. Plumiger, that bears feathers. Plumo, are, to be fetherid, or
have feathers. Plumula, a little fether or plume. Pluo, plui, pluere, to rain.
Plura, many. Pluria, idem. Plurifarius, a, um, of diverse facions. Plurifariam,
many ways, in many places. Plurimifacio, cere, to set much by. Plurimum,
very much. Plurimus, very much, many, long. Ci. in Ver.
Plurisfacio, cere, to make more of. Plus, more. Pluris uendo, I selle for more
or deerer. Plusculus, a, um, a little more. Plutealis, le, that which is
set in a table or case. Plutealia sigilla, small Images in tables or cases.
Pluteum, a space or distaunce, whereby the lower pyllers were dyuided from the
higher in the front or foreparte. Pluteus, an engyne of war, to conuaye men
to the scalynge of walls, keeping them from ordinance. Also hutches or
greatte coffers, or other like places, wherein books, tables, or such things
are kept. Pluto, tonis, called god of hell. Puuia, rain. Pluuialis,
pluuiatilis, and pluuius, a, um, rayny, or of rain. Pluuia aqua, rain water.
Pluuiosus, full of rain. Plyssima, ancient writers used for plurima, very
many.
P, ANTE, N.
PNeuma, atis, spirit or wynd or breath. Pneumaticus, ca, cum, wherein wind or
breathe is used. Pneumonici, they which be sick of the longes.
P ANTE O.
POcillator, pocillatoris, He that brings cups to the table, or a cup
bearer. Pocillum, a little cup. Poculum, a cup. sometime a draught.
Podagricus, and podagrosus, sa, sum, fulle of gout. Podagra, the gout, pain
in the feet. Podalirius, one of the sons of Esculapius a greatte surgeon.
Podaris, a long gown to the feet. Poderis, a strait garment of lynnen
cloth: It may now be called the Albe, which priests do wear when they
say mass. Podex, dicis, the arse. Podia, the cord, wherewith the sail is
spredde. Podium, a place made without a wall, for men to stand and behold
things, Also a stage, whereon is set candelles or books. Poema, matis, and
poesis, a poets warke. Poena, pain, tourment, execution. Poenalis, le,
penal, peynefull. Poenam pendere, to suffer punyshement. Poenas petere, to be
aduenged, to punish. Salustius in lugurt.
Poenas reddere, to be punyshed. Poenas luere, idem. Poenio, ancient writers
used for punio. Poenitens, it is, penitent, repentant. Poenitendus, da, dum, to
be asshamed of, to be little esteemed. Poenitentia, repentance, penance.
Perottus.
Poeniteor, I am in pain, I am grieved. Poenitudo, repentance. Poeniturus, to
be sorye. Poenula, a cloak. Poeon, a man, whom Homer calls excellently learned
in phisike. Poeonia, an herb callid Pyonie. Also a region or country in
Macedonia. Poenicus, poenica, cum, of Affrike. Poeninsula, a place, which for
the more part is enclosed with water. Poeniter, tuit, tere, to repent, to
forthynke, to be sorry for a thing. Poenus, a man of the city of Carthage.
Poeta, a poet. Poetice, ces, poetry. Poeticus, ca, cum, poetical. Poetor,
aris, ari, to exercise poetry. Poetria, and poetris, idis, a woman poet.
Pogonia, a blasing sterre, with a long beam before like a berde. Pol, an aduerbe
of swearynge, as it were by Pollux. Polenta, was barley ordered in this form.
They stepyd barley in water one night, and dried it, and the next day they
fried it, and than ground it, And so kept it long, which their slaves and
pultrye did eat. Polentarius, a, um, pertaining to barleye ground, as is
aforesaid. Polite, freshely, gayly, klenly. Politia, civility, politic
governance. Poliricus, politica, liticum, civil, or pertaining to a city.
Politiones, they which are dylygente in husbandrye. Politius, more clean or
trymme. Pollen, linis, wheat flower. Pollens, it is, puissaunt. Polliceor,
polliceri, and polliceo, pollicere, to promise. Pollicitario, a promise.
Pollinaria cribra, a rangynge syue, wherewith the flower is syfted from the
branne, it may be called also a boulter. Pollinarius, pollinaria, narium,
pertaynyng to flower. Pollit for pila ludit. Polimenta, the stones of boore
pigges. Polio, poliui, polire, to polyshe, to garnyshe or deck. Politus,
polita, politum, polysshed, decked, trymmed. Polities, cleanlynesse. Pollentia,
power, also a city. Polleo, ere, to may, to have power, to shine. Pollex,
licis, a thumb of the hand, It is also an ynche, which is a synger bredthe
and a half. Pollicaris, re, of a thumb. Pollincere, to minister about
funerals, also to boulte meal. Pollinctor, toris, the administratour or
officer in ordaynyng of funeralles. Pollinctura, the ministration of
funeralles. Pollintor, toris, a daker that syfteth meal. Pollis, linis, and
pollen, inis, meal. Pollubrum, a basin. Polluceo, cere, to mynyster sacrifyce,
specially to Hercules. Pollucibilis coena, a costely supper. Pollucibiliter,
costely, gorgiousely. Polluctum, a costely supper. Polluo, luere, to pollute or
defyle. Pollutus, ta, tum, polluted, defiled. Pom. Fes^*
Polus, the pole. There be imagyned to be two certain points in heaven, as
hit were the ends of Extree, where about heaven is meuyd, the oone is in the
North, and is callydde Polus arcticus. The other in the Southe, callydde Polus
antarcticus. Pollux, lucis, was brother to Castor, both being borne at one
bourdeyn, which Poets do feign to come of one egg, laid or brought forth by
a woman, called Leda, with whom Jupiter companied in likeness of a swanne.
Polyama, he that has many lambs. Polybotes, a gyaunte, whom Neptunus slew.
Polycarpus, he that has many flowers. Polycrates, a tyrant, which was so
fortunate, that he never suffered any aduersytie, or grief. Wherefore he at the
last dredynge the change of the favor of fortune, having a ring with a
stone of an excellent valewe, did cast the same ring into the sea, to the
intent that he would suffer sum displeasure, and so satisfy fortune: but a
fysshe devouring the ring, was the same day taken of a fyssher, and given to
the king, for the greatness of the fysshe, which being opened, there was
the said ryng found and brought to the king: whereat as well he, as all other
about him meruayled. Sone after the same king was oppressed by his people, and
hanged. Polydamas, a Troyane, oone of them, which betrayed the city with
Eneas and Anthenor. Polygonum, an herb, which is also callye Sanguinaria, and
has leaves like to Rewe, but it runs on the ground as grass, the juice
thereof put into the nose, stops bledynge. It is supposed to be swynes
grass, or knotte grass. Polyhistor, oris, he that knows much, or of many
things done. Polilogus, he that has many words. Polymirus, mita, tum, of
twyne or twysted thredes. Polymita, a garment made of twisted threde or sylke.
Polymnia, one of the Muses, which word sygnifieth much memory. Polymorphus,
of many forms or facions. Polymyxos, a candelstycke, which bears many
lyghtes. Polyphagus, a greatte eater. Polyphemus, was a gyaunt, that had oone
eye in his foreheed, which was put out by Vlyxes. Polypodium, an herb like
to fern, growing on trees. Polyposus, he that has a soore in the nose.
Polypus, a fyshe, having many feet, which changes his color often: Also a
piece of flesh, growyng in the ouermost part of the nose, which causes a
stynkynge air out of the nose. Polyrizon, that which has many roots.
Polysyntheton, a figure, where many artycles comme into a sentence, as Ille
trahebat, Hic vociferabatur, He drew, and he cried out. Polytes, one of king
Priamus sons. Polytrichon, an herb called Maydenheer. Polyxena, the daughter
of king Priamus whom cruel Pirrhus slew on the tomb of Achilles. Pomarium,
an orcharde, sometime a place wherein fruits be kept. Pomeridianus, and
postmeridianus, a, um, any thing done after noone. Pomiferus, a, um, bearing
appuls. Pomilius, and pumilio, onis, a lyttelle personage, a dwarf. Pomoerium,
the ground without the walls of the city, which moughte neither be
ploughed, nor inhabyted, the territory. Pompa, a pomp, or solemn sight.
Pompeius, the name of a noble Romayne. Pompeianus, of Pompeius part, or a
favorer of Pompeius. Pomum, the general name of all fruits. It is most used
for an appull. Ponderitas, hefte, poyse. Pondero, raui, rare, to way, to
ponder, to consider, to esteem. Pondo, a pound weight, sommetyme.xii. pound.
It was among the Romans the pound of money, as Mina, and mna, was in
Athenes, which was of the value of a hundred old poyse grotes, whereof.viii.
went to an ounce: so that in those grotes after our rate, it contained a pound
and a mark of new grotes ten to the ounce.ii. pound and five grotes.
Pondus, deris, weight. Varro.
sometime it signifies number, also authority. Ponderosus, a, um, wayghty.
Ponere spem, to hope. Pone, after, or behind. Plautus in capt.
Pone eum esse victum, Put the case that he be vanquyshed. Pono, posui,
ponere, to put, to set, to cesse, to build, to lay a part. Pons, pontis, a
bridge. Pontica nux, a kind of fylberdes, which came from the countreye
called Pontus in Asia. Ponticum, is a taste, which has no sent to be
discerned. Ponticulus, a little bridge. Pontifex, ficis, an archebyshoppe.
Pontificatus, tus, the dignity of a bishop. Pontificius, a, um, of a
bishop. Pontones, whyry botes. Pontus, the sea, which is from the great
fenne, callydde Maeotis, unto Tenedum, It is sommetyme vsyd for all the sea. It
is also a prouynce in Asie the less. Popa, fat, grease. Popana, fat
oyntementes. Popanum, a cake of breadde. Popellus, the little or poor people.
Popina, a couern^ or vyttaylynge house, where meat is eaten out of due time.
Popinatio, ryotte. Popinalis, le, pertaining to riot, or places of ryotte.
Popinor, aris, ari, to eat out of due time, to be ryottous. Popiniones,
haunters of tauernes. Poples, poplitis, the hamme of a ma^s leg behind the
knee. Poppisma, oratis, the noise made with the mouth and the hand, in
ryding, or wanton dalyaunce. Populabundus, wasting the countreye, or he that
gothe in forragynge or robbynge of countries. Popularis, re, pertaining to the
people, accepted or favored of the people. Also it sygnifyeth a familiar
friend, or as we use to call country man. Populariter, and populare, homely,
like the people. Populatus, ta, tum, wasted, distroyd. Populeus, a, um, of a
popler tree. Populnus, and populneus, idem. Popularitas, the conjunction or
amytie of people of one country. also affability, humanity, toward the
people. Populatia, boys plays. Liberius i^ No. Mar.
Populatim, of all the people. also euerich one. Populatio, a wasting of the
countreye, a fourragynge. Populator, a forrageour or waster of countries.
Populifugia, was a day in the month of June, at the which day by reason of
a rumor, the people fled. Populor, aris, to wast or distroy a country.
Populosus, a, um, full of people, populous. Populus, people. Also a poplar
tree. Porca, a sow, a rydge of land, a balke. Porcarius, a, um, of a swyne.
Porcarius, a swyneherde. Porceo, cere, to prohibyte. Pom. Fest.
Porcetra, a young sow, or yelte. Porcinus, na, number, of a hog. Porculatio,
bringing up of swyne. Porculator, a fatter of swyne. Porcus, a hog.
Porcellus, a pygge. Porculus, a shoot, a porcatte. Porcus troianus, a hog
roosted with many other beasts and fowls within his bealye. Porgam, used of
the ancient writers for porrigam, I will deliver or take to one. Pori, poores
in the body, out of the which issues sweat. Porphyr^tes, a red marble.
Porphyreticus, ca, cum, of read marble. Porphyriacus, ca, cum, of purple
color. Porphyrio, a bird, which drinks as if he did byte the water, he
has long red legs and bylle. Porraceus, a, um, of the colors of leeke
blades. Porrectus, ta, tum, stretched. Porrecte, straight out. Porriginosus, a,
um, like to lekes. Porrigo, portexi, rigere, to sprede out, to offer, to
overthrow. Porrigo, ginis, skales which do fall from a man's heed or berde,
like branne. Porro, surely. also long before, far of, after, in time
coming, beyond, forsooth. Porrum, potri, in the plu^ell number leeke.
Porraceus, a, um, of a leeke. Porsena, the name of a king, that besyeged Rome.
Porta, a yate. Portendo, dear, to sygnifie before a thing happens.
Portentiferus, a, um, that which signifies strange or monstrous things
coming. Portentificus, ca, cum, idem. Portentosus, a, um, monstruouse,
sygnifieng some thing to come. Portentum, a thing monstrous or very seldom
seen, which may sygnifie sum what to come. Porticus, cus, a porche. Portio,
a portion. portiuncula, a little porcio^. Portiusculus, the pylate of a ship,
which rules the maryners. Portitor, oris, the customer of a haven. Also a
porter, that does bear things that be bought, whither as the byer will have
him. Also he that bears men fro the haven to the ship. Porto, tare, to
bear, to bring. Portorium, the frayte paid for passage or caryage of
merchaundyse. Portulaca, an herb called Purselan. Salustius in iugur.
Portuosus, full of havens. Portus, tus, an haven. Posca, a sauce made with
vyneygre and water. Poscinumius, mia, um, that which requires money. Posco,
poposci, poscere, to ask, to require, to provoke, to assail. Pos, a bridge.
Varr^.
Positio, a setting of a thing. Positura, idem. Positus, ta, tum, put or
set. Positura, and positus, tus, a setting or putting. Possessio, onis,
possession. Possessor, oris, he that has the possession, the owner. Possideo,
sedi, sidere, to possede. Possum, potui, posse, to may. Caesar.
Post, after, afterward, behind. Postea, afterward. Postergo, are, to leave
behynd, to cast back. Posteritas, tatis, the world to come. Posterius, later,
slower, ^yler. Posterus, ra, rum, that which comes after. Postera dies, the
day after Posteri pedes, the hinder ^ete. Post fero, to set after or behind,
to set less by. Post habere, idem. Posthac, from hensforthe. Posthumus, ma, a
child borne after that the father is dead. Posthumus, ma, mum, following, or
to come. Posticum, and posticus, a back door. Postica, all that is behind
us, like as Antica is all that is before us. It is also a line which divides
the feldes from the cast to the weste. Postilena, a crouper. Postis, a post.
Postlimineum redire, is when any man happeth to go from us to our ennemies,
and after retourneth home. Postmitto, tere, to leave behind, to forget.
Postmodum, afterward. Postquam, after. Postremo, at the last. Postridie, the
day after to morrow, the day following the day before expressed. Postomis, a
braake, wherewith a horses mouth is broken, and is made to bear his heed
easyly. Postulo, are, to require, to demand a thing which is dew to the
asker. Also to accuse or sewe oone in the law, or to complain on one.
sometime to desire. Postulatio, a supplication made to a prince. Pl^. in epis.
Potens, it is, mighty, puissant, hable. Potentia, power, puissa^ce, habilite,
great rule. Potenter, myghtily, puissantly. Caes. lib. 1. belli galli.
Potentatus, tus, power. Potestas, tatis, power, authority, counsel, and
reason. Potestatem sui facere, to suffer men to come to him, or to speak with
him. Potiono, are, to give a medicyne. Potior, potius, better. Potior, poti^us
sum, potiri, to have in possessyon, to obtain, to take pleasure of. Potestur,
for potest, he may. Potis sum* I may, potis est, it is possible. Potitius,
Hercules priest. Potito, tare, to use to drink. Poto, tare, to drink: Also
to give drink to one. Potorium, a cup. Potus, ta, tum, that which has
drunk, and that which is dronken. Potus, tus, drink.
P, ANTE, R.
PRae, before, in regard, or in comparyson, for. Prae amore, for love. Also
of. Prae studio, of study. Praeut, sygnyfieth than. Modestior nunc quidem est
de uerbis, praeut dudum fuit, He is more soft or gentle of words, than he
was wont to be, or than he was late. Praebitere, to pass by, or pass forth
in journey. sometime perire, to lose, to cast away. Plautus. Pom. Fest*
Praebeo, bui, bear, to give, to show. Praebia, orum, things given to sick
men. Praecaluus, balde before. Praecarus, ra, rum, very dear. Praecedo, cessi,
dear, to goo before. Praecello, lui, lere, to excelle. Praecentio, that which
is songen or playde at the beginning of a song or balade. Praecentor, toris,
he that first sings. it may be taken for the chaunter in a quyre. Praesultor,
toris, he that leads the daunse. Praeceps, pitis, a high place stepe down.
Praeceps homo, he that is to haslye in his business, and does things
unadvisedly. Praeceps, heedlynge. Praeceptum, a precepte, a rule given, a
commandment. Praecidanea porca, a swine, which the Paynims did sacrifice
before they did cut down their corn. Praecidaneus, a, u^, that which is first
killed. Cice. in Achad. que^^
Praecido, dear, to speak or tell precisely, or certainly, to strike, to cut
of, to beat, to deny styffely. Ci. ad A^. lib. 8.
Plane sine ulla exceptione praecidit, Truly he styffly denied it without
exception. Praecino, nui, nere, to sing before or first, also to tell a thing
before it happens. Praecipio, coepi, cipere, to prevent or take first* to
forsee: also to command. Praecipitium, a down right place or step, which
may not be gone on. Praecipito, tare, to throw down heedling.
Praecipitanter, heedlynge, unadvisedly. Praecipuus, a, u^, chief, special,
principal. Praecipue, chiefly, specially, principally. Praecise, precisely,
determinately. Praecisum, hard, intractable, cutted, very short, Quin^^^^*
lib. ^.
Qui praecisis conclusionibus obscuri, Salustium atque Thucydide^ superant. The
which being hard to be understand in their cutted sentences, do excede
both Saluste and Thucydides. Praeclamo, are, to cry before. Praeclare, very
excellently, very nobly. Praeclarus, very noble: sometime it signifies good.
Praecognitus, ta, tum, known before. Praeco, conis, a cryar, a publysshar of
things. Praeconium, a solemn cry: sometime it signifies praise or glory.
Praecoquor, queris, qui, to be sone ripe. Praecordia, the skin, which
dyuideth the over part of the body from the nether: it is also taken for the
place under the rybbes: sometime all the numbles, as the heart, the spleen, the
lunges, and liver. Praecox, cocis, and Praecoquus, a, um, sone ripe or tymely
ripe. Praeda, a proye, a thing gotten or taken in wars. Q^. Curt^.
Praedabundus, going on foragynge in the time of war. Praedaceus, a, um, of
a proye. Praeda^iuus, idem. Praedator, a seekar for a proye. ^a^^stiu^
Praedator ex socijs, a robber of his company. Praedensus, a, um, very thick.
Praedestino, are, to purpose before. Praediator, toris, a man of law expert in
actions real, or matters concerning lands. Praediatorius, a, um, pertayninge
to lands. Praedicatio, a publysshynge, or open declaration. Praedico, care, to
publysshe, to tell a thing openly, to praise. Praedico, xi, dicere, to tell
before. Praediolum, a little manor. Praedisco, didici, discere, to understand
before. Praeditus, ta, um, adourned: also Praeditus more rore, replenyshed with
heaviness: Praeditus lachrymis, washed with tears, or full of tears.
Praedium, a manor. Praedonulus, a little robber. Praedo, donis, a robber of
countrayes. Cato.
Praedor, aris, ari, to rob a countraye, or to take prays. Praedotiunt, they
chiefly desire. Pom. Fest.
Praeduro, are, to be harder than it was wo^t. Praeeo, iui, ire, to go before.
Praefacio, feci, facere, to set more by. Praefanda, not honest to be spoken or
reherced. Praefari, to speak or say before. Praefatio, onis, a preface.
Praefectus praetorij, was with Emperors the principal officer in his court:
as now in France the great master. Praefero, tuli, far, to prefer.
Praefericulum, a great basin, which was carried before him that did sacrifice.
Pom. Fest.
Praefestino, are, to make to much ha^te. Praefica, a woman, which is hired to
lament at the buryenge of men or women. Praeficio, faeci, ficere, to put in
authority, or to give rule. Praefectura, an authority or rule. Praefectus, a
rular. Praefigo, xi, gere, to shut before. Praefinio, niui, ire, to determyne
before, to assign or appoynte. Praefinitus, ta, tum, prefixed. Praefoco, care,
to strangle, or choke. Praefractus, cta, etum, hard and unflexible, which
will rather break than bow: also that which was before broken. Praefracte,
obstinately. Praefrigidus, da, dum, very cold. Praefulcio, cire, to fortifye.
Plautus in Pseudolo.
Praefulgeo, fulsi, gere, to shine much. Praefu^^ium, the mouth of an oven or
fournayse. Praegelidus, da, dum, exceeding cold. Praegigno, nere, to begin, to
bring in first. Nolebam ex me morem praegigni malum, I would not that an ill
custom should be brought up by me. Praegestio, ire, to rejoice much.
Praegnans, it is, a woman with child. Praegrandis, de, very great.
Praegrauatio, a great grief. Praegredior, gredi, to go before. Praegrauo, are,
to grieve much. Praehendo, di, dear, to take. Cic. in P^^^. and ad Atti. Ti.
Liuius.
Manum praehendere, to take by the hand. Praehensatio, a solicitinge or
laboringe for the attayninge of some great office. Praehenso, are, to embrace
or set hand on one, to solicit. Praeiacio, praeieci, praeiacere, Colum. 9.
to cast before a thing. Praeiacio, cui, cere, to lie before. Praeire
iuramentum, to ministre or give an oath. Praeiuditium, a thing which being
ones decyded and determined, makes a rule or example to men that do follow, to
discuss semblably in a like matter. As those which we do call ruled cases or
matters in the law, which be as examples to iuges. Praeiudico, to judge before:
sometime to condemn, also to let. Praeiuro, rare, to swear before other.
Praeiuratio, the oath that is taken by him that first swears. Praeiurator,
toris: he which first takes an oath, as the fore man of a Jury, or the first
witness, or any other, after whom other men do swear, according to the oath
given unto him. Praelabor, beris, by, to fall first. Praeliaris, are,
pertayninge to battle. Praeliator, toris, a warrior. Praelicenter, very
wantonly. Praelior, aris, ari, to fight in battle. Cato
Praeliganeum vinum, a praeligando, which I suppose to be so called, either
because it is first runned or put into vessels, or else because it is put into
a sack, which is fast knytte before. Praeligo, gare, to bind before. Praelium,
battle also the fight in battle: sometime the act of generation. Praelongus,
a, um, very long. Praeloquium, the beginning of a communication, or thing
spoken, as that which in thetorike is named exordium. Praeloquor, queris, qui,
to speak or tell before. Praeluceo, cere, to bear light before one, as a
torche or candel: also to give more light than another. Praelucere alijs
virtute, to shine in virtues before other. Praeludium, a proheme, or that which
Musicians and Mynstrelles do play at the beginning, er they come to the
song* which they purpose to play. Praeludo, si, dear, to play before.
Praelum, a press. Praelumbo, are, to break ones loins. Praeluo, luere, to
pourge or wasshe clean before. Praemando, daui, to send before. Praemanibus,
ready at hand. Pla^t in Mo^^e^^.
Praemature, to soon, or before the just time. Praemature vita careo, I dye
before my time. Praemeditor, taris, tari, to advise before a man do a thing.
Prae me sero, prae me tuli, prae me far, to declare by deed, word, or
gesture. Prae te fers iracundiam, thou shewyste thy self to be angry: also to
confess: also to have before him a thing (as it were) in remembrance.
Praemercor, caris, cari, to bye aforehande. Praemessum, a sacrifyce or offrynge
to Ceres, of the cares of corn that was first repyd. Praemetium, the
fyrstcroppe. Praemiatores, thieves which steal by night, as we might say,
which commytte burglary. Praemiator, is a rewardar. Praemineo, nui, ere, to be
better than another or excel above another in astate or virtue. Praemior, aris,
ari, to give rewards. Praemiosus, rich of money. Praemissio, a sendinge
before. Praemitto, misi, tere, to send before. Praemium, a reward, given to him
which has done any notable and laudable thing. Cellius.
Praemoderor, aris, ari, to play before on an instrument. Praemodum, above
measure. Praemolestia, fear of a thing to come. Ci. Tus. ^
Praemollis, le, very tender or delicate. Praemoneo, nui, nere, to forewarne.
Praemonstrator, toris, he that tells or shows a thing before that it
happens. Terent. in Heau.
Praemonstro, are, to show before. Praemordeo, dear, to byte or rebuke before.
Praemorior, riris, ri, to dye er the time come. Praemunio, iui, ire, to
prepare. Praenarro, rare, to tell before. Praenato, tare, to swymme before.
Praeneste, a city in Italy. Praenestini, people of the city of Preneste in
Italy. Praenestinus, a, um, of Preneste. Praenomen, the first name: as Marcus.
Quintus, Lucius: and as we now have the name at baptysme. Praenosco, noui,
noscere, to know before. Praenoto, tare, to make annotations or inscriptions.
Praenuncio, are, to show before. Praenuncius, the first messenger, he that
first brings tydinges. Praeoccupatio, a figure in Rhetorike, when we will
say that we will not tell a thing, and yet thereby covertly we will declare the
matter, or make it suspected. Praeoccupo, pare, to take or possede a thing by
preuencion. Praeopto, tare, rather to desire. Praeordinatio, the first
ordinance. Praeordinator, he that made the first ordinance. Praeordino, are,
to ordain before. Praeparcus, ca, cum, very scarce or nygarde. Praeparo, are,
to prepare, to make ready. Praepedimentum, a let before. Praepedio, diui, to let
much. Praependo, dear, to hang before. Praepes, praepetis, swyft. Praepetes
aues, were the birds, which showed them selfs first to the diuinours called
Augures, whereby they supposed to know what should ensue. Praepeto, tere, to
begin first. Praepilatus, ta, tum, hedded with iron, as a Iauelyn or dart:
also sharp before like the heed of a dart, though it has none iron* as the
horns of a lopster, wherewith he swymmeth. Praepinguis, very fat. Praepondero,
are, to way more, to be more worth. Praepolleo, lere, to excede other.
Praepono, sui ponere, to put or set before. Praepositus, ta, tum, set or
advanced above other, set in authority. Praepositus, ti, he that is in
authority, or chief in any office. Praepotens, very puissant or mighty.
Praepoto, tare, to drink before, to bring good luck in drinkinge.
Praeposterus, ra, rum, overthwart, out of order. Salustius (...) Iug.
Praeposteri homines, they that do that thing last, which they should have
done first. Praepostere fieri, to be done against all good order. As when the
servant commands his master, the people their rulars, or a fool a wise man.
Praeproperus, ra, rum, very quick or hasty. Praeputium, the skin which
covers the heed of a man's priuey membre. Praeripio, pui, pere, to prevent, to
catch. Praerideo, dear, to lawghe before. Praerisor, oris, he that laugheth a
fore one. Praerodo, si, dear, to gnawe or eat very much. Praerogata
beneficia, benefytes before employed. Praerogo, gare, to employe or give before.
Praerogatiua, and praerogariuum, a prerogati^e, where one is preferred before
another. Praerumpo, pere, to break asonder. Praeruptus, ta, tum, all to
broken. it is sometime taken, where a hill is broken by the sides, and hard to
go on. Praerupta loca, places broken here and there, that no man may pass.
Praesagio, gire, and praesagior, to perceive or know a thing before that it
happen. Praesagus, a pronosticatour, or perceyuer of things er they hap.
Praesagium, and praesagatio, among the ancient writars, a perceiving of a
thing before that it happens, sometime a conjecture. Praescientia, an
understanding and perfyte knowledge of all that shall happen. Praescius, he
that knows perfytely things er they happen. Praescio, scire, to know before.
Praescribo, psi, bear, to assign, to note or entitle, to put, to lay before,
to tell before, to appoint or determyne. Praescriptio, and praescriptum, a
rule, a law, an order, a form. Praescriptum, a precepte, a form, a rule.
Praeseco, care, to cut before, sometime to cut on sonder. Praesegmina, the
parings of a man's nails. Praesens, it is, present. In praesentia, and in
praesentiarum, at this present time. Praesentius, better. Praesentissimus, a,
um, the best, the surest. Praesentissimum venenum, the greatest and most
fervent poison: also strong. Presens animus, a strong or good courage, also
favorable. Deum praesentem haber, he has god favorable unto him. Praesentaneum
remedium, a short or sudden remedy. Praesentia, presence. Praesentio, and
praesentisco, cere, to feel or perceive before. Praesento, tare, to have ready.
Praesepe, and praesepium, and presepes, a stable, a stall, a shepehouse.
Praesepi^, pire, to hedge before a thing. Praesertim, specially. Praeseruatio,
a preservation. Praeseruare, to preserve. Praeses, sidis, Plautus in Casina.
he that has authority in a province next under the prince: sometime it
signifies a defendour, alsoo sure. Locum praesidem, a sure place. Praesideo,
dear, to be in more autoritye, or of a more dignity: also to have authority
or rule. Praesideratio, tempest, which comes at the beginning of winter,
sooner than it is looked for, or is accustomed to happen. Praesidero, are, where
tempest comes very soon, and before the time accustomed. Praesicco, care, to
dry before. Praesidiarius, a, um, that which is ordained to be aid to another
thing. Praesidium, a garyson of men with a capytayne, set by the chief
captain, to defend a fortress: sometime it is taken generally for all manner
of aid or defense: also for a fortification of a thing. Praesilio, silire, to
lepe before, to sterte out. Praesisto, tere, to stand or be set before.
Praespeculor, ari, to look before. Praespicio, spexi, spicere, to see before.
Praestabilis, le, excellent. Praestabilius, bettar. Praestantia, excellency.
Praestat, it is bettar. Praestans, it is, excellent. Praestanter, excellently.
Praestare culpam, to take the blame on him. Praestare officium, to do his
deuoyre. Cicer. T^.
Praestare iusiurandum, to take an oath. Praestega, a place open before, and
keuered behind like a porche, where men do sit for recreacion after their
business. Praester, a venymouse serpent, of whom he that is stryken, dies
for thurst. Praestigiator, toris, a iuggler. Pom. Fest.
Praesies, titis, of the ancient wrytars called a prelate. Praestigium, a
iugglynge cast, an inchauntment, a delusyon. Praestino, are, to prepare in
byenge a thing. Praestituo, ere, to determine before, to prescribe or appoint
before, what shall be done. Istam enim culpam, quam vereris, ego praestabo, Ci.
de ora.
for the blame, which thou fear, I will take upon me. Praesto, stiti,
state, to be better than another thing, wherewith it is comparyd, to excel:
also to undertake, to waraunt, sometime to grant, also to do, to be
beneficial, to beware, to exchue, to fear, to do or perform, Ci ad Q. (...).
to give, to exhibit, to represent or show, to lend, to assign or appoint,
to do a thing. Praesto, an aduerbe, ready, at hand. Praestosis, help me.
Praesto esse, to appiere, as me^ do in places of iugementes. Praestolor, aris,
ari, to tarry, to be at hand, or ready to do service. Praes^tingo, xi, gere, to
bind fast, to shut, to dasell the eyes, to touch quickly, or shortly, to
shave, to grieve somewhat. Praestruo, struxi, struere, to ordain first, to
build. Praesul, lis, a prelate. Praesulatus, tus, the dignity of a prelate.
Praesulto, are, to leap or daunse before. Praesultor, praesultoris, he that
leads a daunse. Praesum, fui, praesse, to be before or above an other, to be
of more dignitye, to be in autorytye. Praeesse negotio, to be chief in the
business. Praesumere animo, to coniecte. Praesumo, sumpsi, sumere, to take
first, to preuente. Praesumptio, a taking or receyuynge before: it is also
that, which is called preoccupation, when we declare first what our adversary
will say, or what is the iuges opinion: and against that we do argue, to
dissolve it with reason. Praesuo, ere, to sow before. Praesurgo, gere, to rise
before or first. Praetego, gere, to hyde or cover chiefly. Praetendo, ere, to
lay for a thing er it come: also to carry or bear before, also to show or
pretend, to allege, to set a thing about for an enclosure. Praetendere
sepem, to make a hedge about. Praetento, tare, to tempte or assaye before.
Praeteriue, very sklenderly. Praeterduco, cere, to lead before, to lead forth.
Praetergredior, di, to pass by, to go beyond. Praeteritus, ta, tum, passyd.
Praeteriti, deed, departed, decessyd: also they which in suynge for an office,
did suffer repulse, or were put back. Praeter propter, for an other cause than
that which is reherced. Praeter, except, also beside, over and above, before.
Praeter oculos, before the eyes, Against or contrary. Praeter morem, against
the custom or facion. Praeter spem, unlooked for. Praeter opinionem, otherwise
tha^ I thought. Praeter caetera, more than the other. Praeter aequum, against
raison. Praeterbito, tare, to go by. Praeterea, moreover, beside, none else.
Mihi credis praeterea nemini, Thou beleuest me, and none else. also it
signifies afterward. Praetereo, iui, ire, to go over or pass, to leave out a
thing, which should be spoken of. Praetermitto, misi, tere, to leave untouched,
to forgete, to leave out. Praetermissio, forgetynge, or leuinge out of a
thing. Praeterquam, but only, otherwise than, moreover. Praeterquam quod,
but. Praeterueho, here, to carye through. Praeteruolo, are, to pass through
quickly. Praetexo, ui, ere, to make or ordain first, to cover or hyde.
Praetexta, a long garment myxte with purple silk, which was the vesture of
noble men's sons, until they came unto.xvii years of age: and therefore
such children were called Praetextati, but they had alsoo about their necks,
a little round jewel of gold, facyoned like a heart, wherein was enclosed some
thing of great virtue. Praetexta, was also the robe of astate, which the
king of Romans, or the other chief officers did wear, when they sat in
their majesty. Praetexta comaedia, an interlude, wherein are personages of
high dignity. Praetextatus, ta, tum, dishonest, Suetonius Gellius, Macro.
or unclean in speech or acts. Festus takes it in the contrary sense.
Praetextum, a pretense or color. Praetiamitatores, officers which went before
the prelates called Flamines, proclayming openly, that all men should cease of
their warke, because it was not lefull to those prelates to behold any man
warkynge. Praetimeo, ere, to be sore aferde. Praetingo, gere, to touch before.
Praetondeo, to sheere or klyppe, or round before. Praetoritius, a, um, for
Praetorius. Praetorium ius, law made by the Praetor. Praetor, toris, a chief
captain in wars, in a city or contraye. Praetor is he, which has
autoritye to sit in judgment, and to give sentence in causis. Praetorianus, he
that is attendant to him that is Praetor. Praetorium, the house or pauylyon of
him that is Praetor. it is alsoo a princes palayce or manoure: it is sometime
the place, where iugementes are given, sometime the counsel, whereunto
Praetores are assembled. Praetorius, he that has been Praetor. Praetorius, a,
um, belonginge to the office of Praetor. Praetura, the dignity and
ministration, of him that is Praetor. Praeualeo, lere, to prevail, to be
better or of more value. Praeualidus, a, dum, very strong or mighty, sometime
very great. Praeuaricario, is a collusion: alsoo it is where one touches a
thing lytely, which ought to be inculked with a more plain declaracyon, or else
repeted, as making much to the purpose. Praeuaricor, aris, ari, to swarne
from truth, to go out of the right way, to leave vnsayd that, which should be
spoken, to touch a thing shortly in speaking, to warke by collusion, in
suffringe his adversary to obtain, to hurt another person. Praeuaricator,
toris, he that leueth the right way, or speaks not that which ought to be
spoken: also he that in spekinge for him self aydeth the cause of his
adversary, or does any thing by collusion. Praeuelio, here, to bring first.
Praelo, are, to cover or hyde before. Praeuello, lere, to pull or pluck before.
Praeuenio, nire, to come before or prevent. Ti. Liuius. de bell. pu. Ci. de Di.
Praeuentio, a prevention. Praeuideo, dear, to foresee, to beware. Praeuius, he
that leads the way. Praeuerto, uertere, to set more by, or to care more for.
Plautus in Amphi.
Nec me vxorem praeuortisse dicant, prae repub. Nor let them not say, that I
set more by my wife, than by the weal publyke. Plautus in milite.
Also to turn or set a side. Neque praeripio pulpamentum, neque praeuorto
pocu lum, Nor I take away thy meat, nor set or turn aside thy drink.
Plautus in. capt.
Praeuertor, deponens, idem quod praeuerto: also to go before. Inde illico
praeuertor domum, from thense I went home before. also to be turned forth.
Foreis enim clausit, Plautus in Amph.
ne praeuorteretur for as, he has shyr fast the door, leest he should be
turned forth. Also to do any thing first or before any other thing.
Praeuorti hoc certum est rebus alijs omnibus, Surely this shall be done before
any other thing. Praeuertere serio, to turn it to ernest. Plautus in amph.
Si quid dictum est persocum, non aequum est id te serio praeuortier. If any
thing be spoken in iape, it is not rayson to turn it to erneste. Praeuerti
pigritiae, Plautus in Merc.
to be taken with sloth Cave pigritiae praeuortier, beware that thou be not
taken with slouthe. Praeuersus, a, um, that which is done or sped first, or
before any other. Praeuersum fulgur, Pom. Fest.
lightening which is not known, whyther it be by day or by night.
Praeuolo, are, to flee before. Pragmaticus, a practiser in the law. Pragma in
greek, is in latyne negociatio, an act or business: alsoo an exercise of
marchaundyse. Pragmatica sanctio, a determination of practisians of the law.
Prandeo, prandi, and pransus sum, prandere, to dyne. Prandiculum, a brekefast.
Prandiolum, a lyter dynar. Prandium, a dynar. Pransito, tare, to dyne or eat
often. Pransor, oris, he that is at dynar, or he that is boden to dynar.
Prasinus, na, number, green like leekis. Prasius, a green stone. Prasoides, a
stone of the color of leekes. Pratensis, se, of the meadows. Pratense foenum,
medowe hay. Pratulum, a little medowe. Praue, shrewedly, noughtyly, unhappily,
ouerthwartly. Prauitas, shrewdenesse, unhappiness, ouerthwartnesse. Pratum,
medowe. Prauus, a, um, crooked. Praxiteles, an excellent caruar in stone.
Precarius, a, um, that which is borrowed, as the will of the lender, that which
is occupied, at another man's pleasure. Precario, by desire at another man's
will. Preces, prayer. Precium, price, value. Preciosus, a, um, dear,
preciouse. Precor, aris, ari, to pray. Prehendo, prehendi, dear, to take. Et
manuta prehendi, and osculum detuli tibi, I took you by the hand, and also
gave you a kiss. Premo, pressi, premere, to press: sometime to vex, to
dygge, to prese on, to thruste, to destroy, to thrust down, to constrayne, to
restrain. Vergilius.
Premere dolorem, to hyde heaviness or sorrow. Premit alto cord dolorem, he
hyd his sorrow in the secret part of his heart. Varro.
Premere, to drive or put out. Premere, to shyt or close. Pressique oculos, ac
vulnera laui, Verg.
I closed his eyes, and washed his wounds. Premere, to cut away. Et ruris
opaci, false premes vmbram, Ver geo. 1
and with a sithe thou shall cut away the shadow of the dark feldes.
Premere, to trede down. Veluti qui sentibus anguem, Vergili. 2.
pressit humini tens, like as he, which thraslyng his foot to the ground,
tredeth down the snake, that lies in the brembles. Premere testimonio, to
conuicte a man by witness. Presa porca, a swyne which was offered in sacrifice
to Ceres, in satisfaction for a hole household, for as much as a part of that
sacrifice was made in the presence of the corpse, which than was to be buried.
Pressatus, ta, tum, oppressed, charged trodden down. Pres, predis, he that
undertakes, if any incommoditie do happen, C^o^ Nep. A^^ ^ian.
that he shall make sufficient recompense: it is also he that is bounden for
such money as is borowyd of a commune treasure or stock. Presbiter, biteri,
an ancient, or father in years or dygnytye. It is used for a priest. Presso,
are, to press or thrust together. Pressus, ssa, ssum, subtle, compacte, heavy,
pressed. Pressus, ssus, and pressura, pressinge, also oppression. Pretiosus, a,
um, preciouse, dear, of great estimacion. Pretiosior, pretiosius, more
preciouse or dear. Pretium, the price or value: alsoo the reward: sometime
peril or danger. Pretio emptas meo, Terent. in ptol. Hec.
bought with my peril or danger. Pri, of old time was used for Prae.
Priamus, the noble king of Troy, whose history is to no man unknown.
Priapismus, a sickness, wherein the pryuy membre of a man allway stands,
without having any appetite to lechery. Priapus, an ydolle, unto whom the
Paynymes, committed their gardynes to keep. Pridem, lare. Pridianus, a, um,
that which is done the days before. Pridie, the day before. Primas tenere, to
have the preeminence, to be chief, to hold the bettar part. Primas dare, to
esteem above other. Primaeuus, a, um, the elder. Primarius, a, um, chief.
Primas, atis, in chief authority. Primanus Tribunus, he that assigned tribute
to the first legion. Prima lux, the spring of day. Prima vespera, the
evening. Ci. de (...)
Primae, the chief praises. Cui primae sine co^trouersia deferebantur, to whom
the chief praises were given without any controuersye. Primitus, first.
Primetium, sacrifice of the ears of corn* which were first gathered after
that they were repyd. Primores, the tops of any thing. Plautus.
Digitulis primoribus, with the fingar tops. Labris primoribus, with the fore
part of the lyppes. Primotibus labris gustare, to touch a thing skantely, to
smater of a thing, and not to know it substancially or perfitely.
Primicerius, chief ruler. Primigenus, gena, genum, first borne or grown.
Primigenius, a, um, that comes naturally of it self, and is unmixed.
Primigenia, the title of the eldest child in inheritance. Primipara, she that
has her first child. Primipes, he that in battle fyghteth first with a
sword, and after chaungynge his form of fighting, uses a Iauelyne or
darte. Primipilaris, is he that fyghteth next to the standarde. It is most
proprely the Capytayne of a company in the fowewarde. Primitium, the
principal or chief. Primipilus, Vege^i. ^.
a capytayne of a company in the forewarde or vauntgarde, which had under
him four hundred Soldiers. Primiter, and Primitus, first. Primitiae, the
first fruits. Primitius, a, um, the first or foremoost. Primitiuus, a, um, that
which has none other beginning. Primesius, a stake, whereto a cabell or rope
of a ship is tied. Primo, an aduerbe, signifies first. Primodum, for Primo.
Primogenia verba, words which be not dyed from any other. Primogenitus, ta,
tum, first begotten. Primordium, the first beginning. Primores, the first,
the chief. Primores uiri au^ feminae, Noble men or womenne, or gentle men and
gentle women. Primulus, the diminutiue of Primus. Primum, an aduerbe, which
sygnifyethe first, or ever. Primus, a, um, first, best, the chief. Primo
quoque tempore, arre the first time. Prima quaque occasion, at the first
occasyon that shall happen. Princeps, cipis, a prince, the first or chief.
Principalis, le, principal, also, pertaining to a prince. Principaliter,
pryncipallye. Principio, an aduerbe, first, or at the beginning. Liuius
Terent. suetonius
Principia, the place in a Camp, where as are pyghte the pauilions of the heed
capitaynes: but the more propre sygnification thereof is, that it is the second
ward in battle, where in old time were the princis and noble men. Also it
was taken for the order of ray of noble men. Principior, piari, to begin.
Principor, pari, to rule. Principium, the beginning. Prior, the first. Priora
tempora, the old time. Priscus, a, um, ancient, or of the old time.
Pristinus, na, mim, that which was many years passed. Sometime it sygnifyeth
the first, ancient. Pristis, a fysh, of wonderful length, and sclender,
which cuttethe the wawes, as he swymmeth. Priuatus, he that is in none
auctorytie or dygnitie. Priuatus, ta, tum, that is proprely a man's own, that
which pertayneth to oone man or few, also particular. Sometime it signifies
deprived. Priuatim, and private, priuyly, aparte. Priuernum, a town in
Campania. Priuignus, na, the child by an another husband, or other wife,
which is deed, son or daughter in law to the husband or wife. Priuilegium, a
law concerning pryuate persons* also a private or special law. Priuo, are,
to take away, to deprive. Prius, an aduerbe, sygnifyeth before. Priusquam,
before that. Priuus, ua, uum, pryuate, synguler, every man's own or propre.
Pro, for, before. Pro rostris, at the bar or place of pleding. Pro tribunali,
in the place of judgment. also after or according. Pro Platonis sententia,
according to the sentence of Plato. Pro opere, in the warke. Pro merito,
according to his deserning. Salust. in Iugurt.
Pro curia, before the court. Pro uirili, to my power. Pro sancte Jupiter, O
blessed Jupiter. Vide com.
Pro deum atque hominum fidem, O the faith of god and man. Proanus, my greatte
grandfather. Proauia, my great grandame. Probabile, that which may be proved.
Probatica piscina, a ponde, where sheep are washed. Probatio, a proof.
Probatus, ta, tum, proved. Probe, honestely, well, wisely. Probiter, idem. Vide
com.
Probus, a virtuous man, a good man. Probitas, goodness. Problema, it is, a
sentence purposed, having a demand thereto annexed. Probo, are, to prove, to
praise, to approve. Proboscis, dis, a long snowre, as an Olyphant or swyne
has. Probro, are, to reproach or rebuke. Probrosus, a, um, reprochefull.
Probrum, a reprocheful act. Also a reproach or rebuke, an infamy. Procax,
procacis, malaperte in asking, or desiring, shameless, wanton in craving, ill
tounged. Procacitas, malapertnes, or wantonness in asking or crauynge.
Procare, to wowe, to crave, to be ymportunate. Procapis, a progeny, which
comes of one head. Procaciter, malapertely, wantonly, without shame.
Procalo, are, to call one to. Procatum, and procitu^, void, or of none effect.
Procedo, cessi, cedere, to go forth, to proceed, to prosper. Procella, a
storm. Proceleumaticus, a foot in meter of four feet short. Procello, ere,
to streeke, to turn up so down Procellosus, a, um, stormye. Procensu, the
company or felowshyppe of young men in the city, as we behold in London the
Bachelors together, when the Mayre takes his oath. Proceres, the heed men of a
town. Procerus, a, um, long, talle. Proceritas, length, tallness.
Proceriter, an aduerbe, which sygnifyeth long, or of length. Proceritus,
rita, tum, incensed or provoked with an ill spirit, mad or wood. Plautus in
Penulo.
Proceriti lapides, vengeable. Procerto, surely. Procet, for prouocet, let him
provoke, let him appeal. Processus, us, process or success. Procestrium, a
galerye to goo from oone chamber to an other. Also the ouermoste part of the
walls within the imbattylmentes, where men may go: some do call it a
trenche before the camp, in defense thereof from artyllery. Prochyta, an I Will in
the sea, in the gulf or rode of Puteolis, a city in Campania. Procidentia
any, when the bone of the fundement appears out. Procido, dear, to fall down
prostrate. Perottus.
Procico, ere, to provoke or call from far of. Procicta classis, a navy p^parid
ready to fight Procinctus, tus, the prouysyon before that any thing is done.
Procingo, xi, gere, to prepare, to make ready. Procinctus, ta, tum, ready,
prepared. Procino, cinui, nere, to pronounce in singing, to sing out. Procio,
ciui, ire, to ask. Procito, tare, to provoke. Proclamo, are, to cry out, to
proclayme. Procliue, redily, easily in doing. Procliuis, ue, ready to fall,
inclyned. Alsoo ready or easy to be done. Procliuitas, tatis, inclynation to
evil. Proclus, a noble philosopher of the sect of Plato. Proco, and procor,
ari, to ask malapertely. Also to dalye with wanton language, to eye or behold
a woman wantonly. Proconsul, lis, he that was sent with an extra ordinary
power of Consul into a prouynce of the Romans. Procrastinatio, a delay.
Procrastino, nare, to prolonge the time, to defer. Procreo, are, to bygette
chylderne. Procreatus, ta, tum, begotten. Procubitor, toris, he that kepethe
watch and ward without the camp. Procubo, bare, to watch. Procudo, dear, to
stryke or beat a thing. to make it less or thynner. Qu. Curti. Ti. Liuius.
Procul, far of, from far. Procul urbem, far from the city. Procul
muros, far from the walls. Proculco, care, to tread down. Proculdubio, out
of doubt, doubtless. Perottus.
Proculeio, ere, to extend, to promise. Proculiunt, old writers used for
promittunt, they promise. Pom. Fest.
Proculus, he that is borne when his father is far out of the country.
Procumbo, cubui, cumbere, to lie flat or prostrate, to come narowe together.
Procuro, rare, to do or solicit an other man's business, to inserche
dylygentely, to help or sustain, or succor. Procuratorius, ia, um,
pertaynyng to a proctour or factour. Procurator, to^is, a proctour, a factour.
Procuratio, mynystration of things concerning an other man. Procurro, rere,
to run far, or beyond. Procuruus, ua, um, very crooked. Procus, a wower, to
have a womanne in marriage, but most proprely where there be two, which woweth
every oone for him self. Procyon, a sterre called the Doggesterre, which
appears in the canycular days. Prodeo, diui, uel dij, to goo forth or out of
a house, to come before one. Prodigium, a thing seldom seen, which
sygnifyeth, that sum thing shall happen veraye good or veraye ylle, as
blasynge sterres, fyres, or fygures in the fyrmamente, things monstruouse or
against nature. Prodigo, digere, to lasshe out money in vain, or in things
not necessary. sometime to signifye sum strange thing to happen. Prodigus,
prodigal, wastefull, an outrageous expender. Prodo, didi, dear, to forsake, to
differe, or put of, to cast forth, to put out or far of, to show or
disclose. also to differ, to spread, to betraye. Prodere memoriae, to leave in
remembrance. Also to write. Prodire obuiam, to go against one, or to go to mete
with one, which is coming. Prodire in publicum, to goo abroad, to go in the
streets. Prodico, dixi, dicere, to speak more or prate. Quamobrem excutiemus
omnes istorum delitias, omnes ineptias, si prodixerint, Cicer. pro Caelio.
Wherefore we will set forth al these men's pleasures and fantasyes, if they
will prate any more. Prodigalitas, prodygalytie, or outragyouse expenses.
Prodige, excessyuely, outragiously, prodigally, wastefully. Prodigialis,
digiale, that which pertayneth to the procuryng of strange tokens or signs.
Prodigiator, he that by strange tokens or signs, tellethe before what shall
afterward happen. Prodigiosus, sa, sum, that which makethe strange signs or
tokens. Prodigitas, prodygalitie. Prodimentum, a treason or betrayenge.
Prodinum, for prodiunt, used of Ennius, to issue or come forth. Prodius,
further in. Proditio, treason. Proditor, toris, a traitor. Terent. in Hera^.
Prodere uitam, to put his life in danger. Prodromus, he that rounneth before,
as a lackey, or he that bring the tidings of ones coming. Prodromi, he also
sterres in heaven, the which do rise in the North east.viii. days before the
canicular days. Produco, duxi, ducere, to prolonge, to bring forth, to
consume or spend. Producere aliquem falsa spe, Vergilius.
to hold or keep one in a fools paradyse, to put forewarde: also to follow.
Productilis, le, that which is made out at length with beatynge. Producere, to
set forth to hyre. Audientem dicto matter produxisti filiam, Thou being her
mother, Pl^utus in A^^nar.
and she being obedient unto the, thou haste set her to hyre. Producere
filios, to begette chylderne. Productio, the making of a thing long.
Producte, an aduerbe, signifies long. Productus, ta, tum, made long or set
out at length. also brought or put out. Proaedifico, care, to build.
Proaedificatum, that which being a private place, is made commune or publyke.
Profanatum templum, the church suspendyd, where any horrible crime is therein
committed. Profano, are, to convert things being hallowed to a temporal use.
Varro.
Profanus, na, number, that which is not hallowed, temporal, men unlearned, and
that do hate learned men. Also that which is joined or annexed unto the temple.
Profari, to pronounce, to speak abroad. Ci. de ^el in civilly.
Profectio, a passage or. setting forth toward a vyage, a departing from
the place, where a man is. Profecto, in very deed, for sothe. Pil. in epis.
Profectum facere, to profit or goo forth, proprely in study and learning.
Profectus sum, the pretertence of proficiscor, I went. Profectus, tus,
profit. Profero, tuli, far, to bring forth, to show forth, to pronounce,
to enlarge, or dylate, Plautus in Ca^^na.
or make greatter, to prolonge. Profere dolum, to put a disceit in experience.
Profere gradum, to make have in going. Profesti dies, warkedays. Proficio,
sicere, to profit, to proceed. Ci. de sen^ctute, and de amicitia.
Proficiscor, cisci, to go and to come. Profireor, to promise openly, to tell
frankly or boldly. Also to tell or declare, how much a man has of money,
cattal, corn, Plautus in capt. Ci. de am^.
or any other thing. Also to speak or auaunt, Also to discover or confess a
thing. Also to read openly a lesson. Professio, an open confession, an open
redynge or lecture. Professor, oris, a reder in open schools. Profligo, gare,
to overthrow, to drive away, to bring to destruction, to put to flyghte.
Profligatus, ta, tum, overthrown, driven away, put to flight, distroyed.
sometime it signifies finished, brought to a point. Profligo, gis, gere, to
strive much. Proflubeo, ui, ere, to run out. Profluens, it is, a river: being
a participle, is signifies flowynge. Profluo, xi, ere, to run out of a
thing, to run from far. Profluuium, a flyre or laske. Profluus, a, um,
that which flows. Profore, to profit. Quae nocuere sequar, Horatius.
fugiam quae profore credam, That which has done harm will I follow: and
eschew will I those things, which I believe should profit me. Profugio, gere,
to fly far. Profugium, a place, whereto a man flyethe for succor. Profugus,
he that gothe far out of his own country. Profunda auaritia, insaciable
auaryce. Salust. in Iugur^.
Profunda cupido, insaciable couetyse. Profunda libido, insacyable lecherye.
Profunditas, depenesse. Profundo, iudi, fundere, to poor out largely, to
spend excedyngely. Profundus, da, dum, deep, sometime high. Profusus,
exceeding lyberall. Progener, ri, the husband of my dowghters dowghter, or
sons dowghter. Progentes, progeny, succcession in blood. Progigno, nere, to
get a child. Prognare, openly. Prognariter, hardyly. Festu^
Prognatus, ta, tum, begotten. Plautus in Penulo.
Prognosis, prescience, or knowledge before that a thing happens.
Prognosticon, a pronostication. Progredior, grederis, gressus sum, gredi, to go
forth. Progressus, sa, sum, passed over. Progressus, us, a marchynge forth,
or passing forth. Progressio, the same. Progymnasma, an assay or proof in
exercise. Prohibeo, bui, bear, to prohibit, to forbid, to turn away.
Proiecta, the over parts of a house, which do lean outward from the neither
part, as they be now in some rownes toward the streets: some men do call the^
garrettis. Proiecta audatia, fool hardynesse. Proiectare aliquem probris, to
rebuke one. Proiectitius, a, um, a child cast forth and nouryshed of a
stranger. Proiectura, a penthowse to conuaye rain from the walls. Proiectus
puer, a child which is laid abroad in the street, no man knowing who is the
father or mother. Proiectus, proiecta, iectum, thrown or cast out afar.
Proiectus ad audendum, foolehardy. Proijcio, ieci, ijcere, to throw or cast,
to set forth, to leave, to extend or hold out a thing at length. Proin,
therefore. Salustius in (...).
Proinde, therefore, wherefore, like as. Prolabor, beris, by, to slide or slyppe
forth. Prolambo, bear, to lycke. Prolatio, an extendynge forth. Also
pronouncyng, or pronunciation, sommetyme bringynge forth or showing of a
thing. Prolatare, to defer or purre of, until a longer ryme. Prolatus, ta,
tum, set forth, brought forth. Prolectibilis, le, that which tickleth or
plesantly moves one. Prolepsis, a figure in speaking, where we do preuente,
to dissolve by reason that, which we think to be in the opinion of our
adversary, or of the judge. Proles, issue or fruit of a man's body. Also of
a beast. Proletarii, among the Romans were they which for poverty were not
able to goo to the wars: and therefore they were left at home to get
chylderne. Prolibo, are, to taste, or to sacrifice before. Prolicio, prolexi,
olicere, to induce or draw. Eius amor cupida^ huc me per tenebras prolicit,
Plautus in Curcul.
The love of him has drawn me hither in the dark, being desirous of his
company. Prolixe, lyberally, abundantly, at length. Prolixo, lixare, to make a
thing sharp in length. Quare magnopere mouendus putator est, Colum. 5.
ut prolixet acie^ ferramenti, and qua^tum possit, nouaculae similem reddat,
wherefore the cutter of the vine ought to be warned, that he make sharp in
length the point of the instrument, and as much as he may, that he make it
like to a raser. Prolixus, a, um, long, large, sometime ^^perfluous.
Prolixitas, and prolixitudo, length, largenes. Prolocutio, the first speech or
first entree into communication. Plautus
Prologium, idem. Prologus, a prologue. Prolongo, are, to prolonge, to defer.
Proloquium, the beginning of an oration or sentence. Fest^
Proloquor, queris, qui, to speak at length, to tell a long tale. Also to
speak before, to speak that which we think, to declare our opinion. Proludo,
dear, to flourysshe, as musytians do, before they come to the principalle
mattier: and as fence men do with the sword or the two handstaffe. Prolugeo,
xi, gere, to mourn longer than has been accustomed. Proluo, ere, to wasshe
much, to drown or surrounde. Proluuies, the fylthe or ordure, which is
washed of any thing. Proluuium, idem. Also prodigality. Promellere, to
promote or set forth suit^ in the law. Promercalia, things set forth to be
sold, specially that which is sold by retaylle. Promercale aurum, gold
sold in such wise, that besides the just value, so much gold remains to
the seller, as may serve to his propre use, as our nobles and royalles sold
beyond the sea at a greatter price than they be valewed at here in this
royalme. Promercor, caris, cari, to bie things good cheap, to the intent to
sell them dear, to bye at the first hand, to sell them at retail. Promereo,
rui, rere, to deserve. Promereor, reri, idem, Also to bind oone by his acts
to do for him. Also to help, to profytte. Promereri de aliquo, to do a man a
good turn. Promerens, it is, he that does pleasure or service. Plautus in
As^ua^.
Promerenti optime hoccine preth redditur? He that has done very good
service, shall he have this reward for his labor? Promeritum, deserte.
Promeneruar, old writers used for monet, Fest^^.
he exhorts or warns. Prometheus, he that first found and taught astronomy
in Assiria, and also the craft to make images of earth. Promieo, are, to extend
or set out at length. Promiuenter, at length. Prominentia, the extendynge or
setting out at length. Promineo, nui, nere, to appiere far of. Festus.
Promiscam, old writers did use for promiscue. Promisceo, cui, feere, to
mengle together. Promiscue, one with an other, myxte. Promiscuus, scua, scuum,
confused, myngled one with an another. Promissa batha, a long berde. Promise,
long, in length. Promissio, a promise. Promissor, he that promyseth.
Promissum, a promise. Vide co^p.
Promitio, mist, mittere, to promise, to let grow in length. Also to
thretten. Promo, prompsi, mere, to speak out, to tell, to take out of a coffer
or other like thing. Promontorium, a mountain or high place of a land or
country, which lies as it were an elbowe into the sea ward. Promptaria
cella, a prison from whens men be brought to be whipped or hanged. Promptarius,
a, um, that from whens any thing is brought or taken: Promptarium, and
promptuarium, a stoorehowse. Prompte, promptly, redylye. Promptior, more
prompte or ready. Promptitudo, promptness. Plautus in ^acch. and in Ps^udolo.
Prompto, tare, to bring often forth. Promptus, ta, tum, prompte, redye to
do a thing without tarseng. also ready. Promptum ingenium, A redye wit. Res
est in promptu, The thing is ready. also manyfeste. In promptu res est, The
thing is manyfeste. Promul^o nauis agitur, the ship is drawn with a boat.
Promulgator, and promulgatrix, he or she that does publyshe a thing.
Promulgo, gare, to publyshe. Promulgatio, a publycation. Promul^is, idis, Mede,
made with water and honey. Promurale, a countermure, one wall without out an
another. Promus, he that has the keeping of the stoorehouse or dry larder.
Pronepos, poris, and proneptis, my sons or daughters son or daughter.
Prone, redyly* Pronis, old writers used for prona, prostrate or on the
ground. Pronomen, a pronowne. Pronuba, she that attends on the bryde, and is
housewyfe during the feast. Pronabo, nupsi, pronubere, to have a rule in
weddinges or ioynynge of couples. Pronubus, he that leads the bryde home to
her husbands house, and has the surueyenge of the house, during the time of
the solemnisation. Pronubus, he that does celebrate the solemnity in marriage,
it may be now taken for the priest, which does mynister the solemn words
of matrimonye. Pronuntiat^o, a pronunciation or utterance of speech.
Pronuntiatum, a statute. Plautus in Trin.
Pronuntio, are, to pronounce, to declare openly, to give sentence, to say.
Pronuper, long agone. Pronurus, the wife of my sons son, or daughters
son. Pronus, ready, inclyned, stowpinge down, nygh hand. Prooemium, a
proheme or beginning of a marrier. Propago, gare, to sprede as a tree does on
the top, to make to spread, to send far of. Propagatio, a spreadynge.
Propages, a long rewe. Propago, ginis, an old vine spread in many branches.
Sometime it sygnifyeth kind or generation. Propalam, openly, clearly in the
syghte of all men. Propalo, lare, to tell abroode, to grow in length.
Propatruus, my great grandfathers brother. Propatulum, wide open. Prope, nygh,
almooste. Propediem, now every day, shortly. Propello, propuli, pellere, to
drive or put away, far of. Propemodum, almost. Propendere, to hang up.
Prope^ndere, to examyne or consider far of. Propensus, inclyned. Propere,
quyckely, hastily. Properatim, quyckely. Properanter, and properiter, idem.
Properantia, and properatio, an approchyng. Catullus.
Properitas, the same among old writers. Properus, a, um, quycke, sudden.
Propero, rare, to go quyckely or hastily, to say or do any thing quyckely or
hastily. Festus.
Propetro, trare, to command that a thing be done. Prophasis, an excuse.
Proplieris, and prophetissa, a womanne prophet. Propheto, tare, to prophesye,
to sing praises to god: sometime it signifies to preach or interpret.
Propheta, a prophet, he that tells things, which shall happen. Prophetia,
a prophecye. Propilo, are, to make sharp before. Propina, a place by the
commune baynes, where after baynynge men took their refection. Propino,
propinare, to drink to an another manne, to quafte, to bring to, Sommetyme to
give. Propino tibi salutem, I salute the. Propinator, a cup bearer.

affynitie, alyaunce. Propinque, nyghe. Propinquior, quius, nerer.
Propitiabilis, le, that which is sone bowed or inclyned to desires.
Propitialis, idem. Propitiatio, sacrifyce to appease or pacyfye goddis
displeasure. Propitium, sommetyme sygnyfyeth very devout or loving. No. Mar.
Propit^^, peasyble men, or men soon appeased or satisfied. Propius, nerrer,
or nerre. Proplastice, ces, the craft to make mouldes, in the which any
thing is cast or fourmed. Propingeon, the place in a bayne or hot house, in
the which fire enclosed, sends forth heat. Propitiatorium, a table set on
the arc of the old testament. Propitio, and propitior, ari, to appease, or to
make merciful, or favorable. Propitius, pitia, tium, appeased, favorable,
mercyfulle. Propior, nerer. Propola, he that sellyth any thing at retayle,
specially vyttayle, a hukster. Propolis, a subburbes of a town. It is also
that which bees do make at the entry of the hyue, whereby cold and other
annoyaunce is defended. Propono, proposui, ponere, to purpose, to be aduysed,
to promise a price or reward for any notable act, to set out to the show.
Propontis, a see between Greece and Asie. Proportio, a proporcyon. Propositio, a
matter pourposed to be dysputed or reasoned. It is also that, whereby we show
generallye, whereof we will speak. Propositum, a purpose. Propraetor, toris,
he that was in the steed of Praetor, or Mayre. Proprie, proprely. Lucretius.
Propritim, idem. Proprietarius, a, um, whereunto the propretie of a thing
belongs. Proprietas, propretie. Proprius, propria, prium, propre. Propter,
for. Sommetyme nyghe. Alsoo at or in. Propterea, therefore. Proptosis, a
disease, where the eyes meuyd with inflammation, do fall out of their
places. Propudium, shame, dishonestie. Alsoo the most abomynable use of
lecherye, in an inconvenient form. Propugnaculum, a fortress, a strong hold.
Propugnator, toris, a defendour. Propugno, are, to fight far of, to syghte
valyauntly, to defend. Propulsator, he that resysteth a thing, or dryueth any
thing away. Propulso, are, to put of, to drive away. Propyleum, a porche.
Proquaestor, toris, he that exercyseth the office of Questor in his absence.
Prora, the foreparte of a ship. Prorepo, prorepsi, prorepete, to creep
further. Proreta, he that has the rule of the foreshyppe or deck. Prorideo,
ridere, to laugh afar of. Proripio, pui, pere, to withdraw or depart. joined
with me or se, Domum se ex curia proripuit, He departed or withdrew him

or delayenge. Prorogo, gare, to prolonge. Prorsus, and prorsum, utterly, always,
in any wise, straight toward a place, surely. Prorsi, lymyttes in boundynge of
lands directed into the east. Prorumpo, rupi, rumpere, to break forth, to
send forth with vyolence, to leap or go out of a place with violence, to
brast out Proruo, ruere, to drive down, or beat down. Prosa, prose, that
which is not meter. Prosapia, a progenye, a dyscente of blood, a petygree.
