shamefullye. Proscribo, scripsi, scribere, to sell openly, to proclayme any
thing to be sold, to banysshe, to condemn. Proscriptio, a condemnation, an
att^yndre. Proscriptus, condemned, attaynted. Proseco, care, to cut a sonder.
Prosecta, bowelles cut in sacrifice. Proseda, a strumpette or commune harlot.
Prosedanum, a disease, which happens to Rams at blysomynge time.
Proselytus, a stranger borne. Prosemino, are, to sow ^urth. Prosequium, an
affection. Prosequor, qui, to follow after, to pursue. Prosequor amore, I love.
Prosequor odio, I hat^. Prosequor honor, I honor. Prosequor verbis, I ^ha^e
him with words. Prosequor officijs, I show to him great kyndnesse, I do him
many pleasures. Prosequi praemio, to reward. Proserpere, to creape or slide
forth like a serpent. Proserpina, the wife of Pluto. Proseuche, a prayer to
God: alsoo a beggynge. Iuuen. No. Mar.
Proseucha, a beggar. Prosferari, to be optayned. Prosicium, that which is cut
of from any thing, and cast away. Prosilio, lij, lire, to leap forth. Pl^*
in epis. (...).
Prosocer, ceri, the father of my wyfes father. Prositum, old wrytars used for
propositum purposed. Prosodia, the craft of accentinge. Prosonomasia, the
likeness of one word or name to another: as locus and lucus, orator, and
arator. Prosopopoeia, where as personages are supposed or feigned to speak, as
one man to an other: a man to a beast: one beast to an other etc. Prospectus,
ctus, a sight far of, a prospecte. Prospecte, aduysedly. Prospecto, spectare,
to behold, proprely far of. Prospere, prosperously. Prosperiter, idem.
Prosperitas, prosperity. Prospica, and Prospicus, he that beholds a thing
far of. Prospices, for prospice, behold. Festus.
Prospiro, are, to fetch breath or wind. Prosper, and prosperus, prosperi,
prospero, that which gives felycitye. Felix, he that receives it.
Prospicientia, prouydence, circumspection. Prospicio, spexi, spicere, to see
far, to foresee, to provide, to beware. Prospicuus, circumspect. Prostasis,
preeminence. Prosthesis, an addicion of a lettre: as gnatus, for natus.
Prosterno, straul, sternere, to overthrow, or to vaynquysshe in battle.
Prostibulum, a commune brothelhouse: also a commune harlot. Prostibula, idem.
Prostituo, tuere, to be a commune harlot. Prostituere pudiciriam, to be commune
to al men or women in the act of lechery. Prosto, tare, to stand far of, or
before: also to stand to be fold or hired. Prosubigo, gere, to dygge deep.
Prosum, fui, desse, to be profitable. Prosumia, a little bark. Prosumirium, a
place without the walls of Rome, where the bysshoppes of the gentyles made
their diuinations, or took their significations of things to come. Prosupero,
are, to excede, or have more than enough. Protasis, a proposicion. Donatus.
Protego, texi, tegere, to defend. Protectio, a defense. Protector, toris, a
defendour. Protentus, ta, tum, stretched out. Protela, lare, to differ, or
tracte the time, to put out, to drive away, to vex. Protendo, dear, to set
forth, or put forth, to stretche forth. Protermino, to incroche. Protero,
triui, ter^re, to trede down. Proterreo, rere, to make aferde far of.
Proteruia, wantonness: it was also a sacrifice, wherein the manner was, that as
much as was left uneaten, should be consumed with fire. Proteruiam fecit, he
has consumed all that is left. Proteruio, ire, to play the wanton. Proterue,
proudely, immoderatly, Plautus in Ruden.
shamefully. Quis est, qui tam proterue, foribus facit iniu^iam: who is he,
that so proudely rappeth at the door? Ecce au^em tu quoque proterue iracundus
es, Lo and thou also art shamefully angry. Proteruiter, idem. Proteruitas,
tatis, pride, folly. Proteus, the son of Occanus, a iugglar, which could
show him self in sundry fourmes. Protestor, staris, stari, to declare
manyfestly. what should be exchued and not done. Protestator, he that
manifestly declares, what is to be exchued and not done. Protestatio, a
protestation. Protina, for protinus, furthwith. Proteruus, a, um, wanton,
malaperte, shameless, and (as I might say) knauysshe* or lewd. Protinus, a
far of* Also forthewith, without taryenge. Prothymia, promptitude: also
gentle entertaynement. Plautus in Seye.
Proh Di immortales quot ego voluptates fero, quot risiones, quot iocos, quot
fuauia, saltationes, blanditias, prothymias? O lord god, how many pleasures
have I, what lawghingis, what pastymes, what bassinges, daunsinges, daliaunces,
and sweet entertaynementes? Prothyrum, a porche at the utter door of a house.
Protipon opus, an image or form, whereof mouldes are made, in the which
things be cast of metal or earth. Protogenes, of the first kynred or
famylyrit was also the name of an excellent paynter. Protocollum, that which
is first made or written, which requires correction. Protogenus, the first
child. Protogenia, the daughter of Deucalion and Pirrha. Protologia, a
preface. Protollo, lere, to prolonge. Protomartyr, the first martyr.
Protomedicus, the chief physician about a Prince. Protomysta, the chief
priest, or deane. Protonotatius, a protonotary, or chief scribe or Secretary.
Protopages, and Protopagus, first made or wrought, or late made. Protoplas^es,
and Protoplastus, first fourmed so was Adam called. Protos, Proton, first.
Prototocos, a woman late bringynge forth her first child. Prototomus, the
stalk which is first cut. Prototypus, and prototypon, the first exe^ple, or
pattern. Protraho, traxi, trahere, to differe or prolonge. Protrepticus, a book
to instruct one, a doctrinall. Protrimenta, meat mynced small. Proueho, uexi,
u^here, to bring or carry further. Prouectus aetate, aged. Prouectum ingenium,
a long proved wit: also to promote, advance. Prouectus ad dignitatem,
promoted or advanced to honor. Prouectus aetate, run far in years.
Prouectus, ta, tum, promoted. Prouectus, aged. Prouenio, ire, to come forth:
alsoo to grow or increase, Plautus in Menech.
to happen or chance. Nimis prouentum est nequiter, It is ungraciously
chanced. Prouentus, tus, revenues, yearly profytes. Proverb, diligently.
Prouerbium, a proverb. Provide, circumspectely. Prouideo, dear, to provide, to
foresee, to beware. Prouidentia, providence, foresight: Cice. and Quint.
sometime it is used for god. Prouidus, provident, circumspect. Prouinciae, were
countrayes, which the Romans gate far from Rome, where only their officers
did rule. Prouincia is sometime taken for the rule or autoritye of an officer:
also an office, alsoo for a countraye or royaulme. Prouincialis, he that
dwells in a province. Prouinciatim, from countray to countray, or one
countraye with another. Prouiso, prouisere, to see or behold, to goo to see.
Prouidens, uidentis, foreseynge, provident. Prouidentior, dentissimus, more
provident, most provident or circumspect. Prouocator, he that provoke one,
or he that appeleth, the appellant. Prouoco, care, to call from a far, to
stere, to inuit, to provoke, to exhort, also to appele to an higher judge.
Prouocatio, an appele to an higher court. Prouolo, are, to fly away, or
beyond, also to run from aferre. Prouoluo, uere, to roll or tumble a
great stone or other like thing: sometime to lie down prostrate. Prout, for
Sicut, as, Proxeneta, a brokar. Festu^
Prox, of old wrytars was taken for Proba vox, a good voice or noise. Proximo,
proximare, to approach or draw nyghe. Proxim^rium, a place without the
walls, ioyninge to the city, where bysshoppes did assemble in their
conuocations. Proxime, next. Cato.
Proximi, for proximo: die proximi, the next day. Proximitas, nyghenesse,
neyghbourhede. Proximior, more nere. Proximus, a, um, next. Prouulgo, aui,
are, to publysshe, or declare openly to the people. Prudenter, wisely. Prudens,
prudentis, wise, prudente, knowing. Prudentia, wisdom in desiringe and
exchuynge of things. Prugnum, old wrytars used for Pronum, prone or apt.
Pruina, frost. Pruna, a burning cole. Prunioli, small mussherons. Pruinosus,
a, um, frosty. Prunerum, an orcharde set with damlyne trees, or plumme trees.
Prunus, a damlyne tree or plumme tree. Prunum, a ^syne, prune, plumme, slo, or
bullase. Prurio, rij, rire, to yche. Pruritus, rus, ychinge. Prutigo, gli^^s,
ychinge with a delectation, as in the sterynge of lechery. Prusias, a king of
Bythin^a, unto whom Hanniball fled after that he was banysshed from
Carthage. Prymnestus, a post or stake, where unto the cabull of a ship is tied.
Prymnos, a nymphe or maiden of the sea, one of the dawghters of Oceanus.
Prytaneium, a counsel house. Prytaneia, a counsel assembled of great of
fleers and iuges. Prytanis, the president or chief of the counsel.
P. ANTE S.
PSallo, li, lere, to sing. Psalmodia, a diverse or mixed song. Psalmus, a
song proprely to god, or of God. Psalterium, an instrument like to a harp,
also the Psalms called the Psalter. Psaltes, a singing man. Psaltrix, tricis,
and Psaltria, a singing woman. Psecas, adis, a drop. Psegma, the pouldre or
dust, which comes of the fylynge of brass. Psellus, the name of an old
writar, which wrote of diete. Psephisma, atis, a decree. Psephopecta, an
auditour or caster of account. Pseudoadelphus, a counterfayt brother.
Pseudoangelus, a false messager. Pseudolus, a false servant. Pseudo martyr, a
false witness. Pseudoprophera, a false prophet. Pseudothyrum, a faulse
posterne. Pseudo, false or countrefait: and every other nowne joined therewith,
is thereby made false or countrefayt: as Pseudopropheta, a false or countrefayt
Prophet. Ps^lotrum, an oynement to take away hears. Psimmithium, that which
we do call Ceruse or white led. Psitta, a fysshe, which we call a playce.
Pstracus, a popyn^ay. Psycolutres, he that delyteth to bathe in cold water.
Psycomantium, a place where Nigromance is do call up spirits. Psora,
scabbydnesse* Psylli, people in ^ibia, whose bodies are v^enyme to se^ pe^e^:
and they also do cure the slyngynge and poysonynge of serpents by soukynge the
place, which is venymed.
P. ANTE T.
PTe, a syllable joined oftentimes to the ablatyne case, as meapre, tuapte,
suapte, mine own, thine own, his own. Pteris, fern. Pteromata, great
arches over the roofes made like wings. Pretigium, a little skin, which
grows from the corner of the eye, and keuereth the sight: it is alsoo a
grief under the fore part of the nail, when the flesh goes from the nail
with pain. Pterna, the lower part of a sail. Ptisana, the water, wherein barley
is soden, also barley husked, or excorticar, also frume^ty made of barley. Ptyas,
adis, Pli. 28*
an adder having the color green, drawing toward the color of gold.
Ptynge, a rauenouse bird, which takes his pray by night: and sometime
fyghteth with the Egle so valiantly, that in crab bynge together, they fall
both down to the ground, and are taken by Shepehardes. Ptysis, is spettyll:
it is alsoo an exulceration or soore in the lunges, with a consumpcyon of all
the body, and spettynge of blood. Ptisanarium, a mortar, wherein barley is
brayed. Ptochotrophia, an hospital for beggars, a spyttell house. Ptolomeus,
the name of kings of Egypt. Ptosis, ruy^e, also the case of a nowne.
Ptolemais, maidis, the name of a city.
P. ANTE V.
PVbens, he that is between a young man and a boy, of the age of.xiiii. years.
Puberesco, scere, to grow as a child does toward man's stare. Pubeo, es,
and Pubesco, ere, to begin to have a bearde benethe: sometime to spring, as
herbs done. Puber, beris, and Pubes, beris, a young mosy bearde, which
spryngeth in the nether parts of a man at.xiiii. years of age* of a woman at
younger years, wherefore a man or woman at those years is called Pubes: sometime
youth, or a multitude of young men: also the privy parts of the body: also
being an adiectif, it signifies young or tender. Pubertas, the young age of
men and women, when they begin to be apt unto generation: it is also the
first coming forth of bears about the pryucy members. Publicani, were they
which took in ferme of the people of Rome the rentes and revenues due to the
city at a rent certain. Publica sacra, sacrifice done for the people. Publica
fides, a saulfe condute, a general license. Publicanus, a fermour. Public,
and Publicitus, openly in the face of the world. Sumptus public dati, his
expenses borne of the city or town. Publicola, a fauorar of the people: the
which name was given to Valerius, which was one of the first consules of
Rome. Publico, care, to publysshe, to manifest, to make openly known.
Publicum consilium, the commune counsel. Publicus, ca, cum, commune, but more
proprely, public, that is to say, pertaining to every state of the people
jointly and severally: See the true definicion thereof in my book called the
Governor. Publipor, poris, Publius boy, or servant. Publius, the name of a
Roman. Pucinum vinum, wine growing nyghe to the gulf of Venice. Pudefio,
fis, fieri, to be asshamed. Pudenda, the pryuy members. Pudens, it is, shamefast.
Pudenter, with shamefastness, basshefully. Pudeo, dui, dear, to be asshamed.
Pudet, pudebat, puduit, puditum est, to be asshamed. Pudibunde, shamefaslly.
Pudibundus, da, dum, shamefast. Pudice, chastely, honestly. Pudicitia,
chastytye, clennesse of living. Sylustius in Cat.
Pudicitia^ habere, to be violated in the act of lechery. Cicer. pro Flac.
Puditum, asshamed. Nonne esset puditum, si hanc causam agerent severe? had it
not been a shame, if that they had pursuyd that matter rigorously? Pudicus, ca,
cum, chaste. Pudor, doris, a moderacion that lets the mind, that it do not
any thing wantonly, or dishonestly, shamefastness, to say or do any thing
dishonest. Puella, a wenche, in Cambrige shyre they call her a modder.
Puellaris, re, childisshe. Puellascere, to wax young again, to be maydenly.
Puellus, a little child, a babe. Puer, a child, a boy: also a servant.
Puerilis, puerile, of a child, chyldysshe, or boyisshe. Puerilitas, a chyldes
act, chyldysshenesse, boyishenesse. Pueritia, chyldehode. Puerpera, a woman
that lies in of child. Puerperium, the time of a womanne to travail of
child, sometime the child, also the birth. Pugil, a champyon. Pugillaris, and
Pugillare, pluraliter Pugillares, a pair of tables to write in. Pugillatorius
follis, a ball filled only with wind, which is stryken with a man's fiste, and
not with the palm. Pugiunculus, a short daggar. Pugillatus, wrastlynge with
colars. Pugillus, a handful, in gatheringe of herbs or other like thing.
Pugio, onis, a daggar. Pugna, battle, the act of lechery: also an assault, a
disceyte. Pugnaciter, valyauntly in battle. Pugnator toris, a fightar. Pugnax,
nacis, a great fightar. Pugnatior, and Pugnacissimus, more or most fightinge.
Pugnicula, a skyrmysshe. Pugnitatiola, idem. Festus. No. Mar.
Pugnitus, in battle. Pugno, are, to fight. Pugnus, a fyst. Vide (...)
Pulcher, chra, chrum, fair, strong, good, talle. Pulcherrime, most
beautyfully. Pulcherrimus, a, um, fairest. Pulchralis, le, fair. Pulchre, an
aduerbe, signifies fair, (...)
beautyfully, well fauoredly: sometime valiauntly, also wisely: sometime it is
put for valde. Ac dum accubabam, quam videbar mihi esse pulchre sobrius,
Terent. (...) Eunuch^.
And when I laid me down, I thought my self to be very sobre. Pulchellus, a
fair little one. Pulchellus puer, a fair little boy. Ci. ad (...)
Pulchtior, oris, and Pulchrius, fayrer. Pulchritas, beautye. Pulchreseo,
scere, to be fair. Pulchritudo, dinis, beaultye, tallness of personage.
Pulegium, an herb called Penny royal. Pulex, licis, a flee. Pul^einus, a, um,
of a flee. Pulicosus, a, um, full of flees. Pullarius, the keeper of chykens.
Pullarus, a wesyll or Stote, which kylleth chyckens. Pullaster, a young
chycken. Pullatio, hatchynge of chyckens. Pullatus, a mourner. Sometime a man
in poor apparayle, sometime rude, vnlernid. Pullesco, scere, to spring or
burgen. Pullicenus, a new hatched chycken. Pullicies, a bringing forth or
hatchynge of chyckens. also the folynge of coltes. Pulligo, ginis, blackenesse.
Pullinus, na, number, of a colte. Pullini dentes, coltes tethe, which be first
cast. Pullulatio, a spryngynge forth of a thing in growing. Pullulasco,
scere, to bourgen. Pullulo, lare, to spring, to come up young. Pullus, young,
tender, in all kind lyuinge. also a colte or fool, also a chycken. Pullus, a,
um, russette, sometime black, but rather puke color, between russet and black.
Pulmentarium, potage made with flesh or fyshe, as forced gruell, or coleyse.
Pulmentum, gruelle. Pulmo, the lunges or lyghtes. Pulmonarius, he that is
disesid in the lu^ges. Pulmonaria, an herb called Lungworte. Pulmonia, be
certain apples, which be called in some place a hundred shyllingis. Pulpa, a
little synewe like to a vain. Pulpamentum, a delycate dyshe or meat.
Pulpitum, a hault pace or pulpyte. Pulls, a meat made of meal, water, honey,
cheese, and eggs. It may be taken for potage. Pulsatiles uenae, the poulses
of a man or womanne. Pulsatus, ta, tum, stricken as a harp or other
instrument is, which has strings. Pulsim, as a thing were stryken. Pulso,
are, to beat, to stryke, to hurt, to play on a harp, or other like
instrument. Pulsare hostium, to knock at the door. Pulsus, the wreste of the
arm, whereto the had is joined* but it is more proprely the poulse or stroke
that the arteries or beatyng veins do make, whereby the strength or debilitie
of the syckenes is known in touching them. Pultarius, a potage dyshe. Pulto,
tare, to beat at a door. Pulticula, a little potage. Pultiphagi, and
pultiphagonides, greatte eaters of potage. Puluero, rare, to lay with doust, to
be dusty. Pulueresco, scere, to be turned in to poulder or duste. Puluerius,
a, um, of poulder or duste. Puluerulentus, ta, tum, full of duste. Seruius.
Pulueratio, a layenge of fine earth about vynes. Puluinar, a bolstar of a
bed. also a bed which was wont to be made in temples, as it were for the
goddis. It is taken sometime for a temple. also a tabernacle, wherein an image
stands. Puluinatus, ta, tum, soft as a pyllowe. Puluinus, a pyllowe, sometime
a fetherbed, also a cusshyn, also a bed of herbs in a gardeyne, also
grauelle, also an engyne, wherewith ships are brought into the docke.
Puluis, ueris, powlder, duste. Puluisculus, fine powder or duste. Pumex, micis,
a pomeyse to make parchemente smoothe, also to take clean out spots or
letters. Pumico, care, to pomeyse. Pumicosus, a, um, like a pomeyse. Pumigatio,
pomeysynge or polyshynge. Pumigatus, ta, tum, pomaysed, or polysshed. Pumilis,
little in stature. Pumilio, onis, and pumillus, a dwarf, or any thing
little in stature. Punctim, foynynge. Punctus, seu punctum, a point or title.
Punctus temporis, a moment, the leest part of time. Pungo, pupugi, pungere, to
prycke. Vide co^p.
Punicus, a, um, of Africa. Punicus, aut puniceus color, read. Punicum malum,
a pomegranate. Punio, iui, ire, to punyshe. Punitio, punyshement. Pupa, a young
wenche, a gyrle, a modder. it is also a poppette, like a gyrle. Pupilla, the
balle or apple of the eye. Pupillaris aetas, the noueage of him that is in
ward. Pupillus, he that is in ward, or within age not able in years to
occupye his propre land. Also he that has no father alive. Puppes, and
puppis, the foreparte or deck of the ship. Pupus, a young child, a baby.
also a poppette or image like a child. Pupugi, the pretertence of purgo, I
have pricked or pounched. Pure, purely. Puriter, idem. Purgamen, seu
purgamentum, fylthe, which comes of any thing that is cleansed. Purgatio, a
purgation or purging. Purgo, gare, to make clean, to purge. also to excuse.
Vide co^p.
Purifico, to puryfye, or make pure. Purificatio, a purifyenge. Purime, old
wrytars used for purissime, most purely. Puritas, tatis, pureness, cleanness.
Puro, tare, to make pure. Purpura, a Purple, which is a shell fysshe. whereof
purple color comes. sometime it signifies a garment of purple. Purpurarius,
a, um, pertaining to purple color. Purpurasco, scere, to be of purple color.
Purpurissum, idem quod purpurissa. Purpureus, a, um, of purple color.
Purpuratus, apparayled in purple. Purpurati, be the noble men of a Royalme,
called peers. Purpurissa, read payntynge, wherewith harlottes do paynt their
vysages. Purpurisso, are, to paynte the visage ruddy. Purulentus, lenta,
lentum, full of matter, or corruption. Purus, ra, rum, clean, pure, fine. Pus,
puris, matter, which comes out of a soore. Pusillanimis, faint hearted,
feeble couraged. Pusillanimitas, faint courage, cowardyse. Pusillanimiter,
cowardly. Pusillus, a, um, little. Pusio, a boy. Pustula, a pusshe or little
wheale. Pusulae, blystars, which do rise on bred wha^ it is baken. Pusum and
Pusam, old wrytars used for Pucrum and Puellam, a boy and a gyrle. Pustulatum
argentum, roughe silver when it is new molten. Putamen, minis, the shale of a
nutte, or paring of an apple or pear. Puteal, the seat of a great offycer,
also the covering of a well. Putealis, and puteanus, a, um, of a well.
Puteanus, a, um, of a pytte or well. Puteana aqua, well water. Putearius, he
that diggeth a pytte or well. Puteo, tui, tere, to stynke. Puteoli, a city in
Campania. Puteus, a well. Plautus.
Puticuli, places where the commune people was buried. Putidus, da, dum,
stynkynge, unsavory, unpleasant. Putilatum aurum, pure or fine gold. Putisco,
scere, to stynke. Putitius, a fool. Vide co^p.
Puto, taui, tare, to cut of or pluck away. that, which is superfluous,
proprely from trees. Also to suppose, to consider, to discuss, to gather, or
confer, to esteem, to judge. Putare rationem, to make account. Putor, toris,
stenche. Putrefacio, to make to stynke. Putreo, tri^i, trere, to wax lean, to
be resolved into stynkynge matter. Vide co^p.
Putresco, scere, to putrifye. Vide co^p.
Putris, tree, corrupt, rotten. Putridus, da, dum, idem. Putredo, dinis,
corruption. Putulentum, stynkynge. Putus, ta, tum, pure, tried, fine. Purum
putum, fined.
P, ANTE Y.
PYcnostylon, a house or place builded, where pylars stand thick together.
Pycta and Pyctes, a wrastler with a cole^ Pyctatium, a table, wherein the names
of Iuges were written. Pygargus, a beast like to a falowe dear: it is also a
bird like to a hawke, having a white tail, I suppose him to be that, which
we call a ryngetayle. Pygmachia, wrastlynge with colars. Pygmachus, a wrastler.
Pygmaei, people between Inde and Cathay, which are but one cubyte long.
Pympleides, the musis. Pyr, fire. Pyra, a bonfyre, wherein deed bodies were
burned. Pyralis, a fly, which comes of the fire, and as long as he is
therein, he lives: and wha^ he is far from it, he dies incontinent.
Pyragmon, one of the names of Vulcanus. Pyrama, a certain rosen. Pyramus, a
young man, which slew him self for the love of a mayde^ called Thisbe^ it is
also a river in Cilicia. Pyramid, midis, a great thing of stone or other
matter, which he is broad beneth, and upward is small and sharp on the top.
Pyratium, a kind of Sydar, called Pery. Pyrausta, a worm living in the fire,
It is also a kind of spyders, which hurts honey combs. Pyrenei montes,
Mountains, which do dyuyde France from Spain. Pyretru^, and pyretra, an
herb callid Pelitory. Pyretus, a burning fever. Pyraeus, an haven at Athenes.
Pyrgobaris, a house builded like a towar. Pyrgoteles, was a cu^nyng grauer in
stones. Pyrgus, in latyne a towar: also a box, out of the which men do cast
dyse, when they play: it is also a certain company of horsemen in battle.
Pyrgus, a box, out of the which dyse are thrown. Pyriasis, a certain
plaster to assuage the burning of a fever. Pyrim, a little kernel. Pyrites,
every stone, out of the which fire may be stricken. Pyrobola, a smythes hammer,
wherewith he beats on hot iron. Pyroboli, arowes or darts, which send
forth fire, when they be shot or cast, and do burn the thing that they
do touch. Pyrobolarij, they which do shoot such darts. Pyrocorax, a
crow with a red bylle. I suppose it to be of the kind, whereof cornyshe
chowghes are. Pyrodes, he that first struck fire out of a flynte. also a stone
of fyry color. Pyromantia, a dyuynation by fire. Pyrrhicha, and pyrrhiches, a
form of dansynge, with much mouynge of the body and gesture, like to them
which do sight in battle. Pyrrhicarij, they that dance in the form of
daunsynge, called Pyrrhica. Pyrrhichius, a foot in meter of two short
syllables. Pyrrhus, in latyne Flauius, sieve Rufus, he that has a ruddy or
fyrye vysage, by the which name the son of Achilles was calledde, and a
king of Epyre was so called, which did make war to the Romans. Pyrum,
a pear. Pyrus, a pear tree. Pythagoras, an excellent Philosopher, whose
Phylosophye was in mystycalle sentences, and alsoo in the Science of noumbers.
Pythagoricus, he that was of the sect of Pythagoras. Pythagorista, idem.
Pythius, one of the names of Apollo. Pythia, thiorum, plays made in the honor
of Apollo. Python, a Dragon, which was slain by Apollo. Pythopolis, a city
in Asye, in that part, which is called Mysia. Pytisma, matis, a spyrtynge
out of small spyttelle. Pyxacantha, and Pyxacanthos, a Berberye tree. Pyxis,
idis, a box. Pyxidicula, a little box, proprely wherein medycines are put.
Pyxidatus, pyxidata, pyxidatum, made like a box.
QVA, which way, by what place. Quada^tenus, unto what part. Quadi, people of
Boeme, or Boemia, which did eat the flesh of horses and wolfes. Quadra, a
trencher, whereon meat is cut: sometime a lofe of breadde cut square.
Quadragenarius, naria, narium, of fourtye years old. Quadragenus, a, um,
fourtye. Quadragena scuta, forty crowns. Quadragesima, Lent. Quadragesimus,
a, um, the fourtyth. Quadragies, fortye times. Quadraginta, fortye.
Quadrangulum, a figure, having four corners. Quadrangulus, a, um, four
cornerde. Quadrans, it is, a certain coin, which we may call a ferthynge: all
be it proprely it is the quarterne of a pound weight. Also it is the sum in
account where the receyte and the expenses do accord. Quadrantal, a figure
square like to a dyse. Also a certain mesure, contaynyng.xlviii. measures,
called Sextarii. Quadrantaria, a harlotte that will company with a man for a
ferthynge. Quadrata statura, a mean or competente stature. Quadratura, a
square. Qudratus, ta, tum, four square. Quadricornium, having four horns.
Quadriduanus, a, um, of four days contynuaunce. Quadriennis, four years
old. Quadriformiter, in a square. Quadrigati, certain coin, having in them
the prynte of a charyotte. Quadrilinguis, he that speaks four sondrye
languages. Quadrinatus, a child of four years old. Quadrilibris, bre, that
which does way four pounds. Quadringentenus, a, um, the four hundredth.
Quadringentesimus, idem. Quadringenties, four hundred times. Quadringentuplus,
a, um, four hundred times so much. Quadripartito, in four parts.

parts. Quadrifidus, da, dum, that which may be slytte in four parts.
Quadriformis, me, that is of four diverse fourmes or facyons. Quadriga, a carte
drawn with four horses. sometime a carte horse. Quadrigarius, a carter.
Quadriiugi, four beasts yoked together. Quadrilaterus, ra, rum, with four
sides. Quadrimembris, of four parts. Quadrimus, and quadrimulus, a child of
four year old. Quadringenta, and quadringenti, four hundred. Quadrinoctium,
four nyghtes. Quadripartitor, tiri, to diuyde in four. Quadriremis, a ship
with four rewes of oores, or with four tops. Quadrisyllabum, of four
syllables. Quadri^^um, where as four ways do meet. Quadro, are, to bring
in square, to consent or agree. Quadrum, a figure four square.
Quadrupedantia, and quadrupedia, four foted beasts. Quadrupedo, dare, to go
on four fete. Quadrupliciter, four manner of ways. Quadruplico, care, to
double four times, or to make a thing four times as much as it was.
Quadr^^bs, a city, unto the which do come, or are brought all the people,
being left in four cities, ^estus
by the which name the city of Athenes was called of Actius the poet.
Quadrus, a, um, square. Quadrupes, quadrupedis, a beast having four feet.
Quadruplatores, were they, which for accusynge of other, had the fourth
part of the goods of them, that were condemned. Quadruplex, four double.
Quadruplo, and quadruplor, ari, to appeache a man for to have part of his
goods. Quadruplum, four times as much. Plautus in capt. Ci in Ver. Ti. Liuius
Quae, the which woman or other female kind. Quae malum, what a myschiefe.

or abuses against the law. Quaesitio, an inquiry, an exai^ation, a search.

Alsoo a Justice by Commyssyon of Oyer and Determyner. Quaestores Parricidij,
Justices to inquere, of treason, or murder. We may call the coroners by that
name. Quaestores urbani, were as the chaumberlaynes of London be now.
Quaestores aerarij, Officers of the Receypte, as the Chaumberers and tellers be
now. Quaestorius, quaestoria, storium, pertaynyng to the receypte.
Quaestorium, was such a place as the eschequer is. Quaestor aerarij, a
general receyuour: but it seemethe to be such an offycer, as the eschetour is
now in England. Quaestorius, torij, he that had been in the office of
Questor. Quaestorius, a, um, that pertayneth to the office of Quaestor. Vir
quaestorius, a man, which has been in that office. Quaestuariae arts,
crafts, whereby men do gain money. Quaestuosus, a, um, of much gain,
studyous of greatte lucre. Quaestura, the office of Quaestor. Quaestus, tus,
gain, winning. Qualibet, where it lyketh the. Qualisqualis, what so ever.
Qualiscunque, such as it was. Qualiter, in the facyon or form. Qualis, le,
what, of what quality. Qualitates, qualytyes, as foul, fair, wise,
foolysshe, strong, weak, dylygente, slow. etc. Quallus, a baskette, out of
the which wine runs, when it is pressed: Alsoo a baskette or hamper, in the
which womenne do put their spyndelles, their bottomes of threede, and such
like things. Quam, thanne, Sommetyme after that. Sommetyme before that. Pridi^
quam occideretur, The day before that he was slain. Quam been, how well? Quam
fortiter, how valyauntly. Also it is often joined with the superlatiue degree,
to make it more vehemente: as, Quampaucissimi, As few as may be. Quam
doctissimus, excellentely learned. Sometime it imports as much as veraye. Cum
quo quam familiarissime uixerat, With whom he lived very familyarly. Alsoo it
sygnfyeth as. Duplo accepit quam perdiderat, He received dowble as much as he
lost. Quamlibet, quantumuis, quantu^libet, what so ever. Quammox, as soon,
sodaynely. Quamobrem? wherefore? for what cause? what to do? Quam pene,

greatte sort. Quamplurimus, qua^plurima, quamplurimu^, very much. Quampridem,
long before. Quamprimum, very shortly or soon. Quamuis, and quanquam,

concerning. Quantum intelligo, as far as I understand. Quantum suspicor, as

euentus postea praedictum patuit Iudaei ad se trahentes, rebellarunt, The Jews
gatherynge that of the Emperor, according as the thing, which was before
showed of that which should happen, appeared afterward, made rebellyon.

Terent* in prolo. An.
Nam in prologis scribundis operam abutitur, non qui argumentum narret, sed qui
maleuoli uaeteris Poetae maledictis ^espondeat, For he spendethe his labor in
writing of Prologues, not because he will tell the argument, but for as

Qui enim beatior Epicurus, quod in patria uiuebat, quam Metrodorus, quod
Athenis? Wherefore was Epycure moore happy, that he did dye in his
countreye, than Metrodorus that he dyed at Athenes. Quia, for. Alsoo hit
sygnyfyeth that. Ci. de (...)*
Sed tamen recordatione nostrae amicitiae sic fruor, ut beatae uixisse uidear,
quia cum Scipione uixerim, All be it I take this pleasure in remembrynge our
frendeshyp, that I may seem to have lived most fortunatelye, that I lived in
Scypyones company. Alsoo it sygnyfyeth for as much. Salustias in Catil.
Sed quia multis and magnis tempestatibus vos cognoui fortes, fidosque mihi, eo
animus ausus est maximum atque pulcherrimum facinus incipere, But for as much
as in many great storms or daungiers I have proved you to be valiant, and
faythefull unto me, therefore my heart is bold to begin an excellent and
commendable enterprise. Quia nam, wherefore. Quia ne, in deed. Quias, quiatis,
for cuius, cuiatis. Quias, a, um, for cuius, a, um. Quibus in extremis, for
quorum in extremo. Literae dantur mihi a te, quibus in extremis scriptum est? I
received letters from you, in the last end of the which hit is written.
Quicquid est, all that is, what so ever it be, what so ever. Quicquid
pauxillum, never so little. Plautus in trucule^.
Qui cum, for cum quo. Qui cum loquitur filius? With whom does my son
talk? Quicunque, who so ever. Quicquam, any thing. Quid, What. Quid causae
est? What is the cause? Quid aetatis? How old? of what aege? Quid animi? What
mind? Plautus in mercarore
Quid animi est? What mind is he of? Quid captiuo^um? How many prisoners?
Tum Captiuorum quid ducunt secum? Plautus in Epidico.
Thanne how many prisoners do they bring with them? Quid id sit hominis, cui
Lyco nomen sier? Plautus in praulo. Terent. in Hea^^.
What man is he, whose name may be Lyco? Quid mulleris uxorem habes, What
manner of woman haste thou to thy wife? Quid rei est? What is the mattier. Ibo
intro ut quid husus sit rei sciam: Terent. in Eunucho.
I will goo in, that I may know what the mattier is* Quid rei est tibi cum
illa, What haste thou to do with her? Terent. in Phorm. Plautus in Picudolo.
Quid sententiae? what is his or thyn opinyon? Quid istue uerbi est? what
meanest thou thereby? Also quid is taken for Aliquid, somewhat. Also ob quid for
what, or wherefore. Quid? senem quoad expectas uestrum. Terent. in phormi.
But now? how long will ye tarry for your master? Note here that after the
daily form of speaking, quid is rehearsed, Donatus.
wha^ we pass from one matter to an other. Quid mecum est tibi? what have I to
do with the? Quid faceret aliud? what should he do else? Quid eo, what to do?
Propere curre ad Pamphilum. P. Quid eo? D. Die me orate ut ueniat. Ru^ne
quyckely to Pamphilus. P. what to do? D. Say that I prayed him to come. Quid
uerbis opus est? Plautus.
what need many words? Quid multa uerba, idem. Quid multis moror? what shall
I long tarry? Quid mea refert, Cicero de ^^icitia.
what care I? Also quid signifies wherein. Quid enim indigens Affricanus mei?
wherein had Scipio any need of me? Terent. in Iunucho.
Quid istic? Si certum est facere, facias^uerum ne post conferas culpam in me,
What woldeste thou I should do? If thou be determined to do it, goo to on
goddis name: but afterward put not the fault in me. Terent. in phorm.

Will not thou hold thy peace. Also it sygnyfyethe but yet, or but for all

Also more over, or that moore is. Quin, ipsi pridem tonsor ungues dempserat,
collegir, omnia abstulit praesegmina, And that more is, the other day, the
harbor paryd his nails, he gathered the parings together, and carried them
all away with him. Quincunx, quincuncis, of five ounces. Alsoo the gain of
five in oone hundrede by exchange amongeste Merchants. It was alsoo an order
of setting of trees in a gardeyne or orchard veraye exactelye, that which
way so ever that a man did look, the trees stood dyrectely oone
against an another. Quinarius, a, um, the nombre of five. quinarius lapis, a
stone of five pound weight. Quinarius, narij, was among the old Romans
their half penny, which was five pound weight of brass, called As, It is two
soulces of french money, which is of our money. Quincentum, of old writers
was used for quingentum, five hundred. Quincuntialis, le, of five inches.

Quin ergo, Wherefore then. Quin ergo quod iuuat, quod charu^ aestimant, id

was the name of Romulus, after that he was taken for a god. Quiritare, to cry
out, to stir up the Romans with a cry. Quisnam homo est, what man is that?

and weeds: it is used of Cicero for noughty men, the refuse of all other.

Quo, whyther. Quo abis, whyther go thou? Quo non. Perreptaui vsque omne
oppidum, ad portam, ad locum, quo non? I went all the town about, to the
gate, to the lake, there is no place but that I was in it. Also it signifies
from whense and where. Illuc quaeso redi, Terent. in ^^delph.
quo coepisti, I beseech the turn back again, where thou begannest: Terent.

also, because. Non pol quo quenquam plus amem, aut plus diliga^, eo feci, In

that. Neque enim id feci, quo tibi molestus essem, Nor I did it not, that I

conceditur vti, For what purpose shall fortune serve, if I may not have
commodity by it? Quoaxo, are, to cry like a frogge. Quoad, until, as long.

or master. Nube grauida candicante, quod vocant tempestatem albam, grando

also it signifies but. Quod si quiescem, nihil euenisset mali, But if I had

as much. Cice. Te^
Tu velim, quod cum commodo valetudinis tuae fiat quam longissime poteris,
obuia^ nobis properes: I would that ye, as much as may be with the heithe of
your person, make speed to meet with us, as far from home as ye can. Also
it signifies why. Vergilius in ^uc.
Si ad vitulam spectes, nihil est quod pocula lauds: If thou consyderest the
caulf well, there is no cause why thou should praise so thy pottes. Cice. Ter.
In uiam quod tedes hoc tempore, nihil est, There is no cause why thou should
take thy iournay at this time: Also it signifies wherefore. Hor. in ep.
Quod te per genium, dextramque, Deosque penates obsecro and obtestor, vitae me
read priori: Wherefore I beseech and pray the, for thy good aungelles sake,
and for the love between the and me, and for the saints which be thyn
auouryes, restore me eftsoon, to my first life, or to the state that I was in
erst. Ter. in Eu.
Also it signifies, as to that. Sane quod tibi vir videatur esse, hic nebulo
magnus est. As to that, that thou thynkest him a man, surely he is a stourdy
vagabunde. Quod absque molestia fiat, Cice. Sulp.
so that it be no displeasure unto you. Quare pergratum mihi feceris, si eum in
amicitiam receperis, atque eum (quod absque molestia fiat) si qua in re opus ei
fuerit: Wherefore ye shall do me singular pleasure, if ye take him into your
favor, and (so that it be no displeasure unto you) when need requyrethe, be
good lord or master unto him. Quod quidem, no that. Non nouisti me? P. Plautus
in Epidico.
quod quidem veniat in mentem. Doeste thou not know me? P. No that I remember
me. Quodammodo, somewhat. Ci. de. am^^
Quamobrem vt hi, qui superiores sunt, summittere se debent in amicitia, sic
quodammodo inferiores extollere, Wherefore likewise as they, which are superior
in state or degree, should humble them selfs in frendshyp, so they which are
inferior should advance and set them selfs forewarde. Quodcunque, what so
ever. Quodcunque militum, for quotcunque milites. Vos hortor, Cice. atti.
vt quodcu^que militum contrahere poteritis, contrahatis. I advise you, that as
many soldiers as ye can get, ye gather unto you. Terent. in andria.
Quominus, for Vt non. Si poterit fieri, vt ne pater per me stetisse credat,
quo minus hae fierent nuptiae, volo: If it may be brought to pass, that my
father may believe, that it is not in my fault, that this marriage is not
concluded, I am content. Quomodo, how, by what reason, in what manner, Plautus
in Aulul. Plautus in milite. Plautus in amph.
by what mean. Quomodo tibi res se haber, How is the matter with the? Sed
quomodo dissimulabat? But in what manner did he dissemble? Primulo diliculo
abijsti ad legiones, By time in the morning thou wentest to the army. Amph.
Quomodo? In what manner or facion? also it signifies wherefore. Plautus in (...).
Illa quidem nullu^ sacrificabit. G. Quomodo? quid igitur me volt? She will do
no sacrifyce. G. wherefore? what thing would she than with me? Plautus in (...).
Quomodocunque, how so ever it be. Sed tamen quomodocunque, quamquam sumus
pauperculi, est domi quod edimus: Yet how so ever it be, though we be pour
folks, we have at home somewhat to eat. Quomodoliber, idem. Quondam,
Sometime, ones: signifyenge the time past, Virg.
or time to come. Quondam tua dicere facta Tempus erit: The time shall be ones,
when thine acts shall be declared. Alsoo it is put in the time present.
Vergili.
Quondam etiam victis redit in precordia virtus, Ye, and in them that are
vaynquysshed, sometime good courage eftsoon imbracith their stomakes. Sometime
it signyfyeth allwaye. Vt quondam in stipulis magnus sine viribus ignis, Like
as in stubbyll or holme sire is allwaye great without any puyssaunce. Plautus
in Trin.
Quonam, whyther, Eamus intro, sequere. S. Quo tute agis? C. quonam, nisi
domum. Let us go in, follow me. S. whyther wylt thou go? whyther should I goo
but home to my house? Quoniam, for as much as. Quo officio es? what is thine
office? Quopiam, any whyther. Itut^ne Thais quopiam es? Thais, will thou goo
any whyther? Quoquam, any whyther. Quoque, also. Quoquo, wheresoever. Quoquo
pacto, In any manner of wise. Ter. in A^.
Tum si maxim fateatur, cum amet aliam, non est vtile hanc illi dari: qua
propter quoquo pacto caelato est opus, Than if he utterly confess it, for as
much as he loves another, it were not convenient, that he were married to this
woman, therefore in any manner of wise, this thing must be kept secret. Quoquo
modo, idem. Quo quouersum, seu quoquouersum, every way, on every part. Eius
imperio classem quo quouersum dimittunt, Caes. in. (...).
By his commandment they dyspeched the navy in every part. Rates duplices
quoquouersum pedibus triginta e regione solis collocabat: he let ships
double against the son, thirty feet every way. Quorsum, seu quorsus, apud
Plinium, whyther, to what place, or thing. Quorsum istuc? to what purpose.
Quot, how many. Quota pars, how small a portion. Quotanuis, year by year, every
year. Quotennis? of what age? how old? Quot annos natus, idem. Quotenus, a,
um, how many. Quotidianae forma, Ter. in (...).
a commune beautye or facion, every day seen. Quotidiani sumptus, daily
expenses. Quotidianus, quotidiana, quotidianum, a thing that is or happens
daily or day by day. Quotidie, daily, every day. Quoties, how oftentimes.
Quotiescunque, as often. Quotquot, as many. Quotuplex, how many sorts.
Quotuplus, how much in measure or wayght. Quotus, ta, tum, of what number,
how many, Hora quota est, what is it a clock? Horatius.
Dic quotus es? Tell how many be of you. Quotas aedes dixerit, id ego admodum
incerto scio: How many houses he spoke of, I am not well assertayned, or I
remember not well. Quotusquisque, how many. Quouis, whyther, or to what place
ye will. Quouis genrium, idem. Quousque, how long, how far. Quousque tandem,
how long yet. Qur, and Quor, wherefore. Quum, seu qum, when, in the which.
Quum primum, as soon.
RAbia, old wryt^rs used for Rabies. Rabidus, da, dum, mad or wood, as a
mad dog. Rabies, madness of a dog. Rabiosus, a, um, mad or very angry,
wood angry. Varro.
Rabio, bire, to be mad or wood as a dog. Rabiosulus, a, um, somewhat
mad. Rabula, one which is hasty or wilful, in any cause, jangling, or full
of words. Racemarius, a twygge of a vine, out of the which the grapes do
spring. Racematio, the gatheringe of grapes after that the great clusters be
gathered to make wine, the glenynge of grapes. Racematus, ta, tum, that has
grapes. Racemosus, full of grapes. Racemus, a grape or a cluster of grapes.
Racha, a reprochefull word of Hebrewe, which signifies, thriftlesse,
braynlesse, finally it is a rebukefull word sygnifyenge the extreme ire of the
person that speaks it. Radicitus, from the root, or up by the root,
Radicitus euellere, to pluck up by the root. Radico, care, to root or take
root. Radicula, an herb, the juice whereof is good to wasshe woulle: also a
little root. Radio, are, to send forth beams like the sun. Radius, a beam
of the sun, or other bright sterre, sometime of the eyes: also a rod or
yerde, that Geometricians have to describe lines: also a wayuers shyttell,
wherewith he throws the yern in to the web also the spoke of a wheel, alsoo
an instrument, wherewith measures be shaven: alsoo long olyues or oil beryes.
Radix, dicis, a root. Rado, si, dear, to shave, or make smoothe, to cut or
pull up, to hurt, to rent, to offend, to fatigate. Aures delicatas radere, to
offend or fatigate delicate ears. Radula, an instrument to shave with.
Radulanus, a, um, that which is shaven of, from any thing. Ragadia, and
Ragades, cleftes or choppes in the fundament. Raia, a see fysshe called Raye or
skete. Ralla, a thynne garment. Rallum, the staff, wherewith plowghmen in
tyllynge do put the earth from their share. Ramalis, le, a bowghe. Ramale, a
seryd or deed bowghe. Ramentum, a little piece of any thing. Rameus, a, um,
that which is of a bowgh. Ramex, micis, a kind of rupture, when the bowels do
fall down into a man's coddes: also a rail or bar, which goes overthwart a
pale or a gate. Ramicosus, he that is broken. Ramnus, a white thorn. Ramulus,
and Ramusculus, a little bowghe. Ramus, a bowghe. Rana, a frogge: also a
sickness which does anoy cartell. Rana Scriphia, is a proverb applied to
the^ that can not speak in time convenient. Ranceo, cere, to be moldy or
putrifyed. Rancidus, da, dum, rankled, moldy, or putrifyed: also unsavory, or
unpleasant. Rancidulus, la, lum, a little moldy or putryfyed. Rancor, oris,
rancour, fylth. Randus, in old time was taken for aes, brass. Randuscula
porta, the brason gate. Rantum, in the old time was a quartern^ of a pound.
Ranunculus, a little frogge, or frosshe. Rapa, a plant and root called Rape.
Rapacia, rape leaves. Rapatior, more ravenous or catchinge. Rapacissimus, a,
um, most ravenous. Rapacitas, raueny. Rapaciter, rauenousely. Rapax, acis,
rauenouse. Raphanus, a plant, and root called Radysshe. Rapere aliquem in
ius, to arrest one, or cause him to be arrested to appear before iuges. Rapide,
quickly. Rapidus, a, um, very swift. Rapina, robbery. Rapinator, a robbar.
Varro.
Rapio, pui, pere, to take by violence, have, or fury: also to rauysshe a
woman. Rapo, Raponis, for Rapax. Raptim, hastily. Raprio, violent taking of a
person. Raptus, rauysshynge or deflourynge of a woman. Raptito, rare, to take
often violently. Rapto, to take or draw violently. Raptor, toris, a rauysshour
or vyolente taker. Rapulum, a little rape root. Rapuneulus, a little root,
which is eaten in salutes. Rara auis, a bird seldom seen* whereby is
signified any thing that seldom happens. Rarefacio, cere, to make thynne or
slender. Rarefio, fieri, to be thynne or slender. Rarenter, seldom. Rare^co,
scere, to wax thynne, or not thick grown, to be or happen seldom. Caes. in
co^.
Rari, a sonder, here and there one or a few. Raripilus, la, lum, thynne
heared. Rarior, rarius, more selde. Rarissimus, a, um, seldest. Rarissime,
most selde. Raritas, seldomnesse. Raro, selde, rare. Raro, aui, are, to make
scant or selde. Rarus, ra, rum, selde or not often, thynne, not thick grown or
set. Rasamentum, shauinge or shredes. Rasilis, sile, that may be shaven or
made smoothe. Rasito, tare, to shave often. Rasor, soris, a harbor, or shauour,
alsoo a ^ydler. Rasotius, a, um, pertaining to shauynge. Rasta, a duche mile.
Rastellus, a little rake. Rast^um, and Raster, a rake. Rasura, the shauynge.
Rata^iae naues, lyghters, or wood barges. Rates, it is, are pieces of timber
pynned together, whereon hay or other like thing being laid, they are drawn
on ryuers, as on the great streams of Germany and France is now seen: but they
be communly used and taken for ships, or the side beams of a ship.
Ratiarius, the master of a ship. Ratifico, care, to ratyfye, or confirm.
Ratificatio, a ratification or confyrmation. Ratio, rayson, counsel, purpose,
care, respect, cause, the manner, the way, the form, proportion.
Ratiocinatio, raysonynge. Ratiocinator, oris, a caster of account. Ratiocinor,
aris, to rayson, to gather in argument, to account. Rationabilis, le,
raysonable. Rationale, that which has the use of raison: alsoo that which a
priest wears at mass on his heed, and after puts it back like a hoode.
Rations refer, to yield account. Rationem dare, idem. Plautus in amph.
Terent. in Heau. Ter. in Ad.
Rationem dictare, to account. Ratio de integro ineunda est mihi, I must
find another mean. Rationem subducere, Nunquam ita quisquam been subducta
ratione ad vita^ fuit: quin res, aetas, vsus semper aliquid apportet noui,
There was never man in the order of his life so well aduysed: but that matter,
age and experience brings to him somewhat at that is strange. Ratio constat,
the matter appiereth, or is showed. Rationa^ius, a book of account: also a book
belonging to the counsel of Princes. wherein acts done and to be done are
written: also an auditour. Ratiuncula, a little account or reckoning. Rations
putari, when accomptes be examyned and tried. No. M^r.
Ratare, old wrytars used for Ratificare, to ratify, to confyrme. Ratum
habere, idem. Ratus, ta, tum, stablysshed, confyrmed, supposed. Ratus, a
participle signyfyenge, Supposing. Ratus sum, I supposed. Raua vox, Festus.
a voice that may not be well hard. Raucae, worms, being in the roots of
trees, and cares them. Rauce, horsely. Rauceo, Raucio, cere, to be horse.
Raucesco, scere, idem. Raucus, ca, cum, horse. Raucedo, and Raucitas,
horsenesse. Raudus, a thing unwrought, and vnpolysshed: it was also taken for
aes, brass. Rauenna, a city in Italy. Rauilia, purblynde or dull sighted.
Rauio, are, to be horse. Festus.
Rauis, horsenesse. Rauiscellus, a, um, little broune of color. Plautus.
Rauus, a, um, horse: also Rauus color, a dull or sad color, or broune.
R, ANTE E.
REalis actio, an action concerning the goods. Reapse, in the self or very
thing. Reate, a city in Italy. Reatus, a fault or offense. Rebellare, to
rebel. Rebellis, a rebel. Rebellio, rebellion. Rebito, tare, to return. At
vnum hoc te quaeso, si hue rebiter e Philocrare, vt eius mihi facias
conueniendi copia^. But one thing I pray the, if he return from
Philocrates, find the means, that I may speak with him. Reboo, are, to sown
again. Recalcitro, trare, to stryke with the heel, to kick. Recalesco,
scere, to wax warm. Recaluaster, tri, he that is balde before. Recaluus,
idem. Recalueo, ere, to be balde again. Recanto, tare, to charm away or
charm out a thing, which was brought in by inchauntement, as the witches
called wise women are wont to do. Recapitulatio, a rehercynge of things in
chapiters. Recedo, recessi, recedere, to depart or goo away. Recedere a
condition, a persona, a statu, is to change or alter the condition, person,
or state. Cic. de off.
Quanquam id nomen durius efficit iam vetustas, a peregrino enim iam recessit,
All though auncienty makes that name diffuse, yet is it now altered from
being a strange word. Recello, cellere, to pluck back, or withdraw.
Recens, it is, new late. Recentior, newer. Recentissimus, newest, or latest.
Rece^ti pede recurrere, to run eftsoon after that he has rested him, to
make a fresh course. Plautus in ^tin.
Postquam thermopotasti gutturem, recipe te, and recurre pede recenti: After
that thou haste warmed thy throat with good drink, take thy heart to the, and
make a fresshe course. Recenter, newly, fresshely. Recentius, more newly.
Recento, tare, to renew. Recentor, taris, tari, to be renewed. Recenseo, ere,
to number or tell, to reken. Recensus, us, and Recensio, a tale or reckoning.
Recensitus, ta, tum, told, or rekenyd. Receptaculum, the place, which
receives things: also a place of suerty or comfort. Recepti in ciuitatem,
they which of strangers ^e made Citizens. Recepto, tare, to receive often.
Receptitius, a, um, that which is reserved from other. Receptum, taken in
custom. Receptus, tus, a retrayt in battle. Erasm. in Chiliad.
Receptui ca^ere, to blow the retrayte: also it is a proverb, which
signifies to fynysh or end the contention. Recessim, an aduerbe, which
signifies, going back. Recessus, us, a going away or back. Plautus in
Men^ch.
Recident in te hae contumeliae, those rebukes shall light on the. Terent. in
^olo. He.
Recidit ad paucos, it is come to a few persons. Recidipna, a garment to
soupe in. Recidiuus, a, um, eftsoon restored: sometime eftsoon decayed or
fallen. Recido, dear, to fall eftsoon: or to fall backwarde. Recido, di, dear,
to cut again, to cut behind. Recinium, a square garmente, which they that
did wear them, did cast the one part thereof over their shoulders at their
back, like to french clokes. Recinia^i, they that did wear such clokes.
Recino, ere, to sing again. Recipere se, to return or come again. Terent.
in Phorm.
Percuncta tum ibo ad portum, quoad se recipiat frater, I will go seek at the
hauyn, until my brother come again. Recipere se ad coenam, to come to souper.
Plautus in Capt.
Hic homo ad coenam recipit se ad me, This man will come to me to souper.
Recipe te ad me, come hither to me. Plautus in Per.
Recipere se ex opere, to return from his business. Recipere se domum, to
go home. Recipere in aures, to hear: No^ aedepol istaec tua dicta nu^c in
aures recipio, Plautus in cist.
In good soth I do not hear now what thou say. Recipere se in portum, to
arryue at an hauyn. Recipere se in Principem, Plinius in panegyr.
to take on him as a Prince. Recipere anhelitum, to fetch brethe or wind.
Priusquam recipias anhelitum, Plautus in mercatore
vno verbo eloquere, vbi ego sum, Or ever thou fetchest breath, tell me at a
word, in what case I do stand. Recipe animum, take breath. Terent. in Adelph.
Cicero in Cato. Cato speaks here of Fauius the wise Captayn^
Recipere, to recover. Cum quidem me audiente Salinatori, qui amisso oppido
fugerat in arcem, glorianti atque dicenti, mea opera Quint. Fab. Yarentum
recepisti: Certe, inquit ridens, nam nisi tu amisistes, nunquam recepissem: For
in my hearing, to Salinator, which (the town of Tarentum being lost) fled
into the castle, saying unto him, Thou have recovered Tarentum Q. Fab. by my
means: That is true said he, lawghinge: for if thou had not lost it: I
had not recovered it. also to reserve to a man's own use. Recipie, Cato uses
for Recipiam. Receptus, ta, tum, received. Receptio, a return back, Plautus
in Asinar.
drawing or bringing again. Quid tibi huc receptio ad te est meum virum? Why
draweste thou my housbande eftsoon back unto thy house. Reciprocatio, a
going back, or retournynge to the place that he came fro. Recipio, coepi,
cipere, to receive or take, to admit, to call again, to bring in
faulsgarde, to deliver, to undertake, to promise: also Recipere, is to reserve
to him self, or to except a thing in gyuynge or bargaynynge. Reciproco,
care, to turn back, to repete, to go back. Reciprocus, ca, cum, that which
is repeted or eftsoon reherced. Recisamentum, a little piece, a gobat. Recisus,
a, um, new cut. Recito, tare, to read that other may here and understand: to
recite or tell eftsoon. Reclamo, are, to deny with a loud voice or cry.
Festus. Val. in po. Verg.
Recliuia, and Recliuium, is when the skin of the fyngar is loose from the
nail. Recludo, si, dear, to open. Infernas reserat seeds and regna recludat
pallida, Undo he the locks of places infernal, and let him set wide open the
pale regions of death. Justinius puts Reclusus for clausus, shut. Recocia,
second or course cheese. Recogito, tare, to remember. Recognitio, a knowledge.
Recognosco, noni, noscere, to recognize, to know perfectly, to ouerloke.
Recolligo, legi, ligere, to assemble or gather together: also to reconcile.
Quod scribis, etiam si cuius animus esset in te offensior, a me recolligi
oportere, quid dicas? Where thou wrytest, that moreover if any man be
displeased with the, that he should be reconcyled by my means, whatte sayeste
thou? Recolo, lere, to repute, to repete, to call to remembrance.
Recommi^iscor, sceris, recomminisci, to remember, or call to remembrance.
Reconcilio, are, to reconcyle, to restore unto favor. Reconcilior, aris,
reconciliari, to be reconcyled. Plautus in cap.
Reconciliare in libertatem, to set at lybertye. Reconciliatio, a
reconcylynge. Reclusus, a, um, opened. Reconcinno, nare, to new make, to make
meet, proprely a garment. Recondo, dear, to hyde, to lay up. Recordor,
aris, ari, to remember. Recoquo, coxi, coquere, to boil or sees eftsoon, to
amend with study. Recordatio, remembrance. Recreatio, a recreation, a
restoringe. Recreo, aui, are, to recreate, to refresshe, to restore. Recresco,
scere, to grow again. Recrudesco, scere, to renew a fault made by Princes to
their familiars. Recta, a souper, where they sat all in a rewe. Rectangulus,
is where lines are so joined, that no part is longar or shortar than another.
Recta, an aduerbe signifyenge strayghte. Terent. in Eunucho.
Cur non recta introibas? why wentest thou not straight, or the straight way
in. Recte, well enough. Quid tu igitur lachrymas? aut quid es tam tristis?
Pamp. Terent. in Hecy.
Recte matter. S. Quid fuit tumulti? Than wherefore do thou mourn? or why
art thou so heavy? Pamph. It is well enough mother. S. what was all this
noise? Recte, parere, to bring forth no monster. Recte, of good right, with
good raison. Recte, dicis, thou say truly. Recte est, it is enough, or I
have enough. Tum quod them ei, recte est, Terent. in Heauton.
I have alsoo enough to give him. Recte facere alicui, to do good to a man,
Stultus and sine gratia es, tibi recte facere: Plautus in Aulularia.
quando quod facias perit, Thou art a fool and without thank, to do him any
good, when all is lost that thou do. Recte far, to take patiently. Si
sapis, neque praeterquam quas ipse amor molestias habet, Terent. in Eunucho.
addas: and illas quas habet, recte feras, If thou be wise, add to no more
grief than love brings with him, and them that he brings, suffer
patiently. Recte, signifies sometime nothing, as Donate says. Rogo, nunquid
velit. recte, inquit: abeo, I asked if he would any thing, Nothing, he said: I
went than my way. also ye, straight way. S. Tu rus hinc abis? Ter. in Ad.
D. recte, go thou now into the contray? D. ye straight way. Recte valet,
he or she is in good health. Rectius, better. Rectitas, and Rectitudo, Justice
or rightwysnesse. Rector, toris, a rular. Rectus, the nominatife case. Rectum
intestinum, the gutte from whense the ordure passes. Rectus, ta, tum,
straight, which is not crooked, upright, just. Recubitus, a lyenge at rest.
Recubo, are, to lie and rest. Recudo, cudi, dear, to new hamer, or new work,
as it were on an anduylde: also it is taken for, to make new, or new prynte.
Recuperatores, iuges assigned, or commissionars, for a pryuate matter. Recumbo,
to sytte at a table, or at meals: sometime to lean on one. Recumbebat mecum
vir egregius Fidius Rufinus, super eum municeps ipsius, There satte with me
that worshypfull man Fidius Rufinus, and above him his neighbor. Recuperatio,
and reciperatio, and reciperantia, was of old writers said, where there was a
law made between the people of Rome, and other nations and cities, wherein they
accordyd, that pryuate things taken, should be redelyuered, which is now
vsyd in our leagues and entercourses with strange countrayes and princes.
Recupero, rare, to recover. Recupio, cupiui, cupere, to desire much. Quin ita
faciam, ut recupias facere sumptum, and si ego uetem: And yet will I so
handle it, that thou shalt much desire to spend, although I would fordyd
the. Recurro, rere, to rounne again, to goo or come again quyckely. Recursus,
us, a runnyng back, a recourse. Recurso, are, to run often back or again.
Recurue, an aduerbe, signifieng bowid bakwarde, crokydly. Recuruitas, tatis, a
bowynge back. Recuruo, are, to bow back. Recuruor, ari, to be bowed back.
Recuruus, a, um, bowed back, or crooked Recusabile, that which is worthy to
be refusyd. Recusatio, a refusal. Recusator, a refuser. Recuso, are, to
refuse, also to defend. Recutitus, he that is circuncysed. sometime exulcerate.
Redabsoluo, uere, to discharge or dispeche. Sequere hac, te redabsoluam, qua
aduenisti gratia, Follow me thither, I will dyspatche thy mattier, for the
which thou came hither. Redactus, ta, tum, brought. Plautus. in Curcul.
Redambulo, are, to return. Cura quam optime potes. Er. been ambula, and
redambula, Do the best that thou canste. Er. well get the hens, and come again
quyckely. Redandruo, are, idem. Redamo, aui, are, to love mutually. Redarguo,
guere, to reprove. Reddo, di, dear, to render or yield, to deliver, to restore,
to give, to make. Reddere certiorem, to assertayne. Reddere rationem, to make
account, or reckoning. Reddere, to put in other. Tempestas uenit, confringit
tegulas imbricesque, ibi dominus indiligens reddere alias ne uult, The tempeste
camme, and brake the Tyles, and the Eueyses, where as the neglygente owner
would not put other in their places. Reddere commotum, Ter. in An.
to cause one to make haste, to haste him forward. Reddere dictum ac factum.
Videre egisse ia^ nescio quid cum seen. S. De illo quod dudu^? dictum ac factum
reddidi, It seems thou haste done late, I wot not what with the old man. S.
Meanest thou that, the other day? thou had not so soon spoken, but it was
done. Reddidi impetratum, I brought it to pass. Plautus in Epid.
Reddere operam, to require a good turn or an ylle. Reddere aliquem, to
resemble or be like to oone. Redemptio, redemption. Redemptito, demptitare, to
redeem or bye again often. Redempto, tare, to redeem. Redemptor, toris, a
redemer. Redeo, diui, dij, redire, to return. Redhibeo, hibui, bear, to cause
the seller to have again that which he sold. Redhibitio, restitution.
Redigo, degi, digere, to bring by force or cunning. sometime to restore.
Redigere in ordinem, to compelle men to live according to their astate or
profession Redis ad ingenium, thou do after thine old facion, or as thou
art wont to do. Terent. in Hecy. Ter. in An.
Redire ad se. Sed paululum sine ad me ut redeam, But let me take breathe a
lyttelle. Tandem reprime iracundiam, arque ad reredi: Now leave thy fume, and
remember thy self. Redeam ad pauca, Vt ad pauca redeam, Terent. in phorm.
ac mittam illius ineptias, To the intent that I will be short, and pass
over his folly. Redi ad rem, goo to the purpose, Terent. in Heaut.
or to the mattier. Redijt ad restim res. Opera tua ad restim mihi quidem res
redijt, Terent. in phormi.
By thy means I am brought to the point to hang my self. Redijt ad rastros.
Nam si illi pergam suppeditare sumptibus Menedeme, mihi illaec uere ad rastros
res redijt, Surely if I should maintain his expenses Menedemus, it would bring
me to rake corn or grass for my living. Redit res in eum locum, the thing
is come so to pass. In eum iam res redijt locum, ut sit necesse, The matter is
come so to pass, that there is no remedy. Redit mihi animus, Terent. in Hecyra.
my courage is comme unto me. Redit animo, it comes to my mind. Redire in
concordiam, to be agreed. Redire in gratiam, idem, Also to be eftesones in
favor. Redimicula, the ornaments or apparaylle of a woman's heed: as a
veluette bonette or french hode. Redimio, iui, ire, to adorn or apparayle, or
trymme. Plautus in Ruden.
Reditur, is returned. Redhibitum, restored. Redico, cere, to tell or say
again. Rediculi, a temple at Rome without the gate called Capena, where
Hannyball being aferde, retired back. Redimitus, ta, apparayled on the heed.
Redimere, to take in charge. Redinunt, for redeunt, they return or comme
again. Redinregro, a renewynge, a fortification. Redipiscor, sceris, sci, to
recover or get again. Redimo, demi, dimere, to redeem, to bye, to recover,
to recompense, to take in bargayne. Redemptores, they that hyre land, or
takes any thing in great or task. Ti Liuius Cae^. in co^.
Redintegrare, to begin a fresshe. Redintegrato animo, with courage reuyued,
with a fresh courage. Redito, tare, to return by and by. Reditus, tus, a
return. Reduuia, when the skin comes without the nails of the fyngers.
alsoo an adders skin. Rediuiuum, that which retourneth eftesones to life.
Also that which of an old thing is made new or young. Rediuias, a worm
called a tycke, which souketh blood from a man or beast. Redoleo, ere, to
smelle or savor. Redonatio, a gyuynge again of the thing that is taken.
Redono, are, to give again. Redorior, riris, riri, to begin again.
Redormio, to awake. Redormitio, an awakynge out of sleep. Festus.
Redostio, rire, of old writers was taken for to give thank. Reducem, and
reduces, they do call such which are brought out of exile or captivity.
Reducere, to bring saulfe. Meque oppido in arcem reduco, Apulcius.
And I conveyed my self quyckely into the Castle. Alsoo to pacyfye or appease.
Vergilius
Numenque reducant, Let them appease the wrath or dyspleasure of god.
Reduco, duxi, ducere, to bring back, or pluck back, to deliver or set out
of peril, to reconcyle. Reductus, a, um, brought back or safe. Redundo, are,
to ouerflowe, to reflowe or return back, to redounde. Reduro, are, to stop
or close. No. Mar.
Reduplico, care, to double eftsoon. Redulcero, rare, to impostume or make an
impostume in some part of the body. Refello, to prove falls, to repreue of
falsehode, to deny that which is objected. Referio, rire, to stryke again.
Refer ad aliquem, to ask one counsel in any matter. Refer de re aliqua
ad Senatum, was when the Consuls purposed a matter in the Senate, desiring the
Senators to reason and consulte thereof. Refer pedem, to set forth a foot,
or goo. Plautus in mercatore
Eutyche ha^c uolo rem prius agi, quam meu^ intro refero pedem, I will that
this thing Eutyche be done, or I go oone foot in. Retulit ad me pedem, He
came toward me. Plautus in Epidico.
Referunt haec ad rem, these things pertain to the matter. Refero acceptum,
Omnia quae uidimus, Cicero.
si recte rationabimus, uni accepta referemus Antonio. All that we see, if we
reckon well, we may impute it only to Antonie. Quod uiuit, mihi acceptum
refert: He confesses to be long of me, that he now lyuethe. Cicer. pro C^uen.
Verum omnem tranquillitatem and quietem senectutis refert acceptam clementiae
tuae, But all the tranquyllytie and quyetenesse of his age, he confesses to
proceed or have received of your mercy and goodness. Refer gratiam, to give
thank. Plautus in Mostell.
Nunquam ego illi possum gratiam refer, ut meritus est de me, I can never
give him thank suffycyent for that he has done for me. Spero ego mihi
quoque tempus tale euenturum, Plautus in merca.
ut tibi gratiam referam parem, I trust the time shall come, that I shall do
you as much pleasure. Ci. in Sal.
Non enim sperasti mutuam tibi gratiam relaturum, ut uicissim tuos compellarem,
Thou dyddest not think, that I would in this wise have requyted the, in
remembrynge thine auncetours, as thou haste done mine. Referri in acceptum, to
be brought in a reckenyng. Posteaquam reus factus est, primo negabat opus in
acceptum referri posse, after that he was accused, first he denied, that the
warke might be brought unto a reckenynge. Refer in melius, to turn it to a
better use. Refer mores, to express the condicyons or manners of an other.
Refer oculos, to cast the look upon one. Plin. epist. 156.
Refer par, to requyte. Ille quem beneficio adiungas, ex animo facit, studet
par refer, Whom thou gettest with benefytte, he does all things with a good
heart, and studieth to requyte the. Referte pedem, uel gradum, to step back,
to retreat. Refer, to show or tell. At illa retulit, quaesiuitque, quidnam
mihi uideretur, She told me all, and asked what I thought therein. Cicer. pro
Seruilio.
Refert. Cuius consilii magni referebat te inter esse. At the which
counsel, it had been very necessary, that ye should have been. Terent. in
phorm.
Parui retulit non suscepisse, It made little matter, that he took her not.
Mea quid refert? What care I? Mea nihil refert? I have naught to do with it.
Tua refert, It is for thy profit. Quid refert me fecisse regibus, ut mihi
obedirent, si me hodie hic umbraticus deriserit? What avails it, that I have
made kings to obey me, if now this lewd knave shall laughe me to scorn?
Refert, It is expedient or necessary. Ver. geor.
Neque enim numero comprehendere refert: It is not necessary, to reherce them
in number. Refercio, cire, to fylle. Refero, tuli, far, to bring again, to
resemble, to report, to refer, to revoke. Referebam me, I returned. To add
to, or ascribe, to turn, to renew, to bring, to declare or express. Ci. in
Pis.
Refero impensum, I make account of that which is bestowed. Refer rationem,
to yield or make account. Refectus, ta, tum, restored, renewed, amended, made
eftesoones. Reficio, ficere, to recreate, or restore, to amend, to make
again. Reficior, ceris, ci, to be restored, recovered from sickness, Also
renewed or new made. Refigo, fixi, figere, to make fast or sure, to thruste in
hard. Sometime it signifies the contrary, to draw out that which is
fastened. Ci. Phi. 13
Refigere tabulas and leges, to undo or destroy laws. Acta Antonij
rescidistis, leges refixistis: Ye have cancelled the acts of Antony, and
undone or dissolved his laws. Ver. aenei.
Fixit leges, pretioque refixit, He stablyshed laws, and for money eftesoones
dissolved them. Refirmo, are, to fasten or stablyshe again. Terent. in Adelph.
Reflatio, a contrary wind. Reflatus, tus, idem. Reflecto, xi, tere, to bow
back, to turn back or again. Qu^ neque fides, neque ius^urandu^, neque illum
misericordia repressit, neque reflexit, Whom neither promise, nor oath, nor yet
pity, withdrewe or pulled back. Reflo, are, to blow again or contrary.
Refluo, xi, fluere, to flow. Refluxus, us, the tide, when the water flows.
Refocillatio, a comfortynge or refreshyng, or recreation. Refocillo, are, to
recomforte, to refresshe, Plinius in panegyr. Plin. in epistol. 156. Plinius in
panegyri.
to recreate, to fortifye. Reformo, mare, to refourme. Reformator, a
reformatour. Refoueo, foui, fotum, fouere, to nourysshe or comfort eftesoones,
to restore or set in his first state. Refractarius, obstynate, in a wylfulle
oppinion. Refragor, aris, ari, to resyste with words, or clamor. Refrango,
fregi, refrangere, aut refringere, to braste open. Refreno, refrenare, to pull
back one from a purpose. Refrico, care, to renew a sore or grief, which was
out of remembrance. Refrigeratorius, a, um, that which cools or makes
cold. Refrigeratio, a koolynge. Suetonius in Claudi.
Refrigeratus, ta, tum, kooled: also refreshed or comforted. Refrigerium, a
recreation or aduauncynge of the mind. Refrigesco, scere, to make cold.
Refrigero, are, to cool, or make cold, to refreshe or recomforte. Refrina, a
bean, which the old Romans were wont to bring home out of the field, Festus.
to do sacrifyce for the good luck of their corn. Refuga, an unruly
person, which will not be ordered. Refugio, gere, to flee or run away or
back. Colum. 4.
also to refuse. Refugium, refuge, succor, or place where one may be
succored. Refugus, a, um, that which gothe away, Sidonius.
or is laid aparte. Refulgeo, gere, to shine. Refundo, fudi, fundere, to
restore that which lacks. Quicquid deerit, Seneca.
ex meo refundam, Whatte so ever does lack, I will make it up of mine
own. Alsoo to pay home again, or to yield. Id erat non tam accipere
beneficium, quam refundere, That was not so much, Seneca de benefic.
to receive a good turn, as to do a good turn. Alsoo to cast up by
vomyte. Quod hesterna crapula ingurgitauerat, Plinius.
palam refudit, That which in his yesterdayes ryotte he ingourged or devoured,
he openely did parbrake or vomyte hit up. Refutatio, a denyenge, a
replycation, an argument to the contrary. Refuto, tare, to deny, to replye.
Regaliolus, a bird, between whom and the egle is contynual hostility, and is
yelowe of color. Regaliter, royally. Regalis, le, royalle. Regelo, are, to
thawe, or resolve that, which is frosen. Regenero, rare, to regenerate or
eftesones engender. Regero, gessi, gerere, to put in writing, to bring
back, to vomyte up. Regestum, earth cast up. Regia, a kings house. Regiesco,
scere, old writers used, for crescere, to grow. Regificus, ca, cum, that
whereby a king is made. Regilla, a kings robe. Regillus, a little king.
Also the name of a river in Italy. Regimen, minis, a rule or governance.
Regina, a queen. Regionatim, place by place, by every region or cost. Regio,
a region or country, also a cost, as east, weste, north, and southe.
Regium, a city beyond the mountains toward Italye. Regius, a, um, of a
king. Regius morbus, the iaundyse. Regno, are, to reign. Regnum, a realm,
and the governance. Rego, xi, regere, to rule, to govern. Regor, geris, to be
ruled or governed. Regrador, de^i, di, to goo back. No. Mar.
Regredo, dear, to revoke, or call again. Regredior, regredi, to go back.
Regressio, and regressus, us, a return back, a resort back. Regula, a rule.
Regularis, regulare, that which is under a rule. Regulo, are, to rule or
dyrecte. Regulus, a Prince or lord of a lyttelle countreye, proprely Reguli,
be the chylderne of kings. Also Regulus is a little bird, called a wrenne,
and a serpent called a Cockatryce, which sleeth a man with his syghte. It was
alsoo the name of a Consule, which for keeping of his promise, was put to
cruelle death by the Carthaginensis. Also a great Rhetorician in the time of
Plynie. Reieculae, uel reijculae o^es, sheep drawn out of the fold for aege
or syckenesse, kebbers, crones, or cullyars. Reiectanea, Vergil. in Bucolio.
of philosophers be taken for things to be abhorrid, as sycknesse, poverty,
and sorrow. Reiectio, parbrakynge. Reiectio sanguinis, the yssuynge out of
bloudde at the mouth, the noose, or the veins. Reiectus, ta, tum, cast
out, cast away, or put forth. Reijcio, ieci, ijcere, to cast away, to
drive back. Tityre pascentes a flumine reiice capellas, Tityre drive thy
gotes, that do feed, away from the river. Also to refuse, to put away.
Apulcius.
Me uero tanquam inutilem reiecerunt, As for me they refused, as a person
unprofitable. Terent. in Phorin.
Si altera illa magis instabit, forsita^ nos reiiciat: If the other will be
importunate, perchance they will put me away. Reiicere iudices aut testes, to
refuse judges or witnesses. Reiicere, to parbrake or vomyte. Se^tonius in
August.
Senos sextantes non excessit: aut si excessisset, reiiciebantur, He exceded
not twelve ounces, if he passed that, they were cast up again. Relatio, a
report, a respect: Among Logycians, it is the effect of the Relatyue, as
the father, the son, the master, the servant, the husband, the wife. For
without the oone, the other can not retain his name, for a son may not be
without a father: nor a wife without a husband, nor a servant without a
master. Relati in aerarios, were they, which for some defaute were by the
masters of manners, called Censores, put out of the number of Citisens, and did
only pay tribute, or heedsyluer, as strangers. Relative, having relacion to a
thing. Relatiuum, a relatife, which has relation to some thing. Relaxo,
are, to lowse. Relegatus, banysshed. Relegatio, a banysshemente out of his
countreye. Relego, relegare, to banysshe, to remove, to sever oone from an
another, to send away. Religatus, ta, tum, fast bound. Relego, legi, legere,
to read again. Relicinus, he that has a good busshe of hear, well trymmed
behind. Relicina frons, a fair large and high forheed, without hear.
Relictus, ta, tum, forsaken or left. Relictus sum mihi, I am left alone.
Religio, onis, relygion, a reverend dread. doubt lest be shall offend.
Plautus in C^rgal.
Also conscience, or as a man might say, a scruple of conscience. Religiose,
fearfully, doubtefully, daungerousely, scrupulously. Religiosus, sa, sum,
relygious, dredefulle, doubtefull. Liuius. 6.
In religionem uertere, to fear leeste god were displeased. Religionem
inducere, to bring in fear of goddis displeasure. ^^etonius i^ August.
Religio est, it is not lefull. Huc introire, nisi necessario, and cast,
religio est, To enter in there, but for necessity, and chastely, it is not
lefull. Religiosus, sa, sum, religious, also superstitious. Terent in Heauton.
Plautus in ^^y^.
Religiose, any s^dly, circu^spectly, curiously. Relino, releui, relinere, to
open that which is stopped. Releui omnia dolia, I have broched all the
vessels. Nolo ego nos pro summo bibere: nulli relerimus postea, I would not
that we drank all out: for I will for no man set any a broche afterward.
Religioni obstringere, which is commonly said to have conscience in a thing.
Religioni obstringi, to be bound in conscience. Religioni exoluere, to
discharge a man's conscience. Religo, are, to loose or unbind. Relimino, to
give light. Relinquo, liqui, relinquere, to leave. Relinquere animam, to dye.
Relinquit eum animus, His heart fails him. Reliquatores, they which been in
arrerage on their account. Also any other, which have in their hands some
part of that, which they ought to have paid. Reliqu^ae, that which is left.
Reliquium facere, to leave, to omytte. Reliquus, a, um, the remenaunt, that
which remains. Reliquum est, the rest is. Pli. in epis.
Reluceo, luxi, cere, to shine or be bright. Reluctor, tari, to contend or
strive again. Reluo, luere, to pay again that which is borrowed, to fetch
home a gage or pledge. Also to wash eftesoones. Remandere, to chewe the cudde.
Remaneo, si, nere, to abide stylle. Remano, are, to turn back to a place.
Remansio, an abiding. Remecull, little ships, which men of Lemnos used.
Remedium, remedy. Remeligo, a fysshe, which cleanynge to the keale of a
ship, causes him to tarry. Remendo, are, to amend or correct a faut. Remeo,
are, to return or go back ageyn. Remigatio, a rowing or saylynge. Remiges,
they which do row in a galaye or boot. Remigium, the rowing of a ship or
bote. Remigo, are, to row. Remigro, are, to go back, to return. Remillum, a
thing crooked and broad. Reminiscor, sceris, sci, to call again to
remembrance. Reminiscentia, the remembrance of that, which was ones in the
mind. Remiss, fayntly, without courage, humbly: Sometime meryly. Remissio,
remyssion, forgyuenesse, a recreatyng of mind after study or labor. Remissus,
a, um, glad, remytted or forgiven, sent again. Remitto, misi, remittere, to
send, to send again, to send back, to release or forgive, to grant, to
let down, to commytte, or remytte, to relinquishe or leave. Remittere
animum, to put away care, to vnbende or louse. Remittere, to cesse.
Remittere aliquid adolecentiae, pardon him somewhat for his youth. Remittere
nuntium. Gratiam habeo tibi, qum copiam istam mihi and potestatem facis,
Plautus in cap.
ut ego ad parents remittam nuntiu^: I thank the, that thou gyuest me this
leave, and also authority, that I may send to thy friends, to provide for
the else where. Remissio, a release, a losing, a withdrawyng. Oculorum
remissio, a withdrawing of the look. Remora, a little fyshe, which retayneth
a great ship under sail. Ci. de ora.
Remorbesco, to fall eftesones* into sickness. Remordeo, dear, to tourment the
mind, or make one heavy. Remores, birds, which by their flight or voice
sygnyfyed, that the thing purposed was not to be followed, Remoria, a place on
the top of the hyl called Auentinus, where Remus stood, and by the flight of
birds, aduysed the building of Rome. Remona, the dwelling house of Remus.
Remoueo, ere, to remove, to take away. Remouere moram, make ye have, speed
you. Remoror, aris, ari, to tarry or make to abide. Remugio, gini, gire, to
below or low again, to render a great sown. Remulco, care, and remulculo,
is proprely to draw a greatte ship or barge with a less vessel, by
translation it signifies to draw a thing easyly. Remulcus, a little bore or
bark. Remulinus ager, Remus field. Perottus.
Remuncopae, instruments, wherewith ships be driven on land. Remunero, are,
and remuneror, ari, to reward to recompense a good turn. Remunera^o,
recompense. Remus, the brother of Romulus, which builded Rome. Renauciscor,
sceris, sci, to get again. Renarro, are, to tell, to repete. Renato, tare,
to swym back, or swym again. Renes, the kydneyes. Renideo, d^re, to shine, to
savor or smell. Renodo, dare, to vnknytte, or undo a knot. Renoues, garments
made of skynnes of wol^es or other beasts, wherein the anci-Almayns were wont
to lie in the wars. Renouo, are, to renew. Renouello, lare, to make new
again. Rentifolia, a kind of wild roses, which have neither good savor nor
facion. Renumero, rare, to pay again money, which is received. Renuntiata,
an I Will by Ethiope, so rich, that the inhabytantes do give for a horse by
exchange, a talent of gold. Renuntio, are, to report, to signify, to show
openly, to renounce, to refuse, to resign, sometime to restore. Renuntiare
uitae, to refuse to live. Renuntiatur Consul, he is declared consule.
Renuntiatio, a report, also a resignation of an office. also a summons by an
offycer. Plautus in ^^in.
Renunti^, they which do carye tidings from one to an other. Renuo, nuere, to
