refuse, to despise. Renutus, nutus, a refusalle or denyar with countenance.
Reor, reris, ratus sum, I suppose. Repagulum, a door or wyndowe or other
thing that shuts or closes. Repages, idem. Repandus, a* um, bent or bowed,
and broad backwarde, as ores were in the old time. Repando, dear, to bend
back. Reparo, rare, to repair, to restore to the first astate. Reparamen,
and reparatio, a repayrynge or reparation. Reparco, parsi, sere, to spare.
Repastinatio, a new dyggynge about vynes. Also a bryngyng of ground to
temper with much labor and dyggynge. Repastinatus, ta, tu^, new dug or
brought in temper. Repastino, are, to dygge again about vynes, to alter land
or ground, with often dyggynge or labourynge. Repastinor, nari, to be eftesones
dygged, or brought into temper. Repauso, are, to take rest. Repedo, are, to go
away, to go back. Repello, puli, pellere, to put back, to repel. Rependo,
di, dear, to recompense. Repenso, are, to ponder, to ouersee, to judge. Repent,
sodaynely. Repentinus, a, um, sudden. Reperibitur, it shall be found.
Repertor, he that fyndeth. Repercutio, cussi, cutere, to stryke again, to
reuerberate. Repercussus, sus, a reuerberation or strykynge often. Reperio,
reperi, reperire, to find by adventure. sometime otherwise. Plautus.
Repetere, to call again. Hem repudiatus repetor, How now, being ones
refused, I am called again. Alta repetita, Ter. in A^.
rehearsed from the beginning, far sought, or far fette. Repetere poenas, ab
aliquo, to be auengyd on one. Repeto, I remember. Me quidem adolesce^tulo,
repeto quendam principem nomine alternis diebus declamare, alternis disputare,
I remember me, when I was a boy, that one, which was a prince of name, did
one day declame, an another day dispute. Repetenti memoria, to call to
remembrance. Repeto, tij, tere, to ask again, to ask often, or eftesoones, to
reherce again, or repete, to reuolue. Repetundarum accusari, is proprely where
a man sometime being in great authority and having the rule of a country, is
accused and called to a reckenynge, for all that he has received, being in his
office, above that which is his ordynarye allowaunce, also for all thing that
he took wrongefully from any person or town* which was the most
necessary action for a publyke weal, that might be devised, to be now put
in execution. Repignerator, he that redemeth or quiteth his gage or pledge.
Repignero, are, to quite or redeem a pledge or gage. It may be taken sometime
with us, that which in our law is called to repleuy: and repignoratio, a
repleuy: and repignoratitia actio, for a replegiare. Replaudo, dear, to make
noise with the hands beaten together. Replicatio, a replycation or vnfoldynge
of a thing. Replico, care, to unfold. also to reply. Replumbo, are, to
vnsowlder. I^^eco^, (...) d* auro and argent^.
Repo, repsi, pere, to crepe, to run as roots do in the ground. Repoleo,
liui, lire, to polyshe again. Repolleo, lere, to be much able, to be of power
to do. Colum. 5.
Repollesco, scere, to be eftesoones strong or in force. Reponere fidem, to
trust. Horatius.
Reponere, ^s also to put in by writing. Scriptor honoratum si forte reponis
Achillem, Thou that writest, if peradventure thou put in Achylles. Repono,
sui, nere, to put or set again in his place, to lay up, to recite again,
to hyde, to redelyuer or restore, to revoke, to repress, to lay to more, or
exaggerate, to heap one on an other, to make to grow again, to bring again.
Et quantum longis carpent armenta diebus, Vergeo. 2.
Exigua tantum gelidus ros nocte reponet: Look how much the sheep in the
long days shall byte. The cold dew in oone night with growing shall
requyte. Reporto, are, to bring back, or again. Reposco, poposci, scere, to
ask again that which is mine own, or is as it were dew to me.
Repositorium, a storehowse. Repositus, and repostus, ta, tum, laid up, to
hyde. Manet alta mente repostum, Iudicium Paridis, Deep in his mind, remained
the judgment, that Paris gave between the goddesses, of the which sprange the
occasyon of the destruction of Troy. Repotium, when the day after the marriage
friends do come and drink with the bride. Reprehendo, dear, to pluck back,
to reprove. Reprehensi, caught. Represento, tare, to represent, to render, to
bring in presence, or present a thing, to lay before one. Reprimo, mere, to
refrain, to let. Reprobo, are, to reprove. Reprobus, a man reproved.
Reproces, sharp. Reptile, all thing that crepeth. Repto, tare, to crepe much:
also to go softly like a snayle. Repudio, are, to forsake, as a man forsakes
his wife, also to refuse, to aba^don, or leave. Ter. in A^.
Repudio consilium, quod primum intenderam, I will now leave the counsel
that I first intended to follow. Repudium, a deuorce. Repudium remittere, to
be deuorced. Repudium renuntiare, to declare a deuorce. Is me nunc repudium
renuntiare iussit tibi, Plautus in A^i^^.
He wylled me to declare to the, that he has forsaken the. Repudiosae nuptiae,
marriage, after the which follows sone after a deuorce, Plautus in Persa.
Necessitate me mala ut fiam facis, uerum uideto, me vbi uoles nuptum date, ne
hac fama faciat, repudosas nuptias, Thou compellest me to be naught, but take heed, that where thou will mary me, by that report he shall make such a
wedding as shall soon after be dissolved or broken. Repuerasco, scere, to be
eftesones a child. Repugno, are, to repugne or say contrary, to resyste.
Repugnanter, an aduerbe, which signyfyeth contrariously, displeasantly. Cicero
de amicitia.
Vt igitur monere and moneri, proprium est uerae amicitiae, and alterum libere
facere, non aspere: alterum pacienter accipere non repugnanter, sic habendu^
est nullam in amicitus pestem esse maiorem, quam adulatione^, blanditias,
assentationem, Like therefore as to give counsel, and to be counseled,
proprely belongs to very frendeshyp, also the tone to do every thing
frankely, the the other to take all thing pacientely, not displeasantly: So it is
to be considered, that in frendshyp there is no more pestilence, than
flatterye, fair words, and consenting to all things. Repugnantia,
repugna^cy, where one thing agrees not with an another. Repungo, gere, to
prycke again, or mutually displease or offend. Repulsa, a putting back of
him, which either demands or looks for authority or office. Repulsor,
oris, he that puts an another man back. Repulsus, he that is put back.
Reputo, tare, to think often, to consider much, to reuolue in the mind, to
count* Also to cut of eftesoones. Requies, rest. Requiesco, scere, to rest or
take rest. Requietus, ta, tum, that which rests. Requiro, requisiui,
requirere, to seek eftesones or often, to require. Res, occasion. Ere nata
melius fieri haud potuit, quam factum est, Terent. in Adelph.
Of the occasion begone it could not better have been done, than it is. Also it
sygnifieth mean. I am repperi rem, quo pacto nec fur, nec sotius sies: Plautus
in Ruden.
I have now found the mean, how thou shall be neither a thief, nor a
companion with him. Rem facere, to gain or win. Nunquam rem facies: abi,
nescis ine^care homines, Terent. in Adelph.
Thou shalt never gain penye: Get the hense, thou cannest no skylle to
angle men. Rem habere cum aliquo, to have to do with one, to meddell with
one. Ter. in Eu.
Res gerere, to have or make wars. Scipione Aemiliano res in Africa gerente,
Polybius annalium conditor, Plinius. lib. 5.
ab eo accepta class scrutandi orbis illius gratia circunuectus est: Scipion
Emilianus making wars in Affrike, Polybius the wrytar of Histories, with a
certain number of ships, was conuayed about that cost, to inserche that
part of the world. Plautus in Epidico.
Re iuuare, to help with deeds and not with words only. Is amicus, qui in
re dubia re iuuat, vbi re est opus, He is a friend, which in a case that is
doubteful, helps me with his deeds, where deeds are required. Quid isti
credam? Terent. in Eunucho.
res ipsa indicat: what shall I trust him? the deed self declares. Verba ad
rem confer, to do as he says. Vsque adeo ego illius far possum ineptias,
Terent. in Eunucho.
and magnifica verba, verba dum sint, veru^ enim, si ad rem conferentur,
vapulabit: Hitherto I can suffer his lewdenesse, and bragges, as long as they
are but words: but if he do as he says, he shall smart therefore. Re vera, in
deed, in very truth, matter in deed. Resalutatio, a courtayse speaking to
him that speaks to you, a resalutinge. Resaluto, salutare, to salute him that
saluteth you. Resarcio, si, cire, to amend, to refourme. Resarrio, iui, ire,
to weed eftsoon corn. Res, a thing, the thing, the matter: sometime
astate, condition, business, contention, cause, richesse or substance,
profit, weal, experience. Res est, it is matter in deed. Res ad manticam
redijt, it is all come to a bag and a staff, or a staff and a walet. Res
comperendinata, a matter adiourned or deferred until the third day. Res
iudicata, the matter or cause finally determined and adiuged. Res controuersa,
the matter in suit. Res forensis, a matter in law. Respublica, a public weal.
Rescindo, scidi, scindere, to cut or break in sunder, Vergil. ^eor. ^i. 1.
to take away, to destroy, to make void or repel an act or law, to break
up. Coelum rescindere fratres, Ter sunt conati: Thries the brethern assayed to
break up heaven, for to enter. Rescio, sciui, scire, to know a thing, which is
hid and kept secret: also to know a thing after that it is done, which
was not known before. Rescisco, scere, idem quod Rescio. Rescribo, psi, bear,
to write again, to redelyuer, to repay money. Reseco, are, to cut away that
which is superfluouse. Resecare ad vinum, to pare to the quick, to touch the
quick in a matter. Resecro, crare, to pray or desire eftsoon: also to assoyle
one of his auowe. Resegmen, the paringe of a man's nails. Resero, are, to open
a thing that is closed. Resero, tere, to sow or set again. Reseruatio, a
reservation, a keeping of some thing. Reseruo, uare, to keep a part from other
things, to reserve. Reses, idis, ydell from accustumed labor or occupacion.
Resex, secis, Col. lib. 3
that which is cut and springs again, and bears more fruit than it did
before. Resideo, resedi, residere, to rest, to sytte, to stand fast. Resido,
sedi, sidere, to sit down, also to abide. Plinius in Episto.
Nam Viennensium vitia inter ipsos residunt, nostra late vagantur, For the
faults of men of Vienne, do abide with them, ours run abroad, and be
every where known. Residet in vultu, there does rest or appiere in the
vysage. Cic. de (...)
Quorum non in sententia solum, sed etiam in nutu residebat autoritas, In whose
sentence not only, but also countenance, authority rested. Residuus, a, um,
the rest or remnaunt. Resigno, are, to open that which is sealed: sometime to
seal fast, also to shyt, sometime to restore again, also to resign or
surrendre. Resignatum aes, wages stopped for negligent service in wars.
Resilio, lij, iire, to lepe back, or step away quickly. Resimus, he that
has a camoysenose, that is to say, turned upward. Resina, rosyn, all like
gum which runs out of trees. Resinatus, sinata, tum, rased, or dressed
with rosyn. Resipio, pui, pere, idem quod Resipisco. Resipisco, resipui,
resipiscere, to return to perfect understanding, to be eftsoon wise, where
before he erred. Resisto, restiti, resistere, to resyste or withstand.
Resoluo, uere, to resolve, to destroy, to pay dettes, to remove, to undo or
vnlowse. Resolutio neruorum, the palsy. Resono, nare, to sown again, to make
an Echo. Resorbeo, bui, and psi, bear, to pour out or disgorge the licour
that was received. Respecto, are, to see often, to love, to help. Respectus,
tus, a look: also, respect or regard. Neque eo respectu commorus discesserat:
Plini.
Having no regard thereunto he departed. Respergo, si, gere, to cast water or
other licour about, to sprynkle. Respergimen, a sprynklynge or casting about
of licour. ^^r. in An.
Respicere, to help or socour. Age, me in tuis secundis rebus respice: Let se,
now in thy prosperity, socoure me. Respicit nos deus, god has pytie on us.
Tacemodo, Plautus in ^^cch.
deus respiciet nos aliquis, peace now, some god will have pity on us.
Respicere se, to take heed or have regard of him self. Plautus in ^^udo^o.
Non soles respicere te, cum dicas unjust alteri? Art thou not wont to take heed of thy self, when thou say wrong of another man? Terent. in ^^caut.
Non tu te cohibes? non te respicis? non tibi exempli satis sum? Will thou not
beware? will thou not take heed of thy self? am not I a good example unto the?
Respicio, exi, spicere, to look back, to have regard, to provide, to remedy,
to keep, to reserve, to love. Cice. Aul. ^orquato.
Respiro, are, to take brethe, also to take comfort, to return to the first
state. Si armis aut condition positis, aut fatigarione abiectis, aut victoria
detractis, ciuitas respirauerit: and dignitate tua tibi, and fortuna vti
licebit: If that harneyse, either by conditions of peace being laid away, or
by werynesse of both parts being thrown away, or pulled away by victory,
the city shall recover her first estimation, thou than shall enjoy thy
possessions and dignity. Resplendeo, dear, to shine. Respondeo, di, dear, to
answer, to appiere when one is called, to agree, to consent or be like or
equal, to be against, as one thing set or lyenge against another. Responsio,
an answer. Responsito, tare, to make or give answer: it pertayned proprely
to lawiars: and them which had the interpretation of ceremonies. Cice^ pro
C^^en.
Responso are, to answer. Responsum, an answer. Responsus, sus, sui, where
one thing does agree with another, a consent, a conueniencye. Respuo, ere, to
refuse, or reject. Restagno, restagnare, to contain or hold water. Restat,
Restare, to be or remain of that thing, that is left, to stand back, to
resyste. Hoc me restat, that remains or abides for me. Restauro, Restaurare,
to restore, or make again. Restibilis, that which is renewed, or sown again.
Restibilis ager, a feelde which is sown two years together. Restinguo, xi,
guere, to stint or put out, or cesse, as fire, light, and thurst. Restio,
onis, a roper: alsoo he that hangs him self. Restipulatio, a putting in of
pledges, Plautus.
put in gage or pledge, for to make answer to an action. Restipulor, aris,
ari, to make answer in the law. Restite, to be ready to be sown, ploughed,
or dygged. Restis, a halter or cord, a rope or bunche of of garlyke or onyons.
Restem ducere, when maidens and children daunse together hand in hand, or
with napkens, leadynge one another. Ad reftim res redijt, the matter is in
despair, or desperate. Restiro, tare, to abide or tarry. Restituo, ere, to
restore, to yield again. Restitutio, restitution. Resto, tare, to remain, to
tarry. Hic nunc me credit aliquam sibi fallaciam portare, Ter. in An.
and ea me hic restitisse gratia: He weeneth, that I warke him some falshede,
and that I tarry still therefore. Cicero de finibus.
Nullam querentes voluptatem Stoici restant. The Stoike Philosophers do resist
or stick to their opynion, sekinge for no pleasure. Restat mihi, it taryeth
for merit shall happen unto me. Restricte and Restrictim, straytely, or strayte.
Restringo, xi, stringere, to bind or strain backwarde, to bind again, to
restrain: sometime it signifies to lowse. Apulci. Iumentum restrinxit,
abireque stabulo liberum sinit: he lowsed his horse, and let him out of the
stable at liberty. Resulto, tare, to lepe against a thing, to rebounde, to
rebelle, to leap or step back. Resumo, psi, sumere, to take again, to
resume. Resuo, ere, to sow again, or make a double styche: also to ryppe or
undo that which is sown, to vnstytche. Suct. in an.
Sumenti virile^ togam, tunica laticlaui resuta ex vtraque part, ad pedes
decidit: When he came first to man's age, his Senators cote being rypte on
both sides, fell down to his feet. Resupinus, na, number, vpryght, the belly
upward. Resurgo, rexi, gere, to arise up. Resurrectio, resurrection.
Resupino, nare, to turn upward, or upright, to revoke or call back, to
differ, to peruerte. Retae, trees growyng on the banks of ryuers, or in the
ryuers. Retardatio, a taryenge. Retardo, dare, to make to tarry. Rete, it is, a
net. Retego, Retexi, tegere, to discover or disclose. Retento, entare, to
retain often, to tempte eftsoon. Retexo, ere, to vntwyste or untwine, or
vnwynde: sometime to twist or wind eftsoon, to dissolve. Retia culum, a little
net. Retiarius, he that casts a net, proprely in syghtynge to apprehende
his aduersarye. Retia, nets, sometime it signifies one net. Reticeo, cui,
ticere, to hold ones peace, to speak no word, to keep secret, to say
nothing. Reticentia, silence, when one holds his peace. Reticula, a little
net, wherein a man's hear or women's is trussed. Reticulatus, Reticulata,
culatum, made like a net. Reticulum, a cawle or coyfe: also a bag, wherein
meat is carried. Retinaculum, what so ever holds any other thing, a stay.
Retinere, to hold up, that a man fall not. Ab retine me obsecro. Terent in
Heauton,
B. obsecro quid tibi est^ An. Disperij. B. perij misera, quid stupes
Antiphila? Oh hold me up I pray the. B. alak what ayleth the? A. I am
undone. B. alas that ever I was borne, why does thy heart fail the Antiphila?
Retineo, nui, nere, to hold again, to retain, to keep in remembrance.
Terent. in Adelph.
Retinere, to restrain or let one from doing that, that he would. Pudore and
liberalitate liberos retinere satius esse credo, quam metu: I think it better
to restrain children from their wanton wills, by shame and liberality, than
with fear. Retinens, he that keeps still. Retiolum, a Cawle, or coyfe.
Retondeo, dear, to klyppe all over. Retorqueo, torsi, quere, to cast
backewarde, to throw or shute again. Retorresco, retorrescere, to be burnedde
with the sun. Retorridus, da, dum, burned or seryd. Retracto, ctare, to call
back, or revoke a thing that is done, to draw back, to excuse, to lay to
another man, to draw up. Retrahe, traxi, trahere, to pull or draw back, or to
draw to. Retribuo, buere, to recompense. Retrica, old writars called the
water, wherewith gardens are watered. Retrime^tum, the dragges of a thing:
sometime ordure or dung. Retro, behind. Retrocedo, cessi, cedere, to go back.
Retrorsum, bacwarde. Retrorsus, a, um, turned backewarde. Retrudo, si, dear, to
put back. Retundo, dear, to make blunt or dull, that which is sharp: also to
beat often on a thing. Retusus, a, um, dull, blunt, contrary to sharp. Aliae
agrorum parts, Cic. de D^
quae acuta ingenia gignant, aliae quae retusa: Some parts of co^trayes there
be, which do bring forth sharp wits, some bring forth dull. Reualesco,
scere, to be recovered from sickness. Reueho, uexi, here, to bring or carry
back, or again. Reuelatio, a revelling or a disclosynge of a thing. Reuello,
reuellere, to pluck back, to pull again. Reuelo, are, to discover. Reuenio,
nire, to come again. Reuerendus, worthy reverence. Reuerens, rentior,
rentissimus, he that does reverence. Reuerenter, reverently. Reuerentia,
reverence or honor done to one. Reuereor, retis, reri, to have in reverence.
Reuersio, a return. Budeus.
Reuertor, teris, ti, to return. Reuerto, idem. Reuincio, uinxi, uincere,
Verg^l. Gell.
to bind back or behind, as to bind ones hands behind him. Reuincere
paratus est, which the lawyars do say, Paratus est verificare, He is ready to
auerr^. Reuiso, sere, to return to see. Reuiuisco, scere, to be reuyued.
Reuoco, uocare, to call back, to revoke, to bring again, to draw back, to
raise from death. Reuocare pedem, to turn back, to recule. Reuocare, to
restore or renew. Item circa omnium ordinum statum domi, forisque, aut
correxit, aut exoleta reuocauit, aut etiam noua instituit: Moreover concerning
the state of al degrees, as well within his house as without, either he did
amend them, or renewed those things that were out of use, or else ordained
new. Reuocatio, a reuocation or calling back. ^^deus.
Reuocare restes, to reherce the deposicions of witnesses, Publication. Reuolo,
are, to flee back. Reuoluo, ui, uere, to turn up and down, to reuolue, to
turn back, to remove. Reuolutus, ta, tum, to be turned back, to be
removed. Reuolutio, a tournynge back to the first place or point: a
reuolucion or tournynge of celestial bodies or spheres. Reuorto, tere, old
wrytars used for Reuertor, to return. Reus, he that is sued or accused,
sometime he that is gyltye. Reus facti, gylty of an offense. Reus agitur, he is
sued or accused. Reus peragitur, he that is condemned. Reus stipulando, he that
bargayneth. Reus uoti, he that has auowed. Reum subdere, to accuse one of great
offense Rex regis, a king. Rex sacrificulus, was a chief minister of
sacrifices among the Romans only.
R, ANTE H.
RHabarbarum, Rubarbe, a preciouse root, medicinable to pourge coler. also to
corroborate the stomach and liver. Rachinon, a spyder, having a little black
heed, and is somewhat white, and has short feet, whose bytynge is as venymous
as the styngynge of a Scorpion. Rhadamanthus, was king of Licia, which was a
strayghte executour of justice: and therefore was supposed of the Paynyms to be
afterward one of the iuges in hell. Rhagades, and Rhagadiae, certain kleftes
or as it were Scrachis about the siege or fundament. Pli. li. 24. cap. 14.
Rhamnus, a kind of brembles, which is white, and bears more fruit than
other do, and also has flowers, and sends forth branches with straight
pricks, not crooked as other are, and has broad leaves. Rhamnusia, was called
goddess of vengeance. Rhamnusius, a man of a town called Rhamnus, by Athenes.
Rhampsinithus, the propre name of a king of Egypt. Rhaphanus, an herb called
Radysshe. Rhebanus, a river in the mouth of Bosphorus, a countraye in Thracia.
Rhea, was called the mother of gods, called also Cibele. Rhea Syluia, the
mother of Romulus and Rhemus. Rheda, a chariot. Rhedarius, a chariotman.
Rhegiam, a city on the bordure of Italy toward Sicile: also an other city
not far from Parma. Rheginus, a man of the city of Rhegium in Calabre.
Rhemi, people in France, called also Rhemenses. Rhenones, cotes made of the
skynnes of beasts. Rhenus, a noble river in Germania, called the Rheyne.
Rhenense vinum, Rheynisshe wine. Rhenenses, people dwelling on the river of
Rheyne. Rheon, Reubarbe. Rhesus, king of Thracia, which came to the aid of
the Troianes, and was slain of Diomedes: of whom a river about Troy was
called Rhesus. Rheti, a people in Italy. Rhetia, a countraye in Germany, which
some men do suppose to be Bauaria, or Beuer, called in Duche, Berue. Rhetor,
oris, he that teaches Rhetorike. Rhetorica, Rhetorike, or the craft of
eloquence. Rhetoricor, cari, to speak Rhetorike. Rhetorice, like a
Rhetorician. Rhetus, a gyaunt, whom Dionyse, being turned into a lion,
slew. Rhetoricus, an orator, or a man cunnyng in the craft of eloquence.
Rhetorisso, are, to speak in the form of Rhetorike. Rheuma, a rewme or
distillation of humors. Rheumatismus, the disease of rheum. Rhibis, a bremble
called Raspys. Rhinoceron, ontis, a best that has an horn in his nose, which
naturally is enemy to the Olyphant: it is also an oil vessel, out of the
which oil is dropped. Rhinocerotis nasum habere, is said of them that he
witty. Iuuenesque, senesque, Et pueri na sum, Rhinocerotis habent, Young men,
Horatius.
old men, And children, and all be witty. Rhodanus, a river in France, called
the Rone. Rhodia, a kind of vynes. Rhodites, a certain precyouse stone, of
the color of a rose. Rhodope, a mountain in Thracia. Rhodos, an I Will called
Rodes. Rhodius, of the Rodes. Plini.
Rhododaphne, and Rhododendros, a tree, having leaves like to an almonde tree,
but greatter and fatter seeds, open like a horn, which has in them wulle like
purple silk, a long root, salt in taste, it grows in watery places.
Rhodonia, a gardyn of roses. Rhodophone, that part of Syria, that goes over
the mountain of Taurus. Rhodopeius, a, um, pertaining to the mountain, of
Rhodope. Rhombus, a figure four square, having the sides equal, the corners
crooked. it is also a fysh called a Birt: also a spynnynge wheel or turn.
Rhoeas, when the corners of the eyes are open, so that there do still from
them continual dropes. Rhomphea, a sword. Rhoetus, a mountain of Troy,
where ^ax Thelamonius was buried. Rhoeton, wine made of pomegranettes.
Rhopalon, a water lyly, called communely Nenuphar. Rhoxia, a countraye by
Polonia. Rhoxalani, people on the north part, of the river of Danubius, or
Danowe. Rhureni, a people in France called Rhodes. Rhymnus, a river.
Rhyndacus, a river, which runs in to the sea called Pontus. Rhyparographus,
a paynter of tryfles, a Stayner. Rhytion, a vessel like to a moon. Rhythmus,
number or at meny in speakinge.
R, ANTE I.
RIca, a garment of purple, hemmed or purfled. also a kerchief, which women do
wear. Ricinus, and Ricinum, every garment that is four square. also it is a
kind of Cucumbres. also an herb like a fygge tree, but less, having leaves
like to a plane tree. Ricinium, and Ricinum, a cloak, whereof part was cast
over a man's sholder. Ricula, a handekerchief. Rictus, and Rictum, a grynnynge
or scorneful opening of the mouth: also the form of the vysage, when a man
grenneth, or a dog brawleth. Rideo, risi, ridere, to laughe: also to skorne
or mock. Ridibundus, da, dum, that lawgheth much. Ridica, a proppe, wherewith
a vine, or other like thing is holden up. Ridiculate, a thing to laughe at.
Ridiculum, idem. also a mock. Ridiculus, a man whom men do mock or lawghe
at. Ridicularius, a, um, idem quod Ridiculum. Ridicule, folyshly. Ridiculosus,
a, um, idem quod Ridiculus. Ridiculose, folyshly to be lawghed at. Rigeo, gui,
gere, to be fervently cold, alsoo to be hard or styffe. Rigesco, scere, idem
quod Rigeo. Rigide, styffely, sharply, cruelly. Rigidus, da, dum, cold,
hard, styffe, sharp or cruel. Rigo, are, to make weate, or to water a garden
or field. Rigor, Rigoris, cold, hardenesse, styfenesse. Riguus, a, um, that
may be easyly weate or watered. Rima, a chynke, or kleft in wood or stone,
where it is not close joined. Rimula, a little chynke or cleft. Rimas agere, to
be clouyn or chynked, as timber or bourdes are with lyenge in the wind. Rima^
inuenire, to find an excuse, Plautus in Cur. and in Casina.
or mean to escape. Rimor, aris, ari, to search diligently, also to kleue as
timber does. Rimosus, a, um, full of kleftes or chynkes. Ringo, xi, gere, to
grynne or show the teeth, as a dog does when he will bark or byte. also to
be angry, to brawle, to bark. Ripa, a water bank. Riparia, a bird which
breeds in water banks. Ripae, seu Ripei, mountains in Archadia. Riphaei,
mountains in Scythia. Riscus, a cofer covered with lether: also a little
wyndowe. Risibilis, le, that which can lawghe. Risus, laughter. Risus
sardonius, a lawghter without mirth, as of them that be mad or cruel, such
as Irish men use when they be angry. Rite, dyrectely, truly, even as it should
be. Rituales, books, wherein the form of ceremonies, and old manners and
customs are written. Ritus, tus, an approved custom. Riuales, they which
equally do love one womanne, or be woars together. also they, whose lands be
divided by a river or brook: also they which dwell upon ryuers. Riualitas,
tatis, envy or obseruaunce betwixt the lovers of one woman. Plautus in Asinar.
Riuinus, a wower, idem quod riualis. Riuus, a river or broke. Riuulus, a
little broke. Riuo, are, is to go to watryng, as bestis do. Rixa, a braulynge
contention. Rixose, brawling. No. Mar.
Rixosus, a stryuer or brawler. Rixor, aris, ari, and rixo, to contend with
brawling.
R, ANTE O.
RObigalia, the Ceremonies pertaining to Robigus, the preseruatour of corn.
Robiginosus, a, um, much blasted. Robigo, was honored of the Romans for a
goddess, whom they supposed might preserve their corn from blastinge. it is
also that vice in corn called blasting. Robigus, whom the old Romans named
the god, that preserved corn from blastynge. Roboraria, places, which ar
paled about. Roboreus, ea, eum, of oken timber. Roboro, are, to fortify.
Roboses, the old writers used for robore, an oak. Robur, roboris, hard oak. It
is also strength and hardenes of the body. sommetyme the strength or hardness of
any thing generally Robus, old writers called read of color. Also al manner
of matter, which had many read veins, was called Robus. It is also a kind of
wheat, that yeldeth fair meal, which we now called red wheat. Robustus,
ta, tum, strong and hard. Rodo, si, dear, to gnawe as a mouse or other like
beast does. sometime to detracte or backbyte. Festus
Rodus, da, dum, a thing imperfect or rude, vnpolyshed, unwrought. Rogamen,
minis, a desire. Rogatarii, Notaryes, which required the parties, that each of
them should promise. Plautus.
Rogator, rogatoris, a beggar from door to door. Rogito, tare, to entreat
or demand, to inquyre often, to ask for a thing. Rogo, are, to require, to
pray, to inquyre, to ask of one, to inacte. Rogare populum, to treat with the
people. Quint Ilia.
Rogare sacramento, to swear oone, or to give to him an oath. Rogatio. was
among the Romans, when the Tribunes, which were the heed officers of the
people, were content that any act should pass, which was made by the
senate, or by the same Tribunes devised. Rogus, a great fire, wherein deed
bodies were bourned. Roma, the city of Rome. Romanensis, he that comes from
an another country, and dwells at Rome. Romania, is a country called
Thracia. Romanus, a Romayne. Romanus, na, number, of Rome. Romandui, Normandes.
Romula, a tree, under the which Romulus and Remus were found. Romuleus, a,
um, and Romulidus, da, dum, of Romulus. Romulus, the first king of Romans.
Ronchisso, are, to route or short. Ronchus, a routynge. sometime a scorn.
Ronchisonus, he that routeth or snorteth. Rorarii milites, men in the
vauntgarde, or a forward of a battle. Roratio, is a disease in vynes, by the
occasyon whereof the chief grapes do fall away. Roresco, scere, to be washed
with dew. Rorifacio, cere, to spryncle. Rores, dewes. Roro, are, to dew, or
drop down like dew. Rorulentus, ta, tum, full of dew. Ros, roris, dew.
Rosa, a Rose. Rosaceus, a, um, of roses. Aqua Rosacea, Rosewater. Rosalia,
garlandes of Roses. Rosarium, a gardeyn or bed of Roses. Rosetum, a gardeyne
of Roses. Roseus, a, um, of a rose. Rosidus, da, dum, werte with dew.
Rosmarinum, Rosemary, or a lyttel snoute. Rostellum, a little beak or bylle
of a byrd. Rostra, rorum, rostris, was a place in Rome before the court callid
Hostilia, wherein was a pulpite, in which the orators of Rome were wont to
stand, when they preched to the people, or declared any matter, of the which
proceeded this word Pro rostris, in the pulpit, or at the bar. Rostrum, a
beak of a bird, a snowte of a beast or fyshe, also the stem of a ship or
boot. Rota, a wheel. Roto, tare, to turn a thing like a whele. Rotula, a
little whele. Rotella, idem. Rotunde, roundly, aptely, elegantly, handsomely,
proprely in words. Rotundus, tunda, dum, round, sommetyme well compacte or
facioned. Ore rotundo loqui, to express much in few words.
R, ANTE V.
RVbefacio, cere, to make read. Rubefio, fieri, to be made read. Rubellae,
read grapes. Rubellum vinum, clarette wine. Rubeo, bear, to be read. Ruber,
bra, brum, read. Rubesco, scere, to be read. Rubeta, a tode. Rubetum, a
busshy close. Rubeus, ea, eum, read. Rubens, idem. Rubi, borum, a town in
Campania. Rubia, mader, wherewith clothe is dyed. Rubicon, conis, a river in
Italye, which dyuideth Italy from Lombardy. Rubicundus, da, dum, ruddy.
Rubidus, da, dum, a swarte read. Alsoo rowghe or course, as bredde, having
much branne. Rubigino, are, to ruste. Rubiginosus, a, um, rustye. Rubigo,
ginis, ruste. Rubor, oris, redness. Rubrica, red chalk, or ruddell, wherewith
sheep are marked. Rubricera, rosette color. Rubrus, a, um, read. Rubricatus,
ta, tum, colored with read, or ruddelyd, as sheep are. Rubus, a bremble.
Ructo, are, to belke or break wind up ward. Ructito, tare, to break wind
often. Ructuatio, idem quod ructus. Ructus, belkyng or breking wynd upward.
Rude donari, to be discharged of attenda^ce proprely in wars. Rude^ accipere,
has the same signification. Rudens, it is, a cabell of a ship. Ruderarium, a
rangynge syeue. Rudero, rare, to lay on old stoones and rubbell. Rudero, are,
to daube or lay on mortar. Ruderatus, ta, tum, where much rubbyshe lies.
Rudetum, a place, where lies much rubbyshe or rubbell. Also land, which
has lyen^ley, and is newly put in tylthe. Rudiarij, they which are dyscharged
of fighting with swords, as they which were calledde Gladiatores, that
openly faught, one with an other, to animate the Romans, with shedyng of
their blood. They be also bodgers or ame^ders of old garments, also seuiars,
or makers of sieues. Rudicula, a pot stycke. Rudiae, arum, a city in the
further part of Italy, ioynynge to Apulia. Rudimentum, the first teching of
children. Rudio, dire, to teache one, which is vnlernid. Rudis, a rod or
yerde, which was given to sword players, when they came to.lx. years old, in
token that they were set at liberty. sometime liberty from labor. Rudis,
de, rude, imperfect, new, unwrought Rudus, ruderis, shardes or pieces of stones
broken and scattered, rubbell or rubbyshe of old houses. Ruditas, rudenes,
lack of lernyng or wit. Rudo, rudi, rudere, to braye like an ass. It is
sometime spoken of a man. sometime of a woman. Rufeo, and rufesco, scere, to be
sommewhat read. Rufo, fare, to make read. Rufuli, certain Captains made by
the consul, who afterward were called Rutuli. Rufus, a, um, somewhat read.
Ruga, a wrynkle, or playte. Rugio, giui, gire, to rore. Rugo, gare, to be
playted or wrynkled. Rugo, xi, gere, to belke. Ruina, ruin, extreme decay.
Ruinosus, a, um, ruinous, in decay. Rulla, the staff, wherewith the ploughman
cleanses his culter. Ruma, was of the old writers callydde a teate, also it is
the throat bolle. Rumen, the dewlappe of a beast. alsoo a place in the belly, a
panche. Rumentum, a brastynge out, an aposteme that brasteth out of the
flesh. Ruma, a goddess, whom the paynyms did suppose to be beneficial to
women's breasts, and to suckynge chylderne. Rumigare, to chewe the cudde.
Rumigero, rare, to carry tidings. Ruminatio, a chewynge of the cudde, as a
beast does. Ruminalis ficus, a fig tree, under the which it is supposed
that a wolf gave suck to Romulus and Remus. Rumino, minare, and Ruminor, ari,
to chewe the cudde. Also to call eftesones to remembrance. Rumex, icis, wild
sorell. also a weapon like to a spear. Rumifero, are, and rumigero, rare, to
bear or bring tidings. Rumis, a teate. Rumito, to bear tidings.
Rumigerulus, a teller of tidings. Rumo, are, to give the teate to a child.
Rumor, rumoris, tidings, a rumoure, a bruyte. Rumpo, rupi, rumpere, to break,
to make werye, Rumpere moras, to make haste. Rumpotinus, a busshe, which
grows in France, of whom Columella writes, that no corn should be sown
within twentye foot thereof. Rumpotinetum, the place where such bushes do
grow. Rumusculus, a little rumor or brute. Rumula, a little teate. Runa, a
weapon, sommetyme used in France. Runca, a saw, wherewith timber is sawen.
Runcatio, weedynge. Runcina, a whypsawe, wherewith timber is sawen, it is also a
bushesythe, or bylle, to cut busshes. Runcino, are, to saw timber. Runco,
care, to wede or pull up. Runsor, oris, oone of the names of Pluto, called god
of Hell. Vergil.
Ruere, is also to overthrow, to ru^ne forth heedlynge. Quo moriture ruis,
maioraque uiribus audes? Whyther runnest thou hedlynge to be slain, and
attemptest things above thy puissannces Also to lift up. Et ruit atram, ad
coelu^ picea crassus caligine nubem, Ver. geor.
And being thycke, it lyfted up to heaven a cloud, as black as pytche.
sometime it sygnyfieth to make a great noise. Ruit arduus aethey, The high
firmamente rumbled, or made a great noise. Ruo, rui, ruere, to fall, to pour
out, to be deceived, to subuerte, to make plain, to pluck up, to break a
sonder, to throw down. Rupes, be hills, banks, or rocks: so stepe down,
as no manne may clymme them. In leg.xii. tabularum
Rupicapra, a wild goote. Rupicias, for damnum dederis, thou shalt pay or
yield damages. Ruptus, rupta, ruptum, broken or braste, weryed, torn or rent.
Ruralis, le, rusticall, or of the vyllage. Rurestris, re, of the countreye, not
of the city or town. Ruricola, a husband man. Rurigena, borne in the
country, out of a city or great town. Ruro, rare, to do after the country
facion. Ruror, raris, rari, to dwell in the country, or out of the city.
Rursus, and Rursum, eftesones or bakwarde, on the other part. Rus, ruris, the
countreye, out of the City, where as housbandrye is used and exercysed.
Ruscum, a wande. Ruspor, ari, to search dilygently. It is proprely to shrape,
as an hen does, when she seeks for meat. Russus, and russeus, a, um,
read. Rustica, a bird like a partryche, but he has a longer byll.
Rusticanus, na, number, rustycall, of the country or vyllage. Rustice,
rustycally, vncourteysly, rudely. Rusticane, idem. Rusticarius, caria, carium,
pertaining to husbandrye. Rusticatim, for rustice, an Aduerbe, churlysshelye.
Rusticitas, tatis, carlysshenes, sommetyme fearfulness. Et si rusticitas non
vetat, Ouidius.
ipsa rogat, And if that foolyshe basshefulnesse let her not, she makethe
request. Rusticor, caris, cari, to dwell in the country, or exercise
husbandrye. Rusticus, ca, rusticum, rustycall, vplandyshe, homely, without
curteysye. Rusticus, is also the propre name of a man. Ruta, Rewe, callydde
alsoo herb Grace. It is among the lawyers all that is dygged out of the
ground, as stone, cole, leadde, and other mettalle. Ruta and caesa, All be it
Mutius does say, that in Rutis and caesis are those things, that be not fast
in the ground, nor are any part of the building or the covering of a house.
Perchance we might name them heir lomes. Rutabulum, a cool rake, to make
clean an oven. Rutaceus, a, um, of rewe. Pliniu^.
Rutatus, ta, tum, made of rewe. Rutatio, and rutus, for ructa^io, belkynge.
Rutellum, a little mattocke. Rutilo, lare, te shine. Ruto, tare, for ructo,
Fla^. Cicero.
to belke or break wind upward. Rutor, idem. Rutrum, a mattocke. Rutum, idem.
Rutuba, trouble. Id postea uiderimus, Varro.
nunc sumus in rutuba, We will afterward see, now be we in trouble.
Rutubatri, men that dygge with mattockes. Rutulus, la, lum, a brighte red like to coals that be kyndled. Rutupinum promontorium, a goore or elbowe of
land in England, lyenge into the sea, which I suppose is in Norfolk.
SABA, a city in Ethiope. Sabaei, people in Araby. Sabbatarius, he that keeps
the sabbath day. Sabbatu^, the day of rest from labor. Sabbath, in the
plurelle number, in the hebrewe tunge, signifies of hosts, or armies, or
powers. Sabath, a propre name, whereof comes Sabatheni, the name of a people.
Sabbatismus, a vacation after labors. Sabbatizare, to keep sabbat day. Sabe,
in the tunge of Siria, is the month of February. Sabelli, people, which dwell
in the mountains between the Sabines and Marsi, in Italye. Sabim, among the
Arrabiane does signifye god. Sabina, a weapon like a bore spear. Sabini,
people in Italy. Sabiusa, a gate at Rome, out of the which men went to the
Sabines. Sabora, a city of Araby. Sabucus, an elder tree. Sabuletum, a gravel
pytte. Sabulum, greatte gravel. Sabulosus, a, um, grauelly. Saburra, lastage,
or balese, wherewith ships are even poysed, to go vpryght, which is commonly
of gravel. Sabur^i, a ^ynde of sacrifice. Saburro, rare, to balese a ship.
Sacal, a kind of ambre found in Egypt. Saccarius, he that bears a sack.
Saccarum, sugar. Saccellare, to apparelle or amend wynes put into sackes.
Sacciperium, a powche. Sacconia, a clothe to wype a thing with. a napkyn, also
a territory. Sacculus, and saccellus, a little sack. Sacer mons, an hylle by
Rome, an other by Galatia, wherein gold is found. Sacerdoralis, le,
pertaining to a priest. Sacon, among the Indians, sygnifieth a bright purple
color. Sacondion, a precious, stoone of a bryghte purple color. Saccularius,
a crafty deceyuour, which in selling of grain out of sackes, will convey
away part. Saccus, a sack. Sacculus, a bag. Sacellum, a chapelle. Sacer,
cra, crum, holy: sommetyme cursed, detestable. Sacer ignis, a sycknes, wherein
is vehement inflammation and burning of the body. Sacer locus, a place
consecrate or dedicate. Sacer morbus, the falling syckenesse. Sacerdos, dotis,
a priest. Sacerdotium, priesthode. sometime a benefyce or spiritual
promotion. Sacra uia, a street in Rome, where peace was made between Romulus
and Tacius, and through the which the vanquyshers passed with their triu^ph
unto the capitol. Sacramenta, is taken for men of war. Iuuenall^
Sacramentum, an oath among us christen men, it signifies a sign, wherein is
contained a divine mystery, and is called a sacrament. Sacramento contendere,
to swear. Sacramento teneri, to be sworn. Sacrarium, a sextrie or vestrie,
wherein are kept things hallowed, and relykes. Sacratae leges, laws, in the
which it is enacted, that who so does offend against them, is accursed.
Sacratio, a consecration. Sacratius, more holy. Sacrator, he that does
consecrate. Sacrificium, sacrifyce. Sacrifico, care, to do sacrifice, to
consecrate to ask forgyuenes of god. Sacrificulus, a priest. Sacrilegium,
theft, or taking away of things hallowed, called Sacrilege. Sacrilegissimus, an
errant thief in stelynge of things hallowed. Sacrilegus, he that violently
takes away or steals things hallowed, or things unhallowed out of a holy
place. Sacrimum, must or new wine. Sacriscrinius, he that keeps the kings
letters or Records, concerning the Crown, or books of great affairs.
Sacrium, a kind of aumbre, which comes out of Scithia. Sacro, crare, to
dedicate or halowe. Sacrosanctus, ta, tum, consecrate or halowid with a solemn
oath taken. Sacrum, any thing dedicate to god. Also sacrifice. sometime a
temple or church. Paulus Iureconsultus. Sunt aurem sacrilegi, qui publica
sacra compilarint. Also sacra do signifye holy words. also charms. Sacrum
Promontorium, a great mountain or rock in the southwest part of Spain,
lyenge on the sea, called now, Capesainct Vincent. Sadducei, men of a special
seete among the Jews, that believed not of any resurrection, or that there be
any angels or spiritis. Saeculu^, is proprely the space of a hundred years: it
is commonly taken for a space of time, wherein one facion of the world has
continued. Saepe, oftentimes. Saepenumero, saepiuscule, saepicule, idem.
Saepius, more often. Saepissime, very often. Saeuio, uiui, ire, to be very
angrye, to do valyauntly, to be cruel, or exercise tyranny. Saeue, cruelly.
Saeuirer, rudely* Magis cogito, saeuiter, blanditer ue alloquar, I think more,
where I may speak to him rudely, or gentylly. Saeuitia, and saeuitudo,
cruelty. Saeuus, ua, um, cruelle, horrible. sometime angry, valyant, mighty.
Saga, a wise or subtle woman, also a witch. Sagaperium, a gum or rosyn, which
runs out of a kyxe or tree, called Ferula. Sagaris, a river. Sagaria, the
craft to make clokes to wear on harneyse. Sagarius, a seller of such clokes.
Sagatus, apparayled in a soldiers cloak. Sagax, acis, wyttye. Sagaces canes,
yernynge hounds. Sagacitas, wyttynesse or sharpenes of wit. Sagaciter,
wyttyly. Sagda, a grene stone, which the Caldees have made fast to their
hands. Sagena, a greatte net. Sagimen, and saginatio, nouryshynge.
Saginarius, a, um, that which is franked or made fat. Sagina, meat,
wherewith all thing is fatted. sometime superfluous fat. Saginarium, a place
wherein any thing is franked or made fat. Sagino, are, to make fat. Sagio,
ui, ire, to perceive quickly or sharply. Sagitta, an arow, also the top of a
twygge or rod. Sagittarius, an archer. It is also one of the xii. signs
among the sterres. Sagitto, tare, to shoot. Sagma, a pack saddell, or
sumpter saddell. also an heap. Sagmen, minis, grass, plucked up with the
earth, which in the old time the ambassadors of the Romans did, when they
denounced wars to other people. Sagum, a soldiers clooke. Sagulum, idem.
Saguntus, a city in Spayn, which for the constant fydelitie, kept to the
Romans, was distroyed by Hanniball. Saguntina fames, extreme famyne, a
proverb made of the famyne, which was in the city of Saguntus, when
Hanniball besyeged it. Sais, a city of Egypt, where is one of the entries
into the river of Nilus, the entry or port is called Saiticum. Sal, salis,
salt. sometime it is put for wisdom, mirth. Sales, quycke or sharp sentences,
iestynges. sometime it sygnifieth the sea. Sala, a river in Germanye. Salaces,
Vergilius.
water that ryseth out of a quycke spring. Salacia, was called goddess of
water. Salaconia, pride. Salacones, they which are proud. Salamandra, a
beast in figure like to a lysarde, full of spots, which being in the fire,
does extincte it, and is not burned. Salamin, Salamis, mina, an I Will by
Athenes. Salaminius, a, um, of that isle. Salamoniacus, a kind of salt found
under sand, which is like to alume, and is medicynable, in dissoluynge and
purging of fleume. Salanga, a very high hylle between great Brytayne and
Irelande, now callid our ladies hylle. Salapusius, may be callid a merry
jesting boy. It was a name given to Caluus an orator, which being of a childs
personage, used much jesting and tauntynge meryly. Salaria uia, an high way,
by the which salt was carried to Rome. Salarium, wages given to servants.
Salarius, a salter. Salarius, a, um, pertaynyng to salt. Salax, acis,
lecherouse. Salebrae, places which are not plain. Salebrosus, a, um,
vnplayne, where a man can not goo, except he do leap. Salentinum, a country
yt in Italy. Salentini, a people in Italye. Salgama, things condite or
conserved, as pears, figs, grapes, and other like. Sali, a kind of birds,
which be greatte breders: as partriches or hens, I suppose them to be
hethecockes. Saliares coena, a banquet or supper made by the priests of Mars.
Saliares uirgines, maidens, which were with the priests of Mars, and did
sacrifyce with the bishops, wearyng on them cote armures, and bysshoppes myters
on their heedes. Saliaris, re, pertaining to the pristis of Mars. Salicastrum,
a kind of wild vine, rounnynge upon wyllowe trees. Salicetum, and salictum, a
place where wyllowes grow. Salientes, the cocks or pipes of cundites, out of
the which water spouteth. Salignus, na, number, of wyllowe or wythy. Salii, the
priests of Mars. Salillum, a little salt seller. Salina, a place, where
salt is made. Salinae, narum, a city in Sicile. Salinator, the name of a
noble man of Rome. Salinacidus, and salnacidus, a, um, that which is salt in
taste. Salinum, a salt seller. Salio, iui, ire, to salt or powder. Salio,
iui, ij, ire, to leap. Salitura, powdrynge or saltynge. Salitus, ta, tum,
salted. Saliuo, are, to lay salve. Saliua, and saliuum, spettell. Saliunca, a
plant, having long leaves, somewhat yelowe, and a yelowe flower, and grows
short, and has many roots. It is taken for the Spikenarde, that grows in
France, and is commonly used. Salisi, people in the mountains of Alps,
confynes to the Swycers, and the people called Boii. Saliuarius, he that lays
salve. Salix, icis, a wyllowe or wythye. Salmatis, a fountain in Caria.
Salmacia, a pray gotten without labor. Salmacidus, da, dum, that which
sauoureth of salt. Salmo, onis, a fyshe called Samond. Salmonius, the king of
Elides, which taking foolyshely upon him, to have divine honors done unto
him, and would seem to cast lyghtnynges, like unto Jupiter, being overthrown
with lyghtning, was cast into hell. Sal nitrum, salt peter, which is put
into gunne powder. Sallo, lere, to powder with salt. Salo, a river called also
Bibilis, wherewith iron is tempred, and made stronger. Solomon, and Solomon,
monis, is interpreted peasible, the name of a king of Jews, the son of
king David, who exceded all men in wisdom and knowledge, and never the less
was by dotage on women brought to ydolatrie. Salomonius, a, um, of Solomon.
Salon, a country of Bithinia, very commodious for the feeding of cattle.
Salone, a city in Liburnia between Dalmatiam and Illiriam. Salpa, a fyshe
which will not be sodden, except it be beaten, as stockefyshe is. Salpyga, a
kind of emotes or pysmeres. Salsamentatius, he that sells sauce.
Salsamentarius, a, um, pertaynyng to sauce. Vas salsamentarium, a vesselle,
whereinto sauce is put. Salsamentum, sauce. Salsedo, saltenesse. Salsicortex,
a tree, that bears maste, which nothing will eat, except only swyne.
Salsilago, and salsugo, ginis, a salt lycour. Salsura, meresawce or bryne.
Salsus, a, um, salt in taste. Saltabundus, da, dum, that which leapeth or
daunseth. Saltatio, daunsynge. Saltator, and saltatrix, a daunser. Saltatorius,
a, um, pertaynyng to daunsyng. Ludus saltatorius, a scoole of daunsynge.
Saltatrix, and saltatricula, a daunsynge wench. Saltatus, tus, daunsynge.
Saltem, at the least way. Saltiae, people ioynynge to the sea called Pontus
Euxinus. Saltim, uel saltuatim, by leapes. Saltito, tare, to daunse, to leap
often. Salto, tare, to daunse. Saltuarius, a keeper of a wod, a wodwarde.
Saltuosus, a, um, full of woddes. Saltus, a thycke wodde, also a leap.
Saluator, toris, a savior, he that keeps or saves a thing from destruction
or loss. Saluber, bris, bre, wholesome, hole. Salubrior, ius, Saluberrimus, a,
um, more wholesome, most wholesome. Salubriter, holsomely. Salubritas, health.
Salve, and Salueto, and saluete, god speed you. ye be welcome, sometime
contrary, farewell, God be with you. Salueo, ere, to be saufe, or speed well,
to be well at ease. Salve. S. satis est mihi tuae salutis, nihil moror non
salueo, God speed. S. Plautus i^ trucule^.
It suffyseth me that thou art in health: but in few words I am not well at
ease. Saluia, an herb called sauge. Saluiatu^, a drench for a horse or other
be. Saluifico, care, to make safe, or to save. Saluo, are, to save. Saluebis
a meo Cicerone, my son Cicero commends him unto you. Ci. ad A^
Salua res est, the matter gothe well. Salum, the sea. Salus, lutis, health.
Salutarius, the forefynger. Salutatio, a salutation. Salutator, toris, a
saluter. Salutatorium cubiculum, a chamber, where men do stand and abide to
salute a prince or noble man in authority, called now a chamber of presence.
Salutem, in the old time was used for salte^. Salutem dicere, to salute or to
have recommendation to any man. Salutifer, ra, rum, wholesome. Salutaris, re,
wholesome. Salutaris digitus, the forefynger. Salutariter, in health. Salutiger,
he that brings recommendacions from another person. Saluto, tare, to salute,
as well at coming as at departinge: also to honor. Saluus, a, um, saulfe,
hole, sound, without damage or harm. ^^nius
Sam, for Eam, her. Samara, an hill in the east Ocea^ se, at the further end of
the mo^tayne called Caucasus. Samarobrinae, people in France, about Cambry.
Samaria, a countraye in Judea. Sambuca, an instrument of musyke, now called
doulcymers, an engyne of war, wherewith fortresses were assaulted. Sambucina,
a woman which plays on doulcymers. Sambuceus, a, um, of Elder or Alder tree.
Sambucus, an Elder or alder tree. Sambucistria, idem quod Sambucina. Samia,
vessels made in the I Will of Samos. Samius, a, um, of the I Will of Samos: the
old wrytars did use it for sharp, and Samiare, to whette or make sharp.
Samites, people of Samnium a contraye in Italy called now Aprurium. ^o. Mar.
Plautus.
Samium, a shell. Samiolum, a little shell. Samos, the name of an I Will in the sea, called Icarium. Samothracia, an I Will by Thracia in Greece. Sampsuchus, and
Sampsuchum, an herb called Maioram. Sanates, people dwelling about Rome.
Sancio, xi, cire, to consecrate, to make firm. Sancire leges, is to constitute
laws. Festus
Sancus, one of the names of Hercules. Sancte, firmly. Sanctificatio,
halowynge. Sanctifico, care, to halowe. Sanctitas, holiness. Sanctitudo, idem.
Sanctio, a law, a thing decreed and stablysshed. Sanctus, ta, tum, holy,
inviolable by a law, pure and clean, uncorrupted. Vir sanctus, a blessed man.
Sanctimoniales, Nuns. Sanctimonium, the profession of religious persons.
Sanctimonia, and Sanctitas, holiness, perfection. Sanctuarium, a place
consecrate or hallowed. Sandalium, a slyppar. Sandala, a spice called saunders.
Sandaraca, a color found in mines of silver, or gold, yelow ocker.
Sandaliotis, an I Will called now Sardinia. Sandaracinus, color made with yelowe
Ocker. Sandastros, and Sandaphorion, and Sandarison, and Sandassites, a
preciouse stone, having in a bright color yelowe speckes, and is called also,
Garamandita. Sandyx, dicis, an herb of a delicate odor, having a short
stalk, in the residue like to fenell. it is also a color called a bright
yelowe. Sandicinus color, idem. Sane, an aduerbe, which signifies, ye, or
certaynely, on gods name. Bellum sane difficile gessit, he fought a very
daungerouse battle. Sane vt vis, be it as thou will. Sane quam vtile, suerly
very profitable. Gelli.
Sane quidem, ye hardely. Ter. in An.
Nempe ergo aperte uis, quae restant me loqui? D. Sane quidem. But will thou
than that I shall tell plainly all the rest? D. ye hardely. Sanesco, scere,
to be or wax hole. Sanga, a river in Portugal. Sangaris, a river of Galatia,
which runnynge through Phrygia, falls into Propontis, the sea. Sanguen,
guinis, and Sanguis, guinis, blood. alsoo a tree, the bark whereof is of the
color of blood. Sanguineus, a, um, full of blood. also cruel. sometime of
sanguyne or bloody color. Sanguinolentus, idem. Sanguiculum, the blood of a
kyd or swyne, wherewith pouddynges are made. Sanguino, are, to bleed.
Sanguinaria, and Sanguinalis, an herb that stops blood. Sanguinarius,
cruel, blody. Sanguinolentus, idem. Sanguis, guinis, blood. Sanguisuga, a
worm, which is in standinge waters, and does sowke the blood of men or
beasts that come in to it. it is alsoo called Hirudo. Sanies, matter, corrupted
blood. Sanna, a scorn or mock. Sannio, onis, a dysarde in a play or
disguysynge: also he which in countenance, gesture, and manners is a fool.
Sanitas, tatis, health. Saniter, like a hole man. Sannaus, a river in Asia.
Sano, are, to heal. Sansa, the stone of an olyue. Sansucus, Maioram.
Sansucinus, a, um, of Maioram. Sancae, the stones of Olyues. Sa^terna, souldre,
wherewith gold is soudred. Santones, people in France. Sanus, na, number, hole,
wholesome. Sanitas, tatis, health. Sapa, must or new wine sodden to the half
deal. Saperda, a dunge hylle. Sapide, sauourely. Sapidius, more sauourely.
Sapidus, da, dum, sauoury, well seasoned. Sapiens, it is, wise. Sapientia, the
kunnynge of things divine and humayne, wisdom. Sapio, sapui, sapere, to taste
or savor, to feel, to be wise, to have a right opinion. Plautus in P^eudo^o.
Plautus in Epidi^o.
Sapio rem, I know what I have to do. Sapiunt male, they be ill aduysed.
Sapit hic pleno pectore, he is meruaylouse wise. Plautus in T^^n Plautus in
Persa.
Sapit plus, he has more wit. Sapit satis, he is wise enough. Sapis multum
ad geniu^, thou know how to make good chere. Sapor, ^ris, a savor, a
taste. Sapphiratus, a Saphyr full of spots. Sapphirinus, na, number, of a
Sapphire. Sapphirus, a stone called a saphyre. Sappho, a woman poet. Sappinus,
the lower part of a fyrre tree, which is without knottes. Saprum, a drink,
made with salt and the fruit called Sorba, which helps men that have the
colyke. Sapros, vynewed. Sapsa, of old writers was used for ipsa. Sarcasmos, a
manner of jesting or scoffing bytyngely. Sarcimen, a seame. Sarcina, a trusse
or pack, or fardell. sometime it is taken for an unprofitable burden. Sarcinas
colligere, is proprely of men of war, when they remove or depart from
their camp. Plautus in Mostell.
Sarcinas, atis, for sarcina. Sarcinator, a taylour. Sarcinatrix, tricis, a
shepster, or seamester. Sarcinae, all stuff that is closed or shut up in
coffers. Sarcino, are, to lade. sometime to sow. Sarcio, ciui, cire, to make
hole again, to amend a thing decayed or appaired, to make amends. Sarcion,
a stone of carnacion color. Ser. Sulp.
Sarcito, pay the damages or costs. Sarcte, hole. Sarcophagus, a sepulcher.
Sarculo, are, to rake. Sarculum, a rake. Sarda, a red stone, wherein seals ar
graue^. Sardanapalus, a king of Assiria, monstruouse in all kinds of lechery,
and therefore was slain of one of his lords as he satte spynnynge among
harlottes. Sardinia, an Ild in the sea called Ligusticum, by Geane. Sardis, a
city in Lidia. Sardo, for intelligo, I understand. Sardoa, an herb like to
smallage, Neulu^.
which grows in Sardinia, whereof if a man eat, he shall grenne and make
countenance of laughing, and so dye. Sardonius risus, a grennynge or laughyng
without cause, a long laughter. Sardonychatus, having apparayle garnished
with the stone called Sardonix. Sardonychus, idem quod Sardonyx. Sardus, and
Sardinensis, and Sardous, a, um, of Sardinia. Sardonyx, onychis, a stone of the
color of a man's nail. Sarepta, a town in Siria, where Hely the prophet
was borne. Sargacae, people in the north part of the world, ioynynge to the
greatte mere of Meotis. Sargus, a fyshe being in the sea of Egypt. Sari, an
herb, growing in waters, having an hard root, and wounden, necessary for
smythes. Sarissa, a long spear. Saronicus, a bosom of the sea against
Isthmus. Sarmatia, all that great country, wherein is contained Russia,
Liuonia, and Tartaria. Sarmata, a man of that country. Sarmenta, twigges or
shroude of trees cut of. Sarmentitius, tia, um, made of twigs or small
boughs. Sarnus, a river in Campania. Sarpa, a vine cut of, shradde.
Sarpedon, the king of Lisia, which came to the aid of the Troyanes against
the Greeks. Sarpo, pere, to cleanse or make clean. Sarra, an I Will called
sometime Tyrus: also the wife of Abraham. Sarra, a city in Epire. Sarranus,
na, number, of that city. Sarraballa, plurali numero, a word of Caldey,
signifienge breches. Sarraca, the name of two cities, whereof the tone is in
Media, the the other in Felici Arrabia, or the rich Arrabie. Sarracum, a certain
carre, wherein wodde or stones be carried. Sarranae uestes, garments of purple.
Sarrastes, people in Campania. Sarrio, rire, to wede corn. Sarritor, and
sartor, toris, a weder of corn. Sarritura, and sartura, weedyng of corn.
Sarsina, an old city in Italy, where Plautus the writer of comedies was
borne. Sarta tecta, houses letten to certain persons to keep them always
repaired suffyciently, for a certain sum of money. Sarta tecta locare, to
set out houses at a price certain to be repaired. Ci. in Ver.
Sarta tecta exigere, to charge a man with reparations. Sartago, ginis, a
fryenge pan. Sarte, hole. Sarticum, an entry in to the river of Nilus.
Sartor, and sarritor, an harower or weder of corn. Sartum tectum habere, to
keep hoole and sound, or uncorrupted or hurt. Sartutillus, the bealye of a
swyne stuffed with meal. Sas, old writers used for suas. Saso, an isle five
miles from the city of Brundusium in the realm of Naples. Sason, a river.
Sat, for satis, enough. Quantum sat^est, asmoche as is sufficient. Sat habet,
it is sufficient. Sat scio, I know well enough. Satagitae, people in the
country now called Tartarie. Satago, gi, gere, to be dylygent, to do with
speed, to be busy about a thing. Satanas, is interpreted an adversary, by the
which name the devil was called, because that he was aduersarye to Christ.
Alsoo what so ever is contrary to peace, is called Satanas. Satarchae, people
in Scythia, which excluded from them the use of gold and silver. Satelles,
litis, one retained to guard a ma^s person. Also a catchepoll or baylyff, that
does attache men. Satellitium, a guard, the office of such a person or
offycer. Saterona, a beast, which does live some time in water, sometime on
land. Satias, sacietie, fulness or werynesse in much using of a thing,
sometime it signifies abundaunce. Hi, saltibus occupatis, externorum agros
inuasere, ^^^ustius.
frumentique ex inopia graui, satias facta, After that they had gotten the
woddes or forestes, they invaded the lands of them that were borderers, and
from scarsitie of corn, they happened to have their fylle or haboundaunce.
Satiabilis, le, that which may be easyly satisfied. Satietas, tatis, a
sacietie or fullness. Terentius.
Satin, for satisne, Satin sana es? Art thou not well at ease? Satin saluae?
Be all things well? Satio, tionis, the act of sowinge of corn. Satio, tiare,
to satiate or fylle, which has relation not only to the body and senses, but
also to the mind. Satis, enough, as much as does need. Satis acceptio, a
covenant, whereby a man is bounden, and sureties with him. Satisaccipere, to
take joint suertyes. Satisdatio, and satisdatum, dati, the suertie or bond,
whereby men are bounden for an another, for perfourmance of couenaunte, or the
couenantour and suerties with him. Satisdator, he that is bounden for
perfourmaunce of covenant Satisdo, dare, to put in sureties for perfourmance of
couenantes. also to be bounden with suerties for the performynge of
couenauntes. Satisfacio, cere, to satisfye. Satisfactio, satisfaction.
Satispraestatio, idem. Satis praesto, tare, idem quod satis dare, to find
surety. Satis, superque, enough and to much. Satius, the comparatiue degree
of satis, it sygnifyeth better. Satiuus, a, u^, that may be sown, or is sown.
Satnois, a river of Frigia. Sator, toris, he that sows corn. Satrapa, among
the Persians were as dukes and Earls be here. Satrapia, a province, Duchy, or
County. Satullo, are, idem quod saturare, to saciate or fill superfluousely.
Satur, turis, full fed, sometime abundant or plentuouse. Saturcia, an herb
called Sauery. Saturio, onis, he that has eaten enough, Plautus in Persa.
and to much. Saturitas, fertility, or plentuousnes. Alsoo abundance in
excess. Saturnalia, five days assigned to Saturn in December, wherein men
used to feast one an other, and to send mutual presents. Saturnalitium,
pertayninge to the ceremonies of Saturnus. Saturnia, was the name of a town.
Alsoo high places were called Saturnia. Saturnius, a, um, of Saturnus.
Saturniniani, were heretics, which affyrmed, that only seven aungelles made
the world against the conscience of god the father. Saturninus, a mountain at
Rome, which was afterward called Tarpeius. Saturnus, one of the seven
planettes: alsoo a god of the paynyms. Saturo, are, to saturate or fyl with any
thing superfluousely, most commonly in eating. Saturum, and Satyrum, a city
of Calabria, not far from Tarentum. Satus, ta, tum, sown or begotten. Satus,
tus, the sowynge, also sede. Satyra, a matter or poesye made in the rebuke of
some astate or person. Florus.
Satyria, a crow. Satyricus, and satyrus, a maker of such mattiers.
Satyriacum, an image of Priapus. Satyriasis, a syckenes, whereby the membre of a
man stands always without appetite or dilectation. Satyrica, was a comedye,
wherein Satyrs were brought in. Satyrice, an aduerbe, which sygnyfyeth
sharply and with reproach. Satyrus, a beast having the heed of a man, and the
body of a got. Satyrion, an herb, having leaves like a lyllye, but smaller,
a knappe with many small purple flowers, and a root like the genytours of a
man. Saucio, are, to wound. Saucius, a, um, wounded, sometime werye. Savior,
aris, ari, to kiss swetely. Saura, a lysarde, which lies in hedges.
Saurites, a stoone, which is found in the bealye of a grene lysarde.
Sauromatae, people called also Sarmatae, Russes, Tartariens, Moscouites.
Saxatilis, le, stonye. Pisces saxatili, fysshes bredde among stones. Saxeus,
a, um, stonye, or of a stone. Saxlfragium, and Saxiphagos, an herb called
Saxiphrage. Saxonia, Saxony. Saxones, the people. Saxosus, a, u^, full of
great stones or rocks. Saxulum, a little rock. Saxum, a rock. sometime a
stone. Saxumferratum, a city in Italy. Saxum uoluere, to turn the stone. A
proverb applied to them that be fatygate or weryed with contynuall and
unprofitable labors.
S, ANTE C.
SCabellum, a footstool, or low settle. Scaber, bra, brum, rusty, rough,
sometime filthy. Scabies, scabiei, a scabbe. Scabiosus, a, um, scabbed. Scabo,
by, bear, to rub or scratche. Scabredo, dinis, a roughness of the skin, as
when it does wrynkle. Scabrae, roughely, not plain, or smothe. Scabrities,
and scabritia, rustynesse, filthiness, rowghnes. Scabro, onis, a worm, which is
engendered of the carrayne of a deed horse. Scaea, an haven at Troy. Scaei,
people in Thracia. Scaena, a place, which seruyth only for enterludes or
comedyes to be playde in, which was in the form of half a cerkle. It is
also where trees or busshes, are cut and laid over the heed, in such
form, a^ men may under them walk or sytte in the shadow. It is alsoo where
a vice or offense is openly detected, in such wise as me^ do cry out or wonder
at it. Scaenaticus, uel scaenatilis, for a player in comedies or enterludes.
Scaenicula, a diminutiue of scaena. Scaenicus, ca, cum, pertaining to
enterludes. Scaenicus, a player in enterludes. Scaenitae, people of Arabie,
which dwell always in tents, covered with the hears of gotes, among whom
if a swyne or hog be brought, it dies. Scaenoma, a tente, also a bag.
Scaenopegia, the feast of the tabernacles, wherein the Jews did set up
tabernacles or te^tes in similitude of them, wherein they dwelled when they came
out of Egipte. Scaenos, in greek, is a tent or shadow. Scaeua, the left
hand, also he that uses the left hand for the right. Scaeuus, a, um,
ylle, Fest^^.
sometime it sygnyfyeth good, as Scaeuu^ omen, good luck or chance. Scala, and
scalae, scalarum, a ladder. Alsoo a pair of stayres. Scalmus, a little piece
of wodde, whereunto shyppemen do bind their oores, to row the more easyly.
Scalpo, psi, pere, to scratche, also to grave in mettalle. Scalprum, and
scalpellu^, an instrument, wherewith any thing is scraped or rubbed, also a
surgeons instrument, wherewith he takes corrupt flesh from the bones. It is
also a grauynge iron. Scalptor, scalptoris, a grauer. Scalptura, grauynge in
metal. Scalpturatum, pauement made with stones, of diverse colors, joined
together. Scalpturio, riui, rire, to scrape as a Cock does, or other fowls.
Scalpurio, rire, to scrape as a hen does. Scamander, dri, a river, which
dyuydeth Europa from Asia. Scamandria, a town by the haven of Iliu^, not far
from Troy. Scamnum, a benche or form. Also a step or grise, whereby a man
gothe up unto a high bed. Also a balke untilled between two forowes.
Scamonea, an herb, the juice whereof is used in medicine to purge coler
vehemently. All be it that it is venomous, and leaves wars matter behynd, than
it does expel. Scandalides, a kind of dates. Scandalum, occasyon to sin,
given by an another to him that synneth. Scandinauia, an isle in the north occean
see, the quantity whereof was never found. Scandix, dicis, an herb like to
cheruyll, but it is sweter, and has a white flower, and a little root.
Scando, di, dear, to clymme. Scandulaca, an herb, which runs upon corn,
as iuye does on trees. Scandulae, shyngle, which be tyles of wod, wherewith
diverse churches be covered. Scandulum co^tectum, a house covered with shyngle,
or wooden tyles. Scansile, that which may be clymmed or gone upon. Scansio,
a clymmynge up. Scapha, a boot. Scaphiarius, a boteman. Scaphium, a basin or
vesselle to receive vryne or ordure. Scapilium, the space between the shulders.
Scaprum, a knyfe, wherewith vynes and other like things are cut. Scaptensula,
a place in Macedoni^, where silver was dygged. Scaptia, an old city in Italy,
whereof came Scaptia tribus. Scapulae, the hinder part of the shulders.
Scapularis, a boy or wenche, which is often beaten about the shulders.
Scapularis uestis, a garment, which covers only the shoulders. Scapus, the
head of popie or other like herbs, wherein be the seeds, likewise the husk of
grapes, wherein the graynes be contained. Scarabaeus, a fly with a black shell
or husk called a bytell: which breeds in cow shardes, and is black. Also
there is a kind of the^, which has horns like to an heart. Scarabaeus aquilam,
a proverb applied to such as endeavor them self to do displesure to those
that be more puissant thanne they are. Scarifico, care, to lance or open a
sore, that the matter corrupted may issue. Scarificario, launcynge. Scarus, a
fyshe, which does chewe like a beast. some men do suppose it to be a
Gylte heed. Scatebrae, the bollynge or rysynge up of water out of a spryng or
sourges of water. Scateo, tere, to run or brast out, as water does out of a
narowe or strayte place. Scaturigo, ginis, and scaturies, brastynge out of
water or other thing in like manner. Scatu^io, ire, to run out or abroad,
also to spring or grow abroode, as sum herbs done. Scaturitio, a runnynge
as water does. Scauri, they which have their toes swollen, or their ankley
crooked, that they may not goo fast, it was alsoo an honorable house of the
Romans. Scazon, it is, a kind of meter. Donatus. Vergil.
Scelerate, myscheuously. Scelerator, it is, he that polluteth or defiles.
Sceleratus, he unto whom a myscheuouse deed is done. sometime it signifies
him that does an ill deed. Sceleratus campus, a field at Rome, where the
nuns of Vesta were buried quick, if they were found to live incontinently.
Scelerose, ungraciously. Sceleste idem. Scelerosus, a, um, he that has done an
ungracious or myscheuous deed. Scelestus, ta, tum, ungracious, full of
unhappiness, myscheuous, vengeable. Scelerosus, full of ungraciousness.
Scelero, rare, to pollute. Scelus, sceleris, a myscheuous deed. also an
ungracious person. Scenoma, a pauyllyon, a sack. Scena, a pauyllyon or halle.
Also a scaffold. Sceparnon, a covering. Scepsis, a city in Phrigia. Sceptici,
were a sect of Philosophers, which affirmed nothing: the chief of that
sect was Pirrhus and Herillus. Sceptrum, a princis septre. Scheda, a leaf of
paper, a scrowe. Schedia, a thing like to a bridge with trees pynned together,
whereon things are carried in the water, in the steed of a barge, as it may be
seen on diverse great ryuers in high Germany. Schedion, any thing suddenly
made, and without much labor. Schedula, a lyttel scrowe or leaf of paper.
Schema, atis, and schemat^^, a figure. also an orname^t, specially in spech.
sometime a garment. Schesis, where a multitude of words are brought in together
vnioyned, as, Nubila, nix, grando, procellae, flumina, venti, Clouds, snow,
hayle, showers, flouddes, wyndes. Schilichi, among the Jews was a weight of
four ounces. Schisma, matis, a diuisyon, specially in the church. Schiston,
the milk that remains after that the milk is sodden, which is called well
courdes. Schoenobates, he that gothe on a cord. Scoeniculae, harlottes, which
dress them selfs with stynkynge oynementes. Schoenitae, people, which do
dwell in pauyllyons. Schoenoplocos, a roper. Schoenus, nuntis, a river by
Athenes, also an other in Archadia, and also a tree callid Lentiscus. Schoenus,
a space of ground contaynynge three score furlonges. Schola, a school. Also a
place in a bayne, where men did abide, whiles other were bained, likewise in a
porche, wherein men tarried for answers. Scholae, are taken for dysputations
between the master and his scholars. Scholaris, lare, pertaining to
schools. Scholasticus, a scholar. Scholasticus, ca, cum, scholasticall.
Terent. in ^^aut. Terent. in Eunucho.
Scibilis, le, that which may be easily known. Scibo, for sciam, I shall
know. Sci^e fidibus, to be perfytte in playenge on instruments. Sciens feci,
I did it wittingly. Scienter feci, I did it cunnyngly. Scientia, counnynge.
Scilicet, as who says. It is much, surely, moreover. Sommetyme it implies a
negatyue. Scilla, an herb, which has a rote like an oynyon. some call it
Squilla. Scincus, a kind of small cockodryls in the river of Nilus. Scindo,
scidi, scindere, to cut. Scinpodium, a little cowche or benche. Scintilla, a
spark. Scintillo, are, to sparkle. Scio, sciui, scire, to know. Scire
sciscereque, to ordeyne and inacte, as it is in our parlyament. Sciolus, he
that knows somewhat. Scio vti foro, I know what I have to do, also I can
accommodate my self to other men's manners, and to the condycions of the time
and place present. Sciomantia, a part of nygromancy wrought by shadows.
Sciopodes, people, which lyenge vpryght do shadow them selfs with their
feet: all be it every one man has but one leg: and yet be they wonderful
swifte. Sciotericon, a dyalle set upon a wall, to know by the son what
is a clock. Scipiadae, and Scipionidae, they which were of the progenye of
Scipyons, the noble captains of Romans. Scipio, the surname of a noble house
in Rome. Scironia saxa, rockis in the sea by Athenes. Scirpea, a dunge pot or
colne made with rods. Scirpicula, a little hook, wherewith russhes, or any
thing is cut of in bynding of things. Scirpita, howped vessels. Scirpo,
are, to bind. Scirpus, a rushe, or an osyar. Nodum in scirpo querere, To seek
for a knotte in a rushe is a proverb, whereby is signified, to seek to
diligently for a thing that may not be found, or to make doubt of a thing,
which is plain. Scirpeus, a, um, of rushes. Scirpiculum, a baskette. Scirron,
a thing grown in a man or woman's bealy, specially in them, which have the
dropsy, and causes the belly to be great. Scirophorion, the month of May.
Scirthosis, a disease in the eyes, coming of a long inflammation, flesh
growyng in them somewhat blue. Scirta, is a kind of oynyous, growyng in winter,
called scalyons. Sciscitor, taris, tari, and Scisco, sciscere, to demand.
Alsoo sciscere, is to ordeyne or inacte. Sciscito, give thou sentence or
judgment, give thy voice or consent in election. Scisco, sciui, sciscere, to
know, Also to decerne or give sentence. Scissilis, le, that which may be
cut. Scissio, scissura, and scissus, us, a cut. Plautus* Amph.
Scita, ordynaunces made by the people. Scitamenta, pleasant meats. Site,
cunnyngly, craftily. Scitor, aris, ari, to demand or inquire. Scitum, a
decree, or statute. Scitus, ta, tum, wise or wyttie, alsoo propre or feate.
Scytae, people in the north part of Asia, which were cruel, and hard to be
vanquyshed, they be now called Russyans, Moscouites, and Tartariens. Sciurus,
a squyrell. Scius, he that knows a thing. Scythia, the name of all the
countrayes together. Scleriasis, a swellynge of the eye lyddes, with pain and
redness. Sclerophthalmia, where the eye lyddes ben hard, and wax heavy with
ache. Sclopus, a sown, which is made with puffynge of the chekes. Scobina, an
instrument, wherewith any thing is shaven. sometime the shauyng self. (...),
are, to wound, to shave of. S^obs, scobis, that which comith of the sha^yng or
boryng of wodde or metal* also grit of stones, wherewith metal is scoured.
Scoletia, a kind of ruste or canker. Scolopendra, a worm with many feet and
rough, called a palmer. Scolymos, the flower of a thystell. Scombrus, a fyshe.
Scomma, matis, a scoff, or sentence spoken in myrthe, which sowneth otherwise
tha^ is meant of him that speaks. Scopa, a brom or besome to swepe* houses.
Scoparius, and scoparia, he or she that does swepe. Scopei, men of little
stature. Cicero ad (...) c. Ci. de ora^^^^ per^^^.
Scopae, dyssolute men without wit or cou^cil. Scopas dissipare, to say or do a
thing without any purpose or reason. Scopo, pare, to swepe. Scopelon, an high
place, where men stand to behold or epsy. Scopulosus, a, um, rocky, or full
of rocks. Scopula, a brushe, such as payntours and pargettours do use.
Scopus, and scopulus, an high rock, also it is a mark, whereat men do shote.
sometime it sygnifieth any thing, whereunto that which is spoken, has a
principal respect. Scopi, be grapes, after that the wine is pressyd out.
Scoria, the refuse of metal tried out by fire. Sometime it signyfyeth care or
grefe. Scorodon, Garlyke. ^^bro^us.
Scorpena, a fyshe, which keeps her self to one make. Scorpionarii, they
which do shoot in crossebowes. Scorpites, a stone of the color of a
scorpio^. Scorpiuros, an herb and flower called ruddes or marygoldes. It is
also a worm like to that which is called Locusta. Scorpius, and scorpio,
onis, a venomous worm called a Scorpyon, which stryketh with his taylle, and
never ceasseth to search, where he may have occasyon to stryke. Also a sign
in the fyrmament. It is also a crossebowe. Some men take it to be an arkbushe.
Also a whyppe, having plummettis of lead at the ends of the cords. It is
also an herb, which has seeds like to Scorpyons. Scorte^, that which is of
lether: as Scortei numi, lether money. Scortes, the codde of a man or beast.
Scorteus, tea, eum, that which is made of skynnes. Scortor, aris, ari, to
haunt or company with harlottes. Scortum, an harlote or strumpette: it is also
the hyde of a beast. Scotia, Scotland. Scoti, Scotts, or Scottyshmen, of
whom sayncte Hierom writes in this wise. Quid loquar de caeteris nationibus,
quu^ ipse adulesceniulus, in Gallia ^^derim Scotos, gentem Britannicam, humanis
uesci carnibus: and quum per syluas porcorum greges and armentorum, pecudumque
reperiant, pastorum nates, and foeminarum papillas solere abscindere, and has
solas ciborum delitias arbitrari? Whatte shall I speak of other Nacyons, sens
that when I was a boy, I saw in France, Scotts, a people of Britayn, eat
men's flesh: and when they found in the forestes herdes of swyne,
beasts, and cattayle, they would cut of the buttockes of the boys, which
kept them, and alsoo the women's pappeo, and took that to be the most deyntie
and delycate meat. Scotos, in Greek, darkness: It is more aptly called in the
northern tunge, myrke. Scotoma, and scotomia, dymnesse of syghte. Scranteum, a
skin, wherein arrows are put: it may be called a sheafe. Scraptia, a worm,
which is founden in leaves. Also a vile and stynkyng harlotte, a driuelynge
queen. Screabile, that which may be spette or retched out of the lunges or
stomach. Screator, he that retcheth or spitteth. Screatus, tus, spettynge or
rechyng to spy. Screo, are, to reach in spettynge. Scriba, a Secretarye, a
Notarie, a Scribe, a Clerk. Scribello, late, the old writers used for Scribo.
Scriblita, a delycate meat made of paste stuffed and wounden like a rope. I
thynk it to be such as fartes of Portyngal are. Scribo, scripsi, scribere, to
write, also to make sometime to paynte. Scribligo, ginis, an untrue form of
speaking or writing, called also soloecismus. Scrinarius, the keeper of secret
letters. Scriniolum, a caskette or forsar. Scrinium, a coffer, or other like
place, wherein iewelles or secret things ar kept, as euydences and records
of judgments or inrollementes. Scriptio, an inscription, or any other writing
Scriptor, toris, a writer. Scriptorius, a, um, apt for writing. Scriptum, that
which is written. Scriptura, writynge. sometime style. Alsoo reckenynge of a
baylyffe, which byeth and sells cattle. Budeu^*
Scripturarius, he that writes things which be commonly done, or books of
reckenynge for baylyffes and reues. Scrobs, scrobis, a dyche or furrowe.
Scrobulus, a little dyche or furrowe. Scropha, a sow that has pigs.
Scro^um, the codde or skin, wherein be the stones of a man. Scrota, be also
lyttel images made of paste, which are wont to be given to children.
Scrupulosa res, a thing wherein there seems to be some difficulty.
Scrupulosus, a, um, scrupulous or doubtful in light things. sometime it
signifies dyffuse or difficulte. Scrupulatim, by small pieces. Scrupulu^
inijcere, to bring into a man's mind, doubt, carfulness, or thought.
Scrupulu^ eximere, to put away dout or care. Scrupulus, a little sharp
stoone, which sometime happens to fall into a man's show, and hurt his
heel. It is also taken for much solicitude, also for dyfficultie, or spiced
conscience. Also a poise, which is the third part of a dram: and than is
it also written with y, as Scrypulus. Scrupus a little stone or piece of a
stone. Scrupeus, a, um, stonye. Scruta, old garments, horseshoen, and such
other baggage, sold for necessite. also little images made in paste, sold to
the people. Scrutarius, he that sells old stuff, or makes such images.
Scrutinium, a search. Scrutor, aris, ari, to search. Scrutellus, the belly of a
swine farcid or stuffid Sculna, old writers used for sequester, an arbytrour.
Sculpo, psi, pere, to carue images in stoone. sometime to grave in metal.
Sculponeae, woollen sockes. Sculponeatus, he that does wear woullen sockes.
Sculptile, that which is carved or graven. Sculptor, a grauer, a caruer.
