Sculptrix, a woman of that occupation. Sculptura, Ingrauynge or caruynge.
Scurra, a railer, a scoffer. Scurrilitas, railyng. Scurrilis, le, pertaynyng to
raylynge. Scurriliter, in raylynge or scoffyng facion. Scutarius, a buckeler
maker, or a maker of tergates. Scutarius, ria, um, pertaining to shyeldes or
tergates. Scutatus, armyd with a shield or tergate. Scutella, a sawcer.
Scutuca, a skourge. Scutula, a round figure, such as spynners or spiders do
warke. also a vessel, which contains.viii. ounces. also a staff, wherewith
flax is beaten. Scutulatus, ta, tum, round and wroughte (...) the form of a
copwebbe. Scu^igerulus, a custrell* or page, which bears his masters shield
or bucklar. Scutriscum, a diminutiue of scutra, or scutula. Scutulata uestis, a
garment of sylk, wherein be wrought fygures like to round copwebbes. Scutulatus,
is a color, I suppose a wachet. Scutulum, a little shield. Scutum, a t^rgat
or shield, a buckelar. Palladius
Sylace, a city in Grecia. Scylla, a daungerouse Rock in the sea by Sycile.
Alsoo a lady, daughter of Nisus, king of Megarensis, which for love of
Minois, her fathers enemy, stale a pourple hear from her fathers heed,
which caused him to be vanquysshed: But she being forsaken of Minois, threw
her self into the Sea, and was transfourmed into a bird of her name. It is
also a kind of fyshe in the river of Liris in Campania. Scyllaceum, a town in
the furthermooste part of Italy, first builded and inhabyted by men of
Athenes. Scylleta, places wherein is taken the fysshe called Scilla. Scylleum,
a promontorie or hyl in the part of Grecia, now called Morea. Scyllis, the
name of a Greek, which swimmynge under water, did cutin sonder the Cables of
the ships of the Persyans. Scyllus, luntis, a town in Achaia. Scylurus, the
name of a man, which having four score sons, when he dyed, he callydde
them before him, and delyueryd to eueryche of them a sheafe of arrows,
commaundynge them to break the sheafes incontynente: which when they
moughte not do, he took out of the sheafes oone arowe after an another, and
brake them all lyghtely, declarynge thereby unto his sons, that if they
continued and agreed well together, they should be puyssaunt: and if they
varyed and were dysseuered, they should be feeble and shortly distroyed.
Scymnus, the whelpe of a lion. Scynifes, bytynge gnattes. Scyphus, a great
cruse or judge. Scyricum, a blonket color or light wachet. Scyros, an i will in
the sea callid Egeu^, where Achilles was hid in a maidens garment. Scytala, a
little beast called a shyrewe. Scyritae, people in India, which have no
noses, but in the stead of a nose they have two holes in their vysage. Scythia,
is a great countreye, which stretches into the east from the river of Tanais,
and has on the south part Sacos and Sogdianos, people under the king of
Persia, and on the southe part be countries unknown and deserte, and is now
under the dominion of the greatte Cane of Cataye. Scitha, a man or woman of
Scithia. Scythicus, ca, cum, of Scithia. Scython, a countraye now called
Thracia in Greece.
S ANTE E.
SE, is a pronowne, and sygnyfyeth him or her. Sebasta, uel Sebastapolis, a
city in Siria. Sebemytum, a city in Egipte. Sebethos, a fountayn at Naples,
which serves the city, running throughout the cite. Secale, a certain
grain, which serves only to put away hunger. Secedo, secessi, secedere,
to goo back, or to go out of company, to go away, to goo to play or sport
from labor. Secerno, secreui, secernere, to divide, or lay oone from an
another, to lay or put by it self. Secespita, a cuttynge knyfe, wherewith
the paynyms divided their sacrifice. Secessus, us, and secessio, a departing, a
vacation from business, a secret place. Secinium, a cake of breadde cut in
sacrifice. Secius, later. Nec eo secius, never the later. Secludo, si, dear, to
shut out. Seclum, for seculum, the space of one hundred years. Seclusa sacra,
ceremonies, that be secretly used, to be had in the more reverence. Seco,
cas, cui, care, to cut. Viam secare, to lead the way. Secare, is also to
follow. Secors, and socors, dis, hartelesse, apt to no purpose, profitable
neither to him self nor to any other. Secordes agni, lambs late enyd or
fallen. Secordia, and socordia, sluggardnesse, unaptness, luskysshenesse.
Secreta, things secret. A secretis, of the pryuie councyll. Secret, and
secreto, priuyly. Secta, a diverse consent in sondrye wylfulle opinions, a sect
of philosophers, a sect of heretics. Sectacula, the sequel. Sectarius ueruex,
the bell wether, that goth before the flock. Sectilis, le, that which may be
cut. Sectio, onis, a cuttynge, a division, the partynge of a pray in taking
of a town. Sectio, Caes. in co^.
all that is taken in pray at the winning and sackynge of a town. Sectiuus,
ua, um, that is often cut. Sector, aris, ari, to follow, to rounne after one.
Also to follow in manners or form of speaking, or living. Also to hunte or
chase a beast. Sectores, buyers of forfayted goods. Also they that do take
profit by the condemnation of other. Sectura, a cutti^g, caves under earth, or
mines Secubo, bare, to lie aparte. Secula, a sithe, wherewith hey is mowen.
Seculum, some do suppose it to be the space of one hundred years, Plini.
some of one thousand years, other of.xxx. year. sometime it is taken for
time. Seculum sterile, a barrayne time. Secunda mensa, the last course,
wherein comes fruit and conserues. Secundae, darum, the after birth.
Secundarius, a, um, of the second sort. Secundo, the second time or place,
alsoo eftesoones. Secund^, are, to prosper or make prosperous. Secundo lumine,
the next day. Caesaris interdicta, si re secundo lumine hic offendero,
respuentur, If I find the here the next day, I will set little by Cesars
co^mandementis. Secundus panis, brown bread. Pasti siliquis, Horatius.
and pane secundo, Fed with bean husks, and brown breadde. Secundum, an
aduerbe, signifies nigh, or by. Secundum aurem, by the ear. Also next after.
Secundum patrem, next after my father. sometime for. Secundum te litem do, I
judge the matter for the* also in. Secundu^ quietem, in rest. also upon.
Secundum ea, thereupon. Secundum Platonem, After the saying of Plato. Secu^dum
Pythagora^ uino, I live like to Pythagoras. Secundum flumen, Alonge by the
ryuers side. Caes. in co^.
Secundus, da, dum, second or next to the first. Also prosperouse. Secunda
fortuna, Good or prosperous fortune. Res secund^, that which does follow our
desire or appetite, good fortune. Secundo flumine nauigat, He gothe, or
sayleth, or roweth with the streme. Secundus uentus, A good wynd. Secundum
praesentem, as if he were present. Et post edictum secundu^ praesente^
iudicabitur, And after the decre, judgment shall be given, as if he were
present. Vlp^anus.
Securis, an axe. sommetyme it is taken for an offycer, which has authority
to commytte men to thexecution of death. Secure, quietely, surely, in
saufegarde. Securus, ra, rum, sure quiet, without care. Securitas, quietenes,
lack of care, surety. Secus, by, or nighe to. Secus flumen, seruntur salices,
nyghe to the river, wyllowes are set. Also it sygnyfyeth otherwise, or other,
Non dixi secus ac sentiebam, I said none otherwise tha^ I thought* Quid
diximus tibi secus, quam uelles? What said we unto the, other thanne thou
would have us to say? Sed, but. Sed autem, ye but. Sedenim, all be it.
Sedentarius, ria, rium, that which is done sitting. Sedeo, sedi, sedere, to
sytte, to be ydelle, to content, to tarry or abide, to take council. Seeds, a
seat or place to sytte on, Alsoo a mansion house. sometime a sepulcher.
Sedicula, a setle. Sedile, idem. Seditio, a sedition or discord among the
people. Seditionarius, a seditious person. Sedo, are, to mitigate, to pacify,
to assuage, to restrain, to extincte. Sedatio, a mitigation. Seduco, xi, cere,
to lead aside, or lead away sometime to deceive. Cicer. pro (...).
Seducere arrogantiam, to lay aparte pride. Seductilis, he which may be
deceived. Sedulo, in deed, dyligentely, without faynynge. Sedulitas,
dylygence, with much care. Sedulus, dylygente, he that plainly without craft
does a thing diligently. Sedum, an herb callydde Syngreene or howseleke.
Seges, segeris, corn, when it stands. some time the ground falowed, and
redye to receive corn. Segesta, a town in Italye. Segestria, was the straw
that was laid in a lyghter, wherein great men were borne by their servants.
Segmenta, be certain lines ymagyned, by the which Cosmographers do deuyde
the world into porcions, which be callid also Paralleli, whereby the distance
of places are founden. Segmenta, the cuttynges of, of any thing, sometime the
parts of the world diuyded by the son. also gardis, or other like things
sowed to garments. Segmentarius, he that makes cloth of gold Segmentum, a
piece cut of from any thing, be it metal or stone. It is alsoo a be or
colar, which is about womennes necks. Some do take it for the purfyll of a
womannes gown. It may as well be taken for a guard or border about any
garmente. Segmentatus, ta, tum, may be said of any thing, which has
borders or trayles synely wroughte, with small pieces fastened thereon, be it of
metal or timber. Segmentatae uestes, guarded or pourfylled garments. Segnis,
slow and bulle wytted, barayne. Segnitas pro segnitia, slothfulness.
Segniter, slowely. Segnities, slownesse, dullness, baraynnes. Segrego, are, to
sever or separate. Segobriga, a town in the part of Spain, which is now
called Byskay. Plautus i^ Trin. and i^ Asinar. Plautus i^ milite.
Segregare suspitiones, to put away suspicion Segregare sermonem, to speak no
words. Si quis ibi est odiosus, abeo domum, sermonem segrego: If any man be
there, whom I love not, I get me home, and speak never a word. Segrega
sermonem, taedet, Plautus i^ paenulo.
Hold thy peace, I am weary, or it irketh me to here the. Segullum, is a vain
of earth in mines, Plin. li. 33 cap. 4.
which declares, that therein gold may be found. Segor, a city, which
was preseruyd by the prayer of Loath, when Sodoma was dystroyed by the vengeance
of god. Seir, a mountain in the country of Edon, where Esau the brother of
Jacob the patriarche dwelled. Seiugi and seiuges, a teme of six horses.
Seiungo, xi, gere, to separate. Selectio, a chesynge out. Selectus, ta, tum,
chosen among other. also chief among other. Selecti Iudices, Cicero.
among the Romans were judges appointed of the state of gentylmen, called ordo
equestris. Selenetes, a stone, wherein is a white, which decreaseth and
increasethe, as the moon does. Seleucia, the principal city of Siria, which
is.xxx. furlonges from Babylonia. Seleucus, king of Siria, next after Alexander
the greatte. Selibra, half a pound. Seligo, legi, seligere, to gather a part,
or the chief things among many. Selinus, a river. Selinon, an herb called
also Apium, whereof be diverse kinds, as Hipposelinon, Petroselinon. Seek for
them in their places. Seliquastra, a stole to sytte on. Sella curulis, a
Chair, whereon the chief officers of Rome sat in a charyotte, and were so
carried, when they came from their houses. some do suppose that it was callid
curulis, because the fete were crokid the judgment thereof, I remit to the
reders. Sellaria, places, wherein were fourmes and stools for men to sytte on.
Sellularii, artificers, which wrought sittyng. Semel, ones, also at one time,
shortly, brefely, summaryly. Semele, the daughter of Cadmus. Semen, seminis,
sede, sommetyme settes of young trees, or nursgardeynes, sommetime the kind.
Sementicus, ca, cum, that may be sown. Sementis, the act of sowynge, sometime
sede, sede time. Sementa facere, to sow corn. Sementinae feriae, holy days
ordained to pray, that corn being sown, moughte come forth and increace.
Semento, tare, to bring forth sede. Semestris, tree, of six months.
Semesus, a, um, half eaten. Semet, him self. Semetra, half a measure.
Semianimis, half dead. Semianimus, half quycke. Semicadium, half a barelle.
Semicaecus, half blind. Semicinctum, a ierkyn or short iackette.
Semicirculus, half a cyrkle. Semicoctus, ta, tum, half sodden. Semicommestus,
ta, tum, half eaten. Semiconsumptus, ta, tum, half consumyd or wasted.
Semideus, half a god. Semidoctus, meanly learned. Semifera animalia, beasts
engendered between a wyld beast and a tame, as between a wolf and a dog, or
between a wild boore, and a tame swyne. Semiferus, somewhat wild. Semigro,
grare, to goo to dwell in an another place. Semihomo, half a man. Semihora, an
half hour. Cicer. pro ^^bi.
Semilissula, and semilixula, a little cake made with meal, chese, and water.
Semimadidus, da, dum, half wette. Semimares, they which are not perfytte men,
as those, which are gelded. Semimortuus, a, um, half deed. Seminatio,
sowynge. Seminarium, a place from whense settes and plants be translated or
removed. also a tree of the which settes are taken. Seminex, necis, half
slain. Seminium, sede, also the gain of sede. Semino, are, to sow.
Seminudus, da, dum, half naked. Semiobolus, the.xii. part of a greek dra^me.
Semipes, pedis, half a foot. Semipaganus, half an husbandeman, half a carle
of the country. Semipedalis, le, half a foot in quantity or heyghte.
Semipedaneus, a, um, idem. Semiplagium, a little net. Semiplenus, not full.
Semiplotia, were shows, which covered but half the foot: which the Romans
did wear on, when they went in hunting. Semiquinarius, a, um, that which is
half five in number. Semiramis, midis, the wife of king Ninus, and queen of
Babylon, a woman of incomparable power. Semirutus, partly decayed: Semi, half.
Semisenex, uel semiseneus, half old. Semisomnis, and semisomnus, half a
sleep. Semisopitus, he that is half slepynge, half waking. Semisoporatus,
idem. Semispathium, a short sword. Semissis, half a cubite. It was also a
certain coin or money, that was half a piece of gold, as the half noble or
half crown. Semissis homo, a vile person. Semissis vsura, the gayn of syx in
a hundred. Semita, a pathe, also a footeway. Semitatus, ta, tum, dyuided in
paths. Semitogium, a short gown. Semitogatus, and semitogatulus, he that
wears a short gown. Semitritaeon, uel hemitritaeon, a fever, which is a
tercian and a half, and of forty and eighte hours, and vexes one.xxxvi.
hours. Semiuir, an imperfect man. Semiuiuus, half a live. Semiuncia, half
an ounce. Semuntialis, le, of half an ounce. Semiustus, a, um, half burned.
Semimodius, half a busshell. Semoueo, uere, to move or go away. Semper, ever,
always. Semperlenitas, the accustomed gentyl^^sse or myldenesse. Terent. in
Andria. Donatus.
Semperuiuum, an herb called Singrene. Sempiterne, euerlastyngly.
Sempiternitas, the time everlasting. Sempiternus, a, um, everlasting.
Senaculum, a councylle house. Also a little Senate. Senarius, a, um, that
which is of the number of six. Senarij uersus, and senarioli, verses having
six fete. Senator, toris, a Senator. Senatorius, a, um, pertaining to
Senators. Senatus, us, a senate or councyll. Senatusconsultum, an act of

grows on walls, and tyles, and is hoar in summer, and has read stalks,
called grou^dswel. Senectus, senecta, senium, age. Seneo, and senesco,
senescere, to be old. Senex, senis, an old man or woman. Senio, onis, a syce,
or number of six marked in the dyse. Seni, nae, na, six. Sennaar, the field,
where the tower of Babylon was builded. Senogallia, a city in Italy. Senones,
people in France. Sensa, the senses, or those things, which we do mean.
Sensibilis, bile, that which may be felt. Sensiculi, the diminutiue of sensa.
Sensificus, ca, cu^, that which causes feling. Sensilis, le, that may be
felt. Sensim, little and little. Sensus, us, sense, or feelyng, or
perceiuyng. Senta, was called Fauna, or Bona dea, the good goddess. Sententia,
sentence, judgment, opinion, or council spoken or written concerning the life
of man. Sententiola, a little or short sentence. Sententiam dicere, to show
his opinion. Sententia^ far, to give sentence or judgment. Senticetum, a
place full of briars. Sentina, the pumpe of a ship, a place where all fylthe is
received. Sentinatia, a country in Italy. Sentino, are, to avoid peril: also
to pumpe up water out of a ship. Sentio, sensi, sentire, to perceive, to
understand, to feel, to judge, to suppose, to know. Sentio tecum, I am of thyn
opinion. Sentis, a bryar or bremble. Ter. in An.
Senticosus, a, um, sharp as a bryer. Sentus, hearye, roughe. Senum, the
syxte. Senumdenum, the syxtenthe. Seorsum, a part. also namely, or specially.
Omnibus gratiam habeo, and seorsum tibi praeterea Demea, Terent. in Ad^lph.
I thank you al, but namely the Demea. Seorsum a te sentio, I am of an another
opinion than thou art. Plautus in cap.
Seorsus, idem, Separatio, separation. Plautus in Ruden.
Separatus, ta, tum, separate or divided from an other thing. Separo, rare, to
put aparte, or depart one from an another. Separatim, aparte. Sepedes,
emotes. Sepelio, sepeliui, lire, to burye. Sepes, sepis, an hedge. Sepia, a
fyshe called a Cuttell. Sepimentum, an enclosure. Sepio, sepiui, sepite, to
hedge or enclose. Sepius, piuntis, and Sipus, puntis, and Sipontum, a city in
the royalme of Naples. Seplasiarius, a maker of soote oynementes. Seplasium,
uel seplasia, a shop, where sweet oynementes are sold. It was a street in the
city of Capua, wherein were diverse delicate oynementes. Sepono, posui, ponere,
to put or lay apart. Seps, a venymous worm, of whose stroke or bytynge the
flesh rotteth. Septa, the generalle name of all places inclosyd. Septangulus,
a figure, having four corners. Septem, the number of seven. September, bris,
the.viii. month. Septemdecim, seuentene. Septempedalis, le, of seven feet.
Septimus, ma, mum, the seventh. Septenus, na, number, idem. Septemuir, an officer,
having equal authority with seven other. Septennis, of seven years.
Septentrio, the north cost. Septentriones, the seven sterres, which are seen
by Charles wayne, or Vrsa mayor. Septemuiratus, the office, wherein be seven
ioyntely. Septennium, the space of seven years. Septicollis, by that name Rome
was called, because of the seven hills, which were in it, Palatinum,
Quirinalis, Auentinus, Coelius, Viminalis, Exquilium, and Ianiculum. Septies,
seven times. Septifariam, seven manner of facions or wais Septifarius, a, um,
seven diverse. Septimatrus, was a holyday kept the day following the sixth Idus
of every month. Septimana, a wieke. Septimontium, a place having seven hills.
Septingeni, and septingenti, seven hundred. Septingenties, seven hundred times.
Septingentenus, and septingentesimus, the seventh hundred. Septingentuplus,
seven hundred fold. Septuagies, three score and ten times. Septuaginta, three
score and ten. Septuose, darkely. Septum transuersum, the mydrefe, No. Mar.
which dyuydeth the stomach from the lower. bowelles. Septunx, uncis, a
poyse of seven ounces. Septus, ta, tum, enclosed. Sepulchrum, a sepulcher or
tomb. Sepultura, sepulture or burienge. Sepultus, ta, tum, buried or hid.
also like as it were dead. Sepum, talowe. Sepatius, a, um, as it were of
talowe. Sequana, a river in France called Sein. Sequani, Burgonions of high
Burgoyne. Sequanque, for seorsum quanque, every woman aparte. Sequax, acis,
that which follows. Sequela, the act of following, sequel. Sequester, tris,
tree, indifferent to both partis. Sequester, an arbitrer. Also he, with whom
money is left. Sequestro, are, to lay or set a thing indifferently, or in
the keeping of an indifferent person. Terent. in Adelph.
Sequi lites, to sue at the law. Sequor, eris, sequi, to follow. Sera, a
lock. Serapis, idis, a god of the Egiptians, Serenitas, fayrenesse of wether,
drythe. Serenissimus, is a term appropried now adays to kings only, and is
usurped for most famous, or most renoumed. Sereno, are, to make fair and
clear. Serenus, a, um, fair, clear, without clouds. Seres, a people in Asia,
having great plenty of sylke. Sericae vestes, sylken garments. Seresco,
scere, to be fair and dry. also to be turned into whay. Seria, ernest
words, and grave or sad. Seria, an erthen vessel, which is long.
Sericarius, a weauer of sylke. Sericatus, apparayled in sylke, or he that
wears a garment of sylke. Sericeus, a, um, of sylke. Sericum, sylke. Sericus,
ca, cum, of sylke. Series, order. Festus.
Serilla, botes or ships calked with towe. Seriola, a diminutiue of seria.
Serio, in erneste. Seriphus, an I Will by Grecia in the sea called Aegeum. Serius,
a, um, erneste, grave, of importance. Sermo, monis, a speech, a form of
speaking: sommetyme an oration, also communication. Sermocinor, aris, ari, to
talk, to commyn. Sero, are, to shut or lock. Sero, seui, serere, satum, to
sow, to plant, to engender. Sero, an aduerbe, signifies late, to late, after
the time that it ought to be, Alsoo in the evening. Seropta, a city in
Phoenicia. Serotinus, a, um, that which is in the euennynge. sometime late or
latewarde. Serotini fructus, latewarde fruits. Serpens, pentis, a serpente.
Serperasta, a swathynge or swadlyng band. Serpillum, an herb, which growethe
on old walls about wells or pondes, and in some places it smells like
time, and in some places like to sauery. Serpo, psi, pere, to crepe. Serpula,
of old writers was used for serpens, a serpent. Serra, a saw. Serra
praeliari, is to sight in battle, sometime marchynge forward, sometime
reculinge, as a saw goth, wha^ it is drawn. Serrata, and serratula, an herb,
which is called Germander. Seruilis, le, of seruyle or bond condycion or
property. Serratus, ta, tum, like a saw. also sawed. Serro, are, to saw.
Serrula, a little saw. Sertor, he that sows seeds, or settethe herbs.
Serrum, a garlande of flowers. Sertus, ta, tum, set with flowers, as in a
garlande. Sertula campana, an herb callid Melylote. Seruo, are, to keep, to
preserve, to possede, Vergil.
or dwell in a place. Seruare fidem, to keep touch, to be faithful. Seruare de
coelo, to observe tokens or signs in the heaven or firmament. Seruaueris, take
good head what thou do. Plautus, in Amph.
Seruator, toris, he that preserves or delyuereth one from harm. Seruiliter,
like a bondsman or slave. Seruire auribus, to flatter. Seruio, uiui, uire, to
serve. Caes. in co^.
Seruitium, service. Seruitia, bondmenne. Seruitus, bondage. Serum, the last
part of the day, the even tide. It is also whay of milk. Serus, a, um, late,
sometime great. Serum bellum, great war. Seruus, a servant, proprely which
is compellyd to serve, as bondemen or apprentyses done. Seruum poecus, is a
proverb applied to him which in speaking or writing, dare not digress from
an other man's steps or form of writynge. Sesama, and sesamum, a white
grain, which growith in Inde, whereof oil is made which is called oleum
Sesaminum. Sescunx, cuncis, an ounce and a half. Sescuplum, the hole and the
half part. Seselis, an herb called also Siler. Sesqui, as much and half as
much. joined to an another word, sygnyfyeth half as much more. Sesquialtera,
so much and half so much, a proportion in musyke. Sesquihora, an hour and
an half. Sesquilibra, a pound and a half. Sesquimensis, a month and a
half. Sesquimodus, a busshell and a half. Sesquiopera, one iourneye in
tyllage and a hal^e. Sesquipes, a foot and a half. Sesquipedalia ue^ba, great
and stout words, as some noble men do speak to their inferiors, when they
are displeased. Sessio, a sitting. Sestans, et sexstans, that which is also
called obolus, the syxt part of a dram. Sestertius, was two pound weighte
and a half of copper, which among the ancient Romans was always esteemed to
the value of the fourth part of their silver coin called Denarius and Dragma,
of the which.viii. went to an ounce. Ses^ertium, contained.ii.li and a half
weight of silver, esteemed to two hundred and fyfty grotes, whereof.viii. went to
an ounce, that is to say iiii li.iii.s.iiii.d. Ses^ertius nummus, the fourth
part of the silver coin of the ancient Romans, called Denarius and Dragma,
among us it may be named a sterlynge penny. Set^, brystell hears. Setia, a
city in Campania. Se^igerum, a beast which has brystelles. Setinum uinum,
wine made about the city of Setia. Setim, a tree, like to white thorn,
which does never rotte: whereof much of the timber in the temple of Solomon
was. Setosus, sa, sum, full of brystels. Setuosus, a, um, old writers used for
obscurus, dark. Setuose, darkely. Seu, for sieve, either, or. Severe sharply,
cruelly. Seueriter, idem. Seueritas, tatis, gravity, constantnesse, proprelye
in mynystrynge Justice. Seueritudo, idem. Seuerus, ra, rum, grave, constaunt,
cruelle, sharp, dangerous to meddle with. Seuoco, care, to call aparte or
away, to call aside from other. Seuosus, a, um, like to talowe. Seuo, are, to
make candels of talowe. Seuum, talowe of beasts. Sex, sy^e in number.
Sexcenti, six hundred. Plautus in cap.
Sexcentoplagus, he that receives a hundred strypes. Sexcuplus, a, um, six
double, or six times so much. Sexennis, of six years old. Sexies, six
times. Sextans, it is, the syxte part of a pound. Sextarius, a vessel among

the monthe now callid August. Sextula, the syxte part of an ounce. Sextus,
ta, tum, the syxte. Sexus, us, a kind. sexus uirilis, the male kind, sexus
muliebris, the woman kind.
S ANTE I.
SI, if, although, I would god. Si dijs placet, If god will, or on goddis name:
a word spoken either in dysdayne, or in mockage, for any thing not well
done. Etiam latini, si dijs placet, Ci. in ^^^tore.
hoc biennio, magistri dicendi extiterunt, Ye and also the latins, on goddis
name, have been these two years masters of eloquence. Quinetiam, si diis
placet, nephas aiunt, Ti. Li^i^^
consulem plebeiu^ fieri, They say also, on goddis name, that it is unlawful for
a communer to be made Consul. Si sapis, if thou be wise. Siambis, an I Will in the
brytysshe occean see, on the north part. Sibaris, an old town.xii. miles
from Rome. Also a city in Calabria* sometime it is taken for delycate and
wanton living. Sibariticus, ca, cum, wanton or delycate. Sibi, to him. Sibilo,
are, to whystell. Sibilus, a whystlynge. Sibilla, a woman prophet, of the
which were eight, as Varro writes. Sic, so, in likewise, accordyngly, so
lightly. Mirabar hoc, si sic abiret, Terent. i^ A^^ria.
I would have meruayled, if that it should have passed so lightly. Sibus, a
sharp wytted fellow. Sic ago, so am I wont to do. Sic sum, such a one am I.
Sica, a short sword. Sicambri, the people of Nasson, and Hessen in Germanye.
Sicani, a people in Spain. Sicania, a country in the I Will of Sicile. Sicarius,
a murdrer. Sica^eus, a, um, dry of nature. Siccesco, scere, to dry. Siccine,
of that facion, in such facion. Siccine tu illam? Plaut^^.
Siccine nos habes ludibrio omnes? Will thou handelle her of that fasshyon?
Will thou in such fasshyon moc^e us all. Siccitas and Siccitudo, drythe.
Sicco, care, to dry or be dried. Siccus, ca, cum, dry, wythered. Sicera, all
manner of drink made of corn or fruits. Sicileo, cilui, cilire, to cut again
that which was not well cut before, proprely grass in a medowe. Sicilia, the
I Will of Sicile. Siciliences, people dwelling in Sicile, which were borne else
where. Sicilis, lidis, of Sicile. Sicilides Musae, the Musis of Sicile.
Sicilisso, are, to speak the language of Sicile. Siciliqua, uel Sicilicus, a
poyse or wayght, wayinge two drammes: and is the fourth part of an ounce.
Sicilites, the heed of a Iauelyn. Siclus, the ounce of the jews, which is the
fourth part of our ounce. Sicinnium, a kind of daunsynge, wherein they that
daunsed did sing, as they do in Christmasse, when they sing Carolles: and as
maidens do now use to do in the streates. Sicubi, wheresoever. Siculi, men of
Sicile. Siculum mare, the se by Sicile. Sicunde, of any place. Sicut and
Sicuti, as, like as. Sicyonia, an I Will in the se of Aegeum. Sideratio, a
sickness, which in such wise takes some part of a man's body, that it
suddenly becomes dry, so that he felith it not, women do call it taking, or
benummynge. Sideratus, he that is so taken in any membre or part of his body,
that he can not feel it or stere-it, the homely people calls benumbed.
Siderites, an herb, which grows on tyles and old walls. Sidereus, a, um,
of the sterres. Sideror, ari, to be blasted, or taken, that a man may not
stere or move his members. Sido, dis, sedi, sidere, to settyll. Sidon, a city
in Phenicia. Sidonius, a, um, of that city. Sidus, a number of sterres
gathered, which do make a sign or celestial figure: sometime it is taken for
one sterre. Sifilare, to whystell. Sifilator, oris, a whystler. Sigaeum, a
great mountaygne in the sea by Troy. Sigillaria opera, warkes wherein were set
small images. Sigillatim, one after another. Sigillo, are, to seal, sometime
to close or shut. Sigillum, a little image. Sigma, it is, a little table.
Signaculum, a seal. Signatorius anulus, a signet. Signatus, ta, tum, notable.
Signa infesta, Standards and baners advanced in battle, in marchinge
against enemies. Signia, a city in Campania. Signa coelestia, the twelve
signs, by the which the son and other planettes do pass. Signifer, he
that bears standard or baner in a field. Significo, ficare, to signifye or
give knowledge. Signinum opus, a warke made with shelles and mortar, or tyles
and mortar. Signo, are, to make a sign, to sign or seal, to signify or
show by a sign or token, to write. Signum, a sign, token, or mark, a
miracle. Signa, be alsoo images of metal, stone, or wood. Silanius, an high
hill in Irlande. Silatum, brekefast. Sila, an helmet. Silenta loca, quiet
places, wherein is no noise. Silentium, silence, quietness. Silenus, the
foster father of Bacchus. Sileo, lui, lere, to keep silence, to speak
nothing. Siler, a kind of wythy growing in water: it is also a river in the
royaulme of Naples. Silesco, scere, to be in silence, or quyete. Silex,
silicis, a flynt stone. Silicatus, ta, tum, made with flynt stones.
Silicernius, and Silicernium, a certain puddynge, eaten only at the time of
funeralles, some do take it for a feast or dinner made at the funeralles or
terme^t of a man or woman. Senem silicernium, is named of Terence for an old
Cryppel, ready to have such a dinner made for him. Siliceus, a, um, of a flynt
stone. Silicia, sieve Silicula, an herb called Fenugreke. Siligo, ginis, a
grain called Rye. Siligineus, a, um, of Rye. Siliqua, the husk or codde of
any thing, also a certain fruit in Italy, which is in length of a man's
fyngar, and broad, and somewhat hooked, the wayght of six of them made a poyse
called Scrupulus, a scruple: whereof three do make a dram. It is now called a
Characte, and is used among fynars of gold and silver, and also coyners in the
fynynge and alayinge thereof. Siliquastrum, an herb. Siliquor, quaris, quari,
to grow in husk or codde. Silura, a chuntraye in the more Britayne. Silo,
onis, he which has great brows. Silosontis chlamis, is spoken in a proverb
of him, which bostith him self of rich garments. Silus, a camoysed nose, or
a nose which is turned upward. Silphion, an herb. Silu^us, a fissh called a
Stourgeon. Simia, and Simius, an Ape. Simila, fine mele of corn. Similago,
ginis, idem. Simillimus, a, um, most like. Similitas, likeness. Similiter,
likewise, also. Similis, le, like. Simil^is habent labra lactucas, a proverb
applied to them, which being of like ill conditions, be matched together, as
a lewd servant with an ill master, an unruly people to a negligent governor,
a shrewde wife to a froward husbonde etc. Like master like man. Like will to
like. Similitudo, dinis, likeness. Similo, are, to be like. Simitu, pro simul,
together. Simiolus, a little ape. Simois, oentos, a river by Troy. Simonia,
Symony, that is to say, ambition in spiritual things. Simplariae, simple
things or of little value. Simplares, they which do wear hostinge harneyse.
Simplex, plicis, that is not double, sincere or plain, without deceit.
Simplicitas, playnesse. Simpliciter, plainly. Simplicitus for simpliciter.
Simplus, a, um, sengle in number, one only. Simpulum, a chalice or cup of earth,
wherewith they sacrifyced in the old time before that gold and silver were in
great estimacion It is of Varro taken for a cruet with a Pipe, out of the which
wine came droppynge by little and little. Simpuuium, a vessel of tree. Simul,
together with other, moreover also. Simul ac, simul atque, as soon as,
incontinent as. Simulachrum, an image of a man or woman. Simulo, are, to
endeavor, to be like to one, also to feign. Simultas, aris, pryuy displeasure
or hatered, with dissembling countenance. Simulatio, fantasye, also
dissimulation. Simulator, he that dissembleth. Simulter, for Similiter.
Simulto, tare, to be at varyance with one, to hate one pryuyly. Simus, a, um,
flat. Sin, or else, if not. Sinapi, and Sinapis, Senuy sede, whereof mustarde is
made. Sinapium, mustarde. Sinapodes, people in Affrike, which do go as they
crept. Sinarum Regio, a countraye beyond the line equinoctial. Sinciput, the
forepart of the hedde. Sindo, donis, a fine lynen cloth. Sine, without. Sine
vt veniat, let him come. (...) Liui^^
Sine fraud mea, my right saved. Singillatim, to every one, or of every ouche,
one after another. Singularis, re, synguler, excellent, one without any mo.
Singulariter, singulerly, only. Singulatim, every thing by it self.
