Sinistra, the lefthande, sometime it sygnifieth, contrary to prosperouse. Sino,
sini, sinere, to suffer. Sinope, pes, a cite in the contray of Pontus. Sinopis,
pidis, a red stone, communely called Sinoper. Sinistre, unhappily,
unfortunately. Sinistrorsum, on the lefthande. Sinuessa, a city in Campania.
Sinuo, are, to turn or wind in the form of a serpent, making holowe
bosoms or furrows: it is also applied to garments that are pleyghted or
gathered up: also to streams of Ryuers, which do in runnyng make diverse
tournynges. also to banks which have holow creekes or bosoms. Sinuosus, a,
um, that which has many turnynges and wyndynges. Sinus, us, a bosom. also the
tournynges or holownesse of water banks: sometime the holownesse of eyes:
sometime a sail. also a cup for wine: also nets. sometime a sail, when
the wind fylleth it. Siparium, a courtayne. Siphones, the pypes of a Cundyt.
Siqua, for si aliqua, if any. Sipontum, a city in Apulia. Sipontinus, a, um,
of that city. Siquide, for because. also if. Siremps, for similis res ipsa.
Siren, and Sirena, a meremayden. Siri, pittes, wherein corn was laid to be
preseruyd. Sirius, a Sterre, which ryseth the.viii. Calendis of June. Sirpea,
mattes, or other things made of russhes. Sirpices, were instruments made with
teeth like to a saw, which being drawn with oxen, plucked up by the roots
flagges and great weeds, which grew in meadows. Sirpiculae falces, hooks,
wherewith vynes are cut. Sirpo, are, to bind, or wind with russhes or osyars,
or other like thing. Sirpus, a russhe. Nodu^ in Sirpo quaeris, thou fyndest
difficulty or doubt, where there is none. Sirpi, be also warkes or verses,
which be very hard to be understand. Sirpiculum, a little basket. Sisamum, a
manner of poulce or corn. Siser, a delicate root to be eaten, which some men
do suppose to be read Carettes. Sisara, and Sisarum, an herb growing in
Euboea, the flower whereof is most pleasant to bees. it is also called Erica.
Sisto, ere, to make to tarry or stand still, to retain or keep back, to
appear, as a man does being sued in the law. Sistas te, appiere thou.
Plautus in Cap.
Ore sistere. Eminor, interminorque, ne quis mihi obstiterit obuiam, nam
qui-obstirerit, ore sistet. I threten, and I menace, that no man let me of my
way, for whosoever lets me, shall kiss the ground. Sistere uadimonium, to
bring in suerty. Sistrum, an instrument like a horn, which was used in
battle, in the stead of a trumpet. Sisyphus, was a great thief, which was
slain by Theseus, of whom it is feigned, that in hell he tourneth a stone up
to a great hill, but when it is at the top, it falls down again, and
remeueth his labor. Sitanius panis, bred of new wheat. Sitarchia, a bag,
or gardeuiandes, wherein meat is put. Sithonia, a countraye in Macedonia upon
the se side. Siticen, he that did blow in a trumpet wha^ men were buried.
Sitio, tire, to thyrst or be a thirst. Sitiens, he that is a thirst. Situlus
barbatus, a little skyllet. Sitella, a little pot, wherinto lottes were put.
Sitibundus, a, um, very thursty. Siticulosus, he that is allwaye a thirst.
Sitis, thirst, or desire to drink. Situla, and Sirella, a little cofer, wherein
lottes were put, at the chesinge of officers: also a buckat to draw water.
Situs, ta, tum, put or set. Situs, tus, fylthynesse gathered of moisture, by
lack of klensinge. also of sluttisshnesse. also the setting or standinge of a
place, which is now called the syte or situatio^ of a manner or countraye.
S, ANTE M.
SMaragdus, a preciouse stone called an Emeraude. Smigma, Soap, and all other
thing that does put away spottis or uncleanness. Smigticus, ca, cum, the
efficacy of klensing. Smilax, acis, a tree, which has leaves like an yuy, with
beryes, and a white flower, and smells like a lyly. Smyntheus, one of the
names of Apollo* Smyrna, a city in Asia.
S ANTE O.
SOana, a river of Asia. Soanes, people of Asia, dwelling about the extreme
part of the mountain, called Caucasus. Soboles, issue or succession of
children. Sobrie, sobrely, advisedly, prudently. Sobrini, susters childerne.
Sobrius, a, um, sobre, well aduysed. Soccus, and Socculus, a socke, which women
and players in Comedies only ware. Socer, cri, the wyfes father. Socrus, the
mother. Sociale bellum, that war, which is made with confederates. Sociare
sermonem, Qu. Curt. lib. 7.
to have familiar communication with one. Socienus, a companion, or fellow.
Societas, tatis, fellowship. Plautus.
Socio, are, to join or confederate. Socius, a fellow or companyon. also
Socij, be confederates, they which in all counsayles and acts do participate
one with another. Look for Comites and Sodales, in their places. Socors, for
Secors, luskysshe, apt to no goodness. Socordia, for Secordia,
luskisshenesse, sometime it signifies ydelnes. Socrus, my wyfes mother.
Socraticus, he that folowethe the doctrine of Socrates. Sodales, they that keep
company together, at meals or passetyme. they be also they, which be of one
fraternity or company, or gylde. Sodalitas, tatis, a fraternite or
brotherhode. Also a company incorporate of any mystery or craft, generally al
felowshyps privately assemblynge among the people. Sodalitium, idem. Sodes, If
thou dare. Sodoma, orum, and Sodomum, a city in Judea, which for sin, done
against nature, was by almighty god consumed by celestial fire. Sodomito,
tare, to commytte or use the syn of Sodoma, against nature. Sogdiana, a
country in Asia, extendyng to the north part of Scithia. Sol, solis, the
son. Soles, sygnifyeth sometime the day, sometime the beams of the son.
Solamen, minis, solace. Solanum, an herb called nyghtshade. Solanum
soporiferu^, an herb callid dwabe. Solaris, re, of the sun. Solarium, a
place where by the sun, hours are known. Also a soler of a house. Also a
pencion paid to the prince, to live out of commune business. Solati, they
which be dyseased or sick by the heat of the son. Solatium, solace or
comfort. Solea, a show, callydde a galage or paten, which has nothing on
the fete, but only lachettes. Also a fish, called a sole. also a ground soil,
whereon stands the wall of a house. It is also a shoe, wherewith horses and
oxen be shodde. Solearius, a paten maker. Soleatus, ta, tum, shodde. Suetonius
in August. Plautus in castle.
Solemn, accustomed. Solemnia, feasts or holidays. Solemniter, solemnly.
Solennis, ne, annual or yearly, that which is done every year. Soleo, solitus
sum, uel solui, solere, to be wo^t. Solere, to keep company. Solet, it was
wont, or the use has been. Plautus in epidico.
Solens, for ut soleo, Ego abcessi solens paulum ab illis, I went a little
from them, as I was wont. Solers, it is, wytty, cunnyng. Solertia, sharpenes or
quyckenes of wit, craftynesse or subtlety in practysynge, or wyttynesse.
Solicito, tare, to show both hope and fear. Also to inquiete, or make sorye,
to solicit or procure by means: sommetyme to labor the earth. Solicitudo,
dinis, care. Solicitus, ta, tum, careful. Solido, dare, to make fyrme, to
consolidate. Solidesco, scere, to close together, as a wou^d does, when it
heals. Solid, hole, perfytely. Solidarij, they which do selle in gross.
Solidipes, that has fete hole without toes. Solidus, da, dum, hole,
contynuall, not holowe, not broken or cut. Solifuga, he that keeps him out
of the son, or flees from the heat of the son. Solipunga, a fly, which in
the heat of the son prycketh most sharply. Soliloquus, he that talks
being alone. Soliloquium, communication, which a man being alone, has with
god in contemplation. Solinunt, for solent, they are wont. Solitarius,
solitary, alone without company Solitas, solytarynesse. Solitaurilia, an
offryng of three things of sondrye kinds, as a bulle, a ram, and a boore.
Solito, tare, to be wont often. Solitudo, deserte, where no man dwells.
Solitus sum, I was wont. Soliuagus, he that wandreth alone. Solium, a place of
astate, where a king sytteth: it is also a great vessel, which serves to
diverse uses, as to translate lycour from one to an other, to wash linen
clothes, and for men and women to be bathed in. It sygnyfyeth also a coffin,
where deed bodies are put. Soloecismus, a vice in speaking, wherein the true
congruitie and right speech is perverted. Solo, all in the oske tunge. Solon,
lonis, one of the seven wise men of Grecia, which made laws for the
Athenienses. Solor, aris, ari, to recreate. Solox, course woulle, or locks.
Solstitialis herba, an herb, which does bear flowers only at the time,
when the son is at the highest, or as some men suppose but one day.
Solstitium, the stay of the son, when he can not be either higher or lower,
which is twyse in the year, that is in winter, the eight calendes of January,
and is called Solstitium hyemale, and in summer, the.viii. calendis of Iulye,
and is callid Solstitium aestiuale. Solstitialis uita, a life which dureth but
a little space. Plautus.
Solstitialis morbus, a sycknesse which kylleth men shortly. Solstitialis
aegritudo, is of sum men taken for the burning fever* which happens about
the canicular days, of exceeding heat of the air. Soluendo non est, he i^
not able to pay. Solum, the soil or ground, generally it signifies all
thing, which does sustain or bear any other things on it. It is also the
sole of the foot, also the sole of a shoe. Natale solum, a man's natural
country. Soluo, ui, uere, to lowse, to pay, to recompense, to put a way, to
delyueres, to resolve or melte. Soluere fidem, to break promise. Soluere
uenas, to open the veins. Soluere uotum, to perform an auowe. Soluere uita,
to slay one. Solummodo, only. Solute, wantonly, incontynently. Solutus risus,
a great laughter. Solus, alone, one only, solytarie. Solutilis, le, that
which will be soon lowsed or undone. Solutus, ta, tum, loused or louse, also
paid. Somniator, a dreamer. Somnorinum, a dream. Somniculosus, slepy, a
sluggarde. Somniculosus, a, um, that which causes one to sleep. Somnifer,
feri, that which induces or brings sleep. Somnisicus, idem. Somnio,
somniare, to dream. Somnolentus, disposed to sleep. Somnus, sleep. ^^ Mar.
Sonere, to sound or make a sound. Sonito, to sound often. Sonipes, pedis, a
light or swyfte horse. Sonitus, tus, a sound. Soniuit, for sonuit. Sono,
sonare, to sound or make a noise. Sonor, noris, a great sound or noise.
Sonore, shyll or loud. Sonoritas, a shyllenesse, or lowdenesse. Sonorus, ra,
norum, loud, or making a great sound. Sons, it is, gyltye. ^^^^mus in (...).
Sontica causa, a great cause. Sonticus, ca, cum, noyfull. Sonticus morbus, a
contynuall syckenesse* or wherewith all the body is grieved. Sonus, all that may
be hard. Sophaci, people of Africa. Sophistice, ces, the part of logyke,
which is capciouse and subtylle. Sophia, wisdom. Sophisma, sophismatis, a
craftye and deceytefull sentence, ^n Oracyon or invention, which seems to be
true, when (...) false. Sophista, and sophistes, a dissemble^ of wisdom, a
deceyuer under an eloquente or crafty speaking. Sophocles, a writer of
tragedies. Sophron, in Greek, is Temperance in english, whereby carnal
appetites and lusts be refrayned. Sophos, aut sophus, a wise man. Sopio, piui,
pire, and sopior, to set at rest, to bring aslepe. Sopitus, brought aslepe,
or to rests, or into a sown with a sudden stroke. Sopor, oris, deed sleep.
Soporifer, soporiferi, and soporiferum, that brings sleep. Soporo, rare, to
bring or induce sleep. Soporatus, fast aslepe. Sora, an hill in Italy.
Sorbeo, bus, bear, and sorbo, psi, bear, to suppe, as one suppeth potage.
Sorbici uncula, a thynne brothe. Sorbitio, onis, suppyage. Sorbities, idem.
Sorbillo, lare, to syppe. Sorbillum, a cawdell. Sorbum, an harryshe pere.
Sordeo, and sordesco, dui, dear, to be foul, Plautus in Penulo.
or vnkleanly. Sordes, fylthe, or uncleanness. Sordesco, sordescere, to be
unclean or sluttysshe. Sordide, uncleanly, sluttyshely. Sordidior, dius,
vnclenlyer. Sordidissime, most vnkleanly. Sordidissimus, ma, mum, vnclenlyest.
Sorditudo, fylthynes, sluttyshenes. Sordido, dare, to make foul. Sordidus, da,
dum, fylthy, uncleanly, sluttishe. Sorex, ricis, a ratte, or a field mo^^.
Sorech, the Jews do call vynes, which contynually do bring forth most
pleasant and dilectable fruit. Soriantes, sworn brethren. Soriceus, a, um,
of a ratte. Soricinus, of a mouse. Soriculata uestis, Plaut.
a garmente of chaungeable sylke. Sorita, a subtle and captious form of
arguing. Soritae, people which are diuyded from Inde by the river called
Arabis. Sorilla, ships which are calked or stopped with hemp or flax.
Sororiari, is proprely of may dens breasts, when they begin to be imbosed.
Soror, ris, a sister. Sororiae, maidens pappes. Sororius, my systers husband.
Sorracus, a cofer or baskette wherein are carried the instruments or apparayle
serving for comedies or interludes. Sors, sortis, chance, lotte, portion in
enherytaunce: the hole sum in a commune bank or stock, wherein many have
part. It is also destyny, judgment. Sorts, were also the aunsweres of Idols.
Sorticula, the scrowe, wherein the lotte is written. Sortilegium, dyuynation by
lottes. Sortilegi, ben they, which do tell men's destenies by rakynge of
lottes or verses of holy scripture. Sortior, tiris, tiri, and sortio, tire, to
make lottes, to take or have any thing by lotte or chance. Also to dispose or
order. Sortiri prouinciam, to receive the rule of a countray by lottes. It is
usurped to have authority by election. Sortito, an aduerbe, sygnyfyenge by
lotte or chance. Sortitus, ta, tum, taken by lotte. also chaungynge to have a
thing. Sospes, hole or saulfe. also he that gives health. Sospitalis, le,
cause of health. Sospito, tare, to keep in health. Sos, old writers vsyd for
eos. Sosia, a man's name. Sos^ratus, a man's name. So^adicum carmen, meter
having.vii. fete. Soticena, one of the names of Juno. Soter, a saluyour.
S ANTE P.
SPadicus, ca, cum, of scarlette color. Spad^^, dicis, a date with the
branch plucked from the palm tree. It is also scarlette color. Spado,
donis, a geldyng, be it man or be. Spadonia, a kind of laurel. Spargo, si,
gere, to scatter or cast abroad. Cor. Tacitus lib. 3.
Spargere bellum, to make war in sondrye parts of a country. Spartam nactus
es, hanc orna, a proverb signifienge the astate or office, which thou haste,
order or apply it well. Sparganon, the root of an herb called cynquefoyle.
Spargapises, the son of Thomiris the queen of Massagetes. Sparta, the chief
city of Lacedemonia. Spartacus, was a famous sword player, which gathered
an host of slaves, and made battle against the Romans, and was vanquyshed
by Crassus. Sparteum, a money bag. Spartiata, and Spartanus, na, number, of
Sparta. Spartum, and Spartus, an herb called brom. Spara, be called
caltroppes, sown in time of batayl, to wou^d the fete of men and horsis.
Sparus, a clubbe. Sparum, a little darte. Spastici, out of the which any
thing is plucked. Spatha, a two handed or bastard sword. it is alsoo an
instrumente of the kytchen, to turn meat that is fried. Spathalion, an
ornamente, pertaining to women. Spaticus, vexed with an ill spirit.
Spatiator, a wanderer. Spatiosus, a, um, large, spacious. Spatiose, and
spatiosius, largely, more large. Spatior, aris, ari, to walk. Spatium, a space
as well in time, as in place. Specere, among old writers was taken for
Inspicere, to look in. Specialis, le, special, peculiar, propre. Cicero de
reditu su^
Speciatim, specially, peculyarly, proprely. Species, ei, a figure or image, a
form, kind, beauty, favor. It is defyned by Logicyens, to be that, which is
said of many things varienge in noumbre: as Homo, which is spoken of Plato,
Socrates, Cicero, which do not varye in figure but in noumbre. Sommetyme
species, do sygnyfye spyces. Alsoo it is apparaunce. alsoo a syghte or thing
seen, spices. Per speciem legationis in Asiam ablegatus est. Under the color
of ambassade, Plin. de (...) ri^ illustr.
he was banyshed into Asia. Plautus.
In Speciem esse, to be to the honor. Specificus, ca, cum, partycular.
Specifice, particularly. Specillum, a small Instrumente, wherewith Sourgeons
do search the deepenesse of wounds and soores. Alsoo to annoint sore eyes. It
is also a Spectakle to look with. also an ear pycker. Specimen, speciminis, an
example, a proof, also beauty. Specimen aedere, to show a proof of a man's
counnynge. Speciosus, a, um, beautyfull. Spectabilis, le, worthy to be seen.
Spectaculum, Bude^^.
a thing to be seen or looked on. Sometime the self beholdynge. alsoo the
place from whens men do behold things. Spectamen, a Sign or token.
Plautus in Men^.
Spectame^ bono seruo, id est qui rem l^erilem procurat, uidet, collocat, It is
a token of a good servant, that is to say, which attends about his
masters business, and does survey all thing, and set it in order.
Spectatores, beholders, triers of money: Spectatus, ta, tum, approved. Specto,
tare, to behold, to approve, to tend to some conclusion, to compare.
Spectatio, a trial or proof of money. Spectrum, an image or figure in a
man's ymagynation. Specula, an high hylle or tower, whereon things be espied
far of. also lyttel hope, a diminutiue of spes. Specularia, spectakles.
Specularis, re, any thing, whereby a man may see the better. Speculatio, a
beholdynge. Speculator, an espyall in wars. Speculor, aris, ari, to see
far, to consider, to espy, to search out. Speculum, a lookynge glass.
Specus, cus, and specoris, a den. Speluncha, idem. Spelaeum, idem. Spepondi,
for spopondi, I have promised. Sperchius, a river of Thessalia. Speres, old
writers used for spes, hope. Sperma, spermatis, seed, most commonly used for
the natural humor, whereof all living things be engendered and fourmed.
Sperno, spreui, spernere, to despise. Spero, rare, to hope. Sperata uirgo, a
maiden asked in marriage. Spes, spei, hope. Speutici panes, looues of breadde
made in haaste. Speusippus, a noble philosopher cousyne to Plato. Sphaeca, a
waspe. Sphaera, a figure in all parts equally round a speere. Sphaeristerium, a
round place in a bayne, where men are exercysed, a tenyse play. Sphaeromachia,
playenge at tenyse. Sphennida, a balle made of lether or cloth, greatter than a
tenyse balle. Sphragide, a stone which printeth perfitly. Sphinx, gis, a
monster, which had the heed and hands of a maiden, the body of a dog,
wings like a bird, nails like a lion, a tail like a dragon, the voice of a
man, which purposed to men subtyl questions. It is also a beast like an ape,
but more rough, and with a longer tail, I suppose it to be a munkay or babyon.
Sphondilium, a joint or knotte of the back bone.xii. of them do make the
chyne, and the.v. resydue do make the loins. Spica, and spicus, the ear of
corn. also a spice called Spikenarde. Spica mantica, an ear of corn, having
no berde. Spicatus, ta, tu^, eared, or in care, as corn is. Spiceus, ca, cum,
that which has ears like to corn. Spicifera, the surname of Ceres callid
goddess of corn. Spicilegium, glemynge of corn. Spicilegium facere, to
gleme. Spicio, cire, to shute out in ear. Spiculatores, they which be called
of the kings guard. Some men do take Spiculator, to be a hangeman, or other
person, which puts men to death by execution of the laws. Spiculo, culare,
to make any thing sharp^ at the point. Spiculum, a darte, also an arrowe.
Spilumenes, a sluttyshe drabbe. Spina, a thorn, also the backebone. Spineus,
a, um, of thorn. Spineoli, a wild fruit called Sloes. Spinosus, a, um, full
of thorns. Spinther, a pynne, also a tache, sometime a braselette. Spinturnix,
a bird which was wont to comme to the aulters, and carye away a burning
cole, which was taken for an unlucky bird. Spinus, a plumme tree or damsyn
tree. Spio, onis, idem quod Nimpha. Spirabilis, le, lively, or that whereby we
live. Spiritabile, idem. Spiraculum, and spiramentum, Cicero.
out of which the air or brethe passes. Sprarchus, a captain in the fore
ward. Spirae, things which do turn and wind in diverse cerkles like a
trendell, or an adder lyeng round. Also spira, is an ornament of a woman's
heed. also the turning of cables or ropis, wha^ they be wou^d up. also the band
or lace, wherewith a cappe or hat is made fast under a man's chyn. also the base
of a pyllar. Also a cake made like a trendell. also a multitude of people.
Ennius.
Spirillum, a gotes berde. Spiritus, spirit, brethe, wind. Spirituale, and
spiritale, idem quod spiritus. Spiro, spitare, to blow as wind does, to
send forth odoure. Spisse, an aduerbe, signifienge thick. Spissigradior,
gradi, to go thycke, or make many feet. Spissigradus, he that gothe thycke.
Spissitas, thyckenesse. Spisso, are, to make thycke. Spissus, a, um, thycke,
slow. Spissitudo, thyckenesse. Spithama, a measure of.xii. fyngers broad.
Splen, splenis, the spleen. Splendeo, dui, dear, to shine. Splendesco, scere,
to shine often. Splendide, an aduerbe sygnifienge clear or bryghte. also
rychely. Splendidus, da, dum, bright, clear. Also he which uses to have his
house rychelye decked with abundaunce of all things, is called Splendidus,
contrary to Sordidus and auarus. Splendour, oris, light, bryghtnesse, sometime
honor or nobleness in living. Spleneticus, he that is sick in the spleen.
Splenium, a plaster of cloth or lether made to lay to the body of him, which
is sick. Spoletium, a city in Italy. Spoletini, people of the city
Spoletium. Spolio, are, to rob or dispoyle. Spolior, ari, to be robbed.
Spoliarius, ria, um, that which receives spoil or things taken by robbery.
Sponda, the side of a bed. Spondeo, spopondi, spondere, to promise. Spondeus,
a foot in meeter of two long syllables. Spondilus, a whe^ue, which is a
round thing of stone, or wodde, or leadde, put on a spyndell to make it run
round. It is also a white hard thing in an oyster, which is covered with
the fyshe. Spondium, that which comes of lead like to soote, which is about
vessels of brass, that do hang over the fire. Spongia, a spounge, or that
wherewith any thing is wyped. Spongiare, to wype clean a sponge. Spongioli,
mousherons. Spongiosus, a, um, light, and full of holes like a spounge.
Spongites, a stone like a sponge. Sponsa, a woman despoused or affianced.
Sponsalis, le, pertaynyng to spousage. Sponsalia, the spousage, or betrouthyng
of a man and womanne, before that they be wedded. Sponsio, onis, a promise, a
bargayne. Sponsus, us, idem. Sponso, sare, to affyance or betrouthe. Sponsor,
oris, he that promyseth or bargaineth. Sometime a surety, which undertakes
an other man's act. Sponsus, sa, sum, promised. Sponte, naturally, willingly,
of his free will. Spontalis, le, voluntaryly. Spontaneus, ea, eum, that which
does, or is done willyngly, naturally, without constraynt or help. Spopondi,
I have promised. Sporades, yl^s nygh to Crete or Candy. Sporta, and sportula, a
basket or maunde, sometime money or meat distributed by pryncis unto the
people. Sportula, and sportella, a littell gift or alms, also lyuerey of
court, callydde bowge of court, was called Sportule. Spretus, refused. Spuma,
the foam or frothe of any thing lyquyde. Spumeus, a, um, fomy or frothye.
Spumo, are, to foam or gather unto foam. Spumosus, a, u^, that whereof comes a
foam. Spuo, spui, spuere, to spytte. Spurce, vnkleanly, fylthyly. Spurcidicus,
ca, cum, that which speaks dishonestly or uncleanly. Spurcificus, ca, cum,
that makes things unclean or fylthy. Spurcitia, and spurcities,
uncleanness. Spurco, care, to defyle or make unclean. Spurcum uinum, wine
myngled with water. Spurcus, ca, cum, unclean, filthy, vnpure, stynkynge,
blouddy. Spurij versus, verses feigned, the author being false named or
unknown. Spurius, a bastard. also it was the surname of diverse Romans.
Sputo, tare, to spytte. Sputor, tari, to be spytte on. Sputum, spyttell.
S ANTE Q.
SQualla, old writers used for squalida. Squalleo, lui, lere, to be filthy,
shuttishe, soiled or stainid with some unclean thing Squallidus, da, dum,
sluttishe, filthy, causing one to abhor the sight thereof. Sometime it
signyfieth spotted. also carrayne lean. Squallidus ager, ground out of
tylthe. also shynynge. Squalor, loris, sluttyshenes, fylthynes. Squalido,
dinis, and squalliditas, the same. Squalus, a fyshe. Squama, the scale of a
fyshe. Squammosus, skaly. Squatina, a sole fyshe with a rough skin, wherewith
fletchers do make their arrows smothe. Squarosus, a, um, rough and sharp,
like to a thing which is skalye. Squilla, a certain herb, growing in the sea, also a fyshe. Squinitij, people in Italy callydde Sabelli and Samnites.
S ANTE T.
ST, a voice of him that commands silence, as we say in english, busht, wha^
we would have one to hold his peace. Stabilimentum, that which keeps a thing
steadfast. Sabilio, l^^i, lire, to make steadfast or stable. Stabilis, le,
stable or steadfast. Stabularae mulieres, women which keep vyttaylynge
houses, for to refresshe wayfarynge men. Stabularius, an inholder. Also he that
has the charge of the house, where cattayle is kept. Stabulari damas aut
ceruos, falowe deree or read dear to be lodged or harborowed. ^udeus.
Stabulo, bulare, to stand as cattayle does in a stable. Stabulatio,
standing or lyenge of cattelle, also harborowynge or lodging of d^re.
Stabulum, an inn, where men do lodge or bayte. Also it is the generalle name
of the place, where cattelle do abide, when they come from their pasture.
also a stable wherein horses or mules are kept. Stactis, and stacte, the flower
of myrre, or fatness, which first distilleth out of it. Stadium, a place,
wherein runnynge is exercysed, as well of men as of horses. It is also a
furlonge or the eight part of a mile. Stacteus, a, um, gummye. Stadiodromos,
the place ordained to run in. Stadiodromas, he that rounneth in a course of
rounnynge. Stagma, an oyntement. Stagno, are, proprely of water is to stand
and not to flow. Stagnum, a standing water, a poole. alsoo a certain metal
called tynne. Staloginum, a thing to hang at ones care, as Egyptians have.
Stamen, clothe, when it is in the lome or frame. Also slaxe or woulle, when
it is on the dystaffe. also stamyne or worstede. Stanneus, a, um, of tynne.
Stannum, metal called tynne. Stapedes, styroppes. Staphyle, a vine.
Staphylus, he that did first myngle water with wine. Staphis, a kind of
vynes, which has a black stem and strayt, and has a fruit more like to
a lyttelle bladder, than to a grape, which be grene, within the which is a
kernelle three cornerde. Staphilinus, wild parshyppe. Staphis agria,
Stafesagre. Stata sacrificia, sacrifyce customably done at certain days of an
old ordynance. Statae matris simulachrum, an image, which was set up by the
people in every street at Rome. State, sometime sygnyfieth to abide. Stat
mihi, I am determined. Status, ta, tum, fyrme, or stable, alsoo ordained or
decreed. Statarius, a, um, ordynarie. Stater, teris, a certain coin, which
was in value four drammes. Statera, a beam to way without the bala^cis.
Staticulum, a certain wanton meuynge in daunsynge. sometime a little cart.
Stati dies, days ordynarie, days in bank, for appearance, or for the parties
to plede. Statilinus, was called a private god, which men supposed to be always
with them. Statina, an I Will. Staticulum, a little image. Statiuncula, idem, or
a little restyng place. Statius, a noble poet. Statim, anon, constantly,
contynually. Statio, onis, a place, where either men of war or ships do
abide or rest for a certain time. Stationalis, le, that which stands fast
or abides. Stationarij milites, soldiers, which are assigned to abide
stylle in one place, or to keep a town or fortress, or the marches of a
country. Statiua, and statiuum, a certain place fortyfyed, where men of war
lay at the siege of a fortress. Stator, toris, a sernaunt, which is always
redye attendynge about an offycer, to be at commandment. wherefore in that
word be included pursyuantes, posts, sergeantes, baylyffes, and catchepolles.
Also Jupiter, was called Jupiter stator of Romulus, because he supposed that he
made the Romans to tarry when they fled, the Samnites pursuynge them.
Statua, an image of mettalle, yuorie, stone, or timber. Statuaria, the craft
of caruynge or yetting of images. Statuarius, he that carueth or yetteth
images. Statuarius, a, um, pertaining to images. Statuere ex aequo and bono,
to judge or determyne. according to equity, less than the rygour of the law
would require. Statuere pretium, to set a price on things vendible.
Statumen, minis, that which is set up to sustain or bear a thing, a
proppe. Statumino, nare, to proppe up, to underset, to make sure. Statuo, tui,
tuere, to ordain, to determyne, to set fast, to stable a thing, to dedicate,
to beat one thing to an another. Sublim^ illum arriperem, and caput primum in
terram statuerem, ut cerebro dispergam uiam, I would lift him on high, and
beat his heed to the ground, that I might scatter his brain abroad in the
high way. Statura, the stature of a man. Statu^us, a, um, the particyple
future of sto, stas, stare, to stand. Status, tus, state, it is among
orators and lawyers the case, which rysethe in contention, wherein the matter
rests, which must be replied unto, and either be denied, confessed, or
trauersed: of Tullie it is called Constitutio causae. Status, stata, statum,
firm. Stati dies, days appointed. Steatoma, a gatherynge of grease or fat
in some place against nature. Stechades, three little yles by Marsiles. Stega,
a cabyn of a ship. alsoo a cote or cotage. Stegnae febres, fevers in the
which a man may have neither syege, nor vryne, nor sweat, nor none other
euacuation. Stelae, little pyllars. Stella, a sterre, also a sterrefysshe,
also the name of a poet. Stella crinita, a blasynge sterre. Stellatus, ta,
tum, full of sterres. Stellatura, was an extorcion of capytaynes in taking
from the soldiers the porcions of vyttayle appointed unto them by the
Emperor. Stellio, a beast like a lysarde, having on his back spots like
sterres. Stellionatus crimen, a dysceyte in dyssemblynge a thing, to take
profit of an other iniustely. Stellis, a kind of byrdlyme made in Euboea.
Stello, are, to shine or glysten like sterres, or be made like sterres. St^mma,
matis, a garlande of flowers, alsoo the stock or bloudde of a gentylle house.
sometime the degrees in kynrede. Alsoo an inscription graven in a stone. Stemo,
was sister to Medusa. Stenoboea, the wife of Pretus king of Ephyri, which
loved Bellorophon, that vanquysshed the monster called Chimaera. Stentor,
toris, was a man, which had a voice as loud as.xx. men. Stephanoma, every
herb that seruethe for garlandes. Stephanoplocus, a maker of garlandes.
Stephanus, in greek is a crown. Stercoratio, dungynge. Stercorarius, ria,
rium, pertaynyng to dunge or mucke. Stercoratus, ta, tum, dunged or mucked, or
compassed. Stercoro, are, to dunge or compass. Stercus, stercoris, dunge,
mucke, compass. Stercutius, the surname of Saturnus, because he first found
and used doungynge of ground. Steresis, privation. Sterila, old writers used
for steril^s. Sterilesco, rilescere, to be barrayne or wax barrayne. Sterilia
for sterilitas. Sterilis, le, barrayne. Sterilis amator, a lover, which
lacketh^ money. Sterilitas, barraynes, sterilytie. Steriliter, barraynely.
Sternax, nacis, a steerynge or ploungynge horse. Sterno, straui, sternere, to
throw down, to spread, to cover, to lay the table, to make plain or smothe,
to lie down to rest. Sternere lectum, to make a bed. Sernunt se somno, They
laid them down to sleep. Sternuto, tare, to snese often. Vergi^ius
Sternuo, nuere, to snese. Sternutamentum, sneesynge. Sternutatio, idem.
Sterquilinium, a dungehylle or myxen. Sterogonia, a kind of frankincense
called commonly olibanu^, or in latin thus masculus. Sterto, tui, tere, to
route when one slepeth. Stesichorites, is the number of eight in dise, so
called of the sepulcher of Stesichorus the poet, which was made in figure
like to eight dyse. Stesichorus, a famous poet, of whom it is written, that
when he was an infant in his cradelle, a Nyghtyngale satte on his mouth, and
did sing, sygnyfienge that he should be the sweetest poet, that ever was
before him. Also he found first singing of songs in a daunse. Stibadium, a
chair or couche made of herbs wound together: sum do call it an herber
or summer parler. Stibium, a white stone found in silver mines, which stops
the runnyng of eyes, and does make them seem very fair. Stichos, a verse or
an order in a thing. Stigo, are, to prick forth. Stigma, matis, a mark made
with fire, or with a hot iron. Sometime it sygnyfieth infamy and reproach
objected openly. Stigmatici, persons infamed. Stilla, a drop. Stilbo, was a
philosopher. Vide stilpo. Stilbon, the sterre of Mercury. Stillicidium, the
droppynge of a house. Stillo, are, to drop. Stilpo, a philosopher borne in
the city of Megara in Greece, which his countreye being burned, and his wife
and childern lost in the fire, escaped, and departing alone, when the king
Demetrius asked of him, if he had lost any thing, he answered, I have lost
nothing: for all that is mine, I carry with me, meaning thereby, that virtue,
which is only the propre goods of a wise man, and may not be taken from him,
he took away with him. Stilpones, dwarfes. Stimulo, are, to prycke. Stimulatio,
a pryckynge or fervent moving to do a thing. Stimulator, he that prycketh.
Stimuleus, a, um, that which is done with pryckynge. Stimulus, a good,
wherewith oxen ar driven. Stingo, and stinguo, guere, to put out light. Stipa,
for stupa, towe. Stiparius, ia, ium, pertaining to stoppyng or beatynge hard
together. Stipatores, they which do frayte the ship, or lay in such fardelles
or burdeynes as are to be carried. Also they which be of the kings guard, always
about his person. Stipatus, enuyronned with men, to be defended, as princis are
with their guard. Stipendialis, le, pertaining to wages. Stipendiarius, a, um,
which pays tribute, of some called contributarie, to the fyndyng of an army,
or defense of a contray. Stipendiatus, he that takes wages. Stipendiosus, he
that has been oftentimes hired or retained in wars. Stipendior, diari, to be
hired or retained in wars. Stipendium, wages proprely given to soldiers,
Also subsidy paid to princis. Stipes, pitis, a stake, also a stycke. Stipo,
are, to stop chynkes or clyftes, proprely in ships or botes, with towe and
pytche. also to enuyronne to the intent to defend one. Stipendia facere, to
serve in wars, as a soldier. (...) Liuius. (...). 34.
Stips, uel stipis, pis, wages to men hired: also money given to beggars.
Stiptica medicamenta, medycines that do bind or restrain. Stipula, holme,
erige, or straw, apt to thatch houses. it is of some taken for the husk that
closes in the straw. Stipulatus, tus, and stipulatio, a bargayne or promise,
or obligation to pay money, or to perform a thing, which is required.
Stipulor, aris, ari, to make a bargayn, to promise effectually that which he
is required to do. It has both the active and passive signification. Stipulor
abs te, I require of the, or I am required of the. Stiria, an ysykle or drop
of yse. Stiricidiu^, and stillicidiu^, the droppi^g of a house Stirpices,
w^eders in gardeynes. Stirpitus, up by the rote. Stirpo, are, to pull up by the
rote. Stirps, stiripis, in the femynyne gender sygnyfyeth a stock in kynrede,
being the masculyne gender it sygnifieth the stem of a tree or herb.
Stitisse vadimonium, Gell. li. 2.
to have brought forth surety or pledges. Stiua, is that in a plough, which
the plough man holds, when he does ear. Stlata, a broad ship or bote,
callid an hulke. Stlembus, slow and heuye. Stlatariu^, any thing that is borne
on the sea. Stlatarius, a maker of hulkes or botes. Stlitem, old writers used
for litem, variance. Stlitibus iudicandis, for litibus iudicandis. Stlopus, a
sown made with the mouth, wha^ the chekes are blown. Stlotium, for lotum.
Sto, steri, stare, to stand, to endure or abide. Stare promisso, to abide by
his promise. To be full. Stat ager sentibus, Caecilius. Vergil.
the field is full of brembles. Iam puluere coelum stare uident, Now saw they
the sky fulle of duste. To bose out. Lucilius.
Hic corpus solidum inuenies, hic stare papillas Pictor marmoreo, Here in this
marble stone shall thou find painted, the body sound, and the pappes imbosed.
Also to be immouable, or always certain. Sic stat sententia, so the sentence
abides immouable, or is determined. Also Stat, my mind is. Vergilius.
Stat confer manum Aeneae, my mind is to fight with Aeneas Stat, is set.
Omnis in Ascanio chari stat cura parentis, Vergilius.
All the care of the render loving father was set on Ascanius. Also stare,
to cost, Neque ipse hoc periculum ignoro, expertus non leui documento, quanti
steterit mihi, quod semel imperata non feci, Nor I am ignorant of that danger,
having experience of no light warnyng, how much it cost me, that I did not
those things, that I was commanded. Stare firmum, to stand fast. Stat per
me, per te, per illum, when I, or any other is the cause, that a thing is
not done. Si poterit fieri, ut ne pater per me sterisse credat, quo minus hae
fierent nuptiae, uolo. I would if it may be, that my father should think, that
it was not long of me, that this marriage took none effect. Stara me, he is of
mine opinion. Plautus in pseudo. Ter. in E^.
Stat apud te fides parum, Thou art of a small credence. Statur, I stand
here. Stoecades, four Isles in the french see against Languedocke. Stoici, a
sect of philosophers, which affirmed, that no grief moughte happen to a wise
man: and that felicity was only in virtue. Stola, a woman's gown, It was also
a long garment, which the princes of Persia did use, and was the only garment
of honor, as we do call such apparel a robe. Stolatus, he that wears such
a robe. also it may be called honorable. Stolide, foolyshely, lewdely.
Stoliditas, foolyshenes, lewdenes. Stolidius, more foolyshely. Stolidus, da,
dum, foolyshe, lewd of conditions, odyouse. Stolones, branches which do
spryng out of the stemmes or roots of trees. Stomachicus, he that is sick in
his stomach. Stomachor, aris, ari, to have indignation, to be vexed in mind.
Stomachose, angerly, hatefully, disdainously Stomachosus, dysdaynous.
Stomachus, is the pipe, whereby meat goth down. It is also that which is
called Ve^triculus, whereunto we have none other name but the stomach.
sometime it sygnifyeth indignation, vehemente wrath, hatrede, and abhorrynge
of a thing that lyketh not us, Sommetyme facylytie or gentylnesse. Plinius.
Storax, racis, a sweet incense or gum, which is also called styrax, whereof
be two kinds, the one is called Storax calamita, the other is called Storax
liquida. Storea, any thing that is spredde on the ground. It is also a matte.
Strabo, he that looks a squynte, or gogle eyed. Strages, a slaughter of me^,
or a discomfiture. Stragulum, every ouermoste garment. Also a counterpoynte or
couerlyd. Stramen, minis, straw, lytter. Stramentum, idem. Stramentitius, a,
um, that which is made of straw. Stramineus, a, um, of straw. Strangulo,
ar^, to strangle. Stranguria, dyffycultie to pysse. Stratagema, a polycie or
wise councille in wars. Strategus, a general captain of an army. Stratia,
an host or army. Stratiotes, a man of war. Stratiotes, an herb, which
grows on waters without any root. Stratioticus, ca, cum, warlyke,
pertainynge to wars. Stratius, idem. Also the name of one of the sons of
Nestor. Stratumino, are, to paue. Strator, toris, he that helps his master
to horseback, yeman of the styrope. Stratum, any thing that is strawed, Also
a bed. Strata, all that is laid on the bed. Stratum, a horse harneyse, a
streate or caulsey, paued with stone. Strebula, in the old tunge of Vmbri was
a piece of the flesh that was offered in sacrifyce. Strena, a new years
gift, or present. Strenue, valyantly, quyckely, boldly. Strenuitas, tatis,
actiuitie. Strenuus, a, um, valiant, prompt, actife, bold. Strepito, tare, to
make a noise often. Strepitus, tus, a noise made with the hands or fete.
Strepo, pui, pere, to make a greatte noise, proprely in goinge or clappynge of
handrs, sometime generally. Strepsiceroti, certain beasts in Affryke, having
crooked horns. Stria, a rabat or small furrowe made in stone or timber. Striata,
be also creuyses or small lines, which are seen in herbs. Stribligo, ginis, a
viciouse form in speking where the words agree not, and the parts of speech
be out of order. Striblita, bread made like to ropes or cords wounden.
Stricte, straightly. Strictim, shortly touched one after an other Strictim
refer, to report much in few words. Strictim attondere, to clyppe all at
ones. Strictior, ^ius, more strayte* Strictissimus, a, um, most strayte.
Strictiuella, a foul ill favored hoore. Strictiuae, olyues gathered with ma^e
hand. Stricturae, sparks which do issue from metal when it is taken out
of the fire, and beaten with hammers. Strideo, dui, dear, and strido, dis,
dear, to crashe or make a noise like to cords, when they be drawn. Stridon, a
town in Dalmacia, where saynct Hierome was borne. Striga, a rewe of things
when they be laid in length. Alsoo a ridge of land, whereof comes
strigatus ager. Striges, shrycheoules, also women which are supposed to come
by night into houses, and suck the bloudde of chylderne, some call them
hegges. Strigia, wide garments made of lether used in wars. Strigil, gilis,
an horsecombe, alsoo a thing wherewith wrastelers bound their bodies, when
they had wrasteled. Alsoo a certain vessel. Strigiles, were rubbing combs
made of sweet wodde, wherewith in India the men were rubbed for an exercise.
Also kerchifes, wherewith wrastelers after their labors wyped their bodies.
also certain vessels. Budeus.
also pieces of fine gold found in mines, vnmyxt with any other matter. also
little fyshes most commonly taken in winter time. Strigilecula, a diminutiue
of strigil. Strigillo, are, to strain hard. Strigium, a spanyshe garment.
Strigmenta, fylthynesse, which commethe from a man's body, when he is washed.
also the corruption of oil. Strigo, gonis, a well pightman, or well compacte
or strong. Strigosus, a, um, carrayn lean, it is proprely spoken of horses or
routher beasts. Strimon, onis, a river in Thracia. Stringo, xi, gere, to
strain or wrynge. Also to stryke, to make thynne in curtynge, to gather, to
shave, to wound. Stringere ensem, to draw a sword. Strio, striare, to make
rabattes in stoone or timber. Alsoo to make furrows. It is proprely when
beasts in carynge at the end of a furrowe tournethe to make a new furrowe.
Sum do call hit, to wend. Striare, is also to plane or to polyshe.
Stritare, to abide or tarry with an ill will, or with much pain. Stritauum,
old writers used for Tritauo, my grandfathers grandfather. Stritomellus, a
sparowe, which hauntethe the sea costs. Strix, strigis, a shryche oule, a
wytche that changes the favor of chylderne. Striges, gross herbs or
wortes. Strobilus, a pyne apple tree. sometime the kernels, or fruit. Strobus,
a tree, whereof perfumes were made, myxte with the wine of dates, which perfume
was sweet, but it made the heed heavy, all be it without any pain. Stroma, it is,
tapisry. Strombon, a kind of Labdanum. Strombus, a shelle fyshe of the sea,
which has a king, whom they follow. It was thought sommetyme that he which
had seen that fysshe, should have good luck in his affairs. Strongyle, and
Strongylos, an I Will in the sea called Aegeum, now called Axos, sometime it was
called Dia. Stropha, subtyltie in arguing. Strophas, a whirlynge or sudden
turnyng. Strophades, two Isles in the grekysshe see. Strophia, garlandes which
priests were wont to wear. Strophiolum, a little garlande. Strophos,
frettynge in the bowelles. Strophium, a maidens neckerchefe or lynnen
partlette. Structiles columnae, pyllars made of diverse pieces. Structilis, le,
made of many pieces, or of diverse things. Structor, to^is, a caruer of meat
at a table. Structura, buylding, setting of things in good order. Strues, a
pyle of wodde, also a cake. Struices, an ordinance of many things together.
Strufectarij, they which did carye cakes to the temple to be offered, as they
do now carry the holy lofe on the sunday. Struferarii, they which did
sacrifyce at the trees that were burned with lyghtninge. Strufetani, they
which brought meal to be offered. Struma, a swellynge within the throat,
which is gathered matter and blood. some think it to be that, which is
called the kings evil. Strumosus, he that has the kings euylle. Struo,
struxi, struere, to set in order. Strumum, a medycyne or plaster for the
kings evil. Strupearia, holidays among the people called falisci, at the
which day, the people do go with garlandes on their heedis. Struppum, is a
like holydaye among the people called Tusculani. Struppi, were little wrethes
made of leaves put on the heedes of images in the temples, as now
superstitious sooles do set on images heedes in the churches. Strutheus, the
priuye membre of a man. Struthia, a certain kind of quynces. Struthiocamelus,
an ostryche. Struthio, idem. Struthopus, a round foot like a sparowe.
Struthopedes, they which have lyttelle round fecte. Strychius, an herb,
which makes him mad that eats of it. Strychium bibit, a proverb
sygnyfyenge the man is mad. Studeo, dui, dear, to study, or to apply the
mind, or care for a thing, to endeavor. Studiosus, studious, dylygent,
constant, addicte or fervently disposed. Studiose, studiousely. Studium,
study. sometime exercise, will, or appetite, desire. Stultitia, folly, it is
known by four things, or if he has not in remembrance that he should have,
or if he has, he does not retayn it, or does not follow good council, or does
approve ill council or affections. Stultior moricho, he that neglects his
own business at home, and applies other men's abroad, It is alsoo a proverb
touching them, which do things, that cause them to be laughed to scorn.
Stultior Choroebo, a proverb applied to fools, which will assaye to do a
thing that is above their wit or learning: for Choroebus, was a fellow, that
assayed to number the wawes of the sea, wha^ he him self could not tell any
number above five. Stulte, folyshely. Stultiloquentia, and stultilo quium, a
foolysshe babblynge. Stultiloquus, he that talks or speakethe foolyshely.
Stultior, stultius, more foolyshe. Stultissimus, ma, mum, most folyshely.
Stultius, more folyshely. Stultorum feriae, was a time in the monethe of
February, that fools kept holy, fools holy day. Stultus, he that does a
thing unadvisedly or without discretion. Stupa, towe, the course part of flax.
Stuparius malleus, the hammer, wherewith calkers do beat towe into shyps or
botes Stupefactus, astonyed. Stupefio, I am astonyed or abashed. Stupeo, and
stupesco, pui, pere, to be astonyed or dismayde. sometime to marvel at.
Stupefacio, cere, to make astonid, or to cause to marvel or be abashed.
Stupentia, uel stupida membra, the members which have lost all their sense or
feling. Stupiditas, an abashement. Stupidus, dysmayed, abashed, also he that
feleth nothing, or lacks his senses. Stupor, poris, abashement, the sudden
privation of sense or feeling. Stupre, dishonestly, shamefully. Stupro, prare,
to commit auoultrie or rape or to defloure a virgin. Stuprum, auoutrie, or
defloration of a virgin Stura, an isle again the mouth of Tyber. Styga, a
senne in Egypt not far from the city of Memphis. Stygeus, ea, um,
pertaining to Styx, the great fenne, which is feigned of poets to be by the
field called Elysius, which the paynyms did suppose to be a place of
pleasure, wherein rested the souls of good men. Stylobata, a trowgh of timber,
wherein water rounnethe, or is conuayed into a cesterne. Stylus, a style,
which quality of words in speaking, sometime hard, sometime easy, sometime
in a mean. also an elegant form or order in writynge or speakinge.
Stymphalus, a river in Arcadia. Stymphalide, a coppe of feathers, which
stands on the heed of a bird, as of a lark, an heron, a pecocke, and other.
Stipticus, ca, cum, that which stops or binds, or straineth, if it be
eaten or dronken. Also that which in tastynge seems to strain the tunge, as
a quynce or red wine. Styrax, racis, a soote gum called storax, whereof be
two kinds, the one is called storax calamita, the other storax liquida. Styx,
sygnifieth sorrow or heaviness, poets do feign, that it is a fenne, which is
in hell.
S ANTE V.
SVada, called in greek Pitho, was callid the goddess of eloquence or
dylectable speech. Suadela, persuasion, fair speech. Suadeo, si, dear, to
speak fair, to entreat with fair words, to endeavor, to induce a man into
our opinyon, or to believe us. Suadibilis, le, that which may be persuaded.
Suasibilis, idem. Sualternicum, a kind of ambre, which is yelowe, whereof
beads be made, and is called Laumbre. Suapte, of his own nature. Suarius, a
swyne herd. Suasibiliter, an aduerbe signifyenge, in manner to persuade.
Suasio, an exhortation, a mocyon or persuasyon. Suasor, soris, he that does
exhort. Suasum, every color that may turn into an another color. Suauiatio,
a sweet kissing. Suauiator, he that kysseth swetely. Suauilo quium, a sweet
speech. Suauiloquus, he that speaks swetely. Suasorius, a, um, that wherewith
a man is or may be persuaded. Suatim, like a sow. Suauior, aris, ari, and
suauio, to kiss sweetly or for joy. Suauis, suau^, sweet in taste, soote in
odor or smelle. Suauita^, and sua^^tudo, sweetness. Suauiter, sweetly.
Suauium sumere, to kiss. Suauium facere, idem. Suauium, and sauium, swear
heart. Sub, under, by, or about. Sub lucem, by day light. Sub idem tempus, In
the same time, or about the same time. Sub horam pugnae. About the time of the
battayl. Sub eas autem redditae sunt, for they were delivered after them. Sub
sarcinis, with the trussis or carriage. Cicer. pro Planco.
Sub uesperum, in the twye light. Subuesperum Caesar portas claudi, militesque
ex oppido exire iussit, Caes. in co^.
In the twie light Caesar commanded the gates to be shut, and the me^ of
war to depart out of the city. Subacidus, eida, cidum, somewhat eygre, or
sour. Subacidulus, a, um, a little sour. Subactus, ta, tum, constrained,
subdewed, driven under, kneaded or wrought with hands, as dowe is, labored,
exercised. Subaeratus, ta, tum, that which is brass with in, and other metal
without. Subaero, rare, to myngle with brass. Subagito, tare, to solycite.
Subagito blandis, and benedicis uerbis, Plautus in ^^ell.
I solicited with fair and well spoken words. It is also to company with a
woman carnally. Subalaris, subalare, that which is under the wings.
Subalpini, people under the Mountains called Alps, called Peemountaynes.
Subalternatio, a succession by turn. Subalterno, nare, to succeed by turn.
Subaquaneus, a, um, and subaqueus, a, um, that which lies under the water.
Subaquilus, la, lum, broune of color. Subare, is spoken of women, which are
as filthy as swyne in the act of lechery. Subire, idem. Subareo, and
subaresco, rescere, to be or wax somewhat dry. Subasper, somewhat sharp.
Subaudio, dire, to here or perceive a lyttel. Subausculto, tare, to harken a
little. Subbasilicanus, he that walkethe under the place, where iugementes are
practysed. Subbibo, bibere, to drink a little. Subblandior, diri, to flatter.
Subcalidus, da, dum, somewhat hot, warm. Subcernicula, a line bulter, wherewith
the flower is severed from the branne. Subcerniculum, a rangynge sleue.
Subcingulum, a bracynge gyrdell. Subcineritius, a, um, roasted or baken under
the ashes, or axen. Subcisiua tempora, times borrowed or spared from seryous
^^^ynesse. Subcisiua opera, warkes cone at times stole^ from ordinary basines
or labors necessary. Subcollo, lare, to lay a thing on ones neck Subcrispus,
he that has a curlyd heed. Plautus in milite.
Subcu^^os, an under keeper. Subcutaneus, a, um, that which is within the
skin, between the skin and the flesh. Subdelego, gare, to commytte to an
another any matter, which is committed unto us by the king or prince.
Subdialia, things which do stand or be set abroad out of the house.
Subdiali^s, ale, abroad in the air without the house. Sub dio, that is not in
a house, or under a covering. Subdititius, ia, ium, which is not proprelye
his or hirs, whose it is fained to be. Partus subdititius, a birth feigned of
an another man's child. Libri subdititij, books with falls titles or
counterfaite auctours. Subditiuus, a counterfayte child. Subditus, a subject.
Subditus, ta, tum, idem quod subdititius. also put in the place of an other.
Subditus iudex, a judge which is set in the place of a judge departed.
Plautus in mostell. Plautus in epistol. and Plin. in epi.
Sub diu, in the day time. Subdo, dear, to put under, to add to, to put in
the place of an another, to put in danger or ieoperdie. Subdolus, he that
deceyueth craftily, cantelouse. Subdole, craftily cantelously. Subdubie,
somewhat doubtefully. Subdubitanter, idem. Subdubito, tare, I doubt somewhat.
Subdubius, somewhat in doubt. Subdubitatio, a little doubt. Terent. in
Andria.
Subducere, to deceive. Etiam nunc me subducere istis dictis postulas? And yet
now will thou goo about with these words to deceive me? Subducere, to
steal. Plautus in Curcu.
Proximo magnum poculum ille bibit, caput ponit, cum dormiscit, ei sub duco
anulum, At the last he drank a great draught, and laid down his heed, whiles
he slepte, I st^le his ring from him. Subduco, xi, cere, to take away, to
remove, to lift up, or draw up. Subducere rations, to make account, to go or
steal away privily. Subductum omnibus uentis aedificiu^, a house in the
danger of every wind. Subeo, iui, ire, to go under or in, to take. Subire
mortem, to receive death. Subductio, a drawing up of a ship out of the
water. Subdulcis, ce, somewhat sweet. Subduro, rare, to make somewhat hard*
Subduror, ra^i, to be made somewhat hard. Suber, cork. Subiaceo, cere, to lie
under, also to be subject Subiacto, tare, and subiecto, to cast up, as corn
when it is fanned. Subices, subjects. Subiecto, tare, to cast under often.
Subiector, toris, a forger of testamentes, or he that brings forth one
testament for an another. Subicito, tare, to company often with a woman. Plautus
in persa.
Subiculum flagri, a beatynge stock. Subigo, egi, igere, to constrayne, to
subdue, to drive under, to whet, to beat or sta^pe, sometime to ear or tylle
truly, to dig, to meddyll with a womanne, Vergil.
sommetyme to lift up. Subi^cio, ieci, ijcere, to put under, to make subject.
sometime to cast up, to rehearse. Si meministi quod olim dictum est, subijce, If
thou do remember, what was ones spoken, rehearse it. Subinde, more over,
forthwith or anon, often times. Subin, idem. Fe^tus.
Subingere arietem, to deliver a sheep to be killed for him that does
sacrifyce. Ci. A^t. 2.
Subinnanis, ne, somewhat vayneglorious. Subire aleam, to be in danger or
peril, to enter into peril. Subire periculum, to enter into peril. Subijt
mihi, it comes to my remembrance. also to succeed, to resist, to clymme.
Plinius in p^m^gy^i.
Subire, to take charge of any thing. Quis enim curae tuae molem sponte
subeat? Who would wyllyngly take on him the great weight of thy charge. Cicer.
off.
Subire, to suffer or sustain. Qui retinendi officij causa, cruciatus subierit
vitro, He that will for the accomplyshement of his duty suffer tourmentes
wyllyngly. Alsoo to grow or spring up. Vergil.
Also to come to remembrance. Sera poenitentia subijt regem, Late repentance
came to the kings remembrance. Cogitationi nostrae nunquam subijt, It came
never to our thought. Subit recordatio, I or he remembered. Vergi. Atnei. x.
Subire, to put under. Aeneas subijt mucronem, ipsumque morando sustinuit,
Eneas put under his sword, and tarieng, lyfted him up. Subire, to succeed or
come in place. In quarum Iocu^ subierunt inquilinae, impietas, perfidia
impudicitia, In whose place succeeded new inhabytauntes, contempt of virtue,
disloyalty, lechery. Cic. in diuinatione.
Subire, to answer or resyste. Poteris ne orationem eius subire? Moughtest
not thou make answer to his oration? Subire, to clymme or mount up. Hemi
excelcitas, sex millibus passuu^ subitur, the height of the mountain of Hemus
is clymmed or mounted in six thousand paces. Subliasto, tare, to sell any
thing in time of wars that was praised. Hasta, a yerde, which was delivered
to him that was appointed to selle any thing taken in wars. Subfibulum, was
a white ornamente, four square and long, which the nuns, callid Vestales,
ware on their hodes, when they did sacrifyce. Subito, suddenly. Subitaneus, and
subitarius, a, um, and subitus, ta, tum, sudden. Subiugalis, le, used to the
yoke. Subiugo, gare, to make subject. Sub iugum mittere, to bring in
subjection. Subiungo, gere, to add or join to. Sublabor, beris, lapsus sum,
labi, to slyppe away. Sublabro, brare, to put into the mouth. Sublatior,
tius, higher. Sublatus, ta, tu^, lifted up, mounted, adua^ced. Sublegere
sermonem, Clam nostrum hu^c illae sublegerunt sermonem, Plautus in milite.
Privily they harkned, and bare away all that we co^muned. Sublego, are, to
substitute. Sublego, legi, legere, to steal. also to chese an other into the
place of him that is deed. Sublestus, ta, tum, feeble, faint, light, of no
force or value. Subleuo, are, to help, or aid, to defend, to lift up, to
sustain. Sublica, a proppe, a shore, a post, or other like thing, to sustayn
or keep a thing up. Sublicius, a briege at Rome. Subligaculum, a nether coyfe
or brieche. Subligar, garis, idem. Subligo, gare, to vnderbynde. Sublimis, me,
high, that which is above us. Sublimitas, heyght. Sublimiter, highly, on
height. Sublimo, mare, to set on high. Sublino, liniui, nire, to annoint or
touch, to paynt or stayne. Sublinitio, the first color that is laid or
dyed. also staynynge with colors. Sublitio, onis, the ground color, whereon
the perfyte color is laid, in cloth dyed, it is called grasynge. Subluceo,
cere, to shine sommewhat, or to give a little light. Sublucide, somewhat
light. Sublucidus, da, dum, somewhat light. Subluco, care, to vndershrede
boughs, that that the light may come under the tree. Subdialia, places without
the house to walk in without couerynges. Subducere, to go away by stelthe, that
no man do perceive. Sub iugum mitti, to be subdued, it was proprely when a
battle was vanquished, the vanquishers caused three spears to be set up lykes
galowes, and constrained them that were vanquyshed to go underneath it, in token
that they were subdued, which was the greattest reproach that moughte be
devised. Subluere, to vnderwashe, as water, which runs low under a bank
or hylle, Caesar de ^ell. galli. lib. 2.
and washes the foot thereof. Also to wash somewhat clean. Sublustris, tree,
that has some light. Subluines, a disease of cattle, which is betwixt the
cleys of their fete. Cice. pro Planco.
Sub manu habere, to have at hand. Sub manu esse, to be at hand or ready. Sub
manu, after hand, forthewith. Sub manus, easily, handsomely. Bono animo es,
Plautus in melite.
negotium omne iam succedit submanus, Be of good chere, all the matter is come
to pass handsomely. Lepide hoc succedit sub manus negotium, This mattier
comes well and easily to pass. Sub merum, almost pure. Subminia, a woman's
garment. Subministro, are, to do service under one, to give or deliver any
thing that is asked for. Subministrator, he that serves under an other man, he
that delyuereth any thing that is called for. Submissim, and submisse,
softely, proprely in speaking. also humbly. Submissus, a, um, humble.
Submitto, tere, to send privily or by stelth. Cae. de bell. gall. lib. 5.
Submittere, to send or bring in the mean time. Also to put or set under
proprely, as a calfe, a lamb, or a fool, is set under the damme to suck.
Submittere se, to humble him self. Submittere capillum, to let hear to grow.
Submoneo, nere, to warn one priuyly. Submordeo, dear, to bite softely, or
privily. Colum. 5. Plin.
Submoueo, uere, to remove or carry a thing far of. also to drive out of a

note or mark. Subo, are, to brymme as a bore does when he gets pigs.

a mock with bendynge the brows, and snuffynge up of the nose. Subsannator, a
mocker. Subsarcinis, with trusses or burdeyns. Subscribo, scripsi, scribere, to
write under, to subscribe, to favor a matter, Ci. in Ver. Asco. Ped.
to assynge a cause why, to affirm. Subscriptores, they which in causes

table, whereunto other tables are fastened. Subseco, care, to cut under or cut
a little. Subsellia, be^ches, which were under higher seats, they were also

Subuerto, tere, to turn up so down. alsoo to distroy, to subuerte.
Subuerso, sare, to subuerte often. Subueteribus, was a place in Rome. Subula,
an aulle, that cordyners do use for a bodkyn. Subulcus, a swyneherde. Subulo,
an heart having horns without tynes, called as I suppose, a spyttarde.
Subuolo, lare, to flee away. Suburbanum, a manner or ferme without the walls of
the city. Suburbia, the suburbs of a city or town. Suburrana regio, the
street in Rome where the brothell houses were. Subuulturius, a, um, that which
apprehends men like as rauynes do carrayne. Succedaneus, a, um, that which
succedeth. Succedere, to enter. Et nostris succeed penatibus hospes, And enter
thou my friend into my house. Succedere, to go under a thing. Succedere, to
speed well, to be at a good point. Hac no^ successit, alia aggrediamur uia, This
way it spedeth not, let us go to an other way. Succedo, cessi, cedere, to
succeed. Succendo, dear, to inflame to burn. Succe^seo, ui, ere, to be a^gry
for a good cause. Succento, tonis, was a certain garmente, which only hoores

base. Succenturiatus, he that made up the number of the bend of men that
lacked. Succenturio, are, to make up the number of a hundred soldiers, or of
that company that was called Centuria. Succerda, swynes dunge. Succerno, creui,
cernere, to raunge meal in a syeue. Successio, succession. Successor, soris, a
successor. Successore^ dare, to depose a man of his office. Successus, a, um,

be it good or ill. Succida, woulle unwashed. Succidaneae hostiae, beasts for
sacrifice, which were killed in the second place, or next to the first.

down. also to fall under. Plautus in Curcu.
Succiduus, a, um, that which does succeed or follow. also low, ready to
fall down. Succidusda, dum, moist, or full of iuyse. Succingo, xi, gere, to

the.xii. Calendes of June, and be called succulae and Hiades. Sudarium, a
napkynne. Sudes, a certain spear, which is burned at the end. Sudo, dare,
to sweat, to labor soore, to have much to do. Sudor, doris, sweat. Sudum,
the clear part of the firmamente between clouds. Also the clear fyrmame^t
without clouds. Suefacio, and suefio, fieri, to be wont. Suere aliquid capiti,
to get a shrewde turn. Metuo lenonem, ne quid suo suat capiti, I am aferde of
the bawd, lest he get a shrewde turn. Suesco, sueui, suescere, to be
wont. Sueui, a people in high Germany. Sueuia, a country in Germanye.
Suffarcinatus, nata, natum, laded, trussed. Suffarcino, nare, to lade or
bourdeyne, to trusse up. Suffarrancus, he that carries meal or flower to any
place to selle in little quantytie. Suffectus, is he, which an offycer being
deed, or removed, is set in his place. Suffes, was among the Carthaginensis,
as the Consul was at Rome. Suffibulum, was an attire, which the nuns of
Vesta did wear on their heedes, when they did sacrifice, and was like to
the tyres, which wives of London did wear, and becamme them much better
than bonettes of veluette do now, wherewith they mock ladies and
gentyllwomenne, and thereby only do get the name to be callydde Maskynge
ladies. Suffero, sufferre, to sustain, to put under, to suffer. Sufficio,
feci, sufficere, to suffyse, to endure, to minister, to substitute, to stayne.
Sufficit, it suffyseth. Suffimentum, perfume, or fumigation. Suffio, fiui,
fire, to perfume. Suffiscus, the codde of a ram, which was made for a purse,
to conteyne money. Suffitio, and suffitus, tus, a perfume or fumigacyon.
Suffitor, toris, he that blows the fire. Suffitus, ta, tum, perfumed.
Sufflamen, that wherewith a whiele is retained or stopped of his course.

equi, horses, which have the pains or scratches. Suffragor, gatis, gari, to

in the eye. Suffusus, a, um, sprynkled, indewed. Suggero, gessi, gerere, to

rain. Suggrundaria, buryals of young infantes. Suggrundario, the eueysynge of

It is alsoo to scorn, to detracte, or infame, to reprove, to condemn.
Suggillatus, spotted, mocked, detracted, infamed, condemned. Suggillatio, is a
a mark in the visage black or blue, made by some stroke, a mock, a

sugere, to souke. Suinus, a, um, and suillus, a, um, of a sow. Sulcatim, in
furrows. Sulco, care, to falowe. Sulcus, cus, a furrowe. Serere tertio quarto
quinto sulco, To sow in the third, the fourth, the fyfthe falowe. Sometime
it is put of a dyche. Also any manner of cuttynge of the earth. proprely it
signifies any thing that is long and sharp edged. Bisulcum animal, A beast
that has the fete cloven with two talons. Sulla, was a cruel tyrant of the
Romans called also Sylla. Sulmo, monis, a town in the countraye of Peligna,
where Ouidius the poet was borne. Sulmonensis, a man or woman of the city
of Sulmo. Sulphuraria, a place where brymstone is boiled. Sulphur, phuris,
brymstone. Sulphur eus, ea, eum, of brymstone. Sulphuratus, ta, tum, dressed
with brimstone. Sultanus, a sowdane, which was the name of the king of Egipte
and Siria. Sum, I am, es, thou art, est, he is. Sumanus, he that always takes.
Su^ Amphitrionis, I am Amphitrions servant. Plaut.
Sum mihi bis septem praestanti corpore nymphae, I have fouretene maidens of
excellent beauty. Sum in mora illi, I make him to tarry. Terentius
Sum in moetu, I am aferde. Sum in noxia, I am put in the blame. Sum, old
writers used for eum, him. No. Mar. Plautus in milite.
Sit uestra benignitas ad audiendum? Pleasith you to here? Sum septem dies, It
is seven days agone. How this verb Sum, should be set and construed, read
Calepines vocabuler, also look for Est, fuit, and such other parts of sum, in
their letters before. Sumanalia, a great cake made like a whele, such as is
made at brydales and church goinges. Summam facere, to sum a book of
account. Sumen, minis, is made of the pappes of a sow, cut from her the day
after that she has varowed, ad is powdered with salt. Cicero.
Sumere, to hyre. Quoad enim peruentum, quo sumpta nauis est, non domini nauis
est, sed nauigantium, Until they come to the place whither the ship was
hired, the ship is not the owners but theyrs, which are passagers. Terent.
in phormi.
Sumere, to borowe. Sumere, to spend or bestow on one. In mala vxore, atque
inimico, si quid sumas, sumptus est, On a shrewd wife, and an ennemy, what so
ever thou bestowest, is waste. Plautus in milite. Plautus in cap. Plautus in
Bacch. Terentius

supplicium, to punyshe. Summa, is a collection of things or words. also the
principal point of a matter. Su^mates, the chief persons of a realm or cite.
Summatim, and summate, compendiousely by every part of the matter, summarily.
Ad summum duo, two at the most. Sum, excellently, chiefly. Summenianae
uxores, hoores kept in the stead of wives. Summenium, a place where bawdrye
was kept without the walls of a town. Summissi, murmurers. Summissim, and
summisse, softly, not loud. Summissus, a, um, base, low. Summitas, heyght, or

Su^mum fastigiu^ imponere, to finishe a thing perfitely, to bring a mattier

Supellectilis, le, and supellex, household stuff, all things mouable within
the house. Supellecticarius, a bondsman or slave, which is accounted for
chatell. Super, and supra, upon above. Super Garamantas and Indos proferet
imperium, Vergil.
He shall advance his empire beyond the Garamantians and Indianes. Super
Euclionis filia^, of Eucliones daughter Super coenam, at supper. Plautus in
Aulularia^ Plinius epist. 87. Epist. 91. Vergilius.
Super haec, more over than this. Super Priamus, super Hectore, of Priamus of
Hector. Hac super re scriba^ ad te Rhegio, Of that matter I will write unto you
from Regiu^. Super for propter. Nec super ipse sua molitur laud laborem, Nor
he takethe the pain for his praise. Super, for valde, His accensa super,
Vergilius.
with those words she being kendlyd or styred. Superaddo, dear, to put or
add to. Superbe, proudely. Superbiter, idem. Superbia, pride. Superbio, ire,
to be proud. Superbiloquens, and superbiloquus, he that speaks proudely, or
hautely. Superbiloquentia, proud or haute words. Superbos, old writers used
for mortuos, Plautus in Amphi.
deed, because of the pomp, which was at their burienge. Faciam ego hodie te
superbum, nisi hinc abis, I will kyl the, if thou get the not hens. Superbum
bellum, unjust or unhappy war. Vergil.
Superbus, proud, sometime magnifyke or noble, also high, ornate, or
garnysshed, rich, wicked. Supercido, dear, to fall on. Superciliosus, sour
in countenance. Supercilium, the ouerbrowe. sommetyme it sygnifyeth pride,
gravity. It is alsoo the haunce, which is over the door. Superciliu^
attollere, to be stately or proud. Supercilium ponere, to lay aparte pride or
stately countenance. Supercresco, scere, to ouergrowe. Supercubo, bare, to lie
over. Superduco, cere, to put or lay on. Superedo, dear, to eat after a
thing. Superessit, for supererit, shall live, or be left on live. Superest, he
lives, or is on live. Superest, there is plenty or more thanne enough. Aliis
quia defit, quod amant, aegre est: Terent. in pho^m.
tibi quia superest, dolet, Some because they lack the thing that they love,
be discontent: and thou art sorye that thou haste more than thou nedest.
Terent. in Heart.
Superesse, to be the rest or resydue. Porro ausculta quod superest fallatiae,
But yet here what was the resydue of that craft or deceyte. To defend or
plead for one. Cu^ctarise, ne si superesset, eriperet legibus reu^, He would
tarry, lest if he came and spoke for him, he should deliver an offender.
Superexto, tare, to remain over. Superficiariae aedes, houses builded on the
land of an another man than builded them. Superficiarius, he that has a house
of his own builded on an other man's ground, and pays therefore a quyte rent.
Superficies, the ouermost part of any thing. Superfoetatio, oone conception of
a child after an other. Superfluo, fluxi, fluere, to abound, or be
superfluouse. Superflue, superfluousely. Superfluo, idem. Superfluus, a, um,
superfluous. ^^^onius.
Superforaneus, a, um, idem. Superfundo, dear, to pour upon. Supergredior,
gredi, to go above. Supera, for supra. Superiacio, ieci, iacere, to cast on or
lay on. Superiiceo, superieci, iicere, to cast upon, to lay upon. Superi,
they which ben in heaven. Superincido, dear, to fall on. Superior, higher.
Superior aetas, the time or age passed. Superlachrimo, to weep or drop upon.
Supermeo, are, to go over, or slyppe over. Supernato, natare, to swymme over.
Supernati, they which have the hinder part of the thighs next the buttockes
cut away Superne, a high, above. Supernia, the inward part and hindermost
part of the thyghes next the buttockes cut of. Supernus, na, number, high, or
over. Superna regio, the high country. Supernumerarius, that which is in
surplusage, above the true number. Supero, rare, to go over. Also to vanquishe
or overcome. also to ouerlyue. sometime to kylle. Quod superat, which is more,
or is left in a surplusage. Superpondium, ouerweight, that which is added to
the just weight. Supersedeo, dear, to omytte or leave to do a thing. Ci.
Seruio
Supersedeas hoc labor itineris, take not the pain to come now, or forbear
the peyn taking in this journey. Supersede istis rebus, Plautus in Epidico.
Plautus in persa. Plin. epist. 102.
let these things alone Supersede istis uerbis, let these wordis pass, hold
thy runge. Supersedi scribere, I forbear to write, I left unwritten. Superstes,
stitis, he that ouerliueth or remaianeth alive afterthat other be deed, also
alive. sometime present, old writers called Superstites, witnesses. Superstes,
he that is saulfe. Deos quaeso, ut sis superstes, I beseech god save you, long
might you live. also present. Superstitem utrunque monui, ne inuisi abeant, I
aduysed them both, that they should not depart with dyspleasure. Superstitio,
a superfluous or vain religion or devotion, an honoring of that which ought
not to be honored, a vain reverence or fear toward that thing, wherein is no
efficacye or power, but by the illusyon of the dyuelle: as divination by the
cryenge or fleinge of birds, observation of times, and dreams, and other like
vanites. Superstitiosi, they which be tymorous without cause, fearinge that god
is displeased, where there is none offense done: They were at the first so
called, because they contynually prayid and offered to the goddis, to preserve
their chyldern, that they might ouerlyue them. Finally every indiscreet or
unreasonable devotion or religion, may be called Superstition. Superstito,
stirare, to make hoole or recover from death. Supersto, stare, to stand
upon. Superstruo, struxi, struere, to build on. Supersum, Superesse, to
abound, to remain, to vanquishe, to be superfluous, to endure. Superuacaneus,
a, um, superfluous. Superuacuus, a, um, not necessary. Superuaganea auis, was
of the diuinours or sothsayers called that bird, which cried from the top of
any thing. Superuenio, nire, to com unlooked for, to com upon or after an other
thing. Superuiuo, uixi, uiuere, to recover from peril of death, or when a man
seems to be dead. Superus, a, um, the highest or ouermost. Superum mare, the sea, which is callid Mare Hadtiaticum, wherein stands the City of Venyce.
Supinus, na, number, vpryghte, Horation.
the bealye vpvpwarde. sometime it sygnifieth on an hill or high place. Suppar,
almost even. Supparasitor, taris, tari, to follow and flatter for a man's
dinner. Supparium, a clothe or curtayne hanged up where interludes were playde.
Supparus, uel supparum, a smock. it is also a topsayle of a ship.
Suppedaneum, a foot stool. Suppedito, tare, to subdue, to minyster
sufficiently, also to oppress. Plautus in Asinar.
Suppedito, tare, to endure. Ac stomacho no^ queo labori suppeditare, My
stomach will not let me endure the labor. Alsoo to furnyshe expenses, to
give as much as a man would have. Terent. in Brautont.
Nam si illi pergam, suppeditare sumptibus Menedeme, mihi illaec uero ad
rastros res redit, Surely Menedemus, if I would give him as much as he would
spend, that thing would bring me to the point to rake for my living.
Suppeditare, to subdewe or tread under. Nunc, uideo, in iudicio mecum
contendere non uis, ubi suppeditari turpissimum, superare pulcherrimum est,
Now I perceive thou will not contend with me before judges, where it were a
great shame to be subdued, and very much honesty to have the better.
Suppetiae, and suppetias, aid or succors. Suppeto, tii, tere, to ask privily
or craftily. Suppetit, it is in a redynesse. Supperior, ari, to succor or
aid. Plautus in Asinar.
Suppetunt dictis data, aut facta. Non suppetunt dictis data, He perfourmeth
not that, that he promised. Vtinam quae dicis dictis facta suppetant, would god
thou would do as thou say, or would god thy deeds did agree with thy
words. Plautus in Ruden. Plautus in Amphit.
Suppetit lucrum, there is gain sufficient. Res ita supperit, the matter so
requires. Suppetias mihi, Bring to me succoures, aid me. Suppetias adueni,
come and help me. Suppetias far, to aid or succor. Suppilo, are, to steal
underhand or craftily. Supplanto, tare, to put under the foot, to
overthrow, to supplant or deceive, in preventing one to his hynderance or
damage, to vnderplante or set a tree or vine. Supplaudo, si, dear, to rejoice
privily. Supplementum, that which supplyethe or makes up that which lacks
in quantity or number. Suppleo, plere, to make up that which lacks, to make
even. Supplex, plicis, he that desires any thing knelynge or prostrate.
Supplicatio, a prayer, a request. Supplicassis pro supplicaueris. Supplicans,
it is, he that desires a thing. Suppliciter, humbly knelynge. Supplicium,
pain, tourmente, Salust. in bell. ca^. Iugurt.
or execution of death. sometime supplicia, are prayers. Supplitia pendere, to
be put to execution. Supplico, care, to beseech humbly. Supplimentum, a making
up of a number, which lacks or is minished. Supplodo, plosi, ere, Cor.
Tacitus lib. 13.
to stamp or make noise with the fete. also to reiecte or cast away.
Supplosio, a stampynge or noise made with the feet. Suppono, sui, nere, to put
under, to put into the place of an another, to set a false or feigned thing in
the place of that which is the very true thing. Supportare, to bring or
carry privily. Caesar de bell. Gall. lib. 7.
Suppositio, the puttinge or setting of a fained or falls thing in the place of
the thing self, as one child for an another. Suppostrix, she that co^mytteth
that falshod. Suppositus parius, when the child of one woman is laid with an
another womanne, which is not the very mother, as though she had borne it.
Subpraedes, countersureties, they which are bounden to the sureties, to save
them harmless. Suppressus, sa, sum, drowned, beaten under. Justinius.
Victi Persi in naues confugerunt, ex quibus multae suppressae, multae captae,
The Persians fled unto their ships, whereof many were drowned, and many
taken. Also hyd or concyled. Supprimo, pressi, supprimere, to keep down to
keep secret, to keep in silence. Supprimere iter, to stay or omit a journey.
Caes. in co^. de bello civilly. li. 1. Plautus in milite.
Suppromo, psi, mere, to draw out drink. Suppromus, a butlar. Bono cella
suppromo credita, The cellar or buttrie was committed to a good butlar.
Suppudet, I am half ashamed, thou art half ashamed, or he is half ashamed.
Suppurantia, and suppuratio, matterynge of a soore. Suppuratorius, ria, um,
that which pertaynethe to impostumes, or to make a soore to matter. Suppuro,
are, to matter or be an impostume. Suppuratio, an impostume or sore that has
matter. Supra, above, or over. Supra quam, for supra id quod. Supreme, highest
of all, or above all. Supremus, ma, mum, the highest or greatest of all other.
Supus, old writers used for supinus. Sura, the cause of the leg. sometime
the hole shanke or leg from the kne down. Surculaceus, and surcularis, re,
that which brings forth young settes or springes of trees Surculus, a young

used for surgit, whereof comes surrectio, a rysynge. Surrepo, pere, to crepe
under. Surreptitius, a, um, that which is done by stelthe that none other man
knows it. Surgo, surrexi, surgere, to rise, also to grow or spring. Vergil.
Surrigo, surrexi, surrigere, to lift up. Plautus in Amphit.

the host, Plautus in (...).
this time have I borrowed to do you pleasure. Surripere se, to steal his away.

late out of the market? Surripio, ripui, pere, to steal or take away privily.

Surrogatio, a substitution. Sursum, above. Sursum uersum, upward. Sursum
deorsum, up and down. Sus, for sursum. Suscio, scire, for scio, scire, to
know. Suscipere fidem, to promise. Quas parts impleturum te, secundum
susceptam fidem confido, Which part I trust thou will perform, according
to the promise that thou made. Plautus in milite. in Ruden.
Suscito, tare, to awake one out of his sleep, to call one to his warke. Sus,
suis, a sow. Sus Mineruam, a proverb applied unto him, which presumes to
teach or correct one, of whom he rather ought to be taught or corrected.
Suillus, la, lum, of a sow. Susque deque fero, and susque deque habeo, I force
not, I recke not, I care not. Susa, a great city in Persi^. Suscipio, scepi,

provocation or sterynge. Suscito, tare, to styre or provoke. Suspecto, tare, to
behold above. Mart.
sometime to see benethe, or to look down. Suspendeo, dear, Columel. Cicero.
to be hanged over or an high, also to appear a little. Suspendiosus, he that

Suspenso gradu, Haec ubi ego audiui, ad fores supenso gradu, placide ire

lift up. Susurratio, a whysterynge. Susurro, are, to whyster. Susurro, ronis,
a whysterer. also he which with falls and secret report makes dissencyon
between men. Susurrus, and susurrium, a whystrynge, or soft murmuring, or
such noise as trees do make with the wind, or a river when it runs, or
birds when they chatter. Sutatis, a seamster or shepster. Sutela, a subtyltie
or crafty warkynge. Suterna, showemakers craft. Sutilis, le, that which is
