conuenie^tly vsyd, read Valla or Calepines vocabularie. For it is more
abundantly and proprely declared of the^, than can be expressid in english.
S ANTE Y.
SYades, sterres callid also Hyades, seven in number. Syagros, a wild bore.
Sybaris, a city in Grecia. Sybarita, a man of that city. Sybaritica mensa, a
proverb applied to feasts and bankettes, which do excede in delycatenesse.
Sybaritici libelli, wanton books. Sybaritici ludi, plays which are wanton and
costly. Sybariticum carmen, a verse or poem contaynynge wanton matter. Syboti,
people in the north part of the world. Sychaeus, a man's name. Sycion, he that
first found garlandes. Sycomorus, a great tree like a fygge tree, which has
abundance of milk, whose fruit comes not out of the tops of the bowghes,
as fygges do, but out of the same boughs, and sweet like to a wild fygge:
the graynes thereof be les than the grains of figgis, and they be never ripe,
except they be scrapid with an instrument of yro^. Sycophanta, he that falily
accuses an innocent. Also a bearer of tales, or a co^playner. Sycophantia, a
falls accusation, deceit. Sycophantias struere, to deuyse, or inuente
falsehoode. Sycophantor, tari, idem. Sycophantisso, are, idem. Sycophantiose,
deceytefully by craft. Sycon, old writers called a fygge. Sycosis, a disease
in the fundement, which makes a warte like to a fygge. Sycosis, where within
the eye lyd grows a little wart or other like thing. Sydera, the plurell
number of sydus. Syderatio, a spyce of the falling evil in men, but in trees
it is taken for blastynge. Sydus, syderis, a sterre. Syene, a city in the
confynes of Egypt and Ethiope. Sygeum, a promontorie of Troy. Syla, a
mountain in Lucania, and a wod in it. Sylla, a great tyrant of Rome, which
was of an insatiable cruelty. Syllaba, a syllable. Syllabarim, by syllables.
Syllabicus, ca, cum, pertaynyng to sillables. Syllanion, a famous maker of
images, which was never taught. Syllepsis, a figure, where the plurell number
and the synguler are joined together, as socijs and rege recepto. Syllogismus,
a perfyte argument, which has a necessary conclusion. Sylua, a wodde or
place ouergrowen with wedes, also any matter hastily written with out study.
Syluanus, was called the god of woddes. Syluaticus, ca, cum, pertaynyng to
woddes. Syluecula, and syluula, a little forest or wod. Syluesco, scere, to
wax or grow into woddes or bushes. Syluester, syluestris, tree, of a wodde or
forest, woddy, wild. Syluicola, he that dwells in a foreste or wodde.
Syluius, a man's name, which was borne in a foreste. Syma, a city in Asia.
Symbolum, a collation. also a token given by one to an other upon certain
appointmentes, generally a sign or mark to know a thing by. Symbolus, a
signet or sele, or a sign manuel. Symbulus, a wise and good counsailour.
Symmachia, aid in battle, or leage made among men of sundry countries, to
fight against the other part. Symmachus, a man's name. Symmetria, a concord
in measure, where sundry things be of equal proporcion. Sympathia, a mutual
combination of things natural in the operation of their powers and qualities,
as water in coldenesse does participate with earth, in moisture with the air,
the air with the fire in heat, with water in moisture. Symphitum petreium, an
herb called bugle Symphitum magnum, comfrey. Symphonia, a consent in tune,
also harmony. Symphoniacus, a singing boy. Symphonio, are, to agree or accord
in one. Symphonesis, colysion of vowelles. Sympinaticae, women addicte to
ceremonies or devotion. Sympiniu^, a cup serui^g for wine in sacrifice.
Symplator, a friend of him that is married, which accompanies him to feasts.
Symplega, warkes, in the which wrastlers, and they which contend in
fighting, are beholden. Symplegades, two yles in the grekyshe see. Symplegma,
an imbracynge together. Sympos^astes, he that makith a fest or ba^ket
Symposium, a bankette. Sympot^^a, a woman which keeps company at drinking.
Symnisia, a secretary, or one of the pryuye councylle. Sympsalma, a concord in
singing. Sympudcaria, funerals or plays, wherein plays were made. Synada, a
city in Asya. Synaeresis, a contraction of two words, as Bigae, for b^iugae.
Synagoga, a congregation, specially of jews. Synalephe, a collision of vowels.
Synanche, a syckenesse in the throat, called the squynce. Sincere, purely,
incorruptly. Syncerus, ra, rum, sincere, pure, uncorrupted simple without
dissimulation. Synchronos, of one time. Synciput, syncipitis, the forepart of
the heed Also a swynes heed soweyd. Syncopa, a figure, where a letter or
syllable is taken away, as co^postus, for co^positus. Sync^doche, a figure,
where part is vsyd ^^r the hole, or the hole for part. Syndicus, an advocate.
Syndipnium, a soupynge together. Synechon, contynent. Synephites, a stone,
which is called alsoo Leucongia. Syngraplia, syngraphus, and syngraplium, the
wrytinge or deed, made or signed with the hand of him that makes a bargayne
or couenaunte. Synochitides, a stone, wherewith nygromancers do call up dyuels.
Synodus, an asse^bly of me^, or general cou^cil. Synonimum, which in diverse
words sygnifieth one thing, as Eusis, Gladius, both do sygnifie a sword.
Occidit, interfecit, necanit, do signify, he killed. Synopis, synoper or read
lead. Synstratiotes, companio^s together in war. Syntagma, a treaty, an
ordinance. Syntaxis, order in construction. Syntexis, lack, or weakness,
which happens by long syckenes. Synteresis, the pure part of conscience.
Synthema, a token given to soldiers. Synthesis, a short cote or ierkyn. also
a vessel made of many vessels. Syntomon, for circu^cisum. Sypharium, a
curtayne hanged before minstrels when they sing. Syphax, was the king of
Numidia. Syracusae, a famous city in Sycile. Syracusius, and Syracusanus, of
that city. Syria, a great realm in Asia, which has on the east the river
of Euphrates, on the weste the myddell see, and the realm of Egipte, on the
north Cilicia and Cappadocia, on the south Arabia. Syriacum, a kind of sweet
radyshe. Syriacus, ca, cum, of Syria. Syrictae, people which receive their
meat in oten redes. Syricum, a color mixed with sinoper and ruddel Syrium, wine
boiled to the third part. Syrinx, a pype or recorder. Syris, corn kept in
holes in the ground, and covered with chafe. Syrisca, a woman of Syria.
Syrissus, a, um, of Syria. Syrma, it is, the train of a woman's gown. Syrnia, a
shryche oule. Syrophoenix, the sea cost of Syria. Syrtes, quycke sands or
shelpes in the water made by the dryfte of sand or grauel. Syrtites, a little
stoone found in the bladder of a wolf. Syrupus, a syrup. Syrus, a man of
Siria, also an Island belonging to Greece. Syssitia, feasts, and companyes
assembled at feasts. Sysymbrium, an herb callid winter sauery. Syzigiae,
synewes, which do come from the brain to the eyes, so that he, which comes
from the left side, gothe to the right eye, and that which comes from the
right side, goth to the left eye, so that the synewes do cross each other.
T ANTE A.
TABANVS, a fly, which has four wingis, and byteth a man or be.
Tabefacio, ere, to corrupt Tabella, a little table. Tabellarius, a caryer of
letters, an auditour. Tabellio, lionis, a scriuener that writes commune
instruments and deeds. Taberna, every vile habytation, also a shop or tavern,
where wares be sold, and all thing that is vendible, as wine, oil, or any
other thing. Taberna meritoria, an ynne. Tabernaria fabula, a comedia or
Interlude, wherein are base nor sonages, and no persons of dignity or state.
Tabernaculum, a pauyllyon or halle. Tabernarius, he that sellethe any manner of
wares also a tauerner. Taber, his, corruption in the body, also extreme
leanness, by a long consumynge syckenesse. It is also matter and corrupt
blood myxte together. Also the impostume of the lunges, procedynge of humors
descendynge from the heed into the stomach, and so woundynge and corruptyng
the lounges. Tabesco, bui, scere, to languishe or consume, to be extremely
lean, to be corruptid. Tabidus, da, dum, corrupted, consumed. Tabisicabilis,
le, that which may be corrupted, or fall into a consumption. Tabificus, ca,
cum, that which makes one corrupted, or consumes the body. Tablinum, was a
winter parlour, wherein were painted tables and books of stories. Tabo, a
consumption, wasting, or putrefaction of things. Tabor, a mountain in the
country of Galiles, where Chaiste was transfigurate. Tabula, a table. In the
plurell number tabulae, does signify a testament, or any commune instrument
or writynge. Also tabula is a table to play on with dise or chesse me^. Tabulae
nouae, were when detters were not constrained to pay their dettes, that they
did owe, and the old oblygations were dissolved, and new were to be made for
that which should newely be borrowed. Tabularia, ar places, where evidences and
writings be laid. Tabularium, a cheste, in the which evidences and records
are put. Tabulata, walls made of square stones, as if they were bourded. They
be also the boughs of trees and bushes, which do grow straight forth and not
upward. Tabulatus, ta, tum, made of bourdes. Also tabulata, are walls sylded
with bourdes. or made of stone plain like to bourdes. They be also the boughs
of trees, which do lean plain outward, and do not grow upward: Tabulo,
are, to make a thing with bourdes, or to join bourdes together. Tabulatio, a
ioynynge or closing of bourdes together. Taburnus, an hill in Campania, wherein
do grow many olyue trees. Tace, egomet conueniam iam ipsum, Let aloone, I my
self will commune now with him. Tacan^a, those things which are not to be
spoken. Taceo, ta, tui, tacere, to keep silence, to be in rest, to be quycke,
to be sure. Tacito pede, softely, by stel^he. Tacitum ^st, not a word is
spoken of it. Terent. in Adelph.
Taciturnitas, tatis, silence. Tacitus, he that holdethe his peace, and is
secret. Tacitus, citius audies, be still, thou shall here the sooner. Tacit,
without speaking one word. Tactus, fulmine, somewhat burned or blasted with
lyghtnynge. Tactus, tus, feelynge. Taedet, it weryeth me, it yrketh me, I am
werye of it. Taedium, werynes, or heaviness of mind. Taedulus, an old dotarde,
of whom al men are wearye. Taenarus, a dark place at the foot of the hill
called Malea, by the city of Sparta, which was supposed to be an entry into
hell. Taenia, the edge of a fyllette. also a womans fyllette, or that which
now they call rolls: proprely it is a kerchiefe, which maidens do wear on
their heedes. Also a white stoone, which in the water shows long like a
kerchiefe. It is alsoo a vyllage between Mirenas and Corinthum. Taenon, a cite
in Laconia, an other i^ Arcadia Tagasta, a city in Affrike. Tagax, acis, a
felon, which happens on a man's finger. Tages, was he, which taught
first the Thuscanes the craft of diuynation, called Aruspicium. Tago^gere,
old writers used for tango. Tagrus, an hylle in Portyngale, where, as it is
written, that mares do conceive of the wind. Tagus, a river in Spain, wherein
has been found gravel of gold. Taigete, is the name of oone of the seven
sterres, which so appiereth, as it may scantly be perceived, which sterre is
also called Maia, and Electra. Talaria, were shows, which Mercurius did
wear, whereon were set whynges. Talaris, re, that which comes down to the
ancley, as Toga talaris, a long gown to the ancley. Talarius, ria, rium,
pertaining to dyse, as Lex talatia, a law against dyse playenge. Talassio,
was a song contained in certain verses, sungen at weddynges. It was also a
certain exclamation or cry used at marriages, the beginning whereof began,
when Romulus and the Romans reuysshed the maidens of the Sabines, among whom
was one of excellent beauty, whom when many of the Sabines would have reskued,
they which carried her toward Romulus, to the intent that she should not be taken
from them, cried Talassio, which was the name of a noble prince of the
Sabinee, as if they would have brought her to him, and by that mean they
escaped, and brought her to Romulus. And afterward they used at marriages to
cry Talassio. Talea, a stock set in the earth, whereon men do graffe. Also
a truncheon, a staff, a byllette. Talentum, was a poyse, which after the
countreye, wherein it was, it was diverse. One was called talentum Atticum,
which contained.lx. pounds of Athenes, called Minas, or Mnas, and, lxxii.
pou^des of Rome called libras: and this was also called talentum minus, the
other was called Talentum maius, and Euboicum, which contained.lxxx. pounds of
Athenes, callid Minas, and.lxxxiii. pounds and four ounces of Rome weight.
Look before in Libra, et Pondo. Talentu^ Atticum, uel minus, was in value after
the rate of old poyse grotes. Clxvi.li.xiii. s. iiii. d. after.lx. to the
pound, after the new grotes, ten to the once.CCviii.li.vi. s. viii. d.
Talentum maius, of old grotes. Clxxxx.li.xiii. s. iiii. d. of new grotes.
CCxvii.li.x. s. Talgae, an I Will in the sea called Hircanum, where grows
plenty of corn and fruits without culture. Talia, the blade of an any on or
chyboll. Talio, onis, an equal pain in recompense of a hurt, as for the
cuttynge of a man's hand, to lose a hand, or for puttinge out of an eye, to
lose an eye. Talior, ari, to be cut: it is proprely spoken of wodde, which
we now call tallynge of wodde. Talipedo, dare, to go on the pasternes. Talis,
tale, such. Taliter, in such wise. Talitrum, a fyllyppe given with ones
finger or nail. Talpa, a molle or want. Talpa caecior, blynder than a molle, a
proverb applied to them, which lack judgment in things that are plain.
Talum reponere, to refourme that, which was negligently done, with more
diligence. Talus, the ankle above the foot. It is also the pasterne bone of a
beast, Also a dye, or dyce. Tam, as well, also, as, so. Tam bonus, as good.
Ta^ sum amicus republicae, quam qui maxi me, I am so frendely, or as much
friend to the publyke weal, as he that is most. Tama, when with much
trauelle the blood comes down to the leg, and causes it to swelle. Tam
magis, for tanto magis. Tamarindi, a fruit growing in India, Vergil.
the tree whereof is like to a palm or date tree, the fruit sower, like grene
damsins, which is medicinable in asswagyng the heat of cholere. Tamaritae,
people in Asia, not far from the sea called Caspium. Tamarix, ricis, an
herb, which bearethe flowers twyse in one year. Tamen, not withstandyng. also
yet. Tamen a malicia non discedis, Yet will thou not depart from thy malice.
Sommetyme it signifies forthewith, at the last, so that. Quod potero,
faciam, tame^ ut pietatem eolam, I will do that I may: so that not
withstanding I omytte not my duty to my father. Tametsi, all be it, always.
Taminia, a wild grape, growing in woddes. Tam ne, old writers used for
eousque, until that. Tanager, a river in Lucania, between Campania and
Calabria. Tanagra, a town in Perside. Tanais, a great river in the north
part of the world, which dyuydeth Europa from Asia. Tanaquil, was wife to
Tarquinius Priscus, the king of Romans. Tanaus, was king of Siria. Tandem,
at the last, sometime at the least way, also uneath, not withstanding.
Tandiu, so long. Tango, retigi, tangere, to touthe, to meue, to understand,
or perceive, to come to. Tangere ulcirs, to rub on the gaide place, Turp^ilius
to speak to one of a thing, which greueth him to here it. Tangere, to
deceive. Tetigit aures meas, It came to mine ears. Plautus i^ Ruden.
Tanis, the principal city of Egypt, where Moses did show meruayles.
Tanos, a stone of the kind of Emeralde, grene and black. Tanquam, as it were,
like. Tantalides, the progeme of Tantalus. Tantali horti, a proverb
sygnifienge good things to be at hand, which not withstanding a man may not
use. Tantalus, a king, whom poets do feign to be turmented in hell with
hunger and thyrste. Tanti, for so much. This word does pertayne to byenge and
selling. Tantidem, at that price. Tandidem idem. Tanti aestimo, tantifacio,
tanti pendo, I set so much by, or I so much esteem i^. Tantillus, la, lum,
and tantulus, a, um, the diminutiue of tantus. Tantisper, so long. Tantopere,
so much, so vehemently. Tantum, only. Tantum non, almooste. Terent. in
Heautont.
Tantum sat habes? art thou content? Tantummodo, all only. Tantundem
periculum, so great dangier. Tanuina, a wild vine called also Labrusca. Tanto,
an aduerbe, sygnyfienge so much, as tanto magis, so much more, tanto peior,
so much worse. Tantum abest, it is so far from, or so much unlike.
Plautus in paenulo.
Tantundem, even so much. Tantumnum, also, ye also. Tantus, ta, tum, such,
sometime so much, or so greatte. Taos, a stone of the color of a pecoke.
Tapetia, hangynges of houses, or clothes wherewith pauementes are covered.
Tapetum, tapes, peris, tapisrye, or clothes, wherein are wrought diverse pictures
with thredes of sundry colors. Taphiae, and taphus, an I Will by Grecia, where
dwelled the people called Telebois. Taphius, a city in Egypt, the people
whereof were called Taphnii. Taphos, in greek, is a sepulcher or tumbe.
Tapinosis, a figure, whereby a great thing is basely described. Taposiris, a
city in Egipte. Taprobana, a noble I Will in the Indiane see, which isle is
dyrectly against this part of the world, and there is abundance of all manner
of spyces. And the people there lives above an hundred years. Tapsus, an I Will
by Sycile not far from Syracuse. Tapulla, a law made for feasts. I^st. pom.
Tapyri, people in Parthia, which use to give their wives in marriage to other
me^, after that they have had four or five children by them. Taracina, a
town in Campania. Taraconia, a countraye callydde now Aragon. Taracon, the
chief city thereof. Tarandrus, a beast in body like to a great ox, having a
heed like to a heart, and horns full of branches, the hear rough, of the
color of a bear, I suppose it to be a rain dear. Tarantula, a kind of the
beasts callydde Stelliones, like to a lysarde, of whose bytynge no man dies,
only it stonieth him that is bytten. Taras, the son of Neptunus, who builded
Tarentum. Taraxis, when the eyes do bolne out much, and be read. Tarchesius,
was a myscheuous king of the people called Albani. Tarchon, a duke in
Hethruria, which was also a great diuinour or southsayer. Tardatio, a
tarienge. Tardigradus, that which has a slow pase, or gothe slowely.
Tardatio, a tarienge. Tarde, slow, late. Tardiloquentia, a slow speech.
Tardiloquus, he that draws his speech in length. Tardior, slower.
Tardissimus, most slow, or slowest. Tarditas, and tarditudo, and tardicies,
slownesse. Tardius, more slowely. Tardiuscule, somewhat slowely. Tardiusculus,
somewhat slow. Tardo, dare, to tarry, to be slow. Tardus, slow, rude, sometime
well during* also thycke or gross. Tarentinus, a, um, of the city of Tarent
in Calabria. Tarentum, a noble city in Calabria. Tarentu^, a city within the
realm of Naples. Tarmes, a wourme, which eareth flesh, a magotte. Tarpeius,
an hylle at Rome. Tarquinus superbus, was the last king of Romans, which
was expellyd out of Rome for his pride and cruelty. Tarracina, a town in
Campania callydde also Anxur. Tarsus, the chief city of Cilicia, where saint
Paul was borne. Tarsis, a region in Judea. Tartaria, a great countray in the
northeste part of the world. Tartarus, a place in hell. also a man of
Tartarie. Tartarum, the lies of wine. Tartareus, ea, eum, of hell. Tartarious,
rina, number, old writers used for horrible or terrible. Tartesii, a people in
Iberi^, among whom be cattes of exceeding greatness. Tartessus, a city in
the vttermoste part of Spain, on the sea side by Gades, now called Cales,
where Columella the most ^^^quent and perfyte husband, was borne. Tastaneum, a
white claye or marle. Tas^menes, seu tasmenes, one of the sons of duke
Nestor. Tata, dady, which children call their father. Tatoe, a wanton word,
wherewith one answers to an another. Tateus, a kind of salt which comes out
of Phrigia, and is medicinable for the eyes. Taura, a barrayne cow. Tatianus,
a man's name. Tatius, a ma^s name. Tautarij, people in Scythia. Tauria, a
scourge made of neates lether. Taurica Chersonesus, a contray in the north
part of Europa. Taurici, people of cruel manners that offered strangers in
sacrifyce. Taurilia, were plays made in the honor of infernal goddis.
Taurinus, na, number, of a bulle. Taurius, one of the gods of the sea.
Taurominium, a mountain in Sicile, so called for the plenty of neat, which
fed thereon. Also ther^ was by it a city of the same name. Tauromitutanus, na,
number, of the city of Taurominium. Tauroscythae, people of Scithia, dwelling by
the mountain called Taurus. Taurus, a bulle, sometime a strong ox, It is
also one of the.xii. celestial signs, also a great mountain toward India.
Tautologia, a figure, where one thing is twyse spoken. Pl^^^ in (...)
Tax, a stroke. Taxa, a kind of bays or laurel, wherewith herbars are made.
Taxario, a setting of a tax or subsidy. Taxarores, they which do rebuke
oone an another. Taxim, softely, scantly touched. Taxis, old writers used for
tetigeris, thou shalt touch. Taxilli, a small dyse. Taxo, nis, a gray or
brocke, or badger. Taxo, are, to touch often. alsoo to tax, or cesse a thing
at a certain value. also to reprove one an other. Taxus, a tree like to fyrre,
which bears bearyes, wherein is mortalle poison. It is also called owe,
whereof bows be made. Taygetus, a hylle, under the which is set the cities
of Sparta and Amycle.
T ANTE E.
TEarus, a river of Thracia, at the heed whereof Darius king of Persia, wha^ he
went into Scithia, pighte his pauyllyons, and there abode three days. And
delytynge at the most pleasant water of that river, he set in the same
place a pillar graue^ with letters of greek, declaryng his being there, with
co^mendatio^ of the water. Techna, a craft, also a wyle, or subtyl mean
Techines, were they, which also were called Corybantes, and were feined to be
the sons of Minerua and Sol. Technicus, ca, cum, artificial, inuentiue.
Technides, a crafts man. Technophyon, a setting forth of craft. Tectorius,
a, um, pertaynyng to covering. Tecum, with the. Tector, toris, a periettour.
Tectorium, the playstrynge or pariettynge of a house. Tectoriu^ opus,
perietting or plastring wark Tectum, the roufe of a house. sommetyme all the
house. Tecum oro and quaeso, I pray and byseche the. Plaut. in milite.
Tecum sentio, I am of thyn opinyon. Teda, a tree, out of the which sweateth a
lycour, when it is hette. Taedulus, of whom al men be weary. sometime it
signifies him, which is weary of some thing. F^st. pom.
Tegaeum, a city in Archadia. Tegaeates, men of that city. Teges, gitis, a
course blanket or couerlyd, Varro.
which lies on poor men's beds. It is alsoo a matte. Tegeticula, the
diminutiue of teges. Tegillum, a little covering. Tegmen, and tegimen, and
tegmentum, a covering or cover. Tego, texi, tegere, to cover, to hyde, to
defend or keep. Tegula, a tyle. Tegulum, a covering. Teium, a city in
Paphlagonia, where Anacreon the poet was borne. Tela, the clothe, which is
spoken as well of sylke as of lynnen clothe or woollen. Tellanae, a certain
kind of fygges. Telamones, images, which do bear up pyllers or posts.
Telemachus, the son of Ulysses and Penelope. Teleboae, people in Greece.
Telephium, an herb called Orpyn. Telephus, the son, which was nourished
with an hynde. Telina, a certain garment. Telonarius, and telo, lonis, a
collectour or gatherer of tributes. Telonium, the place where taskes or
tributes are paid. Telos, in greek is an end, honor, a legion, a tribute or

iuged to be more fortunate tha^ the rich king Cresus. Tellus, luris, the earth.
Telum, al thing which may be thrown or cast with the hand, be it stone,
wod, or iro^ it is also the general name of all that, wherewith a man does
fight, called weapon. some time it is taken for a sword. Temerarius, a, um,
more hardy than need, or wisdom requires, folehardy. sometime dredefull, or
to be dradde. Temeritas, atis, and temeritudo, folehardines Temere,
unadvisedly, foolyshely, aduenturously, sometime it sygnifieth almost. also
without cause. Temerius, more folyshe, or unadvisedly, Temero, rare, to
vyolate. Temetum, wine. Temulentus, ta, tum, drunkes of wine. Temulentia,
drunkenness. Temno, tempsi, temnere, to set little by. Temo, monis, the
beam, which contains the yoke. Tempe, a place in Thessalia wonderful
plesaunt, having trees and meadows meruaylous delectable, wherein birds of
diverse kinds, do sing contynually with excellent melody. Thereof al pleasant
woddes have the name of Tempe. Temperamentum, a moderacion. Temperanter,
temperately. Temperantia, temperance, which is a firm and moderate governance
of reason against sensuality and other vycyouse affections of the mind.
Temperantior, te^perantius, more temperate. Temperatura, a temperance or
moderation, in the mynglynge of things together. Temperies, temperatenes,
proprely in heat or cold* sometime it is usurped for temperamentum, and for
temperantia. Temperior, oris, more tymely. Tempero, are, to temper or moderate
in order or measure. Temperamus stylum, calamum, appetitum, when we keep in
cure writing a mean form, or do eat no more than is needful. Tempsa, a
city in the country called now Calabria. Tempestas, tatis, sygnifyeth
sometime the same time, sometime tempest, sommetyme wether, sometime a fair
wether. Tempestiuus, ua, um, that which is done in conuenyent time.
Tempestiuitas, tatis, season or time convenient, opportunity. Tempestiue, in
season or time convenient. Tempestu^, old writers used for tempestiuu^.
Tempestuosum, tempestuous or stormy. Templum, a temple or church. sometime it
sygnifyeth heaven. Alsoo the principal beam of a house, also a sepulcher.

that which is done suddenly, and at a time. Temporary, temporanie, and
temporaliter, until a time. Temporarius, ria, rium, that which dureth or
contynueth for a time. also that which pertayneth to time. Temporius, an
aduerbe sygnifieth in time, or by time. Tempus, poris, time, also the state of
time. sometime the temples of the heed. Tenatia, and tenacitas, hardenes in

of most sure remembrance. Tenaciter, fastly, surely. Tenasmus and tenesmus,

Tenere consensum, to agree or consent unto other. Tenet me amor, love meueth

Teneri desyderio, to desire much or ferue^tly Teneri ludo, to take pleasure in

Tepifacio, cere, to make warm. Tepefio, fieri, to be warm. Tepeo, and
tepesco, tepui, poscere, to be warm or hot. Tepidarium, a vesselle, wherein
water is made temperate, also a chaumber, whereinto men do go out of a bayne.
Tepidus, tepida, tepidum, mean between hot and cold, warm. Also kolyd
from heat Sometime noyfull or unprofitable. Tephrites, a stoone, which has
the figure of a new moon, in color black, (...) asshe color. Tepidior,
colder. Tepidissimus, a, um, most warm. Tepidulus, tepidula, tepidulum, a
dymynutyue of tepidus. Tepocon, a form of writing downwarde. Tepor, oris, and
tepiditas, tatis, warmthe, or warmenesse. Ter, thryse. Terapne, a contray in
Lacedemonia, where the fair Helene was borne. also an Island now called
Corsica. Terebinthus, a tree, the wodde whereof is black and hard like box,
out of this tree rounneth a gum, called commonly Turpentyne. All be it the
common turpentyne is not it, but an another, which is as clear as glass, and
is a soueraygne medycyne to cleanse the stomach of putryfyed humors. Ternarius,
and ternus, terna, number, the third in number. Tertius, tia, um, the third.
Tertio, and tertium, the third time. Terdenus, na, number, the thyrdtenth.
Terebellum, a wymble or percer. Terebratio, a borynge with a wymble. Terebrae,
sieve terebrum, an awgour, wherewith holes are boored. Terebro, brare, to bore
or make an hole. Teredo, dinis, a little worm that eteth wod. Terentius, the
most eloquente writer of comedyes. Terentianus, of Terence. Terentum, a place
in the fyelde by Rome, called Campus Martius, wherein was an altar of Pluto
and Proserpyne. Teres, teretis, long and round, like a tree or a pyller.
Teretrum, an instrument, wherewith a thing is made round. Terga dare, to run
away, proprely in barasle. Tergemini, three chylderne borne at oone bourdeyne.
Tergestes, a city in Italye. Terginus, na, number, that which is made of a
beasts hyde. Tergiuersatio, a nonsuite in the law, when the pleintife gives
over his suite. Tergiuersor, aris, ari, to turn back, to deny, in the law it
sygnifieth to be nonsuite. Tergo, and tergeo, tersi, tergere, to wype or make
clean. Tergum, the back of man or beast, or of any other thing. sommetyme
it sygnifyeth a hyde. Tergus, tergoris, a hyde of a beast. Terma, matis, the
extremity, the end of a thing, also the sole of the foot. Termentarium, a
lynnen clothe, wherewith the body is covered. Plaut. (...) Pom.
Termentum, for detrimentum. Terms, a branch plucked of a tree with the
fruit on it. also a worm, which eats the flesh. Termile, a mountain in
Lycia, called also Chimaera. Ter milies, three thousand times. Termillum, a
pot for wine, which was always set on the table, that every manne might
take as much wine as he would. Terminalia, was a certain holy day, at the
latter end of the year. Terminalis lapis, a mere stone, laid or pight at the
end of sundry men's lands. Termino, nare, to end or fynyshe. Terminus, a
sign which declares oone man's land from an other, or one country or
territory from an other. also it signifies the buttynge. Terminus deus, was
an ydoll, which was supposed to have preemynence over the bounds of land,
whose temple had ever an hole in the roufe, for as much as they thought it to
be vnlefulle that bounds of land should be covered or hid. Termo, onis, old
writers used for terminus. Ternarius numerus, the number of three. Ternus, na,
number, the third. Ternundenum, the thyrtenthe. ^ide com.
Tero, triui, rere, to rub, to break or broise. Terere iter, to go his way.
Terere tempus, to consume time. Terere otiu^, to live idelly. Terpander, dri,
an old musytian, which added.vii. strings to the harp. Terpfi^hore, one of
the nine musis. Terra, earth: sometime all the world, also a prouynce, a
territory, a country, land. Terraceus, a, um, of earth. Terraneola, a bird
like to a lark, which we call a hunting. Terrefacio, facere, to make
aferde. Terrae fillus, he that is come up of naught, and no man knows his
kynrede. Terraemorus, erthequake. Terrenum, a field. Terrenus, na, number, of
earth, or living on earth, erthely. Terreo, rui, rere, to make aferde. Vide
com.
Terrestris, tree, erthely. Terreus, rea, reum, of earth. Vas terreum, an erthen
vesselle. Terribilis, bile, terryble, that which is to be feared. Terricola,
he that dwells in the land. Terricrepus, he that rebukes one terribly.
Terriculamentu^, a fear, or a fearful thing. Terrificus, ca, cum, terryble,
or that which induces fear. Terrigena, begotten on the earth. Varro de ling.
latin.
Terriones, ploughmenne. Terripauium, and terripudium, for tripudium,
daunsynge. Territo, tare, to make aferde. Territorium, the fyeldes or countraye
lyenge within the jurisdiction and bounds of a city, a territory. Terror,
roris, fear. Tersus, sa, sum, clean, pure. Tersus dies, of old writers was
taken for a fair day. Tertiata uerba, words not perfytely pronounced: as
when one is in fear or dread of him, to whom he speaks, he trembling in
speech, vnethe pronounces the third word that he would say. Tertiarum, is a
mixed metal, wherein are two parts of lead, and one of tynne. Tertio, are, to
do a thing the third time, or to make the third tylth in earynge. Tertio
Consul, where two have been Consules before him. Tertium Consul, he that has been thryse Consul. So that Tertio signifies the third in order, and place, two
going before. Tertiu^ sygnifieth the time, where twyse gothe before. The like is
of Secundo, quarto, and other numbres. Tertio pedato, Cato.
at the third return or coming again. Tertius, a, u^, the third. Tertius
decimus, the thyrtenthe. Tertullianus, a famous and eloquent author. which for
dyspleasure and malice fell into heresye. Teruncium, a poyse or coin of three
ounces. Tesca, Varro.
a place where misticalle ceremonies were exercysed. Tesqua, places hard or
difficile to come up to, where the Romans did practice their diuinatio^s by
fleing of dirdis, callid auguria Tessellatus, ta, tum, that which is wrought
with small pieces of stone, wodde, or bone, as in playenge tables or
counterbourdes. Tessella, a greffe. Tessera, that which is in every part
square as a dye. also it is a dye. more over a watch word or privy toke^
given to soldiers. Also a token of war and peace, a token given to people
to receive corn of the kings alms. Also a tail, whereon is scored or marked
the number of things received, which is also called Tesserula. Tesseradecas,
fouretene. Tesserarius, he that gives the watcheword Tesserulae, little
pauynge tyles. Tesso, tessi, tessere, to dispoyle or pulle of a garment or
harncis by vyolence. Testa, a sharde of a pot or tyle. also an erthen pot.
also all manner of shellfyshe. Testaceus, a, um, that which has a shelle.
Testeus, idem. Testaceam flagellum, a proverb applied to sodayn alteration of
things, or of banishment unlooked for. Testamentatius, a forger of
testamentes. Testamentarius, ria, ium, pertaining to testamentes. Testamentum,
a testament. Testaum, in pieces or shardes. Testatio, and testimonium,
witness. Testator, toris, he that makes a testament. Testatus, he that is
deed, and has made a will also openly known of all men. Testiculor, cularis,
lari, to put the male to the female. Testillor, idem. Testiculus, of a known
sygnification. Testificatio, a witness bearing. Testificator, and
testificatrix, he or she that bears witness. Testificor, caris, cari, to
bear witness. Testimonium, and testatio, witness borne of a ioynge done.
Testis, he that bears wytnes. Testes, be also a man's genitours. Testor,
aris, ari, to bear wytnes, to call to wytnes, Co^testor. Protestor Varro.
to pray god. Testu, old writers used for testa. Testuaceum, that which is
boiled in an erthen pot. Testudinatum tectum, a roufe, which is holowe in
four parts. Testudo, dinis, a snayle. Also an engyne of war to beat down
walls, which was made of bourdes, and couerid with lether or other things,
which would not bourne. within it was a piece of timber, that had a great hoke
of iron at the end, which piece might be plucked back, and put forth
with the strength of men, and therewith pluck stoones out of the walls of
towns besyeged, It is alsoo the roufe or vaulte of a house. Testus, tus, is a
pan, wherein tartes, and other like things of paste are baken. Tetanicus
morbus, idem quod Tetanos. Tetanothra, a medycine, wherewith the face of a man
or woman is made smothe without wrynkles. Tetanos, when the sins are slyffe,
so that a man can not bow some part of his body Tetarmorton, the fourth part
of the zodiake cirkle, wherein are the.xii. signs. It is also that, which
astronomers do call the quadrate aspecte of planettes. Te te, thy self.
Teter, tetra, tetrum, foul, stynkyng, cruel. Teterrimus, a, um, most foul
or stynkyng, or cruelle. Teterrime, most abhomynably. Fest. Po^.
Tethys, the wife of Neptunus, callid goddess of the sea. Tetinierit, for
tenuerit. Tetinus, for tenus. Fest. Pom.
Tettigoniae, little grassehoppes. Tettigometrae, the mother of grasshoppes.
Tetracinus, a coin, which was in value four dragmas, or old poyse grootes,
of viii. to an ounce. Tetracolon, a sentence having.iiii. me^bres. Tetradoron,
of four handdbreth. Tetragonus, a, um, a thing having four corners.
Tetragrammaton, the name of god, which the Jews do call Ineffabile, that is to
say, unspeakable. Tetragrammaton, in greek, sygnifyeth of four letters.
Tetrametrum, a kind of meter, having but four fete. Tetrarcha, the rule of
the fourth part of a royalme. Tetrasyllabum, of four syllables, as, Im pe ra
tor. Tetre, sharply, cruelly, wyckedly. Tetrices, water, wherewith gardeynes
are wateryd. Tetricus, a sour fellow, and always unpleasant. Tetrinno, are, to
swymme like a ducke. Tetritudo, cruelty or sharpenes. Tetrius, more sharp or
cruel. Tetro, trare, to make foul, to pollute, to make bitter. Tetulit, for
tulit. Teucer, and Teuerus, the name of a king of Troianes. also of the son
of Telamone the valyant Greek. Teucer, Teucra, crum, idem quod Troianus. of
Troy. Teumesus, a little hylle in Boeotia. Teumesus leo, a Lion, which
Hercules did slay, when he was a child, and of his skin made him a cote.
Teurion, the herb which is also callydde Tripolium. Teuta, a queen of
Illiria, which lived ever chaste, and vanquyshed many noble capitaynes, and
diverse hosts of the Romans Teurates, was in old time amc^g the french men
taken for Mercurius. Teuthania, a piece of the country of Troy. Teutones,
people now called Almayns. Vide com.
Texo, texui, texere, to weaue or wind threde, Also to make to build, to
write, to gather, to ornate. Texta, an hearelace, wherewith the hear is bounden
up. Textilis, le, that which is weaued or wounde^ Textim, an aduerbe,
sygnifieng in weauing or wyndynge up. Textor, toris, and textrix, tricis, he or
she that weaueth or wyndeth. Textrina, and textrinum, the place where things
be weaued or wounden. also the craft of weauynge. Textrix, and textricula, a
woman, which warketh in a frame or stole. Textura, the weauynge. Textus, and
textum, the text.
T ANTE H.
THalamus, a chamber where the husband and the wise do lie together.
Thalassicus, chamblette. Thalassio, uide Talassio. Thassus bonorum, a proverb
applied to them that promise great things, as a man would say, a world, a
countray of welthe. Thalasso meli, is a lycour made of honye, salt water, and
rain water, and is put into a vessel rased with pytche. Thales, a
philosopher, which was one of the seven wise men of Grecia. Thalestris, was a
queen of Amasones, which came to king Alexander with three hunderde womenne
with her, to the intent to have issue by him and his men: and when she
perceived, that she and her ladies were spedde, they departed home again.
Thali, are in lyekes, garlyke, and oynyons, when they do grow, the myddell
s^alke between the blade and the heed or rote. Thalia, one of the graces,
which the auncent poets did suppose to be one of the daughters of Jupiter,
and gyuers of dilectable speech, and pleasant pronunctatio^. Thamaras, was he,
which first played on a harp, without singing thereto. Thamnos, in latin
arbustum. Thanatos, mors in latyne. Thapsus, an isle by Sicile. Thapsia, an
herb like to senell, and has a yelowe flower, and a flat round sede.
Tharia, pyckelle, wherein fysshe is salted, and kept. Tharsos, a city in
Cilicia. Thasia, an almonde. Thasia nux, called also graeca. Thasij, men of
the I Will called Thasus in Egypt. Thasium, a certain wine, which is in Egypt.
Thauma, in greek is a marvel or miracle. Theatralis, le, and theatricus, ca,
cum, that which pertayneth to theatrum. Theatridium, a diminutiue of theatrum.
Theatrum, a place made half round, wherein the people assembled to behold
plays and sondrye sbate mentes, sometime it sygnifieth the multitude that
beholds. Theboe, arum, Theba, be, and Thebe, bes, the name of cities, whereof
one was in Egipte, buildid by Busirides, an other in Boeotia, builded by
Cadmus: an another in Cilicia, where Andromaches, the wife of Hector was borne.
Thebaicae, and thebaides, dates of the best forte. Thebais, idis, and idos, a
countraye of Egypt, it is also the name of a book made by Statius the poet.
Thebanus, na, number, a man of Thebes. Theca, a case, a shethe or scaberde, a
box. Theleboae, people of an isle callid Capreae, which lies against Naples.
Theleboij, people of the I Will Capreas. Thelephus, a king, which camme in the
aid of the Troyanes, and was slain by Achylles. Theligonium, an herb, which
has beries like to an olyue. Thelphusa, a city in Arcadia. Thelphussiu^, uel
thelphossion, a cite in Boeotia, where Pyndarus praised Bacchus, Thelypteris,
sheferne, or the female fern. Thema, matis, a thing purposed to be disputed
or resoned. it is also a figure, wherein astronomers do write the state of
heaven, in placinge or setting the planettes in such signs and degrees, as
they be in at the time of a man's nativity, or when any thing shall happen
that they search for. Thembinacha, a country called also Nemia. Themes, an old
town in the i will of Lipres where brass was first found. Themis, one of the
systers of Iupyter, she was callid the goddess, which commanded men to ask
that which was leful. There was an other woman called Themis, which was
called also Carmentis, it was sometime taken for fas, lefull. Themiscyra, a cite
in Capadocia, afterward called Caesaria. Themisones, people by Licia.
Themistius, a philosopher which wrate commentaries on Aristotels warkes.
Themistocles, a noble capitain of the Athemensis, which being expelled out of
his country, and commen to Xerxes king of Persia, was sent by him with a great
army against the Athenienses, but when he perceived his country in peril to
be distroyed, he drank poison, and chase rather to dye, than either to be
vnfeythfull to Xerxes, or else to distroy his country, although it were unkind
toward him. Thensa, a hallowed carte or chariot. Theocritus, a poet of Grecia,
which wrate Bucolica, or the contention of herd men. Theologia, diuynitie.
Theomenia, the wrath of god. Theonino dente rodere, to rebuke a man
shamefullye. Theophrastus, a noble philosopher, and of excellent eloquence.
Theos, in greek is god. Theotochos, the mother of god. Theorema, speculation.
Theoria, speculation, understanding. Theopolis, the chief city of Syria,
called also Antiochia. Thera, a city by Athenes. Theramnum, a city in
Thessalia. Theriace, ces, seu theriaca, tryacle. Thereotrophion, a place where
wild beasts are kept, as a forest, or park. Therioma, a soore of the priuye
members, whereby all the parts therabout, are corrupted, and thereof issues
black and stinkynge humor. Theristrum, a thynne veil, which the women of
Palestina did wear. Thermae, are bathes of hot water. Thermefacio, cere, to
chaufe or make oone hot with outrageous eating and drinking of hot
things. Thermopolium, a place where meats and drynkes were sold, wherewith
men were made hot or warm in cold wether. Thermodoon, a river in Cappadocia.
Thermodontiacus, ca, cum, pertaining to that river. Thermopoto, tare, to
drink hot or warm drink. Thermopylae, a mountain in Greece, having a
narowe entry or passage, where two thousand Lacedemoniens, with their
capytayne Leonidas, faught against five hundred and.xxviii. thousand Persyans*
and resysted them two days, until the said Lacedemoniens were all slain.
Thersites, was a prince that came with the greeks to the syege of Troy, which
in person and condicyons was of all other most defourmed. Thesaurizo, are, to
gather treasure. Thesaurus, and thesaurum, treasure. Theseus, a noble and
valyant king of Athenes, companyon to Hercules. Thesis, a clause in writing or
spekyng, which contains a sentence. Thesmophoria, the ceremonies of Ceres,
the goddess of grain. Thesmophoros, was a name of Ceres. Thespia, a free
town in Boeotia. Thessalia, a region in Greece. Thessalicus, ca, cum, of
Thessalia. Thessalonica, a city in Macedonia. Thetis, tidis, the mother of
Achilles. Theucitis, a rushe growing in Nabachis, which has the taste of
sharp wine. Theositas, for sodalitas. Fest. Pom.
Theutones, and theutonici, people in Germanye, called Duchemen. Thirromachus,
one of the sons of Hercules by Megara. Thiasias, he that is burste or broken
in his stoones. Thideus, was the name of the father of Diomedes. Thieum, for
succinum, aumbre. Thita praefigere, for condemnare. Thymelici, mynstrelles
retained with noble men. Thoa, one of the nymphs. Thoas, the name of two
kings, oone of Taurica, the other of Lemnos. Thoes, be wolfes in Ethiope,
Arrianus does call them tygres in India. Tholos, a scochen or small tergate.
also the the syldynge of a house, or a round house. Thomices, lyches of hemp,
wherewith halters are made, they be also lyttel bolsters, which men do wear
when they carye burdeynes, for frettynge of their necks and shulders with
cords or ropes. Thon, nis, he that first brought phisyke in the form of a
science, among the Egyptians. Thoota, the daughter of Phorcus, on whom
Neptunus gate Polyphemus. Thoracatus, he that wearethe curettys or breast
plates. Thorax, racis, is proprelye the hole boulke of a man from the neck to
the myddelle, it is also curettes or breast plates. sometime it signifies a
tower. Thous, a duke of Troy. Thracia, a region of Europa, wherein is the city
of Constantinople. Thraceas, uel Thrassias, a northwest wynd. Thrasimedes, the
son of Nestor. Thrasomenus, a river in Italye nyghe to Perusia. Thrax, acis,
a man of Thracia. Threces, idem quod gladiatores. Threnodia, a mournyng song.
Threnos, a lamentacyon, which was vsyd a^ buryenge. Thressa, a woman of
Thracia. Throni, be one of the.ix. orders of angels. Thronus, the seat or
chair of an Emperor or king. Thrulla, a trewell, which masons, tylers, and
pargettours do use for layenge of mortar. Thrullisso, are, to lay on mortar.
Thryallis, an herb called in Italye Strella and Bipinella. Thryps, a mowthe.
Thule, an I Will beyond Scotland. Thunnus, a fyshe, called Tuny. Thuribulum, a
sensar. Thuringia, Thuryn in France. Thurini, a people in Italye. Thuriferus,
ra, rum, that which bearethe Frankynsence. Thurifico, to make a perfume, or to
sense. Thurius, ria, rium, of incense. Thus, thuris, frankyncense. Thuscana, a
city in Italye. Tusculani, a people by Rome. Thusculum, a diminutiue of thus.
Also a cite in Latium. Thyas, a sacrifyce made to Bacchus. Thyasus, a dance
dedycate to Bacchus. Thiella, a storm. Thyestes, whom his own brother Atreus
caused to eat his propre chylderne. Thymbra, an herb called sanerye. Thymele,
es, a woman, which first taught daunsynge in open places. Thymelici, may be
callydde daunsers of Morysdaunces. Thymiama, matis, a sweet perfume. Thymus, an
herb called time. Thymu^, a wart, which is as great as a bean. Thynnus, a
fyshe called Tuny. Thyridion, a wycket or little door. Thyrsus, the stalk of
letyse and of other herbs, which may be eaten. sum do take it for a spear
with a sharp head, which had boughs and leaves of yuy wrapped about
them: such spears did Bacchus and his flock of drunken harlottes, bear in
their hands. Lucretius the poet takes thyrsum, for furye or an ardent
mocyon. Thysus, the stalk of every herb, specially of letyse* It is also a
staff wound about with yuy, which was borne of them that did sacrifyce to
Bacchus.
T ANTE I.
TIara, an ornament, which the women of Persia did wear on their heedes,
which was round, and covered only the hinder part of their heedes. Princis
and pristis used also to wear it. Tiatura, a city in the countray of Mis^a.
Tibareni, people in Scithia, being in Asia. Tibia, the leg, proprely the shanke
or shinne bone, it is also an instrument callid a shalme. Tibialis, le,
pertaynyng to shaulmes. Tibiale, lis, pluraliter tibialia, geiues or leg
harneys. Tibicen, and tibicina, he or she that blowethe a trumpette or shalme.
Tibicen, is alsoo any thing, whereby any thing in building is sustained, as
a shore or proppe. Tibi, to the. Tibicis, a river in Scythia. Tibin, a baskette
or coffyn made of wickers or bulle rushes, or bark of a tree: Origenes super
Ex.
such one was Moses put into by the daughter of Pharao. Tibilustria, Fest.
Pom.
were days when men went with trumpettes, as it were in processyon about
their lambs. Tibini, tunes made with shalmes. Fest. Pom.
Tiburtes, people in Italy nigh to Rome. Ticinum, a city in Lumbardye now
called Pauia. Tigillus, a rafter. Tignarius, faber, a Carpentar that makes a
house of timber. Tignus, and tignum, a rafter of a house, which bears the
roufe. It is also generally all the timber, which serves to a house. Tigrane, a
river in the countray of Media. Tigranes, the propre name of a king of Media,
of the greatter Armeny. Tigris, a beast of a wonderful swyftenes, it is also
one of the four ryuers, which comes out of Paradyse. Tigurini, people of
Germanye, which do inhabyte the fourth part of Heluetia, or Swyzerlande.
Tile, an I Will beyond Scotland, callydde also Thule. Tilia, a tree, which some
do think is called quyckebeame. Tilium, a city in the weste part of
Sardinia, on the sea side. Tilos, an isle in the Indian see, wherein is plenty
of perle, and trees of diverse fruits, and the leaves of trees there growing
do never fall. also wolle grows on trees there, which do bear goardes of
the greatness of quynces, and being type do open, in the which do appiere the
wolle, whereof are made fine and precious clothes. About that place does
begin the mountain of Caucasus, which does pass through a great part of
the world. Timalos, an herb and flower growyng in waters, called commonly of
potycaries Nenufer. Timaeus, a noble philosopher of Pythagoras sect. Timanus,
a river in Italy besides Aquileia. Timens* he that fears for a time. Timidus,
he that always fears, called tymorouse. Timeo, mui, mere, to fear or dread.
Timeo te, I fear the as mine ennemy, lest thou shallt do me harm. Timeo tibi,
I am af^rd of the as my friend, lest thou should have any harm. Timeo mihi
abs te* I am afraid that thou will do me harm. ^
Timeo finem pomis, I am afraid that one will seal mine appulles. Timeo
mo^i^tur, I am aferd that he will die Timide, fearfully. Timidi^as, fear.
Timiopilae, ingi ossers or regraters of markettes, which do bye much corn or
vitayle together, to make it scarce and dear. Timor, moris, and timos, fear of
some evil coming. Timotheus, was the name of a noble capytayn of the
Atheme^fes, who for the good fortune that he had in battle, was painted
lyenge aslepe, and having by him a net pytched, wherein fortune was taken.
Also a cunning musician, which vsyd to take of his scholars, which had learned
before* double salarie, that he took of other, which never learned, saying,
that he took with them double labors, that is to say, to make them to
forgette that which they had lernyd before, and thanne to teach them
perfytely. Tin, old writers used for Eum. Tina, and Tinia, a greatte bolle,
which being full of wine, every man might drink thereof as much as he lysted.
Tinctor, ctoris, a dyer. Tinctilis, le, that which is dyed. Tinctura, dyenge.
Tinea, a mothe, they be also worms in the bealye, also worms breding in be
stalles. Tineosus, a, um, full of mothes* Tinge, a promontorie or elbowe of
Africa. Tingitana, a part of Mauritania or Barbaria against Spain. Tingo,
xi, gere, to deep a thing into lycour, to dye colors. Tinnio, nire, to ring
or make a sound as metal does, sometime as in a ma^s ear. Tinnimentu^, a
ryngyng in the ear of a man. Plaut. in ruden.
Tinnunculus, a byrd, which makes a sharp ryngynge noise, and is of the kind
of hawks, and in some place does bread in houses, which with his voice
dryueth away other hawks, and therefore the birds of him are kept in erthen
pottes covered with claye, and hanged up in doue-houses, which causes culuers
meruaylousely to love their house. Tinnulus, la, lum, sharp in sound, as that
which is made by beatinge on metal. Tintinaculus, he that beats with rods,
a transgressour of a law. Tintinabulum, a little bell. Tintino, nare, to ringe
like a bell. Tiphernum, a town in Italy. Tiphis, an excellent carpentar, the
which found first the mean to govern a ship, a rother. Tipula, a wurme,
which runs on the water as other wurmes do on the land, and has six
fete. Tiresias, was king of Thebes, who had the knowledge of things which
should happen, and was blind. Tirius, a river in Grecia: also the contray
where Hercules was borne in Peloponesso, now called Morea. Tirinthius, was a
surname of Hercules. Tirinthis, a famous old city in Grecia. It Is, for tui,
the genitive case of Tu. Tisiphone, one of the furies of hell, which was
supposed to tourment homycydes, or s^eers of men. Titan, and Titanus, was the
brother of Saturn, and is taken for the son, and Titanis, for the moon.
Tithimallus, an herb called werte worte, whereof the milk woll take away
wartes. Tithymalus, an herb which is commonly called Spurge. Titillo, are, to
tyckle, to provoke or meeue pleasantly. Titio, onis, a fyrebrande or wodde,
which has been in the fire. Titiuillitium, sygnifyeth nothing. Titubantia,
stammmerynge. Titubo, are, to stacker in speking or going, as a man being
drunk or sick. Titulotenus, no further than his title. Titulus, the title or
inscription of a warke or act. sometime dignity, also a monument or other
remembrance. Titus, the name of a man. Titus Liuius, the most excellent
hystorien or writer of stories, in whom was the fou^tayne of the milk of pure
eloquence. Tiepolemus, was the king of the Rhodes, which camme to the battle
of Troy, with nine ships. Tityus, the son of Jupiter, whom poets feigned
to be slain by Apollo, because he would have rauysshed Latona his sister. And
therefore lies in hell, having an egle always eating his liver. And it is
alsoo said, that his body was in length nine furlonge. witness Tibulle,
which was a poet, and also a great lover, and therefore could not lie.
T, ANTE M.
TMolus, a mountain in Lidia, whereon did grow great plenty of saffron and
vynes. It is also a little busshe, which bears flowers of saffron color.
T ANTE O.
TOdi, little birds, I suppose it be the bird, which is called a tytmous.
Toga, the common garmente of men and women, called a gown. And because the
Romans specially did wear that garment in the time of peace, toga was
taken for peace, as arma was for war. Toga praetexta, a garment which the
Romans did wear before that they were of the age of.xvi. years. Afterward it
was worn of them, which were in authority. Toga polymita, a garment made
with thredes of sondrye colors, as motleye or bauldekyn. Togata Comoedia, a
comedye or interlude, wherein the manners of the Romans, were expressed.
Togata Gallia, the country now callydde Lumbardy. Toga candida, was a
garment, which they did wear, that sued for any great office in the city of
Rome. Togari, apparayled in gowns. Togatus, he that wears a gown.
Tolerantia, sufferance. Toleranter, patiently. Tolles, a waxynge kernel. ^*
Liuius.
Tolleno, nonis, that wherein any thing is put or laid to be drawn up.
Vegetius. Budeus.
sometime a buckette wherewith water is drawn up. Tollenon, an engyne to draw
up water, which has a great poise at the one end Tolero, rare, to suffer,
to endure, to bear, to live poorly, or nyghly. Tolerare uitam, to live, or to
maynteyne his life. Tolerabilis, rabile, that which may suffer or bear.
Tollo, sustuli, seu tetuli, tollere, to lift up, or set up. Tollere
clamorem, to cry out. Tollere cristas, to set up the crest, applied to them
that be proud or arrogante, and do stretche up their brows with a dysdaynfull
countenance. Toll digitum, hold up thy finger, confess thy self vanquyshed.
Tollere gradum, to set forth, or to march forth. Tollere, to take away.
Toll hanc patinam, Plautus in milite.
take away this dyshe. Tollere, to have a child by a woman. Tollere, to
nouryshe. Verum quod erit natu^, Plautus in Amphit.
^ollito, What so ever is borne, put it to nouryshynge. Tollere, to defer
or prolonge, Plautus.
Omnes tollo ex hoc die in alium diem, I put them all of from one day to an
other. Tollere minas, to thretten or menace. Tolutarius, and tolutaris equus,
an aumblynge horse. Tolutiloquentia, a swyfte or fast speech. Tolutim, an
amblynge pace. Tolutim loqui, to speak fast oone word after an another.
Tomaculae, Tomacula, and tomacla, a certain sort of pouddynges, proprelye
swynes pouddynges. Tomentum, floxe, which is shorn of woollen cloth. also
locks clypped of white wolle. Tomices, hempen cords, also colers, which are
put on carthorses, for hurtynge of their necks. Tomos, a piece of a book, or a
warke vnperperfyte. Alsoo a city in the countraye of Ponthus. Tomyris, was a
noble queen of Massagetis in Scithia, against whom when Cirus the great king
of Persia came, and had slain her son, she pytchynge a fylde against him,
and of purpose having great plenty of vytayles in her pauyllyone, after a
little skyrmyshe she and her host fled. And when Cirus had a while followed the
chase, and blown to the retraicte, he came to her camp, and finding great
plenty of vytayle, he and his people did so much fill them selfee therewith,
that falling aslepe, they were all taken by the queen, and slain, and she
causynge a great vessel to be filled with the bloudde of Cirus, and the
Persyans, did cast his heed therinto, saying, Blood thou haste thyrsted, and
now drink thereof thy fylle. Tonarion, a certain shaulme with a soft sound,
on the which in the old time some orators used to have, to play by them,
when they pleaded, that by the tunes of the shalme, the orator might moderate
and order his pronunciation. Tondeo, totondi, tondere, to clyp or sheare.
Tonesco, tonui, tonescere, to thunder. Ennius.
Tonimus, for tonamus. Tonitrus, and tonitru, and tonitruum, thunder. Tonitruo,
are, to thunder. Tonitus, thunder. Tono, nare, to thunder, to make a greatte
sound or noise, to speak loud. Tonsae, sheep, which be shorn or clypped.
also ores of botes or ships. Tonsilis, le, that which is shorn or clipped.
Tonsilla, a post, having the one end armed with iron, which is pitched into
the earth, to the end that ships or botes may be tied thereat. Tonsillae
plurali, a dysese within the chekes and mouth like to great kernels. Tonsi
montes, hills without woddes. Tonsor, et tonstrix, tricis, he or she which
clyppeth or sheareth. Tonsorius, ria, rium, pertaining to clyppynge. Tonstrix,
tricis, a woman barbar. Tonstricula, idem. Tonstrina, a place where they do use
to clip or a barbers shop. Tonsus, a, um, shorn or clypped. Tonus, a tune or
accent. alsoo the space or distance, which is between the earth and the moon.
Toparcha, he that has the governance and charge of one only country.
Toparchia, the rule of one countray. Topazion, and topazius, a preciouse stone
of the color of gold. Tophus, a kind of stone, which is soon resolved into
sand. Topiarium, a warke made of trees, bushes, briars, or herbs, for
pleasure, and contained places to sytte or walk in, as it is used now with
box, eglantine, iacymine, and other like trees or thorns, that be flexible,
or will be wounden. Topiarius, he that makes such warkes. Topiaria, the
warke. Topica, warkes in that part of logike, which declares the places, out
of the which arguments may be invented, that most proprely pertayneth to
orators. Topographia, the description of a place, as of a country or city.
Topper, the old writers used for soon, Festus.
shortly, or quyckely. Toral, and toralium, in plurali numero, toralia, every
thing that lies on a bed, as shatis blankettes and couerlyds. In the old time
it were certain flowers and sweet herbs wounden together in ropes, and hanged
before the place, where men did lie. Like as now they use in London at
Mydsommer to hang before their doors. Torcular, aris, and torculare, and
torculu^, a press for wine, syder, or vertiuyce. Torcularius, a, um,
bylongynge to a press. Toreuma, matis, and tereumatum, graven or polyshed
warke. Toreutis, a grauer. Toreutice, ces, the craft of grauynge. Tormen,
minis, frettynge or tourmente in the bealy and guts. Tormina, idem.
Tormentum, tourment, or an engyn to turment men, generally all ordinance
pertaining to war. Torminosus, he that has tourmentes or frettynge in his
guts. Tornacum, a town called Tornay. Tornatilis, le, that which is turned
with a whele. Torniamen, may be now taken for a tournayment or iustes. Torno,
are, to torn or warke with a whele, as tourners done. Tornus, the instrument
or whele. Torpedo, dinis, slouthefulnes. also a fysshe, which in the taking
makes the hands of them that do draw, to be stonyed or deed for the time.
Torpeo, and torpesco, pui, torpere, uel torpescere, to be astonyed, or slow.
Torpor, poris, a debilitation or feblynge of mind, an unaptness to do any
thing. Torporo, rare, to astonye, or make astonished. Torquatus, a ring dove,
or stock dove. it is he also that wears a colar or chain. Torqueo, torfi,
quere, to wind in, Vide^^^
to whirle about like a whiele, to sustain or bear up, to tourment. Torquere
telum, to throw a darte or iauelyn, that he run round. Vergilius
Torquere saxa, to turn great stones. Vergilius
Torquere, to spynne. Torques, a colar, chain, or bye of gold or silver, such
as is worn by knights or esquiers about their necks. Torrefacio, cere, to
broyle or roast at the fire, or by the heat of the son. Torrens, it is, a
stream, that comes down of hills, which is caused by much rain or snow.
Torrens, a particyple, sygnifieth flowynge with a great swepe. Torrentior, more
flowing, with a greatter violence. Torreo, riri, rere, idem quod torrefacio.
Torresco, re, to be broilid or roasted, or dried. Torridae zonae, are two
girdels imagined in the firmament on every side of the equinoctial line, under
which gyrdels the people which inhabyte there, are burned with the fervent
heat of the son, because the son abides lo^gest in those.ii. places and ar
also named Tropicus cancri, and tropicus Capricorni, Torridus, da, dum, dried
or burned. Tortilis, le, that which is bent or bowed. Torris, a stycke of
fire. Tortiuum vinum, wine of the last press. Torto, tare, to tourment
vehemently. ^
Tortor, toris, a tourmentour, or he that casts a stone with a slynge.
Tortu^, an engine, to throw great stones with. Tortuosus, a, u^, wou^de^ or
turned many wais. Tortus, ta, tum, crooked. Torue, toruu^, torua, toruiter,
proprely in beholding sowerly or grymly. Toruinus, an apparel of a woman's
heed. Torus, a bed, it was sometime made with herbs wounden together. Tori,
the brawnes of the arms and leggis, or the flesh myxte with synewes. Torosus,
a, um, mighty or strong in brawnes of the legs and arms. Torsio, sionis,
Theodorus, Gaza, and Longolius supposed to be a sturgion. Paulus Iouius is of a
contrary opinion. Torulus, a little bed. Torue, sturdyly in look. Toruitas,
tatia, sturdynes. Toruus, ua, uum, cruel and sturdy in loking. Tostus, a, um,
tosted or roasted. Totidem, verily so many, even as many. Tot, as many. Toties,
so many times. Totus, ta, tum, all, the hole, every whyt. Toxicum, venym or
poison.
T ANTE R.
TRabales, a certain tourment. Trabalis, le, pertaining to a beam. Trabalis
clauus, a iron pin or great nail wherewith bemis ar made fast to the rafters
Trabea, a cerklet or kyrtell worn by kings under their mantell. Trabiea nauit,
a ship made with great bemes Trabs, and trabes, a beam of a house. Trachale,
the over part of a fish callid Mutex, of whom purple color is made. Trachea,
the weson or pype of the lunges. Trachelu^, the middle part of tho fast of a
ship Trachelus, the chine of a man or beast, from the heed to the haunche.
Trachida, Trachina, and Trachurus, I suppose is a banstykle. Trachinia, a kind
of roses, not perfytelyted, like to them, that we call french roses. Traconia,
a roughnes within the eye liddes. Traconitidis, a part of Judea. Tractabilis,
treatable, that may be intreatid. Tractare, to handell. Tractim, on length, a
long time or space. Tracto, tare, to entreat. Haec art tractabat uirum, She
handlid the man craftily, or of that sort. alsoo to use or exercise, to order
or govern. Tractoriu^, a windlas to draw up heavy thi^gis Tractus, us, a space,
a country. Trado, didi, dear, to deliver, also to teach, to commytte in trust
to an other man. Traditio, a tradition. Traduco, duxi, ducere, to bring from
oone place to an other, to bring over, to translate out of one language into
an another. Traducere tempus, to pass the time, to bring up or nouryshe.
Traduces, vynes or trees translated from place to place. Tragelaphus, a beast
in part like a heart, in part like a got. Tragemata, that which are
commonly called bankettynge dyshes. Tragite, cruelly, in the manner of a
tragedy. Tragicum tueri, to look grymly. Tragicus, a writer of tragedyes.
Tragoedia, a tragedye, which is an interlude, wherein the personages do
represent sum history or fable lamentable, for the cruelty and myserye
therein expressed. Tragoedus, Plin. 38. cap. 13.
he that exercyseth some part in a tragedye. Tragonis, sieve Tragion, a tree
growing in Candy, like to Iunyper, the juice whereof is like to milk, and
waxethe thycke like gum. Tragum, is like a tyzan made of wheat, it is also a
fyshers net called a dragge. Tragonia, an herb now callid Taragon, late
seen in this realm, which has a taste like gynger: which herb laid to the
left side, consumes the spleen. Tragopa, a bird in Ethiopia, greatter tha^
an egle, and has on his head horn like a got. Tragopogus, a fyshe called a
barbyll. Tragoriganon, an herb which I suppose, is called Penny royalle,
growyng wild. Tragula, a iauelyn with a barbyd heed. Traguriu^, an i will in the sea called Hadriaticu^* Trigon, is a fyshe called a thornebacke. Tragulam
inijcere, to practice deceyte. Traha, a dray or slyd drawn without wheles.
Trahax, acis, a covetous person, the which draws all thing unto him.

Trahere diem, noctem, tempus, to pass the day, the night, or the time.
Plautus in trinammo Cic ^^teque ir^t in exilium.
Trahere, to tarry. Atque egomet me adeo cumillis una ibidem traho, And I my
self tarried as long with them. Trahere, to live. Et uosut tura^
tranquilla^que fortuna^ traheretis, mea perfeci uigilantia^. And by my
vygilancy I brought to pass, that ye should live in a sure and quiet
prosperity. Traho, xi, here, to draw, to lead, to defer, or delay, to

sonder. Vergilius.
Transcribere, is to give or deliver. Turn tot incassum fusos patiere labores,
Et tua Dardaneis tra^scribi sceptra colonis? Will thou Turnus suffer thy
labors to be lost, and thy realm to be given to the inhabytantes of Troy?
Agretius.
Transcribere, the transposition of a possession from one to an other.
Transcribo, psi, bear, to write out of a copy, sometime to translate.
Transcurro, rere, to run forth. Transcurrit aestas, the summer is passed.
Transcursus, us, a course. In transcursu, In passing forth. Transenna, a
loupe to look out at. also a window, or casement. alsoo a rope stretched out,
a snare or trappe. Transeo, siui, and sii, sire, to go forth, to pass ever,
to pass. Transire domum, to go home. Transeunter, passing by or over.
Transfero, tuli, far, to carry or bring from one place to an other, to
translate from one langage to an other, or from ones possession to an others.
Translatus, a, u^, the participle. Transfigo, xi, gere, to thruste through.
Transfuga, he that departs from his own people or capytayne unto the part of
the ennemies, or of them that are suspected in time of truce. Transfodio,
dear, to dygge through. Transfossus, a, u^, dug or stricken through.
Transfiguro, rare, to transfourme, to turn into an another figure.
Transfretatio, a passage over the sea. Transfreto, tare, to pass over the sea.
Transfugere ad hosts, is to goo and yield him to the contrary part.
Transfugium, an yeldynge to ennemies. Transfulgeo, re, to shine through.
Transfundere, to translate from one to an other. Libentius omnes meas lauds
(si modo sint aliquae meae lauds) ad te transfuderim, Ci. Dol^.
I have more wyllyngly turned my praise, (if I have any praise) unto you.
Transfugio, gere, to fle from place to place. Transfundo, fudi, fundere, to
pour out of one vessel into an another. Transgredior, deris, di, to pass or
go over or beyond, to excede, to transgress a law or commandment.
Transgressio, is a figure of retorike, where a man leaves the principal
matter, and enters into an other thing, and after returns to his matter. We
commonly call it, a digression. Transgressus, us, a passing over the sea.
Transigere uiram, to pass his or their life. Salust. Plaut. in Amphit Terent.
in Andria.
Transigere, is also to perform. Transigo, egi, igere, to drive forth, to
treat a matter, to agree or condescende, or come to a point: as happens between
men, which do contend for somewhat. Transilio, siliui, and silii, ire, to leap
over. Transitio, situs, a passing over, a going forth. Transitorius, a, u^,
that which shortly passes. Translatio, a translation, or brynging from one
place to another. Tra^sle go, ere, to read over Transluceo, cere, to shine
through. Transmarinus, na, um, that which comes from beyond the se.
Transmigratio, a departinge or going from one place to dwell in another.

dwelling. Tra^smissio, a going or se^ding further or over Transmittere mare,
to pass over the sea. Plin. ep^^ 173. Epist. 183. Epist. 16
Transmittere tempus, to pass the time. Transmittere discrimen, to escape a
danger. Transmitto, misi, mittere, to send from one place to an other, to go
or run quickly, to send shortly or quickly to pass over a water Transmoueo,
ere, to remove from one place to an other. Transnato, are, to swym over.
Sueton. de claris gra^maticis.
Transnomino, nare, to change his name. Transpareo, rere, to be seen through a
thing. Transpicio, spexi, spicere, to look through. Plautus in mercator.
Tra^squietus, a, u^, in quiet or rest from he^sforth Transtra, transoms which
