shalowe place of a river. Transueho, uexi, uehere, to carye over. Transuerbero,
are, to stryke through. Transuersum agere, to turn hastily away from the
purpose which a man went about. Transuersum unguem non discedere, not to go a
nail breadth from it. A proverb signifieng a little distance. Tra^suersu^
digitu^, ide^. Transuersus, a, um, overthwart, not straight or direct.
Transuerto, tere, to turn away, or out of the right facion or way. Transuideo,
dear, to se through a clear thing. Plautus in ^pt.
Transulto, tare, to leap over. Transumptu^, that which is written out of a
record, and approved under the kings seal, or the sygnynge of the judge. In
the common law they call it an exemplifycation. Some do also call it a
Transumpte. Transumptio, a figure callid also Metalepsis, whereby one
signification is gathered of an other: as of Nox atra, a black night, is
gathered Nox tenebricosa, a dark night. Transuolo, are, to fly over, or leap
over. or to go or run beyond a place. Transumo, umpsi, sumere, to take of or
from an another, to remeue from one to an other Transuo, ere, to sow through.
Trapetes, petum, a myl wherein oil is made Trapeza, a table, whereon an
excha^ger does tell money. Trapezita, an excha^ger or ba^ker Trapezus, zuntis, a
city in the country of Pontus, Trapezuntius, a man of that city. Festus
Trapit, old writers used for vertit. Traston, a certain rosine or gum, the
best of that which is called gummihamoniacum. Traulius, he that spekith with
great difficulti Trebellicu^ vinum, seu Trebulanu^ uinum, wine growing about the
river of Trebia, in Lu^bardye, the Italions do call it Trebiana. Trebula, an
old town nygh to Rome. Trebulani, men of that town. Treceni, three hundred.
Trece^ti, and trecentu^, ide^ Trecentenus, na, number, the three hundredth.
Trecentesimus, ma, mum, idem. Trecenties, three hundred times. Tredecim,
thyrtene. Tremebundus, he that trembles much. Tremefacio, feci, cere, to make
to tremble or quake. Tremisco, scere, to tremble. Tremo, ere, to quake as one
does in a fever. also to fear. Tremulus, he that quaketh for fear. Tremor,
oris, quakyng, also fear. Trepidatio, tremblyng, fear. Trepidanter,
fearfully, tremblyng. Trepido, dare, to fear, to make haste. Trepidus, da,
dum, fearful, also he that does a thing hastily. Trepo^do, three pound weight.
Tres, three. Tressis, three pound. Treueris, a city in Germany callid Tryre.
Treueri, people called Treues. Triambi, were three which spoke together in a
tragedy. Triangularis, re, having.iii. corners Triangulus, la, lum, three
cornerde, Triarchus, a master of a ship with.iii. tops. Triarij, soudiors that
be set always in the rere ward, which were the strongest men, they faught
standing, bowing their knies, as they would rather die tha^ remeue from their
places Triatrus, a festival day kept after the third Idus of every month.
Tribaces, they which be worn with stripes Tribrachus, a foot in meter of.iii.
short sillables. Tribula, and tribulum, a flayle or other like thing, wherewith
corn is threshed. Tribulis, a kynnesman that comes of the same stock that I
do. Tribulor, aris, ari, to be troubled with heaviness of mind. Tribulus, a
bremble. Tribunal, the place where a Judge sytteth in judgment. Tribunatus,
the office or dignite of a tribune Tribunus, was an offycer among the Romans,
having chief jurisdiction among the communes, also a capytaine in wars,
having authority over soudiours, to view and see that they were well armed
and exercysed. Tribunitius, a, um, pertaining to the Tribunes. Tribuo, buere,
to give, sommetyme to set much by. Also to favor. Tribus, bus, a part of
the people, sometime divided into three partis. It seems that it was sometime
taken for a family or particular jurisdiction among the people, and thereof
comes tribulis. And therefore the partition of the people of Israel were
into.xii. Tribus. hereof be sundry opinions. read Calepine. Tributarius, he
that pays tribute. Tributim, by sondrye families or parts of the people.
Tributum, tribute. Tricae, feathers in the fete of chykens and pygeons, which
do let them to go, and therefore all things which do let a man ar callid
Tricae. Vide extrico, and intrico. Tricaptum, a garment, which was so fine,
that it seemed to be made of small hears. Tricenus, na, number, comes of
triginta, thirty. it is sometime taken for tricentenum. Tricentuplus, a, um,
three hundred fold. Triceps, cipitis, having three heedes. Tricerbe^us, a great
hell hounde. Trichiae, be fyshes called Sardynes. Trichila, a vessel having
three lauers, out of the which water is poured. Trichomanes, an herb callid
Maidenhear. Triclinium, a parlor to sup in, wherein were three tables and three
beds. For in the old time they used to lie, when the^ did eat. Triclinarius,
the servant, which does serve in the parlour. Triclinarius, a, um, pertaining
to the parlour or dynynge chaumber. Triclinarium, idem quod triclinium.
Tricolon, having three members. Tricones, men having sour couuntenances, and
that be never or seldom seen to laugh. Also pykers of quarrels. Tricongius, was
oone which drank or he rested, three mesures of wine, callid congii, which as
I suppose, was three galons and a pynt of our wine mesure. wherefore Tiberius the
Emperor promoted him to honor, and at the last made him Consul of Rome.
Tricornium, that which has three horns. Tricubitalis, le, of three cubytes in
measure. Tricubitus, ta, tum, idem. Tricus, a stone, which although it be black
yet shows he at the root black, in the myddell sanguyne, at the top
white. Tridacna, an oyster so great, that a man must make of him three
morsels. Tridens, ^is, every instrument, tool, or wepon, having three tethe.
Triduanus, a, um, of three days continuance. Triduum, the space of three days.
Triennalis, le, of three years. Triennium, the space of three years. Triennis,
ne, three years old. Triens, it is, a coin which is the third part of a pound,
it is also a cup cuntaynyng that poyse. Trientalis herba, an herb, which
has leaves as great as the coin called triens. Triental, a vessel containing
the third part of that mesure, which was named Sextariu^. Trierarclius, the
capytain of a ship, which is called trieris. Trieris, a great ship,
which has in it three orders of seats for the rowers. Trietericus, ca, cum,
for triennalis, that which happens to be done every third year Trieteris, the
space of three years. Trifaria^, in.iii. parts, or three manner of wais.
Trifarius, a, um, of the same signification. Trifaux, faucis, having three
chekes. Trifax, and triforum, a weapon of three cubytes long. Trifer, fera,
rum, that which brings fruit thryse. Triferus, a, um, idem. Trifera, is a
medycyne and other delycate spyces, to expulse easily corrupt humors Trifidus,
da, dum, dyuided into three parts. Trifinium, the buttyng of three feldes,
which join together. Trifolium, may be taken for the generalle name of all
herbs having three leaves. Al be it there is one herb callid so proprely.
Trifur, furis, more than a thief, three times wars than a thief. Semblably tri,
joined with any thing, signifies more. Triga, a carte drawn with three horses.
Trigarium, a certain course with such cartis Trigamus, he which has or has
had three wives. Trigarius, a place by campu^ Martiu^, at Rome Trigemini,
three chyldern at one birth. Trigeminus, na, number, idem quod tres, three.
Columel. 3. cap. 19.
Trigemmis, a plant or slyppe having three joints and three buddes. Trigesimus,
ma, mum, the thirtieth. Trigesies, thyrty times. Triginta, thirty. Trigla, a
fyshe, I suppose it to be a sore mullette, such as are taken in Deuonshyre and
in Cornwall. Trigles, a stone which is of the color of a soore Mullet. Trigo
gare, to bind or to draw a thing clo^e together. Trigon, gonis, a balle.
also a turtyll. Trigonia, the third age. Trigonalis, le, that which is three
cornerde, having three lines. Trigonus, na, number, three cornerde. Trilinguis, he
that speaks three langages. Trilix, licis, a garment with three diverse thredis.
Trimatus, tus, the time of three years. Trimembris, bre, having three members.
Trimestris, tree, of three months. Trimetrum, a verse of three fete. Trimma, a
wine made with spices, as that which is called ypocras. Trimorion, is named
of.iii. signs in heaven, which contain.lxxxx. degrees or porcions. wherefore
Timorion, is in calculation of natiuities from the time of the birth or
co^ception, the.lxxx. and tenth part or degree. Trimus, ma, mum, of three years.
Trimulus, the diminutiue of Trimus. Trimyxos, a lamp or candellstycke,
bearing three lyghtes. Trinacris, and trinacria, the country of Sicile.
Trinepos, potis, he which is three discentes lyneall from my chyldes child.
Trineptis, a woman in like degree of blood as trinepos is. Trinitas, trinity,
the number of three. Trinoxius, a, um, three nyghtes. Trinundinum, the third
fair or markette, which was wont to be proclaimed, to the intent that it
should be the better reme^brid. Trinus, na, number, three. Trioboli homo, and
triobolaris, a man worth three half pens, of little value. Triobolus, three
half pens, or worth three half pens. Triones, plough oxen. Alsoo they be
seven sterres being in the north. Triophthalmus, a little stone, having in
him the figure of three eyes. Triorchis, a kind of hawks, having three
stoones. Triparcus, a greatte nygarde. Tripartior, tiri, to dyuide into three
parts. Tripartito, an Aduerbe, sygnyfyenge in three partis. Tripartitus, ta,
tum, dyuided in three partis. Tripedaneus, a, um, having three fete. Tripes,
pedis, with three feet. Trifoliu^, three leaued grass. Triphillon, ide^.
Triplaris, thryse as much. Triplex, plicis, three fold, treble, a table with
three leaves. Triplicitas, treble. Tripliciter, three folde^ Triplico, are, to
do or fold a thing.iii. times. Triplium, a vessel like a baskette. Triplus, a,
um, treble. Tripolis, a countray in Africa, an other in Syria, the third in
Phenicia. Tripolium, an herb. Tripondium, three pound weight. Tripontium, a
town in Vmbria in Italy, so called because it has three brydges. Triptolemus,
a man which found the use of grain in the countray of Athenes. Tripudium,
daunsynge. Tripus, podis, every thing that has three feet. Tripodes, were
alsoo tables in the temple of Apollo, of gold. Triquetra, a figure three
cornerde. It was also a name of the I Will of Sicile. Triquetrus, tra, trum,
having three corners. Triremis, a galeye. Tris, three or thryse. Trismegistus,
the name of Mercurius, in latin Ter maximus. Tristegum, a chamber in the third
storye or floor of a house. ^irtius in co^mentar^
Tristimonia, heaviness or sorrow. Trissis, three pound weight. Tristis, is
also taken for doctus, Iudex tristis and integer, A judge well learned and of a
good conscience. Tristis, against his will, not well content. Terent. in
Eunucho.
Tristitia, sorrow, or heaviness. Tristis, sorrowful, heavy, also cruelle, of
much gravity, bitter, more difficile or hard* sometime angry. Tristo, tare,
to make heavy or sorrowful. Trisulcus, ca, cum, having three edges. Trisulcu^
telu^, a weapon having three edges. Trisyllabus, ba, bum, having three sillables.
Tritauia, my great grandfathers mother. Tritauus, my great grandfathers father.
Tritheles, an herb which has thryse in the year flowers. Triticeus, a, um,
of wheat. Triticum, wheat. Trito, tare, to break or beat small. Triton,
one called god of the sea. Tritonia, the name of Minerua. Trituro, rare, to
threshe corn. Tritura, threshynge. Trituratio, idem. Tritus, ta, tum, worn.
Triuenesica, a great sorceresse. Triuia, a name of Diana. Triuialis, le,
commune or of small estimation used or taught in high ways, alsoo rude, not
elegant. Triuialis lingua, a homely form of speech. Triuium, where ways do
mete, also a place where commune recourse of people is. Triuialiter, communely,
in the vulgar or homely facyon. Trium literarum homo, was spoken in scorn of
him, that would seem to be a gentylle man, where he was none, which word was
made by this occasyon, that among the old Romans gentylle men vsyd to write
their names with three letters, as Q, F, M, for Quintus Fabius Maximus. Also
this proverb was spoken of them, which were thieves, because that Fur,
contained but three letters. Triumphalis, le, belongyyng to triumphs.
Triumphator, he that tryumpheth or has triumphed for vaynquishyng his enmyes.
Triumphalis uir, he that has triumphed. Triumphatus, ta, tum, of the which
oone has tryumphed. Triumphatus, tus, a triumph. Triu^phatio, ide^. Triu^pho,
are, to triu^ph, to rejoice excedi^gly Triumphus, a triumph, which is a
solemn pomp or ceremony, where a prince, a co^sul or principal capitayn of
an army, has had vyctorie of the ennemies of his countray, and therefore is
brought home and received with all rejoicing and honor that may be devised of
the people. The order and form thereof ye may se in Titus Liuius, Apianus, and
Julius Capitolinus. Triumuir, one of them which is in any office, whereof be
three in like auctorite. Trium uiralis, le, pertaining to an office or
authority, wherein be three persons. Triumuiratus, is an office in the publyque
weal, wherein three men have equal jurisdiction together. Triumuiratus, the
office or authority of triumuit. Triuncis, and triuncium, three ounce weight.
Trixalis, a worm like to that which is called Locusta, but he has no wings.
Troas, adis, the city of Troy, and the country about it called the less
Phrigia. Trochaeus, a foot in meter, which is of two long syllables, and one
short. Trochilos, a little bird, which is called king of birds.
Trochiscus, a little whele. Alsoo trochisci, be of physicians called, little
balls flat at both ends, which be made of sundry poulders. Trochum, a
certain stool or chair, which will be turned about. Trochus, a top,
wherewith childern do play. Troclea, and trochalea, a poley wherein ye cord
runs, whereby any thing is drawn up. it is also the gyn, which is callid a
crane. Troezene, a city in the part of Greece, called Peloponesus. It is also
a countraye in the less Asia. Troglotidae, people in Ethiopia. Troia, the
city of Troy. also the country wherein Troy stood. Troianus, na, number, of
Troy. Troianus ludus, was a play of chylderne on horseback. Troicus, ca,
cum, for troianus. Troiugena, idem. Troius, a, um, of Troy. Tropeus, he that
does a shrewde turn, and runs away when he has done. Trophaeum, was a
mark or token of timber or stone, set in the place where enemies were
vanquyshed or put to flyghte, sometime it is taken for vyctorie. Tropice,
fyguratiuely. Tropice, ces, a kind of bulle russhes, the sede whereof will make
one to sleep. Tropicus, ca, cum, fyguratiue. Tropei uenti, wyndes, which do
comme from the sea. Tropologia, a figurative speaking. Tropus, a figure, a
manner or facion, an alteracion of a word or sentence from his propre
signification. Tros, troos aut trois, a Troyane. alsoo the name of a king of
Troianes. Trossulum, a city in Italye. Trossulus, in the old time was taken
for a horsman or man of arms. It is also a person delycate, well fed or
fleshy. Troximi, grapes to be eaten. Trua, idem quod trulla. Trucido, dare, to
slay cruelly. Trucidatrix, she that kylleth one. Truciter, cruelly. Truculente,
idem. Trucitas, cruelty. Truculentia, cruelty. Truculentius, more cruelly.
Truculentissime, most cruelly. Truculentitas, idem quod truculentia.
Truculentus, cruelle in countenaunces or menaces. Trudo, trusi, trudere, to
thruste out with vyolence. Truella, a vessel wherewith water is throwe^ into
the synke. Trulla, wherein meat is put when it is roste or sodden. It is alsoo
a pyssepotte, of sum it is taken for a great cup, broad and deep, such as
greatte masers were wont to be. Trulla, a trewell, wherewith masons, tylers,
and pariettours do lay mortar. Trulleum, a bolle. Truncatio, a cuttynge in
pieces. Truncatus, ta, tum, cut in pieces. Truncator, and truncatrix, he or she
that cutteth in pieces. Trunco, are, to cut of. Truncus, a piece cut of
from the resydue specially of a tree. Truncus, a, um, cut of. Truo, onis, a
bird called also Onacratalus, and is like to a swanne. Trusatilis, le, that
which may be turned and driven about with a man's hand. Trusatiles molae, a
querne, such as malte is ground in, or mustarde is made in, and is turned
with ones hand. Trutina, a wayenge balance. sometime it is taken for
judgment. Trutino, nare, to way or examyne. Trux, trucis, cruel, horrible.
T ANTE V.
TV, tui, it is, tibi, thou, of the, to the. Tuatim, after thy facyon or custom.
Tuba ductilis, a brason trumpette. Tuba, a trumpette. Tuber, beris, a puff
growyng on the ground like a musheron or sponge. It is alsoo generally every
swellynge in a man's body or vysage. It is alsoo in a tree like to a greatte
knotte. Tubercula, a little swellynge or pushe. Tubero, are, to swelle.
Tubicen, cinis, a trumpettour. Tubulus, a little pype, wherein water runs
from a spring. it is also a riede. Tubus, a pype, wherein water is conuayed to
a cundyte. Tuburcinor, aris, ari, to eat hastily. Tubus, and tubulus, the pype
of a cundyte. it was also a thing, wherewith they made walls hot, before
there were chymneis. Tucetum, a meat made with choppid flesh like to a gigot
or allow. Tudertum, a city in Italye. Tudicula, a ladell, a pryntynge iron,
wherewith vessel is marked. Tudiculo, are, to steer, to prynte a mark.
Tuditantes, they that travail in business. Tuditanus, the name of a man, so
called because he had a heed as bygge as a betyll. Tuditis, a mallette. Tudito,
tare, to labor for advantage. Tuor, eris, eri, to defend. alsoo Tueor,
tueris, to see. Tugurium, a house of husbandry. Tuguriolum, a cotage. ^^st. pom.
Tu ipse, thou thy self. Tulit, he brought. Festus.
Tullii, some suppose them to be ryuers, some flowinges of bloudde out of sundry
members or joints. Salust.
Tullianum, a dungeon within the common prison of Rome. Tum, than, when he
gothe before cum, it sygnifieth as well. Tumba, a holowe place in the ground,
a sepulcher. Tumdemum, finally. Tumefacio, feci, to make to swelle. Tumeo, and
tumesco, scere, to swelle. Tumet, thou thy self. Tumidus, da, dum, swollen.

Tumultuo, are, to make rumor. Tumultuose, troublously, or without study.

Tumulus, a little hylle or barowe, sommetyme a tomb. Tunc, thanne. Tunc
temporis, at that time. Tundo, tutudi, tundere, to smite, to braye or beat as
in a mortar. Tunetu^, a city in Africa callid now Tunise. Tungo, gere, old
writers used for Nosco, nosce, to know. Tunica, a iackette. Tunica pallia
propior, my iackette is nerer than my gown. a proverb applied where we will
signify that all friends are not to be like esteemed or made of. Tunico, care,
to put on a iackette. Tunicatus, he that wears a iackette. Tuopte ingenio, of
thine own wit. Tuor, eri, to behold, all be hit that word is not in use.
Turarius, a street at Rome. Turbatio, trouble. Turba, a multitude or assemblye
of people. Quid illec turba est? nu^nam ego perij? Terent. in Eunucho. Terent.
in Heautont,
What a multitude is yonder? am not I undone for ever? Also it signifies
trouble. Propter eam haec turba atque abitio euenit, For her sake is all this
trouble or dissension. Turbasis, sterche. Turbella, a little trouble. Turbide,
troublousely. Turbidus, troublous, not clear. Turbinatus, ta, tum, round and
sharp, like a top. Turbino, nare, to make sharp at the end. Turbistum, is
a thing myxte with the lycour, wherewith woulle is dyed, which makes the dye
to synke into the woull, whereby the color is made perfyte. Turbo, bare, to
trouble, to stere. Vide com.
Turbo, binis, a boystouse wind, which does blow down trees and houses,
also a top, wherewith chyldern do play. It is generally all thing, which is
round and broad above, and sharp benethe. Turbulentia, trouble. Turbulentus,
troublous, angry, full of contention. Turdetania, a contray now callid Granado.
Turdetani, and turduli, people of that contray. Turdus, a bird, which is
delycate in eating, a thrustell or black bird, alsoo a fyshe called an
hadocke. Turgeo, ere, and turgesco, scere, to be swollen. Turgidilus, la, lum,
sommewhat swollen or bollyd out. Turgidus, da, dum, swollen. Turiones, the
tendrelles of trees. Turma, a company of soldiers, contaynynge.xxxii.
horsemen. Turmatim, in order of battle. Turpis, pe, foul, dishoneste,
cruelle. Vergilius.
Alsoo greatte. Turpiter, shamefully, dishonestly. Turpissime, most shamefully
or dishonestly. Turpitudo, dishonestie, vyllany, deformity, sometime rebuke.
Turpo, pare, to defyle, dyshonest, or bring out of good facyon. Turreus, rea,
reum, like a tower. Turrisico, care, to ^ense. Turris, a toure or any thing
made like to it. Turricula, a little town. also a box, out of the which
dyse are thrown. Turriger, that which bears a tower, as an Elyphaunt.
Turritus, ta, tum, high, also towred, or fulle of towers. also the name of the
ydol, which was called mother of gods. Turtu^, turis, a bird called a
turtelle. It is also a fyshe. Turundae, pellettes of bread or past, wherewith
capons or other fowls ar crammed. Also a tente which surgeons do put into a
wound. Tu^, tutis, frankyncense, it is alsoo written which (...), as thus.
Tusc^a, a country in Italye, wherein be the cities of Florence, Seen, Luca, and
Pise. Tuscalum, a lyttelle piece of frankincense. also a city by Rome.
Tusculanus, na, number, of that city. T^^^^s, ca, cum, of the country of Tuscia.
Tu^^^^o, dinis, the cowghe. Tu^sicula, a little coughe. Tussilago, ginis, an
herb, which puttethe away the cough. some men suppose it to be coltes foot.
Tussio, siui, sire, to cough. Tussis, the coughe. Tu^anus, was supposed to be a
god, which had the custody of men. Tute, thou thy self. Tutela, the wardshyp
or custody of infa^tes. Tutelaris diuus, the saint whom we do take for our
special advocate to god. Tutelina, was callydde a Goddess, under whose
custodye was corn, which was in barnes or rykes. Tutissime, most sure.
Tutius, more sure. Tuto, without peril. Tuto, tare, to defend. Tutor, taris,
tari, idem. Tutor, a garden, he that has the ward of an infant. Tutorius, a,
um, pertaining to a gardeyn. Tutulus, a top of the hear wounden with a purple
lace on the crown of a woman's heed, which was only worn of her that was wife
to the great priest at Rome, called Flamen Dialis. Tutus, ta, tum, sure,
defended from peril, out of danger. Tuus, a, um, thine.
T, ANTE Y.
TYber, a great river, which is by Rome Tyberinus, of Tyber. Tyberius, the name
of an emperor of Rome. Tybur and tyburtum, a city by Rome. Tyburtinus, na,
number, of the cite of Tyburtu^. Tyburs, burtis, and tyburtis, hoc tyburte, of
Tyber. Tydeus, the father of Diomedes the noble capytayne, whom Venus did
wound at the battle of Troy. Tyle, called also Thule, an i will within one
days journey of the frosen see. Tylus, a worm, which lies under stones and
tyles, which have lain long on the ground, and is somewhat black and
scalyd, and has many legs, which being touched, closes him self round as
a pease, and is most commonly called a cheselyppe. Tymbra, a great field in
the countreye of Troy, through which the river of Timber runs into the river
of Scamander. Tymoetes, one of the sons of king Prtamus. Tymolus, idem quod
Tmolus. Tympanista, he that plays on a drumslade or tymbrell. Tympanis^ria, a
woman that plays on a tymbrell. Tympanites, a kind of dropsy, wherein the
bealy swells great, a tympany, whereof wind is the chief occasyon.
Tympanizo, to play on a tymbrell, tabour, or drumslade. Tympanotriba, idem quod
tympanista. Tympanu^, a tymbrel, a tabour, or drumslade. Seruius calls it a
covered charyotte or carte, other do suppose it to be the struck of a carte
whele. I suppose that it may be taken for that, which is called the corse of a
charyotte or horselytter, made with bayles or bourdes joined, which is not
much from the opinion of Seruius. Tympanum, is also a great whele, wherein men
do goo and draw up water. It is also a platter, which serves for meat.
Tymphei, people in Etholia, which is in Grecia. Tyndarus, the father of the
fair Helene, for whom Troy was destroyed, and alsoo of Castor and Pollux.
Typhon, and Typhos, was a great giant, the son of Tytan. It is also a great
puyssaunt wind. Typhonae, be certain impressyons in the air like globes of
fire or darts. Typhis, was a carpenter, which first did find the way to
govern a ship. Typus, a figure, an example, or a form, a lykenes or
shadow of a thing. Tyrannice, cruelly, tyrannousely. Tyrannicus, ca, cum, of a
tyrant. Tyrannis, nidis, a cruelle or violente rule or governance for a private
commodity, and not for a publyke weal. Tyrannicida, he that sleeth a tyrant.
Tyrannicidium, the killing of a tyrant. Tyrannus, a tyrant. Tyranthina, a
garment of purple color. Tyranthinus color, purple color. Tyrius, a, um, of
the isle called Tyrus, Also vyolette or purple color. Tyro, ronis, a young
soldier or manne of arms. Also he that first enters into the experience of
any science, art, or exercise. Tyroniacus, ca, cum, of a young soldier or
lerner. Tyrocinium, the first exercise in any thing. Tyros, a cite in Phenicia.
also an isle, where the color of purple was first founden. Tyrunculus, a
veraye young sowldiour or young lerner. Tyrotarichus, a sauce made with chese.
Tyrrheni, the people of Thuscane. Tyrsis, the circuit without the walls of a
town, wherein me^ may walk for their solace.
V ANTE A.
VACCA, a cow. Also a city in Numidia. Salust^ in ^^gurt.
Vaccinus, vaccina, cinum, of a cow. Vacerra, mad, without wit, percloses
or railes, made of timber, within the which some thing is inclosyd. Vacillo,
are, to move inconstantly, to wagge or wave, to be unstable, or unsure.
Vacinium, the flower, which is also called Hyacinthus, and has long leaves,
a round root, a stalk of a spanne long and more, having on it many purple
flowers, wherewith in some places they do dye pourple. I doubt whither it be
the flower which is called Hartis ease, or Sweet wyllyam. Vacillatio, a
waggynge or wauerynge and inconstant meuynge. Cl. Tyro.
Vacillantes literae, letters written crokedly or out of order. Vacillans
testis, a witness, which inconstantly does varye in report or deposition.
Vacat, it serves to no purpose, it is superfluous. Also it sygnyfyeth, I am at
good leisure, or without busynes. sometime it sygnifyeth to care or force. Et
cui esse deserto vacat, And who cares to be well spoken or eloquent. Vacatio,
vacation, or time when a man is out of his common busynes. Vaco, care, to
apply wit or study. Vaco sapientiae, I apply my study to wisdom. Vaco
rei diuinae, I apply my wit to gods service. Also to be emptye or void.
Fac uacent aedes, cause the house to be voided. Vacat occupatione, He is
without occupation or ydell. Sometime it signifies to be superfluous, or
unprofitable. Vacuae aures, Date mihi vacuas aures, dum eloquor, Give your
ears oonely to me, while I speak, or here nothing else. Vacuefacio, cere, to
empty or avoid. Vacuo, are, idem. Vacuus, a, um, void, emptye, or without a
thing. Vacuus animus, a mind without care or solycitude. Vacuna, was called
a goddess, unto whom husbandmen after that harvest was clean done, did
sacrifyce, as to the goddess of quyetenes after labor. Vacuitas, emptynesse.
Vadimonium, surety to appiere at a day^ assygned. Vadis, and uas, uadis, he
that undertakes for an another. Vadium, surety. Vado, dear, to go forth. also
to find surety. Vado, dare, to wade. Vador, aris, ari, to find sureties.
Vadimonio obstrictus, let to bail or mainpryse, when a man is bounden to
appear at a day assigned by a justice. Vadimonium obire, to appiere at the day
assygned. Vadimonium deserere, to make defaute at the day, and not to appiere.
Vadimoniu^ missum facere, to discharge the recognisance or sureties that were
bounden. Vadimonium differ, to give a longer day of apparaunce. Vadosus, a,
u^, full of fordes or shalow places. Vadum, and vadus, a fourde or shalow place
in a water, where men and beasts may goo over. Vaeh, an interiection,
wherewith we do curs. Vafellus, he that is somewhat crafty. Vafer, fra, frum,
subtle, crafty, fly. Vaframentum, subtyltie or craft, slynesse. Vafre,
craftily, fynely in deceyuyng. Vagabundus, a wanderer about. Vadigabar, an
hebrewe word, which in latyne is Numeri, one of the five books of Moses.
Vageni, a people dwelling among the mountains called Alps. Vagina, a shethe
or scaberde. Vaginula, a little shethe. Vagio, gire, to cry as a child.
Vagitus, tus, the crienge of a child. Plaut. in milite.
Vago, gare, for vagor, to wander. Vagor, aris, ari, idem. Vagus, ga, gum,
wandrynge and abiding in no place. Vah, an interiection, wherewith we wonder
^r a thing, also of reioysynge. Plautus in casina.
Vaha, an Interiection of reioysynge or lawghynge. Valacchia, a country
beyond Hungary. Valde, very much. Valdius, for validius. Vale, farewelle.
Valens, puissaunt, hole, strong. Valentia, puissance, ability. Valentior,
ualentius, more puissant or strong. Valentissimus, most puissant, or strong.
(...) in (...)*
Valentulus, somewhat strong. Valeo, lui, lere, to be able, to be hoole. Male
ua^eo, I fare ill, I am ill at ease. Valere, to be strong or puyssant, to may
do, or be of force or power. Neque tam imperita, ut quid amor ualeat, ne sciam,
I am not such a fool, but I know what love may do, or of what power love is.
Valere a morbo, to be recouerid fro sickness Valere, also signifies to be
worth. Terent. in Andria.
Valeat, farewell he, I care not for him. Imo habeat, ualeat, uiuat cum illa,
well let him wedde her, I care not for him, much good do it him with her: or
let him have her, god be with him, let him make merye with her. Cicero.
Si deus talis est, ut nulla gratia, nulla hominum charitate teneatur ualeat,
If god be such oone, that he has neither favor nor love to mankind, I care
not for him. Terent. in Andria.
Valiant, qui inter nos dissidium uolunt, They that will have us at variance let
them get them hense. Valesco, scere, idem quod ualeo. Valeria, the sister of
Messala, wife to a noble man called Seruius, who being deed, when she was
asked, why she did not marye again, she answered, that she always lived by
Seruius her husband. Valerius, a man's name. Valesius, for Valerius.
Valetudinarium, a place where men do lie, when they be sick, as the fermerye
in a monasterye. Valgiu^, an instrument to make flores smoth. Plinius.
Valgulatio, a question in rebuke of one. Valgustus, a crooked staff. Fest. Po^
Valgus, he that has his legs or feet bowed inward. Valetudinarius, a,
um, now and than sick, oftentimes sick. Valitudo, and valetudo, dinis,
sometime signifies sickness, sometime health. Valide, valyantly, myghtyly.
Validus, da, dum, valyant, mighty. Validior, validius, more mighty.
Validissimus, most mighty. Validitas, tatis, might. Vallecula, a little
valey. Vallaris, re, pertaining to a trench in a feld. Vallaris corona, a
garlande given to him* which first entered into the trenche of the enemies
camp. Vallescit, old writers used for perierit, he is lost or peryshed.
Vallis, a valey or dale. Vallo, are, to enclose, to fortifye. Valonia, was
called the goddess of valeis. Vallum, and vallus, a trenche, which is made in
a field to defend an hooste, within the which pauilions are pytched. Also a
post whereunto vynes are bound. Valor, oris, value or price. Valuae, dorc^
which be shut on two partis. Valuulus, the codde of a bean or pease, or other
like thing. Vanans, old writers used for fallens, No. Mar.
deceyuynge. Vandalia, a countray in the north part of the world. Vane,
vaynely, foolyshely, lyengly. Vanesco, scere, to vanysshe, to be brought unto
naught. Vanidicus, a liar or teller of folyshe tales. Vaniloquus, idem,
Vaniloquidorus, idem. Vaniloquentia, vain speech. Plautus (...) Persa.
Vanitas, tatis, vanity, lyghtnes, lesyng, folly. Vanitudo, vanity. Vanno,
are, to vanne corn. Vannus, a vanne. Vanus, a, um, void or empty. Also
folisshe or enuyous, a maker of lies. Vapor, oris, and vapos, a vapor, or hot
breath issuynge out of a thing. Vaporarium, a place made hot to sytte in in
the winter time. Vaporo, rare, to hete or make warm a place Vappa, wine, which
has lost his verdure. It is sometime taken for a man, in whom is no wit
or perfyte reason. Vapo, onis, a beast that flees. Vapularis, he that is
beaten. Vapulo, lare, to be beaten. Variabilis, le, variable. Variantia,
varietas, and variatio, variety, dyuersitie in things. Varices, and varicae,
variculae, ar veins which do swelle excedyngly. Varicosus, he that has such
veins swolle^. Varicor, aut varico, to transgress, to pass over a thing
neglygently. Varicus, an aduerbe, which sygnyfyethe strydynge. Varae manus,
crooked hands. Vari, spots in the face. Vary, dyuersely. Variae, for
Pantherae, bestes of diverse colors. Variegatus, a, um, painted or garnished
with sondrye colors. Varius, a fyshe called a troute. Vario, are, to make
diverse. Variolae, measylles. Varius, a, um, diverse, unlike, inconstaunt,
varyable. Varolus, a deuourer, also a pycker. Varro, ronis, was a noble
Romayne, of all other most excellently learned. Varus, whose legs are crooked
inward. Varus, a river, which dyuydeth that part of France, that is callydde
Narbonensis, from Italy. Also it was the name of a poet Vas, vadis, a surety,
he that vndertakethe for an other man. also a pledge. Vas, vasis, a vesselle.
Vascones, Gascoynes. Vascularius, a potter. Vascularius, a goldsmythe, the
which makes plaate. Vasa conclamare, to cry to trusse up caryage and
baggage, as when an army does remove. Vasculum, and vascillum, a small
vessel. Vastatio, destruction. Vasterna, a horselytter, or any thing borne by
two horses. Vastescant, old writers vsid for inhorrescant. Vasto, are, to waste
or distroye. Vastus, a, um, great, huge, sometime desolate. Vastitas, tatis,
vastitudo, and vastities, greattenes, also destruction. Vasum, a vesselle.
Vates, a prophet, a poet. Vatesco, scere, to be distroyed, to be dried up,
to be forsaken. Vaticanus collis, a hylle by Rome. Vaticinor, aris, ari, to
prophecy, or tell what shall happen, to coniecte. Vaticinium, a prophecye, a
conjecture. Vaticinatio, idem. Vatidicum, for propheticum, that which is
spoken in a prophecye. Vatius, idem quod valgus, he that has crooked legs
outward. Vatrax, and vatricosus, he that has ylle legs from the knee
downewarde.
V, ANTE B.
VBer, and huber, a womannes breaste. Vide Huber. Vbi, where* in what place,
sometime when, after. Vbiloci, idem. Vbique gentium, in all countrayes. Vbique,
in all places, every where, in all. Vbique loci, in every place. Vbilibet,
where ye will. Vbicunque, in every place. Vbicubi, idem.
V ANTE D.
Vdus, da, dum, moist. Vuidus, da, dum, moist inward.
V ANTE E.
VE, idem quod Vaeh, Alsoo it is put for uel, or que. Vecors, dis, mad.
Vecordia, madness. Vectabulum, wherein any thing is carried. Vecticularia, ui
ta, to have much to day, and nothing to morrow, suddenly rich, and as
sodaynely poor. Vectigal, a tribute, a pencion, a rent, a yearly reuenewe.
Vectigalis, le, he that pays trybute, pencyon, or rent. Vectis, a bar.
also a leauer, wherewith things be lift, or borne by men. Vecto, are, to
carye. Vectito, idem Vectatio, caryage. Vector, toris, he that is carried,
sometime he that caryeth. Vectorius, a, um, apt to carye. Vectura, caryage,
also the hyre or money given for caryage. Vegeo, gere, to be in health. Veget,
for uegetat. Vegetius, a noble man that wrate of marciall doctrine. Vegeto,
uegetare, to recreate, to quycken, to conserve. Vegetus, ta, tu^, hole, strong
in health, quick. Vegrandis, little. Vehea, for via. Vediouis, and veiouis, was
callid a god which had no power to do good, but only harm. Veheare, old
writers used for vehere. Vehemens, it is, vehemente, great, vrgente, fyers,
sharp. Vehementis, vehemence, might. Vehementer, vehemently, sharply,
mightily. Vehementior, tius, more vehement or sharp. Vehementissimus, ma, mum,
most vehemente or sharp. Vehes, a carte or wayne. Vehia, in the old Tuscane
tongue was a cart. Vehiatura, for vectura, caryage. Vehiculatius, a carter.
Vehicularis equus, a cartehorse. Vehiculum, a general name to all things,
which serves for caryage. Veho, uexi, uehere, to carye. Veios, a city in
Hetruria. Veientes, people, with whom the Romans had long time wars.
Veientanus, na, number, of the city of Veios. Veij, the people of Veios. Veiouis,
uide ante Vedionis. Vel, or, sommetyme also, chiefly, namely, at the least.
Velabrum, a place in Rome. It may be also called a tent, which crafts men do
set up, where they have no howses, to be instead of their shoppes. Velamen,
minis, a covering. Velaria, clothes, wherewith tentis ar made. also the same
tents. Velatura, a frayte. Velatus, ta, tum, apparayled. Veles, velitis, a
soldier that wears light harneyse. Velia, a f^nne in Italy, in the
countreye of Calabria. Velifico, care, to sail. Velina, a street in Rome, by
the hill called Mons Palatinus. Velis equisque, by see and by land. Velitaris
pugna, battle done by them that are light harneysed. Velitatim, by leapes or
skyppes. Velitor, aris, ari, and uelito, uelitare, to strive, to brawle.
Velitatio, brawling. Velittae, plurali numero, a city in Italy. Veliuolus, a,
um, that which gothe with a sail, or is occupied with sails. Vella, old
writers used for villa. Vellaturam facere, to live by carriage from one town
to an another. Vellicarim, by pluckes. Vellico, care, to pynche, sometime to
rebuke, to byte, to rent. Vello, lere, to pluck up, or pull a thing. Vellus,
velleris, a flyse. Velo, lare, to cover or hyde, to bind, to apparayle.

swyftest. Velocissime, most swyftely^. Velociter, swyftely. Velox, locis,
swyfte. Velum, a sail, a curtayne. Velut, veluti, as, like as. Vena, a vain.
Venabulum, a hunting staff. Venalitiarius, he that sells slaves. Venalis,
le, that which is set to sale. Venalitium, a place where any thing is sold.

ta, tum, humblye prayed unto. Sometime reverend. Veneror, aris, ari, to
honor. Veneratio, honor, reverence. Venereus, a man disposed to lechery.

to hunte, to get a thing craftylye. Ventanea, things that seem to be
dangerous, and yet therein is no danger. Venture, tris, the bealy or panche.

wherewith wind is made. Ventilatio, a fannynge or wynn^wynge. Ventilator, a

live by the wind. A proverb applied to them, which have no substance to

blowethe a good cool. Ventus popularis, vayneglorie. Ventrale, a stomacher.

called goddess of love, sometime lechery, also carnal appetite, alsoo beauty,

bramble. Vepres, briars. Vepretum, a place full of briars. Ver, ueris, the
spryng of the year. Veratru^, an herb called also Helleborus. Verax, racis, he
or she that says truth. Veracitas, tatis, truth in speech. Verba dare, to
deceive. Verba mortuo dare, to speak to a deed man, a proverb when a man
loses his labor. Verbascu^, an herb whereof be.ii. kinds: of which one is
supposed to be Molin or long wort, the other is supposed to be that which is
called primerose, not withstanding other men redynge the description, let
them judge at their liberty. Verbena, and uerbenaca, an herb called veruyn.
sometime Verbenae, are all leaves sodeinly plucked up, to garnyshe howses or
churches, or to make garlandes. Verber, a small long stycke or yard.
Verberalis, worthy to be beaten. Verberatio, Verberatus, tus, a beatynge.
Verbereus, ea, eum, worthy to be beaten. Verbero, rare, to beat, to punyshe.
Verbero, ronis, a person worthy punyshement, the reproach of all servants.
Verberito, tare, to beat often. Verbigero, rare, for verba facere, to talk.
Verbenarius, was one of the ambassadors sent fro the Romans unto their enmies,
which ware on his heed a garland of veruyn. Verbose, an aduerbe, signifienge
with many words. Verbositas, much talking or speking. Verbis meis salutem
dicito, salute him in my name. Verbosus, full of words. Verbulum, a little
word. Verbi causa, as by example. Verbi gratia, ide^. Verbum, a word, also a
sentence comprised in one word, a proverb. Vercellae, was a city in Liguria,
nigh to the mountayns called Alps. Vere, truly. Verecundanter, and
verecunditer, shamefastly. Verecundia, shamefastness. Verecunde, shamefastly.
Verecundor, aris, ari, to be ashamed. Verecundus, da, dum, shamefaste.

nagge, or swyfte geldynge. Verenda, places in a man and woman, which without
shame may not be named. Verendus, da, dum, to be feared or dradde. Vereor,
reris, reri, to fear as the child does the father. Timere, to fear, as the

asonder. Vermino, nare, to have worms. Verminatio, the disease of the wourmes,
proprely in cattle. Verminosus, a, um, full of worms, or that wherein worms
are. Vermis, a worm. Also it is a fish in the river of Ganges, which is in
length.lx. cubytes, and is blue in color, which has such strength, that
when oliphantes com to the water and do drink, he will take one of them by
the nose, and pluck him into him. Verna, a bondeman or bondewoman, borne in
the house of the lord, or in his own countreye. Vernaculus, la, lum, all that
takes beginning in our own country, as Vernacula lingua, the country
language, the common speech, peculyar or propre to country or house.

year. Vernalis, le, pertaining to the spring of the year. also seruyle.
Vernaliter, lewdely, flatteryngly. Vernatio, the old skin of an adder. It is
sometime taken for age. Vernilis, le, seruyle. Coecilius.
Vernilitas, flatterye. Vernilitus, old writers used for a flatterer.

birds done. Vernula, a dyminutiue of verna. Vernus, a, u^, lusty, fresh, as

follows. also but yet. Vero, is also a river in Byskay. Vero, are, to say
truth. Verona, a city in Italy. Verones, people dwelling nyghe to the river
of Vero. Veronensis, and Veronius, a man of Verona. Verpus, pa, pum, that
which has no skyn. It is also the myddell finger. Verpi, be alsoo Jews.

borne. Verres, a hog vngelded, a tame bore. as aper may be called a wild
bore. Verricula, old writers used for articulus. Verriculum, a net called a
dragge. Verrinco, care, to turn or change a thing unto better. Verrinus, a,
um of a bore. Verruca, an hyllocke or knappe on a hylle. also a warte.

that are turned or wounden one about the other, as two cords or two styckes
wou^den together. also pillars made of the same facion. Versatilis, le, that
which tourneth or may be turned. Versicolor, oris, chaungeable, or that

turned out of his natural color. also that which is of diverse colors mixed

dettes to an other. and to borow in such wise is Versuram face^e. Versuram
soluere, is to change creditours, as to borowe of one man to pay an other.

Versus, toward. Versute, craftyly. Versutus, mutable, often tournynge, wylye,
expert. Versutia, wylynesse. Versutiloquus, a crafty speaker. Vertagus, a
hounde which will hunte by him self. Vertat tibi been, God give the thereof
good luck. Di been uertant, I pray god turn it to good. Vertebrae, places in
the body, where the boones do not meet: but are knytte together in such
wise with synewes, that they may turn the more lightly. Vertere terga, to
rounne away, or fly in battle. Vertere solum, to goo and dwell out of a
man's propre country. Vertere, for versuram facere. Vertere stultitiae, to
repute folly in a thing. Plautus in Epidic.
Vertere uitio, to put the blame in one. Quis erit, uitio qui id non uerta^
tibis? Who is it, that will not put the blame in the? Vertere, to translate* or
interpret out of one tunge into an another. Verrex, and vortex, ticis, a

heed. also the top of every thing. Vertibulum, idem quod vertebra.

fire. Vestales, were virg^ns, which mynistred to Vesta. Vester, tra, trum,
your. Vestiarium, a warderobe, wherein garments are laid. Vestiarius, the

V ANTE I.
VIa, a way, a, iourneye, the manner, or mean, custom. Viam munire, to make
or repair a way Viatica coena, a banquet given to a man at his departing.
Viaticor, aris, ari, to prepare vytayles necessary for iourneye. Viaticu^,
necessaries for journey, be it in vitaile or other thing, preparation for
journey. Viator, toris, a trauayler by the way, a way farynge man, which
warns men to assemble to counsel, and serves officers, to call men unto
them. Viatorius, a, um, pertaynyng to the way. Viatoria vasa, vessels which
do serve for iourneye. Vibex, bicis, a spotte remayninge in the skin after
beatynge. Vibratio, a brandyshynge. Vibrissae, hears in a man's nose. Vibrisso,
are, to quauer in singing. Vibro, brate, to shake a thing, or to make a
thing to shake or quauer. Viburnum, the spring which commethe out of the
root of a tree. Vicani, men of the vyllage. Vicarius, a, um, that which is in
the steed or place of an other. Also the servant of him, which is a
servant. Vicatim, in vyllages or streets. also street by street, or vyllage by
vyllage. Vice^, vice, plurali, uices, uicibus, time and times. p^multas inces,
multis uicibus, many times. Vnica uice, Horatius. Vergilius. Horatius.
ones. Sometime it sygnyfyeth pains. Also peril. sommetyme place or stead.
Fungar uice cotis, I will use it in the stead of a whetstone. Vicenarius, a, um,
the twentieth. Vicenus, a, um, twenty. Vicia, a certain grain, which like to
a vine, runs upon the stalks of herbs. which do grow hye. Viciarium, the
sowynge of such grain. Vicies, twenty times. Vicinia, the neyghbourheed,
which corruptely we call vicinetum. Vicinitas, tatis, nyghnesse. sometime the
multitude of neighbors. Vicinus, a neighbor. Vicissatim, by times, by
tournes. Vicissim, by turn, now one, now an another, sometime it sygnifyeth,
on the other part. sometime semblably. Vicissitas, idem quod vicissitudo.
Vicissitudo, dinis, the turn, now oone, now an another. Victima, the beast
that is killed in sacrifice. Victimarius, the mynister, which serves to the
sacrifice. Also he which boughte the sacrifice to selle it. Victito, tare, to
live by eating certain meat. Victor, toris, he that vanquysheth. Victoria,
vyctorie. Victoriatus, a certain coin, wherein was the image of vyctorie,
Victoriosus, accustomed to have vyctorye. Victricus, a fader in law, my moders
husband Victrix, plurali victricia, pertaining to victory. Victrix, a woman
that vanquysheth. Victurus, the participle of the future tense, as well of
Viuo, as of Vinco. Victus, tus, and victuis, sustinance or fedynge. Also a
kind or form of living. Victus, ta, tum, vanquyshed. Vicus, a street in a
town. also a vyllage. Viculus, a little street or vyllage. Videlicet, as who
says. sometime it signyfieth surely. Video, di, d^re, to see. It is sometime
applied to other senses, as, Vide qualis est sonus, Here what a noise it is.
Vide quid oleat, Smell whereof it sauoureth. Vide quam durum sit, Feel how
hard it is. Also it signyfieth to take heed or consider, to provide. Vide tibi
provide for thy self. Tu uideris, look thereto well, take good head, for I care
not for it. Videro, I will provide. Videor, I remember me well. Videre uideor,
me thinks I see. Videtur mihi, me seems. Viden, for Vides ne? do thou not
see? Vidua, a wydowe. Viduertas, calamytie or myserye. Viduitas, widowhed, lack
of things necessary Vidulum, wherein any thing is kept. Viduo, duare, to
dyuide or take away, to leave alone. Viduus, a, um, dyuyded, alone. Vie^na, a
cite in Austria, an other i^ Dolpheni Vieo, ere, to bend, to bind. Vietor,
toris, a couper, which with howpes byndeth vessels. Vietus, ta, tum, soft,
weak, bendynge. Vietus, a howpe, or struck of a carte. Vigeo, gui, gere, to
live, to be strong, to thryue in growing. Vigesimae, as decimae, Vigesimariu^
auru^, ide^. Liuius.
Vigesimus, ma, mum, the twentieth. Vigil, lis, watchful, vigilant. also a

vygilancy, dylygence. Vigiliae, watches, as well by day as by night. sometime the
men which do watch. Vide com.
Vigilo, lare, to wake, or watch, to be vigylant, or very dilygente. Also to
here diligently. ^^uenalis. Plautus in ^uden.
Also to take pain. Vigilare decet hominem, qui uult sua tempori conficere

for Continens. Vincibilis, le, easy to be vanquyshed. Vincio, vinxi, vincere,
to bind. Vide com. Vide com*
Vinco, vinxi, cere, to vanquyshe. Vinctus, ta, tum, bounden. sometime it
signifies a prisoner. Vinculum, and uinclum, a bond. also vincula pluraliter,
is taken for a prison. Vindelicia, a countray in Germany, wherein is the city
of Augusta, called Ausburgh. Vindemia, the time of gatherynge grapes to make

syder. Vindemialis, le, and vindemiatorius, a, u^, pertainyng to gatherynge of
grapes or fruit. Vindemiatio, a gatherynge of grapes, to make wine, also a
making of honey. Vindemiator, toris, he that does gather grapes to make wine.

to gather grapes or ripe fruit Vindex rerum capitaliu^, the mynister of

man's cause. Also he that delyuereth him self out of bondage. Vindiciae,
assercyon of liberty or fredome. Vindicias secundum libertatem dare, Ti.
Liuius lib. 3.
to put in pledges to prove him or her to be free and not bond. Vindico, care,

did bear in his hand. Vitis alba, an herb, which runs up in hedges, and
wyndeth about the settes, having a leaf like a vine leaf, but rougher and a red berye. It is called also Brionia, and in english Vitis nigra, a like
wiede, which commonly grows among herbs, and byndeth them together,
having a leaf in facyon like to yuy, and little tendrynges with knappes, and
is called of some men Vitisator, he that sells vynes. Vitisco, scere, to
spring unto a vine. Vitium, vice, contrary to virtue. Alsoo a faut or error.
also sycknes, an impediment. Terent. in ^ecyra.

another. Vituperones, rebukers. Viuacitas, and uiua^^a, among old writers
bodyly strength. Viuacissimus, most lively or strong of nature. Viuaciter,
strongely. Viuarium, a place, where wild beasts. birds, or fyshes be kept.
It may be called as well a ponde, as a park, a counnyngar, a walk for
birds. Viuatior, more lively. Viuatus, and viuidus, full of life or naturalle
strength. Viuax, nacis, lively, strong of nature. Viuere diem, to live
without any prouysion or stoore. Viuerra, a ferette. Viuidus, da, dum, lively,
quycke. Viuior, and viuissimus, old writers used for more living or most
living. Viuiradix, icis, a young vine set with the rote. Viuitur. Quid agitur?
T. Viuitur, How is the mattier? T. I live as well as I may. Viuo, uixi, viuere,

epistola Penelopes.
toraque Troia fuit, King Priamus and all Troy was not so much worth. Vix,
with much a do. Si idem istuc imitamur, ita tamenuix viuimus, Although we do
the like. yet with much a do we live.

VMbella, a lyttel shadow. also a skrine to keep away the light of the son.
Vmber, of the country of Vmbria. Vmbilicatim, in the facyon of a nauyll.
Vmbilicatus, ta, tu^, made like a nauill. Vmbilicus, the mids of every thing.
also the nauyll. also a lyttelle cerkle made in the ground, to know which
way the wind stands. Also it is a little smothe stone, or pyppell stone, a
bose, such as is set on the back of a book. Ad umbilicu^ adducere, to
bring to a point. Vmbo, bonis, the bose of a buckler or shield Vmbra, a
shadow. It was also that, which was callid a ghost of a man being deed, which
not only paynims but also christen men supposed did appear visibly unto me^.
Vmbraculum, a place, where men moughte be out of the son, or that which made
shadow. Vmbraticus, ca, cum, like a shadow. Vmbraticus homo, a man living at
ease, and out of all labor or business. Vmbraticae arts, crafts exercysed
in the shadow, as the more part of handy crafts. Vmbratilis, le, that which is
done in the shadow, or as it were with ease, and without any sweat or pain.
Vmbratiles res, tryflyng things or trifles. Vmbratilis pugna, exercyses of
feats of war out of battle as in a house. Vmbria, a part of Italy.
Vmbrifer, fera, ferum, making shadow, as a greatte wodde does. Vmbrina, and
vmbra, a fysshe, which by the description of* Paulus Iouiue, seems to me to
be an halybut, for the greattenesse and delycacie of the heed, and similitude
to a sturgion. Vmbro, brare, to shadow. Vmbrosus, a, um, having much
shadow. Vmbro, bronis, a river in Lumbardye, called also Lamber.

VNa, together. Vna cum Cicerone, together with Cicero. Vnanims, and vnanimus,
of one mind and will. Vnanimus consensus, one hole consent. Vnanimitas,
tatis, concord. Vncia, an ounce. also an ynche. Vnciarius, a, um, of an ounce.

that lies by the back and the rybbes, which husbands use to roll up, and
keep for to make saulues, or else to fry meat, as fritowes and pancakes.

do. Vndegentiu^, idem Vndecim, eleven. Vndecimus, ma, mum, the eleventh.

Vngues arrodere, to gnawe on his nails, a proverb applied to them, which are
in a study, how they may alter such things as they do repent them of.
Vnguis, a nail of the fyngars or toes. it is also a disease which at length
covers all the eye with flesh in the corner of the eye. Vnguicula, a little
soft nail. A teneris vnguiculis, from his tender youth or infancye. Vngula,
a house of a horse or other beast. Omnibus vngulis, with all might and powar.
Vngulatus, he that has foul great nails. Vngulum, of old writers was taken
for a ring. Cato. Non. Mar.
Vngularius, a great nail and ragged. Vngustus, a crooked staff, or such as
commonly men do call a croke, wherewith they draw to them any thing. Vnicalamum
frumentum, wheat, which has but one read growing out of the rote. Vnicallis,
