V ANTE O.
VOberca, a town by Bilbo in Spain. Vocabulum, the denomination of any thing.
Vocalis, le, loud, als that which has a voice, also a vowell. Vocalitas, a
tune or sound of a voice. Vocatio, a calling. Vocator, a caller. Vociferatio,
a cryenge out. Vociferator, he that cries out. Vociferor, aris, ari, to cry
out, to cry loud. Vocifero, idem. Vocito, to call often. Voco, care, to call,
to bid, to ask. Voconia, a kind of pears. Vocula, a little voice, sometime
obloquie. Voculatio, an accent in speech. Vola, the mids of the hand or the
foot. It is taken for the soole of the foot. Volaticus, ca, cum, that which
flies or goth away suddenly, flittinge. Volatilis, le, that which can fly.
Volatus, and volatura, a flight. Volema, a great pear, a wardyn. Volens,
willing. Volenter, wyllyngly. Volentia, will. Volito, tare, to fly often.
Vide com.
Volo, are, to fly, to run or go quycklye, or fast. Volo, uis, nolui, uelle,
to will. Volo tuam gratiam, I desire your favor. Volo te, I would speak with
the. Volones, were bondemen at Rome, which in the wars of Cartage when there
lacked Romans, offered them selfs to fight for their masters, and because they
did it willyngly without constraynt or called, therefore they were called
Volones. Volsella, an instrument to pluck hears from the body or face. Volua,
for Vulua. Volubilis, le, that which is easyly turned. Volucer, cri, swift,
light Volucra, a beast which eats the tender vines. Volueres, birds,
fowls. Volucrior, more swyfte. Voluctis, ere, all thing that does fly.
Volucrum, the after birth in a woman. Volumen, minis, a book: sometime part
of a book, called a volume. Voluntas, tatis, will. Voluntarius, a, um,
voluntary, willing. Voluo, uere, to wrappe, to turn. Voluox, and Voluola,
idem quod Conuoluolus, a little wurme with many legs, which eats the leuys
of vynes, and of other trees. Volup, for Voluptas. Volupe, delectable. Volupia,
and voluptia, goddess of voluptie or delectation. Voluptabilis, le, that which
rejoices. Sal. in Ca.
Voluptaria loca, placis of pleasure. Voluptas, tatis, an inordinate reioycinge
or delectation in things worldly, or carnal. Voluptuarius, and voluptarius,
he that is given to carnal delectation. Voluptuosus, a, um, voluptuouse,
insatiable in carnal pleasure or delectation. Volutabru^, a place where swyne
do walow. Volutabundus, walowynge, tournynge, tossynge in the mind. Volutatim,
an aduerbe signifienge, eftsoon tossinge in the mind. Voluto, tare, to turn
lyinge, to walow, to reuolue and toss in the mind. Vomer, meris, the culter
of a plowghe. Vomica, a rotten impostume, wherout runs matter. Vomitus,
vomit. Vomitio, idem. Vomo, mui, mere, to vomyte or parbrake. Vide com.
Vopiscus, where two children are conceived, and one of them is abort, he that
comes to perfyte birth is called Vopiscus. it was also the name of one that
wrate the lives of Emperors. Festus.
Vopte, for Vosipsi. Voraciter, like a glutton. Vorago, ginis, a swolowe or
gulf. Voro, rare, to swolowe down meat ere it be chewyd. also to eat
gredily. Vorax, racis, a glutton. Voracitas, gluttony. Vorsura, for versura.
Vorsura^ soluere, a proverb applied to them that so discharge them selves of
one business, that they enter into another more paynefull or dangerouse.
Vortex, for vertex. Vortu^nalia, a solemn feast to the god Vortumnus. Vos,
you. Votiuus, ua, um, that which is vowed. also desired. Votiua verba, votiuae
praeces, words and prayers, wherein we desire somewhat. Votum, a vow, sometime
a desire. Votiuae aures, ears which desire to here. Votitum, old wrytars
used for Vetitum. Voto, and Votito, to make auowe. Voti compos, he that has
that which he desired. Voueo, ui, uere, to vow, or make auowe. Vide com
Vox, uocis, a voice. Voce assa, with the voice only of a man without any
instrument of musyke.
V, ANTE P.
Vpupa, a lapwynk or black plouer.
V, ANTE R.
Urania, one of the Musis, which is president of Astronomy. Vragus, of old
writars was used for Orcus, death. Vrbanatim, and vrbane, like a gentyl manne,
courteysely, gratiousely. Vrbanicani milites, souldyours of the city.
Vrbanitas, courtesye, good manner, gentilnesse in speech, ciuilitye. Vrbanus, a,
um, civil, courtaise, gentle in speech and gesture. Vrbicula, a little city.
Vrbicus, ca, cum, of the city. Vrbo, are, to cast a mere with a plough. Vrbs,
bis, a wallyd town. also a city. Vrceolaris, an herb which is called
Pelitory of the wall. Vrceolus, a little water pitchar. Vrceus, a pytcher pot,
wherein water is carried. Vredo, dinis, the fault in corn or trees, when they
are blastyd. it signifies also an yche and burning in the skin. Vergilius
Georg.
Vrgeo, ursi, urgere, to provoke, to haste forth. sometime to cover. Vriculum,
any thing that is holow. Vri, wild beastis like oxen, called Bugles or
buffes. Vrina, vryne or piss. Lucanus Verg.
Vrere, is also to byte as froste does the grass. Ter. in Eu.
Vro hominem. Non malum hercle. G. vro hominem. P. vt falsus animi est. It is
no harm. G. I have given him a corsy. P. Se how falsharted he is. Vrere, to
tourment or vex. Plautus in Most.
Vrito, tare, to burn sore or fervently. Vropigium, is the lowest and narowest
part of the chyne next to the fundement. Vrsulus, and vrsellus, a little or
young bear. Vruat, Ennius used for Circundat. Vruare, is also to draw a
furrowe with a plowgh about a place. Vruum, a plowghe beam, or crooked part
of a plowghe. Vrinum, an adell egg. Vrino, are, and Vrinor, ari, to dyue under
the water. Vrinator, toris, a dyuar. Leo. Por. and Men.
Vrna, a waterpot: it is proprely a vessel, which contains as much water as
does way fourtye pound waighte: and two of them do make Amphoram. Vrnarium, a
bourde whereon pottes where set. Vrnula, a little pot. Vro, ussi, urere, to
burn, to be turmented, or vexed. Vror, reris, uri, to be bourned. Vrsa, two
figures of sterres, the one called Vrsa mayor, and the other Vrsa minor. Vrsus,
a bear. Vrsa, a she bear. Vrsinus, na, um, of a bear. Vrtica, a nettyl.
also a fisshe, which as Paulus Iouius writes, is of the quantity of a
wallnutte, and the keuerynge of him is between a shell and a hard skin, and
is somewhat read, and the fysshe of him is hard.
V, ANTE S.
VSia for essentia. Vsitatio, an usage. Vsitor, taris, tari, to use often.
Vspiam, in any place, to some place, any where. Vsquam, any where, in any wise
or manner. Vsque gentium, any where. Vsque, until, well nygh, diligently,
continuelly, so long, allwaye. Vsque dum, until. Vsque adeo, as long. Vsque
eo, in so much. Vsquequaque, all about, every where, allwaye. Vsquequo,
until when, or what. Vstrigo, ginis, blast of corn. Vstrina, the meltinge
house, or place where metal is molten or het. Vstulo, are, to burn or sere a
thing. Vstus, ta, tum, bourned. Vsucapio, and Vsucaptio, a possession by
prescription of a long time. Vsuarius, he that is in possession, the pernour of
the profytes, the occupyar. Vsura, the occupation. Vsurarius, a, um, that which
is occupied. Leo. Port. de Pond.
Vsura semissium, where they give six for the yearly lone of one hundred, As
if I borowe of one a hundred pounds, and pay to him every month ten
shillynges, during the time of the lone: this yeldeth every year.vi. lb. for
the hundred. Vsurpo, pare, to usurp, to use often and much. Vsus, us, use,
sometime the occupation or exercise of a thing, also profit or fruit.
Vsurpatio, an usurping or usurpation. Vsus fructus, the use of an other man's
goods by the consent of the owner, the substance of the thing being saved.
Vsuuenit, it happens often.
V, ANTE T.
VT, as, that, as soon, how, like as, would to god, how much, all be it,
sometime for quippe and i^a, lest not. Caes. in c^.
Vt satis commode supportari posset, uaereri dicebant, They said, that they
feared, that it mowght not be. Vt, as well as. Vt uales? R. vt queo, Plautus in
Persa.
How farest thou? R. as well as I may. Vt, behold how. Vt saepe summa
ingenia in occulto latent, Behold how that most exellent wits do lie hyd in
a corner. Vt, admit it, or set the case, or put the case. Legem illam appellare
fas non est, Ci. in Phs.
and ut sit lex, non debemus illam Hircij legem putare, It is not convenient,
that we call it a law, and admit that it be a law, we should not yet suppose
it to be Hircius law. Etenim vt circumspiciamus omnia, quae populo grata,
arque iucunda sunt: nihil tam populare quam pacem, quam concordiam, quam otium
reperiemus, for put the case that we might se perfitely all things that were
plesaunte and delectable unto the people, we should nothing find, that they
so much desire, as peace, as concord, as vacacion from labor. Te. in Ad.
Vt est dementia, Se the man's folly. Vt istum dij deaeque perdant, I beseech god
and all halowes send him a myschief. Ci. in Bru.
Vt, for postquam. Nam vt illos de Republica libros edidisti, nihil a te sane
postea accepimus, for sense ye set forth your books of the weal public, I
never after received any thing from you. Pli. in ^^i.
Vt in limme auditur, he was as well herd, as if he had been within. Plautus
in poena.
Vt, so that. Olent, salsa sunt, tangere vt non velis, They be so salt and
stinkinge, that thou will wish, that thou had not touched them. Plautus in
(...).
Vt, se that. Operam vt det, See that he do his endeavor. Vt ad pauta redeam,
To make a short tale. Vt ne addam, To be short. Vtcunque, In what manner or
facyon. Sed nostrum est intelligere, v^cunque, and vbicunque opus e^t obsequi.
But it is our part to know, in what facyon, and where soever we shall give
our attendaunce. Vtcunque, how so ever. ^
Vtcunque erit, how so ever it shall happen. Vten^ile, necessary to be used.
Vter, tris, a botell. Vter, teri, a womb, a bealy. Vterum gerere, to be great
with child. Vter, tra, trum, which of the two. Pli^.
Vter alteri dixerit nescio, which of them told it to the the other, I can not
tell. Cicer. pro Milo.
Vter vtri insidias fecerit, which of them laid awayte for the the other.
Terentius in Phorm.
Vterque utrique est cord^, They do like well the one the other. Vterque alterum
uerberauit, the tone beete the the other, each did beat other. Vterculus, a little
bealy. Vterlibet, which ye will. Vterque, both, the one and the other.
Vteruis, which of them thou will. Vti, for vt. Vtica, a city in Affrike, where
Cato did sle him self, and therefore was afterward called Cato Vticensis.
Plautus in Trinu^mo. Plautus in Mercator. Plautus in Aul.
Vtibilis, le, for vtilis, profitable. Vtibilitas, for vtilitas, profit. Vti,
sometime sygnifyeth to have. Et te vtar iniquiore, and men's me ordo irrideat,
that I may have the, the warse toward me, and that my company may mock me.
Ter. in (...)
Mihi si vnquam silius erit, vt ille facili me vtetur patre, It ever I have a
son, he shall have me a gentle father. Vti amore, to love. Vti amicitia, to
sauoure, or be in amytye. Plaut. in Asi.
Vti eadem disciplina, to be of the same learning. Vti oculis, to see
perfytely, or well. Maris caussa hercle hoc ego oculo vtor minime, Plautus in
Mili.
In good faith the se makes that I se not well with this eye, or I se not a
whit with this eye. Vti officio, to do the office or part. Vtilis, le,
profitable, convenient. Vtilitas, profit. Vtiliter, profytably. Vtinam, would
to god. Vtique, like as, verily. Vti valitudine, to be in health. Plin.
Vti foro, to take the market as it comes, a proverb applied to them, which
can take the state of every time and chance, as it comes. also it may
signify, to apply him self to the facions and conditions present. Vtor, teris,
ti, to use, to be conuersaunt with one, to occupye. Vtere vt vis mea opera,
Plautus i^ Per. Plautus i^ Aul.
Take my service at your commandment. Da mihi operam amabo. M. tua est,
vtere, atque impera si quid uis, A good fellowship lend me thy help. M. It is
redye for the, have here, command what thou will. Vtpote, because that he
was, as. Vt puta, for quemadmodum, as. Vtquid, for quamobrem, for what cause,
wherefore. Vtraque, by both places, by the tone place and the the other.
Vtricularius, he that pypeth in a botell. Vtriculus, the place in a woman
wherein the child lies. Vtrinque, of the one part and the other, Plautus in
Amphitri
of the one and the other. Vtris, a skin blown full of wind, also a ball filled
only with wind. Vtrobique, in the one place and the other, Plautus in Mili.
on the one side and the other. Vtroque, to the one place and the other. Vtroque
versum, on both parts, on the one part and the other, on every part. Vtrum,
whyther. Vtut, how so ever it be, in what facyon. Haec adeo mea culpa fateor
fieri, non me hanc re^ patri, vtut erat gesta, indicasse, I confess, all this
happened by my defaulte, that I showed not to my father the matter, in what
facyon it was done.
V ANTE V.
VVa, a grape, it is alsoo that, which is in the roufe of a man's mouth,
which sometime will swelle, and is also called Vuula. It is alsoo a swarm of
bees hanging round. Vua passa, a greatte reason. Vueu^, a, um, of a grape.
Vueus succus, wine. Vuidus, da, dum, moist. Vulcanus, called Iupyters smythe.
Also it is taken for fire. Vulcanius, a, um, of Vulcane. Vulga, a skryppe or
sachelle, sommetyme a womannes bealy. Vulgaris, re, commune, much used. Non.
Mar.
Vulgaria, for vulgaris. Vulgatus, ta, tu^, commonly known or used. Vulgo,
abroad among all men. Vulgo conceptus, whose father is not certain. Vide com.
Vulgo, gare, to publyshe, to manyfeste, to make commune. Vulgus, uulgi, the
common people. Vulnerarius, a surgeon. Vulnerarius, a, um, belonging to
wou^des. Vulnero, rare, to wound. Vulnus, a wound, sometime grief. Vulpes, a
Fox. Vulpecula, a cubbe or a young fox. Vulpinus, na, number, of a fox.
sometime subtle and crafty. Vulpinor, naris, nari, to be wyly. Vulsinus, a
river in Italye. Vulsinienses, people dwelling about the river of Vulsinus.
Vultorij, certain dyse. Vultuosus, sa, sum, heuye, sorowfulle of countenance.
Vultuose, dysdaynfully, heuyly, with frowning countenance, with gesture
agreeable unto the matter. Vultur, turis, and vulturius, a rauyn. Vulturinus,
na, number, of a rauyn. Vulturnum, a town in Campania. Vulturnus, the northeaste
wind. Vulta, Lucretius used for the plurell number of Vultus. Vulticulus, a
little vysage. Vultus, of old writers is taken for will, a Volendo. Vultus,
vultus, and vultum, countynaunce or ch^ere. Vulua, the womb or mother of any
female kind. It is alsoo a meat vsyd of the Romans, made of the bealye of a
sow, either that has farowed, or is greatte with farowe.
V ANTE X.
VXor, vxoris, a wife. Vxorius, he that doteth on his wife. Vxorius, a, um, of
the wife.
X ANTE A.
XANTHA, a nymphe. Xanthij, a people in Asia whose city being besieged of the
captain of Cirus, they brought into the castelles their wives, servants, and
goods, and putting thereunto fire, bourned all together, and afterward
issuinge out of the city, faught until that they were all slain. Xanthicus,
among the Jews was the month of Aprylle. Xanthus, a, um, yelowe. Xanthus, a
river of Troy, callid also Scama^der, also a city in Licia, also He^tors
horse. Xantippe, the wife of Socrates the philosopher.
X ANTE E.
XEnia, prese^tis sent by one to an other. Xeniolum, a small present.
Xenodochium, an hospytall. Xenocrates, a philosopher discipleto Plato.
Xenophon, a philosopher, which as well in marcial acts, as in eloquence
excellyd. Xerampellinae uestes, Probus.
garments of a color, which I suppose is called Murrey. Sum do suppose it
to be black garments. Calepinus
Xeria, dry playsters. Xerophagia, eating of dry meats. Xerophthalmia,
when the eyes be soore without droppynge or swellynge. Xerxes, a king of
Persia.
X ANTE Y.
XYlinae uestes, garments of cotton. Xyloaloes, a sweet and precious wod
callid Lignu^ aloes, our women having beads made thereof called it Acellula.
Xylobalsamus, the wodde whereof baulme natural comes. Xylophagus, a worm
breding in old wode, which is white and great belyed, and has a black heed.
Xilon, cotton. Xiphiae, certain blasynge sterres, which have beams like to a
sword. Xisticus, he that exercyseth him self in a place covered out of the
son or rain. Xyphius, a fyshe named a sword fyshe, which has in his nose
a bone, like to the sea berde of a sword, such one have I seen. Xystus, et
Xystum, a place, wherein men do exercise wrastlynge and other like pastyme in
winter. It may be taken for a galerye or place to walk in out of the rayn.
Z ANTE A.
ZACANTHEI, people in the mountains called Pyrenei, by the river of Hiberus.
Zacharias, the name of a prophet. Also the father of sayncte Johan Baptiste.
Zacynthii, people of the isle of Zacynthus. Zacynthos, an ylande in the sea
called Ionia, wherein is a city of the same name. Zagrus, a mountain, which
divides Media from Babilonia. Zancle, a city in Grecia, an other in Sicile.
Zaphyrus, a fyshe of the kind of gylt hedes but that he is somewhat blewe in
color. Zathene, a stone like to aumber, now black, now yelowe.
Z ANTE E.
ZEa, a kind of wheat. Zelo, are, and zelor, lari, for ae mulari. Zelor,
zelaris, ari, to be angrye, or to have zeal. Zelotes, for aemulator, he that
has envy at one, or assayeth to follow an another in living. Zelotypia,
ialowsye. Zelotypus, ialowse. Zelus, sometime envy, sometime love, some time
emulation. Zenobia, a queen of Siria, which in greek and latyne was very well
learned, and was also valyant in arms. Zephyrus, the weste wind. Zeros, a
kind of crystal, which has spots white and black. Zera, and zetecula,
a place made in a chaumber, wherein was a bed and three stoles, which with
courtaynes was so divided from the chaumber, that sometime it was part thereof,
sometime it was separate from it, and it had three wyndowes or lowpes, by the
which the son might enter into it. Zeugma, a figure, whereby many senses ^r
joined together with one verb, as, Neque is es Catilina, ut te, aut pudor a
turpitudine, aut metus a periculo, aut ratio a furore reuocarit, Ne thou art
such a man Catilyne, as either shamefastness can withdraw from
dishonestie, or fear from danger, or reason from vengeable anger. Zeusis, an
excellent paynter, which so painted a boy caryeng grapes, that birds came to
the table and pecked on the grapes, wenynge that they had been very grapes,
which Zeusis, beholdynge, was with him self angrye, and said, If I had made
the boy, as well as I have done the grapis, the birdis durst not have come so
nygh to the grapes. Zeus, a fysshe taken about Calys in Spain, which is
black, but he is very delicate.
Z ANTE I.
Zigena, a fysshe of the sea. Zigari, people, which we do call Egyptians,
that wander about in every royalme and be horrible thieves. Zigarum, the contray
from whens the said people do come. Zizania, cockle, which grows in corn.
Zinziber, gynger.
Z ANTE O.
ZOdiacus, a cerkle in heaven, wherein be the.xii. signs. Zographia, the
pycture of beasts. Zoilus, was a poet, which enuyed Homerus, and therefore
the enuiers of well learned men are called Zoili. Zoelicum, certain flax,
that comes out of Spain, whereof threde is made for nets to take birds.
Zomos, gruelle. Zona, a gyrdell. Zonatim, in compass about. Non. Mar.
Zopissa, pitche taken from ships, which being tempred with wax and salt,
is of more efficacy than other pytche. Zopyron, an herb, which some do
suppose to be Puly ol mountain. Zopyrus, was a man, which by phisnomye knew
every ma^s co^dicions. And wha^ in beholding Socrates he judged him to be
unthrifty, and therefore was scorned of many me^* Socrates answered, Zopyrus is
not deceived, for in deed I had been such one as he says, if I had not by
philosophy subduid nature. Also Zopirus was a noble Persian, servant to Darius,
which when the city of Babylon rebellid against king Darius, and that he had
madelong war, and could not subdue the^, unawares to any man, did cut of his
own nose, and wounded him self, and fled to Babylon, saying, the king had so
disfygured him, because that he persuaded him to have peace with the
Babylonians, which they heryng, made him their chief captain. Than by
little and little declaryng to them the strength of the king, and how they
might not endure long against him, at the last he caused them to submit
them selves to the king, and to receive him into the city. Wherefore Darius
was wont to say, that he had leauer have one Zopyrus, than twenty Babylons.
Zoroanda, a river, which the great water of Tigris makes on the one side of
the mountain Taurus. Zoroastes, the first fynder of Magike.
Z ANTE V.
Zura, bearies of white thorn. Zygia, a pype, wherein men did play at
weddynges. Zithus, drink made with barley sodden. It may be taken for ale or
biere.
Finis Dictionarii.
THE ADDICION OF SIR THOMAS ELIOT KNIGHT unto his Dictionarye.
A ANTE B.
Varre.
ABAGIO, gere, to fetch a compass in speaking, and not to consist or abide in
one oration or sentence. Abalienatio, alienation. Abalienator, he that does
aliene or put away a thing, or alters the possession thereof, an alienour.
Abanec, a gyrdel, which priests did wear, wrought with colors of scarlet and
purple, in such wise that there seemed to be in it flowers and precious stones
set in order. Abania, is interpreted the father, unto god acceptable, or
gratifienge unto god. Abarceo, cui, cere, to prohybyte or put of. Abauia, my
great grandames mother. Abbreuio, are, to abbreuiate or make short. Abbatia,
the dignity of an abbotte. Sometime the monastery. Abdicatio, a renou^cing of
one whom I take for mine heir, Cic. in Pisonem. and ad At.
a puttyng out of favor. Abdidit se domum, he kept him at home. Abdere se ex
conspectu heri, to keep him away that his master see him not. Abdere se
literis, to live unknown in continual study. Abducere clauem, to take the
kaye out of the door. Abecedarius, he that sets any thing in order by
letter. Abedo, dear, to consume. Aberuncare iram deorum, to withdraw the
vengeance of god with prayers. Aberuncasso, sere, to turn up. Cicero.
Abhorreo ab urbe relinquenda, I have no mind to forsake the city. Abhorret
ab illo mea sententia, mine opynion is contrary to his. Abhorret a suspitione,
it is contrary to my supposalle. Abhorret a charitate uulgi, he tendreth not,
Cicero de Amic. Plautus in cistell.
or passes nothing on the poor people. Abhorret hilaritudo, thy myrthe is
turned into sadness. Abhortatio, a contrary advise. Abhortor, tari, to give
contrary advise. Abi in malam rem, go hens with a mischefe. Plautus in Mercator.
Abibitur, I or he will depart or go away. Abiectus, a vile person. Abiegnus,
na, number, of fur tree. Abigena bos, was among the diuinours, Varro.
callid Augures, the ox, which was to be sacrifised, about whom the other
beasts to be sacrifised, were set. Plautus in Asinar.
Abigere ex aedibus, to drive out of the doors Abijcio, cere, to pour out.
sommetyme to give away. Abijcior, ci, to be out of reputation. Abijt hora, the
time passed. Abijt sol, the son is gone down. Terent. in Eunucho. Plautus.
Abitus, tu, a departing. Abyla, a mountain in the se against Spain in
africa, callid one of the pillars of Hercules Ab incunablis, from his infancy.
Ab ineunti aetate, from his chyldehode. Abitio, a departure or going away, old
writers took it for death, as we may call it, the decesse of one. Abiudicare a
uita, Plautus in Asina.
to put to death. Abiudicabit nunquam ab suo triobolum, He will never be of
the mind to give three half pens of his own. Abiuratio, a forswearynge, an
abiuration. Ablectae aedes, nete fair and pleasant houses. Abludo, lusi,
ludere, to speak of a thing covertly, that other shall not epsy what the
matter does mean. Ablutio, a washing. Abluuium, a universal floudde,
wherewith a countray is drowned. Abneco, care, to strangle. Abneptis, a daughter
in the fourth descent. Abnormis, out of rule. Abolitus, ta, tum, rased out,
put out of remembrance. Festus.
Aboloes, old writers used for ab illis. Abominalis, le, abhomynable. Abortor,
and aborto, idem quod abortio. Abraham, the name of a patriarche, signifienge
father of many nations. Abradere de bonis, to polle or spoil a man of his
goods. Abripuit repent sese, he went away sodeinly Abrogare fidem, to bring
out of credence. Abrogatio, the dissoluynge or repellynge of a law. Abrupta
loca, rocks and hills here and there broken or dygged, so that one may vnethe
go or crepe up to them. Abruptum, that which has such a fall or s^epenesse
down, that no man may pass by it, ^
but only fall down. Ab^te ^^at, it stands upon the, or it lies in the.
Abs qui^^s homine, of every man what so ever he be. ^
Abscissus, a, um, broken, sharp. Abscissior iustu i^, sharp justice.
Absconsus, a, um, hid. Absolue^e vno uerbo, to tell at a word, to make an
end shortly. Liuius. 2.
Absoluere suspitione, to discharge or put of all suspicion. Plautus in capt.
in Amphitri.
Absoluere, to depeche of business. Absolute, perfytly. Absolutio, a
discharge, or depeche. Absolutus, ta, tum, discharged, depeched. Absonum fidei,
not credible. Absonus uoce, he yt has an untunable voice Abstergeo, si, gere,
to wype, to wipe away. Absterrere, to fear away, or drive away with fear.
Plautus in Mili. Plautus in Ruden.
Abstinenter, with abstinence. Abstinere inco^moditate, to behave him honestly.
Abstinere manum, to hold his hand. Abstineas me manum, take heed that thou
stryke me not. Sueton. in Clau. Pli. in epi.
Abstinuit diu publico, it was long or he came abroad. Abstinere uerbis, to
take heed, what he speaks. Abstinens alieni, he that medleth not with other
men's goods. Abstraxi me illinc, I gatte me thens. Abstractum, taken by
force. Abstrudere colaphos, to buffet or give blows. Abstrusus, a, um, hid
or shut up. Abest mihi animus, I have no courage. Absit uerbo inuidia, a
form of speking wha^ one would not be suspected of arroga^ce in some thing
that he will speak. Absente nobis, while I was away. Absento, tare, to keep
from a place, or cause to be absente. Plaut. in Mostel.
Absumpti sumus, we are undone. Absumedo, dinis, dispense, waste of money or
other like thing. Absumptio, a wasting, waste. Absurd, without purpose or
reason, to no purpose. Absynthium marinu^, wormefede. Absynthium santonicum,
may seem to be Lauander cotton. Abundanter, abundantely. Abunde est, it is
enough. Abundans, a rich manne. Abundare ingenio, to have a great wit.
Abuerto, tere, to turn from a place. Abusque mane ad uesperam, from the
morning to night. Ambustus, ta, tum, bourned up. Abusum, worn out. Abusus,
us, and abusio, abuse, ill use. Abutor, ti, to wear out. Terentius in Prolog^
Andri.
Abutitur operam, he lost his labor. Abydeus, a man borne in the i will of
Abydos.
A ANTE C.
ACananthide, the old name of the isle of Cypres. Acanthus, is an herb
commonly callid Brankursyn. Look before in Acanthis. Acapis, a river in Asia.
Acarpos, vnfruytefull. Acasta, a nymphe. Acar, and Acarus, a little worm that
breeds in wax. Acatia, a thorn growing in Egypt, whereof comes a gum.
which is medycynable for many diseases. Acatium, a boat. Accede adiutare, come
help me. Plautus in Truculen.
Accedit huc, more over than that. Accedere obui^am, to mete with one. Accedere
periculum, Plautus in Epidic.
to take on him the daungiere. Accedere alicui, to grant to an other, to be of
an other man's opinion. Accelerare gradum, to go apace. Acceleratio, haaste or
speed. Accento, tare, to sing often. Accessio, an augmentacyon, increase. Also
a coming. Accessio morbi, the beginning of a syckenesse. Accersio, sire, to
send or call for one. Accersitus, ta, tum, called for. Accersi iube filiam,
command thy daughter to be sent for, or called for. Liuius.
Accido cidere, to extenuate or make feeble, to destroy. Accisus, a, um, made
feeble, decayed. Accidit, there happened, it is chanced. Acecinere, to sing to
an instrument, or to sing a part, as a treble to a tenoure, or a descant to a
plain song. Accipenser, a fyshe having the skales turned forewarde, contrary
to other fysshes. which in the old time was of most estimation at the tables of
kings and princis. Plautus in casina. Ci. Tyro.
Accipere auribus, to here. Accipere causam, to hold excused. Accipere clade^.
to have great loss in bataile. Accipere cord, to perceive well. Pol haud
satis meo cord accepi querelas tuas, in good faith I do not well perceive the
cause of thy grief. Accipere conditionem, to take the offer. Cicero de Amic.
Accipere dolore^, to take thought, to be heavy Accipere nomen, to take
accounte. Accipere potesiatem, to have leave. Accipere uulnus, to be wounded.
Acceptus, received, entertained. Acceptus, ta, tum, accepted, acceptable.
Accepti and expensi ratio, account of receites and expenses. Accipiter
humipera, a sparhawke. Accipiter hierax, an hawke callid a sakre. Accipiter
pecuniarum, a poller of people. Accipitiarius, a faulconer. Accliuitas, a
raysynge up of a hylle. Accommodatus, ta, tum, applied to a thing besemyng,
couenable. Accommodus, da, du^, apt, mete, convenient. Accreduo, duis, duere,
idem quod accredo. Accubatio, a sitting at the table. Accubitores, they that
sytte at the table. Accumbere alicui, to sit by one at the table. Plautus in
Trucu.
Accurare, to do a thing dylygently. Accurare prandium, to make ready the
diner. Accurata malitia, malice prepensed. Accuratum habere, to prepense.
Accusatio, an accusement. Accusatorius liber, a bylle of complaynt. Accusare,
to blame. Accusabilis, le, worthy to be blamed. Accusator, an accuser, a
rebuker. Accusatrix, a woman rebuker. Acedaria, salettes or meat lightly
p^pared. Acri ingenio, quycke wytted. Acer equus, a swyfte horse. Acerrimi
inimici, mortal ennemies. Acer morbus, a grievous syckenes. Acres oculi, clear
eyes. Acerrima uxor, a very shrewde wife. Acere, a city by Naples. Aceratum,
mortar, or claye myxte with hey or straw, wherewith walls are daubyd. Acerbe,
bitterly, vnripely, cruelly, vehemently. Acero, rare, to myxte with chafe.
Acernus, na, number, of the tree called Acer. Acerra, a ship, wherein
frankyncense is put. some do name it an altar, which was set before a deed
corpse, whereon incense was burned. Some call it a cup, wherein they did
sacrifyce wine. Acerosus panis, brown bredde not ranged. Acesinus, a great
river in Persia, which runs into the river of Indus, wherein do grow canes
of such greatness, that they do make between every knotte or joint thereof,
botes to row in. Acesis, an herb, which is yelow in color. Acestis, a great
river in India. Acerabulum, a measure contayninge in it of water measure, two
ounces. Acetositas, a^grenesse or sowrenes. Acetofus, a, um, eygre, sour.
Acetum in pectore. Nunc experiar, sit ne acetum tibi cor acre in pectore, How
will I prove, if thou haste any thing that does prycke the in the stomach.
Aceum, a city in Colchis, on the bank of the river called Phasis. Achantia, a
fyshe, which some men do suppose to be thornebacke. Achar, a city in Siria,
now called Nisibis. Acha^eon, the main sail of a ship. Achelous, a river
in Grecia, so named of a king of that name. Acheloeus, of that river.
sommetyme it is put for aqueus. Achemenia, a countray in Persia. Acherontinus,
and Acherontius, of the river of Acheron. Acherusia, a fenne in the realm of
Naples. Achilleias, a kind of barley, peradventure that which is called bear
corn. Achilleon, some do suppose to be mylfoyle. Achras, a wild pear.
Achylus, without lyppes. Aciale, hard iron. Acidalia, a name of Venus, of a
fou^tayn in a city of Boeotia, called orchomenae. Acidylus, a knotte in the
gyrdell of Venus. Aciem trahere, to set in edge. Acies animi, the capacity
of a man's wit. Acinaceus, a, um, full of kernels. Aciritani, were a people in
Spain. Acis, a river in Sycil, which comes from the mountain of Aethna.
Acitia, an Island called also Melos in the sea by Candye. Acilon, the bearye of
holy. Aclassis, a garment unsown from the shulders Acon, aconis, a fyshe,
which after the description of Paulus Ioutus, I suppose to be that, which at
London is callid a shad. Acopus, an herb called also Anagyris, full of
branches, and has flowers like to colewortes, and has an ylle sauoure, the
sede thereof is in long coddes, hard and like in facion to kydneys. Acorus, an
herb with long leaves, like the blade of a sword. I suppose it be that,
which is called Gladwen or Gladen. Acratismus, and acratisma, a breakefast.
Acris, a river of Italye. Acrodria, be all fruits, which have an hard rynde or
shale, as pomegranades, nuttes, chestyns, pistaces, and other like. Acre,
swyft, sour, cruel, valiant, vehement, dyligent, circumspecte. Acritas,
sowrenesse, cruelty, dilygence. Acriter, swiftly, cruelly, vehemently,
diligently Acrisius, king of Argiues, the father of ^anaes, on whom Jupiter
begat Perseus. Acroama, a subtyle sentence, which requires an exquysite study
to perceive. Acroamata, were certain lectures of Aristotle, which he radde to
his scholars, wherein was the most subtylle and counnynge part of philosophy.
Acroecraunia, mountains of wonderfulle heyght, between Armenia and Hiberia.
Acrocomus, one having long hear. Acrocorinthus, an high mountain in Morea,
between the two sees Aegeu^ and Ioniu^. Acropolis, a castle set on a hylle.
Act, an elder tree. Action, the bearye of an elder. Acteus, a, um, of Athenes.
Actia, orum, plays made ones in five years. Actitatus, ta, tum, determined by
judgment. Actitatio, a debatynge of a case in law, or pleedynge. Actius, a
noble poet that wrate tragedies. Actiuus, actyue. Actualis scientia, a science
that declarethe things by their operation, of the which are three parts,
moral, dispensatiue, and civil. Acta aetas, age when youth is paste. Acta
agere, to do that which is all redye done, to lose labor. Actus, put in
fear. Actus, a braid in tillage, it is also a cartway. Actuosus, always in
business. Actuosus ignis, fire which always burns. Seneca.
Aculeatus, ta, tum, any thing that prycketh. Acupedius, he that has a quycke
and apt foot to run with. Paul. Iouius
Acus, a fish, which is long and somewhat grene, and has a beke, as it were
the byll of a crane, I suppose it is that, which some call an hornekeke.
Acustici, they which do here all, and speak nothing them selfs. Acute,
quyckely, subtly. Acuti oculi, clear eyes. Acuti cibi, sharp meats. Acutum
ingenium, a subtle or quycke wit. Acylon, an holy beary. Acyphantes, a city
in Thessaly, which is also called Pindus.
A ANTE D.
ADAD, in the Syrian tongue, is the son, also it signifies only. Ad me,
with me. Commodum ad te dederam literas, de pluribus rebus, Cice. Atti. lib. 9.
cum ad me been mane, Dionysius fuit. I had scarsly sent my letters unto the,
when Dionyse was with me erly in the morning. Ad breuissimu^ tempus, for a
very short time. Pli. in pan.
Ad id tempus, at that time. Ad sapientiam huius, nimius nugator fuit, In
regard of his wysedom he was but a fool. Ad illam faciem, ita ut illa est, ut
emerem sibi, Plautus in Mercator.
mandauit mihi, He commanded me to bie for him one, which had such an another
face as she has. Ad cyathum stare, to awayte on the cup. Sueton. in Caesare
Ci de ora^tore. 2.
Ad manum seruus, he that is clerk to one, or writes for him. Ad pedes, a
lakay. Ad manus venire, to come to handestrokes, to cope together. Ad meridiem,
until noone. Ad multam noctem, late in the night. Terentius Cice. Atti.
Ad tempus, in season. sometime according to the time also for a time. Ad
dextram, on the right hand. Ad hoc exemplum, nunquam a maui, Plautus in
mercator.
I never louyd of that facyon, or in that manner. Ad hunc modum, this way or in
this manner. Ad extremum, finally, in conclusyon. Plin. Plautus in Au^ul.
Cicero. Plinius. Cicero de Amic. Plinius. Plautus in Ruden. Plautus. Terentius
in Phor^.
Ad postremum, idem. Ad summum, at the most. Ad uerbum, word by word. Ad
vnum, not one left. Ad vnum idem sentiunt, they be all of oone opinion. Ad
assem, to the vttermoste penye. Ad annos sedecim, syxtene years herafter. Ad
rauim poscere, to ask until one be hoorse Ad restim res red^t, It is come to
the point that be will hang him self. it is a sentence signifienge
desperation. Ad rem suam sapere, Plautus in Trucu.
to be wise for his own profytte. Cicero.
Adaequo, are, to make or be equal. Adaggero, rere, to gather and lay
together. Adam, the first manne, which sygnifyeth read. Adamanteus, and
Adamantinus, of a diamand, or as hard as a diamande. Adamaster, a gyaunt,
which was of an incredible greattenesse. Adamiani, were certain heretykes,
which went naked about all their business, saying that they did follow the
nakydnes of Adam being in Paradise, who believed that there should have been no
marriage, if no man had sinned. Adaperio, rire, to open a thing. Adapertilis,
le, for apertum, open. Adarca, a salt foam, which comes of the ryndes of
caanes or reeds grownyge in fennes. Adasia, an old ewe, which has late eaned
or had a lamb. Adasso, old writers used for Adigo, to compelle. Non. Mar.
Adaucto, tare, to augment or increace. Adaugeo, gere, idem. Adauctus, ta, tum,
augmented. Adaxi^t, for adegerint, let them compelle, or constrayne. Adcensi,
soldiers put in the place of them which are deed. Addico, cere, to set to
sale. Addicere animu^, to give or apply his mind. Terent. in Eunucho.
Addictus, bounden to one. Addebat hoc, he said moreover. Addere animum, to
give courage. Addere gradum, to make him go faster. Vergilius.
Additus, for an ennemie. Nec Teucris addita Juno, usquam aberit, Neither Juno
ennemy to the Troyans shall lack or be away. Addo, dare, to give to one.
Addormisco, scere, to sleep. Addubito, tare, to doubt. Adducere habenas, to
hold strait the bridel. Adductus, ta, tum, brought, led, moved. Adduplico,
care, to double any thing. Adelphi, brethren, it is also the name of a
comedy in Terence. Adeo res redijt, the matter is comme to that point.
Adeousque, until that. Adest ei animus, he has a good courage* Adest, he is
at hand. Adesse, to aid or succor one. Terent. in Andria.
Adesdum, come hither. Adeor, the passyue of adeo. Ader, a place by Bethlem,
where angels did sing at the birth of Christ, and Jacob kept there his
sheep. Non. Mar.
Adesus, a, um, consumed. Ad exitam aetatem, for ad ultimam aetatem, Festus.
at the vttermoste age. Adfabrum, well wrought. Adhaeresco, scere, idem quod
adhaereo. Adhaesus, a, um, cleaued to. Adhibere animu^, to take heed what is
spoken Adhibere aures, to harken, to give an ear. Adhibere in consilium

to neye as a horse does after a mare. Cicero by a metaphore makes it to

to approve a thing Adijcere animum, to set his mind or love on oone. Adijcere

Adipisci, to overtake one. Adiposus, rich. Adipson, a sweet root called

Terent. in Andria.
Errat long mea quidem sententia, qui imperium credat grauius esse aut
stabilius, ui quod fit, quam id quod amicitia adiungitur, He is foul deceived
in mine opynion, that thinks, that rule to be more ferme and stable, which
is gotten by vyolence, than that which is obtained by friendship. Plautus in M^n.
Adiurgium, debate. Adiuratio, a con^uringe. Adiurati, confederate or alied
together by oath. Adiutor, an helper, Adiutrix. Adiunamen, help. Adlino, nere,
to enoynt, or rub a thing with any thing liquide. Administer, a stuarde of
householde. Administro, rare, to do service, to exployte, to fournyshe

wonderful. Admirabundes, he that does wonder or maruayle at a thing.

another. Admistura, idem quod admistio. ^
Admittere uitam, to retain life, to live. Admittere, to do. Quid tandem
admisi in te? what have I offended the? Admittere noxiam, to pardon an offense.
Admittere diem, to open the wyndowe, that the light may come in. ^
Admittere equum, to lyte up to horseback, or as we say, to take his horse.
Admittere, to put the male best to the female for genera^ion. Admittere
sumptum, to do great cost. Admodum. ye. Ad^^to, tare, to swym to a place.
Adnecto, tere, to knyt to a thing. Festus.
Adnexio, a knyttynge or fastening to a thing. Adnicto, nixi, nict ere, to wynke
on one. Adnitor, niteris, niti, to lean to a thing, to bear or sustain it.
Adnotatio, a titillinge, or short notinge of that, which we do read or here.
Adnumero, rare, to add to. Adolabilis, without grief or sorrow. Adolescens,
it is, a young man, which is yet growing. Adolescentulus, a ladde. Adonat, the
name of god among the Iues, which signyfyeth, The Lord of all creatures.
Adoperio, rire, to kouer or hyde. Adoptatitius, he whom a man ordayneth to
be his heir, and takes unto him in the stead of his son. Adoptio, where a man makes one his heir, and takes him for his son, being of his own
kynne or a stranger. Ador, and Adoreum, a kind of wheat, called also far,
which by the description seems to be the wheat, which we call ducke byll.
Adorno, nare, to apparayle, to prepare, to praise. Adquiro, quisiui, quirere,
to geate, to conquer. Adquo, for quousque, until. Adramelech, an ydolle of
Syria, whom also the Samaritanes honored. Adrastia, a contraye not far from
Troy, also the name of a city there. It was also called a goddess, which
took from manne both memory and wit. Adrastus, a king of Argyues in Greece.
who had two dawghters, of the which the one was married to Tideus, the other
to Polym^es, read the historye of the syege of Thebes. Adrepo, psi, pere, to
reach at a thing, to take it with vyolence. Adscisco, scere, to join or take
to, as when one joins another with him in auctority, or takes one to aid
him in his office. Adscriptitii, were men of war, which were taken into an
army to supplye the places of them that were slain, or other wise lacked.
Ascripti, were they that were appointed to inhabyte towns or cities, made by
the Romans, called Coloniae. Adscriptiui, idem quod Adscriptitii. Adsitis domi
facite, Se that ye be both at home. Aduallas, a mountain, from the which
the great river called the Rene, runs Northward. Adubanus, the famous river
called also Danubius and Hister. Aduelitatio, a mutual reprochinge, or
contention in words. Aduentus, tus, a coming. Aduerbialiter, like an
aduerbe. Aduersaria, a reknynge book of expensis. written first before the book
of account be made. Aduersa aerumna, aduersyty, damage. Terentius in Phorm.
Aduersa valetudo, syckenesse, Aduersatus, ta, tum, against or contrary. Pli de
uiris illust^.
Aduersis vulneribus, with wounds in the forepart. Aduerso flumine, against
the streme. Aduersus, sa, sum, that whereof only the fore part is seen, as
Auersus, whereof only only the hynderpart is seen. Aduorso animo, against my
will, thy will, or his will: against his heart. Aduersum, against. Quis est hic,
qui aduersum mihi fit? Who is he that comes against me, or marchyth toward
me? Aduersum, for erga. Aduertere, to perceive. Aduertere animum, to take heed,
or harken. Pli. in pan.
Aduertere oculos, to perceive, to see, to behold. Aduesperascit, the
evening, or euentyde is commen, or it waxyth late, or it is night. Aduigilo,
uigilare, to watch, to take good heed. Adulteror, rari, idem quod Adultero.
Adumbratus, a, um, feigned, countrefayted, portured. Adumbratio, portrayture.
Adulator, toris, a flaterar. Adulatrix, a woman that flatreth. Aduocito, ^are,
to call for one often. Aduocatus, he that defends an other man's cause.
Aduocatio, pleadynge. Aduoluo, uere, to wrappe round together. Aduorsor, for
Aduersor. Aduorsem, old wrytars used for Aduersarium. Aduro, ussi, urere, to
roast, to burn. Adustio, rostinge, or burning. Adustus, ta, tum, rostyd, or
burned. Adyticulum, a dyminutif of Adytum.
A, ANTE E.
AEantion, a town in the promontory or hill of Troy, called Sigeum. Aeas,
aeantos, a river of a contraye called Epyrus, which runs out of Macedonia,
and falls into the Se called Ionium. Aeacus, was the son of Jupiter and
Europa, whom Paynymes did suppose to be of such justice, that he was
appointed by Pluto, called godde of hell, to be one of the iuges there, with
Minoes and Radamanthus, to discuss the transgressyons of men being deed,
and to assign to them punysshement according to their merits. Aedificatio,
building. Aedificator, a buyldar. Aeditio, a publication of a thing. Aeger,
aegra, um, sick, sorrowful. Aegerrime, very grievously. Aedes, a chamber.
Aedilitius, a, um, pertayninge to Aediles. Aeditimus, idem qui Aedituus. Aedon,
a Nightingale. Aegae, a city in Cilicia, also an I Will in the Se called Aegeum.
Aegaeon, a giant called also Briareus, also it is one of the names of Neptunus.
Aegaea, a city in Macedonia, another in Mauritania. Aegeria, a Nymphe or
goddess, with who^ Numa Pompilius the second king of Romans, feigned to have
familiar company and communicacion concerning religion and worshyppynge of
gods, to the intent that he might thereby withdraw the people from the
appetyte of wars, wherewith they were inflamed. Aegaeum mare. Aegeus, the
father of Theseus. Aegealus, was a countraye called also Achaia, in Greece*
Aegides, of Aegeus, patronymicum. Aegylops, wild otes. Aegina, a city
ioynynge to Peloponeso or Morea, against the countraye of Athenes, also an I Will
from Pireum.xii. miles. Aeginenses, the people of Aegina the city. Aeginitae,
people of the I Will of Aegina. Aegineticus, ca, cum, of Aegina. Aegimuros, an I Will
called also Capraria, beyond Corse. Aegiochus, a name of Jupiter. Aegis,
gidis, an haubergeon, which only the goddis were painted with. Aegium, a
town in Peloponeso, now called Morea, where they feigned that Jupiter was
norysshed with a got. Aegle, a Nymphe. Aegloga, a communication of shepeherdes
together. Aegocephalus, a bird, Aristot. de animali. 2.
which is without a spleen. Aegocerus, idem quod Capricornus. Aegonomus, a
got herd, or kepar of gotes. Aegos, a river in Thracia. Aegre, with much
pain, or difficulty. Aegrefero, tuli, far, to be sorry. Aegresco, sci, scere,
to be sick. Aegrum, idem quod aegritudo, sorrow, displeasure. Aegrius, more
sorowfully, more displeasauntly. Aegrio, I am sick. Aegritudo, dinis, grief of
mind, or sorrow. Aegrotare, to fail, or be feeble of courage. Aegrotus, feeble
of courage. Aegula, a kind of brymstone, wherewith in some places they do
perfume wulle to make it white. Aegylops, a fistula in the corner of the eye by
the nose of a man, which rounneth mattier. Aegyptini, people of Ethiope,
marchynge on Egypt. Aegyptius, and Aegyptiacus, a, um, of Egypt. Aegyptus, the
country called Egypt. Aegystus, he that slew Agamemnon. Aelius, the propre
name of a Romayne. Festus.
Aelutus, a catte. Aemi^^um, swollen. Aemilius, the propre name of a Romayne.
Aemilia, a countray in Italy, callid also Flaminia, and Romandiola. Aemulatio*
envy, or imitation. Aemonia, a countray called also Thessalia. Aen^^s, a noble
man of Troy, which with Anthenor betrayed the city of Troy. Aenoba^bus, the

Era, rae, dernel, which grows in corn. Aeratus, indetted. Aerarii
Tribuni, were treasourers, which paid to the soldiers their wages. Aerarii

Aerumnosus, a, um, miserable, full of pain or travail. Aerumnulae, little

seruire, Plautus.
Litanum modo ut co^ueniam, I would do service all the days of my life, on the
condition that I might mete with Litanus. Aetas acta est mihi, my time is
passed. Cicero.
Aetas bona, the flower of youth. Aetate adulta, of full age. Aetate affecta,
of old age. Aetate exacta, very aged, in extreme age. Aetate confectus, idem.
Aetate integra, in the flower of youth. Aetate prouecta, aged, or of great age.
Aetatem, an aduerbe, signifies long time. lam dudu^ aetatem lites sunt inter
eos, There has be^ variance between them long time. Aeterne, euerlastyngely,
Aeterno, nare, to make perpetual. Aethereus, a, um, of the firmament.
Anaxagoras puts it for the element of fire. Aethiopia, a great country in
Affrike, containing many regyons, called Ethiope: wherein be found people,
beasts, and serpents of meruaylous form. It has on the west, the
mountains callid Athlantes, on the east it extends to the marches of Egypt:
on the south it has the sea occean: on the north part, it is enclosed with
the river called Nilus. Aethiopicus, ca, cum, of Ethiope. Aethiopissa, a woman
of Ethiope. Aethiops, aethiopis, a man of Ethiope. Aethon, one of the horses of
Phoebus. Aethrusci, the old Inhabytauntes of the countray in Italy, callid now
Tuscana. Aetiologia, a rehersynge of the cause. Aetites, a precious stone,
which has the color of an egles tail that is white. Aetius, the name of a
famous writer in phisik. Aetolia, a countrays in Greece. Aeuitas, eternitye.
A, ANTE F.
AFfecta, almost fynysshed, or nyghe at a point. Sue^on. in Vesp. Plautus
Affecta fides, credence almost lost. Affectus uirgis, beaten with rods.
Affectus morbo, vexed with sycknesse. Cice.
Affectum bellum, wars nyghe at a point. Affecta aestas, Somer well nyghe
passed. Cice.
Affectio, affection, sometime trouble of mind. Varro.
Affector, taris, idem quod Affecto. Afferre auxilium, to help, to aid. Varr.
de re ^ust.
Afferre dentes, to byte. Afferre manus, to set violent hands on one. Afferre
uim alicui, to make assault on one. Afferre molestiam, to do displeasure to
one. Afferre morbum, to make sick. Catullus.
Afferre pedem, to come. Abite, vnde malum, pedem attulistis, Goo hense, from
whense with a myschief ye came. Affero ad te salutem, I come to salute you.
Afficere cura, to bring in care. Afficere lucro, to make one to win or
gain. Afficere bonis nunciis, to bring good tidings. Plaut.
Vti bonis uos, uestrosque omnes nuntiis me afficere nultis, As ye will that I
bring to you and yours good tydinges. Affecit praeda atque agro populares
suos, Plaut.
He made his countray men rich both of lands and goods. Cicero.
Afficere stipendio, to pay to him his wages. Affici, to be moved with
affection. Affinis negociis publicis, he that medleth with the affairs of a
communalty. Affinitas, tatis, affinity, aliance. Affinis rei capitalis, gylty
of a great offense, which deserves death. Affinis sceleris, gylty of the
trespace. Affirmative, with an affirmaunce. Afflatus, tus, a blast. Plautus.
Affleo, affleui, flere, to weep in the remembrance of a thing. Salust.
Afflictus, stryken down to the ground. Affligere, to throw or beat down
to the ground. Plaut.
Affligam te ad ^erram scelus, si me uno digito attigeris, I will beat the
down to the ground wretch, if thou touchest me but with one fyngar.
Affluenter, abundantly. Affluentia, abundance. Affluens, it is, abundant.
Afformido, dare, to have great fear. Affricus, ca, cum, of Affrike.
A ANTE G.
AGar, the maiden of Sara, on whom Abraham begat Ismael. Agaricum, a thing
like to a white mussheron growyng on the stem of a tree, and is called Agarike,
which is medicinable in pourginge of fleame. Agaso, sonis, a horse kepar, a
muletour. Agatho, the name of one of the sons of Priamus, also a boy, whom
Plato louyd. Agathyrsi, people by Scithia, which be rich of gold, and yet be
neither couaytouse nor enuyouse, and their hears are blue. Agathocles, was a
king of Sicile. Age dicat, let him speak on, let him speak hardyly. Age, age
ut lubet, well go to, do what ye will. Age, and agite, go forth, forth on.
Agea, a way in a ship. Agelastus, he that never lawghyd. Agenor, the father
of Europa, whom Jupiter rauysshed, and of Cadmus, who builded the city of
Thebes. Agere, to here, to perceive. Plautus.
Vos agite spectatores, ye that behold, here, or take heed. Hoccine agis, an
non? Perceyuest thou this matter or no? also to conclude. Terentsus*
Herus me relictis rebus, iussit Pamphilum hodie obseruare, ut quid ageret de
nuptiis scirem, My master has commanded me, that layenge all things apart, I
should awayte upon Pamphilus, to thintente I might know, what he would
conclude, touching the marriage. Agere, to go. Quo hinc te agis? Terentius
Whyther go thou from hense? Sometime it signifies to come. Vnde agis te
nunc Dorpale? from whense come thou now Dorpalus. Agere. Pectus mihi agit
nunc cubiro: Plautus.
She hitteth me on the heart with her elbowe. Agere ad praescriptum, to do that,
that he was appointed. Agere aetatem, to live. Agere ambages. Plautus.
Quid opus me multas agere ambages? what needs me to make many words? or to
speak by circumlocution? Agere animam, to dye. Agere annum octingentesimu^, to
live eight hundred years. Agere apologum, to tell him a fable. Plautus.
Agere amicum, to do like a friend, Pli. in pan*
or play the part of a friend. Agere cum aliquo, to treat with one, or to
speak. Cum mecum saepe ageres, ut de amicitia scriberem: Where often times thou
dyddest entreat me, that I should write of frendshyppe. Illo praesente, mecum
agito, Plautus.
si quid uoles: If thou will any thing with me, speak it in the presence of
that manne. Agere iniuriarum, to sue one for trespase or wrongs done. Agere
summo iure, to proceed with rigor. Agere sou iure, to execute his auctority
Agere lege, to sue, to proceed by the way of Justice. Plautus.
Agere di^is malis, to curse. Agere mensuras fideliter, to measure things
justly. Cicero.
Agere ^^gas, to mock, to tryfle. Agere orationem, to pronounce an oration.
Agere uineas, to lay ordinance to a thing. Actum de me est, I am undone.
Agesilaus, a king of Lacedemony, which was little of stature, and haltyd on the
one foot, but in virtue, wisdom, and prowess he exelled all princes of his
time, whose life is written by Plutarche and Xenophon. Plautus.
Aggerre, to bring to one. Namque ecastor, amor and melle and selle est
foecundissimus, gu^^^ it dulce, amarum usque ad sacietatem agge^t, for in good
faith, love has abundance both of honey and galle, in taste it is pleasant,
but it brings with it bytternesse, so much that it becomes lothesome.
Aggrauatio, a grief, a bourdon. Aggrauesco, scere, to wax more greuouse.
Aggredi, to assail. P^s.
Aggretus, idem quod Aggressus. Ag^^iter, nymbly, quyuerly. Aginor, nari, to
marchandyse vile things, or of small value. Cicero.
Agis rem actam, thou lesest thy labor. Agit rem suam, he goes about his
own business. Plautus.
Agit hic perpetuum diem sol, The sone shyneth here all the day long.
Terentius Plautus.
Agitare, to entreat well, to compel to go. lam calcari quadrupedem agitabo
aduersum cliuum: Now will I with a spur make my horse run up the hill.
Plautus.
Agitare co^uiuium, to banquet and make good chiere. Age ergo, hoc agitemus
conuiuium, uino et sermon suaui, Therefore go to, let us banquet, drink talk
and make good chiere. Plautus.
Agitare custodiam, to take good head in keeping of one. Plautus.
Agitare diem, to pass forth the day. Agitare imperium, to govern. In pace
vero, beneficiis magis quam metu imperium agitabant: In the time of peace, they
governed, more by gentyllnesse, than by fear. Agitare iustitiam, to exercise
justice. Pli in ep. Salust.
Agitare letitiam, to make joy. Agitare mente, to conceive in the mind, to
think. Agitare cum animo, to reuolue in the mind. Salust. Salust.
Agitare praesidium, to be in garyson. Agitare uigilias, to keep watch.
Agitare uitam, to live. Agitatio, a meuynge or styrringe. alsoo exercise.
Agitator, a dryuer of a cart, or of beastis. Agitedum, ite mecum, than forth,
and come ye on with me. Agitur mecum been, I am in good condition. Val. Man de
Mi^^ia
Agere been, sometime is of a like signyfication. Agitur de capite, de fama,
etc. when the life or renomme is in danger to be lost. Agitur res capitis,
Terent.
the question or matter in debate, concernyth life. Aglaia, one of them which
are called Charites, gracis. Agnascentia membra, Plinius.
members which are superfluouse, as where one has three legs, or six
fingars on one hand, and other like. Agnitio, knowledge. Agon, agonis, a
contention in form of battle, or a wrastlyng, also the place where it was
exercysed. Agonalia, certain festival days kept among the Romans.
Agonensis porta, a gate of Rome called also Colina. Agones, were sometime
called hills. Agonia, sacrifice done on hills. Agonius, was named a god,
which had preemynence over things to be done. Agraria lex, a law made for
the ce^mon disposition of lands, as be our statutes of enclosures and
decayenge of husbandry. but among the Romans they were such laws as did
appoynte, how much land a Senator should have, and not excede, and how
much should be dyuided among the people. Aggrigentinus, tina, number, of the
town of Agrigentum, which is in Sicile. Agricolatio, tyllage or husbandry.

mother of Nero the Emperor. Also the dawghter of Octauyan. Agrippina, Colonia,
the city of Coleyne. Agylla, a city in Thuscana.

A ANTE L.
ALabandae, a city in Greece, in the country of Ionia. Alabandicus, ca, cum,

Senators of Alba. Albegmina, part of the inward of bestes, which was offered
to Dis, callid god of hell. Albeuses, people of Alba. Albesto, scere, to be
white. Albicaleull, white stones, with the which the people of Creta did note
or mark the days, wherein they had good fortune like as they marked ill days
with black stoones, called nigri calculi. Albia, a river, which passes
through the ^a^ime of Boemia. Albiecra, is kind of olyue tree.

shieldes or targates. Albula, the old name of the river of Tiber. also a water
in the field called Tiburtinus, which was medicinable for fore eien. Album
plumbum, tynne. Albunia, a wodde and fountain by the river called Aniene, in
Italy. Albu^^us, a hill in Lucania, Ale^a, a lion. Alce, a wild beast in the
woddes of Germany, in facion and skyn like to a got, but greter, which have no
iointes in their legs, and therefore they do never ly, but only do lean to
trees, when they do rest the^, which the hunters knowing, do saw the trees
that they lean to, half a sonder, whereby they fall down, and be taken.
Alces, a beast in France like a mule, but he has his over lyppe so long, that
wha^ he sedeth, he goth backewarde, or else he can not bi^e of the grass and
herbs, which he should eat. The horsekynde of them have horns on their over
brows. Alceste^seu Alcestis, the wife of Admetus the king of the people
callid Pherei, who being sick, and having answer of the goddis, that he should
escape death, if any of his kynne or frondes would die for him willingly, when
all men and women refused it, only Alceste his wife consented thereto, and
willyngly dyed. Alcaeus, a famous poet. Alchech, in the Araby tongue, is the
beast, which is callid Linx, which is begotten between a lion and a lybarde.
Alcibrades, a noble captain of the Athenienses, which in nobility, beauty,
prowess, (...), and eloquence, passed al other in his time, not withstanding
his yyces were accounted equal unto his virtues. Alcides, idem quod Hercules.
Alcinous, Homerus Odyss.
the name of a king of a people callid Phaeaces, excellent in Justice, which had
a fair and (...) palyce, with or charde a which ^are most plentuousely fruits
^wyse in the (...). A^cman, a famous poet. (...), the mother of Hercules.
(...), a cunning grauou^^ (...), a good archer of Creta, which beholdynge a
dragon ready (...) are his son of did (...) so craftily, (...) as the dragon
(...) of the child, the arowe passed unto his heart, and hurt not his son, so
that the dragon immediately died. Alcyonae, the name of.ii. ladies, whereof the
one was wife to Ceisis, who seeing the deed body of her husband cast on land,
threw her self into the sea, whom the poets fained to be turnid into a bird of
that name: the other was daughter of Euene, callid also Marpesia Aleatoriu^, a
dice playing, or a dycyng house. Suetonuis calls it aleatorium forum. Alebria,
things which do nourishe well. Alec, is a sauce made of the livers of fishes,
also a fyshe, called a hearing. Alecto, one of the furies of Hell. Alectoria, a
stone found in a cocks gysar or mawe, of the greatenes of a bean, of the
color of crystal. Alemani, people of Germany, callid Germai^s Aleo, aleonis,
a dysar, or dyseplayer. Aletudo, fattenesse of the body. Alexander, the name of
a man, specially of a king of Macedony, which conquered all the cast part of the
world, and was in prowess and wysedom incomparable: but being drowned in
ouermoche felicity, he fell into exceeding pride and cruelty, and was at the
last poisoned, and died in Babylon, exceeding little the age of thirty years.
Alexandria, the name of a great city in Egypt* also of dyuere other cities.
Alexandrinus, na, number, of Alexandria. Algenses, fyshes called also purpurae.
Algidense, a kind of radysshe, long and clear through. Algidus, a
mountain.xii. miles from Rome. Algida sylua, a wod at the foot of that
mountain. Algo, idem quod algeo. Alguasen, an herb like to a lyly. Plautus.
Algus, uel algu, cold. Alia, a river.xi. miles from Rome. Alias res agis,
thou think on other matters. Vnde anulu^ istu^ nactus? di^ mihi, ille alias
res agere se simulare, Tell me where gattest thou this ryng? he made semblance
as if he thought on an other matter. Alicarij, they that do sell alicam.
Alicariae, common harlottes. Alicastrum, a diminutiue of alica. Alienatio, an
alienation or alteration. Alienator, he that alters a thing. Terentius
Alienior* aetate, of no^age, not of co^pete^s age. Alienus animus, Iam primum
illum alieno animo a nobis esse, res, ipsa indicat: The thing* self declares,
that even now he has no favor toward us, that he is not my friend. Alieno
more mihi uiuendum est, I must live after an other man's facion. Salust.
Aliena consilii, unmeet for the counsel. Alienum suis rationibus,
unprofitable for his purpose. Alienatus, a, u^, put away altered, estranged.
Alieu^s agimus, we become strange unto the^ Alimentarius, a, um, pertaining to
living or sustinance. Alimonia, idem quod alimentum. Alimodi, idem quod
aliusmodi, of an another facion or manner. Aliouersum, toward an other place.
Aliptes, he that annoynteth a man. Aliquis, aliquae, aliquod, some. Alirei,
Plautus uses for aliae rei. Alisma, an herb called also barba syluana, water
plantayne. Aliter ac, aliter atque, aliter qu^, otherwise tha^. Alites, birds.
Aliubi, for alicubi, somewhere. Aliuta, old writers used for aliter.
Aliusmodi, i^ an other man^, of an other facio^ Alligare alique^ furto, to
apech one of felony Alligare se furti, to charge him self of felony Alligatos,
he that byndeth. Alligatura, a bond. Allobrox, allobrogis, a man or woman of
the countray in France, called Dolpheny. Allocutio, a speaking to one.
Allocutum ire, to commune with one. Alloquium, communication, speech. Aludor,
idem quod alludo. Alluuium, idem quod alluuies. Alluuio, idem. Almities,
quietenes, secretenes. Almopia, part of Macedonia. Aloe, aloes, is used
commonly for a juice of an herb congeled like a gu^me, whereof be two sorts,
one is named Succotrina, which is like a liver, read, bright, and bronkle: the
other is called Caballina, and is sandy and gross* The first cleanses and
confirms the stomach of a man, and therefore is mixed with purgative medicines,
because they shall not anoy or hurt the stomach, the last is occupied about
horse and other beastis. Aloe lignum, or lignu^ aloes, is a sweet and precious
wod, which being received in medicine, comfort the stomach, and all the
inferior partis of a man, and makes sweet breath. Alogia, unreasonable or
beastly feding, and ingurgitation of meat and drink. Alopecus, he that has a
pylde heed, that is to say, the hears falling with scurse. Alosa, a fyshe
called also Laccia, and Clupea, is that, which by the description of Paulus
Iouius seems to be a cheuyn. Alphabetarii, they which do learn first the
order of letters. Alphabetum, the order of letters, as a. b. c. Alpheus, a
river in Archadia, also the name of a man. Alphos, a morphy or staining of
the shinne^ Alpinus, a, u^, of the mountain^ of Alpe^. Alpus, pale, careful,
or studious. Alsine mayor, an herb called wodbynde. Alsine minor, an herb
called the second mouse ear. Alsiosus, a, um, cold of nature* also which
are soon hurt or anoyed with cold. Altanus, a wynd, which is on the deep
sees. Alte, on high. Altellus, a surname of Romulus the founder of Rome. Alter
and vicesimus, one and twenty. Alter quisquam, any other. Alteras, old
waiters used for alias. Altercatio, a contention in words, where one man
purposes, an another replyeth. Altercum, sieve altercagenum, an herb called
also faba porcina. Alterplex, plicis, old writers used for duplex double.
Alter^a, ide^ quod alterutra. Altior, altius, higher. Altissimus, ma, mum,
highest. Altimetor, an Instrument wherewith high things are met. Altinu^, an
old city by the riuage of Venice. Altinates, people of Altinum. Plautus.
Altitudo, height, or depenes. Altrouersum, on the other part, or on the other
side. Altum otium, long rest, great leisure. Aluini, they which have
frettyng in their bealyes with contynuall flux. Alumnatus, nouryshed. Alyba, a
countraye not far from Mis^a, where as Homerus does write, were mines of
silver. Alysius, the name of Bacchus. Alysina, an herb called water plantayne.
A, ANTE M.
AMalthea, a woman, which with her sister called Meissa, nouryshed Jupiter
with the milk of a gore. Also the name of a prophetess. Amantior, more
loving. Amantissimus, most loving. Amantissime, most louyngely. Solinus.
Amantlies, people in Affrike, which have such plenty of precious stones,
that they build therewith houses. Amanus, a mountain called also Taurus.
Amaracinum, an oil made of maioram. Josephus.
Amaramis, the father of Moses. Amarantus, an herb, which grows a foot in
height, and has leaves like basile, and has a flower facionid like an ere of
wheat, ^f crimson color, which never dies: in french it is callid
Pass^uelute* some there be, which do suppose it to be callid in englysh
Baldar. Amarico, are, to make bitter, to make angry Amaror, idem quod
amaritudo. Amarus, ra, rum, bitter, very angry. Amariscus, an herb called de
Mathis, or Dog senell. Amarillis, the name of a shepeherde in the bucolic is
of Vergile. Amasenus, a river in Italy. Amasias, a king of Jews: which
signyfieth as much as populum tollens. Amasis, was a noble king of Egypt,
which made a law, that every year, ech^ man should make a rekeninge to the
heed offycer of his realm, of his life, and show whereby he lived, or by what
occupation he was sustained, and he that did not make such account, should be
put to death. Amasso, idem quod amauero. Amatio, a loving. Amastrum, uel
Amastris, the principal city of Paphlagonia. Amatli, the son of Chanaan.
Josephus.
Amathus, thu^tis, a cite in Ciprus, dedicate to Venus. Amathuntius, a, um, of
the said city. Amathusa, the isle of Ciprus. Amautosis, the dymnesse of the
eyes. Amazones, women of Scithia, which wa^ne a great part of Asia: who slew
all the men children, and kept the women children, of whom they burned the
right pappe, because it should not let them to throw their Iauelyns, or to
shote. Amazonicus, ca, cu^, pertaining to the Amazones. Amazonius, a, u^, ide^
quoth Amazonicus. Amazonicus, nici, a countraye called afterward Cesaria.
Ambarualis hostia, was a sacrifice made for the fields, with a sow great with
farowe. Ambedo, ere, to eat or gnaw about a thing Ambegni, were an ox and a
ram, where on every side of them lambis were brought to be sacrificed.
Ambesus, a, u^, eaten round. Ambest* ^dem quod circum est. Ambiani, seu
Ambianenses, people in France about Languedoke. Ambidentes, sheep of two tethe,
of sum called hogs, of some theaues. Ambiguitas, doubtfulnesse. Ambitus,
ta, tum, enuyronned or compassed. Ambitus, tus, enclosure, alsoo ambycion or
desire of promotion. Ambra, a very sweet thing, which is found on the sea, as
musherons are on the earth* whereof is made very precious and cordial medicines.
Ambracia, a cite in the cou^tray callid Epirus in Greece. Ambracienses, people of
Ambracia Ambrices, tyles, which be laid overthwart between other tyles.
Ambrones, people in France. Ambrosia, ^n herb, which some men do suppose to
be Tansey. Ambubeia, the commune cykorye with the long leaf, and the blewe
flower, which will be closed at the goinge down of the son, and opened at
the rysynge. Ambubeiae, dronken drabbes, which wander about the streets.
Ambulatiuncula, a little walk. Ambustus, ta, tum, bourned. Amecus, and ameca,
old writers used for amicus, and amica. Amen, a word of Hebrew, which after
the interpretation of Aquila, signifies fideliter, faythefully, after the.lxx.
interpretours, it signifies fiat, be it. Amentia, folly. Amento, tare, to bind
a thonge about any thing. Amentior, tius, madder. Amentissimus, a, um,
maddest. Ameria, an old city in Italy. America, a country late found in the
east by Amercum Vesputium. Amerinum, a city in Italy. Amethystus, a precious
stone of vyolet color, an ametyst. Amethystinus, a, um, of an ametyst. Amia, a
fyshe like to a Tuny, but he has no scales, but a plain skin, which
shyneth like to silver mixte with blue, and his tail is in facyon like a new
moon. Amica, a woman that is loved. alsoo a concubyne. Amicibor, for amiciam,
I will clothe or put on a garment. Amicior, ciri, to be cladde. Amicissime,
most frendely. Amice, frendely. Amiciter, idem. Amicissimus, a, um, most
frendely. Amicius, more frendely. Amictorium, a lynnen rail that womenne do
wear. Amicula, a diminutiue of amica. Amiculum, a short cloak. Amiculatus, he
that wears a short cloak. Plautus.
Amicabilis, le, frendely. Amineae vites, vynes growing in a country by
Salerne. Amyson, a famous city in the royalme of Pontus. Amissio, the loss of
a thing. Amissus, a, um, lost. Amiternum, a town in Campania, where Salust
was borne. Plautus.
Amites, perches, whereon hawks be set. Amittere iusiu^andum, to break an
oath, to lose credence. Quod si non dederit, atque hic dies praeterierit, ego
argentum, ille iusiurandum amiserit, If he do not pay it, and this day do
pass, I shall lose my money, but he shall lose his credence. Amittere
libidinem. Iam non possum, Plautus.
amis^ omnem libidinem, I may do no more, I am paste all pleasure. Ammon, a
surname of Iupyter, worshypped in Egypt. Amnestia, forgetfulness of things
passed. Ammoniacum, a certain gum. Amnicus, ca, cum, of the broke. Amo, are,
to love. Amaene, merrily, pleasantly. Amomum, a spyce growing in India, like to
a wild vine, and is in color somewhat yelowe or brown, and very soote in
savor. Amorthei, people beyond Jerusalem, and had their name of Amorrheus the
son of Canaan. Amores, wanton passetymes, or affections of lecherye. Amosio,
for annuo. Festus.
Amouere seg^itiem, to cast away sloth. Amouere crapulam, Plautus.
to parbreake when one is drunk. Ampendices, old writers vsid for appe^dices.
Ampelos agria, a wild vine. Amphibea, beasts or byrdis, which do live as well
on the water, as on the land. Amphilogia, a form in speaking, where a
sentence may be taken two sundry or contrary ways. Ampelusia, an isle called
now Tinge. Amphibolum, a doubtefull sentence. Amphibrachus, a foot in meter,
being of three syllables, the first and last short, the mydell syllable
long, as Cupido. Amphilochus, a philosopher. Amphesibene, a serpent, having
two heddes, whereof the one is before, the other behind, where his tail should
be. Amphimacrus, a foot in meter, having the first syllable and the last
long, the myddell syllable short. Amphimalla, garme^tis rough on both sides
Amphitapetes, garments of Cotton on both sides hearye. Amphimerimon, a fever
co^idyane, which comes of fleume. Amphion, a man, which with natural
eloquence, brought rude and wild people to a c^uile form of living: and as
some do suppose, sound first harmony. Amphipolis, a city nigh to Macedonia.
Amphiroe, a nymph or maide^ of the ryuers. Amphitana, a precious stone, the
brimme or edge whereof shines like to gold. Amphitheatru^, a round place made
with seats or scaffoldis, where men beh^ld plays. Amphitreatrales ludi, playce
exercysed in those places. Amphitrite, the wife of Reptunus. it is also taken
for the sea. Amphitrio, trionis, the husband of Alcmena, mother of Hercules.
Amphitrionides, he that comith of the ligne of Amphitrio. Amphictyones, the
generalle or commune counsel of all Grecia. Ampiruo, are, is proprely where
in dau^cing like mening or cou^tena^ce that one makes, he unto whom it is
made, shall do the semblable, it was first vsid of the pristes callid Saly.
Amplant, old writers vsid for amplificant, they enlarge. Ample, amply,
largely. Non. Mar.
Amplexa, for amplexare, embrace or take to you. Amplexati, for amplecti.
Amplexus, imbracynges. Ampliatio, a deferring of judgment. Amplificatio, an
augmentation. Amplifico, care, to augment. Amplior, larger, greatter.
Amplissimus, a, um, greattest, largest. Amplissimus ordo, was used for the
Senate of Rome. Amplissimus magistratus, the highest office. Ampliter, largely,
abundantly, magnifikely. Plautus.
Ampliter occupatus, let with much business. Ampliter testis, witness of all the
hole matter Amplius, more over, more largely. Caesar.
Amplius horas quatuor fortissime pugnauerunt, They fought mightily more than
four hours. Coeperunt amplius tria millia hominum, Liuius.
They took prisoners three thousand men and above. Cicero.
Ampliare, to defer or delay a thing in judgment, to reprie. Amplius
pronuntiare, idem. Ampron, a cord or chain fastened to the yokes, whereby
beasts do draw a wayne. Ampullarius, a bottell maker. Amuleus, the great uncle
of Romulus and Remus Amussitatus, tata, tum, made by line, well proporcyoned.
Amyclae, a city in Lacedemonia, where Castor and Pollux were borne. also an
other city in Italy. Amyclaeus, a, um, of that city. Amylum, is wheat laid
in water.iii. days, and every day the water changed five times, and being
soft, to pour out the water softly, that none other thing do pass, than to
pour in a little and rub the corn, and to skymme away the husks and the
branne, and strayn the residue, and being somewhat dried in a clothe, than to
lay it on new tyles, and set it in the son, and dry it. Anagallis, an
herb, which has a square stalk, and leaves like to peritory of the wall, but
much less, the male has red flowers, the female blewe. some do suppose it to
be our pympernell, some take it to be chykweede.
A ANTE N.
ANabasius, he that rides by post horsis. Hieronymus contra Rufinum.
Anabathrum, Iuuenalis.
a pulpyt or other like place, which stands on high, whereunto a man must go
up by a ladder or grie^es. Anabula, a beast in Aethiope, Plinius.
having a heed like a camel, a neck like a horse, legs like an ox, and is
of color a bright read, full of white spots. Anacephaleosis, a short
recapytulation or repetition of things before rehearsed. Anacharsis, a
philosopher of a meruaylous wysedom, all be it that he was borne in the
barbarous country of Scithia, whom Pliny supposes to have first fou^den the
potters whele: And being in the time that Solon made laws to the Athenienses,
He said, that laws were like to copwebbes, which tied fast little flies, and
the great flies brake them, and went clean through them. In like wise the poor
and mean men are fast wou^den in the penalties and dangers of laws, but
lords and men in great authority daily break laws, and are not corrected.
Anachorita, an hermit: the interpretation thereof is, he that lives a part,
and out of company. Anaclinterium, a mattresse. Anadiplosis, is a doubling
of a word, Spartianus in Ceiouio.
as the last word of the first verse, is the first word of the second verse:
as, Certent and signis ululae, sit Tytirus Orpheus, Orpheus in syluis inter
delphinas Arion. Anaglypha, and anaglypta, vessel or plate of gold or silver
chaced, as cuppis or bolles beaten with the hammer, and not ingraued.
Anaglyptes, he that works such vessel. Anagliptice, ye craft to chase or
i^boce plate. Anagnostes, he that redeth to other men, as bible clerks, or any
other clerk, which redeth while an other writes. Anagoge, the high and
subtylle understanding of scripture. Analecta, fragme^tis of meat, which fall
under the table, and be afterward swept away. Analesia, is a sickness of the
heed, which takes away sensiblenes from the hole partis of the heed, and
comes of the weakness of the stomak, or of to much meat, or of to much
lechery, or drinking much cold water, or to much study, drink, or of
indigestion. Analogia, conuenie^cy or proporcion, whose propretie is to
co^ferre that which is doutfull, with that which is like to it, which is more
certain, to make it more plain. Analogos, proporcionable. Anapestus, a foot
in meter of.iii. sillables, having.ii. the first fete short, the last long.
Anapis, a river in Sicyle, ten furlonge from the city of Syracusis.
Anarchos, without a prince, or without a beginning. Anastrophe, a tournynge
out of a commune order, as, Italia^ contra, for contra Italiam. Anaticula, a
little ducke. Anato^ius, a keeper of duckes. Anautos, a river in Thessalia.
Anaxagoras, a famous philosopher, noble of blood, but more noble in virtue and
wisdom, which abandoning all his possessyon, gave him all holly to the
study of natural philosophy: and when one said unto him, Haste thou no care
for thy countreye, he answered, Yes verily. I have exceeding care for my
country, poyntynge up to heaven with his finger. Also when he had been long
out of his countray, and was eftsoon returned, and beheld his possessions
distroyed and wasted, he said, I had not be^ safe, except these things had be
lost. Anaxarchus, a philosopher, which falling in the indignation of a
tyrant, called Nicoc^e^n, king of Cipres, was by him apprehended, and put into
a great mortar of stone, where he was beaten or pound with iron pestyls:
which tourment he took so patiently, that he doubled these words, worthy of
remembrance, Beat on, beat on Anaxarchus wynd bag, for Anaxarchus thou
bear not. By the which words he accounted his body but a bag full of wind.
Anaximander, a philosopher, which first sound the description of the compass
of the sea and land, and made first the sphere. Ancesa, graven vessel. Anceps,
cipitis, doutfull. sometime it signifies double. also cuttyng on both sides.
Anchises, the father of Aeneas. Anchoratius, a, um, pertaining to an anchor.
Ancillula, a little or poor wenche servant. Anclabra, vessels which priests
used. Anclare, seu antla^e, to empty a vessel. Ancona, a City in Italye,
upon the sea of Venyce. Anculi, and Anculae, goddis and goddessis of serving
womenne. Ancus, he that has a crooked elbow. it was also the name of a king of
Romans. Anchusa, an herb, of whose rote comes a red iuyse, wherewith
sanguyne color is dyed. Ancyra, the name of two cities, the one in Phrigia,
the other in Galatia. Andabatae, certain men that faughte with swords
wynkynge. Andegauia, a countray in France, called Angiewe. Andrachne, an herb
called purcelan. Andrago, a woman having a man's heart. Andricus, an hylle in
Cilicia. Androdamas, a stone, which is like to silver Androgeus, the son of
Minoos, king of Crete, which by envy was slain of the Atheniensis. For the
which many years after the sons of Athenienses were sent to Crete, to be
delivered to the monster called Minotaurus, which was afterward distroyd by
Thefeus. It was also the name of a noble Briton, when Julius Caesar came hither
into this realm of Britayne. Androgynae, people in Asia, being of both kinds
in one person, man and woman. Androgynos, a man having both members of a man,
and also of a woman. Andromache, the wife of the valiant Hector. Andromede, the
wife of Perses, whom he saved from a monster of the sea. Andron, a chaumber,
whereinto men only do come, and not women. Also a space between two houses,
wherinto the rayn falls. Andronitis, idem. Andronae, festis, whereunto only
me^ do com. Andros, an i will between Greece and Asia, directly against the city
of Ephesum. Andruare, old writers used for Recurre, to run again. Anellus,
a little ring. Anemonae, wild popie, with red flowers. Anethum, an herb
called dyll. Anger, a certain serpent, after whose stingynge happens
intolerable peynes. Angerona, was callid the goddess of pleasure, called also
Volupia. Angilae, people in Affrike, of whom the women, the first night that
they be wedded, do accompany with all men, which come to the wedding, but ever
after they be chaste. Anglia, England. Angaria, a constrained service.
Angariae, arum, some do expound it for a post or a currour. Anguimanus, an
Elyphant. Anguinus, na, number, of a serpent, or winding and crepynge like a
serpent. Angustitas, a strayte or strayte place. Anhelator, he that fetches
his wind often, or blows much, poursike. Ania, a Romayne woman, which
being fair and young, after that her husband was deed, was counseled to take
an other, but she would not consent thereto, For if said she, I shall hap to have
as good as I have had, I will not be in fear to lose him: If I shall have an
ill husband, what shall I need, after a good man, to suffer a shrewe?
