Anicetum, idem quod Anethum, dyll. Anicula, a little old woman. Animam
adimere, uel extinguere, to kill. Animam debe^, he owes more than he is
worth, he owes so much, that he has not his life but in lone. Anima,
sometime signifies brethe. Dic amabo, an foetet anima uxori tue? Tell me of
good feloship, does thy wives dreth stink? Plautus.
Animam comprime, hold thy brethe. Anima, sometime signifies wind, sum
time water. Si situlam lamiam caepero, ^^mquam aedepol tu mihi diuino quid
credas post hunc diem, ni ego illi puteo, si occepso, animam omnem
intertraxero, If I take the buckerte, never believe me for a prophet after this
day, if I draw not clean out, if I ones begin, all the water of the well.
Animitus, from the very soul or life. Animo male est, it greueth him at the
very heart. Animum eijcere, to put away affection or fantasye. Anio
praesenti, with a bold spirit or courage Animo obsequi, to take pleasure, to
follow appetyte or will. Animo morem gerere, idem. Animum explere, to
acco^plishe will or desire Animum adiungere, to apply or set mind to a thing.
Animum aduertere, to take heed. Animum appellere, to dispose or apply him to do
a thing. Animum adiscere ad uirginem, to set his love on the maiden. Animum
recipere, to take heart or courage. Animus tibi pendet, thou stand in doubt
what thou may do. Animo bono esse, to be of good chere. Animus impotens, an
impatient courage. Animo iniquo pati, to suffer impatiently. Animos lactare, to
draw men's hearts with fair promyses, to make fools feign, to bring men in
fools paradyse. Anime mi, my dear heart. Animule, idem. Plautus.
Animi causa, for pleasure. Cur eam emit? T. Animi causa, Wherefore did he bye
her? T. For his pleasure. Animatus, ta, tum, having a fantasye or favor to a
thing, or to be disposed. Ita animatus fui, Plautus.
itaque nunc sum, ut ea te patera donem, I had such a fantasy, and yet have,
that I would give the cup to you. Amabo s^ quid animatus est facere, fac iam
vt sciam, If he be disposed to do any thing, let me know it. Animaduerto,
uertere, to take heed, to perceive. Experrecta nutrix animaduertit dormientem,
Plautus.
circumplicatum serpentis amplexu, The nouryce awaked, and perceived the child
being on sleep, wrapped all about in the wyndynge of the serpent. Terent.
Da^e operam and cu^ silentio animaduertite, Take you head, and with silence
perceive what I will say to you. It is also to punysshe or correct, Cicero.
Ea sunt animaduerte^da peccata maxim, quae difficillime praecauentur, Those
offenses ought to be most sharply corrected, which most hardlye are
eschewed. Caesar*
Hac re animaduersa, Caesar iubet signa conuerti, After that that matter was
punyshed, Caesar commanded to advance the standerdes. Animaduersio,
punyshement, correction. Animaduersi, they which are punysshed or corrected.
Animaduersor, he that punysheth. Anio, anienis, a river in Italye in the field
called Tibu^tinum. Anisum, an herb called Anyse, whereof comes anyse seed.
Annarius, a, um, aged. Anicularis, re, idem. Annibal, the most valyant
captain of the Carthagine^sis, a man most expert in marcial prowess, who
at.xxv. years of age subdued Spain, percyd the mountains, called Alps, where
before never was passage, dystroyed all Italy, and slew the more part of the
nobylitie of Rome, and kept wars with the Romans.xxx. years. Anniuersalis,
the compass of the year. Anniuersarius, a, um, that every year returns at
one time. Annonarius, and annotinus, a, um, pertaining to vyttayle. Anodina,
things, which do put away pain or grefe. Anomalum, unequal, diverse,
rough. Anonymum, without a name. Anonium, an herb called dead nettylle or
archaungelle. Anophytus, sprongen or grown upon a thing. Ansatus, ta, tum,
having a handell. Ansanctus, on every part holy. Ansula, the diminutiue of
ansa. Antae, Iambes. also posts of a door. Antaeus, was a giant in Libia,
which was xl. cubits long, as it appeared by his sepulcher found by
Sertorius in a cite called Tigena. Antandros, a city in Phrigia. Antarcticus,
the fyfthe cerkle in heaven, called the southepole. Antariu^ bellu^, bataile
before a cite or town. Anteambulo, lonis, a lackey or other servant that gothe
before his master. Antefixa, things cast in mouldes, and set over doors.
Antelapides, stones set at both the sides of a door for strength.
Antelucani ue^ti, wyndes that do blow from the water, or from some creek.
Anteluco, an aduerbe, before day. Anteluculo, an hour before son. Antenor, a
prince of the Troianes, which betrayed the city of Troy: he first inhabited
the countray of Venice. Ante oculos, before his eyes: but it signifies further
of than Coram oculis. Antermini, the inhabitants of the marchis or frontiers
of a contray. Anterote, love mutually set between two persons. Antesum,
antefui, antcesse, to excel an other in any thing. Anteuibanus, a, um, nyghe
to the city: as Anteurbanum praedium, a manor nygh to the city.
Antexpectatus, ta, tum, come before that he was looked for. Anthedon, a kind of
medlars, which has leaves like an almonde tree, the fruit less then the
common medlar, but much plesaunter, and will be lengar kept. Anthemis, an
herb called chamomyll. Anthrax, cis, a stone called a carbuncle, which
shyneth in the night: it is also an aposleme or swelling callid a carbu^cle or
botch. Anthracides, a stone, in the which there seems to be sparks as it were
of fire. Anthracinus, na, um, black as a cole. Anthraceus, a colyar.
Anthracia, a burning cole. Anthropophagi, people in Asia, which eat men.
Anthropomorphitae, were heretics, which of a folyshe symplicitie affirmed,
that god had members like a man. Antibacchius, a foot in meter, having the
first syllable and the last short, and the myddell syllable long.
Anticthones, people dwelling in the uttermost part of the world, directly
against us. Anticyra, an I Will in Asia, where the herb called Elleborus grows,
which purges melancoly, and there it may be taken with out any danger: whereof
grew this proverb spoken to men in their melancholy, Nauiga ad anticyras: Go
sail to Anticyra. Antidora, gift for gift, one for a another. Antigerio, old
writars used for very shortly, forthwith, or the thing were done.
Antimerabole, a figure in speech, where words are repeted to a contrary
sentence: as, Non vt edam uiuo, sed vt viuam edo. I live not to eat, but I
eat to live. Antiochia, a great city in Siria, another at the riuage of
Persia. Antiochus, the name of diverse kings of Siria. Antiperistasis is that
thing, whereby where heat comes cold is expelled, where cold is, heat is
expelled: by this, well water in the winter time is warm, for as much as the
high parts of the air being cold, the heat withdraws him to the lowest
parts. like wise in the body of man the spirit is kept in more feruente by
the outward cold, by the joint conscent and tolleratio^ of al parts of the
body. Antipater, was a philosopher, borne in the city of Tirus, of the sect of
Stoici, which from the time of his birth, until his death, had always a
fever, and not withstandyng he lived until he was old. Antipathia, a natural
dyfference or repugnancy of things. Antipelargesis, one good torn for
another. Antiphrasis, a word or sentence having a contrary meaning: as,
Parcae, the mynisters of death be so called, because they spare no man.
Antipodes, people which do inhabit the part of the world, in respect of the
roundnes thereof, underneath us, that it seems that their feet be against our
feet. Antiqui homines, men of the old facion. Antiquus hospes, mine host of
long time. Antiqua ratio, the manner of time passed. Vergilius.
Antiqua terra, a noble countray. Terra antiqua, potens armis, et vberae
glebae, A noble countray puissaunt in wars, and of a fertile soil.
Antiquatio, an abolicion of a law. Antiquum obtinere, to keep the old facion.
Antistitor, he that stands before them that do work and controlleth them.
Antithesis, a figure, where one letter is set for a another: as olli, for illi.
Antitheton, a figure, whereby one contrary is joined with a another. Frigida
pugnabant calidis, humentia siccis. Quidius i^ Metamor.
Mollia cu^ duris, sine po^dere habentia po^dus. Cold things contended with
them that were hot, moist things with dry, Hard things with soft, light
things with heavy kept not one note. Antium, a city in the part of Italy
called Latium. Antlia, Martialis.
a pumpe or like thing to draw up water. Antaeci, people which dwell in the
contrary Zone or gyrdell, to Anticthones. Antrum, a den under the earth.
Anubis, was a god of the Egiptians, which they honored for Mercurius. Anxur, a
city, called also Tarr^sins. Anygrus, a river in Thessalia.
A, ANTE O.
AOnia, the countray called Thracia. Aonius, a, um, of that countr^y. Aornos, a
place, whereunto no bird may come.
A, ANTE P.
Plautus.
APage, fie, fie. Apage, haud nos deceat fugitiuos imitari: Fie, fie, it will not
beseme us to play the michers. Apage te, get the hens. Apage a me, have away
from me. Apalaestris, he that can neither wrastell nor do any other maistrie.
Apamia, the name of oone city in the less Asia, an another in Parthia.
Aparine, an herb that growethe in corn feldes, which is rough. and cleaneth
to the garments of them, which pass by it, and has a white flower, the stead
like to a nauyll: I suppose that it be goose grass or clyuers. Apathes, were
philosophers, which of a froward and stubborn nature, held opinion that a
wise man had none affections or passions. Apedes, a by^de, whose fete be so
little, that they seem to have none. I suppose they be martlettes. Apelles, the
most excellen^e paynter that ever was. Apello, lere, pulsum, to amoue or put
of from ^ thing. Appenni^us, the part of the mountains of Alps, which
begin at Grane. Aperte, openly, plainly, evidently, without dissimulation or
color. Apertus, ta, tum, open, plain, evident, discovered, without color or
cloak. Apesus, suntis, a mountain in Grece^ Apexabo, bone, a pudding callid a
bludding Aphaeresis, a figure, whereby a letter or syllable is taken from a
word: as Pone met^, for depone metum, mi, for mihi, tun, for tu ne. Aphilos,
he that has no friend. Aphr^ct^, a little bark or baygantine. Aphrodisia,
days dedicate to Venus, or veneriall pastymes. Aphronitrum, the some of
saltepeter, callid of the Arabiens, Maurach. Apiculus, the diminutiue of Apox.
Apinus, a tree, whereof comes pitche. Apina, a tryfle. Apirla, (...) enasse.
Apis, called also Serapis, (...), whom the Egypri^s honored Sspan^ chief god.
Apla^es, the part of heaven, which never moves. Apluda, wh^^ien ^^oone.
Aplusite, et aplustris, erum, the taklynge of a ship. Apoculypsis, slos, a
revelation. Apocleti, counsaylors of the privy counsel. Apocope, a figure, by
the which a letter or fillable i^ taken away, is peculi, for peculij. Apocopi,
men being golded. Apocroti, ^^on that be hard and miserable in living.
Apocryphus, a um, hid, not known. Apocryphi libri, books, the authors whereof
be ^^^nowen. Apocyno^, a little bone in the left side of a frogge, wherewith it
is supposed, things may be done, which were not expedient to be openly
known. Apodixia, an euydence, demonstration. Apodyterium, the place by a
bayne, where (...) which will be bayned, do put of t^^yr clothes. Apogaei,
wyndes that do arise out of the ground. Apogeum, an habytation under the
ground. Apolactizo, are, to strike with the heles also to despise or set at
naught. Apollinaris, an herb called a henbane. Apollinares ludi, plays made
in the honor of Apollo. Apollo, linis, whom the gentyles honored for god,
referrynge to him the inuencion of musyke, of poetry, and of phisike: It is
sometime taken for the son. Apollonia, the name of a cite in Epiro, now
callid Malonis, an other in Creta, an other in ^^ri^, also an i will by Thracia.
Apolloniarae, people of Apollonia. Apo^^^^, a broke of hot water by Padus.
Apoplesticus, he that is taken with the palsy. Apostope^^s, where s^^^what is
left our, specially in speaking, and left to the conie^^u^^ of them that be
herers. Apostasia, rebellyon or forsakyng of a man's profyssion or allegiance.
Aposta^a, a rebelle or rennagate. Apost^ophe, a conuertion in speaking from one
to an another. Apotelesma, a prouos^^^tion* or declaration of the signyfications
of sterres at a man's nativity, or the beginning of any thing, what thereof
shall happen. Apo^^^psi^, a dedycation or consecration, proprely of men into
gods. Apo^^^^^, a decoction of diverse herbs and spyces. Apparere quaestioni,
to serve process as sergeantes and baylyffes done. Apparo, are, to apparayle
or trymme, to be ready to do a thing, to prepare or ordeine. Apellare Caesare^,
to apele to the Emperor. Appendicula, a diminutiue of Appendix. Appia uia, the
name of a high way at Rome Appiana poma, a kind of appulles as great as
quinces, and having as great a savor as they. Applicat primum ad Chrisidis
patrem se: He first made repair to Christ's father. Apronia, an herb called
also Vitis nigra, a black vine, which runs up, and wyndeth about trees and
stalks of herbs, and has a leaf like an yuy, but greatter, and bears
beryes in clusters, which at the beginning are green, and black when they
be ripe, also the rote is black without, and within is yelowe like box.
Approbo, aui, are, to approve or allow. Appropinquo, are, to approach, to
draw nyghe to. Appropinquatio, an approchynge or drawinge nyghe to. Appropero,
aui, are, to make have to come. Aprurius, et Aprugnus, a, um, of a bore.
Aprunum, uei Aprugnum callum, the brawne of a bore. Apsis, the fely of a carte
wheel. Apsorus, an I Will in the Venecian See. Aptera, a city in the countray of
Licia, and a town in Crete. Apud eum est primus, he is his pryncypall mynyon.
Terentius
Apud me priores parts habet, he may do most with me. Terentius
Facio te apud illum deum, I will make him to take the for a god. Per eam te
obsecramus ambae, si ius, si fas est, uti aduersa eius per te tecta, Terentius
tacitaque apud omnes sint, we both desire you on her be half, if it may be
by any means possible, that by your polycy her mysfortune may be keuered, and
from al men kept secret. Apud aliquem mentiri, to make a lie to one. Apud nos
imperium tuum est, we remember your commandment. Salust.
Apud animum meum statuo, I determyne in my mind. Apud forum, In the market,
apud aedes, In the house. apud horcum, in hell. Cic. in off.
Apud quem, in whose presence. Apud maiores nostros, In the time of our
forefathers. Terent.
Apud se non est, he is out of his wit, or he is not in his right mind. Vix
sum apud me, ita animus co^motus est metu, spe, gaudio. mirando hoc tanto, tam
repentino bono: I am well nyghe out of my wit, my mind is so vexed with
fear, hope and joy, with this good chance, which is so wonderful, so
great, and so sodaynely happened. Apud te sis, think what thou haste to do,
remember thy self. Apud ignem, by the fire. apud aquam, Salust.
apud quem, by whom, apud eum, by him. Apud te exemplum experiendi ^abes,
Plautus.
noneges foria: ye have the experience at home, ye need not to seek for it
abroad. Apulia, a countraye in Italy, marchynge on the sea called Hadriaticum.
Apus, odis, a bird like a swallowe, but he has larger wings, and is most
commonly about the sea cost a where always he either flies or houereth in the
air, and bredeth in a rock. Apyrena, sweet pomegranates. Apyrotus, a stone
that no fire may damage, or deface.
A ANTE Q.
AQuaelicium, rain water used in medicine. Aquaintercus, cutis, water which
runs between the skin and the flesh, the dropesy. Aquarioli, boys
which do attend upon common harlottes. Aquarius, one of the.xii. signs.
Aquarius, a, um, partaynynge to water, as aquarius sulcus, a forow, by the
which water is drayned. Aquifolia, a wild medlar, Vide The^ ophrastu^.
or a tree like a wild medlar. Aquilegium, a gourde of water, which comes of
rain. Aquileia, a city in Italye, in the countreye whereof the people are
called Carni. Aquula, a little water.
A ANTE R.
ARabarches, a lord of Arabi^. Arabia, a great country ioynyng to Judea and
Siria, Araby. Araba, a^abi^, a man or woman of Araby. Arachue, the name of a
woman, which first invented spynnyng of lynnen, and making of nets. it is
also taken for lynnen yarne, or the woufe. Arachneus, a little beast, which
gothe a soft pace. Arachnion, fine threde. Arachosia, a country in Asia.
Araciae ficus, fygges broad and white, which do grow on a little stalk.
Aracynthus, a mountain in Greece, in the countray called Aetolia. Araneolus, a
young or little spyder. Araris, (...) arar, a river in France, which runs
out of the countray of Languedocke by Barbone and Burgoyn, into the river of
Rone. Ararus, a river of Scithis, why he r^^^^oth through the realms of
Armeny. Arath, a countraye in A^^eny wonderful fertyle. Aratro, a^^, ari, to
ploughe eftsoon land that is sown, to make the ground fat. Araxis, a
river in Armeny, where it is supposed, that the arch of Noyabode, when the
stodde ceased. Arbea, a city in Judea, where Adam and other three patriarchs
were buried. Arboses, old writers used for Arbos, Arcadia, a countray in
Greece, in the part called Peloponesus, now Morea. Arcadicus, ca, cum, of
Arcadia. Arcas, ca^is, one of the sons of Jupiter. it is also a man or woman
of Arcadia. Arcatus, ta, tum, bent like a bow. Arce^^laus, a philosopher,
which affirmid by Sophemes, that he nor none other knew any thing. Arcessere,
to purchase or get a thing. Archarius, a treasorer, or coferer. Archidamus,
a noble man of Sparta, who being demanded how much money would serve to the
war of Peloponesus, answered, saying, that war sought for no certaynty.
Archigenes, the name of a famous physician. it is also he that would be taken
for the wisest of his kynne. Archigr^mateus, a chancellor or chyefe
secretary. Archimedes, was a geometricion of Siracasts, in S^eile, which
invented a sphere of glass, in the which all the mo^sons of heaven were
plainly perceived. he made also a done of wood, which contained such an
equal poyse, that it would hang in the air. Archyias, a noble philosopher of
the city of Tarentum in Italy, which was of the sect of Pythagoras, and was a
great friend unto (...). Archox, was the chief dignity in Athenes. Archin^^aus,
the master or chyefe of the players. Architectoniae, (...) idem quod
archirectura. Archon^^^, certain hare^^kes, which affirmed that the universal
state of things was not made by god, that by princi^, and they al ^o denied
the resurrection of the body. Arcirna, a little unto, a whalebarowe.
Arconitum, wishynge called Arcenyke. Arctophylax, a certain figure of sterres,
following Charles wayne. Arctos, a figure of sterres called Charles wayne. also
Vrsa mayor. Arctous, and arcticus, ca, cum, of the north. Arcturus, a sterre
which is at the tail of that, which is called arctos, or vrsa mayor. Arcuor,
ari, to be made bent like a bow, Liuius. Plinius. Ouidius in Metamor. 12.
or to be vaulted. Arcatus, ta, tum, idem. Ardeates, people of the city of
Ardea. Ardeola, an hernesewe. Ardere cupiditare, to couete ardently. Ardere
itacundia, to be diflamid with anger. Ardere maximo flagi^tio, to have done, or
to be in^^med of a myscheuous deed. Plautus.
Ardere, to shine. Tyrioque ardebat murice laena, His mantell did shine of
fine purple of Tire. Ardens, burning, ardent, fervent in doing. Ardum, old
writters vsid for arduum. Arelate, a city in France, callid Orleance.
Arenarius, a, u^, pertaining to a fighting place. Areopagitae, were Judges,
which sat in a place by Athenes, and judged causes of murder, and weighty
things concerning the common weal. Areopagus, Marces town, where the said
judges did sytte in judgment. Areopolis, a cite in Araby, callid also Moab
Areopolitae, the inhabita^tes of Areopolis. Arete, in latin virtus, in
english virtue. It was also the name of the wife of Alcinous king of Phoeacis,
of whom Homere writes in Odyssea. Arethyssa and Aretliusa, a river in the
great Armenye. Arethusa, the companion of Diana. it is also the name of a
fountain in Sicile, and of diverse other. Arerium, a city in Tuscan^.
Aretinus, a, um, of that city. Arferis, wine or water offered to the infernal
gods, or rather deuyls. Argentarius co^me^^us, prouisyon of money. Argentari^
cura, care for money^. Plautus.
Arge^tariae illecebre, things getting money Argentaria mopia, lack of money.
Argentaria, a bank of exchange. Argentum uiuum, quycke silver. Argesses, the
western wind. Argeus, a, um, of the city of Argos. Arg^^ plurali, a city in
Laconia. Argiletum, the sepulcher of Argus. it is also a place to here posters
clay is dygged. it was also a street in Rome, where the book sellers ^^^^lled.
Arg^^^^, book sellers dwelling in the said street called argilerum. Argimyssy,
three little isles in Asia, S. ra. li. 13.
by the isles of Mitelenae, and Lesbus. Argis, at the city of Argos. Argo, the
ship wherein Jason and his company sailed in to Colchos, to win the f^y^e
of gold. Argolicus, ca, cum, of Argos. Argonautae, were the noble men, which
accompanied Jason unto Colchos. Argos, singulari: Argi plurali, a city not far
from Athenes, a another in Achara. it is also a countray, part of Greece.
Plautus.
Arguere, alique^ pecuniae interuersae, to accuse one for stealing of money.
Arguta diuisio, a subtle division. Argutu^ caput, a sharp or pikyd hedde like
a sugar lofe. Argyranche, the silver sykenesse. Argyraspidae, men bearyng
shildes of silver Argytitis, the spume or foam of silver. A^^adne, a lady, the
wife of Theseus, whom he forsook, notwithstanding that she had sauyd his
life. Aricia, a city in Italy. Aricinum noemus, a wood by the said city where
Numa king of Romans feigned to speak with Aegeria the fayry. Plautus.
Aricinus lacus, a brook by Aricia. Aridus homo, a dry fellow, of whom no
thing may be gotten: some do call him, a pelt, Plautus.
or a pynchebeke. Arimaspi, people in the north part of Europa which have but
one eye, and that is in their sorched, which do fight contynually with
^^^phons. Ariminu^, a city in Italy. Arimphaei, people in the north part of
Asia, which all though that they have only woods for their dwelling, and
only beryes for their sustynance, yet keep they justice and peace among them
selves, and be temperate of manners. Herodotus. Ge^^us. Plinius.
Arinca, a corn called Rye. Arion, a famous harper, whom the maryners would
have thrown into the sea, for to have his money: but he desyryng them to let
him play a song on his harp or he dyed, afterward lepte into the water, but
a dolphyn receyuyng him on his back, and brought him to land a live.
Aristathea, the malowe with the greatlese. Aristarchus, a famous gra^marien,
which corrected the books of Homere, tryeng out what verses were his, and
what verses were counterfayt. Therefore they use to call him Aristarchus, that
is a sharp co^rectour of other men's works. Aristides, a noble man of
Athenes, who for his plain and just. dealing, as well in deeds as in words,
had the surname given him, Ryghtuous, or Just: He that reads this man's
life, in the lives of Plutarche, shall think him before all other to be
followed by a cou^saylour or governor under a prince. Aristippus, a
philosopher, which first did put the principal good thing in the pleasant
mocions of the mind: the pryncipall ill thing, in gryefe. Aristocratia, the
form of governance of a weal public, where they do rule, which are of
most virtue. Aristolochia, an herb, whereof be two kyndestone is called long,
the other round. The round has leaves in facion like yuy, but somewhat rounder,
wherein is a sharp and soft odoure, the flower white like a little bonet upon a red knoppe, the roots are round and many. The long Aristolochia, has
longer leaves, small branches, and a purple flower, which stynketh: and when it
spryngeth, it is of the facyon of a pear, the rote thereof is long, and of the
greatness of a man's fyngar: both of them do bear beryes like to capers,
within of box color, which are bitter and stynkynge. Aristomenes, a man of
Messene, which was called Iustissimus, most just. This man, when he was
dead, was founden to have his heart all heary. Aristophanes, a famous poet,
which wrate Comedies, wherein he tau^ted them, whom he did not favor: all be
it he was very eloquent, and much mirth is in his works Aristophoru^, a
disshe, wherein meat is borne to dinner. Aristoteles, a philosopher, of whom
Quintylyane writes in this wise: whatte say you by Aristotle, whom I wot
not, whither I may judge more excellent in knowledge of things, or in
abundaunce of writing, or in swetnesse of eloquence, or in sharpness of
wit, or else in diuersyte of works. Notwithstanding he was little of
personage, crook backed, ill shapen, and stuttynge. Ariuido, drythe, or
dryenesse. Arma coquinaria, vtensyles of the kechyn* Arm^n^^, a royalme in
Asia, lyeng between the two great mountains, Taurus and Caucasus, and
stretches from Cappadocia to the sea called Caspium. Armeniacum pomum, a pome
citron, or a Eitton, which is like an orange, but that he is somewhat in
length. Arme^^a^iu^, the keeper of an a^^^ry: sometime Esqui^^ de Esquyry.
Armille, an instrument of falshode or craft. Armilustrum, was a festiual day,
in the which the Romans did sacr^^es armed, and trompettes did blow bluddy
soundes. also the place wherein such sacrifyce was made. Palladus. Columel.
Armocea, a wild radyshe. Armoradum, the tendrels or young stalks of wild
radyshe. Josephus.
Armon, a river that comes from the hills of Arabye, and dyuydeth Moabiride
from Amoni^ide. Arnoglossa, an herb callid broad Plantain or waybred. Aroma,
atis, pleasant savor, also spyce. Aromatites, a precious stone, which has
the savor of Mirre. Aromatorius, and aromatopola, he that sells things
having sweet savor. Aros, an herb, called wake Robyn. It is called of some
Serpentaria minor, because it has leaue^ like to Dragons, but brother, and
having black spots, it grows much about hedges. Arpinum, an ancient
town in Italye, famous and noble by the birth of Plautus, Tulli, and Marius.
Arpinas, a man or woman of Arpinum. Arquires, old writers used for an arche^.
Arquus, arqui, the raynbowe. Arrideo, ere, to smyle on one. also to like or
seem pleasant. Plaut
Aedes mihi arridebant, The house lyked me well. Terentius.
Arrige aures, lay to thyn ears, or give an care to that which is spoken.
Salust.
Arrexit animos, it advanced their courage. Arrecta^ii parietes, walls made
with timber and parget, to divide chambers. Arripere se for as, to get him
out of the ^^otes. Plautus.
Arripere sermon^, to take him at his word. Arripere maledictum, to take heed
of an ill report. Cicero.
Quare cum ista sis auth^ri^^^^non debes Marce arripere male dictum (...), aut
ex scurrarum aliquo, conuitio, Wherefore in as much as ye are in this
authority, or of this estimation, ye ought not Maro, to take heed of an ill
word spoken a ^^^de, or of the rebuke of a raylynge (...)* The. est. de claris
gra^.
Arripere conditionem, to take the offer. Arrugia, a Conen, Ars parasitica, the
feate of flatterye. Ar^^^es, was the several name of the kings of Parthia.
Aristotel.
(...), beast, which is both male and female as some do say that a (...) is
one year male, (...) other year female. Arraba, a measure of the Egyptian^
contaynynge (...) and.xii. Romayn mesures, called Sextarii. Artaxa^^, a city
in (...). Artaxerxes, the name of diverse kings of Persia, of the which one of
them called Artaxerxes with the long hand, vse^ to say, that it was much
more kingly to give, than to take. Artemisia, was the name of a noble princess
which was the wife to Mans^lus, king of Caria, who was of a notable
chastity, and in love toward her husband so excelled, that when he was dead,
she caused his heart to be dried in a vesselle of gold into pou^er, and by
little and little drank it up saying, That their two hearts should never
depart a sonder, and that she thought, that there might be made no worthy
sepulcher for it, but her own body. Natwithsta^dynge she made for his body
such a sepulcher, that for the excellents wark^manshyp that was in it, also
the beauty, and costlynesse, it was taken for one of the meruayles of the
world, and for the notable saame thereof, all sumptuous and great sepulchers
were afterward callydde Mausole^. She found also an herb called Artemisia,
M^gwort, or Motherwort in english, of great virtue in women's diseases.
Artemisius, the month of May among the Macedonians. also a hill in Arcadia.
Artemon, monis, a trouble, whereby ropes do run. It may also be taken for any
instrument, which has troukles. Artitu^, well instructed in sciences.
Art^^^rica pas^io, called also Morbus articularis, the joint syckenesse, is
thus divided into Coxendix, called Sciatich, which is in the ^uckle bone,
Podagra, the gout of the legs and fete, and Chiragra, Galenus. Plautus.
the gout of the fyngers. Ar^^ue^^is, ^dem. Articularius, he that has the
gout. Articulate, articulately, as when one does express every syllable.
Arth^^^^^^, ^am do suppose it to be that herb and flower, which is called
Prym^^ose. Artocrea, may be called a pastye or pie, with flesh or fyshe
bakes. Artolag^^^^^, ^y^e cake bread. Plautus.
Artop^a, a bakynge pan, wherein they brake tarte^^ or other, things, made
of fine paste. Some take (...) vesselle to (...). Artoptestie, tartes or cake
shaken in a pan (...), browed bread, or breadde (...) wheat. Arto^^^^^^,
people, which did^^ offer unto god (...) and these. Aruales fratres, were
supposed to be the foster brethren of Romulus, to whom he gave the dignity of
priesthode, to make sacrifice for growing and increace of corn, and
preservation of the corn feldes. Aruisium, an hill on the sea cost of the i will
called Chium, where grows the wynes called Aruisia vina. Arunca, a town in
Italy. Aruncus, the bearde of a got.
A ANTE S.
ASarum, an herb, whose leaves are like unto yuie, but they be less and
rou^der, and has a good savor, the flower is purple, like to the flower of
henbane, but it sauoreth swetely, and grows between the leaves by the root,
the stalk is edged, and somewhat roughe, the roots ar small, crooked, and like
to grass, full of knottes: it is commonly callid Asarabaccha, some call it
wild Spikenarde. Asarotum, pauynge tile with pictures enelyd, which may not be
swept with a besom, but the dust and other thing must be swept with a wynge and
gathered up. Ascalon, a city in Palestina. Ascaloniae, a kind of onyons called
scalions. Ascanius, the son of Eneas. Asci^ae, Arabians. Asclep^ades, the
name of a famous physician. Alsoo of a philosopher, which being blind, was
demanded in skorne, what his blyndnes did profit him, and he answered, that he
had the more company by one boy that did lead him. Ascopera, a bag of
lether. Ascra, a city in Boeotia, where Hesiodus the poet was borne.
Ascriptus, ta, tum, inrollyd. Ascripti milites, sowldiours, whose names are
regystred or entered with other. Ascriptiuus, idem quod ascriptius, he that is
regystred with other. Asellus, a little or young ass. also the name of a see
fyshe, called an haddocke. Asianus, a, um, of Asia. Asiaticus, a surname given
to oone of the Scipyons, because that he subdewed the less Asia. Asilus, a
great fly, which byteth beasts, and is called a horse fly. Asion, an owl,
which has feathers on every side of her heed like unto ears. Asiortum, a
kind of spyders, with white strakes, of whom if that one be stunge, his knees
shall bow and wax faint. Asomatos, vnpalpable, or that ca^ not be felt
Asopus, a river in Achaia. Asotia, ryotte. Asotus, ryottous. Aspalathus, a
thorn growing in the east parts of the world, the rynde whereof is somewhat
read, and within, the wodde is of a sad purple, and smellith very sweet, and
therefore is used in parfumes. Asparagus, an herb called of common apotycaries
Sparagus, in english Sperage. Aspello, aspuli, aspellere, Plautus*
to drive away from one. Asperum uinum, a roughe wine. Asper numus, money new
coined. Aspersus infamia, stained with dishonor. Cicero*
Aspergere comitatem seueritate, to myxt famyliaritie and gravity together.
Asphaltum, a water in Syria, wherein nothing that has life may be drowned. It
is called Mare mortuu^, the deed see. It is supposed, that in that place stood
the cities of Sodoma. It is also a certain lyme myxte with brymstone, which
being ones hette, may never be extinete. Asphodelus, an herb called daffadyll.
Aspidisca, a little tergate or shield. Aspilates, a stone like to silver.
Assae, dry stones. Assatura, roasted meat. Assectator, a companyon. Assentio,
to perceive. Plaut.
Sed assentio aperiti fores, quae absorbent quicquid uenit infra pessulos, But
I perceive the doors are opened, which deuouren all that commethe within the
boltes. Assentatio, flatterye. Assentatiuncula, a flattering tale. Assequor,
assequi, to render as much to one as he has deserved. Cicero
Nullam partem uidear tuorum meritorum assecutus, It may not be found in me,
that I have rendered to you any thing after your merytes, or have done so
much for you, as ye have deserved. Assequi nomen, to get renoume. Plinius.
Asser, asseris, a pole. Asserculi, and assiculi, little bourdes or lathes.
Asserere aliquem manu, to set one at liberty or to manumyse a bondsman.
Asserere in seruitu^em, Plautus.
to bring in bondage or seruytude. Asserere ab iniuria, to defend from wrong
or danger. Asserere se studijs, to leave al other besynes, to apply study.
Assertor, totis, he that sets one at liberty, or defends him from
bondage. Assidela, a bishops seat or chair, wherein he sytteth when he
ministers. Assidere literis, to be always in study of letters. Assiduus
scriptor, an author approved, whose sentence* is holden for certain and true.
Assiduitas, continuance in a thing. Cicero.
Assidue, and assidu^, aduerbes, which do signify continually. Assigna^a
fame, to apply him self to get renoume. Assimilo, are, to do a thing like to
an another man, to (...) or follow one. Assimilis, le, like or semblable.
Assimiliter, al semblably. Plautus.
Assimulo, are, to feign to do a thing, and not to do it. Assipondium, a
pound weight. Assisia, one of ye names of Pallas or Minerua Assoleo, lere, to
be wont or accustomed. Assono, are, to sown or make a sown. Assauoce cantare,
to sing without an Instrument. Varro. Cato.
Assuefactio, a bryngyng of one in custom. Assuesco, scere, to use of a
custom. Assumptio, a taking. Assure, a city in Judea, builded by king
Solomon. Assus, a, um, tosted or roasted. Assyria, a region in Asia, called now
Syria, in english Surrye, having on the east Indie, on the west the river of
Tigris, on the south Medi or Mede, on the north the mount of Caucasus. Asta,
depart not, stand still. Astachus, a kind of crabbes of the sea. Astare, to
stand by, or to be present. Astare in genua, to knele. Astare aduocatus, to
assyst or speak for one. Plautus.
Astaroth, an old city sometime belonging to Og, king of Basan, in the which
dwelled gyantes, and afterward it came to the lotte of the tribe of Manasses,
and is in the countray of Bethania. There be two castelles of that name nine
miles a sonder, between the city of Adara and Abella. Asterte, a goddess of
the Sirians, to whom Solomon to please his concubyne, raised an Altar.
Asterias, a kind of herons, I suppose that it is an Egrette. Asthma, matis, a
sycknesse, where one may not fetch his wind but with much difficulty, with
weasynge of the breast: which happens by straytenesse of the pypes stopped
with toughe fleume, or of sum impostume grown in the pypes. Astomi, people
of Indie, having no mo^thes, which lyuen by air and smelle of sweet things.
Astrea, sygnyfieth Justice. Astringere fidem, to promise. Astringere se furti,
to yield or make him self gyltie of felony. Astroites, a stone like to a
^^shes eye. Astrologus, an astrologie^, he that studieth the speculation of
astronomy. Astronomus, an astronomer. Plinius.
Astruer^ digni^ati alterius, to augment an other man's dignity or honor.
Astruitur his, is put for more over, Plinius in Epistolis.
or furthermore. Astur, any thing of Asturia, a cite in Spain. Astur equus, a
spanysshe horse, called a genette. Astur co^es, idem. Astura, a town and river
in Italy. Asturia^, a city in Spain. Asuestinum, lynnen threede, which may
not be burned. Asymbolus, he that comes to a bankette, without appoyntement,
an vnboden geste.
A ANTE T.
AT* yet, or at the least way* Cicero pro Flacco.
Si non propiquitatis, at aetatis suae, si no^ hominis, at humanitatis rationem
haberet, All though he had not consideration of kindred, yet should he have had
regard to his age, and though he caryd not for the person, yet should he have
had respect unto good humanity. Arabulus, a fervent wind, which when it
blows in the realm of Naples, pestylence immediately insueth. Atalanta, a
maiden, which was daughter to the king of Argiues, which keeping perpetual
virginity, haunted forestes and woods, and did slay wild beasts, and was
the first that wounded the greatte bore of Calidonia. Attalus, a king in the
less Asia, of marvelous richesse, of whom all magnifyke and stately things,
are called Attalica. Attamen, but yet. Atechna, things vnkunningly handled.
Ategia, a bouthe, or place made up with trees and boughs. Ater panis, broune
breadde. Atharus, a bird with four legs, having the longest behind.
Athanatos, immortal. Athenae, narum, the city of Athenes. Athenaeum, a place
at Rome, where all scyences were radde. Athenodorus, a philosopher, which
left with Octauian the Emperor this lesson, wha^ he took his leave of him:
Roble prince, wha^ thou art attached with wrath, neither say nor do any thing,
until thou have by thy self perused the.xxiiii. greek letters, and remembered
the order of places where they stand, to thi^^ent that the passion of ire, by
withdrawyng the mind to an another thing, might languishe and vanishe away.
Atheromata, little pousshes in the neck, and under the arms. Atheos, he that
does not believe that god is. Athesis, a river in Italy that passes by the
cities of Verona and Tridentum called Trente. Athos, a hylle in Macedonia, of a
wonderfulle heyght. Athrax, a city in Thessalia. Athracia ars, art magike.
Atlanticae insulae, the yles called now fortunatae, where fruit and herbs
do grow without labor. Atlantides, the daughters of Atlas, alsoo certain
sterres. Atlas, Atlantis, the name of a king, which first taught the course
of sterres, and therefore it was feigned of him, that he sustained heaven on his
sholders. It is also the name of a hylle in Barbaria, high and small, that it
perceth the clouds. Atlantes, Moors dwelling about that hyl. Atocion, a
medicyne, which makes a woman to be barrayne. Atocius, a certain spyder which
is heary. Plautus in (...)*
Atque, than. Illi sunt alio ingenio atque tu, They be of an another manner of
wit than thou art. Non Appollinis magis verum, atque hoc responsum est,
Appolloes answer was never truer than this is. Plautus in (...).
Atque adeo, and that more is. Esurio hercle, atque adeo nunc haud parum sirio,
I am hungrye, and that more is, I am a thyrste not a lyttelle. Atque eccum, but
lo where he is. Atractilis, an herb, having a long stem and rough, with
long leaves growyng by the top, the residue without leaves, the top full of
pricks, and a yelowe flower, women were wont to make spyndelles of the
stalks thereof. Atricapilla, a bird, with black feathers on the crown of his
heed. Atrifer, a rushe that bears a black sede. Atriolum, a little ynner
court. Atriplex, an herb called orache or arage. Atritas, blackenesse.
Atrophia, an affecte or discra^ye, wherein the body can not be nouryshed with
any thing but consumes with leanness. Atrophus, he that has that affecte.
Atropos, one of the fatal ladies, which is feigned to break the threde of
life: it is sometime put for necessitte of death. Atta, is he that gothe so on
the soles of his fete, that he swepeth the ground, rather than walks.
Attagen, and attagena, a byrd, which is found in Ionia, and is very delycate,
and has feathers of sundry colors, and being at large, is always singing o^
chatteringe, when he is taken, he makes no noise, nor seems to have any
voic^. They are deceived that take him for a woodcocke. Attalica toga, a gown
of tynsette. Attelanae fabulae, were comedies or enterludes, which only were
^iestes and merry scoffs, or bourdynges. Attelae, a city nygh to Naples.
Attentu^, he that hereth diligently, attentive. Attentus ad rem, careful to
get goods. Attero, triui, terere, to rub against a thing. Atterere famam,
Salust.
Post ubi ^orum famam atque pudorem attriuerat, maiora alia imperabat, After
that he had made them consume their good name and honesty, he set them in
hand with other greatter attemptatis. Attica, a countray in Greece, wherein
stood the famous city of Athenes, the nourice of all scyences. Attice, an
aduerbe, sygnifyenge in the eloquence of speech of Athenes. Atticismus, the
form of that speech. Atticisso, sere, to speak like an Atheniense. Attigo,
idem quod attingo. Attilus, a fysshe, which is in the river of Po, very great,
and with long rest waxes meruaylous fat, which Franciscus Philelphus
supposed to be a sturion, but that is denied by Iouius, which affirms that he
is greatter than a sturion, and unlike to him in form, taste, and price.
Attingit me sanguine, he is nigh of my blod. Plinius.
Attingere senectam, to come to great age. Attingere parts naturae, Vergili.
in Geor.
to com to the knowledge of natural causes. Attingere studia, to savor of
letters. Attingitur, it is night. Attondeo, attondere, to clyppe or sheare a
thing nygh. Attondere arbores, to shrede trees. Plautus.
Attondere auro, to rydde one of his money, to take all away from him.
Attributus, ta, tum, attributed. Attributa pecunia, money delivered to be
given to an another manne.
A ANTE V.
AVarus, coueytous of money. Aucupare sermonem alicuius, to harken or take heed
what one says. Audin tu? Herest thou not? Audire been, to have a good name.
Audire male, to have an ill name. Audiens dicto, ready to do that he is
commanded, at commandment, obedyent* Audienciam facere, to command or make
silence, as they do wihche are cryers in places of justice. Auello, auulsi,
auellere, to pluck away by vyolence. Auellere se a meretrice, to withdraw
him, or go away by force from an harlotts. Auenaria, a kind of grassehoppes,
which appers not until the corn be ripe. Auentinus, an hylle at Rome. Auerni,
people in France, callid Auergnes. Auernus, a look in Campani^, which was
dedicate unto Pluto king of Hell, where ^^on supposed, that there was an entry
or passage to hell. Auersus, a, um, strange, unacquainted. Vergilius.
Auertere ab aliquo loco, to let or prohybyte one to enter. Aueruncus, god
which puts away all euylle. Aufero, abstuli, auferre, to take away.
Terentius
Aufer te hinc, get the hense. Aufer te domum, get the home. Plautus.
Auferas iurgium, leave thy chiding. Auferre litem, to get by action or
process of the law. Maiore mulcta mulcta^, quam li^em auferunt, Plautus in
Ruden.
He makes them to spend more than they may win by their suite. Aufer nugas,
leave these trifelynges, leave your mockes. Auferre petitionem, to have the
thing that he asks. Plautus in Cur.
Tuo arbitratu, dum auferam abs te id quod peto, Even as ye will, so that I
may have the thing that I ask or demand. Auferre pignora, to take a
dystresse or gage. Plautus in Asina.
Auferre tacita, to make oone to confess a thing secret. Suspendas potius
me, quam tacita haec auferas, Thou may rather hang me, thanne make me
confess that secret. Terentius in Andria.
Auferre inultum, to goo quyte without punyshement. Ergo pretium ob stultitiam
fero, sed inultu^ nunquam auferet, I am well rewarded for my folyshenes, but
yet he shall not go quyte away without punyshement. Cic. Tusc. quest. 3. Ennius.
Auferri sibi, to be vexed in mind, or from him self. Augifico, for augeo.
Augere auxilia, to make a new host, after a discomfyte. Auguratus, the
dygnitie of them, which were Augures, of whom was a college in Rome: as
there be now of priests in Cathedral churches. Augurium, dyuination or
telling before of things, which shall happen, specially by the flight, or
voices of birds. Cicero ^ L. Murena
Auguror, ari, idem quod Augure. Auguror opinio^e, I suppose in mine opinyon
Augusta Caesaria, a city in Spain, upon the river of Iberus. Augusta
emerita, a city in Portugal. Augusta Vindelicorum, a goodly and beautyfulle
city in Germanye, now callydde Awsbourghe. Augustalis, ale, the Emperors
Palayce or Pauyllyon. Augustus, a place consecrate, full of majesty and
honor, it is also a name of addicion given to emperors. Auiatius, and
auiaria, he and she that has the charge of the keeping of pultrie or
wildfoule. It may also be used for a pultar, which sells pultrie. Auiarium,
the place where pultrie is kept. also busshes set for birds to haunte and
sytte in. Auide, affectuously, couetously, ardantly. with great desire. Auidis
moribus, of an exceeding couaytous appetite. Auiditas, desire of a thing,
couetyse, ardant affection. Auidus cibi, hungrye. Terent.
Auilla, a lamb lately yeaned. Auius, uia, uium, Plaut. Vergil. Salust.
whereby there is no passage or way. Auius, he that gothe out of the way. Aula,
of old writers was vsid for olla, a pot. Aulula, a little pot, whereof comes
Aulularia, a comedye of Plautus, wherein is declared the covetous mind of one,
which hid his money in a pot, thynkyng that no man knew hit but him
self, and yet was he deceived of it. Aulicotia, boiled meat. Aulicus, a
courtyar. Aulicus, ca, cum, of the court, Sueton, in Nerone.
as aulicus apparatus, courtely apparayle, but most proprely the apparayle of
pryncis. Aulis, lidis, a lyttelle countraye or shyre in Boeotia in Greece. It
was also a great city and haven, where the princis of Greece assemblyd, and
conspired together the destruction of Troy. Aulon, the name of a Mountain and
city in Calabria, where growethe excellent good wynes. Alsoo of two other
cities, the oone in Macedonia, the other in Cilicia. Aul^, shaulmes or waytes.
Auleticus, he that plays best on a sha^me or wait. Auocare animum, to
withdraw the mind from a thing. Auocamentum, passetyme, recreation, that
withdraws the mind from heaviness or melancholy. Aurata, a fyshe of the sea,
which I suppose to be a gylte heed, for he has in his foreheed a thing
congelate, which in the water shyneth like gold, and also has a set of t^the
like check t^the, wherewith he has been hard of fyshers in the night to
crushe cockyls, and such other little shell fyshes, whereon he fedeth.
Terentius in Andria.
Aures arrigere, to lift up the ears, to here attentyuely. Cicero in Salust
Cicero pro G^^la^co. Plautus in Tr^nu^mo. Plautus in Mi^^. T^^b^nius Cicer^.
Cic. V^lu^.
Aures calent illius criminibus, mine cares glowe or burn to here of his
mischeuous acts. Aures hebetes haber, he is dulle in berynge, or he lysteth
not to here. Auribus accipere, to have herd. Auribus cap^re spolia, to harken
and bear away our sacrefies, or secret counsel. Auribus dare, to flatter,
to speak that which shall content a man's ear. Auribus aequissimis alicuius
uti, to be favorably hard of one. Apulcius.
Auribus prouehi, to be carried by the ears, it is proprely used, where we will
declare, that being in journey with one, we delight so much in his
communication, that we feel no labor or pain by going or riding. So may we
say, auribus prouehimur, in hering of him our pains are relieved, or in heryng
him talk, our journey seems short, or is abbreuiate. Auricularius, a, um,
pertaining to the ears. Auricularis confessio, confession made secretly, as
priestis do here it. Auricularis* re, idem. Aurigo, a sickness callid the yelow
iaundise. Aurilegus, he that has stolen gold. Auripigmentum. Aurum
coronatium, was gold gathered of the people, to make crowns, to send to
Emperors, after their vyctories. Plaut. in Mercator.
Auscultabitur, he will do as ye bid him. Auscultare alicui, to obey one, or
be at his commandment. Auscultare inter sese, to whyster oone in an nothers
^are. Ausim, sis, sit, is put for audeam, as, at. Ausitis, the contray callid
also Hus, where Job dwelled. Ausonium, Italy. Ausones, were the ancient kings
of Italy. Ausum, and ausus, a presumptuous enterprise. Plautus in Peria.
Auspicium liquidu^, a manifest sign or token. Auspicia optima, tokens of good
luck. Plautus in Aui.
Auspicio malo, with ylle luck, or in an ylle time. Nae ego edepol ueni huc
auspicio malo: I camme hither in an ylle time, or, An unhappy or unlucky
fortune brought me byther. Auspico, are, to seek for a thing by diuinatio^.
Auspicatus, ta, tum, honorably enterprised. Quintilia.
Auspicato, happyly. Austrum, the spoke of a whele. Aut certe, or at the least.
Quo enim vno uincebamur a victa Graetia, id aut illi ereptum est, Ci. in Bru.
aut certe nobis communicatum, That oone thing, wherein we gave place to Greece,
which is vanquyshed by us, either it is taken clean away from them, or at the
lest we be therein equal unto them. Autenticus, ca, cum, of authority.
Autocthones, people which began in the countray that they do inhabyte,
which name was given to them of Athenes. Autodidactus, he that lernith without
a master by his own study. Automata. things without life, which seem to move
by them selfs: as it may appear in old horologes, and images, which by vices
do move. Autopyros, bread of clean wheat without other mixture, saving a
little leven. Author, T^. Liuius, Paulus inreco^sultus. Ci. in Ver. Plautus in
Cur. Terentius in Prolog. Andri. Plautus in poenu.
the first Inuenter or maker of a thing also a reporter of news. also he that
has the custody of one within age. also he that does sell or deliver a thing
on warrantise. also he whom a man follows in doing any thing. Authoritas,
authority, credence, puissance, opinion, judgment, the inioying of possession.
Authoritatem defungi, to deny to have done any thing, or to have been the
cause that it was done. Authoritatem defugere, Terentius Eunucho.
to refuse to do that which he is commanded. Authoritatem interponere, to
command a thing to be done. Authoramentum, wages, or hyre. Authoro, rare, to
bind one by covenant to do service. Authoratus, ta, tum, bounden by
covenant.
A ANTE X.
AXis, an extree of a cart, sometime the hole carte, Sometime it is shyngle,
Iuuenal^^.
wherewith howses are covered in the stead of tyle. Axilla, the armehole.
Axamenta, verses made by the priests of Mars, called Salii, in quycke
tauntynge of all men. Axare, old writers used for nominare, to name or ask.
Axioma, a sentence spoken and proved: as If Plato walks, Plato moves, if it
be day, the son is above the earth. It is put by Tulli for that, which
sophisters do call a proposition, which is a sentence true or falls.
A ANTE Z.
AZymus panis, unleavened breadde. Azanlum, was a well, the water whereof being
drunk, caused men to hate the savor and taste of wine. Azotu^, a city in
Siria.
B ANTE A.
BAAL in the tongue of Siria, signifies lord, and is attrybute to Jupiter.
Babe, an interiection of wondering. Babylon, a great city in Caldey, and
signyfyeth confusion or translation. where was a tower edyfied by Hembroth,
which was in height five miles, and a hundred three score and ten paces,
afterward being enlarged by Semiramis, the wife of Ninus king of Assiria, it
was so great, that it contained in compass three score miles, and the walls
were in the height three hundred fete, and in thyckenes or bredthe three score
and fyftene fete, and had a hundred gates of brass, and there ran through
the middell thereof the noble and most famous river Euphrates, which is oone
of the ryuers, whereof the hedde or spring is in Paradyse. Babylonia, the
countray where the city of Babylon stood. Babylonicus, ca, cum, and
Babylonius, a, um, of Babylon. Babylonica, are clothes wouen with sundry
colors. Baccalia, a kind of bay trees or laurel, but it has larger leaves,
and great plentye of beryes. It is also called Augusta. Baccar, car^s, and
Baccharis, is an herb having a lefe in facyon and greatness between violet
leaves and the herb, which is called Moleyn or longwort, the stalk square,
and somewhat rough, which is in hayght a foot and a half, having a flower like
purple, myxte with white, the root black, but that sauouryth like unto
Cinamome, some do call it Asdrabacca, some our ladies gloves. Bacchari, to do a
thing like a mad man or vexed with spirits. Bacchatim, like a mad man.
Baccaricum, a sweet ointment, made of the root of Asdrabaccha. Bacchius, a,
um, of Bacchus. Baccisera, a tree bearing bearies. Baccula, a little bearye.
Bacillum, a little staff. Bactra, trotum, a contray in Scithis, beyond
Assiria, it is also the name of a city in that countraye. Bactriani, people of
that countray. Bactrianum, a cou^tray wherein were a thousands cities. Badizare,
to goo. Plautus in Asina.
Bagous, in the Persian tongue signyfieth a geldyng, or a man gelded. Bagrada,
a river in Affrike by the city called Vtica, where Att^hus Regulus, and the
host of the Romans, slew a serpent, which was in length one hundred and.xx.
fete. Bahal, the ydoll of Cyre. Balanites, a stone, which is a light grene,
and has a vayn in the myddell like a flame of fire. Balanitis, a kind of
round Chestens or cheste nuttes. Balaustium, the flowers of wild pome
granades. Baleares, two Isles by Spain, whereof the one is now called Maiorca,
the other Minorca. Ballistarium, the place where a great brake ^or slynge is
laid. Balneatorius, a, um, of a bathe. Balneb^um, a little bayne or bathe.
Balito, tare, to blete often. Balsamum, baulme. Bambia, a kind of olyue tree.
Banausus, an artificer that works at ye fire. Banchus, called an haddok.
Baphia, a dyehouse. Baptae, men which had their visages painted. Baptes, a
stoone green, of the color of a frogge. Baptismus, and Baptismum, and
Baptisma, matis, Baptym. Barbala, a little berde. Barba iouis, an herb called
Sing^eene, and grows on tyles. Barba senis, is an herb, which grows among
stones, the leaves whereof be like to long hears. It is also called Barba
petrae, it has a yelowe flower, and the root thereof is bitter. Barbatulus,
he that has a young berde. Barbus, and barbo, a fyshe called a barbyll. Barce,
a city in Libia, also an other city called Ptolomais. Bardesanes, was an
excellent astronomer. Bardiacus, a certain garment. Baris, barides, vel
baridis, a boat in Egypt, wherein they carried ded bodies to burieng. Bariona,
i would, quod filius columbae, the Culuers son. It was the surname of saint
Peter the apostell. Barnacida, a garment that childern did wear. Martialis.
Barrus, a toothe. Quid tibi vis mulier, nigris dignissima barris? What would
thou have woman, that art worthy black tethe? Basan, a countray beyond the
river of Iordane in Judea, which was diuyded to two of the Trybes: which may
be interpreted most fertile and fat. Martialis.
Bascanda, a certain vessel, which came out of England, when it was called
Britayn. Basilca, a city in Germanye. Basilia, an I Will in the north occean
see. Plaut. in capt. Plautus in ^rinu^mo. Plautus in Persa. Plautus in Carcu.
Basilicae edictiones, the kings ordinance or commandments. Basilica
facinora, acts or gestes of kings. Basilica nux, a wall nutte. Basilice
agere, to do a thing royally. Basilicus, a certain chance at dyce.
Basilides, a certain heretic, which affirmed to be.CCClxv. heuens.
Basilidiani, the folowers of Basilides. Bassaris, tidis, a priest of Bacchus.
Bat, is a word that is spoken to one, when we will have him speak no more, as
peace or huysht. Batauia, a countraye in Germanye, called Hollande. Batauus, an
Hollander, or man of Hollande. Batiochus, a little pot, out of the which
wine is poured at the tablel Batrachion, an herb, which I do suppose is that
which is commonly called goldknap, or crowefoote. It is also called of
Democritus Chrisanthemon, for it has a flower as yelowe as gold, and the
leaf is somewhat like unto parcily, but that it is much greatter. Battologia,
idem quod multiloquium, much talk or speech, clatterynge. Josephus.
Batus, is a measure for lycour among the Hebrews, which contained.lxii.
measures of Athenes, called Sextarios, every Sextarius contaynynge.xviii.
ounces, which amounts to four score and.xiii.li. of english galons.
B ANTE D, and E.
BDelium, is a tree growyng in Arabia and Scithia. also a gum coming of the
same tree, like to wax, but clear as gum, within unctuous or fat, very
sweet of savor, when it is rubbed or burned, and bitter in taste. Bebry^ia, a
cou^tray callid the great Phrigia. Bebrytius, a, um, and bebrix, bebricis, of
the countray of great Phrigia. Bebritium, seu Bebriacum, a town in Italye
between Cremona and Verona. Beelphegor, a gapynge ydoll. Beelsephon, lord of
the north, an ydol set up in the places of espiall. Beelsebub, an ydoll called
god of flies. Beemoth, the devil, and signifies a beast. Belbus, a beast
called also Hiena. Belgae, people of Gallia, between the rivers of Ryne, Marne,
and Seyn, and stretchith to the northwest see, in the which are now contained
the countrays of Brabant, Fla^ders, Holland, Ghelder, part of Friseland,
Gulyke, Hennow, Pycardy, part of Champayne, the great forest of ^^dan, the
cities of Acon, Colayn, Triere, Rhein^s. Belial, the devil, which is
interpreted Apostata, without yoke. Bellatula, little sweet heart. Plautus.
Plautus in Ruden.
Belliatus, ta, tum, beautified. Belle, well. Belle se habet, he does or
fares well. Bellerophontes, seu Bellerophon, Note here the malice of hariots.
was the son of Glaucus king of Ephyra, who being a man of much beauty
and prowes was arda^tly beloved of Stenobea, the wife of Pretus king of Ephyra,
next after Glaucus, and when she desired him to commit adultery with her, he
fearing the vengeance of Jupiter god of hospitality, and remembrynge the
frendshyp showed to him by her husband, refused her, and did put her away from
him, which she disdayning, and being in a wood rage, accused him to her
husband, that he had rauyshed her, but he like a sober man would not than slay
him in his own house, but delyueringe to him letters to his wives father, sent
him in to Licia, where he than reigned, who perceiving thereby the mind of
Pretus, encouraged Bellerophon, to distroy the two mo^sters callid Solymos and
Chymera, and sent him thereto that he might be s^ayn under the color of a
valiant enterprise, but he acheuyng it nobly, returned with honor. Bellica,
was a pyllour in the temple of Bellona, called goddess of battle, where they
used, when wars were proclaimed, to cast a Iauelyn. Bellicrepa, a certain
form of daunsynge in harneyse. Bellator equus, a horse of war. Bellatrix,
tricis, a woman valyant in wars. Belligero, rare, to make war. Bellona,
called goddess of battle. Bellis, seu bellium, the white daysye, called of
some the Margarite, in the north it is called a Banwort. It is also a fyshe
with a long beak like a crane, which is called of some a kekehorne.
Bellouaci, people of Beauuosyne in France Cice. Atri.
Bellum merum loquitur, he speaks oonely of war. Belon, the name of a city
and river in Spain. Beluosus, a, um, full of monsters of the sea. Bel^^^tus,
^a, tum, painted or ^erued with great beasts. Belluara ^apetia, Tap^strye
wroughte with great beasts. Belus, the first king of Assiria, father of
Ninus, and is signifies the son, it is also a river in Syria, which has
sand of the nature of glass, which it casts up, also it torneth all
other metal that comes into it, into glass. Bembina, a town by the forest
called Nemaeus. Bembinatus, of that town or wood. Benacus, a great lake in
Lumbardy. Been accipere aliquem, to entreat one well, or entertayne him. Been
acceptus, well entertained. Plautus.
Been agitur, the thing is well done. Been ambulato, god he with the. Been
audire, to be well spoken of. Been conuenire inter cos, they agreed well to
gether. Plinius.
Been cogitare de aliquo, to have a good opinion of one. Plautus in Pseud.
Plautus in Trinum. Plau^
Been curare aetatem, to live pleasantly. Been hercle denuncias, thou tellyst
me good tidings. Benedico, dixi, dicere, to praise, to say well. Benedice, an
aduerbe, signifieng in praising or saying well. Cum illiciebas me ad te blande
et benedice: when thou dyddiste train me unto the with pleasant words and
praisynge of me. Benefacio, cere, to do well. Benefactum, it is well done.
Benefacta, Benefytes, pleasures. Beneficiu^, a benefit, a pleasure, or good
torn Beneficentia, is not only lyberalitie in gyuing of money, or
possessions, or other like things, but also in helping a man with counsel,
solicitation, or other labor. Plautus in Rude. Plautus in Epidic.
Been far gratiam, to do pleasure to one. Been habere, to behave me or him
well. Been hoc habet, this matter comes well to pass. Been longus sermo, a
very long tale. Been magnus, very great. Been mane, very tymely. Been mereri,
to do pleasure to one. Been multi, very many. Been nummatum marsupium, a purse
well stored with money. Been nummatus homo, a well monyed man. Been successit,
it came well to pass. Been ^ale, farewell, a dowe. Been ualere, to be in good
health. Been uerta^t di^, god turn it to good: I pray god bring it well to
pass. Been uiuere, to make good chere. Beneuolens, beneuolent, he that loves
well an another. Benigna terra, a ground that is fertile. Benign, an aduerbe,
which signifies curteysly, graciously, bounteously. Benignitas, curteysie,
lyberalitie, gentylnes. Berecyntus, a mountain and city in Phrigia, where
Cybele, callid the mother of the goddis was chiefly honored. Berecyntia,
callid the mother of goddis. Bersab^, a city in Judea, called also Puteus
iuramenti, the pytte of the oath, where Abraham dwellid, which is the consynes
of the land of behest. Berillus, a stone which is very clear, and somewhat
inclynynge to a grene color. it is not that, which we commonly do call
Berall, in drinking cups, but it is rather that, which we do call
crystal, which being wrought into squares, has in them a glymse of a
light grene. Beta, an herb called Beetes. Bethania, a town two miles from
Jerusalem, on the side of the mount Oliuete. Bethel, a city in Samaria,
where the people dwelled which were called Iebus^i. Bethleem, the city of
Dauyd the prophet, where he was borne and dyed, where alsoo our savior Christ
Jesus was borne: there also dyed Rachel the wife of Jacob the patriarche. it was
assigned to the tribe of Judah, and was distant from Jerusalem.vi. miles, and
was first called Euphrata, and signifies in the hebrewe tongue, the house of
breadde. Bethsaida, or Bethesda, was a great ponde in Jerusalem, wherein the
pristis washed the sheep, which should be sacrifised, and may be interpreted
the house of cattle. It was also the name of a town, where Peter and Phylyp
the apostels were borne. Bethsamis, a city in Galilee, where Christ did many
miracles. Bethsamitae, people of Bethsamis. Bethsura, and Bethsurae, a strong
fortress of the Jews. Baeticatus, he that wears a black or broune garment.
Baeticus, ^a, cum, black or brown. Baetica, a prouynce or countray in Spain,
called now Granado, Baetis, a river in Spain by Granado. Betonica, an herb
called Betayne. Betonica altilis sieve coronaria, I suppose hit to be Gyllofers.
Betphage, a town in Judea, and may be interpreted the house of a mouth, or a
iawe. Betula, a tree, called birche.
B ANTE I.
BIaeon, wheat which is hard to be beaten out of the husks. Bias antis, was
one of the.vii. wise men of Greece, and was governor of the city called
Priene, and was very rigorouse in iutice against ill men, and defended his
contray long against outward hostility: at the last the town being taken,
and the people fleinge away, and carienge with them such treasure as they
had, he went quietly out of the town, leuyng all his substance behind him:
and when he was demanded, why that he only carried nothing with him, he
answered: I carry al with me that is mine own, meaning thereby, that his
wisdom and virtue were his propre goods, al other things were the goods of
fortune, and by her appointed to them that might catch them, but wisdom and
virtue were constante, and might by no man be taken from him. Bibisia,
bybbynge. Biblio, blere, to make a sown as a pot does, when drink is drawn
into it. Bibliographus, a writer of books. Ci in Ve^. act. 3.
Bibitur. Mature ueniunt, discumbitur, fit sermo inter eos, et inuitatio vt
graeco more biberotur, They come at the time appointed, and there was among
them talking and quaftynge, that every man might drink after the Greeks
facion.
B ANTE. L.
Plautus in Trinu^mo.
BLandi loquentulus, a pleasant speaker. Blande, graciousely, amorousely,
flateryngely. Blanditer, idem. Blandicia, flatery, pleasant motion, intysement
by words. Blapsigonia, loss of generation, proprelye in bees. Blatio, tiui,
tire, to speak or talk like a fool, or without any purpose or reason, to babble.
Blatero, ronis, a babbler, he that talks to no purpose. Blattaria, an herb
called Moleyn. Blatteus, a, um, purple. Blitteus, ea, eum, unsavory.
B ANTE O.
BOa, is also a sickness, wherein the body is full of read blysters. Boalia,
plays made for the health of oxen and kyne. Boaria, an herb called a clote or
burre. Boca, uel Bocas, a fyshe, which has his back as it were painted with
sondrye colors, Iouius says and affirms, that he is taken in all costs in
great sculles, not withstanding I do not yet find his name in english.
Boebis, a lake in Thessaly. Bogud, a town in Affrike, alsoo the name of a
king. Bolus, a throw or cast at dyse. also a braught with a net in waters. it
is also a morsel. Bombax, an aduerbe spoken of him, Plautus in pseudolo.
that sets naught by that which is spoken, as one would say, when he is
rebuked of a fault, And what than? or tushe, I care not for that. Bomolochus, a
common scoffar, or he that susteyneth all vyllanie for to get money. It was
also taken for a boy, that stood at the aulters end, to stele away the
candels. Bona caduca, the goods of them that be damned, goods escheted. Bona
dea, was she that some called fatua, or fauna, of whom Varro writes, that in
her life never man did see her but her husband, nor herd her named. Bonae
aedes, a substanciall house. Bona dicere, to report well. Bona fide dicere, to
say truly and plainly. Bona pars, the more part. Bona uerba quaeso, say well
I pray you. Terentius in Andria.
Boni frugi, honest, of good conditions. Bonaria, the calmenes of the sea.
Boreae, Jasper stones. Borsyrites, a kind of olyue, having many boughs,
white and spotted with sa^guine. Bosra, a city of Idumea. Botytillus, a
little cluster of grapes.
B, ANTE R.
BRachicatalecton, where oone syllable lacks at the end of a verse.
Brachicatalecticum carmen, a verse lacking one syllable or mo. Breuiculus, a
little short man. Breuiter, shortly. Breuis, idem. Bryon thalassion, or
Marinum, a thing growing on the rocks, whereon the salt water beats,
somewhat like to moss, and is called of the northern men flank. Bryonia, a
^^lde vine, having read bearies, and the leaves more rough tha^ of a vine.
Britanica, an herb like greatte sorelle, but blacker, thycker, and therewith
mosye, the root black and litell, and in tasting straineth the tongue.
Bromus, one of the names of Bacchus. Bronchosela, a waxinge kernel. Bronteus,
the surname of Jupiter. Brupeo, ere, old writers used for stupeo, stupere, to
be abashed.
B ANTE V.
BVa, the word of young children when they ask for drink, with us they use to
say Bumme. Bubula, Befe. Bubonocele, where the bowell is braste by the share
of a man toward his privy me^bres. Bucea, a thynne husk in a bean within the
hulle. Bucerum paecus, an herd of rother beasts Bucolicu^ carmen, a poem
made of herdme^. Bulbine, nes, scalions. Bullula, a little water bell or
bobill. Buphonum, an herb, whereof if catell eat, they do dye of a grief in
their throat. Buphihalmon, an herb, called also Cotula fetida, and is like to
camomyll, but it growith more upright, maywede. Bupre^tis, a fly like to a
black bytel, but he has longer legs, which if a beast does eat, he
swells, and therewith dies. Burbarus, a fyshe, which by the description of
Paulus Iouius, seems to be a Carp. Burrum, a deep read color. Busicon, a
great fig. Bustuarij, sword players, which went before the ded corpsts when
they were borne to be burned. Buteo, onis, a bus^arde. Buttubata, a trifle of
no value. Buxeus, a, um, of box.
C, ANTE A.
C BY HIM SELF, sygnyfyeth Caius, the propre name of a man, and therefore is
joined with an other name, as C. lul. Caesar, Caius Julius Caesar. Ci.
signifies Claudius. Cabala, a tradicion of the Jews, left among them by
Moses without writing, but from the father to his son, and so continually in
their generation, wherein is included the understanding as well of the
secrets of nature, as the mysticalle sense, included in the words of holy
scripture. Cabus, a ^^^dre of the hebrews, containing two sextatios and a
half.vi. ounces, and.iii. drammes of Athenes measure, which amounts to four
pound, three ounces, and three drammes. Cacaturio, to desire to go to the stole.
Cachexia, a spyce of a consumption, which proceeds of an ill disposition of
the body, and the body and vysage is therewith very lean, and ill colored.
Cacia, viciositie, or that which we commonly do call, a fault in a thing.
Cacoblepa, a little beast in Egypt in the banks of the river of Nilus,
which has such venenosytie in his eien, that who that beholds them, dies
incontinent. Cacoetlie, a vice or sore engendered in oone from his infancy,
hard to be recovered or caryd. Cacologia, ylle speech. Cacologus, an ill
speaker. Cacophaton, is an ill form of speaking, or where the words do not
sown well and conveniently. Cacoxelus, an ill follower or imitatour. Cacus, a
gyaunte, whom Hercules slew in Italye. Cadiscus, a vesselle, wherinto are
gathered scedules, bills, or lottes, where things at done by a consent of
many counsaylours, or of the people. Cadmites, a stone, which has little
blue sparks about it. Cadmus, the name of a king of Phenicia, which builded
Thebes: by whom some men do suppose, that diverse of the Greek letters were
found. Cadit mimus, the courage faylethe, or is ^^^ted. Cadere, to be slain.
Caducias, the rod, Plautus in Amphit.
which Mercurius did always bear in token of peace. Cadoc^ator, ambassador or
heraulte at arms, sent to demand peace. Caduca, things that will shortly
peryshe or decay, old writers used them for significations of that which
should happen. Ci. in phil.
Caduca haereditas, an inheritance which is fallen in excheate, for (...) of
heirs. Caducus labor, labor lost. Plinius.
Caducae literae, letters which will be shortly put out. Caduci tituli, honors
and dignities, Pli. in pan.
which endure but a little while. Caduri, they which are decessed. Vergili. 7.
Caducor, ceris, duci, to be over thrown. Cadul^, the dryppyng of fle^she
roasted. Cadu^, a vessel con^^ynge the same measure that Amphora does. Cara,
an I Will in the sea called Aegeum. It is also called Co^, where fyshe worms were

Caecigeni, they which are borne blind. Caeca die, Eme die caeca hercle
oliuum, id uendito oculata die: bye oil olive good chepe and sell it again
dear. orels, bye oil for days, and sell it again for ready money. Caecus
morbus, a sickness that is hid, or may not be discerned. Caeci haemorroides,
emoraudes or piles, which are within the foundement, and do not appear. Caeca
uestigia, where one may not se his way that he rydeth or goes. Caecum uallum,
a trenche, which in time of war is pyght privily with sharp stakes, which
are hid with brakes or bushes. Caecum intestinum, is a bowel, which comes
from the right side, at the point of the houkle bone, and goes to the left
side in length, and is also called Monoculus. Caecitas, blyndnesse, not only
of the bodyly eyes, but also of the mind. Caedes, murdre. Cic ad Q. (...)

Caedere calcibus, to kycke. Caeditur testibus, he is convict by witness.

custom they sacrificed two hoggrelles. Caelatus, ta, tum, gra^^^. Caelesus,
te, et hoc caeleste, of heaven or heavenly. Caelibaris hasta, was the staff of a
Iauelyn, which had been in the body of one of them, which were called
gladiatores, and was slain: with the which staff the head of a maiden new
married was hemp and stricken, sygnifiyng, that likewise as the staff was
stycked fast in the body of him that was slain, so should she stycke fast,
and be joined with him that married her. Caelostomia, a vice in speech, where
one speaks inwardely, and makes rather a sound than a pronunciatio^ of his
words Plinius.
Caelum, the palate, or roufe of the mouth. Caelipoteus, all mighty god.
Caeneus, the surname of Jupiter. Caepi, I began. Caeremoniae, ceremonies.

Calamitae, little grene frogs. Calasastri, boys which do sing with a

whitynge, mean between a haddocke and a whytinge. Callipolis, a city in
Thracia. Calleo, iui, lere, to perceive, to know by long experience.
Calliblephara, medicines to make here is to grow in the chekes or brows.
Calliblepharon, a medicine for the eyes, specially when the eye lyddes do
cleave together. Calliscere, to wax hard, proprelye in the skin and flesh.
Calliirichum, an herb called maiden hear. Callum obd^^^ere, to harden, to
make to endure labors or peynes. Calones, shoes of wodde. Also scullyons and
boys, which do follow an hooste to carry baggage, wodde, coled, or other like
things. Calophanta, a mocker. Calurisicus, ta, cum, that which heateth or
makes a thing hot. Calotecheus, a good workman. Calp^^, a tun. Caltha,
an h^r^ callid marigold^^ or tuddis Calthala, a garment of the color of
M^rygoldes. Calu^^ia, the hole heed of a (...) or beast. It was also a common
place of (...) some men do suppose, that it was the place where Adam the first
man was buried. Caluaster, a man somewhat balde. Caluor, ueris, ui, to be
dysappoynted. Calx, calcis, masculyne gender, the hele. Calx, the feminyne
gender, lyme made of stones burned. it is taken sometime for the end of a
thing. Calydon, a city in Greece. Camarina, a stynking herb, the air whereof
provoke one to vomyte. Cammarus, a fish callid a creuyse, specially of the
fresh water, a creuyse deaudoulx. Camerinam mouere, is a proverb spoken to
one, signifieng that he hurts him self, which proceeded of a fenne so callid
which being dried up, there happened a great pestilence, wherefore the people
adjoining, asked of Apollo, if they should make it dry for ever, who answered,
Ne moueas camerina^, as he should say, stir no myschyefe to thy self.
Camuri boues, oxen or kyne, with crooked horns. Canaan, the son of Came, the
son of Noe, of whom comes Cananeus. Canalitium aurum, gold dygged in
pyttes. Josephus in antiqui.
Canan, the countray called Arabye. Cananaea, a part of Siria, now callid
Judea. Cananitis regio, idem. Canaria, an isle in the sea called Atlanticu^,
nygh to the fortunate yles. Canarius, a, um, pertaining to dogs. Canatim, an
Aduerbe, sygnyfyenge like a dog. Cancellarius, in the old time was taken for
a scrybe or notarye, now it is callydde a chancellor. Cancellatim, lattyse
wise. Cicero de lege agraria.
Cancelli, little crabbes of the sea. Canere sibi, to speak for his own
profit. Canere sibi and musis, to sing or write for his own pleasure, and
for them that do favor him, nothing caring for any other. Canta, old
writers used for cantata. Cantito, tare, to sing often. Plautus in Trinu^mo.
Cantare, to monysshe or exhort. Haec dies noctesque tibi canto ut caueas,
This I exhort the day and night, that thou may beware. Cantatio, a
singing. Cantator, a synger. Capere rationem, to find the mean. Rationem
coepi ut and amanti obsequerer, and patrem non offenderem, I found the mean to
please my lover, and not withstandyng I dyspleased not my father. also to know
the cause why. Terent. in Heautont.
Scio tibi esse hoc grauius multo, ac durius cui fit: uerum ego haud minus
aegre patior id qui nescio, nec rationem capio, nisi quod tibi been ex animo
uolo, I know well that to you, whom the thing touches, hit is much more
displeasant and grievous: but yet it greuith me no less, I can not tell why, but
only because I love you. Capere rationem oculis, to judge by syghte. Hi loci
sunt atque ^ae regiones, Plautus in Pseud.
quae mihi ab hero sunt meo demonstratae, ut ego oculis rationem capio, These
are the places and streets, that my master showed me, as far as mine eyes can
judge, or as far as I can perceive. Capere uoluptatem, to delight. Capere
uersoriam, to change a purpose, to turn saylle, to do contrary to that he
intended. Capere usuram corporis vxoris alterius, Plautus in Amphitri.
To commytte aduoultrie with an another man's wife. Capidulum, a hoode.
Capillatia uela, be clothes of hear. Capito, tonis, a see fyshe, greatter
commonly than a Myllet is, which as I suppose, we do call a base Capitulo,
lare, to divide by chapiters. Capnion, an herb called Fumitorie. Plinius li.
26.
it is also called Capnos. Capo, a fyshe called a Gurnarde. Caprilis, le, of a
got. Caprillus, la, lum, idem. Caprotina, a surname of Juno. Capsis, for cape

one in the act of lechery. Captare ^oenam, to get a supper of fre cost.
