Captare sermonem, to harken priuyly what men talk. Captatio, a purchase.
Carba, a wind that blowethe from the Southe. Carbunculatio, is a faut in
vynes, when the clusters of grapes are not sufficiently covered with leaves, by
the which occasyon, they be wythered and dried. Carbunculus, is also a kind
of earth, the which with the hear of the son, waxes so hot, that it
burns the rotes of herbs and trees. Carchedonius, a kind of Carbuncle
stones, which in the house seem of purple color, abroad in the air they are
fyrie, against the son they send out sparkles, and if wax be touched with
them, it melts. Carcinus, a crabbe. Carabus, a fysshe called a lopster, like
to a Creuyse, but that he is greater, and is red when he is alive. Chalchis, a
fysshe of the sea, of the kind of Turbutte. Charax, a Fysshe, callydde alsoo
Dentix, with teethe standinge out of his lips, and is a broad fyshe, and
somewhat read, with a chaungeable color. Cardomine, an herb called water
cressis. Cardopos, an huche or coffar, wherein bread is laid, In the North
countraye hit is called an arc. Carduus, a thystell. Caricus, ca, cum, of the
country of Caria. Carides, a fysshe callydde Pranes, like to shrympes. Cariem
trahere, to wax rotten, or to be putrified or vinnewed. Cariophillon, a spice
called cloves. Carnus, na, number, fat. Caros, excess of meat or drink. also
an herb and sede called carways. Carpere iter, to take his journey.
Carpocrates, an heretyke, which denied that god made the world. Carpophyllon,
a tree, which has leaves like to laurel. Carthallum, a baskette. Caryopos, the
juice of a nutte. Carynus, na, number, of a nutte: as oleum carynum, the oil of
nuttes. Carystae, and Carystos, an I Will in the sea called Euboicum, wherein is
plenty of marbyll of diverse colors. Carystaeus, a, um, of that isle.
Casabundus, da, dum, falling often. Caseale, a stable. Casner, in the Oske
tunge is an old man. Cas^^o, tare, to fall often. Cassinum, an old market
place. Cassiterus, tynne. Cassiterides, certain yles, wherein tynne is dygged.
Cassutha, a wede that windeth about hemp or lynne, called Doddar. Catabasis,
the son set. Catachresis, a figure, whereby the propretie of a word is
abused: as, Facies simillima lauro, where facies oonely belongs to a man, and
not to a tree, although it does signifye there a similitude or figure.
Cathysta, a garment close all about. Catacrysis, a condemnation. Catagrapha,
images lokyng diverse ways, and in diverse fourmes. Catalepsis, occupation or
deprehencion. Catalexis, a fynyshynge of a thing. Catalyma, refection, also an
ynne. Catamidio, are, to set one up with a paper on his heed to be mocked or
rebuked for some offense, as they use to do with men perjured, or with forgers
of evidences. Catapultarium pilum, a bolte. Cata^yposis, a figure, where one
thing is described by an another. Cato, wise. Also the name of a noble Senator
of Rome. Catoblepas, a beast full of poison, called a Basylyske. Catillo, are,
to eat like a glutton. Catorthoma, the right exercise of virtue. Catulinus,
na, number, of a catte. Caudecae, little coffers of wyckers, or a iu^ket, wherein
eles are taken in ryuers. Plautus in Rude.
Caudeus, a, um, of the stem of a tree. Caudex, is a dulle brayned fellow, a
dulle hedde. Caudicalis, ale, pertaining to the stem of a tree. Caudicariae
naues, ships made of thick plankes. Cauere alicui, to give counsaylle to
oone in mattiers of law, or concerning contractes. Cauere, with accusative
case, sygnifyeth to bid to beware. Cauere sibi ab aliquo, to take a quytaunce
or other discharge for the payment of money or delyueraunce of any thing. At
uero, Ci. in Bru.
inquam, tibi ego Brute non solua^, nisi prius a te cauero, amplius eo nomine
neminem, cuius petitio sit, petiturum, Truly (said I) Brutus I will not pay
the, except I have first a quyttance of the, that thou shalt not eftesones
demand it of him, of whom thou moughtest ask it. Cauere capite, to be
bound body for body. Plinius li. 34. plautus in Bacch.
Cauere, to provide. Quid isti caueam? B. Vt reuehat domum, Whatte shall I
provide for him? B. one to bring him home. Caueri, to be taken head of.
Caueares hostiae, and cauae, were parts of the beasts next to the tail, to
be sacryfysed for the bishops. Cauillatio, a cauillation, a subtyl forged
tale Cauillor, lari, to speak in mockage. Caulias, the juice of colewortes
myxt with bran, and being tossed togider, was brought into the form of a
paste. Causam accipere, to take the matter in hand. also to take an excuse.
Causam capere, to take an occasion. Causam dicere, to answer unto that,
which is laid to his charge. Caussam dicere, to say contrary, to deny.
Plautus in capt.
Hoc si secus reperies, nullam causam dico, quin mihi and parentum, et
libertatis apud te deliquio siet, If thou do find hit other wise, I will
not say contrary, but that it is at thy pleasure, that I shall lose both my
parents and liberty. Caussam dicere ex uinculis, to answer in ward, or
being a prisoner. Terent. in Heauto.
Causa mea, for my sake. Syro Ignoscas uolo, quae mea causa fecit, I will that
ye forgive Syrus all that he has done, for my sake. Liuius.
Caussas nectere, to feign matters. Caussam orare, to plead. Caussam quaerere,
to seek an occasyon. Cice. Atti.
Caussam sustinere, to bear the blame.

CEdere creditoribus, is proprely where one not being able to pay his dettes,
leaves all his goods or lands to his credytours. Plautus in pseudolo.

fygges be. Pli. epi. 50.

Cedunt dies, the days pass away. Celatus, ta, tum, hid. Celebratus,
brata, bratum, much spoken of, or haunted. Celebris locus, a place much
haunted and known. Accius. Sisenna.
Celeranter, for celeriter, hastily or quyckly. Celeratim. idem. Celeres, old
writers used for Equites, horsemenne. Plautus in Merca.
Celeris copia. Date di quaeso co^ueniundi mihi eius celerem copiam, God grant
that I may very shortly mete with him. Varro.
Censere, to be angrye. Ne uobis censeam, si ad me referretis, Lest I would be
angrye, if ye told me. Plautus in Stico.
Censere, to speak or tell. G. Quid grauare? censeas. Tell me, what is that,
that greuethe the? Plinius. 8.
Censeri, to be had in estymation, or to be set by, also to be meruayled at.
Censio, onis, a price, advise, or opinion. Censoria nota, the rebuke or check
of the master of manners, Censoria animaduersio, was a punyshement of them,
which were of ill manners. Censorius, a, um, pertaynyng to them, which had
ouersyghte of the manners of the people, which were called Censores.
Centaurium, an herb, whereof there be two kinds: The great, which apotycaries
do call Reuponticum: And the less, which is called Centorye. Alsoo fell
terrae, and Febrifugia. Centenariae coenae, were suppers on the which by a
law callid Licinia, was bestowid but one hundred of the brasyn coin called
Asses. Centesimae ursurae, were gains of the hundred penny value of every
thing, for every month lone. Centesimus, ma, mum, the hundred, as Centesima
pars, the hundred part. Centralis, le, that which is set in the very mids
of a thing. Centurupe, a feld in Sicile, whereof is Centurupinum crocum.
Cephalocrustes, a worm, which is in the leaves of a peache tree. Cepa, pae,
and cepe indeclinabile, an oynion. Cepas edere, to eat onions, was a proverb
spoken of them, which do seem to weep, or do weep often. Cephenes,
unprofitable bees, which make no honye, but only with the multitude of them,
do keep warm the young bees. Cera, wexe, also wexed tables. Ceramion, the same
mesure that amphora is Cerea pruna, wheat plummes. Cereus, a, um, soft, also
fat. Horatius. Actius.
Cerinum, a garment of the color of wax. Cerium, a soore like an honey comb.
Ceritus, mad. Cerinthe, an herb having the taste of wax and honey together.
Cerinthus, the meat of bees, which is found in honey combs, separate from
the honye, which is in taste bitter and is also moist. Cernere, to deuyse
together, Plautus in Trinu^mo.
or talk oone with an another. Verecundari neminem apud mensam decet, nam ibi
de diuinis atque humanis cernitur, No manne ought to be abashed at the
table, for there men do devise or talk of matters concerning as well god as
manne. Cernere, to syfte or range flower of corn. Plinius. 1^.
Cerno animo, I do foresee or consider before. Cernulus, he that is busye to
find fault in an another man. Hier. con. Ruffinum.
Cernus, nus, nui, a certain show. Ceroma, oil myxt with wex. Cic. in ca.
also the place where wrastlers were anointed. Certatio, debate, strife,
study, prouocacion. Certo, tare, to strive or contend. Certi, certain other.
Cicero. Salust.
Certi homines, sure men and faithful. Certae opes, riches that is permanent.
Certum habere, to know surely. Ceua, a lyttelle cow that gyuethe much Milk.
Ci. ad Art.
Certo, without doubt. Ceruclius, a cabyn in the hygheste part of a ship.
Cessare, to be ydelle. Cestus, a gyrdell, wherewith the housbande did gyrde
his wife, which was set with little studdes. Ceu, as it were.
C ANTE H.
CHaere, for salve. Chalasis, the knotte wherewith women's garments were knytte
about they necks. Chalastricum nitrum, saltepeter, which is very pure, and
like to salt. Chalcantum, a kind of ynke like to brass. Plinius ^ 4.
Chameleuce, ces, an herb growing by rivers, having leaves like a poplar,
but much greatter. Chamemirsyne, is a busshe or tree, which has sharp
pryckes in the leaves, and read bearies cloustred, I suppose it to be that,
which is called holy or holme. Chamitterae, and chamitteridae, little images,
made following a greatter image. Chaniscus, the hyndermost part of a ship, by
the which the anchor hangs. Chanotia, a tarte or marchepayne, or other like
delycate thing. Chaonides, wolfes that do slay hearts. Charchesia, a cup
long and small in the myddell, and full of handels. Charisma, matis, a grace
or special benefit. Charistium, a grene marble. Charmesinum, a kind of
sylke, which deliteth the beholders. I think it be crimsin. Charopus, amyable,
pleasant, or having a good grace. Chartula, a little leaf of paper.
Chelonalopices, I suppose to be the birds which we do call Barnakles.
Chenotrophia, a house or place where waterfoule are kept. Cheospes, a king of
Egypt, which made the great steple at Memphis, whereon were so many men
workynge, that the same king spent only in parcely, oynyons, and garlike, a
thousand and three score talentes, which if it were the great talent, it
amounted of our money, to CCl. thousand five hundred and fyfty pounds.
Leuit 11.
Chirogylius, an hedgehogge. Chironomus, a daunser of a moriske. Choa, a
certain measure. also vessel, wherein was put lycour, which was offered to idols
Choenix, a mesure containing.xxvii. ounces, which is one Sextarius of Athenes,
and a half Chomer, idem quod Chorus. Chorocitharista, he that leadethe a
dance, and plays him self on an instrument. Chors, it is, a place enclosed,
wherein cattelle is kept, a barton called in some place. Chortales aues,
pultrie fedynge abroad in a barton or court of husbandry. Chorus, sieve chomer,
a measure of the Hebrews, which contains ten times as much as Batus, or
Ephi, and amounts to as much as one and fourtye measures of Athenes, called
Medimni, which in all makes two thousand, nine hundred.xii. pound of
measure, every pound being xii. ounces. Chorus, a measure of grayn, salt, and
other like things, which conteyneth as much as ten of the measures called
Medimni Attici, where in every Medimnus be.lxxii. Sextarii Attici, Read in
Sextarius. so that hit contains of our galons Chreston, an herb called also
cykorie. Chrysoberillus, a crystal stone, wherein the color of gold shyneth.
Chrysoprassus, a stone grene as a leke, having speckes of gold. Chus, seu
choa, a measure contaynyng nine pounds of measure, which is Chytracus, a
tryuet or cradel, whereon pottes are set to boil meat.
C ANTE I.
CIbum subducere, to take meat away from one. Cibum facere, to make redye
meat. plautus in Truculen.
Mane aliquid fiet cibi, There shall be some meat made ready betyme. Cibi
repositi, meat set up to be kept. Quintilla. Ci. tus. q. 1 Varro.
Cibarius panis, ra^ged bred or crybbil bread. Cibarium uinum, small wine.
Cibatus, tus, tui, vyttayles. Cicatrico, care, to strike one so that a mark
always remains. Cicatrizo, idem, also to heal a wound, so that only a
seame or scarre may appear. Ciceronianus, he that coueyteth to follow Cicero in
eloquence. Cicerbita, an herb called Southistell. Cichorea, and cichoreu^, an
herb called cikory Cicum, a thynne skin, which is within a Pomegranate.
Cicur, every beast or bird, which ones being wild, is made tame. Cicuro,
rare, to make tame. Ciere, to trouble or make him angry. Plautus.
Quid negotii est, Pistoclerum Lydus quod herum tam ciet? What is the mattier
that Lydus thus troubles or angreth his master? Festus.
Ciere, is sometime to name. Cinabulum, a cradelle. Cinara, an herb, which
some men do suppose to be an artochoke. Cinifactum, brought into ashes, as
things which are bourned. Circania, a bird, which in his flight fetches a
compass. Cirsion, an herb, which we do call buglosse. Circulo, are, to
compass about, or to make a cerkle or compass about a thing.
Circumcidaneus, a, um, cut round about. Circu^cisitum mustum, wine, which
after that the grapes are pressed, is taken out of the same grapes, being cut
and new pressed. Sueton. de claris rhetoribus. Ser. Sul. ad Cicerone^.
Circumcise agere, to make an oration by pecis, without coming to the purpose.
Circumcirca, all about. Circumcurso, are, to run hither and thither. Circundo,
dare, to enuyronne or compass about. Paulus de re iudicata Vlp. de iudiclis.
Circunduco, duxi, ducere, to lead one about. it is also to abolysshe or put
aside an act. Quod si is qui edictum peremptorium impetrauit, absit die
cognitionis, tunc circu^ducendum erit edictum peremptorium, And if that he that
has optayned the paremptorie decree, be absent the day when the matter should
be determined, than the peremptory decree is to be dyssolued or abolyshed.
Plautus in Pseud. Plautus ibidem. Plautus in Capt.
Circu^ducere, is sommetyme to deceive by cautelles. Circumducere aliquem
argento, to get ones money by falsehode. Circumductus, ta, tum, led about.
Circumductio, deceyte. Circumferre se, to go bragging about the streets.
Vergilius.
Circumflecto, tere, to turn hither and thither. Circumfundo, dear, to cast
water or other lycour about. Vergili.
Circumfusus, a, um, gathered about, as people when they desire to se a thing.
sometime wrapped about like an adder or serpent. Plin. de uitis illustr.
Circumlino, to annoynte about. Circummissus, a, um, sent about.
Circummunio, ire, to enuyron strongely, to fortify with walls or men. Cicero
Circumpedes, lackayes awaytynge at their masters styrop. also footmen of
princis. plautus.
Circumspecto, are, to behold about. Circumspectatrix, a woman that beholds
about, or watches. Circumsto, stare, to stand about. Plautus.
Circumtego, texi, tegere, to cover al about. Circumuerto, tere, to turn
about. Cirri, be things like hears about oysters. Cirratus, he that has his
hears brayded. Cis paucos dies, within few days. Plautus.
Cis vndique, in all places about. Cisium, aut cissium, a cart with two
wheles. Cispello, puli, pellere, Plautus in Amphit.
to keep out oone that he come not into the house. Citta, a pie. Ciuiliter,
like a citesyn. Also courteysly, or with good manner.

CLauola, seu clabula, a bough or stock, Varro.
wherinto a graffe is set. Cla^ me, clo^ te, I or thou not knowing. Clam
alter alterum, the oone knowyth not of the other. Clam omnes, no man knowing
or witting. Plautus in Pseud.
Clara pugna, a battle worthy memory. Claritudo, ide^ quoth claritas, also
brute, renome. Classici, they which in a town were most rich and
substanciall. Classici authors, writers of most estimation. Vergilius.
Classiarius, a man of war on the sea. Claudere, to turn about. Claudite
nymphae Dicteae, nymphae nemorum, iam. claudite saltus, Turn about ye
goddesses of Dictea, ladies of the forestes turn your daunse about.

sometime it is taken for letter patentes of a prince. Coeli, the part of

Cohibere filium, to keep under his son. Cohibere se, to moderate him self.

about a noble man. Colina, for culina, a kytchen. Collabefactari testula, to

Se after Ostracismus. Collacteus, he that sucketh of the same breast and at the
same time. Collatitius, a, um, that which is gathered and brought to gyther.
Collaudo, are, to praise with other. Collegium, a company of them, which have
equal authority. also a company of men which be of one mystery or craft.
Collibet, and collubet, collibuit, collibitum est, collibere, Plautus in Amph.
to like, to please. Vtcunque animo collibitum est meo, Even as it pleases me,

Collocare se in arborem, to klim up on a tree Colocare aliquem in soporem, to

to speak hit more shortly, to lay one aslepe with a stroke. Plautus in Merca.
Colloces te in otium, draw the to ease. Collocatus, ta, tum, put or set in
some place. Collocupleto, tare, to enryche. Colloqui aliquem, to speak to one.

with one, or to talk together. Colluuiaris porcus, an Hog that walloweth in
the mire, and there has meat given him. Colludo, dear, to play with one, or
together. Collusor, oris, a playfelowe. Plautus in Capt.
Collus, idem quod collum. Collybus, money received by exchange, or in bank,
as men do which goo into strange countrays, delyuering money of this
realm, to receive as much of an other coin, where he comes. Collybistes,
and collybiste, he that delivers money by exchange, a banker. Collyra, a
lofe of breadde, or a bunne. Colere se, to apparayle him self. Colere
officium, to do his duty or endeavor. Plautus.
Colere pietatem, to have his parents in reverence. Colere vitam, to live.
Plautus in Ruden.
Coloratus, ta, tum, colored. Columbulus, a pygeon. Columnae Herculis, are two

of hasyll. Colutea, the tree called Seen, whereof the leaves and coddes are

the facility or curteysie of one, the which agrees to any request. Terent.

Commorari, to cause one to tarry. Ante auspitium commoratum est? an tempestas
continet, qui non abisti ad legiones ita vt dudum dixeras? Did the token showed
by the birds, cause the to tarry? or else the wether keep the back, that thou
wentest not unto the army as thou saydest a while a go that thou woldeste?
Commossem, for commouissem. Donatus.
Commotus, ta, tu^, meued, troubled, afraid, angrye: also quick. Communes
dies, were unlucky days to go about any thing, such as we do call dysmoll

Comparebunt quae imperas, You shall see all things done, that ye do

ymagyne, contryue even as thou thynkest best. Compacto rem agere, to conspire
a matter, plautus in capt.
or to do a thing by one accord. Comparare, to get or purchase. Comparare

hi qui minus habent, ut semper aliquid adda^t ditioribus? What an ill use is
this, that they, which have but a little, Ci. de ami.
shall give more to them that be rich? Quando quidem ita ratio comparata est
vitae naturaeque nostrae, vt alia ^^tas oriatur ex alia, Sens the form of our

Vbi abijt co^clamo, heus quid agis tu in tegulis? When he was gone, I cried
unto him, How ferra, what do thou among the tyles? Also to make a cry or
proclamation. Plautus in Menech.
Vis conclamari auctionem fore quidem? Wylt thou have it proclaimed that there
shall be port sale. Conclamata vasa, proclamation made to trusse, to gather
bag and baggage, as is used in the raysynge of a syege, or remouynge of a
camp in battle. Conclamito, tare, to make many cries. Festus.
Conclauia, many chaumbers or places under oone kaye. Conclauium, idem quod
conclaue. Concoquere odia, to suffer dyspleasures or malice. Concredo, didi,
dear, to deliver or commit a thing upon trust. Concorditer, by assent, or
agreement. Concresco, creui, crescere, to grow together. Concretus, creta, tum,
joined or congelyd to gyther, as a thing that is lyquide, to be made hard.
Concubinatus, hooredome, fornication. Conculco, care, to tread under the
foot. Concuro, rare, to care for a thing. Concurro, rere, to rounne with an
another, Plautus in Bacch.
sometime to accord. Concursus, sus, a runnynge of people together to one
place. Condecoro, rare, to honor a thing in making it more commendable.
Condignus, na, number, worthy, and according as it is esteemed. Condign, worthyly,
honestly. Condisco, scere, to learn. Condiscipulus, a scholefelowe. Conditura,
saulse or pyckelle made with spyces. Condolet caput, my heed aketh. Plautus.
Condono, are, to give, to forgive a det or duty, to pardone. Condormio, ire,
to sleep with other. Condormisco, scere, to sleep a little, to nap. Plautus in
Asin.
Conduci non possum, I can not be made to believe: no man can make me believe.
Conductus, ta, tum, to be set to hyre. Conductor, he that hyreth a thing.
Co^dus, a steward of household, or he that keeps the store of household.
Conduplico, care, to pay the double of a thing. Conduplicatio, doubling.
plautus in Rude.
Confer, to deuyse, to talk together. Confer amorem, to love. Co^ferre
animu^ alio, to set his mind else where Confer capita, to assemble for
counsel, to lay their heads to gether. Plautus.
Confer gradum, come forth. Confer in pauca, to conclude shortly. Confer
manus, to assail each other. Pli. in pan.
Confer tempus in aleam, to spend the time in playenge at the dyce. Terent.
in Eunucho. Plautus in Bacch.
Confer uerba ad rem, to do as he says. Confer se in pedes, to run away,
to take his legs. Confert, it is profitable. Caes* in co^.
Confertus, ta, tum, full. alsoo in a flock, or multitude, in a bushment. Vt
nunquam conferti, sed rari, magnis que interuallis praeliatentur, That they
might fight, not a multitude together, but a few at oones, and a great
distaunce on sonder. Ti. Liuius.
Turba conferta iter clausit, The people gathered in a bushment, Caesar.
stopped the way. Qua part hostium acies confertissima uisa est, erupit, He
brake out on that side, where the host of the enmyes seemed to be most thycke
of people. Confertim, in a bushement. Plautus in Mercator. plautus in persa.
Conficere pensum, to spynne out her threde, it is translatid into this
sentence, To have done or brought to an end that thing, which he was
commanded or appointed. plautus in Men.
Conficere prandium, to have dyned. Pallium ad phrigionem fere confecto
prandio, when dinner was done, or when he had dyned, he carried her mantell to
the brouderar. Terentius in Andria. Ci pro L. Flacco.
Conficere solicitudines alicui, to bring one into heaviness, or to make him
sorrowful. Conficientissimus literarum, he that puts all thing in writynge.
Confidentia, trust, hope, certain assurance, also mad hardynesse.
Confidentiloquus, he that speaks boldly, without fear. Plautus.
Configo, fixi, figere, to stycke or thruste in to a thing. Confingo, finxi,
fingere, to feign a thing to be true. Confingere dolum, to find a mean to
deceive one. Confirmo, are, to confyrme, or assure a thing to be as it is
spoken. Confirmare se, Ci. Tyro.
to make him self strong after his sickness. Confirmare animum, to take
courage. Confirmitas, assuridnesse. Co^flagro, are, to be on a fire, to be
inflamid Conflictatio, Donatus.
is where as one thing beats against a another. Confluuium et confluxus, a

Terentius. in And.
Conformo, are, to bring to a facyon or figure, to make apt or like to a

to be out of favor, Plautus in Cistell.
or no more welcome to one. Confringere rem, to spend away all his
substance. Confragosus, a, um, roughe, Ibidem.
as a ground which is not plain, also hard to be understand, rude in

to trouble all, Liuius. 6.
also to myxe out of order. Confutatio, a disprouynge of that which is spoken.
Congelatur, it is frosen or congelyd. Congemino, nare, to double. Congeminatio,

he that keeps company only in pastyme and merry deuysynge. Congestitius, a,
um, cast up in a heap. Conglacio, aui, are, to be frosen. Conglobatim, in a
round form like to a bottom of threde. Conglutino, nare, to join together,

commune word, to make good chere. Congressus, us, is also company with other.
Congruens, according, like. Conijcere in saginam, to put to fattynge, to go
where he may fill his bealy. Coniugata, be those words, which being of one
kind, be diriued one of an other, as of Iustitia, iustus, and iustum, whereof
an argument may be made in this wise, If Justice is to be chiefly honored and
loved of men, a just man is to be had in estimation and reverence among men.
Coniugatio, a ioynynge to gether. Coniunctura, idem. Coniunctus, ta, tum,
joined. Coniunctim, to gether. Connato, tare, to swymme to gether. Connecto,
nexui, nectere, to bind together. Conniuentia, a sufferaunce of a thing, or a
fayninge not to se or espy. Connatio, a swymmynge to gether. Conquassatio, a
bruysnge together. Conqueror, queri, to complain, Conquiesco, eui, escere, to
cesse, to leave of. Conquiro, quisiui, quirere, to seek all about. Conquisitor,
a sercher, also an officer, which is sent to attache a man for a great offense.

after our manner of speaking is to demourre in law, or dwell in law, to

to confyrme or advance the reverence dew to the supreme authority.

For thou may now bring to pass, that thy wench may be with thy father
without any dread. Copia est, I may or might. Terentius in p^o^m.
Ego in eum incidi infelix lo cum, ut neque eius sit an ittendi, nec retin endi
copia: I am vnhapily come to that point, that I may neither leave her, nor

plautus in Epidico. Plautus i^ Milite. pli. in epi.
Thou haste no leisure to tarry. Copia est tibi magis, thou may more easily.

nine ounces, as well at Rome, as in Greece. Cotyla hyppoiatrica, that is to
say, which was used in medicines for horses and cattle contained.xii. ounces.
Cotyla georgica, that is to say, which was used in things concerning
styllage, conteynyd.xiii. ounces and a half. sometime it is usurped for
Sextarius.
C ANTE R.
CRacentes, for graciles. Crambe, a kind of colewortes. Cramben repetitiam, is
called of Iuuenalie a Declamation to be often herd, with much tediousnes to
the herers. Crapulam exhalare, to vomyte when one is drunk. Crapulam
edormiscere, to sleep out drunkenness until he be fresh again. Crasis, a
greek word, sygnyfieth complexion, temperature, or myxture of natural
humors. Crassamen, thyckenesse. Crasse compedes, weyghty gyues. Plautus in
pseudolo.
Crasso, are, to make fat. Crater, is also the basin of a water cundite,
wherinto the water runs out of pypes or cocks. Creator, the first maker of
a thing. Creber, bra, brum, is also standing, or being thycke together, as
trees. Crebritas, and crebritudo, oftennesse, or thiknes in being or growyng
together. Credere verba alicui, to tell to oone his counsaylle. Creditur tibi,
I trust the. Plautus in Sticho plautus in Curcu. Plautus. Columel. 6. cap. 25.
Creditur male, it is ylle lent. Creduis, uel creduas, for credas.
Cremasteres, the synewes, whereby the stones of a man or beast do hang.
Cremo, are, to bourne. Crepa, of old writers is used for Capra, a Goote.
Crepare, to be broken, also to speak or prech. Vergili. Horatius.
Crepidatus, he that wears slyppers. Crepidula, a little slyppar. Crepitare
dentibus, to crashe with the teth. Plautus in Ruden. plautus in Amphit.
Crepitat mihi uenter, my bealy courleth. Crepuit foris, the door craked.
Crispus, he that has a curlyd hear. Crista, a kreste, or any thing growyng
on the head of a foul or beast, as a cocks comb, or the feathers on the
head of a bird, called a coppe. Crociatus, ta, tum, colored like saffron.
Crocito, tare, to croke like a raven or crow. Crocitus, the noise that raven or
crow makes, called crokynge. Crocitatio, idem. Crocomagma, matis, the duste
or refuse of Saffron. Cronia, the feasts of Saturn. Cruciabilitas, and
cruciatus, turment, affliction. Cruci dare aliquem, to hang one. Plautus in
Milite.
Crucifigo, fixi, gere, to crucyfie. Crucio, are, to tourment. Cruda poma,
fruits that are not ripe. Crusculum, a little or small leg. Crustum, is
also a morcel of bread or meat. Vergili.
Crux, sygnifieth all manner of tourment.
C ANTE V.
CVcurbitula, a little gourde or cup, wherewith blood is drawn out of a
man, when he is scarified. Cucuma, a vessel of brass or tynne, facioned like
a Cucumer, wherewith bathes were filled and emptied. Cudetur in me faba, all the
blaame shall be laid to me. Cuiusmodi, what, what facion, what manner. Plautus
in Menech. Oicer. procluen. Cicer. pro Roscio.
Cuiusmodi homines erunt? What manner of men shall they be? Cuiusmodicunque
matter sir? What so ever a mother she be? Cuiusquemodi. Vereor enim cuiusque
modi es Rosci, ne ita hunc uidear voluisse setuare, ut tibi omnino non
pepercerim, I fear me that in what so ever state thou art in Ros. lest it
shall be thought, that I would so excuse or defend him, forasmoche as I have
not all spared the. Salusti. in catelin.
Cuiuscunque modi genus hominum, of all manner of sorts of men. Culcitrula, a
little fether bed. Festus.
Culcitula, a little staff. Culeus, among the Romans was the greattest
measure, and receives twenty of the measures called Amphora, which amounts
to two thousand, eight hundred, four pound of measure, every pound being
twelve ounces. It was also a sack of lether, wherinto they, which had
slain their fathers or mothers were sown, and with them were also put alive,
a Cock, a Serpent, and an Ape, and thrown al together in to the river of
Tyber. And this was the punishment of paricides or murderers of their parents.
Plautus in Capt.
Culpa carere, not to offend. Culpam commereri, to commit an offense. Culpam
in alterum confer, to lay the blame to an another. Culpito, tare, to blame
often. Culpo, pare, to blame. Cululus, a little chalyce or cup of earth,
which the bishops used in sacrifice. plautus in paenulo.
Cum, all be it. Nam cum sedulo munditer nos habemus, uix aegre amarorculos
inuenimus, All though we do appoint us never so kleanly, yet uneath find we any
lovers. Cum dicto, forthewith, as soon as it was spoken. Terentius in Hecyra.
Cum maxume, to much. Cumulatus, ta, tum, augmented. Cumulate, abundantly.
Vergilius.
Cunabula, is also taken for the beginning of things. Cunctanter, slowely,
soft and fair. Cunctatio, and contatio, taryenge. Cunctus, ta, tum, all
togther. Cunilago, a kind of sauerye. Cupiens, he that desires a thing.
Cupiens tui est, he loves the hartyly. Cupienter, with great desire. Cupitus,
ta, tum, desired. Cupressus, a Cypress tree. Cupressinus, na, number, of cypres
tree. Curiata comitia, were assemblyes of people in places of judgment, for
matters in varyaunce. Curio, is also a curate, Liuius.
or he that has the spiritual charge in a paryshe. Curionatus, the office of
a curate. Curionium, the money that is given to a curate for doing his office.
Curmundulla, pears very delycate, having so thynne parings, that men did
eat them vnparyd. Curare, to care for a thing, to take heed, Terent. in
Andria.
or be dilygent about a thing. Cura ut valeas, Look to thy health. Curasti
probe, Thou haste done every thing well. Curare aedes, to take heed to the
house, Plautus. Terent. in Heauto.
that nothing be lost. Curare aliena, to meddell with other men's business.
Curare amicos, Plautus in Sticho Plautus in Trinu^mo.
to entertayne friends or acquayntaunce. Curare fidem, to keep promise. Curare
munus suum, to do his office. Curabo illi pecuniam, I will provide that he
shall have money. Curabitur, it shall be provided. Curatus, ta, tum, done with
dilygence. Curatus, in good point or state. Curatio, charge. Curatio mea est,
Plautus in poenu.
It is mine office or charge. Currens, he that runs. Currentem incitare, to
exhort or set forward him that of his own courage is well disposed to a
thing. Cursim, with all speed, very spedyly. Cursura, a course. Cuticula, a
thynne skin. Cutiones, they which in selling make many prices or they come
to a point. Festus.
Cuturnium, a vessel, out of the which wine was poured in sacrifices.
C, ANTE Y.
CYanus, a blewe flower growing among corn, called a bluebottell. Cyathisso,
are, to syppe or to quafte, all out, or halues. Cyathus, the.xii. part of the
mesure called Sextarius, which was supposed to be as much as commonly a
temperate man did drink at one draught. Read more after in Sextario. Cyborium,
a kind of appuls of Alexandria. Cydarum, a boat. Cynodontae, are dogs tethe,
which do grow in the latter age. Cyperus Babylonicus, Galyngale. Cypsili,
birds called swalowes. Cyrnij, people of the I Will of Cors. Cysthus, a kind of
yuye. Cytinus, the flower of a garden pomegranate.
D ANTE A.
DAGNADES, were little birds, which in Egypt men used to make fast to
garlandis when they went to drinking. Damascoena, prunes. Vlpian. L. aqu^^^a.
Cic. Epist. libr. 17. ad Volu^n^um Cic in L. pi^onem.
Damnas dare, to pay damages. Damnum facere, to suffer damage, to have loss.
Damnatus, condemned. Damnatior, more worthy death. Danista, an vserer.
Danisticus, ca, cum, pertaining to vsery. Plautus in Trucu.
Dapsilis lectus, an excellent good bed. Daphnoides, an herb callid Lorell
or Laury, which cuseth a vehemente purgation. Dapsilia dicta, words frankely
spoken. Dascia, thyckenes of brethe. Daucus, yelowe carette, whereof the roots
sodden in brothe are pleasant and holsom.
D ANTE E.
Plautus (...)
DE nocte abijt, he went away at night. De nocte uigila^e, to wake i^ the night
De die, to day. Ergo ne una orationis pars de die dabitur mihi, Than shall not I
be suffered to speak one little word to day. ^
De die uiuere, every day, or from day to day, to live. Plautus in per^a.
Plautus in Bacch. Plautus in Monech. Cicero. Cicero. Terentius in Hecyra.

De meo, of my good, de tuo, of thy good. De mea sententia, by my counsel. De
illis verbis cave tibi, beware how thou spekest such words. De imperio
decertatur, they fight for the empire, or chief rule. De manu in manum, from
hand to hand. De filia te adij, I comme to speak with you for your daughter.
De meo exemplo aedificet, let him build according to my platte. De ista^ te
amo, I love the for her sake. De compacto, by agreement. De industria, of
purpose. De integro, eftesoones from the beginning. De improuiso, at adventure,
unsought for, or unlooked for. De more, as it has been accustomed. De nihilo
nihil est irasci, It is folly to be angry for nothing. De praefacili exores,
Thou shalt lyghtely opteyne. plautus.
De proximo senex, the old man that dwells hereby. De repent, suddenly. De
subito, idem. Deam bulatio, a walking forth, or abroad, out of the house.

foolysshely, Fe^^^^. Non. Mar.
to babble rebukeully. Decaluo, to make very balde. Decaphorus, a lytter borne
by ten men. Ci. ad At. Plinius.
Decedere, to give place to an other. Decedere itinere, to turn out of the
way for some purpose. Plautus Ci. in Ver.
Decedere uia, to go out of the way. Decedere de suo more, Ti. Liuius.
to change his custom. Decedere instituto suo, Ci. in Ver. Liuius.
to do otherwise than he was wont. Decedere officio, to do against his duty
to do no more his duty. Terent. in Adelph. Cic. A^t. 1.
Decede^ nihil de summa, there shall be nothing minyshed. Decedere, to dye.
Decedi, to have place or way given. Cicero de senectute.
Haec enim ipsa sunt honorabilia, quae uidentur leuia atque communia, salutari,
appeti, decedi, assurgi, deduci, reduci, For those things ar honorable,
which seem to be of small effect and commune, to be awayted on, to be sued
unto, to have the way given, to be risen unto, to be brought to the court. and
brought again home. December, the number of ten. Decemuiri, where ten men be
in one authority. Such were at Rome soon after that they ceased to have
kings, and they had authority to gather laws, and also to make laws: At the
last they conspired to have a perpetual authority, and fynallye were
therefore deposed for ever. Decemuiratus, the dignity or office of Decemuiri.
Colu. li. 4.
Decenus, na, number, a dosen. Decies, ten times. Decennalis, le, of ten
years. Decennium, the space of ten years. Decenter, comelye, seemly, Terent.
in Necyra.
or as hit is conuenyent. Decermina, things pulled away, in making things
clean. Decernere, to purpose. Plautus in Mostel.

fight in battle. Decet me haec vestis, this garmente becomes me well. Pli.
in epi. 105. Terent. in Heautont. Plautus i^ Bacch.
Decidit ab archetypo, he did not follow his first example. Decidere de spe,

do fall. Decies sestertium, was used of the Romans for a thousand Sestertia,
which amounts of our money to six thousand, five hundred, four score and
seven pound, and ten shyllynges. Plinius. Varro.

is a proverb which sygnifyeth to be without any manner of care. It may be

DVbenus, old writers used for dominus. Dubitatim, doubtfully. Vergilius.

Hanc esse in te sapientiam existimant, ut omnia tua in te posita esse ducas,
Men think that wysedom to be in you, that ye think all that which is your
own, to be in your self and not in Fortune. Ducere honori, to repute it
honorable. Salustius in iugurt. Ibidem.

D, ANTE Y.
Dynastea, a rule or governance.
EFOR THE MORE part signifies of. Ere nata, considering the matter. Ere nata
mellus fieri haud potuit, quam factum est: Co^sideringe the matter, or as the
matter chanced, it could not have been better done than it was. Eregione, on
the other part, on the other side against.

EBeati, they which from great prosperity are fallen into mysery. Ebeo, are,

ECastor, an oath of the paynymes. Plautus in mercator.
Ecce me, lo here I am. Eccere, some used it for an oath, as it were, by Ceres:

reherce the judgment. Cicero

E ANTE F.
EFfascino, nare, to bewytche any thing, as wytches do, which disfygure
children, and distroye grain and other things with sorcery. Effata, were
certain prayers, which the diuinours used to make at the end of their
divination or telling the success of thingis Effectum dare, to bring to
pass. Terent. in Adelphis. Cicer. her tensio.
Efferre sese, to praise him self. Effere manum, to lift up his hand. Effere
aliquem laudibus, to extolle oone with praises. Efferre, to deuulgate, or to
tell abroad. Efferre, to advance or promote. Effero, rare, to make wood as a
beast. Efferueo, ere, to boil much. Efferuesco, scere, to begin to boil or
sethe. Cicero de oratore. Plautus in Casina.
Efferuescentia uerba, hot angry words. Effexis, for effeceris. Efficere
argentum alicui, to get money for a man by some mean or deuyse. Efficientia,
idem quod effectus. Effigio, are, to counterfayte ones image in payntynge or
keruynge. Effilo, lare, to sow. Effilatum, that which is sowed or stitched on
a garment, as a guard or purfle. Plautus in (...). Plaut. in (...). Plautus in
(...) Ci. de (...). Terent. in Eunucho. Cice. ^^^e.
Effio, fieri, to be done. Effligo, flixi, fligere, to tourment. Efflare,
animam, to dye. Efflauit animam spes, I have no manner of hope or trust.
Effiuet, it shall out, I will not keep it, all men shall know it. Effluxit,
it is quyte gone. Effoetus, ta, tum, hatched, as a bird that is come out of
the egg. Effoetum corpus, a weak body. Effreno, nare, to vnbrydell. Effringo,
effregi, gere, to break to pieces. Effractus fame, made feeble for lack of
meat Effugit memoria, to be forgotten. Plautus in Bacch. Terent. in Andria.
Pli. in epi. and in pane.
Effugere nuptias, not to be married. Effuse, effusius, effusissime, abundantly,
more vehemently, excedyngly.
E ANTE G.
EGens est consilij, he lacks counsel Egeria, was an ydol, to whom women
with child did offer, supposyng that thereby they should travail easily. Egerit
aquam fons, the fountain pousheth out water. Egestio, onis, distribution
abroad, it is also the putting forth of ordure or dunge. Ego, I. Egomet, I my
self. Terent. in Eunucho.
Ego ne, who I.
E ANTE H, and I.
EHem, is a word spoken, when a man is moved with some thing, which is newly
happened. Eheu, alas. Eho (...), how serra, when one calls a man to him,
forgetting his name. Eiectus, ta, tum, cast out. Eiecto, tare, to throw
out. Eiulatio, a brayenge out with lamentation. Eiurare, to renounce,
Eiuratio, renouncing.

bonis, Plautus in Asina.
to be clean washed from all his goods, to spend all, and leave nothing.

illum, see where he is. Donatus.
Elops, a fyshe called also Accipenser. Eluceo, cere, to shine. Vergilius.

E ANTE M.
EMaciatus, ta, tum, made lean. Emancipatus, ta, tum, alyened. Emancipati, are
also they, which are out of their fathers rule, or they, Festus. Cic. in
catelina^.
which are made subjects to an another. Embata, a ship called a barque.

the adding of a day in the year Emeritum stipendium, the last wages that a man
takes in wars. Emeriti senes, old men excused from labor by age. Emico,
care, to skyne forth. Emicare, to dance or leap. Emigro, grate, to goo from
oone place, Plautus in Aulular. Vergilius.
to dwell in an another. Emmanuel, is interpreted, God is with us. Emoueo, uere,

spheeres, and signifies the fyry heaven. Emu^io, tire, to humme or make any
other sown like a man that is dumme.
E ANTE N.
ENarro, rare, to tell a thing at length. Enato, tare, to swymme out.

be fallen into a man's codde. Enucleate, clearly.

E, ANTE P.
EPacta, things added to. Ephesus, a city in Greece. Ephialtes, is that
disease, which is called the mare in slepynge. Ephimeron, the great wild
Lylly. Ephod, a stole, which a priest wears about his neck, when he is at
mass. Epicoenum, of both kinds. Epicia, called aequum and bonum, equytie,
which is justice without rigor of the law. Epimytheon, the declaration of a
fable. Epiphora, a syckenes of the eyes, callid the droppynge of the eyes.
Epiroticus, ca, cum, of the countray called Epirus. Eporhedicae, good breakers
of horses. Epulae, larum, a banquet made to many persons Epha, seu Ephi, a
mesure of the Hebrews or Jews, containing.lxxii. times the measure called
Sextarius Atticus. Read more after in Sextarius.
E, ANTE Q.
EQuiceruus, a beast in the oryente, having horns, and a long mane to the
shulders, and a bearde under his chyn, and fete round like a horse, and is as
great as an heart. Equisetum, an herb called horsetayle.
E ANTE R.
ERadico, care, to pluck up by the rotis. Eradicare aures alterius, to pulle
oone hard by the ears. Plautus in Epidico.
Erasus, a, um, rased or scraped out. Erogatio, distribution of things to
other men, a lyberall gyuynge. Erogito, tare, to desire heartily. Eros, love.
Erotema, it is, a demand. Erotematicus, he that often demands. Errare de
verbis alicuius, to mysvnderstande the words that one speaks. Erratio, a
goinge out of the way. Terent. in Adelph.
Erratum, an error. Erumpo, rupi, erumpere, to braste out, some time to leap
forth. Erumpet in neruum istae^ fortitudo, Terent. in phorm. Donatus. Erasmus
in Adag.
is a proverb, which is dyuersely expound, for it may signify, This courage
of thine may bring the to a halter, or to ^y^te by the heles. or it may
sygnify, This great strength or courage of thine will come unto nothing. which
proverb is taken of archers, which oftentimes when they put forth most
strength: they break the string of their bow, and the arowe falls down at
their fete, whereby the shot is lost, and comes to nothing. Eruptio, is
when an host issues hastily out of a camp or fortress, and falls on their
ennemies. Eruum, the grene peason. Eryngion, an herb like a thystel, the rote
whereof being condite or conserved in honey with cynamome and cloves,
comfort nature, and styrreth courage, and is of some men called Yringus.
E ANTE S.
ESalon, is a bird, which breaks crows eggs, and her birds be distroyd by
the wolf, and likewise she kylleth the wolfes whelpis, if she may com by them
Esau, the son of Isaac, and brother of Jacob. Essedarius, a charyot man.
Estrix, a woman rauenour or deuourer. Esurio, onis, an hungrye fellow. Plautus
in persa. Varro.
Esurigo, ginis, hunger.

GABA, a town in Galile Gabalum, a town in France, nyghe to Narbona, where

fysshe, which Hermolaus Barbarus takes for a Sturgeon.

IN annum, for a year. In bonis, among good men. In coenam, for supper. In
conspectum aspice, look before the. In diem uiuere, to live without carynge for

In pedem, for every foot. Is se ternis nummis in pedem tecum transegisse

every foot. Cicer. pro lege Ma.
In potestatem esse, under the rule, or at the pleasure of one. In praesentia,

Incoctae mulieres, women which do trymme their hears to much. Incoctile, a
brasyn or copper vessel, tynned within. In consilio ad^sse, to be of counsel
in a matter in law. Cic. act. 4. in Verrem
Me quoque Petilius, vt sibi consilio adessem, rogauit: Petilius alsoo desired
me, that I would be of counsel. Plautus in cistell.
Incordio, aui, are, to put into a man's heart, to persuade him. Incubo, bonis,
they that set al their study on treasure. Plautus in Aulular. Ibidem.
Incumbere, to be inclyned to some thing. Incumbere gladium, to thrust him
self on a sword. Indecens, unsitting, inconvenient. Indecoris, re, idem quod
Indecor. Indecore, an aduerbe, sygnifyeng unhonestly, vnconueniently. Indico,
dixi, dicere, to denounce properlye war. Indicere consilium, to call or
command a counsel. Indicere iustitium, to command a vacation or as we do
say, to keep no term. Indicere pecuniam populo, to set a tax or subsydie on
the people. Induere posts pice, plautus in mostel.
to lay on pytche on the posts. Induere personam alterius, to speak in the
name or stead of a another man. Quintilia.
Induere personam iudicis, to represente a judge. Industry, wyttyly. Inire
rationem, to find the mean. Inire, to leap, as a horse lepeth a mare.
Ineunte aetate, in youth. Ineunte uere, at the beginning of the spring of the
year. Inexhaustus, a, um, never ceasynge. Infer crimen alicui, to lay to
ones charge. Infer sermonem, to talk. Infectus, infected, stained, dyed.
Infectum reddere, to undo that which is done. Infecta pace, without any
peace made. Infector, a dyar of colors. Infit, he said, he began. Inflecto,
tere, to bow or plye. Influo, xi, ere, to run into a thing, as water or
other lycour does. Infuco, care, to color a thing, intending deceipte.
Infuscare uinum merum, Plautus in cistell.
to alaye wine with water. Ingeniculus, a figure among the sterres. called
now Hercules. Ingenua facta, noble acts. Ingens animus, a great courage.
Plautus in milite. Plautus in Asina.
Ingerere dicta in aliquem, to chyde with one, to say ill of one. Ingerere
malum, to do displeasure. Ingerere pugnos, to strike with the fyste. Ingratijs,
maulgre one. Plautus in Amphit. and in curcu. Terentius in Eunuch.
Ingratus, ta, tum, unthankful, dyspleasaunt, constrained, or against a
man's will also unkind, and not remembrynge frendshyppe, or benevolence.
Inguinium, a city in Liguria, aunciente and rich. Inhabilis, le, unapt.
Plinius in Epistolis, Plautus in Sticho Ci. in phil.
Inhabito, tare, to dwell in a place. Inhibere imperium, to have charge or
rule. Inhibere supplicia alicui, to execute turmentes on one, or to put one to
death. Inhibere nauem, to cast ancre, or to stay a ship, which is under
sail, that she sail not a full course. Terent. in Eunucho.
Inhonestus, ta, tum, dishoneste. Inhoneste, dishonestly. Inhonoratus, ta, tum,
lacking honor. Inhospes, he that will lodge no man. Inhospita tecta, houses
where no man may lodge. Inhospitalis, le, unapt for lodging, Cicer. pro
Roscio.
Inh^mo, are, to put into the ground. Inijcere manus in aliquem, to apprehende
or attache one. Terentius in phormi.
Inijcere scrupulum alicui, to put one in a fantasye. Sucton.
Inijcere studium alicui, to cause one to study. Iniquo animo far, to be
myscontented or so rowfull. Inique, myscheuousely, or unjustly. Plautus in
Trucu^en. Cicero de senectute.
Iniuria tua, through thy defaulte. Iniussu imperatoris, without the emperors
commandment. Iniusta, ta, tum, unjust, also exceeding just measure.
Unjust, unjustly. Innascor, sci, to be engendered in one. Innatus, ta, tum,
engendered. Innocens, vnharmefull, innocent. Innocentia, integrity, true
intent. Pli in epi. (...).
Inossensus, unhurt. Inofficiosum testamentum, where the father by testament
gives away from his son his lands or goods without cause. ^
Inops ab amicis, dyspouruayed of friends. Inops amicorum, idem. Inopia,
poverty, lack of things necessary Inopi^atus, unthought on or unlooked for. ^
In quantum, in as much, or for as much. Inquam, I said. In^anitas,
madness. Insaciabilis, le, insatiable. Ins^endo, dear, to go up, or to clyme.
Terent. in H^^^to. Cicer pro P. Sylla. Tit. Li. 4.
Insciens, vnwyttinge. also not thinking on that he does. Inscientia,
ignorance. Instaurare bellum, to make war eftsoon. Insuitor, may also be
called a factour which byeth and ^elleth for a another man. Institoria actio,
an action brought by the master against his factour, or by the factour
against his master. plautus in Epidic. Terent. in phorm. Cicero in philip.
Instiruere astutiam, to find a craft to deceive oone. In integrum restiuiere,
to restore a thing to as good point as it was in. Integrum est, hit is at his
pleasure or in his power. Integre, truly, and diligently. Cicero de oratore.
In integro esse. Sed quoniam haec iam neque in integro esse possunt: But for
as much as there is no remedy, or that these things may not be helped, or
may not be in as good point as they were. Cic. de Senectute.
Intemperans, he that does every thing with out order or measure. Intendere
f^rmulam, to bring an action against one. Sueton^^s in Vitell. Sueton. in
Ty^^^ in Cic. ad Q. fratrem. Terent. in Eunucho.
Inter coenam, for In coena. Inter nos amamus, we love together oone an another.
Inter ^ias, by the way riding or goinge. Intercessor, he that lets a
matter, that it may not goo forward. Interpellatio, a let in a man^
business. Interpellator, he that lets oone that he may not speak or do a
thing. Intrarius amicus, a special friend. plautus.
Intybum, seu Intybus, is the generalle name to all kinds of Lichorye or
Succhorye. as commune Succhorie, Scariole, Endive, and Dendelyon.
I, ANTE S.
Ischiros, idem quod fortis, strong. Isatis, Ode, wherewith clothes are dyed
blewe.
I, ANTE T.
ITa me deus amer, So god love me, Plautus. Terentius
or help me. Ita ut fit, as it happens. Dum rus eo, Terent. in Eunucho.
coep^egomet mecum inter uias, ita ut fit, ubi quid in animo est molestiae,
aliam rem ex alia cogitare, When I went down into the countraye, by the
way riding, as it happens oftentimes, when any displeasure comes to my
mind, I bethought me of one thing and other. Ita ut erat, as it was in deed.
Ita ne? but is it so? or is it as thou sayste? Also it sygnyfieth a note of
dysdayne. Terent. in Andria.
Ita ne contennor abs re? Settyst thou so lyttelle by me? Itaque, wherefore
than. Itaque, and so. Item, even as, also, in like manner. Iter facere, to goo
a journey.
I, ANTE V.
IVcunde, merilye, gladdely, pleasauntly, dylertably. Iucunditas, dilectation,
pleasure. Iudi^io perfundere, Cicer. pro Sex. Rose.
to bring one to the point to be condemned. Iurare in uerba alterius, to do
fealty, or to be sworn a subject. Iurare in lege alterius, plin. de viris
illustr.
to swear to keep the laws or ordinances of an another. Ius bonum dicis, thy
request is reasonable. Plautus in Stico. Plautus in Epidico.
Ius dicis, thou speak reason. Iure, with good cause. Iure ue^iuiu^ia, by
right or wrong. Terent. in Andri. Plautus in Capti. Ter. in Ad.
Iusta seruitus, service without rygour. Iusti honores, honors due. Iuuat
mihi, It does me good, it is a pleasure to me.
L ANTE A.
LABIO, is a fyshe, which I suppose to be that that is called God, with the
great lyppes. it was alsoo the Surname of a Romayne. Labrum, a lyppe. also the
brymme of a river also a washing basyn. Laccia, a fyshe called a cheuyn.
Plautus in Sticho Plautus in Asin. Priscianus Festus.
Lacerare diem, to lose the day, to spend the time about naught. Lachrimula,
a little ^eare. Lacio, lacui, and lexi, lacere, to bring into a snare, or to
wind one in to deceive him. Lamia, is alsoo an herb called a blind or dead
nettyll. Lagopus, an herb, which I suppose to be Auyns. Latheris, an herb
called Spurge.
L. ANTE E.
LEchia, a fysshe, which some have taken to be Tunye, for the symylitude of
them. Legere, to ch^se. Lege agere, to sewe in the law, also to do execution.
Lent palustyis, duckes meat, which is in standing waters. Leo, a shelle
fyshe called a lopstar. Lepide, pleasantly, pratyly. Lepista, a little pot
or vyole. Lep^a, is the smalleste poyse that may be, whereof there are.lxxxiiii.
in one scruple, in a dram..CClii. Leucophlegmantia, a spyce of the dropsye,
where the face and members are white, and swollen great. Leuare aliquem onere,
to discharge oone of his burdeyne. Leuare laborem, to mynyshe his labor.
Leuare morbum, to put out of pain. Leuia nina, small wynes. Leuita, a deacon.
Leuiter, lightly.
L* ANTE I.
LIa, oone of the wives of Jacob the patriarche. Libella, the diminuti^^ of
Libra, it was also a small coin, and of them were two sorts, one was worth
the senthe part of Sestertius, the other the tenthe part of Denarius.
Libelhones, caryers of letters. Libere, frankly, liberally, without constraint
Libere uiuere, to live at pleasure. Liberalis forma, a good favor. Liberale
ingenium, a free courage. Libertus, a bondsman manumised. Libra, a pound
weight, whereof were diverse, one was the Romayne pound, which contained.xii.
ounces, or four score and xvi. drammes, an another was belonging to exchaungers
or bankers, and was but of viii. ounces, an other was callid Mina, whereof read
more in Mina. Lichen, an herb called Lyuerwort. Limaria, the fyshe callid
Tuny, when it does not excede one foot in length. Lingulaca, a fyshe called a
sole. Litem contestari, I suppose does sygnifie as much as that which our
lawyers do say, to enterpleade when oone, which is not party to the action,
comes in, or is called in to plead with the other, to the intent to save his
title or interest, which is supposed that he has with them.
L ANTE O.
LOcus obiurgandi, occasion to chyde. Terent. i^ And.
Loca^e filiam, to bestow his dowghter in marriage. Locusta, a fyshe callid a
creuyse. Locutor, he that speaks much. Log, is the same measure of the
Hebrews, Gellius.
that Sextarius atticus, is among the Greeks. Read more in Sextarius.
L ANTE V.
LVcigena, engendered of light. Lucto, idem quod luctor. Ludos reddere, and
ludos facere, Terentius Martialis. Cicer. pro domo sua.
to mock Ludia, a merry wene he full of sport. Lummibus obstruere, to stop up
the light, to let that the light may not come into a house. Lumina
prefer, to inspyre. Lumminosus, a, um* full of light. Cic. antequam iret in
exilium.
Lumbrici, little fyshes taken in small rivers which are like to lampurnes,
but they be much less, and somewhat yelowe, and are called in wylteshire
prides. Lupus, is a fyshe, which some men take for a pyke. Lupus sanctarius,
hoppes, wherewith biere is made.
L ANTE Y.
Lydius lapis, a proverb spoken of an exact judgment, or that which is
exactly tried. Lysimachia, a city in Ponto, which fell down with an
erthquake.
M, ANTE A.
MACER, seu Macir, a spyce called Maces.
M ANTE E.
Medica, an herb, which I suppose to be clouer grass with purple round
flowers. Melandria, the lean parts of the fish called Tuny. Melanurus, a
kind of perches, callydde Ruffes. Melita, an isle lyenge between Sycile and
Affryke, which is now callydde Malta, where at this time the company of the
knights hospytilers do inhabit, as they did at the Rhodes. Merula, a fyshe
called Merlyng or whiting. Minutum, idem quod l^pta. Mygala, a field mouse with
a long snoute, called a shrewe.
O ANTE C.
OCymum, an herb called Basyll. Ocuiata, a perch fyshe. Olus atrum, an herb
callid Alisa^der. Orchynus, a great Tuny fyshe. Orphus, a fyshe like to a
Burnarde. Orcha, a great fyshe of the sea, which deuoureth men and beasts
hole, of the which fysshe we do see great bones hanged up in the kings
houses. It is also a great pytcher, which serves for wine or oil.
P, ANTE A.
PAGRI, fyshes, which I suppose are dacis. Paliurus, some do suppose it to be a
fyrse, or a whyn. Partheniu^, is supposed of some well learned men to be tansye,
which opinion I think to be best.
P, ANTE E.
PEctines, shell fyshes called Scalopes. Pectunculi, cockylles. Perca, a fyshe
called a perch. Persicaria, an herb, which is supposed to be Arssmerte.
Pertica, a measure conteynyng.xvi. fete, and is called a perch or a pole, or a
rod, it is sometime but.x. fete, and in wodde land xviii. fete. Perasites, a
clote, the leaves whereof are laid on butter.
P ANTE H.
PHellandrion, an herb callid Filipe^dula Philago, Cudworte. Phisides, fysshes
like tenches, but that they are greener. Physiter, a great fyshe, which
spoutethe out of his mouth great goulfes of water. Phoenix, waybenet or bent.
Phocena, a fysshe called Porpuse, or like unto it.
P ANTE O.
POlygonon, knotte grass. Pompilus, a kind of great Tuny. Iousus.
Populus alba, an aspe tree. Porca, Columel.
in mesure was reckned half a roude land, or the.vii. part of an acre.
Pseudonardus, lauander. Psitta, a fysshe called turbutte. Pugillus, as much as
the holownes of the hand may conteyne. Pychis, a cubyte. Pygmei, people,
which are but a Cubyte in length.
R ANTE A.
RAIA, a fyshe called skeate. Ranunculus, an herb called crowfote or
goldeknappe. Rhombus, a Fysshe called a Turbutte. Ricinum, an herb callydde
Palma Christi.
R ANTE V.
RVbea mayor, an herb called madder. Rubea minor, an herb callid cliuers.
Rumex, dockes, sometime it is taken for Sorell. Ruscum, holme or hethbrushe.
S, ANTE A.
SABINA, an herb called Sauyne. Sampsuchus, an herb called Maioram gentle.
Satureia, an herb callydde Sauerye.
S ANTE C.
Scarus, is a fyshe, which I suppose is in Deuonshyre called a Bekar. Scilla,
some do call it a sturgion.
S, ANTE E.
SEDVM maius, houseleke or syngrene Sedum minus, an herb callid stonecroppe.
Selibra Romana, the Romayne half pound comprehended asmoch as our hole pound.
Saepia, a fyshe having but one bone, wherein goldesmythes do make mouldes, and
is called a cuttyll. Seris, an herb callid white endive and scariole Sextula
gemina, is the third part of an ounce, called also Duella. Siclus, among the
hebrews was half an ounce. Siliquastrum, an herb which some do suppose to
be cost mary. Smilax, lacis, french peasyn. Solanum, an herb, which some do
suppose to be nyghtshade or morell. Solanum soporiferum, an herb, which I
suppose to be Dwale. Solonos uesicaria, Alkakengi. Sonchus, an herb called
Southistell. Sportula, the stipende given to cayly awaiters, for them and their
company, among the noble Romans, amounted to.ii. poyse grotes, and a half
grote, or.x. pence of the old coynage. Stater argenteus, was a coin of half
an ounce weight, and was also callid Siclus and Terradragmon. Striatus, ta,
tum, imbowid or made with ridges and furrows, or like unto it. Symphitum, an
herb called Comfrye. Sysimbrium, horsemynte as I suppose. Sysymbrium
cardanine, water eresses.
TIthimallus, a kind of spurge. Some take it for wertwort. Tussilago, an herb
called coltisfote. Typhonicus uentus, a whyrle wind, which plucketh up trees
by the roots.
VEttonica, an herb called Bittayne. Vettonica coronaria, Byllofers. Vmbelicus
veneris, an herb callydde Penygrasse. Verbena, an herb called Veruen. Vitia,
a pulse called a vetche. Vlua, a flagge. Xestes, idem quod Sextarius.
Finis Dictionarij.
TO THE HONEST AND gentylle readers.
TO THE MORE plain declaration of these tables following, briefly compiled
out of the books of Georgius Agricola, and Robertus Senalis, which wrate last
and most exactly of poises and measures, It shall be expedient to the reder to
have in remembrance these things following.

FIRST when he redeth in any book of poyses, coins, and measures, to consider
whither they be of Rome, Greece, or of the Hebrews, and than to seek the
columns, over the which those countries ar written, and there shall he find
that which he seeks for.

Also to remember the valuation of all our coyns, as they be rated at this
present time, and account.xii. d. to a shylling.xi. grotes and ii. d. to an
ounce.xx. s. to a pound.xiii. s. iiii. d. to a mark.xii. ounces to a pound,
as well of measure as of poyse.

Moreover that every ounce or ynch measure quadrate as a dye, is diuyded into
the same minutes or porcio^s, that an ounce poise is, and.xii. ounces in
measure, concerning vessels, is not callydde there a foot, but a pound
measure.

Also that the vessels or receptories are first counted by measure, because
that therein it is more certain than poise, as a poise ofice of honye is not in
quantity like to a poyse ounce of wine or oil. wherefore Vncia red in old
authors without addicion of pondus, is to be taken for the measure ounce, as ye
shall find more abundantly in the books of the said Agricola and Senalis.

Item in the redyng the mesures of greek, if ye find them not here declared,
ye must always remember, that the english pynte is xxiiii. ounce measures, the
pynte of Rome called Sextarius, is.xx. ounce mesures, the greek pynte called
also Sextarius, and the hebrew pynte callid Log, is but.xviii. ounce mesures,
and according to that rate, ye must make calculation in conferring together
all other measures.

And this I trust shall at this time suffice, for the understanding of this
matter, whereby the reders, as well of old hystories, orations of Tulli, as
also ancient physicians, and the books of holy scripture called the Bible,
shall apprehende more understanding, with singular dilectatio^ and pleasure.
For the which I shall require them to give praises to god, of whom it has
chiefly proceeded, and thanks to our most excellent souerayn lord, by whose
most gracious comfort and aid, I have performed it, and to pray to god to
give me grace and time, to accomplish such warkes, as I have purposed for the
commodity honor and weal of this my natural country.

The computation of Georgius Agricola.
Romayne poyse.
SCriptulum, the.xxiiii. part of an ounce. Victoriatus, the.xiiii. part of an
ounce. Denarius, the seventh part of an ounce. Sextula, the syxte part of an
ounce. Sicilicus, the fourth part of an ounce. Duella, the third part of an
ounce. Semuncia, half an ounce. Vncia, an ounce, the.xii. part of a pound
troy. Sescuncia, an ounce and half. Sextans, two ounces, or the syxt part of
any thing, having poyse or measure. Quadrans, a quarterne of a pound, or three
ounces, or the.iii. part. Triens, four ounces, or the fourth part.
Quincunx, five ounces, or the fyfte part. Semissis, half a pound or half
any thing. Septunx, seven ounces or the seventh part. Bes, viii. ounces, or
the eight part. Dodrans, nine ounces, or the nynthe part. Dextans, ten
ounces, or the tenthe part. Deunx, xi. ounces, or the leuenth part. Libra,
Pondo, seu As, twelve ounces. As, is sommetyme taken for the hole of that
which is divided in parts.
Greek poyse.
GRanum, the.iiii. part of Siliqua, the.CCCCC.xvi. part of an ounce measure or
poyse. Siliqua, the third part of obolus, the.Cxliiii. part of an ounce poyse
and measure. Obolus, the half of Scriptulum, or Scrupulus, the.xxxii. part of
an ounce. Scriptulum, the third part of Dram, the.xxiiii. part of an ounce.
Dram, the.viii. part of an ounce, which practysers in phisyke have esteemed
to the weighte of.lx. barley corns taken out of the myddell of the ears,
the.viii. part of an ounce poyse and measure. Vncia, an ounce, the.xii. part
of a pound poyse and mesure. Mina Attica, twelve ounces and half. Mina medica,
xvi. ounces. Mina Alexandrina, xx. ounces. Talentu^ atticu^ minus,
conteyneth.lx. Minas atticas, which of our Troy weight amounts to.lxii.
pounds and half a pound. Talentum atticum maius, co^teyneth.lxxx. Minas,
which is of troy weyghte.lxxxiii.li. and four ounces.
Hebrew poyse.
SIclus, in poyse is half an ounce or four dra^mes. Mina hebraica, co^teineth
two poundis and a half, troy, or.lx. Siclos. Talentum hebraicum, contains. C.
Minas, that amou^teth to.CCL. pounds troy. Talentum Syrum, contains Minas
Atticas.xv. that is.xv. pounds.vii. ounces and a half.
The old English poyse standerde.
Four graynes of wheat poyseth the.viii. part of a penye, so.viii. graynes
ought to way a farthynge xxxii. graynes a penye. Penny and farthynge makes
the.xvi. part of an ounce. Four Royalles makes an ounce of gold. Xii.
ounces makes a pound of troy weight.
Romayne coin.
AS, before the time of Augustus the emperor, was rated to the tenth part of
Denarius, The co^putation of Robertus Senalis, bishop of Abrent
and afterward to the.xvi. part of Denarius. Sextans, the.vi. part of As.
Quadrans, the fourth part. Semissis, half As. Sestertius, the fourth part
of Denarius, contains.iiii. Asses. Victoriatus, the half of Denarius.
Denarius, whereof.vii. made one ounce, was by estimation of our money.vi. d.
ob. and the.vii. part of a halfpenye, after.xi. grotes and.ii. d. to an ounce.
Tressis.iii. Asses. Senarius.vi. Asses. Decussis.x. Asses. Solidus, was
dyuersly taken, sometime for a brasyn coin, containing.xii. small coins.
sometime for Dram, in silver, as primi Esdrae octano ca. and.2. eiusdem.7. et
Paralipo.xxix. Some were the value of Dram, as in the time of Alexander the
emperor. Also Solidus aureus, was in the time of the same emperor.ii.
drammes of gold. After in the time of Justinian.vi. of them made an ounce,
which was the just poyse and value of our royals. Centussis, x. denarij, of
our money.v. s. vi. d. ob. half farthyng, half half farthynge. Mill aeris,
a hundred Ce^tusses, which is of our money xxvii.li.xvi. s. vi. d. q^. XX.
Sestertij, ar.v. Denarij, of our money.ii. s. vii. d. ob. half farthinge, and
the.xxiiii. part of a farthynge. XL. Sestertij.v. s. iii. d. ferthi^g and
the.xii. part of a farthing. Lxxx. Sestertij, x. s. vi. d. ob. and the.vi.
part of a farthyng. Centum sestertij, xiii. s. ii. d. half farthyng, the.vi.
part of a farthyng, and the.xxiiii. part of a farthynge. CC. Sestertii.xxvi.
s. iiii. d. q^. the third part, and the.xii. part of a farthynge.
Greek coin.
CCCC. Sestertij, iii. s. viii. d. ob. a half farthing, a quarter and the.vi.
part of a farthing* DCCC. Sestertij, v. ^^v. s. v. d. a farthing, half

Greek coin.

Measure in length or breadthe. Romayne and Greek.
GRan^^^, is the fourth part of digitus a finger. Digitus, a finger bread is
the length of four grains iiii. digiri makes.iii. inches. Pollex, seu Vncia,
callydde an ynche is the just length of three ^arly grayne^ or four where
corns, and a quarter, taken out of the myddelle of the care of this one is
vncia linearis, or an ynche by line: ^n other quadrata, or square, that is to
say an ynch in length and hiede an another cubica, or in.iiii. quarters like a
dyse, every quarter being an ynch. Exodus 25.
Palmus minor, contains.iiii. fyngers or.iii. inches. Palmus mayor,
co^tayneth the h^ndbrede.iiii. fyngers, and the rhumbe in depenes. Palmus
duplex seu dichas, conteyneth.^iii. fyngers. Sp^^^^^^ne seu Dodrans, a span
which is the space between the thumb and the little finger stretched forth,
and contains.ix. inches, or.xii. fingers Per, (...), co^teineth.iiii.
palms.xii. inchis, or xv. fingers which measure is made with a span and the
length of half the myddell finger, or with the two (...) closed, and the two
(...) extended metyng together, but these measures are not to certain as the
ynche before rehearsed, by reason that all men's hands are not like great. and
therefore as I have proved, the foot which is made by the said ynche, to be
the foot which Budeus, supposes to be brought by the Romans into France, as
Glareanus says, but the Romayn foot, whereof Portius makith mention, is
shorter than that foot one inche, and the.vi. part of a finger. And the foot of
the squire used by our Carpentars is shorter than the Romayne foot of Budeus
one ynche, so that it conteyneth xv. fyngers, whereby apereth the diversity of
foot mesure, not withstanding the said first foot is the true foot, and thereby
all other mesures shall be compted most perfitely. Palmipes, contains a foot
and a palm, or.v. palms. Cubitus, conteyneth one foot and half. Gressus, a
step, contains two foot and a half. Passus, a pase, contein.v. foot.
Orgia, a fathom, it is proprely.vi. fete. Pertica, a perch, among the Romans
contains.x. fete. Pleth^um, conteyneth a hundred fete. Stadium, a furlonge,
conteyneth.Cxxv. pacis. Diaulus, conteinith.ii. furlo^g. Milliare, seu
Milliatium, a mile contains.viii. furlong, or a thousand pacis. Dolichos,
contains.xii. furlonges, or.MCCCCC. pacis. Parasanga, xxx. furlonges.
Schoenos. lx* furlonges. Statlimos, Statio, seu Mansio, one days journey
contains xxviii. miles. Porca, Cxx. fete in length, and xxx. in breadth.
Actus, Cxx. fete square. Iugerum Romanu^. in length CCxl. fete, in breadth Cxx.
fete
Hebrew measure^.
ZEreth, a palm^. Cubitus sanctuarij, contains.vi. palms.
Romayne measure.
Gomor, as much as a man may receive between his two arms. Calamus
sanctuarij, co^teinith x. fete and a half. Calamus vulgaris, contains ix.
fete, of our measure three yerdes. Choemis, co^teineth.iiii. miles Castra, seu
Stationes, contain every of them.ix. miles. Iuger, seu Iugerum, as much land
as a yoke of oxen could falowe in a day. December iug^ra, as much land as ten
yoke of oxen moughte falowe in a day.
Measure in vessel or things to receive. Romayne measure.
LIgula, sine Coclilear, the iiii. part of Cyathus, and receives.iii. drachmas
and one Scriptulu^, of the inch measure. Cyathus, whereof one makes ace^abulum,
and is of mesure one ynche and a half, a dram, and a scriple, and receives
of oil one ounce and half, of ^yne one ounce.v* drachmas and one scriple, of
honey two ounces di^. Acetabulu^, the half of Quartarius, is two inches and
half of mesure, receives of oil ii. ounces and.ii. drachmas, of wine.ii.
ounces and a half^, of honey.iii. ounces di^* and.ii. drachmas. Qua^tarins, the
half of H^mina, is.v. inches of measure receives of oil.iiii. ouncis and
di^, of wine five ounces, of honey.vii. ounces di^. Hamina, the half of
Sextarius is.^. inches of measure, and receives of oil.ix. ounces, of mine
ten ounces, of honey xv. ounces. Sextarius Romanus, is.xx. inches of measure
called Cubica, and receives, in noise of oil.x^iii. ounces, of mine xx.
ounces, of honey.xxx. ounces, and is the.vi. part of Congius, in our measure it
is less than a pynte by four inches of measure. Modius, is of grayn and salt,
and contains.xvi. Sextarios and of our measure a ^alon a pottell and a
quarte, saving iiii. ynche measures. Congius, has.vi. Sextarios, Cxx. inches,
in mesure callid Cubica, and receives of oil in poyse.ix. pounds of wine
x.li. of honey.xv. pounde^* of our measure it is.v. pintes, or a potttell and a
pynte. Vrna, co^teineth.iiii. Congios and receives of oil.xxxvi. pounds: of
wine.xl. pounds: of honey.lx. pounds. It is of our measure, in galons and a
pottell. Amphora, seu quadrantal, contains.xlviii. Sextarios, is a foot
square in measure, called cubica, or like a dyse, and co^teineth of oil.lxxii.
pound of wine.lxxx. pound, of honey.Cxx. pound weight. It is of our measure.v.
galons. Culeus, conteyneth.xx. Amphoras, It is of our measure a hundred galons,
a pype ^^uynge.xxvi. galons.
Greek measure.
COchle^rium Atticu^, seu medicum, is of ynche mesure a dram, half a
scriple.ii. graynes, and two five parts of a grain, and receives in poyse a
dram and.ii. scriples of oil, and of wine as much in poyse as in measure.
Chema, has.ii. Cochlearia, is in mesure.ii. dra^mes one scriple.iiii. graynes,
and.iiii. five parts of a grayn, and receives in poise double as much as
Cochl^^rium. Mystrum medicum, has.ii. Cochl^aria, and a half, one Chem^, and
a quarter, and (...) in measure.^^^. drammes, and receives in poyse of wi^^ or
pure water, as much as in measure. Cochlearium ueterinariu^, belongyng to
cattle, is in measure a quarter of an ynche, and receives in poise of wine a
dram.ii. scriples, one obolu^, one grain and a third part of a grayn, of
honye.ii. dra^mes.ii. scriples.vii. grains and very little more. Mystru^
ue^erinariu^, belonging to catel, is in mesure half an ynche, and receives in
poise of oil.iii. dra^mes and a scriple, of wine.iii. dra^mes.ii. scriples.ii.
graynes and.ii. third parts of a grain, of honye v. drammes, an half.iii.
grains and.v. sixte partis. Mystrum Georgicu^, or of husbandry is in measure
half an ynche and half a dram and receives in poyse of wine half an ounce
and half a scriple, of honey half an ounce and two drammes, a quarter of a dr^m
and half a scriple. ^oncha, is double as much ^s Mystrum. Gyathus medicus, is
double as much as Concha, in mesure an inche and a half, and receives in
poyse of wine, one ounce.iii. dra^mes, and.iiii. Siliquas, of honey.ii. ounces
and ii. scriples, of oil one ounce and.ii. drammes. Cyathus georgicus, or of
husbandry is in mesure.ii. inches and a quarter, and receives in poyse of
wine.ii. ounces and ii. scriples, of honey.iii. ounces one dram and.ii.
scriples, of oil one ounce and seven drammes. Cyathus Veterinarius, pertaining
to cattle, is in mesure.ii. inches, a receives inpoyse of wine one ounce, an
half, a dra^me.ii. scriples.ii. siliquas ii. grains.ii. third parts of a
grain, of oil one ounce, a half, one dram, and a scriple of honey.ii.
ounces, a half, a quarter, oone obolu^.iii. graynes and a third part.
Oxybaphum medicum, is in measure.ii. inches a quarter, receives in poyse of
wine.ii. ounci^ and.ii. scriples, of oil one (...) half.iii. drammes.
Oxyba^^^^ Georgicum, or of husbandrye, is in measure iii. inches a quarter, and
a dram receives in po^ ^f wine.iii. ounces and a dram, of oil ii. ounces, a
half, a quarter, a half, a dram, of honey.iiii. ounces a half, a quarter,
and half a dram. Oxybaphum ueterinariu^, pertaynyng to cattle, is in

scriple.ii. siliquas: of oil.v. ounces, of honye viii. ounces, a quarter
and.ii. Scriples. Quartarius, is double Oxybaphum. Cotyle Medica, is dowble
Quarta^^us, and is in measure ix. inches, and receives in poyse of wine.viii.
ounces a quartern and.ii. Scriples, of oil.vii. ounces and a half, of our
measure it lacks.iii. inche mesures of half a pynt. Galenus says, that there
were diverse opinions of Cotyle, for sum affirmed it to conteyne.xii. ounce
mesures and some said.xvi. Cotyle georgica, is in mesure xiii. inches and a
half, and receives in poise of wine, a pound and half an ounce. of oil.xi.
ounces, of honye a pound a half, and.vi. drammes, of our measure a pynte and
one ounce mesure. Cotyle ueterinaria, pertaining to cattle is in measure.xii.
inches, and receives of wine xi. ounces.ii. scriples, one obolum and one
siliqua, of oil x. ounces, of honey one pound iiii. ounces a half one dram,
and one scriple. It is of our measure just half a pynte. Sextarius atticus,
is.xviii. mesure ounces, and conteyneth in poyse of oil.xv. ounces, of wine a
pound.iii. ounces v. ^^^^mes and a Scriple, of honey.ii. pound and one ounce.

Hebrew measures.
LOg, (...) the hebrew Sextarius, and is equal to Sextarius atticus, and
co^teynyth in measure.xviii. ynchis. Satum, contains.xxiiii. Logim, and is in
measure.xxxvi. pound, receives in poise of wine.xxxiii. pound* an^ our
ounces, of oil.xxx^* of honey.l. pound. It is of our mesure.ii. galons and a
quarte. Hin, is half Satum, is in mesure.xviii. (...), receives in poyse of
wine.xvi.li. di, and ii. ounces. of oil.xv.li. of honey.xxv.li. of our mesure a
galon and a pynte. Batus, conteyneth.iii. S^t^, which is of our measure.vi.
galons a pottell and a quart. Ephi, seu Epha, a measure of dry things, as
corn and salt, and is equal with Batus. Gomor, the tenth part of Ephi, and
lacks of our pynt.ii. ounces, and almost half one ounce. Chorus hebraica,
contains* (...) x. Ephim, which is of our (...) mesure.vii. bushel and a
half.
FINIS.
THIS AT THIS TIME shall be sufficient for the declaration of poisis and
mesures. And he that desires a more ample and exquisite trial of them, let
him diligently read the books of Georgius Agricola, and Robertus Senalis, who
writing last of all other in that kind of matter, have found diverse things,
which were not before of other remembered, as it daily happens in all kinds of
writing. I know well that Budeus, Alceatus, and Portius are men of excellent
learning, and their books to be made with an exact study and diligence: But
Agricola being a great physician, and therefore more accustomed to read the
warkes of Galenus, than the other, which in their profession be lawyers:
semblablye the warkes of other, which wrate of the diseases of cattle, and
remedies for them, more over attaynyng the books of Cleopatras, a noble and
great learned woman, which also (...) ^f measures, specially pertaininge to
^nd^^: no meruail though that he more perfitly has determined that thing,
which among the other was in contencion. Semblably Senalis an honorable
bishop, following Agricola, and approuyng his diligence by making true
conference between him and the other, and more over being well learned in the
hebrew tunge, and consequently in holy scripture, trieng out studiousely the
poyses and mesures to the hebrews pertaining: has happily brought unto light
that which the other has remembered, or else not understanding substancially
the hebrew tongue, they purposely omitted. For these causes I have preferred
the computation of these two before any other, exhorting not withstanding al
them that do understand latin, that they do not therefore neglect the others
books, but to embrace and read^ them studiously, as in whom they shall (...)
marvelous knowledge, which else perchaun^ they shall lack. And as concerning my
calculation, which I have done with much study and incredible labor for the
profit of other, if I have therein any thing failed, as I trust that I have not
(although the division in breking of numbers callid fractions, is a thing
subtle and marvelous hard to observe always truly) I heartily pray al gentle
reders, fyndyng it by an exquisite trial to correct it without indignation:
and likewise all the resydewe of the dictionarye preceding, and frendely
communicate with me their labors, for the which I will give unto them most
hearty thanks, not leaving unremembered, god gyuing to me life, their honest
labors, being benesyciall unto this their country.

Tho. Berthelet. regius impressor excudebat. ANNO. M.D.XXXVIII.
